He stepped down from the pole of his battleaxe and set foot on the road. Pavement splashed as if he‚Äôd stepped in a puddle. More splashed and rippled as he moved his axe in a circle around him.

When he took a step and moved, it was faster than I could track. I could see the splash that followed behind, a cresting wave that quickly settled, leaving only a faint wavy pattern in the road as it dissipated.

I‚Äôd spoken against the herd. I tried not to pay too much attention to them or give them any excuse to push back against me, instead turning my attention to the old man.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm offering tea or coffee, my treat. We can talk it out, or talk about something else entirely,‚Äù I told him. ‚ÄúAs soon as the police are done.‚Äù

He still looked like he was carrying that fresh pain, in expression and posture. He flinched some as he looked at his son‚Äôs memorial pillar. He gave the girl in the car a hard look, then seemed to let the anger out, sagging.

She was in the driver‚Äôs seat, both hands and forehead on the wheel.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll have some place to be. I shouldn‚Äôt keep you more than I have. I‚Äôll be fine.‚Äù

‚ÄúWork,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThey wouldn‚Äôt fire me, especially if I explained. I‚Äôd get in trouble, maybe, but I wouldn‚Äôt mind much. Job is‚Ä¶ a seven out of ten fit.‚Äù

‚ÄúSeventy percent is a lot better than some are getting,‚Äù the man said. ‚ÄúKeep that job. I‚Äôll manage now.‚Äù

I glanced at the girl in the car. She had barely moved.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll leave her alone?‚Äù I asked.

The old man heaved out a sigh.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs a kid who made a stupid mistake,‚Äù I said, in case he was trying to come to a decision. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to forgive her, but you can‚Äôt go and hurt her or anything.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt have‚Ä¶‚Äù he said, and he didn‚Äôt finish the sentence. Because he might have, or because he didn‚Äôt know what he wouldn‚Äôt have done.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs good.‚Äù

‚ÄúGo. Work. Don‚Äôt let me keep you,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be straight with the police there.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll stick around for the cops and then duck out.‚Äù

The police cars had appeared at the edge of the block, but with traffic on the narrow road slowed by the girl‚Äôs car, they‚Äôd stopped there. The cars couldn‚Äôt progress, but the police were getting out.

One officer went to talk to the girl, another to the old man. I waited around a minute, then gave a statement and my info.

As in most things having to do with law or bureaucracy, it took longer than it should have, for a relatively simple process. I hurried to the high school once they were done with me, and I arrived rather late.

High school.

We still weren‚Äôt at the point where we had nice lawns and yards. This schoolyard was no exception. We had grass and fields, yes, but it was coarse and the ground beneath wasn‚Äôt usually landscaped. The area was large with large trees left untouched in the corners, chain link fence separating the field from the roads on two sides, the grade school formed the third boundary to the west, and the high school formed the fourth boundary to the north. The ground was uneven, more hilly than flat, and there were still large stones here and there, and a seemingly out of place play structure for the grade schoolers.

It was an odd thing. So often, nature was transplanted into a city, and it was new and inauthentic, made overly neat. Trees, lawns, flowers. Here, the nature was rough and unpolished, the city itself new and somewhat artificial in how overly tidy it was, untouched by time or elements.

A sports field in the middle section separated the grade schoolers‚Äô area from the theater. It was a stage in the old Roman style, slabs of stone set into the ground like stairs, stepping down as they got closer to the stage, where the platform sat.

Hundreds of students had gathered on the stone seats, and more stood around the top edge of the theater, watching and listening. They were our survivors, our next generation. Not so different from the crowd I‚Äôd had to deflect earlier. A third of them still wore the very simple clothes that were handed out with supplies in the tent cities. Some had even taken to strategically ripping and dressing up those clothes. I didn‚Äôt fault them for it. It was hot.

A speaker carried the voice to those of us on the top edge.

The teachers of the school were on the stage, but they weren‚Äôt speaking. It was a series of community leaders and volunteers instead.

‚Äú‚Ä¶And I make that a guarantee to you,‚Äù a man in an orange vest was saying. ‚ÄúIf you take those credentials, bring good shoes and work clothes, and if you don‚Äôt screw around, you can walk into any lot and you can be working within the hour and get your pay by that day‚Äôs end. Good pay. You can do whatever you want, after school, but you‚Äôll always have this as a fallback, you‚Äôll have the security of being able to walk into a lot and have a job waiting for you. We can always use more hands.‚Äù

Not enough seats at this school either. High school was and might well continue to be a half-day thing. The people on the stage were telling the kids their other options for the other half of the day.

I spotted Gilpatrick on the stage. He wore a black t-shirt and gray pants with boots, and in the summer heat he was sweating a fair amount. He had no hair on his head, but he had a five o‚Äôclock shadow well before five o‚Äôclock, bushy eyebrows and thick hair on thick forearms. Everyone else looked like they were trying to make their best pitch, in dressing nice and wearing smiles. Gilpatrick looked like he was trying to scare his prospects away.

Some of the non-prospects were standing around the upper edge, looking down at the new students and the stage. Most were senior students who‚Äôd picked what they‚Äôd do with their half-days last year, now waiting to induct the others. Some were siblings of those seniors, or younger friends. Others were like me, miscellaneous staff for miscellaneous roles.

I joined them.

‚ÄúWe wondered if you‚Äôd bailed,‚Äù Jasper said. He was very much a teenager, with acne, thin chin-hair and black hair that had had product in it, that had turned spiky from sweat.

‚ÄúDelayed by a car accident.‚Äù

‚ÄúEveryone‚Äôs okay?‚Äù he asked.

‚ÄúYep.‚Äù Insofar as anyone is okay. ‚ÄúHas Gil done his five pounds of gun thing? I was kind of looking forward to it, it‚Äôs so corny.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think he‚Äôs saving it for the deeper explanation later. He mostly talked about how he was going to make it his objective to make people quit, he isn‚Äôt going to pay anyone, job prospects suck, he‚Äôs going to make people march in the heat and the cold for miles while carrying unreasonable burdens. The ‚Äòfive pounds‚Äô speech isn‚Äôt bad, you know. It gets through to the kids,‚Äù Jasper said. For all that he was defending the speech, he smirked a bit.

‚ÄúIt gets through to most,‚Äù Cubs said. He was a big guy, tall, broad-shouldered, fit, with his hair cut short. He thought for a second and then amended his statement, ‚Äúsome.‚Äù

‚ÄúUs,‚Äù Jasper said.

‚ÄúGuess so, yeah,‚Äù Cubs said.

I didn‚Äôt miss the glance he shot at the girl at the far end of our little sub-group. Cami wore an expression I might have termed ‚Äòresting angry face‚Äô. Perpetually pissed.

All three of them, and many other members of the group besides, were dressed in similar shades as Gilpatrick. Blacks and grays.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to duck into my office,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI want to check my email and make sure it‚Äôs nice and neat if anyone stops in.‚Äù

‚ÄúOnly a short bit before we migrate over,‚Äù Cubs said. ‚ÄúOne more speaker.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll let Gilpatrick know you‚Äôre there,‚Äù Jasper said. He extended a fist. I rolled my eyes and instead of tapping it with my own, pushed it away. Jasper smiled.

My destination wasn‚Äôt in the high school, but was across the street. It was an open building with a partial second floor. The main floor was hardwood, with mats folded and piled up at the side. A few more senior students were already there— some were just entering or leaving the showers. It seemed like a good idea for cooling down, but I didn‚Äôt have the time.

I waved at some of the seniors in passing and headed up the stairs. The stairwell ran up one wall, unbounded by barriers, so it offered a view of everything below.

My office was the closest thing I had to a home, in this world. It was narrow and long, with a bookshelf at the right wall, a desk, computer and chair. Some boxes were piled up in the corners.

The bookshelf was my accomplishment. My fingers ran along the spines of books and other texts. Many of the works were collections of articles or official documents, bound by hand with a three-hole punch, rings, and patience.

Parahuman science. University textbooks, old workbooks with notes— not all mine. There were important articles, copied to plain text and printed out, with a lean toward the sciences, the nuances, the big revelations and reveals.

Official files. Classification documents. Then there were the notes for case one, case fifteen, case thirty-two, case fifty-three, case ninety. The ‚Äòcases‚Äô were the events the PRT had deemed of interest. Riddles both solved and unsolved. My collection there was incomplete, but some were official enough to be confidential, and I‚Äôd never had that access. Others were closed, the mystery deemed nonexistent or something to be folded into popular knowledge.

I had other files. There were names on those files. Whittler, Bilious, King Crow were some of the many on the shelf I‚Äôd deemed ‚Äòindependents‚Äô. For teams, there were ones like the Ambassadors, Green Tea, N.N., Ossuary, Empire Eighty-Eight, and the Clans. I‚Äôd made it a priority to collect those. I worried we might need them.

On the bottom shelf, I had my magazines. Costumes Under Clothes, Gleam, Heroines, Masque, Shine On. Some of the boxes in the corner had my latest haul. Much of it would be duplicates. Maybe I‚Äôd give some of them out to seniors.

I could still smell a faint mildewy smell, and promised myself I‚Äôd identify the source when I had time. I‚Äôd left the window open, and the weather was warm, which was helping. A lot of this was what I‚Äôd salvaged from the office back home; I‚Äôd retrieved it from boxes and filing cabinets and hauled it here over a dozen trips. I‚Äôd rigged up tarps to keep the water off that corner of the house, but some of that moisture had been coming up from below. I would have to find the source of the smell and transcribe the text before throwing it out.

Maybe I could get Gilpatrick to get a kid who needed punishing to do it for me.

Information was too important. Even if that information was from the glossy, superficial magazines about superheroines that had been pitched to girls just like me eight to ten years ago.

Faint smells aside, I could draw in a deep breath and feel muscles from shoulder to calf relax. This was more of that seventy percent part of the seventy percent fit where the job suited me.

That thirty percent, though. I wouldn‚Äôt stay here forever. I hoped. It had been a thing that I‚Äôd hoped would look good on my college applications. That hadn‚Äôt worked.

I could hear the commotion as the mob of kids started coming in downstairs.

I walked over to my computer and booted it up. It booted up instantly, but the connection to the internet took a while. I opened a notebook and began searching through it.

I found the name before the internet succeeded in connecting. I closed the conversation from the day prior and waited for the internet before composing an email.

To: Deferent.I@Mail
Subject: Damaged pillar
I was a bystander when a car crashed into a pillar on Small St, near Basil Ave. Thought I‚Äôd let you know it‚Äôs damaged. Let me know if there‚Äôs anything I can do to help or any info I can provide.

Thanks for what you do.

I sent it, then stood, walking to the window. I didn‚Äôt have much of a view— mostly the side of a building and a bit of the alley. If I stuck my head out the window, I could see a sliver of the school and some of the street. Students were milling around, some undecided on where they were going.

My computer chimed.

From: Deferent.I@Mail
Subject: Re: Damaged Pillar
I already heard. Advance Guard were on the scene and let me know. Will have it fixed tomorrow. Thanks.

That would be fixed soon then. I thought the things were an eyesore, really, but people clearly felt like they were important.

I was caught up in checking recent events online when there was a knock on the door.

Gilpatrick.

‚ÄúShouldn‚Äôt you be handing out guns to kids?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúOr giving a hard-assed speech that sends them running?‚Äù

‚ÄúI wish,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúCan‚Äôt give them guns until later. Give me a week, we‚Äôll see how many of them I can get rid of. Can you show your face downstairs for me, so they know who to look for?‚Äù

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúLet me get organized and I‚Äôll be right there.‚Äù

He didn‚Äôt step out of the doorway. His arms remained folded, and he had paper in one of his hands, held where I might not notice it.

‚Äú‚Ä¶Actually,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù I said. I gave him a stern look. ‚ÄúNo. Don‚Äôt ‚Äòactually‚Äô me. Please.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you know anything about Fume Hood?‚Äù

I raised one eyebrow, keeping that stern look otherwise in place. ‚ÄúFume Hood? No.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe apparently went by another name, a while back. Poison Apple?‚Äù

‚ÄúThen I do know stuff. She went by Bad Apple,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúAnd a few other Nom De Pommes. I know some of her story. She was controversial.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs a hero now,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs getting announced as one member of a new team today.‚Äù

I nodded slowly, taking that in. ‚ÄúThat could be bad.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs looking like it will be,‚Äù Gilpatrick said. He revealed the papers. ‚ÄúCan you brief my seniors? Fill them in on who she is?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat I can do,‚Äù I said. I approached him and took the papers.

He didn‚Äôt let go of them. He opened his mouth.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got too many new kids,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúNo, Gilpatrick.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy hands are full. I don‚Äôt have enough seniors to manage them all. I don‚Äôt want this to be fun or even tolerable and that requires more supervision.‚Äù

I let go of the paper, backing up. ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúI won‚Äôt force you,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúPeople connected the new heroine Fume Hood to her old persona. They‚Äôre upset. Enough that they‚Äôre hiring people to kick up a fuss, and we don‚Äôt know just who or what‚Äôs going to happen.‚Äù

I thought of the people who‚Äôd been in the crowd when the pillar had been hit. I could picture it.

‚ÄúJust that they‚Äôre hiring people?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúFrom one of the more distant settlements. Police know and are taking precautions, hero teams have been notified, but it‚Äôs messy.‚Äù

‚ÄúMessy how?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúJurisdictions. Our apple heroine is on a new team, announcing themselves in a new jurisdiction‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚Äú‚Ä¶It makes them look bad if they accept outside help or have other teams elbowing in on their big first day.‚Äù

‚ÄúSomething like that,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúApple girl is getting a lot of serious hate thrown her way online. If you can tell us anything about how she might react to this situation, or anything else, that‚Äôd help.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat I can do.‚Äù

He went on, ‚ÄúAnd if you could captain a squad of some new guys I‚Äôve got from another school, let me know if they‚Äôre decent and trustworthy, and just do a bit of standing guard, giving advice and information to the officers at the scene, it would be a massive help.‚Äù

I gave Gilpatrick my best angry glare, hands on my hips.

‚ÄúI won‚Äôt force you,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSuperiors are pressuring me to handle this. If you say no then I‚Äôll figure something else out.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou know I‚Äôm taking it easy with all this stuff. I told you on day one I wouldn‚Äôt be one of your patrolers. I‚Äôm only here to dispense some advice.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not frontline. I can‚Äôt be frontline.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a natural leader,‚Äù he said.

I shook my head.

‚ÄúI really didn‚Äôt want to use Jasper. He was joking about my speech, so I‚Äôm going to make him deliver it to the recruits,‚Äù he said.

I smiled, despite myself. That would be partially my fault, for reminding Jasper.

‚ÄúCan you do the briefing, at least?‚Äù Gilpatrick asked.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. I dropped my hands from my hips. ‚ÄúShe really called herself Fume Hood?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Gilpatrick said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt take many of the names seriously. This doesn‚Äôt seem much worse.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really terrible,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúA heroine calling herself a hood? As in a gangster?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think she has an actual hood as part of her costume.‚Äù

‚ÄúI really hope so,‚Äù I said. I sighed and looked at my shelves. ‚ÄúGive me a second to review files? I‚Äôll be right downstairs.‚Äù

‚ÄúJust one second,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to have Jasper start with the recruits. Try to be done before I send them scurrying off.‚Äù

I checked the papers. Forum transcripts, some intercepted emails, some notes on Fume Hood.

I had a folder on my shelf. Notes from home. She was from Boston, among other places. Itinerant.

There were a lot of newspaper articles. She‚Äôd drawn a lot of attention once. Everyone was supposed to be getting a second chance, and it seemed that people‚Äôs memories were long enough that she wasn‚Äôt necessarily getting hers.

I gathered everything together, and I headed downstairs.

Jasper was in front of an assembly of roughly a hundred kids. Boys and girls. Not all were ninth graders, new to high school. Some would be refugees, their educations interrupted by the rather massive inconvenience of the world ending.

‚Äú‚Ä¶mostly long treks into the middle of nowhere to deliver supplies or check on things. If we‚Äôre lucky, we get a car. It‚Äôs not glamorous. Seriously. Run away,‚Äù he was saying. He spotted me coming down the stairs, and a smile crossed his face. ‚ÄúOnce you‚Äôve been with us for two years, you get one of these embarrassments and you have to be seen in public with them—‚Äù

He held up a gun with slide back and magazine removed, a bright red bike lock threaded through the bottom of the gun and out the top.

Jasper went on, ‚ÄúAnd you‚Äôll be expected to clean it as well as the gun you use on the range. You‚Äôll have to treat it like a real, loaded gun. That means you pretend it‚Äôs loaded, you don‚Äôt aim it at anything or anyone you wouldn‚Äôt want to destroy, you never leave it unattended, and so on. We‚Äôll drill it into your skull and frankly, we‚Äôre really hoping you make a mistake so we can kick you to the curb.‚Äù

The other senior students were dressed in their uniforms now. Black clothes with some body armor worn over them, and the body armor was recognizable. In places, flakes of the letters and symbols that had once been stenciled onto the armor panels in white were still visible, having survived the steel wool and turpentine scrub. PRT issue, salvaged.

When they‚Äôd been trying to figure out what to do with the high school kids when there weren‚Äôt enough schools and seats for all of them, some idiot in the administration had come up with this. Some teenagers could go help on farms, some could get trained in construction, some would work, the ones who could keep their grades up enough could take afternoon classes too, and so on. There were sports teams and clubs. Finally, there was the patrol group. Us.

Maybe it wasn‚Äôt fair to blame it on an idiot in charge. Maybe it was inevitable. Some wanted to feel like they had power, when the capes had dropped the ball. Some wanted answers. We talked and ran errands pertaining to power stuff. Some of the kids might go on to police, investigate, or study the power stuff, as more informed police officers. Possibly.

This was the thirty percent I didn‚Äôt like. The question mark. The places this could lead, theoretically. Places we were already starting to edge toward, slowly but surely.

‚ÄúLess than five pounds of gun, if you even have a gun,‚Äù Jasper said, holding up the gun with the bike lock threaded through it. He caught my eye as he said it and he had a gleam in his eye. ‚ÄúFifteen pounds of armor. It‚Äôll be twenty-five pounds of armor if you‚Äôre with us for the long haul. These backpacks? They‚Äôre heavy. They‚Äôre miserable. Twenty-five pounds strapped to you. Food, water, first aid, tools.‚Äù

He holstered his gun and lifted up the bag with two hands, grunting a bit.

‚ÄúPay attention to those ratios. Twenty-five pounds of stuff to support and help‚Ä¶‚Äù

He dropped the bag and gave it a pat.

‚Äú‚Ä¶A good bit of protection‚Ä¶‚Äù

He rapped knuckles against the armor he wore on his chest.

‚Äú‚Ä¶And possibly a bit of offense.‚Äù

He tapped the gun where it was in its holster, the bike lock draped down and resting against his leg

Gilpatrick stepped up beside Jasper. ‚ÄúGood.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you sir.‚Äù

‚ÄúStudents, if you‚Äôll turn around to see the young lady on the stairs‚Ä¶‚Äù

The students did.

‚Äú‚Ä¶She‚Äôs our resident cape expert. If you‚Äôre sticking with us here in patrol block, if her door is open, you can go ask her questions. She knows her stuff. If you‚Äôre not sticking with us and her door is open, you can go ask her questions and we‚Äôll let you cut to the head of the line. You‚Äôll find her office upstairs and to the left.‚Äù

I hadn‚Äôt heard that part before. Priority to people who weren‚Äôt part of the club. I smiled.

We had more kids than we wanted or could use, even though we didn‚Äôt pay any wages until they‚Äôd been with us at least a year, and we did everything we could to keep them miserable. Powers were compelling. Too many had reasons for wanting to be here.

An unfortunate share of the students were here because they were angry. Because the patrol block had been started up by some ex-PRT folk and Gilpatrick‚Äôs speech aside, a lot of people looked at the armor, looked at the guns, looked at how we touched on the power stuff and the portals, and connected the dots.

‚ÄúYou want to go brief my seniors?‚Äù he asked me, from the far end of the room, over the heads of hundreds of new students.

I gave him a mock salute, then finished descending the stairs, joining the seniors while he resumed outlining things for the new kids. I motioned to the door, indicating for the group to follow.

A few of them were new, Gilpatrick had said. I didn‚Äôt like how angry or naturally resentful some of them looked. Cami was among them.

‚ÄúNew team is having its grand unveiling at one of the community centers,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúOne member is Fume Hood. She was a B-list villain, once upon a time. She‚Äôs what we term itinerant. Wandered from city to city, looking for opportunities or teams to join. Petty robbery, grand larceny, mischief, vandalism, criminal mercenary work. A lot of the time she was one of the low-rate hangers-on in a group that a bigger villain would hire to pull a bigger job. You could even call her a professional distraction. She started when she was sixteen, stopped at twenty-four or so. She‚Äôd be twenty-nine now.‚Äù

They were listening intently, even the new guys. That was good.

‚ÄúAs a villain, she went by Bad Apple, Poison Apple, Pomme De Sang, probably called herself Applesauce, I don‚Äôt even know. I guess she wanted to corner the market on apple-related names so nobody would have something similar. She spent a lot of time palling around with a biotinker called Blasto. She kept going back to him to pair up. Might have been boyfriend-girlfriend, even. That ended when the Slaughterhouse Nine passed through Boston. We don‚Äôt know what happened to Blasto, but we can guess it wasn‚Äôt good. Poison Apple got a little reckless after that, even though she hadn‚Äôt met up with him in over a year at that point.‚Äù

I opened my folder and found one of the articles. I laid it against the front of the folder and held it out so they could read it.

‚ÄúShe pulled together a group of some old teammates and new teenage villains and pulled a shopping spree, hit a mall and took what they wanted. Heroes showed up, they ran.‚Äù

‚ÄúMiscarriage,‚Äù one of the new people in the group said, reading from the article.

‚ÄúPoison Apple makes globes in her hands. One of the tricks she can pull with them is send them flying off in straight lines. They explode on contact with hard surfaces, just enough oomph to knock you to the ground, and they create clouds of gas or splashes of liquid poison. Usually enough to make you nauseous, a little bit feeble, more if you touch the poison in its liquid form. Nonlethal and mostly nonviolent, most of the time. Except this time, a pregnant lady was caught in the gas, or in the explosion. She lost her baby, and it became a thing in the media. Poison Apple turned herself in, partially because of the backlash she‚Äôd generated. She was serving time for pled down charges of assault and battery when Gold Morning came around,‚Äù I said.

A couple of the angry faces in the group looked a little angrier.

‚ÄúShe did her time,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúShe made a mistake, she paid for it as much as she was able. We don‚Äôt have enough good jails and so she‚Äôs free, and it looks like she‚Äôs trying to do good. That‚Äôs pretty decent, really. She‚Äôs not the enemy here.‚Äù

‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt she?‚Äù someone asked. Their name might have been James. They‚Äôd been around last year.

‚ÄúThe threat is the people targeting her. They‚Äôve recruited help. We don‚Äôt know how much, but the intel Gilpatrick gave me said money changed hands. You guys know the basics when it comes to capes, you can inform the cops if something comes up, you know her story, and you‚Äôll be a few more people in uniform keeping the peace and giving protesters a little more reason to hang back. If it gets bad, any real danger, you back off.‚Äù

There were a few nods.

There were also a few looks on a handful of faces that made me concerned. Too heated, or too cold. They weren‚Äôt the majority, but I wasn‚Äôt sure the majority was on Fume Hood‚Äôs side, either.

It put me in mind of the crowd and the broken pillar. If it was just this, I might have been able to let it lie. I could have accepted that the students here were among the angriest and most invested in the grittier side of the cape stuff. That it was just them.

Except it wasn‚Äôt. The old man, the girl who couldn‚Äôt drive, the crowd there and the response to the visiting cape‚Ä¶ there was so much emotion bound up in things, I couldn‚Äôt trust that this was an isolated thing.

I couldn‚Äôt stand by and let this be the new normal, without any opposing voices. Even if my voice was a badly biased one.

With the climate, both general and even the fact that it was hot and tempers would be short, it would be so easy for us to see another Vikare.

I glanced over my shoulder and through the door. I saw Gilpatrick with Jasper and the kids.

Damn it, Gilpatrick.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll come with you,‚Äù I decided. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll do our part to keep people organized and keep the peace.‚Äù

What did it say about the state of things, if I was increasingly the voice of restraint and reason?

I turned my attention back to the squad.

‚ÄúFor those of you who‚Äôve just joined us, my name is Victoria Dallon, and I‚Äôll be your squad captain today.‚Äù

Daybreak — 1.2

I had badly neglected my locker. I had an office, so my locker in the changing room was more for the things I didn‚Äôt use much at all.

Bag. The backpack was light, but it only had the nonperishables in it. I‚Äôd done a few patrols for Gilpatrick over the winter, visiting some of the settlements that were a little further afield, while many of the students were taking Christmas off. I‚Äôd also used it for my fitness test.

I set it on the table in the center of the room. Something to weigh when I was done getting outfitted. For now, I just needed it out of my locker. The bag took up the bottom half, the armor took up the upper half.

Outfit change. I couldn‚Äôt go out in a skirt and body armor. I had some self respect. The pants in my locker were part of an emergency change of clothes, heavier fabric intended for winter and trips to Bet when the weather was bad.

I hadn‚Äôt put the pants through the wash since having to shovel snow over the winter, but I hadn‚Äôt worn them much either. There was still salt crusting the heels, white against black fabric. I walked over to the sink and rinsed the worst of the salt off, then rolled up the cuffs a bit so I wouldn‚Äôt have wet pants slapping against my ankle.

I kicked off my shoes and hiked up the pants so they were under my skirt, then unfastened the skirt.

‚ÄúVictoria,‚Äù Gilpatrick said, behind me, a deep male voice in the girl‚Äôs change room. I jumped a little. ‚ÄúAre you free to talk?‚Äù

I turned my head. There wasn‚Äôt a door to the girl‚Äôs changing room, but there was a solid wall blocking the view. I could see the edge of Gilpatrick‚Äôs arm — he stood with his back to the wall and the changing room.

Camisola was in the room too, unpacking and repacking her kits for her bag. She met my eyes.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll step out,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúThank you, Cami,‚Äù Gilpatrick said. I pulled my shoes back on and laced them as Cami left the room.

Belt. Holster. I threaded the belt through my belt loops, careful to position the holster.

Cami was apparently out of earshot, because Gil spoke again. ‚ÄúThank you, Victoria.‚Äù

‚ÄúGive me Jasper,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúFor my squad.‚Äù

‚ÄúJasper?‚Äù he asked. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

Well, that said a lot, didn‚Äôt it?

‚ÄúBecause I‚Äôm paranoid,‚Äù I said. Paranoid on more than one front, but I wouldn‚Äôt tell Gilpatrick that. I had suspicions and his willingness to give me Jasper would tell me things. ‚ÄúIs anyone else standing outside the door?‚Äù

‚ÄúThis conversation is just you and me.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay. I know Jasper, and I‚Äôm honestly more worried about the attitudes of the people you gave me than I am about the protest or whatever it is people are going to pull with Bad Apple.‚Äù

‚ÄúJasper‚Äôs attitude isn‚Äôt great.‚Äù

‚ÄúJasper is a joker and he can be immature, but he can give that five pounds of gun speech because he believes it. He‚Äôs in this because he thinks capes are cool, not because he‚Äôs pissed. Give me one person I know will agree with me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI kind of need every senior I can get. But I‚Äôll give you that.‚Äù

I bit my lip, thinking as I worked the combination of the safe at the topmost section of my locker. I pulled out the pistol and holstered it. I kept my hand there, reminding myself of the weapon‚Äôs weight as I tried to figure out how to word my question, and if I wanted to ask it.

‚ÄúThen how about you take some of the angry ones? The new guys you were giving me.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat was a quick assessment.‚Äù

I gathered the pistol magazines and slotted them into the pouch, before setting to attaching the pouch to my leg and belt. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want them. I don‚Äôt want to get some people from elsewhere with their own habits and ways of doing things, and have to train them on top of doing this thing.‚Äù

‚ÄúTake them, Victoria,‚Äù Gilpatrick said. ‚ÄúThey came with good recommendations, they know their stuff, and if it does wind up being a protest, you‚Äôll want the extra bodies. If it doesn‚Äôt, then it doesn‚Äôt matter.‚Äù

‚ÄúThings are never that simple, Gil,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúTake them,‚Äù he said, firm.

‚ÄúYou owe me for this,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù he said.

I sighed.

Armor. I pulled my vest from the bottom of the locker. I saved it for last because once it was on, I wouldn‚Äôt be able to bend down or move as easily. The old name and number was still visible by the impression that had been made in the armor when it had been punched in and painted on. The steel-wool scrubbing I‚Äôd given it hadn‚Äôt erased the whole impression.

I didn‚Äôt know who Cameron was or where they‚Äôd ended up, but I wore their armor now. I tucked the papers in between my chest and the armor, where the straps would help keep them in place.

I spoke, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a cushy job, I get to geek out and show off, and I like my office and the access I get to the portal, I don‚Äôt want to take that for granted, but you owe me a few already. This is one more.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll make it up to you. I‚Äôve got to run. Kids to torture. I‚Äôll send Jasper your way.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúDo I need my full pack?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúNo, I wouldn‚Äôt do that to you. Full pack is a torment I reserve for the newbies.‚Äù

I was glad to put my bag back in the locker. I heard Gilpatrick walking away, raising his voice to shout orders.

I used fingernails to comb my hair back, then began braiding it. I had to look in the mirror to make sure I‚Äôd gotten all of the stray strands.

Hi me, I thought, as I made eye contact.

How to describe that feeling? Something resembling relief and a sinking feeling at the same time. It was a small feeling but still one that I would carry with me for the rest of the day. That day would be a little bit worse because of the moment, but it would feel more stable for the reminder, too.

I had a good two years of experience to draw from, in figuring that out.

I‚Äôd stopped braiding my hair, I realized, and I‚Äôd started holding my breath without realizing it. I exhaled, closed the safe, spun the dial, closed the locker, and walked out onto the floor of the building, resuming the braiding of my hair.

Forward. Breathing in through the nose and out through the mouth. Moving on with the day.

I caught up with Jasper as he joined the group.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm driving, apparently,‚Äù Jasper said, wangling the keys in front of me. ‚ÄúAnd keeping you company. Gilpatrick explained the situation.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù I said. I pointed in the direction of the bus. We started walking.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre friends?‚Äù one of the new guys asked.

Still braiding, I looked over at Jasper. ‚ÄúEnhh.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can tell she‚Äôs really diplomatic,‚Äù Jasper said.

‚ÄúWork friends, kind of?‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt hang out,‚Äù Jasper said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure what we‚Äôd do if we did. We don‚Äôt have anything in common.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe got stuck together for jobs and errands enough times we became familiar with each other,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúWe get on okay. Jasper‚Äôs cool. Just don‚Äôt ask him about the tattoo.‚Äù

‚ÄúTattoo?‚Äù someone asked.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll explain when we‚Äôre driving,‚Äù Jasper said, smiling.

We reached the bus. It wasn‚Äôt pretty. A half-size school bus, rust had been mostly scrubbed away and it had received a paint job in black with white sides. The emergency exit at the back had been redone so it was the main way in and out, and a passenger seat had been added at the front. There was an area for supplies and bags to be stowed between the wheels at the right side.

I wrapped my braid around itself a few times, and tied it there in a slightly messy bun-coil, then climbed up to the passenger seat. The seniors climbed into the back. There were a few faces I recognized but couldn‚Äôt name, a dozen more that I didn‚Äôt recognize and definitely couldn‚Äôt name. I could tell that they were from elsewhere by the fact that the armor they‚Äôd brought with them had been painted black, rather than have the white letters scrubbed away. Twenty-four in all.

Jasper took the driver‚Äôs seat, starting up the bus immediately.

Even parked in the shade, even in September, the heat was such that the seats were uncomfortably hot. I‚Äôd thought about removing my armor once my hands were free, and carrying it by hand, but I decided to keep it on for the extra buffer.

Didn‚Äôt do anything to spare my ass from the warm faux-leather seat. I didn‚Äôt like being aware of my body to that extent.

‚ÄúWhere to?‚Äù Jasper asked, rescuing me from my thoughts.

‚ÄúNorwalk-Fairfield span,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúRural, isn‚Äôt that?‚Äù Jasper asked.

‚ÄúLast I heard.‚Äù

Jasper had to almost stand up to get the perspective to see through the open back of the bus. He reversed out of the lot and took us onto the road.

‚ÄúMaybe you guys can answer. What‚Äôs the deal with stretches and spans?‚Äù one of the new guys asked.

I turned sideways in my seat, looking back. Now that I was sitting and looking back at them, they were older, I noted. Seventeen at a minimum. ‚ÄúYou guys are from one of the denser parts of the city?‚Äù

‚ÄúNew York Central. Near the Bet-Gimel portal,‚Äù a girl said.

One of the two big ones, then. We‚Äôd bled into the areas surrounding the portals. Brockton Bay had been the first, but we‚Äôd had a few in a few major cities and New York was a big one. The cluster of settlements around the portals in the northeastern US and people‚Äôs desire to have ready access to that cluster and the resources, community, information and security it afforded had played a big part in the megalopolis forming.

One blob around New York, one blob around the New Brockton settlement, clusters south of New Brockton, near what would or should be Boston, and everything had spread out or extended from there, mostly hugging the coast and connecting to one another.

I explained, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got these long narrow bands of mingled city and agriculture connecting the primary settlement points, to the point it‚Äôs hard to say where one thing starts and the other ends. And instead of building five big houses they‚Äôd rather build an apartment building that hosts twenty, which makes things fuzzy with the distinctions of urban and rural. So we get the ever-expanding megalopolis blob and we can‚Äôt figure out what to call it, even though it‚Äôs already this monster.‚Äù

Our progress out of the city center was slow. Construction. Endless construction. Jasper seemed happy to be driving, even at a crawl.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù the first guy spoke.

‚ÄúIn terms of the bands that rope everything in together, we go by the cities and locations that were there beforehand. If you look at where Norwalk would be on a map, that‚Äôs the name for the region we‚Äôre heading to. If it‚Äôs east-west it‚Äôs a span. If it‚Äôs north-south it‚Äôs a stretch. But it‚Äôs all a part of the city.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat if it‚Äôs both?‚Äù someone asked.

‚ÄúThen it‚Äôs neither,‚Äù Jasper said. ‚ÄúYou just give it a name.‚Äù

‚ÄúMore accurately, you try to give it a name and end up in a heated, months-long debate about what to call the area, with way too many emotions tied up into things,‚Äù I said.

The guy from right behind me said, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see why we can‚Äôt just give the individual areas names like they used to have. If it‚Äôs close to Norwalk, then we call it fucking Norwalk.‚Äù

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù I said. I gave a stern look to the guy who‚Äôd said it. ‚ÄúSwearing‚Äôs fine, but not if you‚Äôre getting heated. We‚Äôre chatting, not getting up in arms.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight. Sorry,‚Äù the guy said. He didn‚Äôt look particularly sorry.

We picked up speed as we pulled onto a street with less construction. With the back of the bus open and the windows on either side of Jasper and me rolled all the way down, the wind whipped through the bus. The city smelled like dust, drywall, and hot pavement.

I dangled one arm out the window, moving my fingers and feeling the air moving against them.

‚ÄúIt gets complicated,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúGeography‚Äôs slightly different, they‚Äôre hardly checking longitude and latitude exactly when we settle in one place or another. They‚Äôre doing what the surroundings allow. Means the Norwalk we‚Äôre going to might actually be between two places, or off to one side.‚Äù

Jasper chimed in, ‚ÄúI always remember the Norwalk-Fairfield span because it‚Äôs close to the portal for Earth N. N for Norwalk.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI guess that works.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got a question for you, though,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúYou want to talk about your tattoo idea.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he said.

I rolled my eyes. ‚ÄúDo what you want.‚Äù

He turned his head so he could talk to the back of the bus while watching the road. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre doing the squad thing, right? And a lot of us are doing this with the idea we‚Äôll police the capes, or help them out.‚Äù

‚ÄúPolice them, mostly,‚Äù a guy said.

‚ÄúOpinions vary,‚Äù Jasper said, ‚ÄúBut I don‚Äôt want to get sidetracked. What I‚Äôm thinking is, what‚Äôs better than a good callsign? We have nicknames to call each other. The trouble is getting a good one to stick.‚Äù

‚ÄúOpinions on what a good callsign is are going to vary,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúQuiet you,‚Äù Jasper said. ‚ÄúYou and I have talked about this and I‚Äôve determined you have no idea what you‚Äôre talking about when it comes to this. You know the cape stuff, sure, but you clearly don‚Äôt get this.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou want to decide your own callsign?‚Äù the girl from the back asked.

‚ÄúJester,‚Äù Jasper said. ‚ÄúAnd I swear, if people don‚Äôt start using it, I‚Äôm going to make it happen by getting a tattoo of a jester and ‚Äòfool‚Äô written beneath it, right on my bicep.‚Äù

The protests, naturally, started rolling in from the rest of the bus. He couldn‚Äôt decide his own callsign, why would he have it say fool if he wanted the callsign to be Jester, why even have it be Jester?

I tuned it out, sticking my head out the window. Jasper tried to sell the rest of the bus on his idea and was very thoroughly shot down. In this, at least, all was right with the world. It was a bad idea. Forty year-old Jasper didn‚Äôt need to live with the mistakes of seventeen year-old Jasper.

We drove past skyscrapers paneled in gold-tinted glass. Solar glass, it was supposed to be called. We drove past parks with the same rough-edged slice of nature that touched the schoolyard back at the high school. We drove past a lot of construction, and we were lucky that it didn‚Äôt slow us down much.

‚ÄúVictoria Dallon.‚Äù

I‚Äôd heard my name. I was broken from my reverie. How long had we been driving now? The city was seemingly unending and I didn‚Äôt recognize the landmarks enough to nail anything down.

Victoria Dallon. I looked at myself in the bus‚Äô side view mirror.

‚ÄúWhat was that?‚Äù Jasper asked, while I remained silent.

‚ÄúName sounds familiar,‚Äù the voice said, from the back. It sounded almost smug, knowing. ‚ÄúCan‚Äôt quite place it.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat so?‚Äù Jasper asked. ‚ÄúMaybe keep it to yourself, then.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs that how this is?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs how everything is,‚Äù Jasper said. ‚ÄúNot just this. When you‚Äôre bringing up the past, whoever you‚Äôre talking to, there are two likely possibilities. First, it‚Äôs good, and we miss the shit out of it, or, second, it‚Äôs bad and why would you bring up the bad except to be a tool?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt could be important,‚Äù the guy said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good to know who or what we‚Äôre dealing with.‚Äù

‚ÄúCould be,‚Äù Jasper said. ‚ÄúBut I can tell you this. Gil trusts her. I trust her. If you want to know who you‚Äôre dealing with, why don‚Äôt you start by taking our cue?‚Äù

There was no response from the back.

‚ÄúOtherwise, if you‚Äôre not going to listen to us,‚Äù Jasper said, ‚Äúwhy are you on our bus?‚Äù

Again, no response.

Then, belated, one of the others uttered a quiet, ‚ÄúLeave it.‚Äù

Not aimed at Jasper. My detractor had been about to say something, I took it, and he‚Äôd been told to be quiet. Not the best result, but it seemed to end the line of questioning.

I wondered if there was something nice I could do for Jasper, for sparing me having to handle that.

I fished the papers out from my vest, smoothing them against my lap. I glanced out the window. The city had thinned out, and I could see farms and tent cities further out.

We had to be pretty close to our destination now.

I twisted around in my seat again, looking at the people in the back. I could tell by the way one of them held himself, shoulders square, eye contact forced, that he‚Äôd been the one to speak out against me. He studied me like he would an opponent.

I addressed them, ‚ÄúWhen we get there, we stay together. We‚Äôll have a quick chat with the people in charge, all together. If the police have orders for us, those are the orders we follow. If not, I‚Äôll tell you guys to get to work. You head to the crowd, and you say hi.‚Äù

‚ÄúSay hi?‚Äù

‚ÄúMingle. Show your faces, let people know we‚Äôre around. Ask how they‚Äôre doing. What do they think? Look for anyone antsy, especially anyone antsy that we‚Äôre there. Don‚Äôt engage if there‚Äôs trouble. Let the police know and let me know, and we‚Äôll figure it out.‚Äù

‚ÄúI like looping through the crowds,‚Äù Jasper said. ‚ÄúWe did that once or twice, when Gilpatrick was calling the shots, last year. People don‚Äôt see the face or the hair, only the uniform. If you loop back, it looks like there are more of us than there are.‚Äù

‚ÄúGive them second thoughts?‚Äù the girl from the back asked.

‚ÄúSomething like that,‚Äù Jasper said.

I wrapped up. ‚ÄúWhen we get settled and things are going to start, we‚Äôll be keeping eyes out or standing guard, probably. We regroup before then, we‚Äôll figure out what‚Äôs up, and see where we‚Äôre needed.‚Äù

I saw people nod, then turned around in my seat.

‚ÄúWhich street?‚Äù Jasper asked.

‚ÄúMyrtle.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think that‚Äôs it down there,‚Äù he said.

There were still a lot of tents and cubicle houses hereabouts, it seemed. On the southern side of the main road, to our left, we had apartment buildings, stores, and something that looked like a brand spanking new swathe of city. On the other side, it was more construction, tents, farm, and the houses that weren‚Äôt real houses— more like mock houses made of panels that had been bolted together, like overlarge tents with hard exteriors.

We turned away from the main road, into the deeper section of the city. The community center was made of stone, had a squat clock tower situated on top, and looked stately, even with the tall buildings surrounding it, many at least as tall as the community center was. A patch of park with a fountain sat squarely in front of it.

School was just getting out, it seemed. Students were streaming through the area. They walked through and along the road to the point that we couldn‚Äôt get very close. Many heads turned our way, curious.

Jasper found a parking space a block away from the center, and parked there. Our people climbed out the back while Jasper and I got organized at the front.

‚ÄúJasper,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúSpecial orders for me?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen and if the rest of them are going through the crowd, stay near the front door. If anyone gets nervous and ducks out, it might be something.‚Äù

‚ÄúShould I follow?‚Äù

‚ÄúProbably not. Keep an eye out, let me know if anything happens.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd why is this a secret from the others?‚Äù

Because I didn‚Äôt trust the others. They‚Äôd been foisted on me, they had clear attitudes, and I was worried that if push came to shove, they might let a troublemaker go if it meant fucking with the capes.

‚ÄúParanoia,‚Äù I said. I started to climb out of my seat. ‚ÄúThanks for the backup back there. Jester.‚Äù

Jasper grinned as my face fell.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, but it sounds bad,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt make this a thing.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt sounds bad when you‚Äôre saying it as if someone‚Äôs pulling your fingernails out while you‚Äôre talking.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey might as well be,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs cool.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs against everything I stand for,‚Äù I said. I climbed down from my seat.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs great,‚Äù Jasper said, from the other side of the bus. He tossed the keys into the air and caught them.

Some of the others were pulling on the armor they‚Äôd left off while sitting on the bus. Once we were set, we moved as a group toward the town hall.

The fact that the community center was actually in the center of this neighborhood meant that the foot traffic was heavy. A lot of it was moving around the crowd that had formed. A lot of people with signs, but a lot of young and eager eyes. Kids aged ten to seventeen, all fresh from their first day of school, genuinely interested in their fledgling hero team.

No police parked outside, at a glance. No barricades, either.

Inside, it was standing room only. Cheap plastic chairs were arranged in rows and columns, and there were many places where parent and young child shared chairs.

I saw some people up at the front perk up at our appearance, and the crowd parted to let us through.

I identified a woman with gray and black hair and a gray suit-dress that the other people up at the front seemed to be standing around. I approached her.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre in charge?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm the closest thing to someone in charge. District representative,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt have a group like yours here. You‚Äôre all so young.‚Äù

I kept still, not letting my emotions show. I felt the sinking feeling again, without the relief, and without the steadiness that I got from seeing myself in the mirror.

Not a big thing. It was like treading water and a hand on my forehead pushing me down, before pulling away. Surfacing again, finding my equilibrium, realizing how tired I was as I resumed treading water.

I was very aware of the eyes on us.

‚ÄúDo you have more outside?‚Äù the representative asked.

‚ÄúMore‚Ä¶ of us?‚Äù I asked, finding my composure again.

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo. No we don‚Äôt have more outside.‚Äù

She looked spooked. More spooked after my ‚Äòno‚Äô.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt help but notice that you have no police presence at all,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWe have some, but not many. It‚Äôs the way it is in Norfair span.‚Äù

‚ÄúNorfair,‚Äù I said, noting the coined name. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not really a presence, is it?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt expect this many naysayers. With this many, they had to have come from outside the community.‚Äù

The crowd in the room with us looked eager and happy enough. A few frowns, but rare. Had it been just this, overlapping conversations, anticipation, bright eyes and parents with kids, maybe a few people ready to raise some pointed questions if given the opportunity, then all would have been well.

It wasn‚Äôt just them. The protesters outside were audible, even with stone walls between us and them. Two angry voices outside, for every one quiet, polite person inside.

I didn‚Äôt like how much this was stacking up against us. The police not having much presence, the controversy, the number of protesters.

Paranoia again, that I couldn‚Äôt help but wonder about the recruits I‚Äôd been given. Forced to take, as it had turned out.

Too many things together.

‚ÄúI think we should talk to the capes,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù the district rep said.

She led us into the back room, just behind where the de-facto stage was. The team of heroes was there, anxious, waiting to be announced and to step out in front of the crowd.

Four of them. Their costumes were close to being clothing, but had just enough stylization to make them something more. The masks and face-coverings helped to make them more cape-like.

Fume Hood did have a hood, as part of a green hooded coat she wore. Fans were built into the coat, only partially disguised, each of them much like the ones that were built into the back of a computer, and they made her coat, hair, and hood flap.

There was a man in a deep purple tank top and skinny pants with glass jutting from his skin at the elbows and hands, his upper face only a craggy mass of glass or jewel-like shards sticking out of flesh, just beautiful enough to not be macabre.

A man about my age slouched in a chair, looking dejected. He had something that looked like small shields over the back of each hand, three large scimitar-like blades jutting from the back of each shield like they were oversize claws. He wore a top that showed his muscular stomach, with shorts that reached his knees. A two-part icon was displayed on chest and belt buckle.

The last was a woman in overalls, muscular, with hair shorter than most of the boys in my troupe, something that looked like thick paint slashed across her eyes and nose, and covering her arms up to the elbows. The paint was black at the very edges, where it was thinner, but pure white elsewhere. Her eyes were black from corner to corner.

‚ÄúGreat,‚Äù the woman with the paint said, sarcastic. ‚ÄúJust what we needed.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre here to help,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWe might need it,‚Äù Fume Hood said.

‚ÄúDo you know who‚Äôs after you?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúOr what‚Äôs going on?‚Äù

She shook her head.

‚ÄúI might be being paranoid, but this feels off,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúA lot of little things,‚Äù Fume Hood said. ‚ÄúCrystalclear‚Äôs getting a bad vibe.‚Äù

I nodded. I looked at the man with the glass chunks where his nose, eyes, brow and scalp should be.

‚ÄúHave you considered canceling the event?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúWe were actively debating it before you came in,‚Äù the man in purple said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre split.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan we break the tie?‚Äù I asked.

They exchanged glances.

The painted woman scowled, ‚ÄúYou can.‚Äù

The man with the claws stood abruptly, shoving his chair to the ground in the process, before stalking off.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù the painted woman said, again. She looked at the district rep. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre sorry. Can you have them disperse? Tell the protesters they win.‚Äù

The rep nodded, hurrying from the room to where the people were seated.

‚ÄúDeath knell for our group,‚Äù the painted woman said.

‚ÄúMaybe. Probably,‚Äù Fume said. She looked at Crystalclear. ‚ÄúFeeling better?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he said.

Fume nodded at that.

‚ÄúWould you stick around?‚Äù Crystalclear addressed us. ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt mind the backup, if you‚Äôre here to help, and I have the sense this is going to get worse before it gets better.‚Äù

‚ÄúGut feeling sense or‚Ä¶ power sense?‚Äù I asked.

I could hear the commotion as people started to leave. I could hear the complaining. Even before he answered, my gut feeling sense was that he wasn‚Äôt wrong.

‚ÄúThe latter,‚Äù Crystalclear said, corroborating.

Daybreak — 1.3

This was the point in time that I would have liked to be able to take to the skies. Information was important, and if I didn‚Äôt have surveillance cameras, I would have been pretty content with a bird‚Äôs eye view of the scene.

I clenched one fist, cracking my knuckles, before wrapping my other hand around it, cracking them again for good measure.

I turned to look at the people from the patrol. ‚ÄúSet up around the building. Watch what‚Äôs going on outside, stay in touch, report anything unusual. Jasper? Hang back.‚Äù

The others turned to go, some looking back at the capes one last time before leaving. Interest, other things.

‚ÄúCan‚Äôt hurt,‚Äù the painted lady said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm Victoria,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs Jasper. I know Fume Hood from the notes we got, and I caught Crystalclear‚Äôs name.‚Äù

‚ÄúLongscratch is the one who just left,‚Äù the painted lady said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Tempera.‚Äù

‚ÄúThanks,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúGood to meet you. Crystalclear, can you fill me in on your power? What are you getting?‚Äù

‚ÄúI see through everything,‚Äù Crystalclear said, tapping the chunk of crystal that stood out from the lower edge of his eye socket. ‚ÄúAs if everything was crystal. I‚Äôve learned there‚Äôs a lot of nuance to it. A little bit of seeing into the past, a little bit of seeing into the future, a little bit of a sense of people‚Äôs focus.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe has a blaster power too,‚Äù Tempera said. ‚ÄúGoes through walls and the ground. Synergy.‚Äù

‚ÄúI really hope it doesn‚Äôt come to actually using that. Right now, I‚Äôm more interested in how this points to possible trouble in the future,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúUh,‚Äù Crystalclear said. He looked around. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to explain because it‚Äôs not a sense anyone else has. Say I was looking at a wall. It looks like a chunk of clear glass and the light catches at the edges and corners and they‚Äôre highlighted.‚Äù

My eye roved over the room. It was reminiscent of a teacher‚Äôs lounge, but it had less of an emphasis on the lounging. Coffee cups sat on windowsills and there were places where furniture had been stacked once, and the furniture had been moved out into the open room at the front of the building, where all the people were or had been seated. Glass cases with model buildings had been brought inside and carefully stacked against the wall. A long table that might have served as a conference table was folded up in one corner.

I tried to imagine it like Crystalclear was describing it. A sketch in three dimensions, only the lines visible. ‚ÄúI follow you so far.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe edges of walls and floor are usually clear, crisp, and closer to white. Solid objects don‚Äôt change, so there‚Äôs no reason for that to change. It‚Äôs blurred. Blue tinted.‚Äù

‚ÄúFuture sight,‚Äù Tempera added. ‚ÄúPast-sight is red, future-sight is blue. Like the doppler.‚Äù

Crystalclear went on, ‚ÄúIn the future, that wall vibrates. Similar effect with people, but they move around more. I see you all as streaks, shifting around, white-edged where you‚Äôre resting in present. There is refraction and some fractures around people‚Äôs heads, representing focus and kind of thinking.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat gets blueshifted redshifted?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not displayed as color?‚Äù

Crystalclear nodded his head. It was a motion made more weighty by the heavy growth at the top of his head. ‚ÄúNot as color. It‚Äôs‚Ä¶ edges to the light around them, sharpness and softness, distortions like how you can look at a glass of water with a straw in it and the straw isn‚Äôt straight, or you see multiple straws. The worst breaks in focus look like grooves or outright breaks. A lot of people here are going to be distorted soon. Or were. They‚Äôre leaving and they‚Äôre clearing up.‚Äù

His head turned as he focused on things on the other sides of the walls.

‚ÄúWhat about, say, Jasper?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Jasper said. ‚ÄúUse yourself as an example.‚Äù

Crystalclear looked at Jasper. ‚ÄúHard to say. Whatever it is, it‚Äôs small or it‚Äôs distant.‚Äù

Crystalclear glanced over at Tempetera and Fume Hood. ‚ÄúNot just him either. It doesn‚Äôt give me much to work with.‚Äù

He turned his attention to me.

I cut right to asking my next question, before he could comment. ‚ÄúDo you see the direction of it? Anything big and blue that‚Äôs suggesting a major thing coming in sometime in the future? One section of the building that gets hit harder?‚Äù

He shook his head. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd have to see it before I saw how things were around it, and even then there‚Äôs nuance.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre thinking of a parahuman or weapon?‚Äù Tempera asked.

‚ÄúI have no idea,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIf I was a civilian with an issue, and I was going after capes, I‚Äôd go big or I wouldn‚Äôt try at all. If we‚Äôre talking something that shakes this whole community center‚Ä¶ bomb? Parahumans are definitely possible, except I‚Äôm not sure how using parahumans squares with the sentiment toward parahumans.‚Äù

Fume Hood spoke up from the background. ‚ÄúSet us against each other, they benefit either way.‚Äù

‚ÄúCould be,‚Äù I said. I paused. ‚ÄúAs soon as the crowd has dispersed enough, I want to get you guys clear of here. Do you have a decent mover power to use?‚Äù

‚ÄúLongscratch does,‚Äù Tempera said.

‚ÄúNot a mass mover power, is it?‚Äù I asked. At the negation, I turned to Jasper. ‚ÄúCan you bring the bus close? If the crowd is thinning out, you should be able to pull right up to the door. Take someone with you, if we‚Äôre delayed, do like I discussed earlier. Keep an eye out.‚Äù

Jasper saluted, turning to go.

The bus wasn‚Äôt elegant, but hopefully it would take us away from vulnerable civilians or areas.

‚ÄúHow is Longscratch?‚Äù Tempera asked Crystalclear.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs fine. Stalked off. He‚Äôs keeping an eye out for trouble,‚Äù Crystalclear said. He pointed up and off to one side. On an upper floor, it seemed, or on the roof.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs how he is. I won‚Äôt bother him. I‚Äôll go talk to the district representative, instead, if that‚Äôs alright,‚Äù Tempera said, looking my way.

‚ÄúIf the coast is clear,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúMost people have cleared out of the main hall,‚Äù Crystalclear said. ‚ÄúThe ones who are hanging back seem like the types to be doing it for good reason. Parents with kids, teenagers hoping to get a glimpse of the heroes they came to see.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs positive,‚Äù Tempera said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll give them a glimpse then. Thank you, Victoria.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to get a glass of water and get my head straight,‚Äù Fume Hood said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll catch up with the rest of you in a minute.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt go running off,‚Äù Tempera said. ‚ÄúGet your water, take a minute, but come back after. I don‚Äôt want you to throw yourselves to the wolves.‚Äù

‚ÄúI won‚Äôt,‚Äù Fume Hood said.

‚ÄúOr whatever variant on that plan you might be thinking. I can see you trying to lead the enemy way from us,‚Äù Tempera said.

‚ÄúI won‚Äôt,‚Äù Fume Hood said, annoyed.

‚ÄúIt wouldn‚Äôt work anyway,‚Äù Crystalclear added.

‚ÄúYour future sight telling you that?‚Äù Fume Hood asked, her annoyance becoming something more bitter.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see the future like that. You know that. But I do know that they‚Äôre mad at all of us. Our fortunes are intertwined, and their hate is— it‚Äôs not very targeted.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot hate,‚Äù I said.

They looked my way.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs easy to see it as hate, but I‚Äôve been thinking about it a lot,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that. It‚Äôs blame.‚Äù

‚ÄúBlame,‚Äù Fume Hood said.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a reflection on you. Humanity is hurt. It‚Äôs hurt in a way that makes it a little bit animal. Reactive. They‚Äôre snapping at any target that presents itself, because the hurt is fresh. They‚Äôre taking that hurt and they‚Äôre looking for anyone they can put it onto. You‚Ä¶‚Äù

I trailed off.

‚ÄúWe presented ourselves,‚Äù Tempera said.

‚ÄúNot in a bad way,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt your fault.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll get my water,‚Äù Fume Hood said, curt. She didn‚Äôt wait for a response, heading into the adjacent room, further from the front of the building.

Once Fume Hood was gone, Tempera nudged Crystalclear. ‚ÄúKeep an eye on them?‚Äù

Crystalclear nodded.

Tempera gave me a nod before stepping out the door.

‚ÄúIs Fume Hood going to be okay?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúWho knows?‚Äù he asked.

‚ÄúTrouble still isn‚Äôt imminent?‚Äù

Crystalclear shook his head. ‚ÄúAt least fifteen minutes off. I‚Äôm thinking we should go get a better vantage point, see if I can‚Äôt spot any troublemakers.‚Äù

‚ÄúWatch out for my guys,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWatch out for what?‚Äù

I glanced at the door. ‚ÄúBlame.‚Äù

‚ÄúGot it,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI shouldn‚Äôt stick my neck out or draw attention to myself, then?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot unless I‚Äôm there.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd where will you be?‚Äù he asked.

I looked at the other door. The one Fume Hood had taken. ‚ÄúI was thinking I‚Äôd get a glass of water. Unless you think that would be overstepping.‚Äù

He looked in the direction Fume Hood had gone. His voice was soft as he said, ‚ÄúI have no fucking idea.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll catch up with you,‚Äù I said, clapping a hand on his shoulder in passing.

The area adjacent to the conference room was a kitchen, set up with multiple stovetops and long counters. Catering-focused, at a glance. The stoves were of different makes and models. Scavenged.

Fume Hood was standing by the sink, a glass of water in hand. She looked at me, her eyes barely visible with the surrounding mask and the overhanging hood.

‚ÄúCan I grab some water? The bus ride was warm, even with the windows rolled down.‚Äù

She filled a glass, then slid it along the counter to me, so it met me halfway as I made my approach.

‚ÄúWhat was the plan?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúThe plan?‚Äù

‚ÄúCorporate? Sponsored? Ideology-driven? There are a lot of those nowadays. Move forward, rebuild, hold to the past, unity in strength, religion‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúNo ideology,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúNo sponsorship. No business partnerships. I‚Äôm not even sure what we would have done about the money.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat can be hard,‚Äù I said. I drank my water.

‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt supposed to be easy.‚Äù

I finished my water, then approached the sink to get more. Fume Hood turned around, leaning against the counter just beside me.

She said, ‚ÄúIt was community focused. Serving the area, hometown heroes like the old days. I thought of it as community service, in more than one way.‚Äù

‚ÄúI like that,‚Äù I said.

She shrugged. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure if there‚Äôs anything to like about it.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a good idea. It sounds positive. Maybe it‚Äôs worth trying again later.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt won‚Äôt come together again like this later. Tempera is pretty good at this whole thing, and she needs to do the cape stuff, so she‚Äôll find a team to join. Crystalclear will get poached because decent thinker powers are in demand. Longscratch‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt know why he‚Äôs even here. Tempera suggested it to him, for some reason, he accepted for some reason. He‚Äôs upset it fell apart. Next time, he‚Äôll just say no. He‚Äôll steer clear so he doesn‚Äôt have reason to get upset again.‚Äù

‚ÄúMover psychology?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know about that stuff. I just know he‚Äôs a weird mix of wants and needs and he‚Äôs really cool when things are good and he‚Äôs impossible to understand when they aren‚Äôt. Which they aren‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYou wouldn‚Äôt be sorry if you knew,‚Äù she said. She stood taller, stretching a bit. She tossed the empty glass between her hands. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs my fault.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou orchestrated this?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI hurt a pregnant lady and she lost her child and I don‚Äôt even feel that bad about it,‚Äù Fume Hood said. ‚ÄúI turned myself in, but it was because people thought I‚Äôd become a PR problem for capes in general. I‚Äôd run out of friends and places to run to. It seemed like the only way to get things to cool down.‚Äù

The glass smacked against each of her hands as she tossed it back and forth.

I drank my water, still watching her.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm pissed,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúPeople are making such a big deal over this, and I can‚Äôt bring myself to see it their way. It was an accident. I told the civilians to sit and stay put, and this stupid—‚Äù

She stopped there, clenching her fist.

Fume Hood continued, ‚Äú—stupid fucking woman. She ran right to where I was shooting out a display window, gets knocked on her ass, breathes in the gas.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wonder what she was thinking,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve wondered that every day since. I‚Äôm mostly caught between thinking she wanted to get hurt and lose the baby, it was so blatant, or that she thought the broken display window was an escape route, even though there were others she could have run for,‚Äù Fume Hood said. ‚ÄúI was so pissed. I shouted at people to take her outside and get her some fresh air, even though I knew it made everything harder with the robbery. They‚Äôd contact authorities, we‚Äôd have to protect ourselves, whatever. I thought I was pretty fair. She got medical attention and shit.‚Äù

‚ÄúCould have been worse,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI shouldn‚Äôt have pulled that robbery at the mall. I know that. But it‚Äôs not one of my big regrets. Her being a stupid fucking idiot isn‚Äôt one of them either, obviously.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou turned yourself in after that.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe heat got too much, like I said. And— and I was tired, you know?‚Äù

Her voice had cracked on the ‚Äòtired‚Äô.

She sounded tired now.

‚ÄúIt had been years, trying to get by. A lot of it was fun. The drugs, the robberies and mercenary work, the adventure, new places and really interesting people. Some shitty people, lots of scary people, but they were always interesting. Capes are interesting in a way you probably wouldn‚Äôt get if you didn‚Äôt know any for real.‚Äù

‚ÄúI grew up with capes,‚Äù I said.

She stopped passing the glass from hand to hand, holding it in both instead. ‚ÄúDid you? Huh.‚Äù

I shrugged. My glass was empty. I put it on the counter and, finger on the inside, spun it in a circle, the bottom rattling on the metal countertop.

She continued, ‚ÄúWell, all I know is, the crime stuff started to feel like work. The drugs stopped feeling like they were a plus and started feeling like they were something I had to do. I was never addicted, I never craved it, I never had withdrawal after. This analogy I‚Äôve been thinking of is it‚Äôs like I had to go to the bathroom every half hour and who wants to do that, you know? Who wants to keep interrupting their day for something they aren‚Äôt even enjoying anymore?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo idea,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúBut I can see what you‚Äôre saying.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe cool people started dropping away. A couple dead, others just stopped being cool. High people are really boring to be around. So like a genius, I thought hey, let‚Äôs just go to prison. I made a deal. I wanted a bit of an education, training at some job or another, safety, I didn‚Äôt want to be stuck in there too long.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow‚Äôd it work out?‚Äù

‚ÄúDeal worked out fine. Judge agreed, heroes agreed, it was one less parahuman on the streets that people were really upset about. Jail isn‚Äôt fun, but it was what I needed, I think.‚Äù

‚ÄúShows character, I think,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúRealizing where you were at, where you were headed, and changing course.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have character,‚Äù Fume Hood said. ‚ÄúIt was selfish and self-centered. It was me, me, me, I‚Äôm bored, I‚Äôm done with the drugs, I‚Äôm scared of being caught by angry people, I want this deal, I want some education. I don‚Äôt and I never cared about that pregnant idiot.‚Äù

She met my eyes as she said that last bit.

Challenging me.

I spun the glass on the countertop again. ‚ÄúThe community service hero stuff?‚Äù

‚ÄúMe, me, me,‚Äù she said, her voice quiet. ‚ÄúI thought it gave me the best chance of dodging any lingering heat. Ha.‚Äù

I took my finger away from the glass. It spun in a circle before settling with a rattle.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt buy it,‚Äù I said.

She shrugged, tossing the glass into the air, catching it.

‚ÄúYou said before that you have real regrets,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúAnd you can call yourself selfish, but I think the dots connect here. Your reasons, your regrets.‚Äù

She tossed the glass into the air, caught it.

She did it a few more times.

‚ÄúWe should go,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúCheck on the others. Do our part.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe should,‚Äù I said.

The water from the faucet we‚Äôd used deposited a fat droplet on the metal bottom of the large sink, producing a hollow sound. Neither of us budged.

‚ÄúI got friends into the soft drugs and I egged them on instead of stopping them when they got themselves into the harder stuff. I regret that, I turned myself in for that, even though I was supposed to be serving the punishment for the pregnant woman. For other stuff, more on that level. I turned myself in for the‚Äù —she took a deep breath, as if to signify magnitude— ‚Äúyears of being a low to mid tier nusiance. For being tiresome. And because I was tired of it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a priest,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have the power to say some words and absolve you. It‚Äôs up to society to decide how angry they are and how they come to terms with it. It‚Äôs up to you to decide how willing you are to face your deeds. When it comes to me‚Ä¶ I can say I respect a lot of what you‚Äôre saying. I definitely think you should own up more to what you did to that woman, stop calling her stupid. It‚Äôs not a point in your favor.‚Äù

Fume Hood nodded.

‚ÄúHonestly,‚Äù I said, ‚ÄúI really like the community hero idea. I‚Äôd really like you to try it again, after a bit. For that to be your way of working through it all, from influencing your friends to hurting that woman. We‚Äôre dealing with blame, not hate, and blame finds a place to roost eventually. There has to be another shot at making this happen.‚Äù

‚ÄúBlame seems like too small a word for what Crystal was saying.‚Äù

‚ÄúBlame can be big,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúBlame has led to the ruin of nations.‚Äù

She nodded. ‚ÄúThat sort of helps, actually.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad to have sort of helped.‚Äù

‚ÄúBlame can become something else, given time, can‚Äôt it?‚Äù she asked.

‚ÄúIt can,‚Äù I admitted. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm spooked at the idea it will. For now, just‚Ä¶ be a hero,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt walk away from this sort of thing for good.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou guys keep saying stuff to me, like, don‚Äôt run off, don‚Äôt sacrifice yourself, be a hero, as if it‚Äôs implied I‚Äôve got ideas I haven‚Äôt said out loud.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a self-described shitty person and an ex-villain. We‚Äôre not allowed to be suspicious?‚Äù I asked.

That got a half-smile out of her.

‚ÄúCome on,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm getting worried about my guys and I‚Äôll get yelled at by my boss if I leave them to their own devices for too long.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis is your thing, then?‚Äù she asked. She followed me as I left, setting her glass next to where I‚Äôd left mine. ‚ÄúYou joined the junior-PRT to convince shitty people to be less shitty?‚Äù

‚ÄúOn the most basic level, I got into this because capes are what I know,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúBecause you grew up with them.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, but keep that under the lid for now,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not broadcasting it to the world.‚Äù

‚ÄúLips zipped.‚Äù

I pushed the door open, stepping back into the now-empty conference room. ‚ÄúI want to help. I could have helped with construction or farming or whatever else, but like I said—‚Äù

‚ÄúCapes are what you know.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah. I knew so many great people and I don‚Äôt know if all of them made it, but I want to be in a position to help them through whatever comes next. I want to figure things out, because the lack of answers is what fucks us over, and fucks them over. I want to talk to people like you, if you happen to be on the fence, so maybe you land on the side where you‚Äôre more likely to help out those really cool, great people.‚Äù

‚ÄúI thought you junior-PRT kids were all about training so you can go after the monsters.‚Äù

She‚Äôd created a hard green sphere, the size of a billiard ball. She tossed it between her hands as she had the glass. It smacked against each palm.

I answered her, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt get me wrong, but I have pretty strong feelings when it comes to the monsters. I‚Äôm pretty far from being okay with them.‚Äù

She gave me a sidelong glance while opening the door to the main room.

‚ÄúBut I don‚Äôt think you‚Äôre one of them,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúSorry, but you‚Äôre safe from me.‚Äù

She threw the ball to the right, but instead of smacking into her palm, it curved in the air, orbiting her hand in a long ellipse as a moon might a planet.

‚ÄúWhat a relief,‚Äù she said. She was smiling a bit more, now.

The smile faltered a bit more as we faced the situation at hand.

Some of the police had come inside. My guys were standing near the windows, looking out. Some were talking to the police.

A share of the crowd had remained behind. Community leaders, possibly.

Fume Hood hung back as I approached them all.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre in charge?‚Äù a police officer asked. He had a mustache. It bothered me, because I‚Äôd never really got mustaches, barring the truly awesome ones. This was lip decoration, bristly and at odds with how his hair was combed back and close to his head.

‚ÄúYessir. I‚Äôm Victoria, I take my orders from Instructor Gilpatrick at Wayfair High School.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey said you told them to follow our orders?‚Äù

‚ÄúOr to keep a lookout for trouble. There‚Äôs still people here? Is there a problem?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù the officer said. He sighed. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what to do with them. Yours or with the others. Situation seems to be resolving itself, but the teenagers in uniform are insisting it isn‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe capes say it isn‚Äôt,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd believe them.‚Äù

‚ÄúHuh,‚Äù he said.

I took a deep breath, exhaling slowly, while the officer took a look around at the situation.

‚ÄúHaven‚Äôt you talked to them?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúThe capes?‚Äù

‚ÄúA little bit,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúNot recently. I don‚Äôt really know how.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre people,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúCapable people who want to help.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôve got the eye thing, and the masks. One doesn‚Äôt have eyes at all,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúHe has these crystals. He pulled one out of the top of his head earlier, and it made a wet sound. It was in so deep it should‚Äôve been inside his brain.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre people,‚Äù I said, again.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs disconcerting,‚Äù the man said.

I wanted to say things to that, but I bit my tongue. I could hardly criticize when I‚Äôd been talking to Fume Hood.

I‚Äôd just— I‚Äôd really hoped for better.

‚ÄúIf you need me to be a liason, let me know,‚Äù I said. He didn‚Äôt give me an immediate response, so I called out to the squaddies. ‚ÄúGet back from the windows, guys! The working theory is a bomb, heavy impact, cape power, or something like an earthquake, and you don‚Äôt want your nose pressed against the glass when it comes!‚Äù

They shuffled back.

‚ÄúBomb?‚Äù the officer asked.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúCan you get everyone here clear of danger?‚Äù

‚ÄúTo somewhere inside or further outside?‚Äù

I looked around. Crystalclear and the others hadn‚Äôt come to find us, so I was left to imagine the danger wasn‚Äôt super imminent. Inside posed risks.

I didn‚Äôt like making the calls, but I said, ‚ÄúOutside, but hurry it up. If there‚Äôs any remaining crowd outside, get them further back or get them to go.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúMakes sense.‚Äù

He whistled for the attention of his people and the crowd that had gathered closer to the front door.

While he handled that, I looked at the others, ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs Jasper?‚Äù

‚ÄúStill out there. He has Mar and Landon with him. The crowd is in their way.‚Äù

I hurried to approach the window. I could hear a commotion behind me, as others entered the room, but my focus was on the commotion outside. My view was briefly blocked by the cops and the people they were leading outside and across the street to our left, away from both the building and the lingering protesters.

‚ÄúVictoria,‚Äù Crystalclear said, behind me. He was with a small few members of the community center staff, including the district rep, and he had Longscratch and Tempera with him.

He would be here because trouble was imminent.

‚ÄúHow soon?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúTwo impacts in a couple of minutes. Six or seven.‚Äù

Two. Six or seven minutes gave us a window to act.

I watched the scene in progress through the window. Jasper wouldn‚Äôt make it to the front door in two or three minutes. Some of the protest had dispersed, but a lot of it had spread out from the square of grass, sidewalks, fountain and trees just in front of the community center, dotting the streets. A share of them occupied the street Jasper needed to come down to reach us, and a lot of them had their back to him. He honked, not for the first time, and one of them gave him the finger.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to help Jasper out, get us our bus so we can drive out of here without being mobbed,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIs there a side door?‚Äù

Crystalclear pointed at what would have been the south side of the building, to my left.

‚ÄúGo there, stay clear of windows. Protect my people, keep them clear of danger. The moment there‚Äôs real trouble, they‚Äôre just high schoolers and should be treated as such. High schoolers— you guys protect Fume Hood. Protect the capes. Be good.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you need help?‚Äù Tempera asked.

She couldn‚Äôt help. She would cause more problems than she fixed, being in costume.

No. I shook my head, heading to the front door.

Was this an emergency? Yes.

Did I like using my power? No.

I marched toward the bus, glaring at the first person in my way. I activated my aura.

‚ÄúMove,‚Äù I said, and I pushed out with my power. Heads turned, noticing. Maybe they would put their finger on why they‚Äôd noticed. Maybe not. I was nudging, here.

I could see the man‚Äôs reaction. He took a partial step back.

I stepped it up a notch, not with more use of my power, but by raising the volume of my voice. ‚ÄúOut of the way!‚Äù

He got out of the way. That and me drawing nearer made it easier for the next person to come through.
