That was what my aura did, really. Another of those contextual emotional things, like the Stockholm syndrome. Awe and admiration if they liked me, fear if they didn‚Äôt.

Just fear, here.

‚ÄúS-stop.‚Äù

Not my voice this time. Jasper‚Äôs.

I stopped.

I trembled as I made myself get back to my feet. I wiped my cheeks where they were wet. My hair was a mess from being thrown around. I used numb fingers to pry at it, undoing the tie.

‚ÄúChrist,‚Äù Mar said.

For the first time, Jasper didn‚Äôt shut him up.

The building shook. Daylight reached parts of the indoors it wasn‚Äôt supposed to. This would be their plan B. Property damage indeed. Lord of Loss was tearing off the roof.

‚ÄúWe need to go,‚Äù Tempera said.

I nodded. I looked back for the hole I‚Äôd made. I saw the teenagers in uniform in the trashed room. They‚Äôd opened the hole the rest of the way and filed out. Now they stood as far away from me as the room‚Äôs boundaries allowed.

They would have seen me throw the bed.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. My voice sounded hollow.

The partial uniform I wore, still without the vest that I‚Äôd left outside, dusty blood-spotted, it didn‚Äôt fit me anymore. I felt choked by it, because I knew I‚Äôd just lost my job.

I led the way down the stairs. I stumbled in one place where a trace of Nursery‚Äôs effect made the stair a different shape, carpeted when it shouldn‚Äôt have been. Flight helped keep me from sprawling.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre Glory Girl,‚Äù Landon said.

I‚Äôm not, I thought.

‚ÄúPeople said you died when the Slaughterhouse Nine attacked Brockton Bay back in twenty-eleven.‚Äù

‚ÄúLandon,‚Äù Jasper said. One word.

The people who had been gathered inside were evacuating. Kingdom Come wasn‚Äôt making it easy, either. As they reached a safe distance, near where people had been protesting, they were gathering in offset rows, so we would have to move diagonally or zig-zag through their ranks to get past them. A fence.

It was hard to tell what the villains were doing when Blindside was part of the group and they were already distant, but I could turn my head and see a bit of them out of the corner of one eye. They were backing up, moving away without actually fleeing the scene. Nursery was creating her effect.

The kids I‚Äôd brought with me were backing away, putting themselves a distance away from us.

I looked up for the branches overhead and I didn‚Äôt see them.

‚ÄúWatch out for Lord of Loss,‚Äù Tempera said, following my line of sight.

Where was he?

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs up there,‚Äù Crystalclear said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs changing. Centaur?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs his combat form,‚Äù I said. I still didn‚Äôt sound like myself. ‚ÄúOne of them. It‚Äôs mobile.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll keep the others busy,‚Äù Longscratch said. He swiped one of the weapons he held, the buckler with the three swords mounted on the back, and three deep furrows appeared on the ground, stretching out beneath the feet of the crowd.

‚ÄúWait,‚Äù Tempera said.

Longscratch flickered, appearing momentarily at two of the points on the far side of the crowd where the furrows ended, before finalizing at the third.

‚ÄúHelp him,‚Äù she told Crystalclear, touching his shoulder, leaving white fingerprints. ‚ÄúFume Hood, stay close. They‚Äôre still targeting you.‚Äù

Tempera moved her hand, and deposited what looked like fifty gallons of the white paint with black edges on the street. We spread out as it appeared. She moved her fingers, and it spread out.

‚ÄúTempe!‚Äù Crystalclear shouted. He extended one hand out to the side, pointing.

The paint moved, a tidal wave, leaving a streak where it went.

I chased it.

Lord of Loss leaped from the rooftop. Ten feet tall, a centaur in vague shape only. His lower body looked more rhino-like, though the legs were longer, and he was plated in those same straps that looked like twists of smoke frozen in place, or wispy bands of metal that peeled away from him at the end. He carried a heavy shield on one side, cut in a way that let its bottom left edge rest against the shoulder of his foreleg when he held it tilted forward, and he carried a heavy lance in the other hand.

His face was a helmet, the slits for the eyes and lower face were closed up, so the face was only a series of ridges where bands met and poked out, Y-shaped. His hair was a mane of bands left to flow like smoke.

He landed in the streak of Tempera‚Äôs paint, and he lost traction, falling to one side.

The paint rose up and over him, then solidified. He shattered it, lurched to his feet. The paint liquified and rose up and over his legs, and he shattered it again.

Was it more easily than he‚Äôd shattered it the first time?

Actions he repeated were supposed to be stronger.

To give Tempera a hand, I threw myself forward at Lord of Loss. Flight, forcefield up. He twisted around and raised the shield, blocking me. I still hit him hard enough to cost him footing. Paint covered him, hardened.

He broke the paint, swung his lance around, hitting me with the broad side.

Forcefield down, impact dampened but not entirely broken. I hit the ground and it hurt.

He broke through the paint yet again, found his feet, hit me again, this time while my feet were planted on the ground. My forcefield came back up just in time to be broken again.

Yeah, that hit had been harder.

Fume Hood shot him, hit him in the face. The paint crawled up to his upper body and joints, hardened there, trying to limit his movement, and he broke it again.

He laughed. Then he hit me again. I deflected the hit, swatting at his lance with one hand.

He was advancing, pressing closer to Fume Hood, and as much as I retreated, as much as I was sure Fume Hood was backing up, he had longer legs.

When he hit me yet again, pavement cracked beneath me, around my feet, the forcefield pushing the impact out and around me. I almost lost my step backing away, with the cracked ground.

Each hit stronger than the last by a significant margin.

This was the point I was supposed to throw my hands up and surrender, or get out of the way. If he decided to hit me more frequently, or if he lurched forward and kicked me with one of those feet of his after swatting me with his lance—

Crystalclear had turned around, was using his blasts on Lord of Loss now.

Loss, losses, losses, losses.

I threw myself forward, flying, seizing him by one leg, twisting, trying to knock him over.

I got him off balance, and then he hit me. Only a moment of me holding onto him kept me from getting smacked into the ground with no forcefield. I fell to the ground and scrambled out of the way of his legs.

I waited until my forcefield was back, then threw myself at him, bowling him over. I tore at strips, peeling away at him.

In the background, Kingdom Come had abandoned his control over the crowd. They woke as if from a deep sleep, and they seemed surprised by what was happening around them. They fled. Away from the brutes fighting, away from the chaos and the damaged building.

He elbowed me. It took him long enough to rise to his feet again that I was able to get in front of him again.

I could do this.

I needed to do this.

It—

It wasn‚Äôt my day to get what I wanted. I barely registered the sound. A crack, coinciding with the noise of the crowd. Lord of Loss went still.

My back had been turned, so I hadn‚Äôt been in a position to see it.

One bullet, from somewhere nearby. Fume Hood on the ground, Tempera beside her.

It wasn‚Äôt my day to get what I wanted.

I‚Äôd frozen. A lot of people had.

‚ÄúGo to her,‚Äù Lord of Loss said. ‚ÄúHelp. I‚Äôll let you go if you let us go.‚Äù

Numb, I nodded.

‚ÄúLet people know it wasn‚Äôt us. This wasn‚Äôt our plan,‚Äù he said, behind me.

I flew as much as I walked, and dropped to my knees at Fume Hood‚Äôs side. I put my forcefield up, tried to position myself where I could be a wall for her.

‚ÄúPut your hands here,‚Äù Tempera told me.

I did, pressing down on the stomach wound. Blood pooled out, covering the backs of my hands.

The crowd had gone still. There was a murmuring, and people were drawing closer to watch and to see.

Reminiscent of Vikare.

In the background, Longscratch and Crystalclear had already apprehended the suspect. A protester that had been in a building nearby. Hunting rifle. The villains were leaving.

‚ÄúNot—‚Äù Fume Hood grunted.

‚ÄúNot?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúNot a good day,‚Äù she muttered, through gasps.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù I agreed. Very much agreed.

Landon had come closer, and was helping by getting the first aid kit out. Tempera took the components.

‚ÄúNot a good day for any of us,‚Äù Tempera said, giving the crowd a glance.

Daybreak — 1.7

The sun was just starting to set when the police were wrapping up with us. They‚Äôd had to arrive first, of course, the ones who had been on the scene were compromised, victims as much as anything.

Nobody Kingdom Come had affected remembered much of anything. It was as though they‚Äôd fallen asleep — they remembered losing awareness, some reported briefly coming to in the middle of things as the building had shook or they had been knocked around, and they hadn‚Äôt really processed or understood much of those glimmers.

A few had reported me as a recurring image.

There was some concern that Kingdom Come might have absconded with someone or that not everyone that had been in the crowd was accounted for, but from what I could tell, it had been an all or nothing thing. People remembered coming to, many of them dangerously close to a superhero fight in progress, but the recollections were hazy.

I sat on the sidewalk near the front door of the community center, aware that it was very late in the day. The sky was orange-yellow now, with darkness on the eastern horizon. The thickest parts of the clouds overhead were cast in shadow, zig-zags of darkness through the amber.

The heat of the day was subsiding, helped by the cloud cover. Dust and sweat had left my arms mottled with grime and tracks where sweat had wiped it away. I‚Äôd washed my hands after helping Fume Hood, and I‚Äôd realized I hadn‚Äôt gotten all of Tempera‚Äôs paint and the blood on the backs of my hands. I was painfully conscious of the sweat, grime and blood, yet I couldn‚Äôt bring myself to go wash up because that would require attention to it.

Paradoxical, I was well aware.

I turned my attention back to the kids. Making sure they were okay. At some point where I had been lost in thought, Gilpatrick had showed up. I watched until he glanced my way. He raised a hand, and I raised mine. Then he turned his attention back to the teenagers. As it should be.

I‚Äôd figured I would be working late. I‚Äôd just thought it would be paperwork and talking to the students. I‚Äôd really liked that part. It was fascinating stuff when it wasn‚Äôt so close to home.

I could relax some, seeing Gilpatrick. Not because it meant great things, but because it meant I didn‚Äôt have to think about finding Gil after, getting the details, putting off hearing the news or delivering the essential details.

I put my hands behind me where I wouldn‚Äôt see the blood or the places where the paint had settled into the cracks, oil-black, and I leaned back, eyes closed, trying to focus on the voices and the sounds, on the breezy wind and the ambient warmth.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù Gilpatrick said. He‚Äôd approached me.

I kept my eyes closed. I said, ‚ÄúAre the students okay? The others?‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre fine. Some have parents here, I‚Äôve got a bus coming for the others. Psychologically, emotionally, I don‚Äôt know. It was scary and it was hard to know what was happening. The staff of the community center are obviously upset about the building, but that‚Äôs not on us.‚Äù

I opened my eyes.

Gilpatrick wasn‚Äôt wearing his vest. A sleeveless undershirt tucked into black pants, a sweatshirt slung over one shoulder. Bald, bushy eyebrows, hairy, hairy arms.

‚ÄúJasper filled me in on most of it,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs reliable when it counts, it seems.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a good guy,‚Äù I agreed. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a reason I wanted him with me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI get it now, I think.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you want this project to be a positive thing, at least at our school, you‚Äôll want more Jaspers. You wanted a verdict on the kids you sent with me? I wouldn‚Äôt put them in leadership roles. Not if there are going to be capes on scene. What I heard and saw wasn‚Äôt very positive, and if there were any who disagreed, they didn‚Äôt feel confident enough to say it out loud.‚Äù

Gilpatrick ran his hand over the skin of his head, not giving me a response.

My arms were tired from propping myself up. I leaned forward instead.

‚ÄúAlright. Thanks. Not good to hear, but I appreciate it,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll take that under serious advisement.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey follow orders, at least.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was really hoping to have more hands to help out,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúReally unfortunate.‚Äù

Some parents were joining students who were talking to the police. I watched them. Parent and child side by side, parents concerned as they listened, getting the details at the same time the officers were.

‚ÄúI am sorry this happened,‚Äù Gilpatrick said. ‚ÄúI meant it when I said it. I mean it now.‚Äù

‚ÄúI gave my point-by-point retelling of events to the police,‚Äù I said. I stared at my hands. ‚ÄúIncluding the part where I was hit by a few emotion-affecting attacks. It‚Äôll take some of the responsibility off your shoulders, if anyone asks.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that important,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWell, it‚Äôs important, obviously, thank you, but I don‚Äôt want to dwell on that. If people make an issue out of it, I‚Äôll handle it. I knew what I was doing when I brought you on board. That‚Äôs not what I want to talk to you about.‚Äù

‚ÄúI stuck around,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúTo be something like a guardian for the students who were acting as witnesses, making sure they weren‚Äôt pressed too hard or made uncomfortable. I stopped when I realized being there was making some things harder, because they didn‚Äôt like being around me, or that it looked like I was trying to protect myself by inserting myself into things and influencing their testimony.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Gilpatrick said.

‚ÄúI backed off, Jasper and Landon took my cues, I think.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs good.‚Äù

I thought that‚Äôd be the time he followed the thread of the conversation and got around to saying what he needed to say. He didn‚Äôt.

There was a break in the convo. More cars were pulling into spaces along either side of the ‚Äòsquare‚Äô of grass, sidewalk, and fountain in front of the community center. Some more parents.

‚ÄúDid they mention Fume Hood?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúOnly that she was taken to the hospital and all signs were good when she left. Tempera was staying close to her. Something to do with paint?‚Äù

No news then. ‚ÄúTempera stopped the worst of the blood loss. She poured paint in the wound, shaped it, and solidified it. We might have lost Fume Hood in another way, though. We might not keep her as a hero after this.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid she say that?‚Äù

‚ÄúThere was a brief twilight between when the pain meds kicked in and when the meds knocked her out,‚Äù I said. I moved my fingers, felt how unlike skin the backs of my hands felt, stiff with the stuff I hadn‚Äôt managed to wash off. I‚Äôd rushed, because I‚Äôd wanted to get back to keeping an eye on the students from the patrol group.

‚ÄúAre you going to finish that thought?‚Äù Gilpatrick asked, his voice soft.

I closed my eyes. ‚ÄúUm. We chatted. She said she was staying with a family member already, so she‚Äôd have someone to look after her if she needed it.‚Äù

Thinking about family pulled my thoughts in a few different directions. I could have tried picking a safer one, but I wasn‚Äôt sure I was that on the ball, being as tired and discouraged as I was.

I went on, ‚ÄúHer brother cut ties with her when she went villain. She was living in that area where all the building foundations were screwed up because they were rushed, and everyone had to leave the homes they‚Äôd just settled in, reached out to her brother, and she‚Äôs been staying with him, reconnecting. It might give me some hope for her, having that positive influence, but she sounded pretty cynical about it all when we had the conversation right after meeting, before everything happened.‚Äù

‚ÄúCynicism is understandable, to a degree. That‚Äôs where she‚Äôs at. Where are you at, Victoria?‚Äù

‚ÄúSimilar to Fume Hood, really. I wasn‚Äôt evicted because of rushed apartment construction, but I‚Äôve been staying with my dad because it means we each pay half the rent, and I want to keep my options open with things being what they are.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt talking about living accommodations,‚Äù Gilpatrick said. ‚ÄúYour head, your heart. Are there any lingering effects from the emotion effect?‚Äù

‚ÄúFor the last two years,‚Äù I whispered.

‚ÄúSorry? I didn‚Äôt catch that,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs gone. It really sucked while it was in effect, but it‚Äôs gone. Right now I‚Äôm in that heavyhearted, almost-blameless-but-guilty ‚Äòmorning after‚Äô phase, where I‚Äôm reflecting on everything I did when I was under the influence,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI know that well enough. I‚Äôve been hit a few times by those, back when I was a squaddie and squad leader. And by you, once.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou asked me to,‚Äù I pointed out, looking up at Gilpatrick, ‚Äúand this was a bad one. Snag? I read about a thing online, keeping tabs on who was out there. I‚Äôm pretty sure he‚Äôs part of a new multitrigger cluster. It might have been amplified by the tinkering, if it wasn‚Äôt, then something else was in play. That didn‚Äôt hit me like it was a minor or secondary power.‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù he said.

He wasn‚Äôt a bad guy. I wanted to be angry but I couldn‚Äôt justify it.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry it happened like this,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt supposed to be anything like this. I thought it‚Äôd get a bit nasty with the civilian protesters but I didn‚Äôt think it‚Äôd be anything like this. Not the capes, not the gunshot at the end.‚Äù

I hadn‚Äôt either.

‚ÄúJasper said you guessed why I sent those students with you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. I climbed to my feet.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm especially sorry for that,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIf it was up to me, I wouldn‚Äôt have ever tested you like that. It wasn‚Äôt wholly up to me.‚Äù

‚ÄúWho?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúEveryone,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúNo-one. It‚Äôs complicated. Wardens and the hero teams are being pressured to be mindful of who is out there, touching base, and they reached out to some of the other patrol groups with concerns. They wanted to coordinate, so teenagers wouldn‚Äôt be out interviewing or exposing themselves to anyone dangerous. School got to talking, and they got into CYA mode.‚Äù

‚ÄúCover your ass,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThey wanted to be able to say that they‚Äôd made a reasonable effort to check that the parahumans the students were exposed to were reasonable and safe, in case anything happened down the line. I could have kept quiet about you, but‚Ä¶‚Äù

He trailed off.

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt have asked you to,‚Äù I said.

‚Äú‚Ä¶I didn‚Äôt get the impression you wanted me to, either. You weren‚Äôt being secretive. I don‚Äôt want to operate that way, either.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo. I wouldn‚Äôt want you to,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYou know I can‚Äôt keep you on the staff,‚Äù he said.

I nodded.

There it was.

Fuck.

I hadn‚Äôt been super attached to the job, but‚Ä¶ fuck.

‚ÄúUsing power on kids, the contention about possible conflict of interest, undue influence, danger. I think things will stay at that, I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôll follow you.‚Äù

I nodded.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a dim chance of a student claiming emotional distress because of your aura and pursuing things in court, I‚Äôve already talked to one officer to get them on board and we‚Äôll get something in writing. I‚Äôll vouch for you and for the events as Jasper described them, one hundred percent, if you end up needing someone to stand for you. None of this was you.‚Äù

‚ÄúCourts are a million years behind as it stands, and getting further behind every day we don‚Äôt have an established system of government,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúBy the time things get that far it‚Äôll be forgotten.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat is a factor,‚Äù Gilpatrick said.

I wasn‚Äôt worried about that side of things. I was hurt, but I wasn‚Äôt worried.

‚ÄúDo you need a hand getting things cleared out of the office?‚Äù he asked.

I shook my head. I didn‚Äôt want to think about that.

‚ÄúCan—‚Äù I started. I cleared my throat. ‚ÄúCan I get back to you on that? I‚Äôve— I guess I‚Äôve got a family thing I should go to.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor sure,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnytime outside of usual school or work hours.‚Äù

I might have flinched in a way that he saw, hearing that. I knew why he‚Äôd said it, but it still sucked to hear.

I started to walk away.

‚ÄúVictoria,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúAny favor you need, reference letter, intel, if you need Jasper or some other trustworthy faces in uniform to lend a hand with something‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù I said, my voice lighter and more cheerful than I felt. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be in touch.‚Äù

I took off.

‚äô

There was something very human about the desire to gather around a fire. Power rationing meant every household had only a certain amount, more if there were more people in the house. Conversely, there was a lot of cheap firewood. Streetlights flickered on, and many house lights went off. In back yards there were three other families on the city block that were gathering around fire pits. Two of the families were playing different kinds of music, but it wasn‚Äôt too discordant. There were trees in each yard, front and back, and that helped to dampen the sound.

The entire street smelled like burning charcoal, and the light from the streetlights was just a little bit hazy with the ambient smoke.

It was a nice neighborhood, even if it had what I felt was the artificial quality. Houses with character, sufficiently different from one another in style and architecture, but still so new that they looked more like movie sets than lived-in places. Time and clutter would wear at those crisp edges. Paint and attention would turn fences of new wood with the occasional edge still frayed from the saw‚Äôs touch into something more personal.

This was the flip side to the hostility and the street-wide gap between protester and community center. Boyfriend and girlfriend sat on an outdoor love seat together, arms around each other, bathed in fire‚Äôs warmth. Friends sat and talked, beers in hand. Kids in another yard played with their dog.

With the path I‚Äôd taken, I reached the backyard first. The driveway was wider than it was long, crushed gravel, with room for multiple vehicles, and a fence stretched from the house at one corner to the garage at the other. My mom had invited neighbors, so it was a thing, even if things had reached a more relaxed point.

My dad sat on one of the lawn chairs, fire pit in front of him with the fire having burned down to just glowing coals. The barbecue was to his right, lid open, tiny bits of meat clinging to the grill.

He was forty-two but looked younger. The fact that he was as fit as he was played into it— only the white in his beard stubble really gave it away. His hair, too, was short. He was the only one who hadn‚Äôt put a sweatshirt or jacket on, owing to the proximity of the two heat sources— he was wearing a t-shirt that was form-fitting in a way that showed off his muscles. Pretty darn gross, given he was a dad, my dad, and he was supposed to dress his age. I would have insisted on clothes that hid any sign of muscle at all, really, had I been given a say.

He looked relaxed though. As relaxed as I‚Äôd seen him in a while, really, and I‚Äôd seen him passed out on the couch back at the apartment.

I was aware that my mom had seated herself so that two neighbors sat between her and my dad. Where my dad had dressed in a t-shirt and sports pants for the occasion, she had dressed up. Just a bit of lipstick, her hair short and styled, a ruffly sort of white blouse and pencil skirt. She‚Äôd kicked off her shoes earlier in the evening, leaving them beneath her chair.

I was aware of the distinction in how they‚Äôd dressed, too. In another time, before everything, there would have been more‚Ä¶ connection, I supposed. Each influencing the other, until they matched more.

She was smiling. She folded one knee over the other, then a moment later was undoing the position, both feet on the porch again as she leaned forward, laughing at something someone had said.

I smiled.

The lights were on inside the house, too. The door was open, and people were scattered through the space between the stairs down to the porch, the back hallway, and the kitchen on the other side of the hallway. The room to the left of the hallway was dark. The neighbors kids, I presumed, teens to twenty-somethings. I saw a glimpse of Crystal stepping into the unlit room, tried to catch her eye with a raised hand as she looked toward the window, and failed.

I did get the attention of someone sitting next to my mom, though. She touched my mom‚Äôs arm and pointed.

I remained where I was, arms folded on the top of the wooden-slat fence, chin on my hands, while my mom approached.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre hurt,‚Äù she said, touching my arm, where the road rash was.

‚ÄúScuffed up.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid you get the other guy?‚Äù she asked. She reached out and touched my hair, fixing it by moving strands to one side.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúBut there were five of them.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you want to talk about it? I‚Äôm interested.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot really,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúToday—‚Äù

My breath caught.

‚Äú—Kind of not a good day,‚Äù I said.

I saw her expression change, even though the light source was behind her.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt tell me you didn‚Äôt save me the dessert you promised. Looking forward to that is pretty much the only thing keeping me going right now.‚Äù

She smiled, touching my cheek, before kissing me on the forehead. ‚ÄúI saved you dessert with extras to take home, in case you want pie or pastries for breakfast tomorrow.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve done your duty then,‚Äù I said, with mock seriousness.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been a long time since I‚Äôve failed a mission,‚Äù she said, in the same tone. She put her hand on the side of my head. ‚ÄúYou missed Uncle Mike, I‚Äôm afraid.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh shoot,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI barely remember him. How is he?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs Uncle Mike. He brought his wife and your cousins, and I haven‚Äôt child-proofed at all. It was‚Ä¶ something, in the brief time he was here. A whirlwind of chaos and emotion, and then he was gone.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh, too bad,‚Äù I said.

In the background, my dad was trying to get my attention. He‚Äôd sat up, and didn‚Äôt look relaxed anymore. He offered me a small smile. I acknowledged him by lifting one hand up from where it sat on my elbow, in a mini-wave.

‚ÄúThank you for coming,‚Äù my mom said. ‚ÄúI know the family stuff is hard, after everything, but it means so much to me. To everyone.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm here for the desserts,‚Äù I said. I amended it to, ‚Äú‚Ä¶and a bit for family.‚Äù

My mom lightly rapped me on the side of the head before stepping away. ‚ÄúCome on in, then. Meet people, I‚Äôll get your pie.‚Äù

As she stepped over to the gate by the garage to unlock it, Crystal stepped out into the backyard, joined by a few others in our age group. She glanced in my direction, saw me, and froze like a deer in the headlights.

Her arms folded, defensive, like something was wrong.

She mouthed words at me, and I couldn‚Äôt see her face well enough at a distance to know what the words were, but I could draw conclusions from context.

My dad‚Äôs posture, still sitting upright now, both feet planted on the ground.

My mom‚Äôs earlier change in expression. Even the wording—

I backed away from the fence a few steps. My mom froze, the gate only slightly open.

‚ÄúYou invited her,‚Äù I said. I wasn‚Äôt talking about Crystal.

In reaction to that, my mother didn‚Äôt look confused, she didn‚Äôt negate. She looked toward the house, to see what I‚Äôd seen that had clued me in.

Whirlwind of fucking chaos and emotion indeed.

‚ÄúYou invited her,‚Äù I said, again. More emotional this time. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs in the house?‚Äù

My mother rallied, composing herself. Now she looked confused. ‚ÄúI told you I invited everyone.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs actually in the house,‚Äù I said.

I backed away again, and my mother threw the gate open, taking several steps on the driveway, stepping on crushed gravel with bare feet.

I raised my hand, indicating for her to stop. She continued forward.

I threw my aura out, one push.

My mother stopped. Crystal stopped in her tracks, already at the fence. People rose from their seats.

‚ÄúI thought you knew,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI very clearly said everyone. It was supposed to be a family reunion with everyone getting together again for the first time in‚Ä¶ in a really long time.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a lawyer,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre too clever with wording to be that fucking stupid.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù she said, with a tone like she was the one who needed to exercise patience and restraint here. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs keep things civil.‚Äù

I couldn‚Äôt even look at her. I trembled as my eyes dropped to the ground.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve made mistakes, as your sister has,‚Äù my mother said. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs been doing so well. I want to make up for past wrongs and be a mother to both of you, like I should have been from the beginning.‚Äù

I looked up, staring at her.

The lipstick, the composed outfit, the words, the everything about this all seemed so false now, so forced. I didn‚Äôt even recognize her.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre kind of fucking it up,‚Äù I said, in the kind of whisper that was the only tone I could manage that wasn‚Äôt outright screaming at her. My hands were clenched at their sides.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not fair.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre kind of really fucking it up,‚Äù I said, in the same strangled whisper.

‚ÄúVictoria—‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre fucking it up, mother,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre fucking— you‚Äôre fucking— did dad play along with this?‚Äù

‚ÄúI told him everyone was coming. You, your sister, Crystal, Uncle Mike. He was surprised, but‚Ä¶ pleasantly surprised.‚Äù

Dad too, then. There was that heart-wrenched-out feeling again. I screwed my eyes shut, inadvertently squeezing out tears. I was aware her neighbors were seeing.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt— don‚Äôt get emotional, Victoria,‚Äù my mom said. ‚ÄúPlease, I didn‚Äôt do this to hurt you. The furthest thing from it.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou fucked that up too,‚Äù I whispered.

‚ÄúStop saying that. Please,‚Äù my mother said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the age of second chances, she‚Äôs worked very hard to get to this point. I‚Äôve talked to people who worked with her and she‚Äôs getting back into her routine in a good way. I want all of us to have a second shot at this, and do it right this time.‚Äù

I shook my head.

‚ÄúLeaving things as unresolved as they are is doing more harm than good. To both you and to her.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo you thought you‚Äôd invite me to dinner and surprise me with her, and you thought there was nothing I could say or do because people are here?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre putting thoughts and conspiracy in my head,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI want you to be sisters again. I want us to be a family again.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not for you to decide,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúHoly shit. Holy shit. Holy shit.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease, don‚Äôt wind yourself up. You‚Äôre getting out of breath. Let‚Äôs communicate. Please.‚Äù

I was getting out of breath. I gulped in a breath of air. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre aware I can‚Äôt set foot in that house again, right? I‚Äôll see her looming in the shadows, potentially another surprise invite.‚Äù

‚ÄúI want you to find reconciliation, so you wouldn‚Äôt feel upset even if she did appear by surprise.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt accept any invites from you,‚Äù I said. My face started to contort, and I forced it back into something more normal before I lost the ability to see my mother or focus on her altogether. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt grab dessert from you or do anything with you again because she might be there, surprise. I can‚Äôt trust you. How can I trust you again?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry you feel that way. I did not realize that was where things stood. You‚Äôve been doing so well, and she‚Äôs been doing well.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow—‚Äù I started. I gulped in another breath of air. My voice was a whisper again when I managed to speak again. ‚ÄúHow do you not realize when you saw me at the hospital? How do you even think rec— how do you think this is ever possible? How does—‚Äù

I closed my eyes. More tears.

‚ÄúHow does Dad? How could you see me then, how could you— how— how—‚Äù

My chest hurt.

‚ÄúCrystal—‚Äù I said, I looked toward the house.

Crystal was still on the porch. Standing guard by the back door, red shield up. She watched me talking with my mom over one shoulder.

‚ÄúI told Crystal the same thing I told your father. She was skeptical but she agreed it was for the best.‚Äù

I didn‚Äôt trust my mom‚Äôs version of events on that. Crystal at least had my back in this moment.

I tried to find words, and I didn‚Äôt have the oxygen.

‚ÄúCatch your breath. We can talk this out.‚Äù

I worked at it, swallowing air.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll wait,‚Äù she said.

The sound of her voice made it harder, not easier.

When I spoke, my voice was very small. It gained more strength as I went.

‚ÄúHow can you have not been there, missed visits, or come to the visit and spend more time talking to doctors than to me because it was hard to be around me? How can you have come to see me then, and have had to avert your eyes mid-conversation with me, and found that hard, and not realize that I had to live it for two years, and had that be a million times harder for me?‚Äù

‚ÄúI know it was hard, honey. I get it, I really do. But you can‚Äôt dwell in the past. It‚Äôs not good for you. You can‚Äôt carry that.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou say that, when you still sleep with the lights on,‚Äù I said.

It was her turn to not have words.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs different,‚Äù she said, finally. She didn‚Äôt say how it was different.

I stared at her.

‚ÄúI want all of us to conquer our demons,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI think you want that too.‚Äù

I continued to stare.

Finally, I said, ‚ÄúI want that too.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe can talk this out. We can find things we all want,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe can make inroads on this.‚Äù

She looked nearly as upset as I felt, even as composed as she was.

But in the end, and I‚Äôd known this from very early on, seeing her with— with her, she wasn‚Äôt a whole and complete person. She tried, she put on a good face, but my mother had been broken long, long ago, and with the way she‚Äôd put herself together, she retained only sufficient compassion, understanding, and empathy for a very small number of people. For one daughter, at most.

Second chances. Second go-around, and I wasn‚Äôt that daughter, this time.

‚ÄúIn the interest of putting my demons to rest,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to keep my distance. Don‚Äôt call, because I can‚Äôt trust a thing you say. I‚Äôll figure out what I‚Äôll do about Dad later.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúNothing gets better if you close off communication.‚Äù

There were things I wanted to say to that.

It wasn‚Äôt worth it.

I turned to go.

I heard the gravel under her feet as she gave chase, and I pushed out with my aura, hard.

‚ÄúDo not use your power on me, Victoria Dallon. That has never been okay, and it doesn‚Äôt work anyway.‚Äù

I drew in a deep breath. There were things I wanted to say to that, too.

I settled for, ‚ÄúLet me go. If you follow me, I‚Äôm liable to hit you with something harder than my aura. I‚Äôm pretty sure that would work.‚Äù

It might have been a good line, if I hadn‚Äôt been choking back emotion as I said it.

I walked away. I didn‚Äôt trust myself to fly when I couldn‚Äôt see straight. Having a panic attack in the air made for an embarrassing moment.

People stood in rows at the fences that bounded their yards, staring and watching. I wiped away my tears once, then resolved not to shed more, not where people could see. I set my jaw.

In the background, I could hear my father‚Äôs raised voice.

Breathe. Center yourself. Move forward. Plan.

I thought about what I‚Äôd need to do next. I couldn‚Äôt go back to the apartment I shared with my dad.

For the time being, I only walked, out in the general direction of the water. Streetlights lit up in advance of imminent cars and as I stepped onto the streets, turning off otherwise. Here and there they would turn on for wildlife, illuminating a lost deer or raccoon mid-scurry down the road. We‚Äôd set ourselves up so abruptly that the animals were still confused.

It was getting cooler. I wore my skirt, my clothes from earlier. My forcefield shielded against the wind, which kept it from lowering the temperature even further, but it didn‚Äôt do a lot to shield me from the ambient heat or lack thereof.

I tensed as I heard running footsteps behind me. I stopped in my tracks.

Not Crystal. She would have flown, and she would have set down well in front of me. She wouldn‚Äôt have chased, maybe.

Her, then.

I didn‚Äôt want to look. I didn‚Äôt want to speak to her.

I pushed out with my aura, instead.

Another footstep, closer.

Our mother‚Äôs daughter.

I threw my arm back and to the side, a backhand swipe. I tore through lawn, through slabs of sidewalk, and the edge of the road. Dirt flew across the street alongside clumps of grass and chunks of sidewalk.

A long pause, and then I heard the footsteps again, running. This time the other way.

‚äô

Gilpatrick jumped as I appeared in the doorway of his office, nearly knocking over a paper container of noodles in red sauce that rested on a stack of paper. Paperwork I would have been helping him with, had the day gone differently.

‚ÄúVictoria? What‚Äôs wrong?‚Äù he asked.

So it was that obvious something was wrong.

‚ÄúI need to call in a favor,‚Äù I said.

Okay, hearing my voice, I could get why he‚Äôd known. I sounded like another person entirely.

‚ÄúIf it‚Äôs okay,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúOf course it‚Äôs okay,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs wrong? Are you cold? The temperature dropped steeply tonight. What can I get you? Sit.‚Äù

He stood, circling around his desk. I backed away a little as he did, which was his cue to stop.

I wasn‚Äôt sure how to respond, how to ask.

‚ÄúBy the way,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAs far as I‚Äôm concerned, there‚Äôs no need to count. I consider you a friend, and I feel like a piece of shit for setting you up to fail like that.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI just need a place to stay tonight. While I figure some things out. I‚Äôll be gone before the students arrive first thing.‚Äù

I noted the hesitation before he responded.

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúYou paused.‚Äù

‚ÄúOnly because it‚Äôs not really a great place for staying overnight. You could come to my apartment, but that‚Äôs—‚Äù

‚ÄúI kind of want space to think,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúOffer‚Äôs appreciated.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs an issue with power rations and temperature is supposed to drop a few more degrees, and this place isn‚Äôt insulated well. It was a bitch last winter.‚Äù

‚ÄúI remember,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù Gilpatrick said.

He kept giving me very deeply concerned looks. Almost pity.

I really hated those. I‚Äôd had a lifetime‚Äôs fill and then some.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got a space heater right by my desk here. You‚Äôll want to be careful if you‚Äôre leaving it running for a while, fire hazard.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll be careful,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThere are blankets we stowed in the locker rooms that you can use if you want to sleep. You could get something serviceable if you gather a bunch. I laundered them not too long ago, too.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know where to find them.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere are candles too, in case the power runs out. But again, fire hazard.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be careful.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúYou sure you don‚Äôt want company? We can talk it out, if you haven‚Äôt eaten I can go grab something, or‚Ä¶‚Äù

I was already shaking my head.

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI was needing an excuse to go home, this will do. Unless maybe I should stay around? You could settle in upstairs, and I‚Äôll be all the way down here, you can have your space to think and you can still have me to talk to in case you decide you need it.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt let me keep you. Go home. You‚Äôll have angry parents to talk to first thing tomorrow, once they‚Äôve figured out what happened and had time to get angry.‚Äù

He frowned. ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI know where everything is.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúYou sure you‚Äôre okay? You‚Äôre not going to‚Ä¶‚Äù

He trailed off.

‚ÄúIf I was going to do anything, I‚Äôd take someone out with me.‚Äù

He scrutinized me.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm worried here, for the record,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll manage,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve managed this far.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou have my number,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou call if you need anything.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you‚Ä¶ be here in the morning when I show up. Which will be well before the kids do.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he said.

He gathered up his paper container, a stack of his papers. He was trying to pick up the remainder when I approached, picking it up myself.

Silent, I walked him to his car, handing over the papers when it was time. I walked inside and locked the door behind me. The place was big and it was dark, with the open gymnasium space unlit.

I carted the space heater upstairs, and then I got the blankets. I got the candles and the matches, and then I found the file boxes, collapsed and gathered in piles.

I situated myself in my office, which wasn‚Äôt technically my office anymore, and I set to making the boxes, pulling my things off the shelves, and getting them stowed away.

The space heater hummed and the computer monitor clicked, as I periodically checked something or followed up on something I‚Äôd seen on a file.

I made a stack of the things I wanted to read, the files that intrigued or that I‚Äôd forgotten about, the magazines I liked. I was a third of the way through my shelves, twelve boxes filled, when I finally settled down in my chair, pulling blankets over me, and started to read.

I got about two pages read before deciding I didn‚Äôt have it in me to read more.

I didn‚Äôt have it in me to sit still, when my anxieties were churning.

I stood, dropping blankets on the floor, and walked over to the window. With the cold, the space heater, and the imperfect seal, moisture and fog had collected on it.

I reached out toward the window, a foot away from touching it. I turned on my forcefield.

A pause.

Then a handprint on the window, in the condensation. Then another.

A circular smudge that streaked, a naked breast pressed against the glass, moving.

Then the mark that couldn‚Äôt be anything but one half of a face, beneath the circular smudge.

They moved, and I wasn‚Äôt asking them to move. The window rattled a bit as it was pushed against. The prints smudged.

A fingernail dragged against the glass, and produced a high pitched squeal, almost ear-splitting.

I dropped the forcefield. I sank back into my seat, and it protested the landing.

Not a second trigger. I was well aware of that. When I‚Äôd first had my forcefield, it hadn‚Äôt protected my costume. I had two theories as to why.

The first theory was that I‚Äôd grown, and the boundaries that the forcefield used to define ‚Äòme‚Äô had changed. I‚Äôd breathe out, breathe in, gain a pound here, lose a pound there, and it would adjust for the maximum bounds. It didn‚Äôt explain how my skirt was often protected, but I‚Äôd mused on that too, that my legs moved, my hair had been long at one point, I‚Äôd been shorter‚Ä¶

I‚Äôd been that, the forcefield had adjusted, and that was the new upper bound of what I was, forever with me.

It felt thin, as theories went.

The second theory was that it was the Manton effect, that broad-as-bells term for the built in protections and limitations of the power. The theory was that the built-in protections of the power only protected what I saw as a part of me, and it had taken some time before the costume was that much a part of my identity.

That that was me, now, as much as the costume I wore.

I couldn‚Äôt be that. I couldn‚Äôt sit still and be crushed under the weight of that thing.

I needed to do something, and taking books off the shelves felt like it was moving backward, not forward.

I spun around in my seat, and I loaded up the webpage. Something to do. Methodically filling out details on the group I‚Äôd seen, researching, filling myself in, and letting others know what they were up against.

Something constructive to keep me occupied until the power ran out, or until I was so tired I had no choice but to sleep.

Daybreak — 1.8

Daylight streamed in at a low angle as I stepped back into my office. The light was blurred as it came through the condensation on the window, spotted with dots of darkness due to the melted frost that still clung to the window‚Äôs surface in lines and constellations of droplets. Ninety percent of my books were packed up, the boxes that were still here were stacked near the door and the bookshelf, labeled in thick marker, with shorthand notes on the most interesting and essential files within written on the boxes in pen. I‚Äôd left a few of the more interesting files available. I‚Äôd put them in a box on their own, in case I needed something to read.

My phone was plugged into the computer. I checked it, and made a small and sleepy pump of my fist as it lit up. Then I saw the red number on the digital-display dial, and let my hand drop. Missed messages: too many.

It wasn‚Äôt that I cared that much about the phone. It was that the phone being on meant there was power again. That the power was on again meant I could turn the space heater on. I flicked the switch, turned on my computer, then lit the candles for what little good heat they offered and wrapped a blanket around me before settling in my computer chair.

I was freshly showered, towel around my hair, and I‚Äôd gotten dressed in a slightly musty spare change of clothes. I had a blanket, candles, and a computer booting up. I watched as it started the struggle of fighting every other computer out there that was wanting a piece of the web.

There were worse ways to take things easy on myself.

I slid my to-do list across the desk until it was beside my keyboard. I‚Äôd need a car. Plenty of people were willing to offer the use of theirs in order to pay for fuel. Food, a place to stay.

Living accommodations might be tricky. Demand was high, and it was a pretty steep drop in quality from the central areas and the fringes. Many companies were putting up five or more houses a day or an apartment complex over the course of a week, slapping them together like there was a gun to their heads. When it came time to find renters, they were more interested in filling the spaces fast. They had no reason to answer questions or have a potential buyer investigating the nooks and crannies or checking the plumbing if they could turn that person away and have someone else on their doorstep within minutes.

It was a minefield. Word of mouth, cash, contacts, or luck were required to get a proper house that wouldn‚Äôt start falling apart after the fact. Fume Hood was one of the ones who‚Äôd been unlucky.

In more than one way.

My homepage was parahumans online, though. On top of the missed calls and messages on my phone, I had a slew on the site.

‚ô¶ Unread Private Messages from NW_Brandish (2)
‚ô¶ Unread Private Messages from Glitzglam (8)

I deleted the messages from my mother.

I opened the second link.

‚ô¶ Private Messages from Glitzglam:

Point_Me_@_The_Sky: Staying the night at work. Don‚Äôt fuss about me. Tell the Dallon parental units if you think it‚Äôs necessary to keep them from going on warpath. I want to be left alone for now

Glitzglam *New Message*: i can field them
Glitzglam *New Message*: I‚Äôm *so* sorry that happened i want to explain
Glitzglam *New Message*: I arrived and then Amy did and my eyes must have bugged out of my skull but your mom said it was okay we were trying this and you knew it was a reunion and I was wtf
Glitzglam *New Message*: It didn‚Äôt sound like you but I thought ok if you thought you were down I could roll with and back you up
Glitzglam *New Message*: Then Uncle M came and oh man if a man could shit crocodiles and piss bears Uncle M would have been doing that he was so fucking pissed b/c HE wasn‚Äôt told and he knew the story from the funerals right?
Glitzglam *New Message*: and he brought his wife/kids there
Glitzglam *New Message*: I knew something was up and tried to call but no answer? & then you didn‚Äôt show so I let my guard down. I thought u knew and had cold feet and was relieved
Glitzglam *New Message*: I am so sorry. I had no part in this. I should have been smarter. I did not know really truly

I marked it as unread and minimized it. I didn‚Äôt want to think about it for the moment.

News. Inquiry into the circumstances of Lachlan Hund. Not a trial, but an inquiry, some questions by people with more official standing. He‚Äôd fallen in with some sketchy people, and there were thoughts about there being powers involved.

The inquiry was the story of the hour, it seemed. Heroes stood by to step in and take him away to get help if officials were suspicious he‚Äôd been manipulated, but it was sounding like he would go home with his new family. That sucked.

Other articles, further down the pages. Fume Hood was alive, and she was a contentious topic. The actions on the part of the shooter seemed to have split people into two factions, with the ones supporting Fume Hood slightly edging out the ones who condemned her. Strange to see.

I wanted more info on her situation, and unfortunately, that was all I got.

I added another note to my to-do list. I‚Äôd reach out to Fume Hood, check in. I‚Äôd satisfy my curiosity and nag her about the name choice, which I‚Äôd been meaning to do but hadn‚Äôt had the chance to.

My eye traveled up to the unread messages. Crystal‚Äôs responses.

It all felt like I was taking a massive backward step. Like I was back in the immediate aftermath of Gold Morning. Two legs, two arms, bewildered, emotional. I was bothered, upset. I didn‚Äôt know what to do with myself.

I‚Äôd been angry at my parents then too. For various reasons. Angry at a lot of people and things.

I hadn‚Äôt and didn‚Äôt want that to define me.

I clicked on Crystal‚Äôs account name again.

Glitzglam *New Message*: I am so sorry. I had no part in this. I should have been smarter. I did not know really truly

Point_Me_@_The_Sky: S‚Äôokay.
Point_Me_@_The_Sky: I know how these things go.
Point_Me_@_The_Sky: I saw this sort of thing play out when it wasn‚Äôt aimed at me. I can read between the lines and speak Carol-ese and I picked up on what she was saying about you being skeptical about the situation
Point_Me_@_The_Sky: I absolve you on the condition of one get together where we have some good eating, your treat, and you need to let me know if you hear of any good apartments or things because I am not good going back to my dads

I drummed my fingers on my desk, mused that my motivations might have to do with my being hungry.

More news articles. Some capes were taking on roles as icons and iconoclasts for the various movements in the civilian sectors. Four hero teams led the ‚Äòicon‚Äô groups. Advance Guard, Foresight, the Shepherds and the Attendant.

The first two were aimed at pushing forward. New approaches, doing things right this time. The opinions on what that way forward looked like it differed, feeding into the division between the two groups.

Things were changing. The Shepherds and Attendant had been groups divided along similar lines, but the Shepherds were self-combusting, and the remaining members were folding into the Attendant. There was some debate over what the name of the resulting team would be.

And then there were three, I thought.

I idly browsed, caught between liking the Shepherd‚Äôs aesthetic and icons better while liking the Attendant‚Äôs mindset of moving slowly, with caution. I was suspicious it might end up being the opposite. As it was, the Attendant‚Äôs approach tacked on a bit too much ‚Äòremember what we lost‚Äô for my liking, clinging to the past, being defined by it, but—

There was a knock on the door.

‚ÄúCome in,‚Äù I said.

Gil opened the door. He had two coffees in a tray in one hand and a bag in the other, and he had to juggle them both as he opened the door.

I rose to my feet.

‚ÄúSit,‚Äù he said. He nearly dropped his drink as he saw the boxes. ‚ÄúShit on me, you‚Äôre packed.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll be done in time to be gone before the students turn up,‚Äù I said, sitting.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not so concerned about that right now,‚Äù he said. He put the bag and coffees on the desk. ‚ÄúHow are you?‚Äù

I shrugged.

‚ÄúYou look better.‚Äù

I had a headache from not sleeping and not eating, and from the post-stress hangover, but I also felt lighter than air in a euphoric, fragile way. It was as if I‚Äôd just gotten over a bad round of the flu, and I was at the point where I was getting over the worst of it, but if I did the wrong thing or tested my body in the wrong way I‚Äôd be sick and hurting again.

Better.

I shrugged again. ‚ÄúYeah. That word could apply.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid you sleep at all?‚Äù

I snorted air out of my nose. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll sleep when I‚Äôm so tired I have no other choice.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut you‚Äôre feeling better than you were?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah. Better than I was. Thanks for letting me stay over,‚Äù I said.

He pulled a breakfast burger out of the paper bag, and my eyes must have lit up, because he smiled, passing it to me.

A double-decker English muffin, with bacon, two eggs, lettuce, tomato and very sharp mustard.

I wasn‚Äôt normally one to eat egg, but I didn‚Äôt let that stop me.

I‚Äôd taken too big of a bite. I swallowed hard.

It was good. Visceral. Like Snag‚Äôs power, the hit of emotion as I enjoyed it was like a bit of metal, closing an electrical connection. Rounding off a thought I hadn‚Äôt wanted to make.

Feeding tubes. The insertions, the removals. The tube being there, one eye watching the beige fluid moving through steadily. Really wanting something good. Going almost four months without, because they weren‚Äôt sure I could. Then having it be a chore. It had been better than the alternative, but a chore, to force myself to eat it right, to chew it thoroughly enough.

I swallowed hard again, not because I had another bite to swallow.

Gilpatrick was looking at my files and notes, his back to me, my English muffin sandwich in my hands.

He glanced at me, saw the blinking, and looked away. ‚ÄúIf you want to talk, I‚Äôm all ears.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt, thank you,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI had a bad day, the part you knew about, then it got worse. Now I‚Äôm trying to get centered.‚Äù

He nodded.

‚ÄúThis is really good,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThey are, I took a bite of mine in the car and then ate it before I got here,‚Äù he said. He bent over a box, looking at the notes. ‚ÄúMan, I wish I still had access to these files and books. I‚Äôd try bribing you if I could do it in good conscience.‚Äù

I swallowed again. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre mine and I‚Äôm too straightlaced to be bribed. You can call me if you want to ask about any of it.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen I owe you more favors, am I right?‚Äù

‚ÄúI thought we weren‚Äôt counting anymore,‚Äù I said.

He didn‚Äôt respond to that. He picked up a file, paging through it.

‚ÄúWhich one is that?‚Äù

‚ÄúOssuary. Why leave it out?‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre back, or they will be soon,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúActivist villains with a heavy focus on environment. They wouldn‚Äôt call themselves villains, I don‚Äôt think. Long list of really messy executions, longer list of leaders with very short tenures, who try to pull a very disparate group together, fail, and abdicate.‚Äù

‚ÄúWere they the ones who used to call themselves Elephant Graveyard?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the one. One of the early leaders pushed the name change along with a shift away from focusing on animals and animal welfare,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI liked Elephant Graveyard more, I think. Clunky, but clunky in a way that stands out, and it made for really good imagery, when they left a spray painted calling card.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to pry,‚Äù Gilpatrick said.

‚ÄúAbout Ossuary?‚Äù

‚ÄúAbout you. I spent a while thinking about what to do. I‚Äôve had some good bosses and bad bosses over the years. When you throw yourself into the fray like you do when you‚Äôre a PRT squaddie, you really need to know that the people above you are looking out for you. That your back is covered.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. Same applied to family, to parents.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to push boundaries or cross any lines, and I don‚Äôt want to ask the wrong thing. When you say you don‚Äôt want to talk, can I ask why? Any answer you gave could help me make sure I‚Äôm covering your back as you move on to better things.‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause I‚Äôd have to fill you in on years of background and that‚Äôs not stuff I want to relive,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúAh.‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause it‚Äôs confidential, because it‚Äôs messy, because‚Ä¶ as cool as a guy as you can be, you can‚Äôt make it better. You can‚Äôt give me the answers or guidance I need because there‚Äôs a whole ream of things that‚Äôs separate and aside from the years of my background that you‚Äôd need to get into or know and‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm going overboard with this.‚Äù

‚ÄúI do want to hear,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnything else?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs mostly it,‚Äù I said.

He nodded. He rubbed his head for a second, thinking. ‚ÄúYou want company?‚Äù

‚ÄúNah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd just be packing the last few boxes. I wouldn‚Äôt mind a hand getting them out to the car, just to speed things up when the time comes.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou have a car?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll get someone off of a listing or something. I‚Äôve got to figure out what I‚Äôm doing, so there‚Äôs that too. I wouldn‚Äôt be good company, while I‚Äôm working through all of that.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to be packed up and gone today,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúI kind of need to,‚Äù I said.

He nodded, rubbing his head again. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll cover the car. I‚Äôll pay the driver.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYou know where to find me. Place is empty, so you can shout from the stairs and I‚Äôll hear you.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to head to my office. I‚Äôve got something to do.‚Äù

I gave him a little salute.

Energized by food and coffee, still feeling lightweight, I worked on getting my boxes packed up. Along the way, I slotted my files and folders into the box I‚Äôd reserved for the most pertinent factors. The villains of the area, the heroes, and the villains turned hero. The hoods.

The day was warming up. The light from the sun was warm enough to counteract the lower temperature. By midday, if yesterday was any indication, it would be short-sleeves and shorts weather again.

A message popped up on my screen.

‚ô¶ Private Messages from Glitzglam:

Glitzglam: game plan. u situate yourself at my place until you have apartment ur happy with. u & I raid ur dads place while he at work, get ur stuff. standard attack formation, I play defense, make sure coast is clear, I support you, u take point and do what u need

I fired off my response. That worked. I had a couch to sleep on.

One thing off of my to-do list. I liked the progress. Progress was good. So long as I moved forward, I could stay aloft.

I cleared off the remainder of the bookshelves, stacking the boxes. I scribbled out my notes on the lid, checking the contents.

There was a knock at the door.

‚ÄúCome in,‚Äù I said.

Gilpatrick.

‚ÄúTime for me to go?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúNah,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a bit. I don‚Äôt want to force you out the door like that.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said. I raised an eyebrow.

‚ÄúI was thinking, over the past twelve hours, if you were my student, I wouldn‚Äôt want to let you go with things like this. Normally I‚Äôd contact a guardian.‚Äù

My heart skipped a beat at that. No.

‚ÄúBut you said last night you had a family thing to do. I can connect dots.‚Äù

I nodded.

‚ÄúI made some phone calls,‚Äù he said.

He stepped out of the doorway.

Mrs. Yamada. Shorter than me, hair tied back in a simple ponytail, wearing a skirt, white top, and jacket, with a simple, short string of pearls at her collarbone.

‚ÄúOh wow,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúLook at you.‚Äù

I didn‚Äôt have words, so I just lifted my arms to either side and let them fall.

‚ÄúIs this okay?‚Äù Gilpatrick asked.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. I swallowed. ‚ÄúYeah. Just about perfect.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll leave you to it,‚Äù he said.

Jessica blinked a few times, before fanning herself. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a little misty eyed. Sorry.‚Äù

I was a little misty eyed myself.

‚ÄúCan I give you a hug?‚Äù she asked. When I nodded, she did so. I hugged her back.

‚ÄúYou put me down as your emergency contact?‚Äù she asked.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI— I honestly forgot I did that. It was more than a year ago.‚Äù

I‚Äôd had to name someone, and I hadn‚Äôt named my parents because—

Because.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs more than alright,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúYour boss said he was worried about you.‚Äù

I opened my mouth to reply, and then the waterworks started instead.

‚äô

Jessica slammed the back hatch of her car, most of the boxes settled inside.

‚ÄúDo you want to walk?‚Äù she asked. ‚ÄúAround the block, maybe? Or we could step back inside.‚Äù

If I was going to start crying again.

Students were just now starting to appear, and I didn‚Äôt want to sit still.

‚ÄúWe can walk,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been amazing to hear your voice,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI know you were often frustrated, trying to communicate with the means you had available. I was frustrated too, but I wasn‚Äôt allowed to say that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI could tell,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYou were a challenging patient, those first few months—‚Äù

I snorted.

‚Äú—but much like many teachers say they grow to care most about the class clowns and problem students, I came to hold you close to my heart. I wanted so badly to give you answers and to hear you out without having to rely on text to speech and letters you wrote between appointments. I wanted to dialogue, and it was so very hard to do that.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was,‚Äù I said.

Why was it so much easier to talk about the things that I couldn‚Äôt normally even think about, like this?

‚ÄúHow did you find your way back from that?‚Äù

How did I become Victoria again, instead of the wretched thing in the hospital room, or in the home for invalids?

‚ÄúMy sister,‚Äù I said, my voice soft.

‚ÄúOh. That‚Äôs not an easy thing,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù I said, my voice even softer.

I‚Äôd already filled her in on the details of yesterday and the past few months. She‚Äôd offered a listening ear. I‚Äôd spent all night working out my next few steps, I knew what the situation was, I didn‚Äôt really need more angles to view it from.

This, though‚Ä¶ if I was going to make the most of the time I had with her here, then I wanted to at least get a handle on this.

‚ÄúWe were all brought to the battlefield during Gold Morning. There‚Äôs‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs a hard topic to field.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs an unspoken agreement that the civilians don‚Äôt get to know,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúBut you‚Äôre not really a civilian,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve heard reports. Some from very close to the center of the action. I know what happened.‚Äù

‚ÄúBody, mind, and heart, you know how that‚Äôs a thing?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúI lost my body, two years before Gold Morning. My heart was‚Ä¶ twisted into something unrecognizable.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd‚Ä¶ Gold Morning hit. And the—‚Äù I paused. There were people on the street, walking toward the school gate and the various block buildings as we walked away from it all. A tide we walked against. I had to shut up until people were mostly out of earshot. ‚ÄúAnd I was controlled in mind. I didn‚Äôt have much, but I could make my decisions. I could decide to use my power or not. She took that away from me, for a brief time.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve talked to a number of people who had a very hard time with that.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou know who she was?‚Äù

‚ÄúI do.‚Äù

I nodded to myself.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúMy sister told me.‚Äù

Even if I was free to talk, the words still carried their ugly weight. The words and associated mental pictures still dragged my mood down.

‚ÄúShe knew me or knew of me, or she knew my sister. She decided in the end that she‚Äôd put my sister right next to me. She didn‚Äôt do that for many people at all, as far as I can tell.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd your sister healed you?‚Äù

‚ÄúGave me a body again. Um. She made me seventeen again. Walked back the clock, as if it‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt know. So she didn‚Äôt take two years of my life from me in body, like she did in everything else. I‚Äôm physically nineteen now, apparently.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou said body, mind and spirit. She fixed one of the three. Did she undo the effect on your emotions?‚Äù

I drew in a breath, sighed heavily. I nodded. ‚ÄúShe actually— she turned off my emotions. Suppressed them. Then she asked me what I wanted.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat did you want?‚Äù

‚ÄúI remember thinking, you know, it was really possible she wanted me to say that I wanted to go back to liking her. And if she did think that, then it was unconscionable. Divorced from all emotion, I thought it was unconscionable.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd divorced from all emotion, I thought I‚Äôd be fair. That I‚Äôd give her the benefit of a doubt. That I‚Äôd assume that wasn‚Äôt what she meant or wanted. I told her I wanted to remember.‚Äù

‚ÄúTo remember?‚Äù

‚ÄúThose two years,‚Äù I said, my voice hollow. I drew in another deep breath.

Further down the street, a nine or ten year old boy with straight black hair and brown skin looked at Jessica, his eyes widening, then he looked at me. He raised his hand, extending it toward Jessica as they passed one another.

She gave him a high five, then pushed his head, sending him on his way, toward the school.

‚ÄúThey weren‚Äôt good years.‚Äù

‚ÄúRationally? Divorced from emotion? I knew. I can‚Äôt forgive her. Ever. I can‚Äôt forget what she did, or she might do it again. To someone else. To me. I told her to fix my feelings and leave my brain alone otherwise.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a heavy weight to carry,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúThose two years are really damn heavy,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúEverything else is. But I‚Äôve been holding on to that moment. I hate that I hold onto it, because she did it, but everything is tainted by her, so what can I do?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou hold onto it? How?‚Äù

‚ÄúBeing emotionless, putting those feelings away. My feelings and impulses got me into that whole mess in the first place. I hurt an awful lot of awful people, you know.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve talked about that. You wrote letters outlining your thoughts and how you wanted to apologize to some of those affected.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy entire life leading up to that basketball game, I wanted so horribly badly to be a hero, you know? It felt like I thought about it every ten minutes. My parents were heroes, my cousin was, my aunt and uncle were, and everything revolved around it. I wanted it all so badly it hurt, and I didn‚Äôt have it for years. Then that basketball game, and I wanted to have something where I was the hero, where I got to stand out. Because sometimes it felt like my parents didn‚Äôt see me.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs been a recurring idea. You talked about their missed visits.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey came a lot,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI know that. My dad more than my mom. But every missed visit was a horrible thing, and the little things mattered so much when I had nothing else. Um. And this basketball game, I know I‚Äôve talked about this before. But this one girl kicked my freaking ass. In my face, knocking me over, intercepting every pass, blocking every shot. She didn‚Äôt have any powers or anything, she was just‚Ä¶ good. Better.‚Äù

‚ÄúA lot of things came into focus in that moment.‚Äù

‚ÄúEvery time she or one of her teammates beat me, I could see the look of disappointment on my parent‚Äôs faces. In the other moments, they looked so bored. And it was boring, you know. No parent wants to go sit through amateurs doing badly at a high school sport.‚Äù

‚ÄúSome do.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnyway, she hit me hard, she said something about me being overrated, and it was the last straw. Realizing I stood so far from family, that I didn‚Äôt want to be there, but I had no other choice, my sternum was hurting where she‚Äôd driven her elbow into me. I got my powers.‚Äù

‚ÄúYears of wanting, leading up to that.‚Äù

She‚Äôd caught the thread I‚Äôd wanted to lay out. It helped. ‚ÄúAnd then just under three years as Victoria-slash-Glory-Girl. And then‚Ä¶ hospital.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhich was undeniably horrible.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt felt like my life had ended. No hope or help. All I had to cling to were those memories of the three years I was Glory Girl. I could look back, think about every fight, every encounter. The ones I was proud of. The ones I wasn‚Äôt. I had so much regret, replaying events out in my head. It started with me thinking about— that moment when it all went so wrong. When she messed with my emotions, then going backward.‚Äù

Emotions caught me. I made my expression a scowl, because I was worried what my face might do otherwise.

‚ÄúI was such a stupid fucking kid,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs allowed,‚Äù she said.

I shook my head. ‚ÄúNot when you‚Äôre as strong as I am.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you want to be emotionless? I don‚Äôt know if that‚Äôs healthy.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot emotionless. But‚Ä¶ smarter about it. The idea I keep coming back to is I want to be a warrior monk.‚Äù

‚ÄúA warrior monk?‚Äù

‚ÄúJust— centered when it counts, I guess?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy the warrior part? Do you envision yourself fighting?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt honestly know. It never occurred to me.‚Äù

Jessica smiled.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs next for Victoria Dallon?‚Äù she asked.

‚ÄúYou need to mock me, say Victoria Dallon, warrior monk,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI deserve it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIf everyone in costume could remain centered while doing what they do, it would make a world of difference. I think it‚Äôs good. I‚Äôd think about that more as you take your next steps.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know I want to move forward, because‚Ä¶ I dunno. I feel like I‚Äôm a shark that drowns if it stops moving, or a bird that drops out of the air like a stone if I‚Äôm not flying forward. I know I need to get some of the basics of life squared away. I‚Äôm okay for money for a couple of months, but I can‚Äôt stay on Crystal‚Äôs couch.‚Äù

‚ÄúIn my brief interactions with Crystal, I did like her,‚Äù Jessica said.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs great. But not great to live with long-term, I don‚Äôt think. You‚Äôd never know it to look at her, she‚Äôs beautiful, she‚Äôs fashionable, and very well put together, but if you looked at her apartment‚Ä¶‚Äù

I trailed off, using my expression to convey a bit of the horror to Jessica.

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Jessica said. She smiled again.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what to do next.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, I‚Äôd think about how to apply the warrior monk role to your day to day life,‚Äù she said. She pulled off her jacket. The weather had warmed up enough. ‚ÄúWhat it means to you, why it‚Äôs the first thing or the recurring thing in your thought processes.‚Äù

‚ÄúI just want to‚Ä¶ do.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou said you regretted yesterday, but Jasper thanked you. Would you rather have not done it? Is it the ‚Äòwant‚Äô in wanting to do things that‚Äôs problematic, or is it the ‚Äòdo‚Äô?‚Äù

I drew in a deep breath. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs‚Ä¶ a very complicated question, I think.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to answer it right now,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúI think I can, though. I think‚Ä¶ I had to. And as much as it was hard and cost me my job, I preferred it to the alternative. I can‚Äôt not do things that help out. I just want to do it in a good, centered way.‚Äù

‚ÄúCould it be a mundane job? Construction? Desk work? Would you want to do something like you were doing with the patrol?‚Äù

I thought about it.

I couldn‚Äôt see it. Not long-term.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the first thing that comes to mind?‚Äù she asked.

‚ÄúI think‚Ä¶ fuck me, I think even now, I can‚Äôt quite see myself being anything but a hero. There are good people I‚Äôve gotten to know. People I want to protect and help. Like Gilpatrick, like Weld and Vista and my cousin and a couple of the teenagers I was working with in patrol block. You. I want good things for them.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThat means a lot to me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been trying to convince myself there‚Äôs some other way, but‚Ä¶ I can‚Äôt not do anything.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs worse things. Especially if you can do it smart and centered.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to be Glory Girl,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúSomeone remarked yesterday that they‚Äôd thought she died and‚Ä¶ good. She can stay dead.‚Äù

‚ÄúSounds like you have an idea of what you‚Äôre doing next.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the wrong climate for it,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI just watched a team of heroes get eaten alive by the public. One took a bullet.‚Äù

‚ÄúFigure it out,‚Äù she said.

I frowned.

‚ÄúAgain, there‚Äôs no rush,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt sit still,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a bit of a rush.‚Äù

‚ÄúTouch base with me,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll go out for coffee, catch up. I can offer unofficial, more-friend-than-therapist advice. I think you‚Äôll figure it out, and I can give you a few nudges here and there.‚Äù

That gave me pause.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not a therapist anymore?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúJust the opposite,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm very much a therapist. Ten hour days, six or seven days a week, and other peripheral obligations. I‚Äôm afraid I‚Äôm not in a position to take you on as a patient again, Victoria, as much as I would dearly like to.‚Äù

That hurt. I didn‚Äôt want to say it, but it did hurt.

‚ÄúI just joined the Wardens as a staff psychologist for their junior members and some special cases, and I‚Äôm just not equipped, unfortunately. If you want it, I could try finding a colleague who you could talk to. Most are as busy as I am, so it might take a bit of time.‚Äù

I want you.

I want—

‚ÄúSorry to take up your time today, when you‚Äôre as busy as you are.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs more than alright, Victoria,‚Äù she said. She was looking straight ahead as she talked, one hand on her jacket as she walked. ‚ÄúWith the hours I work, I lose objectivity. It becomes the work, and I lose sight of the patients. Sometimes it‚Äôs hard to see the wins. Like I said, you were a patient close to my own heart, and I thought you were one of the ones we lost. Seeing you, hearing you? It means the world to me. It gives me a measure of hope.‚Äù

I nodded.

She looked over at me. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll reach out to a colleague. I‚Äôll see what I can do, if that‚Äôs okay. Give you some reassurance there.‚Äù

‚ÄúI—‚Äù I started.

‚ÄúYes?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay, but‚Ä¶ if you wanted to reassure me—‚Äù I said.

It felt a little less like I could talk about certain topics with her, now.

‚ÄúIf it‚Äôs within my power, I‚Äôll try anything,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúMy sister,‚Äù I said, my voice soft. ‚ÄúSend someone her way.‚Äù

Mrs. Yamada raised one eyebrow.

I knew what she was thinking. She wondered if it was selflessness, or if I was a surprisingly good person. I wasn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs the scariest damn person in the world, Jessica,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúAnd I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs bias. There‚Äôs a chance she‚Äôs going to do something bad, and she‚Äôs so damn powerful, that when and if it happens, it‚Äôs going to be so much worse than what happened to me, and it‚Äôs going to affect an awful lot more people.‚Äù

Daybreak — Interlude 1

The truck stopped at the gate, producing the occasional sputter and knocking sound as it sat there. The driver extended a hand out the window, waving for the camera, and the gate opened by way of remotely operated pulley.

It was another minute to the top of the hill, where the truck rolled to a stop in the parking lot, an expanse of gravel without any defined parking spots. The three people within remained where they were, warily observing the restaurant from a distance.

It was a log cabin writ large, the cedars stripped of their bark and stained with something that made them almost glossy, a warm yellow under the sun. The third floor was half the size of the other two, allowing the other half of what would have been the third floor to be a rooftop patio instead. A series of tables was scattered around the building, some close together and others a considerable distance away, as if they were trying to escape into the woods. Beyond the building was a cliff, and a vast expanse of forests, hills, mountains, and a small lake.

‚ÄúNice view,‚Äù Moose said, from the backseat.

Linc was settled in the passenger seat, reclining a bit with his seat angled back and his legs folded under him. With Moose in the back, he‚Äôd had to slide his seat as far forward as it could go, and it didn‚Äôt leave him much legroom. ‚ÄúJust think, past that view there isn‚Äôt nothing at all. If you headed straight ahead and kept going, you might not find any habitation until you ended up on the backside of this settlement here.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you headed straight ahead,‚Äù the driver said, pausing to take a swig of the bottle of water she‚Äôd wedged into her cup holder, making a face at how warm it was, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôd put yourself into that lake down there. Or you‚Äôd end up in the ocean. You‚Äôd drown either way.‚Äù

Linc smirked.

‚ÄúPeople would call you an idiot,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWhy would you go straight ahead like that? Are you proving a point?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs what Linc was getting at,‚Äù Moose said.

‚ÄúHarper knows what I‚Äôm getting at,‚Äù Linc said, turning around in his seat to look at Moose as he said it.

Moose was a big guy, with tousled blond hair. He‚Äôd undone some of the straps of his mask and had the mask laying over one muscular shoulder. The mask was metal, crude, and Moose wore something cloth under it for padding, which he had on now. He wore a sleeveless undershirt, jeans, boots, and had two gauntlets sitting next to him on the car seat. Even with the truck being large and Moose lying down across the length of the seat, he barely fit. He didn‚Äôt seem to mind much.

Behind Moose and the truck was the gravel road that led up the hill, the gate checkpoint, and a ways below that, the simple settlement where most visitors would be made to feel unwelcome. One to two thousand people would be living there at most.

‚ÄúThey built this place and situated it on the very edge of civilization,‚Äù Linc said, to round off his earlier thought.

‚ÄúYou two always seemed like the kind of edge of civilization people to me,‚Äù Moose asked.

‚ÄúWe do okay,‚Äù Linc said. ‚ÄúPut us in the middle of a city, we do fine, eh babe?‚Äù

‚ÄúMm,‚Äù Harper made a vaguely affirmative sound. ‚ÄúThis a trap, y‚Äôthink?‚Äù

Linc turned his attention to the building at the top of the hill. ‚ÄúNah. Why would you build a nice place like this and use it for a nefarious purpose.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, y‚Äôknow, it‚Äôs gonna be nefarious. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre here,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a question of if it‚Äôs a murderous sort of nefarious.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a good question, I admit,‚Äù Linc said.

‚ÄúI knew a guy,‚Äù Moose said. ‚ÄúHe had a mansion. Inherited or somethin‚Äô. Super nice.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe guy or the house?‚Äù Linc asked.

‚ÄúHm?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe guy was nice or the house was nice?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe house. That‚Äôs what I‚Äôm gettin‚Äô at. The guy was as nefarious as they get. He renovated the insides. He wanted to make a whole business of holdin‚Äô people that needed holdin‚Äô. For ransom. Said he‚Äôd deal with ‚Äôem and clean up the mess if ransoms weren‚Äôt paid. Wanted to be a contractor for disposin‚Äô of people in horrible ways.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre supposed to just drop them off at the nice, conspicuous mansion, hand over cash?‚Äù Harper asked.
