‚ÄúThat was it, I think. He‚Äôd make sure they died slow and horrible for you, clean them up, make sure they weren‚Äôt found.‚Äù

‚ÄúDefinitely not a nice guy then,‚Äù Linc said.

‚ÄúI dare say he wasn‚Äôt,‚Äù Moose said.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a terrible idea for a business,‚Äù Harper said.

‚ÄúIt kind of is,‚Äù Linc said.

‚ÄúMight‚Äôve been,‚Äù Moose said. ‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt seem in it for the money, gotta say. I highly suspect he was more focused on the part where he would do horrible things to people. Guy has a nice place, he wants to do creatively bad things to people, and he wanted a bit of pocket money. Draw lines between each of those things and you end up with something shaped like his game plan there.‚Äù

‚ÄúA triangle?‚Äù Linc asked, looking back at Moose. At Moose‚Äôs shrug, he elaborated, ‚ÄúIf you draw straight lines between three things, you get a triangle.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe the lines weren‚Äôt straight,‚Äù Moose said. ‚ÄúBut if you‚Äôre wondering if this is a trap, I don‚Äôt think it being fancy is ruling anythin‚Äô out.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a log building, Moose. Nothing that fancy.‚Äù

‚ÄúFancy to me.‚Äù

Harper leaned forward against the steering wheel, to get closer to the windshield, squinting against the sun.

‚ÄúWhat do you think, babe?‚Äù Linc asked. ‚ÄúIs it a murderous nefarious or a prosperous nefarious.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs something,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThe people on the roof are in costume and some of them are looking at us. I think we better get ourselves inside or they‚Äôre going to start laughing at us.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre going to laugh whatever happens,‚Äù Linc said. ‚ÄúYour truck has seen better days—‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt go talking about my truck, Linc.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd we‚Äôve got Moose with us, no offense Moose.‚Äù

‚ÄúSome offense taken, thank you very much,‚Äù Moose said, indignant.

‚ÄúYou call yourself Moose. People are going to laugh. That‚Äôs when you show your merits and make them stop laughing, is the way it works.‚Äù

‚ÄúPeople shouldn‚Äôt laugh in the first place,‚Äù Moose said. ‚ÄúThe Moose is a terrifying and noble creature. If you wouldn‚Äôt fuck with a rhino, you shouldn‚Äôt fuck with a moose. It‚Äôs one of the only proper prehistoric, giant animal species to have the grit to last to today.‚Äù

Harper turned off the truck. The truck sputtered, coughed, and died abruptly, in a way that suggested it wouldn‚Äôt revive again.

‚ÄúI know, bud,‚Äù Linc said, taking his eye off the truck‚Äôs much-abused, dust-caked dash. ‚ÄúI know that much, I‚Äôve seen one up close. I‚Äôve seen one run through snow that a normal person couldn‚Äôt walk in and hit a car hard enough to roll it. I have a healthy respect.‚Äù

‚ÄúDamn right,‚Äù Moose said.

Harper gave Linc a look, pulling her full mask on and flipping up her hood.

‚ÄúBut they don‚Äôt all know it,‚Äù Linc said. ‚ÄúYou gotta work with that. You picked a jokey name, you gotta put up with the jokes.‚Äù

‚ÄúHope was they‚Äôd be laughing with, not laughing at,‚Äù Moose said. ‚ÄúAt least I‚Äôd hope you weren‚Äôt the ones poking fun at me. It‚Äôs unkind, Linc.‚Äù

Harper climbed out of the truck.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not laughing at, bud. I‚Äôm just saying they might be. That‚Äôs all,‚Äù Linc said. He pulled his mask on, fixed his hair and beard with few sweeps of his hand, and climbed out, then hit the lever to flip his seat forward and give Moose room to squeeze out.

Moose kept the cloth mask on over his upper face, leaving the metal mask on his shoulder. He stretched, his joints popping audibly, and pulled his fur-lined gauntlets on.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to have to take those off again if we end up eating,‚Äù Linc said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs about presentation,‚Äù Moose said. ‚ÄúBesides, the name doesn‚Äôt make sense if I don‚Äôt got ‚Äôem.‚Äù

Harper was in costume, though the costume part was mostly a hooded, sleeveless top in her namesake velvet color, lopsided in how it trailed down over one leg in a robe-like aesthetic. She wore skintight shorts underneath. A black mask covered her upper face, and had truncated, forking horns that poked out through the top of the hood and kept the hood from falling back.

Linc wore a mask like Velvet‚Äôs, but his traced the area around his eye sockets and eyebrows, with the edges tracing back and into his hair, forking as they did. He wore a bodysuit for the upper body and pants. His costume had always been meant to be layered, but the heat had forced him to strip down to the base layer, with the pants only because he felt like a clown if he wore only the skintight stuff.

People leaning against and over the railing on the roof watched them as they approached the door.

‚ÄúThis place is a hell of a lot better than the last couple we visited,‚Äù Prancer remarked.

‚ÄúMore expensive too,‚Äù Velvet said. She was looking at the blackboard posted by the door, with prices. ‚ÄúTwenty dollars for a chicken sandwich?‚Äù

‚ÄúCome on,‚Äù Prancer said, pushing the door open.

The inside was expansive, with the kitchen as an island in the middle, counters and surrounding it, booths around the edges of the room, and tables in the space in between. There were only eleven non-staff people within, but the ground floor could have seated a hundred or more.

Prancer approached the kitchen island. He spoke to a black, twenty-something woman in a tan polo shirt and apron, ‚ÄúWho do I talk to for the rules?‚Äù

She jerked a thumb over her shoulder, indicating an elderly black man who was wiping out a glass. The man was watching, squinting with one eye, as he carried out the routine motion of cleaning the glass.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs in charge?‚Äù Prancer asked.

The employee gave Prancer a single nod.

‚ÄúWhat can I do for you?‚Äù the man asked, as the three approached.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been around the block a couple of times, I‚Äôm just looking for a primer on customs, and any special rules.‚Äù

‚ÄúPayment up front for what you‚Äôre ordering, have the money ready when you order if it‚Äôs busy. Don‚Äôt cause trouble, don‚Äôt draw weapons, don‚Äôt be loud, give us a heads up and use the side door or the patio if your power is going to bother anyone. Upstairs is the bar, you don‚Äôt go upstairs unless you‚Äôre invited or you already know you qualify to go upstairs.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat kind of qualification?‚Äù Velvet asked.

‚ÄúIf you have to ask, you don‚Äôt have it,‚Äù the old man said. He put the glass down and picked up another. ‚ÄúRoof is for more private meetings than you‚Äôd have on the second floor. Don‚Äôt go taking yourself up there if you wouldn‚Äôt be allowed on the second floor.‚Äù

‚ÄúNoted,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúAnyone to avoid, watch out for, anything like that?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs more for you to watch out for than for me to bother with. If they‚Äôre causing a problem or being a bother to others, they‚Äôll get kicked out. If you help with the kicking out, I‚Äôll give you something on the house.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúGot it.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you serve drinks down here?‚Äù Moose asked.

‚ÄúWe do. Anything fancier than beer or wine, we‚Äôll have to send someone upstairs to fetch it.‚Äù

‚ÄúCould I grab a mightyman?‚Äù Moose asked. He pulled off a gauntlet and retrieved a wallet from his pocket. He held out a twenty. ‚ÄúLong, hot drive.‚Äù

‚ÄúName?‚Äù the old man asked, gesturing at an employee. The employee set to getting the beer. The old man pulled a pad and pen out of his apron.

‚ÄúName? Uh, M.K.,‚Äù Moose said.

‚ÄúNo initials,‚Äù the man said.

‚ÄúJust Moose then,‚Äù Moose said, sliding the twenty across the bar. ‚ÄúWe can order food at the tables?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can,‚Äù the old man said. He picked up the money, then pulled out a fiver from the pocket of his apron and passed it back to Moose. He looked at the others. ‚ÄúNames?‚Äù

‚ÄúPrancer. She‚Äôs Velvet.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo I need to worry about you?‚Äù

‚ÄúNah. We‚Äôre pretty tame. We‚Äôre here to make contacts and get our names out there for the small stuff.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you do any business, be discreet enough I and my staff don‚Äôt see it. If you use powers, don‚Äôt bother the person next to you.‚Äù

‚ÄúGot it. Can I grab a beer? What my buddy Moose is having,‚Äù Prancer handed over the bills.

‚ÄúMe too,‚Äù Velvet said.

Prancer withdrew a larger bill from his wallet, and set it on the counter, sliding it toward the old man. ‚ÄúGratuity?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo need,‚Äù the old man said. ‚ÄúService fees and peace of mind are worked into the food prices. Order something, if you want to thank me.‚Äù

Beers in hand, they briefly considered sitting at the counter before Moose took a seat at one of the tables.

‚ÄúWhere you sit is important,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúBooth, you‚Äôre minding your own business, you‚Äôve got walls around you. Sitting at the counter, you‚Äôre open to people approaching you and joining you, I think. Not entirely sure how it works here in particular.‚Äù

‚ÄúI hear you,‚Äù Moose said, ‚ÄúBut I was sittin‚Äô funny the entire drive here, and if I sit on one of those stools then I‚Äôm going to have my back spasming the entire way back. I need a sturdy chair, here.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure, doesn‚Äôt matter that much,‚Äù Prancer said. He twisted around in his seat, one hand on his beer, taking a look at the others who were present. ‚ÄúPretty laid back here.‚Äù

‚ÄúCould be a quieter time of the day,‚Äù Velvet said.

‚ÄúOut of the way place, too,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúYou heard what he said about using powers? How many places have we been to, and how many allowed use of powers at all?‚Äù

‚ÄúTen. Ten places,‚Äù Velvet said, hunkering down over her beer. ‚ÄúThis is the only one, I think. Might have been a rule in The Well, but that was more the kind of place where you don‚Äôt know the rules until someone‚Äôs punching your face in for violating them.‚Äù

Prancer watched as a faint speck of dust traveled across his vision, pink-tinted. He smiled.

Four teenagers in the corner booth. They wore dark clothes with symbols and designs spray painted on and bleached into the fabric. One with a bandanna on his head looked their way, and Prancer flashed the guy a smile.

Three in another booth, against a wall. Tinkers. There was a cloth strewn out over the table, and parts were laid out. They ranged from twists of metal to a glass tube housing something that looked like a large, chewed wad of gum. The wad was throwing itself against the sides of its glass cage.

He wondered how that worked with the ‚Äòno business‚Äô rule. Were they only talking shop? Where was the line drawn?

Sitting alone in one booth was a woman with a mask covering her lower face, long black hair, and a long red dress with a slit down one side, exposing a tantalizing bit of leg. She wore an intricate framework of metal at her arms and hands, a series of bands at the elbow, wrist, knuckles, and rings at the finger, with thin rods of steel extending between each, along the back of each finger, and stopping at each finger and thumbtip. Each tip was enveloped by an ornate claw.

Her heels were much the same, Prancer noted. Heels were unusual for someone in costume, and hers were more unusual still. She wore something similar to her gloves, with the same bands at her leg, ankle, and foot, with the thin metal bars extending between each. Her toes were covered with the same metal claws, there was a strap of metal below the balls of her feet, and at her heel, one large claw-point served as the ‚Äòheel‚Äô of her heel, stabbing straight down.

When she moved one leg to fold one knee over the other, the claw tips moved on their own, twitching, recalibrating, the heel shifting back to stay pointed at the ground, flick back and away, then flick down.

She undid one side of her mask so it swung toward Prancer, still blocking his view of her mouth, helped by the draping of long hair, and she leaned down, taking a bite of her wrap. She put one hand to the loose end of her mask while she chewed, and fastened the end as she swallowed.

She saw him looking, turning her head his way. He smiled at her.

She only stared.

‚ÄúSomeone‚Äôs coming,‚Äù Moose said.

One of the spray painted kids. The guy Prancer had smiled at.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre new.‚Äù

‚ÄúPrancer, Velvet, M.K.,‚Äù Prancer introduced the group.

‚ÄúWhere are you from?‚Äù

‚ÄúAlaska, believe it or not.‚Äù

‚ÄúLong way,‚Äù the teenager said.

‚ÄúEspecially when you‚Äôre driving it,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúWho are you guys?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe group‚Äôs Ripcord. I‚Äôm Gorgos. We raid stores and resell, mostly. We‚Äôre nobodies. It‚Äôs the B-listers and small fry down here. The people with name recognition go upstairs.‚Äù

‚ÄúMeaning the people we want to do business with are upstairs,‚Äù Velvet said, still leaning heavily over her beer.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll work it out.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat do you guys do?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe wheel and deal,‚Äù Prancer said.

‚ÄúPrancer likes to be clever, but he doesn‚Äôt get that sometimes you have to explain why it‚Äôs clever, otherwise you only confuse people,‚Äù Velvet said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs why I have you, babe.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe wheel part is getaway driving and transporting,‚Äù she explained.

The kid leaned forward. The decoration on his outfit looked like the sort done with a stencil and a spray bottle filled with bleach, strategically bleaching fabric. Snakes and a woman‚Äôs face as a recurring motif. He had a bandanna over the top of his head and one over his nose and mouth. ‚ÄúWhat do you deal?‚Äù

‚ÄúGrass, mostly,‚Äù Prancer said.

‚ÄúYou actually have some?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot here, but we have it. Brand new and in high demand, given the times,‚Äù Prancer said.

‚ÄúAre you looking for resellers?‚Äù

‚ÄúFor the right price. Mostly we‚Äôre looking for new friends, and we‚Äôre trying to get the lay of the land before we do anything too enterprising.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan I get back to you?‚Äù the guy asked.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre welcome to,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúWe wouldn‚Äôt mind company either, if you guys wanted to join us.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd have to get back to you on that too,‚Äù the guy said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre trying to find our way these days. We agreed in the beginning we wouldn‚Äôt have one leader, and that was great then, but right now we‚Äôve got two different leadership styles butting heads.‚Äù

Prancer looked over at the table, where those seated were having a very fierce, hushed discussion.

‚ÄúIf you want to just sit and trade stories, we‚Äôd be happy to have you,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúGet away from all that, maybe come away with some fresh perspective.‚Äù

‚ÄúI might take you up on that. For now I‚Äôd better get back and make sure nobody reaches across the table to strangle someone.‚Äù

‚ÄúQuestion before you go,‚Äù Moose said. ‚ÄúIs it always this quiet?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs about to get noisier,‚Äù Gorgos said. ‚ÄúKeep an eye on the guy at the end of the kitchen there. He communicates with people in town. He was talking to the boss about something and the boss put another cook on the stove. Wait ten minutes and I bet he‚Äôll hit the button to open the gate. If he holds it down it‚Äôs a lot of people. My guess is the ferry from NYC hit the shore near the G-N portal twenty minutes ago.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood to know, thanks,‚Äù Prancer said.

Gorgos jogged back to his team.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre dwellin‚Äô a lot on going upstairs,‚Äù Moose observed.

‚ÄúReminds me of being a kid and being told I had to stay downstairs with my cousins and their friends during the holidays. My cousins were assholes,‚Äù Velvet said. ‚ÄúOne good thing about Gold Morning is it took them out of the picture.‚Äù

Moose whistled.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs wearing the purple cloak, that‚Äôs a sign of royalty, don‚Äôt you know?‚Äù Prancer plucked at Velvet‚Äôs hood. Velvet batted his hand away. ‚ÄúAnd royalty doesn‚Äôt not go upstairs. Royalty doesn‚Äôt show mercy.‚Äù

‚ÄúY‚Äôknow I went to prison because of you, Prance,‚Äù she said, quiet.

‚ÄúWell, yeah. I will point out we survived Gold Morning because we weren‚Äôt home when Alaska got hit.‚Äù

‚ÄúI went to prison for you,‚Äù she said, again. ‚ÄúThat counts for a lot.‚Äù

‚Äú‚ÄòCourse. How does that connect, though?‚Äù

‚ÄúJust sayin‚Äô,‚Äù she said, her accent thicker as her voice became softer. ‚ÄúYou said things would be different.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey will,‚Äù he said. He put a hand around her shoulders and pulled her closer, then kissed the top of her head. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got a decent crop, a lot of demand. We‚Äôll do okay. We‚Äôll make inroads.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm optimistic,‚Äù Moose said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not unoptimistic,‚Äù Velvet said.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not enthused either, doesn‚Äôt sound like,‚Äù Moose said.

‚ÄúJust sorta hoping for more, sooner,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he said. There wasn‚Äôt much more to say.

Velvet reached out, and the menu flew from the tabletop to her hand. It was tinted red and dusty, but much of their table and glasses were, now.

Prancer took stock of the other three capes in the room before the newest batch of arrivals reached the front door.

There was one, who might have been a bouncer, who had stepped out the side door momentarily and was now taking a seat by that same door. He wore a mask of metal bars that looked like they‚Äôd been welded to one another, all vertical, but he also wore a black apron.

That left only the couple at the bar. Matching costumes, white armor with jet black iconography, multiple circles and crescents in various patterns, with the armor sprayed black around each icon, so it looked like the darkness glowed. The man wore full armor, the woman wore only scattered pieces of armor, with white chainmail to cover the rest of her.

They drank white wine, in the middle of the afternoon.

Capes were strange people, Prancer mused.

‚ÄúI want to be the kind of person who earns her way upstairs,‚Äù Velvet said. Her head still rested against his shoulder, where he‚Äôd pulled her close.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs really stuck in you, huh?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs stuck,‚Äù she said. Without moving her head, she raised the beer to her lips and took a careful sip.

‚ÄúYou might have to lose the beater of a truck, babe, if you want to dress the part.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt go talkin‚Äô about my truck, Prance.‚Äù

‚ÄúEvery time you turn it off, it sounds like it‚Äôs off for good. I say a little prayer to myself that it will be, even knowing it‚Äôs a long, long walk back to home. Then I can take the money I‚Äôve got saved up and buy you something nice. All the bells and whistles.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen I got out of prison, I only had two things, babe. That truck, and you. I wasn‚Äôt feeling especially fond of you at the time, either. It‚Äôs the only thing I‚Äôve had for myself since I was old enough to have anything, that I‚Äôve been able to keep.‚Äù

‚ÄúCounts for somethin‚Äô, that,‚Äù Moose said.

‚ÄúIt does,‚Äù Velvet said, frowning down at her beer.

Prancer frowned at Moose, who only shrugged. Guy wasn‚Äôt making it any easier.

‚ÄúWhat if we overhauled the outside, got someone to give the engine a real solid lookin‚Äô-at?‚Äù Prancer asked.

‚ÄúSo long as it stays my truck. I don‚Äôt want you ship-of-Theseusing it.‚Äù

Prancer resisted swearing under his breath. So that tactic wouldn‚Äôt work.

There was more of the pink dust in the air, now. He gave Velvet a kiss on top of the head, then shrugged slightly. She moved her head off of his shoulder, sitting upright.

‚ÄúThings will be better,‚Äù he said.

She reached for his hand and squeezed it. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to go find the ladies‚Äô room. Order food before things get hairy. I‚Äôll have the chicken caesar sandwich and grab a few bottled waters while you‚Äôre at it. For the drive back.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou know the markup on those will be insane,‚Äù Prancer said.

‚ÄúJust get me my water,‚Äù she said.

She walked away. Prancer watched her walk away, feeling wistful.

He signaled the waitress. He made sure to give Velvet‚Äôs order while he remembered it, and then gave his own. Moose put in enough of an order for two people.

When they were alone again, Moose commented, ‚ÄúSorry, for interjectin‚Äô.‚Äù

‚ÄúInterjecting?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen you were talking about the truck, and about prison.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh. Yep. Apology accepted.‚Äù

‚ÄúHard to be the third wheel sometimes. Especially when things get complicated, relationship-wise.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan‚Äôt speak about the third-wheeling. That‚Äôs for you to figure out. But for the relationship part, it‚Äôs the simplest thing in the world, Moose,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs my girlfriend, I‚Äôm her boyfriend. Sometimes you and she enjoy each other‚Äôs company, sometimes I enjoy someone else‚Äôs company, but that doesn‚Äôt change that it‚Äôs me and it‚Äôs her as the boyfriend and girlfriend.‚Äù

His voice had become progressively more stern as he‚Äôd talked. He paused, meeting Moose‚Äôs eyes.

‚ÄúMakes sense,‚Äù Moose said. Prancer smiled.

‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt seem like you‚Äôve had anyone but her keeping you company, gotta say,‚Äù Moose said.

Prancer looked at the woman with the mask on her lower face and the claw-heels. ‚ÄúTrying to be better.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood for you,‚Äù Moose said, before taking a drink of his beer.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to marry that Velvet sometime soon,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve just got to make amends for old wrongs first. Can‚Äôt ask her to marry me when the last momentous event in our lives was me being a screwup.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe prison thing?‚Äù

‚ÄúEverything before, too. Trying to be better.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to step on any toes or get into anythin‚Äô too sensitive here,‚Äù Moose said. ‚ÄúBut can I ask? Would be easier to not step on toes if I can ask.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the whole thing. Get powers as a kid, sixteen years old, make friends with the right people, start dealing. It‚Äôs an elevation in status, y‚Äôknow? I was the guy who the cool kids in high school went to for product. Had money, had girls throwing themselves at me, I was invited to all the parties, and I meet Velvet there. One of many girls in one of many cities. But she gets powers and comes back to me, wants in, wants out of her house, especially. I oblige, and she doesn‚Äôt make me regret it.‚Äù

Moose nodded.

‚ÄúYears pass, we find our fit. She‚Äôs got more financial sense, I‚Äôve got the salesmanship. Most capes, there‚Äôs going to be conflict. She‚Äôs got her thing, you know how her power works. She hangs around somewhere, and this dust collects, and she can telekinetically control stuff, more dust there is on it. It‚Äôs how she gets that fucking truck going again, when it refuses to move. She makes us sit there for five minutes and then gives it another try, and it works, and she‚Äôll fiddle with it later and get it tuned up just enough it starts going.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe must care an awful lot about it,‚Äù Moose observed.

‚ÄúShe does. But that‚Äôs her whole psychology. She wants to settle in, wants to have a place she can call hers, whether it‚Äôs that truck cab or, I don‚Äôt know, going upstairs. I get restless. The mover thing. That causes friction. But we work despite it. We‚Äôre as soulmate as you can get when you‚Äôve got‚Ä¶ whatever these things are giving us our powers. Parasites. You had the visions when we were on the battlefield, that day.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù Moose said.

‚ÄúAs yin-yang soulmate as you can get with these things screwing up the fit,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúBut we got comfortable. I graduate school, barely, she graduates a year after me, we keep up the routine. Some wheeling, mostly dealing. The parties every weekend, tooth and nail fights because we‚Äôre both the type to flirt with others, before we realized we were fine just not worrying about it. Couple more years pass, I‚Äôm twenty-one, she‚Äôs twenty, still in the routine.‚Äù

‚ÄúA rut?‚Äù Moose asked.

‚ÄúJust the way things were. Somewhere along the line, you know, I‚Äôm twenty-seven, she‚Äôs twenty-six, and I‚Äôm still boning boys and girls from high school. Still partying.‚Äù

Moose‚Äôs eyes had widened.

‚ÄúLegal, mind you,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúBut‚Ä¶ sketchy, in retrospect.‚Äù

‚ÄúMore than a little, no offense,‚Äù Moose said.

‚ÄúNone taken. I deserve it. I didn‚Äôt realize until they came after us. Capes, police. You get into a groove and you don‚Äôt think about things and somehow a decade gets away from you. You‚Äôre not the cool guy people are excited to get to know. You‚Äôre the guy they‚Äôre into because they have to be if they want a discount, or if they want someone accessible that‚Äôs older. Sad. Pathetic. Slapped me in the face while people were talking to and about me in court. Forced me to take a long, hard look at who I was and who I wanted to be.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs good,‚Äù Moose said.

A young woman entered the restaurant. Prancer almost thought it was the first of the influx, but she was alone. She was an older teenager or twenty-something, with long white hair, wearing a black dress and black makeup, and she took a seat alone at the table. She rummaged in a bag to find a book.

The waitress approached her, kettle already in hand. The money was passed across the table, and the tea was poured. A regular.

Her mask was so simple it might as well have not been there. Curious, too, that she‚Äôd come this far to read a book. Maybe someone would be joining her.

Prancer watched the new arrival, but he kept talking, ‚ÄúShe told me, over and over again, I needed to be better. That she wanted better. That we needed to be careful. I didn‚Äôt listen. We got out of prison, she took me back, and I owe her for that.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf your critical flaw was not listening, might be you‚Äôve gotta listen when she‚Äôs saying she loves that vehicle out there.‚Äù

Prancer nodded slowly. Then he let his head loll back, and he groaned. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve put up with that thing for so many damn years.‚Äù

Velvet‚Äôs glass of beer slid across the table, and Prancer caught it just before it could reach the edge of the table and tip into his lap.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre talking about my truck?‚Äù Velvet asked, making her way back from the restroom.

‚ÄúMoose is telling me to let it go,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm trying to come to terms with the idea.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a good boy, Moose,‚Äù Velvet said, taking her seat. The glass pulled out of Prancer‚Äôs hands, sliding across the table to slap into Velvet‚Äôs hand.

‚ÄúAppreciate that, Velvet.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid you order or did you forget?‚Äù she asked.

‚ÄúRemembered,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs coming soon.‚Äù

The front door opened.

A large collection of capes entered and immediately headed off to find their booths and tables. One of the new arrivals stepped inside and loitered by the door. She was a woman with a slender figure and a bag over her head, for lack of a better description. The bag was cloth, with a pink animal pattern on it. The rest of her form-fitting outfit matched, including the shawl she wore.

Prancer leaned in the direction of the door, putting his mouth near Velvet‚Äôs ear. ‚ÄúI see Nursery. I wonder if Blindside is around.‚Äù

‚ÄúI hope the kid‚Äôs okay,‚Äù Velvet said. She looked at Moose. ‚ÄúWere you there when we talked to ‚Äôem?‚Äù

‚ÄúI was.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey were up to something.‚Äù

‚ÄúI remember.‚Äù

A man in armor was one of the last to arrive. The armor was white, and looked like it was fashioned of strips, woven and wound around him, the ends left frayed and sticking out to the sides and behind him. There was no face to it. Only a Y-shaped set of ridges. He stood between Nursery, a man in a black outfit and heavy hood, and a heavyset man with long hair, a dense beard, and a mechanical arm that extended to the ground.

At his arrival, people across the room started applauding, from Ripcord to the people at the counter, to the white haired girl and the woman with the mask. Even the kitchen staff. The man in armor laughed, the sound mingling with the general applause.

Moose joined in, and Velvet and Prancer offered their own light, confused applause.

‚ÄúThank you. Thank you. Is Marquis here?‚Äù the man in armor asked.

The old man at the kitchen pointed skyward. ‚ÄúRoof.‚Äù

The man in armor saluted, then ducked back through the door.

Velvet raised her hand to get Nursery‚Äôs attention. The woman‚Äôs group was already splitting up. The man in black joined the people in white armor. The bearded man with the mechanical arm walked over to the woman with the claws, sitting in her booth.

Nursery approached the table.

‚ÄúGood to see you,‚Äù Prancer said.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think I would see you three all the way out here,‚Äù Nursery said.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre trying to see who‚Äôs out there. The other places have been a little seedy.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey are. Seedy can be fun, though,‚Äù Nursery said. ‚ÄúReminds me of the old days.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou keep updating your costume,‚Äù Velvet said.

‚ÄúSilly thing, isn‚Äôt it? It‚Äôs easier to make a new one than to wash the blood and slime out. I feel ridiculous.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat was happening with the applause?‚Äù Prancer asked.

‚ÄúMission success,‚Äù Nursery said. ‚ÄúIn a roundabout, unexpected way, but that‚Äôs often how these things go.‚Äù

‚ÄúCongratulations,‚Äù Moose said.

‚ÄúThank you, Moose. It was a thing. We took a week to figure out what we were doing, we had to check with a few people, a number of thinkers, make sure we weren‚Äôt stepping on toes. The peace being what it is, we didn‚Äôt want to cause too much trouble.‚Äù

‚ÄúWas it a big mission?‚Äù Prancer asked.

‚ÄúBig,‚Äù Nursery said. ‚ÄúPlenty of room for things to go very wrong, with some bad repercussions that could be felt by everyone.‚Äù

Prancer‚Äôs eyebrows went up.

‚ÄúBut we were careful, we had the right people—‚Äù

‚ÄúYou included among those people,‚Äù Velvet said.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Nursery said, clasping her hands together.

‚ÄúWhat was the job?‚Äù Prancer asked.

‚ÄúTo kidnap someone, and have her disappear for long enough that people would get upset about it.‚Äù

‚ÄúHuh,‚Äù Prancer said.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre anxious out there. They feel powerless. The idea was to pick someone controversial, and take them out of the picture. Make them the topic of debate. Is vigilante justice right or wrong? In this case, where the wrong isn‚Äôt so terribly wrong? Well, that was their idea. I do think she did something horrible. It‚Äôs why I agreed to the job.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat was that?‚Äù

‚ÄúHurt a woman and made her miscarry. They say it was a mistake.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can see where that hits close to home.‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry to hear,‚Äù Moose said.

‚ÄúThank you. You‚Äôre kind. The plan was to provoke the debate and raise the issue before things reached a more critical point. Venting off the steam before things exploded. The debate seems to be trending that way.‚Äù

‚ÄúSounds like it needed a fine hand,‚Äù Velvet said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs some good work.‚Äù

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt do it alone,‚Äù Nursery said.

‚ÄúYour first time working with the others?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was. Lord of Loss is sweet, good at what he does.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe went straight to the roof, I‚Äôm guessing that means he isn‚Äôt the type to work with B-listers like us.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, I suppose not. He doesn‚Äôt like being indoors. You‚Äôre recruiting? That‚Äôs what you‚Äôre asking after?‚Äù

‚ÄúOr looking for a spot of work,‚Äù Prancer said.

‚ÄúSnag, sitting over there, is looking to hire people for a project down the road. He wants to do test runs first, make sure he succeeds on the first try. Those two hired the same information broker we worked with for that job.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou had an information broker?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe was ops too. Talked to us on the earpieces. A little shaky on some things, surprisingly quick on others. But I think you run into that with any thinker.‚Äù

Prancer nodded.

‚ÄúSnag is a few months new, a rookie, with a rookie‚Äôs mindset, but he has good instincts. If I can say this in confidence‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù Velvet said.

‚Äú‚Ä¶I wouldn‚Äôt want to be on a team with him long-term,‚Äù Nursery said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs mean. Unkind, impatient. Emotional. You get that with a lot of the new ones. Too close to whatever set them off.‚Äù

Prancer nodded slowly. ‚ÄúOld ones have their own problems. Ruts and routines.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey do. Um, I should hurry. Blindside has a mouth but I do like them. They do a decent job, if you can work around the limitations. They‚Äôre outside now, sitting on the patio by the side door. Can‚Äôt come inside without turning a few heads.‚Äù

Prancer smiled at the bad joke.

‚ÄúKingdom Come likes his bible verses, I earned some considerable brownie points by knowing the names and numbers to go with most of them. Benefit of bible school until I was eighteen. He‚Äôs a consummate professional. Very gentle, very efficient.‚Äù

‚ÄúExpensive?‚Äù Velvet asked.

‚ÄúNot too bad, I don‚Äôt think. I don‚Äôt know what he was paid, but if it‚Äôs close to my own wage, it shouldn‚Äôt be horrendous. He‚Äôs very selective about the jobs he‚Äôll accept.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat about you?‚Äù Prancer asked.

‚ÄúMe? I‚Äôm boring. I‚Äôm not even a parahuman, not really.‚Äù

‚ÄúWait, what?‚Äù Moose asked.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not,‚Äù Nursery said. She had a light tone of voice, like she was smiling from the other side of the cloth mask. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs why I feel so out of place in costume.‚Äù

Prancer watched as others came through the door. He recognized Biter but failed to get Biter‚Äôs attention with a wave.

‚ÄúHow does that work?‚Äù Moose asked.

‚ÄúShow him the bump,‚Äù Velvet said, smiling.

‚ÄúThe bump?‚Äù Moose asked. ‚ÄúOh.‚Äù

Prancer glanced over at Nursery, who was holding her cloth costume tighter against her stomach, showing her slightly protruding belly.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre the parahuman,‚Äù Nursery said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm the ride.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù Moose said. ‚ÄúOh wow. Sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo need to be sorry. It‚Äôs a bond unlike any other,‚Äù Nursery said. She gave Moose a pat on the cheek. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard sometimes, but I owe it to them. Making up for mistakes I‚Äôve made.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Prancer said, staring at his beer. He looked from his glass to Nursery. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be too hard on yourself, hm?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll try,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI should go. Take care and wish me luck.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood luck,‚Äù Moose said. He still looked shell-shocked.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs next?‚Äù Velvet asked, smiling.

‚ÄúWhat we did yesterday is only one instance. They‚Äôll have to do it again when the pressure builds. Sooner or later, however many thinkers they work with, however good the people they hire, there will be a mistake. Something will happen, it could be too much, too little, and then everything goes to hell in a handbasket.‚Äù

‚ÄúHeavy,‚Äù Prancer said.

‚ÄúBut I‚Äôve stayed too long. My baby and I earned ourselves an invite upstairs, because they might hire me again, and because we showed our stuff, I don‚Äôt want the offer to expire,‚Äù Nursery said, excited. ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt drink at the bar, but it‚Äôs still a chance to meet some of the people running the corner worlds, the major players. A huge opportunity.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs amazing,‚Äù Moose said, looking down at the bump. ‚ÄúCongratulations. Both of you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre so sweet. I should go, excuse me,‚Äù Nursery said, leaving.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll talk again,‚Äù Prancer said.

Velvet raised a hand, her smile frozen on her face. Prancer reached over to squeeze her thigh.

‚ÄúI think I hate her now,‚Äù Velvet said.

He gave her leg another squeeze.

His thoughts turned over as he watched the people enter. Some headed upstairs. Ones with nice costumes, scary ones. He recognized quite a few.

There were also the others. The B-listers, the dregs, the people who weren‚Äôt yet established, filling up the ground floor, ordering their food and drinks.

‚ÄúHey Moose,‚Äù he said.

Moose stared off into space, in the direction of the stairs.

‚ÄúMoose,‚Äù Velvet said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm pretty sure she‚Äôs a loon. I wouldn‚Äôt worry too much about it.‚Äù

‚ÄúMoose,‚Äù Prancer tried again.

Moose frowned, glancing back at the stairs. ‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúLook at the room. Tell me, who do you know here?‚Äù

‚ÄúSome of the big guys. Biter, you and I had drinks with him. Etna, Crested, Beast of Burden, Bitter Pill, Nailbiter, Hookline, Kitchen Sink.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo me a favor?‚Äù

‚ÄúSure.‚Äù

‚ÄúRound ‚Äôem up. Anyone you get along with, who you think wouldn‚Äôt cause a fuss.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat are you doing?‚Äù

‚ÄúStill figuring it out,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúYou recognize anyone?‚Äù

‚ÄúFew people. You want me to gather ‚Äôem?‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease. We might have to take it outside. Actually, let‚Äôs definitely take it outside. By the side door. So the owner doesn‚Äôt complain.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve piqued my interest,‚Äù Velvet said.

Prancer nodded, still lost in thought. He watched as she walked away, pausing to feel a moment of fondness for her, and then resumed his thinking. He made his way to the side door.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Blindside said.

‚ÄúHey. Gathering some people. Thought we‚Äôd come to you, invite you to hear me out.‚Äù

‚ÄúThanks, Prancer. What‚Äôs this about?‚Äù

‚ÄúGive me a second to think. I‚Äôm a salesman, and I‚Äôve got to figure out exactly what I‚Äôm pitching.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure.‚Äù

Prancer stuck his fist out, stopped where Blindside‚Äôs power made it stop. He felt Blindside tap a fist against the side of his hand.

The others assembled. The people who had been invited, then the people who hadn‚Äôt, who were curious.

‚ÄúI want to organize,‚Äù he started. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not the person to lead it, don‚Äôt get me wrong, this isn‚Äôt a power play. I‚Äôm not a power player. But I think, right now, while we‚Äôre still at peace, while there aren‚Äôt so many people who have beefs with one another, or the beefs have had two years to go quiet, this would be the chance to do it.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou wouldn‚Äôt be the first person to think about doing this,‚Äù Biter said.

‚ÄúNo?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, some other groups, some small, some large. They‚Äôre banding together, a mutual peace. Forming a set of rules and expectations that aren‚Äôt unwritten, that we actually discuss and work out.‚Äù

‚ÄúWith the little guys?‚Äù Prancer asked. ‚ÄúB-listers? Those of us who aren‚Äôt being focused on while the big guys are laying out tracts of territory and settlements?‚Äù

‚ÄúSome of them. Those groups are smaller than you‚Äôd be talking, if you‚Äôre talking about everyone here.‚Äù

Prancer nodded.

He glanced at Velvet, and he saw the way she was looking at him, and he felt like a proper man for the first time. She reached for his hand and squeezed it, hard.

Then, more alive and excited than he‚Äôd seen her in a long, long time, Velvet spoke, ‚ÄúYou think they‚Äôd be open to talking?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think they might,‚Äù Biter said.

Flare — 2.1

‚ÄúThe Wardens are cooperating with seven major cape teams and, last I checked, ten minor teams. We are not a monolithic entity. We are not an authority. We are not the bad guys, Julia.‚Äù

I rummaged through a cabinet. My life was in boxes, from my clothes to my hair and skin stuff to my files. If it were that alone, it would have been tolerable. I‚Äôd tried using logic and going to the most common sense places. Not in or among the dirty dishes, not in the various jars and vases of spoons and spatulas on the counter, not behind or under something. I‚Äôd checked the other rooms in the apartment.

‚ÄúPeople are worried. You have Legend as a second in command, and memories aren‚Äôt so short that we don‚Äôt remember the Alexandria fiasco.‚Äù

I moved methodically through the kitchen, left to right, while the television played on a low volume.

‚ÄúI can tell you this: all we want to do is help. We want to find the right capes for the major crises and we want to equip the teams out there with information and resources. ‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs admirable, but—‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, wait, hold on, Julia. You told me when you asked me to have a chat with you on camera that you wanted to have a conversation. Let me say this.‚Äù

I looked at the little TV in the corner of the kitchen.

‚Äú‚Ä¶that people are going to draw on what they know to fill the blanks, when they don‚Äôt have enough information. I understand that the closest parallel that many Americans draw to the Wardens is the PRT. Give us time to make our impression and show how we operate,‚Äù Chevalier said.

‚ÄúWould you not say there are quite a few of those blanks when it comes to your organization?‚Äù the reporter asked.

‚ÄúI accepted this interview because I want to fill some of those blanks.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you an open book, then?‚Äù

My eyebrows went up. That was dirty pool from reporter Julia. There was no way that question wouldn‚Äôt be followed by something that Chevalier couldn‚Äôt or wouldn‚Äôt want to answer, cornering him.

‚ÄúSome of those blanks,‚Äù Chevalier said, stressing the ‚Äòsome‚Äô. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre still figuring things out, we‚Äôre still finding our footing and we‚Äôre negotiating a comfortable and healthy position with the public, the various teams under our umbrella, teams that aren‚Äôt under our umbrella, and the authorities. The lack of answers and the number of blanks isn‚Äôt me being evasive or underhanded. It‚Äôs that the Wardens and society as a whole have a lot of figuring out to do.‚Äù

He was good at what he did, and he did a lot. I wished I was in a position to study what he was saying and how he was fielding the questions, but I had more hunting to do.

I went back to the drawers I‚Äôd already checked, pulling out the cutlery drawer enough that I could check the back, behind the tray that held the forks and knives. I was too used to drawers having a mechanism that stopped them once they were pulled out to their limit, and I‚Äôd expected it to be longer, which led to me pulling the drawer straight out of its housing.

I only barely caught it, sticking my knee out under it and moving my hands to grab the sides. The cutlery rattled loudly, with a few miscellaneous cheese and holiday themed knives clattering to the floor.

‚Äú‚Ä¶would you say about the rumors circulating around Valkyrie, then?‚Äù

I put the drawer on the countertop, collected the fallen knives, and sorted through the contents, lifting up the tray to make sure nothing had fallen beneath. No luck.

I tried to put the drawer back, failed a few times before realizing that the construction wasn‚Äôt especially sturdy, and that the back end had pulled a bit loose. I fixed it, then resumed trying to put it back inside the hole it was meant for.

There was the saying: affordable, nice, or safe and sane. Pick one. It was a chronic problem with the speed they were trying to get buildings and houses up. Shoddy construction, rush jobs, cut corners, mistakes, and general ugliness were pretty normal. I was hopeful that in a little while we might be able to get to a point where it was ‚Äòpick two‚Äô instead of ‚Äòpick one‚Äô, but we had a ways to go.

I tried to squeeze the end together where two pieces didn‚Äôt quite meet and simultaneously push it in with my stomach. It refused to slide in.

‚ÄúWhat are you doing to my kitchen?‚Äù

Crystal was in the doorway, her hair a mess. She wore an oversized t-shirt and pyjama shorts, and she still looked half asleep.

‚ÄúDid I wake you?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúUh huh,‚Äù she said, sleepy. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt tell me you‚Äôre a morning person. That would be a problem.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not. I‚Äôm a person who fell asleep early last night—‚Äù

‚ÄúAlmost right after eating. Yep. And now you‚Äôre up, showered, dressed, and you‚Äôre dismantling my kitchen. For reasons.‚Äù

‚ÄúI woke up and thought I‚Äôd keep my normal work routine while I figure out what I‚Äôm doing.‚Äù

‚ÄúRenovating my kitchen?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm trying to find scissors,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd settle for a sharp knife.‚Äù

Crystal smiled wide, her eyes still sleepy. She grabbed a glass from a cabinet, and she half-walked, half-floated across the kitchen.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt laugh,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre such a cliche,‚Äù she said, as she passed me on her way to the sink. ‚ÄúOh my god, Victoria. You‚Äôre that person with super strength that trashes everything she touches.‚Äù

‚ÄúJust help me,‚Äù I said.

She reached over and helped me hold the drawer together. As it slid into the confines of the front of the counter, the framing held it together where the drawer‚Äôs own construction wouldn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt using my super strength, for the record,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYeah. I‚Äôve done that with the drawers before, I‚Äôm just making fun of you. It‚Äôs a funny image, to walk into the kitchen and see that.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh ha,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThen can I make fun of you for having two big jars of spatulas, whisks, spaghetti scoops, having two food processors—‚Äù

‚ÄúOne was a gift.‚Äù

‚Äú—And no scissors or shears anywhere I can find? I‚Äôd settle for a sharp knife. You have those steak knives, but they look nice and I don‚Äôt want to use them for the wrong thing and ruin them.‚Äù

She reached across the counter to get the package of bacon, holding it up. It was inside a hard plastic tupperware-like container with a small black and white label stuck to it. A mark stamped on it had it sourced from another world. Even without the mark, the pricetag might have given it away.

‚ÄúThought I‚Äôd treat you to breakfast,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúWent for a walk to get some stuff.‚Äù

Still appearing half asleep, she moved one hand, creating a deep red forcefield behind the bacon, then she produced a thin laser from her fingertip, slicing off the end of the package.

She handed the bacon to me, open end up.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have scissors?‚Äù

She shook her head, smiling.

I sighed, picking up the bowl where I‚Äôd already mixed the dry ingredients. ‚ÄúFruit crepes, bacon on the side?‚Äù

‚ÄúSounds amazing,‚Äù she said, leaning against the counter, eyes mostly closed.

‚ÄúYou look beat,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúIt was pretty unforgiving, being there. I timed everything so I could unwind starting with the barbecue, and unwinding didn‚Äôt happen.‚Äù

I nodded. ‚ÄúSorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not on you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm still sorry it happened.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou slept okay though?‚Äù

‚ÄúI slept a solid ten hours. I just‚Ä¶ started sleeping at six thirty or something. Then I woke up, I started thinking, and I decided to be productive. I‚Äôm talking to some teams today.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you want me to put a good word in with my guys, I‚Äôd be happy to.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to do the quasi-military cape thing,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúA little bit too intense.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Crystal said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so physically tired, two days out, that I‚Äôm not sure I would be standing if I couldn‚Äôt fly.‚Äù

I looked down at the ground. Her feet were barely touching the ground.

It wasn‚Äôt the physical intensity that worried me. It was the mental and emotional cost. It was the fact that when it came to the military and the military-like stuff, the trend was to beat the individual into shape. Organization, conformity.

I couldn‚Äôt take much more of the harsh lessons on identity or the forced redefining of the self.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just waking up, so forgive me if I got something wrong, but did you already find a place?‚Äù

I shook my head.

‚ÄúYou took the sheets off the couch.‚Äù

I looked over at the living room. There were boxes stacked around, and only half were mine.

‚ÄúYou said you might have friends over at some point, I thought it‚Äôd be weird if you had to navigate around my stuff, so I moved it out of the way.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù she said. She paused. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm tired, so I want to make sure I say this right.‚Äù

I went to the fridge to get the fruit stuff I‚Äôd already prepared.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt care,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúFirst of all, I know I have a lot of stuff. You know I have a lot of stuff.‚Äù

I looked at the stuff around the kitchen and adjacent living room. It was a bit messy, to the point counter space and table space was occupied.

‚ÄúJust— I really don‚Äôt care if you add your stuff to it. I like my places feeling lived in. Some of the stuff is a friend‚Äôs, and they‚Äôll take it when they get set up. Some is mom and dad‚Äôs. Some is yours, and that‚Äôs fine. That leads me to my second point. I want you to be here. I want you to feel comfortable.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know my couch isn‚Äôt much, but you need a place that you can kick your shoes off and leave them where they are.‚Äù

I might have mentioned that I wasn‚Äôt quite that personality type, but I held my tongue. I understood the sentiment, what she wanted.

‚ÄúI want you to have a place that‚Äôs yours, Vic.‚Äù

‚äô

‚ÄúI‚Äôll start by asking this: why not be independent?‚Äù

Foresight had a strong aesthetic running through their costumes. Primary among those things was a mask or helmet design where each of the members of the team lacked eyeholes. Helmets with opaque visors, masks without eyes. The aesthetic involved lots of paneled body armor and loose fabric elsewhere, with iconography worked into the panels. It made me think of ninjas from movies, with the mix of lightweight costumes and armor, but without the Eastern style.

Their team symbol was a stylized eye, sans pupil, with a wildly exaggerated ‚Äò4‚Äô struck out in bold lines that extended well past the curved lines of the eye.

I was wearing my best civilian clothes. I‚Äôd opted to leave the mask off. I sat in a chair. Two of them sat in chairs in the office, and another two stood at the side.

I gave my answer. ‚ÄúIf I‚Äôm being entirely honest, independent doesn‚Äôt pay unless you‚Äôre really good. At the risk of sounding arrogant, in another time and place, I think I could scrape by because I do have that experience, I have the knowledge, and I can hold my own.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt think you could do it now?‚Äù Countenance asked. He was the second in command and the highest ranking team member in the room. His outfit was heavier and draped more than the others, both in how the cloth hung loose and how the armor panels were connected so they dangled from the piece above. The Foresight icon was in the center of his mask, like a cyclopean eye.

‚ÄúI know who Foresight is and how you operate,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI know you want to move forward, you‚Äôre interested in helping the little guys, tackling the right issues, and take decisive, needed action in a calculated, smart way.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou read our webpage.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been following Foresight since it started,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúWhatever answer you give me today, I‚Äôll be following you guys from here on out, because I think it‚Äôs important to know the lay of the land. Which goes back to what I was saying. Being calculated, being smart. I‚Äôve been watching and researching you guys, and I‚Äôm sure you have the mentality where, from the time I reached out about an interview, you were looking me up and asking questions. Which means you heard about the incident at the Norfair community center.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes. We talked to your reference about it. I imagine he talked to you?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt, but he‚Äôs busy and this interview happened on short notice,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúEverything that unfolded there and a lot of what I see elsewhere, it suggests that it would be really hard to make it as an independent. Too many want to blame parahumans for what happened, and both independents and fledgling teams are easily targeted. Established teams absorb and diffuse that impact. That aside, being part of a team, cooperating, having the information and sharing that information, it‚Äôs too crucial. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm not going independent, given the chance. I want to help build something.‚Äù

Countenance nodded. He reached over to his friend, who handed over the paperwork he‚Äôd been reading. He looked down. ‚ÄúYour reference sang your praises.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a great guy. I really respect what he‚Äôs trying to do with something as tricky as the patrol block.‚Äù

‚ÄúOur problem, when it comes to assessing any candidate, is that each person we add to our teams is added strength, added power, but they‚Äôre also a possible set of complications. It forces us to strike a balance. We‚Äôre smaller than many of our peers because we‚Äôre selective. We want to make sure anyone we add will be a good fit, with minimal complications.‚Äù

‚ÄúI reached out to Foresight first, to you, because I like how you do things. It‚Äôs what and who I want to be.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen my next question to you would be what you think is going to happen next,‚Äù Countenance said.

‚ÄúWhat I think is going to happen? I think trouble is incoming. We see hints of it, the out-of-control triggers, we hear about some scary monsters and then the big names go and try to handle it, then we have other circumstances where the big names are running off to go handle things that they don‚Äôt tell anyone about. I think those situations might be worse than the monsters. So far, Gimel is untouched by the worst of it. We‚Äôve been on top of things. But sooner or later, something is going to hit us that we aren‚Äôt prepared for and can‚Äôt neatly handle.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat do you think happens then?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think it depends a lot on us having the right information and tools.‚Äù

Beside Countenance, Anelace was nodding. Anelace was a young guy, his costume the opposite of Countenance‚Äôs in how it was tighter-fitting, his mask bearing a dark gray dagger illustration on the right side of the white surface in the same exaggerated style the ‚Äò4‚Äô was drawn on the emblem on his chest. The knotted area where hilt, blade, and the two prongs of the guard all met was located where one of his eyes would be.

‚ÄúYou said you know how we operate?‚Äù

‚ÄúSupport work with the megalopolis and police, patrols and events for the day to day. Several times a week you make calculated, strategic strikes on priority targets. It‚Äôs like what the Wardens are doing with the big, scary threats, but you‚Äôre more city-focused than whatever‚Äôs going on outside of Gimel. A lot of your members go on to work with them, which is why you have openings.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe does her research,‚Äù Anelace said.

‚ÄúShe does,‚Äù Countenance said. He said it in a way that suggested he was admitting it, almost reluctant.

My heart sank.

I looked over my shoulder. The two at the side of the room were Effervescent and Relay.

Effervescent was an emotion manipulator with an emphasis on stunning people. Relay was capable of some complex moves with teleportation I wasn‚Äôt sure I had a grasp on, most of which seemed to amount to them teleporting to where others were, shunting that person to a random position elsewhere, and he also had some ability to communicate without words, both sending and receiving.

‚ÄúCan I ask?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúAsk?‚Äù Countenance asked me.

I indicated the pair. ‚ÄúI get the impression they‚Äôre communicating something to you, and you sound like you‚Äôre winding up to tell me no. Both took some shifts at the portals, watching the refugees as they came in to make sure there was no trouble, which makes me think they‚Äôre thinkers, they read people, and they‚Äôre reading me.‚Äù

Countenance turned his head to fix the cyclopean, drawn eye on the pair.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt get a consistent read on you emotionally,‚Äù Effervescent said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs repressed.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy long-time boyfriend was an emotion manipulator. He had a hard time getting a read on me too,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm better than most when it comes to getting reads,‚Äù Effervescent said. ‚ÄúNo offense, but it‚Äôs what isn‚Äôt as repressed that concerns me.‚Äù

‚ÄúEnough you‚Äôd say no,‚Äù Countenance said.

Effervescent nodded.

‚ÄúRelay?‚Äù

‚ÄúMy read was fine. Minimal secondary noise.‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Countenance said. ‚ÄúFor reading you without permission. It‚Äôd be a point in your favor that you caught on, but—‚Äù

‚ÄúBut you have to put stock in what the others say. No hard feelings,‚Äù I said. I made myself smile as I stood from my seat. Countenance stood too. He shook my hand. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll see you around, I hope we can work together then.‚Äù

‚ÄúI hope so too. Good luck,‚Äù Countenance said.

‚ÄúLet me get the door for you,‚Äù Anelace said. He jumped to his feet and opened the door for me. His voice was quiet as he said. ‚ÄúSorry to see you go.‚Äù

The thinkers would have noticed that.

I wondered what Effervescent and Relay would be reporting about my emotional state as I left.

‚äô

‚ÄúMrs. Dallon?‚Äù

I stood from my seat in the waiting room.

The cape had a costume that looked like a suit, metallic silver fabric, with a black dress shirt underneath. His mask consisted of two panels that met and ran down the center of his face, creating an almost beak-like profile with how the two sides swept along the sides of his face and back. Not bird-like, but as if his entire head was the beak. The hair I could make out above the ‚Äòv‚Äô where the mask parted was longer and heavily styled.

It reminded me of the Ambassadors from Boston, but I was pretty sure they wouldn‚Äôt have worn suits as ostentatious as this, nor such a dramatic full-face mask.

‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt come in costume?‚Äù he asked. He sounded surprised.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm pre-identity adjustment,‚Äù I said, caught in trying to find my footing with my rehearsed explanation as I simultaneously crossed to where he was to shake his hand. ‚ÄúMoving on from the identity and methodology I had as a teenage heroine. I‚Äôm a blank slate, and there‚Äôs a lot of room to adjust my brand moving forward.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you ex-Protectorate?‚Äù he asked. ‚ÄúI might have missed that if it was in your application.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo. Ex-Ward, but only very briefly.‚Äù

‚ÄúI only ask because you went straight to the term ‚Äòbrand‚Äô. I‚Äôm used to hearing it from people who were in the PRT and people from other corporate teams. I know I read your file and there was no mention of a corporate background. I‚Äôm Lark. You‚Äôll meet Dido soon, all going well.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nice to meet you, Lark.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy office is this way, if you‚Äôll join me,‚Äù he said. He briefly touched the small of my back to guide me in the direction his other hand was indicating.

I was bothered by the contact. Unsolicited touching, the presumed closeness, and the fact it was a hot day, my back was damp from the walk and he would have felt that.

It was such an unnecessary thing and it made both of us uncomfortable.

‚ÄúBrockton Bay,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúYes. From birth to Endbringer and immediate aftermath.‚Äù

‚ÄúA mom and pop small town team?‚Äù

‚ÄúAunt and uncle and cousins too,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúExtended family. They passed the fifteen year mark with just donations and small events. I think that counts for something.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs better than what Dido and I have managed, but give us time. We have five parahumans on the team, and we‚Äôre already in the black when it comes to the business end of things.‚Äù

‚ÄúI spent most of my childhood watching my mom balance the books, I did the events, the photoshoots, the merchandising as a PRT-acknowledged team. I have something of a sense of what you‚Äôre probably going for.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh, the merchandising. I think I have your PRT trading card from that time period in a binder in my office.‚Äù

I smiled. ‚ÄúWhich one? I had one that was holographic, which you could swipe through the controller for the video game to have me as a polygon-rendered helper, and the higher quality one that had the bio on the back.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think it was the second one. My office is through this door.‚Äù

I took a seat opposite the glass-top desk while he closed the door. He undid the button in his suit jacket before sitting down.

‚ÄúTypically those of us at Auzure like to work with new parahumans,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre easier to brand. When we work with capes with a history, we like that history to be a strong one.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think you get the best of both worlds with me,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúMost people assumed I was dead when everything happened in Brockton Bay, and nobody corrected that misunderstanding. If you do dig up information about me, a lot of it is strong.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think that‚Äôs where we run into problems,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúA lot of your history and presence is tied into your family‚Äôs group identity. ‚ÄòGlory Girl‚Äô isn‚Äôt famous beyond a certain range. Hometown heroine, yes, with some people in Boston and New York who might know of you, but not famous.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen consider me new. Untainted by the past.‚Äù

‚ÄúI would, but we use things we term perception turns, or just turns.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know the term,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI like that you do. Branding, turns. You do seem to know what you‚Äôre getting into here. When we‚Äôre tracking someone‚Äôs marketability, we map out the turns. You‚Äôre fine, nothing exceptional, for most of your career, with an upturn if you count your disappearance, after the Slaughterhouse Nine.‚Äù

I took a deep breath, then nodded.

‚ÄúBut if we include your family, there‚Äôs a lot of baggage.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou could say that,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúDownturn, death of Fleur. Downturn, times when New Wave was subsisting, but not in the eyes of the media.‚Äù

‚ÄúFour adolescents and two couples, there were weeks where school or work took priority. That got better as my cousins and I got older.‚Äù

‚ÄúCousins‚Ä¶ and your sister?‚Äù he asked.

I felt the shock like it was cold water.

He continued, ‚ÄúI think if it were up to the turns and the background alone, it would have to be a no. At the time you should have been drawing the most attention, given your age and potential, you‚Ä¶ died, as you put it. You were gone for the two years before Gold Morning.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre offering cape services for the reconstruction, with Spell offering some massive assistance with the argriculture. It‚Äôs a big part of what‚Äôs driving us to the front pages, giving us some upturn in the most general sense, for public perception. What we really want is the human angle, something where we could have an attractive young lady like yourself in a photo op, or your sister—‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúHer and the right person in a photograph? If you two paired up, Auzure could make you big.‚Äù

I winced, and I stood from my seat.

‚ÄúVictoria?‚Äù

They hadn‚Äôt accepted the interview to get me for me. I was just a stepping stone to the person they really wanted.

‚ÄúThank you for your time,‚Äù I said.

I managed to restrain myself from slamming the door on the way out.

‚äô

‚ÄúThanks for meeting us out here,‚Äù Whorl said. He didn‚Äôt shake my hand, but instead reached out to clasp my wrist. I clasped his.

‚ÄúNot a problem,‚Äù I said. I looked up at the structure that had been erected around the portal. It cast a shadow. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nice to be in the shade, with a decent breeze.‚Äù

Whorl wore a blue mask with a white border around the eyes and outermost edge, and his costume was a ‚Äòpreppy‚Äô bodysuit, complete with a folded collar, like a polo shirt, a narrow belt, and leggings. His icon was large on his chest, a circle with angled spokes at the edges. He had an armband with the gold morning symbol on it, but the colors were the blue and white of his costume.

He grinned, showing off white teeth. ‚ÄúYou should have been here at noon. It was brutal.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe people weren‚Äôt too irritable, with the heat?‚Äù

All around us, people were coming through the portal, forming lines. There were buildings to the left and right of the street that people were heading into, to get the instructions and things necessary to start their lives in Gimel.

‚ÄúI think they were happy for it,‚Äù Whorl said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been going back and forth, and it‚Äôs miserable on the other side.‚Äù

‚ÄúI just realized I got us started on a conversation about the weather,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm kind of a weather manipulator, not really, but it‚Äôs fun to say. Talking about the weather happens more than you‚Äôd think, when it comes to me,‚Äù he said.

Again, that smile with those very white teeth.

‚ÄúI read up on you online,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúAh, did you? Should I be flattered or worried that I‚Äôve been stalked?‚Äù

I was reminded of the segment on television, the reporter trying to corner Chevalier by getting him to claim a certain attitude.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not stalking,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm doing my homework, is all.‚Äù

I had to admit, the preppy look with the wide shoulders, narrow waist, clean cut and nicely taken care of, it appealed to me, and it had always. Not that I was even remotely thinking of actually moving forward with a relationship.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm probably going to have to duck out and handle some minor crisis or another, but stick around and don‚Äôt disappear on me, we‚Äôll find the time and figure out if we can place you with the Attendant.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôd be great.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf I get caught up in something, find one of the others. Chat with them, they‚Äôll tell you what they think of the team.‚Äù

There were a few other capes distributed across the crowd. It was interesting how people seemed so keen on them, even approaching them, happy to see them. The sentiment of blame hadn‚Äôt gripped the refugees here.

A teenager with a moon design on her mask and dress-like costume.

I saw a humanoid mech the size of a car, with a glass tank for the ‚Äòbody‚Äô, something large and fishlike within the tank. The mech sat on its ass, feet sticking out, and children were crowding around to tap the glass and climb on the feet. The tinker, as I took it, was the one sitting on the suit‚Äôs shoulder. Another cape was standing on the end of a rod, three stories above the ground, the end of the rod stuck into the side of the building. He looked stern as he looked down at the scene, his arms folded, until someone waved up at him and he waved back.

‚ÄúIs that the whole team?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot even close. With the teams merging, we‚Äôre taking on a lot of others. We‚Äôll be breaking up into three sub-teams later, but all with the same name and brand.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if I‚Äôm hurting my chances saying this, but I‚Äôm kind of crossing my fingers you guys are going with the Shepherd‚Äôs name and brand, but the Attendant‚Äôs approach.‚Äù

Whorl smiled again. ‚ÄúWe might be.‚Äù

‚ÄúI like the approach,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúHow do you interpret it?‚Äù

‚ÄúGiving people security. Moving slowly, with measured steps, informed by the lessons of the past. You guys seem pretty focused on taking and holding territories, improving neighborhoods. After what happened at the Norfair community center, I think giving people time to get used to capes again is key.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think it might be,‚Äù Whorl said.

Above, the cape that was standing on the end of the horizontal pole whistled. As we looked up, he pointed.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs my cue,‚Äù Whorl said. ‚ÄúNo pun intended. I‚Äôll be right back.‚Äù

Whorl headed toward the building that the people were filing out of, moving at a light jog, with a fog-like nimbus building at his shoulders and arms.

I looked at the various capes, debating my options. I worried that flying up to say hello to the one at the end of the pole would spook him and make him fall from his roost, and I wasn‚Äôt that keen on flying.

That left two options. The tinker or the teenage girl with the moon iconography.

I made my way toward the girl, because she had less people around her. The crowd was a bit of a tide I had to work against.

‚ÄúStuck?‚Äù I heard a voice.

I turned my head. It was a man with tattoos, a cleft chin and eyes that looked like he was perpetually squinting, even in the shade of the gate that housed the Bet-Gimel portal. He was talking to a couple.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a big decision. We‚Äôre not farmers.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard, getting started again,‚Äù the guy with the tattoos said. ‚ÄúThe tent cities are rough, while you wait for an available apartment. You can work your ass off, earn fake ‚Äòdollars‚Äô that might not have value in a few weeks or months, you sweat, you hurt, and everyone around you is doing the same. Stinks, when everyone‚Äôs working that hard and getting only a few minutes to shower.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve heard of things like that.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you want another option, we‚Äôve got a settlement at Canaan. Small city, even. Or a big town. We‚Äôve got extra rooms, food, and dangerously strong alcohol. We‚Äôre still trying to figure that out.‚Äù

I heard the rustle of papers.

‚ÄúCanaan?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúYes. Have you been?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve heard stories,‚Äù I said. I turned to the couple, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm ninety percent sure the Canaan area is Fallen territory. Outskirts of the megalopolis.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not really holding fast to all of that anymore,‚Äù the guy with the tattoos said. ‚ÄúWe said the world would end, we tried to draw attention to it, the world ended, we were right. Now we make the best of things.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat seems like a pretty skewed take,‚Äù I said.

He rolled his eyes as he looked away from me. He turned back to the couple. ‚ÄúYou have the directions. Easy to catch a bus to New Haven, catch another bus to the Hartford Stretch. Go to the address, we almost always have someone with a ride waiting there for the buses, to drive you into Canaan. The hard work has been done, it‚Äôs easier, it‚Äôs more fun, and there‚Äôs actual community. It‚Äôs one of the things that‚Äôs strangely missing from most parts in this city. You‚Äôll notice that.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù the guy from the couple said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll keep this.‚Äù

‚ÄúMcVeay, Crowley, or Mathers?‚Äù I asked.

The guy shot me an annoyed look. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhich family branch were or are you?‚Äù I asked. I turned to the couple. ‚ÄúThree branches, each loosely themed after one of the Endbringers. There was a nascent fourth in twenty-thirteen that was based on one or all of the other three, but I missed the memo on that.‚Äù

‚ÄúCrowley,‚Äù the guy said. ‚ÄúWe were the jackasses.‚Äù

‚ÄúMcVeays were the ultra-religious, more violent ones, loosely themed after Behemoth,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúMathers were the ones themed after the Simurgh. They‚Äôre still around too, they did a lot of the kidnappings of kids and capes, with intent to force marriages. Then you have the Crowleys, who were a little bit more than jackasses. Stirring panic, scaring people, violence.‚Äù

‚ÄúTo draw attention to the imminent end of the world,‚Äù the guy with the tattoos said. ‚ÄúDo you want us to apologize for trying to get people‚Äôs attention and failing? Or should we not have tried? We were right.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs there a problem?‚Äù

A woman‚Äôs voice. I thought it was the girl with the moons on her costume. It wasn‚Äôt. Another woman with tattoos, with friends. One of the tattoos was of a bat-winged schlong. Another was of a cartoon character I didn‚Äôt recognize getting spit-roasted, in the metal pole, open fire sense.

She had others, but I couldn‚Äôt see enough of them to tell what they were. I could guess they were similarly tasteful. Her top was tied at the sternum, exposing ribs and stomach.

‚ÄúJust a bit of one,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúYou guys are openly recruiting from this crowd here?‚Äù

‚ÄúRecruiting is an strange way to put it,‚Äù the guy with the tattoos said.

I looked at the couple. ‚ÄúIf it sounds too good to be true, it probably is. Free rent, free food, drinks, company?‚Äù

‚ÄúCheap rent,‚Äù the woman with the tattoos said. ‚ÄúA lot of people stay just long enough to make some extra money while commuting to Hartford and paying rent to us.‚Äù

‚ÄúAll we ask is that people who decide to go make sure to tell people that hey, we aren‚Äôt assholes,‚Äù the tattooed guy said.

‚ÄúWe aren‚Äôt assholes!‚Äù the burly guys who were keeping the woman company cheered in near-unison.

‚ÄúWhich Crowley is in charge?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúHey, bitch,‚Äù the woman said. ‚ÄúJust move on. Fuck off.‚Äù

The cheering had drawn attention. The teenage girl with the moons on her costume approached, ducking beneath one of the burly guy‚Äôs arms. She spotted me, saw that last exchange, and drew close to me, putting one hand on my shoulder.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the one Whorl was talking to?‚Äù she asked.

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúTake it from me, it‚Äôs not worth it. Come on.‚Äù

The guy with the tattoos smirked.

‚ÄúYou know they‚Äôre recruiting here, right?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúWe know,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve drawn attention to it. We were told to keep out of it, so long as they behave.‚Äù

She put pressure on my shoulder, urging me to move. I took one step back.

I didn‚Äôt want to let this go. I would have more regrets if I walked away.

‚ÄúWhich Crowley?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúThere were three brothers and one sister, last I heard.‚Äù

‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt matter,‚Äù the tattooed guy said.

‚ÄúEldest brother was a murderer, got ousted from the family for that, back in twenty-eleven, when the Fallen were still minor. But around the time their numbers swelled in twenty-twelve, early twenty-thirteen, he got accepted back, head of the Crowley branch. He killed two of his own family members after that. I think that matters a lot, since if he‚Äôs in charge, you can‚Äôt really call yourselves mere jackasses.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot him.‚Äù

There were a few more faces appearing in the crowd. Unfriendly.

The girl with the moon design leaned in close, murmuring in my ear, ‚ÄúThey have someone with powers in the crowd. They send people out to fish for recruits, and if there‚Äôs trouble, they have these reinforcements summoned into the middle of the crowd and they‚Äôll shout you down.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúMiddle brother and the sister were pretty skeevy too. They didn‚Äôt kidnap anyone directly, but they networked with the other families, gave shelter to some McVeays who needed to duck the attention of the law, and they traded a few of their family members for some of the kidnapped minors and capes the Mathers family had. I‚Äôd be concerned about going to that camp.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe little brother,‚Äù the guy with the tattoos said.

‚ÄúThe party animal,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what we‚Äôre about!‚Äù were the shouts. There was more of a raucous response from the other reinforcements. Cries and shouts of ‚Äòparty‚Äô. People throughout the crowd were looking.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôll try to steal your girlfriend before he makes you welcome!‚Äù I had to raise my voice to be heard. The people who were pushing forward made it harder for me to see the couple. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not worth it. You can look him up at a library. Jake Crowley! Four wives, all half his age!‚Äù

There were shouts and bellows of denial, a few swears directed my way. One ‚Äòcunt‚Äô, from someone close enough to have punched me if he‚Äôd felt the desire.

‚ÄúThrow away the paper,‚Äù I called out. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not worth it!‚Äù

With the press of bodies, I didn‚Äôt see the paper get thrown away. But I saw the guy hugging his girlfriend closer, I saw the fractional nod.

That was all I got. The moon girl pushed me harder, and I allowed myself to be pushed this time.

I walked backward out of the crowd, looking at the group. They were still making a lot of noise.

Whorl was waiting for me as I made my exit from the thicker part of the crowd. The mech tinker was standing on the head of his suit, now, and the suit was standing too, which gave him a decent vantage point overlooking everything.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to take an hour before they settle down,‚Äù Whorl said. ‚ÄúWhat was that about?‚Äù

‚ÄúFallen recruiters,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI know that much.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wanted to make sure the people they were talking to knew,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúTold them who the family was, how they operated, who the leader was.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou think they listened?‚Äù Moon girl asked.

‚ÄúThey might have,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt get the impression I was going to start a riot, so I thought I‚Äôd be okay trying.‚Äù

‚ÄúNah,‚Äù Whorl said, ‚ÄúYour impression was fine. No riot. They know to keep their hands to themselves, and just to be loud. They stick to the rules so they can keep coming back. We were told to let them, which sucks, but we have to work with the authorities.‚Äù

‚ÄúI told her that,‚Äù Moon girl said. ‚ÄúThat we were supposed to leave it be.‚Äù

‚ÄúBefore or after she stirred them up?‚Äù

‚ÄúBefore,‚Äù I answered for her. ‚ÄúI knew, I went ahead anyway.‚Äù

Whorl frowned.

‚ÄúI knew it would probably cost me my spot on the team,‚Äù I said.

Whorl nodded slowly.

‚ÄúBut if it stops one person from going over to that town of theirs‚Ä¶ I guess it‚Äôs worth it.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt might have worked,‚Äù Whorl said, ‚ÄúBut they‚Äôve got the reinforcements, they‚Äôll double down. They‚Äôll try harder, make up for it.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou guys are all about learning from the mistakes of the past,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúPaying respect to the casualties. You have to know they can‚Äôt be allowed to get a foothold. They‚Äôre too monstrous, and the people they‚Äôre going after are too vulnerable.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey have a foothold already,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre the guys who failed to stop the end of the world, and they‚Äôre the ones who were right about it. To some people that‚Äôs all that matters. It doesn‚Äôt matter that they‚Äôre scumbags or that they‚Äôre dangerous. Not everyone, but even one out of every thirty is a lot.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe should go calm things down,‚Äù Moon girl said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Whorl said. ‚ÄúDistract the people from the tattooed hooligans.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood luck with that,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúTake care, Victoria. Keep fighting the good fight, whatever you end up doing.‚Äù

I gave him a two finger salute.

I braced myself, both in balance and emotionally, then took to the air, moving slowly. I raised myself up to the same level as the guy at the end of the pole, staying within his field of vision so I wouldn‚Äôt surprise him.

They were using the powers to teleport people in. I couldn‚Äôt see where the fade-in happened or where the teleportation destination was, but as the crowd shuffled, there were more of the people with tattoos, trashy people, and people that didn‚Äôt look like refugees.

The guy on the end of the pole pointed. I moved closer to him, and followed the line of his arm and finger to see.

A man with a daughter, sitting on a blanket at the base of a fence.

‚ÄúThe girl or the man?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúThe man. He‚Äôs the one bringing them in. Keeps the kid close as a shield, in case someone catches on. Different kids, some days.‚Äù

I nodded.

‚ÄúI think every day of going over there and taking him out of the picture. Letting him know I know.‚Äù

‚ÄúWouldn‚Äôt be worth it,‚Äù I said.

The noises of the crowd of Fallen increased, a fresh chant. Heads were turning and people were smiling, because they didn‚Äôt know, and positivity and high energy meant a lot when they were as tired and despondent as they were. Some would have spent a long time waiting for their chance to come through.

A dangerous and vulnerable thing, to have no place to go.

Flare — 2.2

There was something to be said about the fact that the hospital was still in construction while it was running. There were patients in the waiting room, sitting in the chairs that had been bolted to the floor, and the unhappiness of needing a hospital visit was compounded by the fact that a third of the way across the room, behind a plastic sheet that had been taped to walls, ceiling and floor, a team was using power tools and calling out in loud voices as they built the rest of the room.

The hospital staff looked pretty miserable too, most of them sequestered on the other side of a counter, walled off from the patients by a plexiglass window. Security guards stood off to one side.

‚ÄúCan I help you?‚Äù a secretary asked.

‚ÄúI was wondering if it was possible for me to see a patient?‚Äù

‚ÄúVisiting hours are open. Patient‚Äôs name?‚Äù

‚ÄúFume Hood. I don‚Äôt know her real name.‚Äù

The secretary stopped, then looked at the male secretary, who sat at the other end of the counter. She looked past him at the security guard.

Of course.

‚ÄúI was one of the people giving her medical attention when the ambulance arrived,‚Äù I said. I knew it wouldn‚Äôt matter, that they would assume I‚Äôd been lying, but I hoped it would temper the reaction.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not accepting visitors,‚Äù the secretary said.

‚ÄúOne second,‚Äù I heard. A female voice.

Two overlapping sections of the plastic sheet peeled apart. Tempera ducked through, and put the tacky sides of the plastic back together. She was dusty from plaster and streaked with paint that wasn‚Äôt from her power. She wore overalls, a black t-shirt for a top, and had a different pattern to the paint she‚Äôd applied over her eyes with fingers, more like she had applied it to her fingers and pressed them to her eyes as a series of vertical bars, each bleeding into the one beside it.

‚ÄúHi, Victoria,‚Äù she said to me.

‚ÄúHi.‚Äù

She looked at the secretary, ‚ÄúWe know her. Can I take her back to the room?‚Äù
