‚ÄúLet me get her information, and I‚Äôll buzz you two through.‚Äù

I took the clipboard with the paperwork, and I filled out the information, checking my phone to remind myself of the specifics of Crystal‚Äôs address. She took the clipboard, read it over, and let us through.

We walked down the back halls of the hospital, past individual clinics and their signs and separate waiting areas, past patient rooms and nurse‚Äôs stations. Tempera indicated the turns. We didn‚Äôt rush it, an unspoken agreement that we‚Äôd take our time, have a chance to talk.

‚ÄúThere was one attempt on her life. We were worried there would be another,‚Äù Tempera said.

‚ÄúAre you standing guard?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI am keeping an eye on things, but mostly by accident. I‚Äôve been helping with the construction. I like getting my hands dirty,‚Äù Tempera said. She smiled as she held up one hand, which was covered in wet white ‚Äòpaint‚Äô down to the elbow, the paint turning black before transitioning to her light brown skin. ‚ÄúLook at you, though. You look tidy.‚Äù

Tidy. It was an amusing choice of words, when Tempera looked anything but. I smiled. ‚ÄúLooking around to see if any teams are looking to fill positions.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd?‚Äù

‚ÄúOnly one was actually posting any openings, a corporate team, Auzure. Foresight and the Attendant were open to interviewing me. There are two other big teams; one gave me a hard no, and the other is folding into the Attendant and won‚Äôt exist soon, they didn‚Äôt give me a response yet, and with how the talk with the Attendant went, I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôd work out.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre pretty conservative. In a lot of respects. A lot of the religious capes went to the Shepherds and will be part of the Attendant. I‚Äôve been paying close attention to that.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúOne or two of the sketchy people from Empire Eighty-Eight, too.‚Äù

‚ÄúEmpire Eighty-Eight? They sound familiar.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey had a presence for a while. A few years back they broke up into two other groups. The Pure and Fenrir‚Äôs Chosen.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh. I know the Chosen. They were linked to the Clans, I think?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes. The Clans spread out across multiple cities, and would funnel anyone who got powers over to the Empire Eighty-Eight core group, back before Leviathan broke the group‚Äôs back. They were a background element in my childhood and cape career.‚Äù

‚ÄúAhh. Was that a factor in your wanting to join?‚Äù

A very carefully neutral question, that. I wondered if she was prodding me, not declaring a stance while feeling me out. I was still an unknown, in a way.

‚ÄúViolent racists on the team? Definitely a factor, big point against. Question is, are they ex-violent, ex-racists? Gets muddier. Even then, I might draw the line there, and not join. If they were contrite? I could roll with that, I think. Barring one or two especially scummy individuals. Interview didn‚Äôt get far enough for me to raise the subject.‚Äù

Tempera nodded, not saying anything.

‚ÄúI think‚Ä¶ maybe I‚Äôm being unsubtle, saying it, but I think there‚Äôs a big difference between who those guys were and who Fume Hood is.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think so too.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow is she?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs hurt by what happened. It‚Äôs hard, to put yourself out there, face your shortcomings, try to be better, and get shot for it.‚Äù

‚ÄúPartial facing of shortcomings, from what she and I talked about,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs why I said face, instead of ‚Äòadmit‚Äô,‚Äù Tempera said. ‚ÄúBut I don‚Äôt want to quibble. Change of subject. You said your meeting went badly. Can I ask what happened?‚Äù

‚ÄúFallen,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúDid you get in another fight?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù I said. I sighed. ‚ÄúNo. They did what they often do, they caused a disruption, and that‚Äôs a playing field that suits them well. I‚Äôd call it a draw, but I‚Äôm pretty sure they‚Äôre still out there recruiting and I‚Äôm not out there counteracting that.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere will always be bad guys. They will always be out there. There will always be murders, there will be theft, there will be drugs.‚Äù

I nodded.

‚ÄúQuestion is,‚Äù Tempera said, ‚ÄúWhere do you want to be, in relation to that, as it happens?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat is a deceptively tricky question,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYou definitely put yourself out there, backing us up when things went sideways at the community center.‚Äù

‚ÄúI really appreciate that you see it that way,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYou put yourself in front of Lord of Loss. I don‚Äôt know how your power works, but it‚Äôs obvious you can bleed. There was some danger there.‚Äù

I acknowledged that with a small nod.

‚ÄúAnd now you‚Äôre interviewing for teams? So soon after? It sounds like you want to be out there, helping.‚Äù

‚ÄúI do. I‚Äôm zero for three, though.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt want to be independent? Hold on a second. We‚Äôre nearly at the room, but let‚Äôs finish talking before we go in.‚Äù

We stopped midway down the hallway. A nurse‚Äôs station was a short distance away.

‚ÄúI—‚Äù I started. ‚ÄúI think, the way things are going, I might end up going that way. Teams are a complication of their own.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey are,‚Äù Tempera said. ‚ÄúI had a phone call earlier, offering a position. I can go right there and sign the paperwork if I want to.‚Äù

‚ÄúWith?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Attendant, as it happens,‚Äù Tempera said.

I was momentarily lost for words. She‚Äôd been doing what I‚Äôd thought, inviting me to answer without declaring a position, but from a different angle.

‚ÄúI want to wait and see how the merger with the Shepherds shakes up, how it feels after, they said not to wait too long. It‚Äôs decent money, decent exposure. A lot of decency.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt let what I said change your mind on anything. I‚Äôm griping, it‚Äôs—‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI invited you to gripe, if we‚Äôre going to use your word. It‚Äôs interesting to hear that take on them. I didn‚Äôt know about the racist ex-villains joining. I‚Äôm curious about how they handled the Fallen there, too, in your situation.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think, uh, don‚Äôt tell them I said this‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù

‚Äú‚Ä¶I think they or the people they‚Äôre taking guidance from are approaching that stance of there always being bad guys to deal with, and they‚Äôre deciding to conserve their energy. To not fight that fight. Maybe it‚Äôs right to.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou got a draw. That‚Äôs better than a win for the bad guys there.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs— yeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI tried to use reason, draw on the stuff I studied, old knowledge I had about the group. Who they were, how they operate, the families, the names. Put that information out there, so the potential recruits would know the key facts. I tried to get them to say who their leader was, pressed the issue, and of course it was the least bad one, so the argument I was gunning for didn‚Äôt have much clout, and I lost steam.‚Äù

‚ÄúI picture the Fallen as a group that‚Äôs pretty comfortable defying reason.‚Äù

‚ÄúThem, yes. The recruits, I think they were open to hearing it. I threw out some more information I remembered at the last second, but the Fallen were getting pretty loud, I didn‚Äôt want to start a riot, and that was more or less it.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd the Attendant?‚Äù

‚ÄúWeren‚Äôt keen on me making a point of things when the word from on high was to let the Fallen be. I didn‚Äôt get my invite to the team.‚Äù

Tempera made a face.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like ignoring the monsters. And I do think the Fallen are monstrous, as a collective force.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre a headache I was always glad I wouldn‚Äôt have to deal with,‚Äù Tempera said. She scratched her nose as she scrunched it up, the paint there highlighting the creases. The scratching deposited more paint on the bridge. ‚ÄúOne I guess I‚Äôll have to prepare myself for dealing with. Or possibly not dealing with, if I take the Attendant‚Äôs offer.‚Äù

‚ÄúPossibly,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt give my words too much weight.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll try to be sensible about it. I might end up asking those questions you didn‚Äôt get a chance to, if that‚Äôs okay.‚Äù

I nodded.

‚ÄúI think I‚Äôll be okay, whatever happens. The Wardens facilitated Attendant‚Äôs contact with me, and from their tone, I think they‚Äôd push to get me on another team if I didn‚Äôt go with that one.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs great,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI could put in a word for you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt say no,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think I‚Äôll get my hopes up, either.‚Äù

Tempera frowned.

‚ÄúSorry. I didn‚Äôt mean to sound negative.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you finding your way, with these setbacks?‚Äù

I shrugged. ‚ÄúComplicated. Just wanted to check in on Fume Hood, while things are quiet. When the law or the system fail to outline a process, do what seems right. When it‚Äôs not clear what‚Äôs right, go with the law. When neither is clear, reach out.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor perspective?‚Äù

I shrugged. ‚ÄúThat too. More eyes on a problem never hurts.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnother point for the team, instead of going independent,‚Äù Tempera said. She looked back down the hall, in the direction we‚Äôd been walking to. ‚ÄúHold on a moment? I‚Äôll check if she‚Äôs decent. I wouldn‚Äôt mind bringing Fume Hood into it, now that we‚Äôre past the semi-confidential stuff about other teams.‚Äù

I nodded.

She touched the wall by the door as she rounded the corner, stepping into the room, and she knocked on the door as she entered.

There was a brief pause. The handprint of paint on the wall dropped to the floor with a splat as Tempera said, ‚ÄúCome in.‚Äù

The blob of paint on the door fell to the ground as well. Both moved along the ground as I entered, spattering against the back of Tempera‚Äôs shoes and the back of her overalls.

Fume Hood had donned a mask, but she didn‚Äôt wear the hood. She lay down on the bed, which was angled so she could sit up at an angle. A blanket had been pulled up to her waist, covering her legs.

Crystalclear sat in the chair between her and the window, the crystal configuration on his head slightly different than before. He wore a t-shirt and shorts. There was something odd about a guy with crystals where his eyes and hair would be having very ordinary hairy legs.

‚ÄúHeya,‚Äù Crystalclear said.

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúHey, patrol girl with a name I can‚Äôt remember,‚Äù Fume Hood said.

‚ÄúVictoria,‚Äù Tempera volunteered.

‚ÄúVictoria. Right. Thank you for helping to hold my blood in,‚Äù Fume Hood said.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre very welcome,‚Äù I said. I noted the flowers and cards sitting beneath the window. ‚ÄúSorry I didn‚Äôt bring anything. This is my awkward ‚ÄòI was in the neighborhood‚Äô visit. I saw the hospital name and remembered you were brought out this way.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got too much as it is. Turns out that the key to popularity and acceptance is to get yourself shot.‚Äù

Her tone was light, almost amused. Tempera had said Fume Hood was hurt on an emotional level, but I didn‚Äôt see a sign of it. I could remember how Tempera had acted on my first meeting with her, how in tune with her team she had been. I was willing to put a lot of stock in her take on things.

‚ÄúVictoria, what I was going to say, before deciding I‚Äôd rather say it here, was that we‚Äôre going our separate ways, yes—‚Äù

‚ÄúLongscratch is already gone,‚Äù Crystalclear said. ‚ÄúBut I don‚Äôt think he was ever going to stick around on a permanent basis.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Tempera said. ‚ÄúWhich is a shame. I do hope he finds what he‚Äôs looking for. My point is, I don‚Äôt want to lose touch. It‚Äôs helpful and nice that Crystalclear happened to be here to help illustrate that maintenance of contact.‚Äù

‚ÄúHappy to take credit,‚Äù Crystalclear said.

‚ÄúVictoria said— if you don‚Äôt mind me repeating?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe said that it‚Äôs important to reach out, if I‚Äôm recalling that right. I‚Äôd like to stay friends with you,‚Äù Tempera said. ‚ÄúCrystalclear, Fume Hood. Victoria, you too.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù Fume Hood asked.

‚ÄúWhat do you mean?‚Äù Tempera asked.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre very different people,‚Äù Fume Hood said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt get how that works. How do you stay in touch with people you have very little in common with?‚Äù

‚ÄúEasy. Grab a bite sometime,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúSandwich, beer or soda, share stories, get different perspectives. I wouldn‚Äôt mind.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôd be nice,‚Äù Crystalclear said.

‚ÄúBut—‚Äù Fume Hood started. She frowned. ‚ÄúOkay, whatever.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou should find the words for what you‚Äôre trying to say,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIn case it festers or gets in the way.‚Äù

‚ÄúI dunno. I don‚Äôt get why you‚Äôre here. I‚Äôm grateful, don‚Äôt get me wrong. You put pressure on my wound, Tempera gave me first aid and used her paint to keep me from dying. I probably owe you my lives. But that whole fiasco was my fault.‚Äù

‚ÄúI blame the attacking villains, not you,‚Äù Tempera said.

‚ÄúYep,‚Äù Crystalclear said.

‚ÄúAre you trying to be clever and get me to keep being a hero, then?‚Äù Fume Hood asked.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm here because I was interested in how you were doing,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúObviously I‚Äôd prefer it if you stayed a hero, but that‚Äôs not the objective.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you guys keep showing up with flowers or to make small talk, you make it awfully hard for me to fuck off and go back to being a villain.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a plus,‚Äù Tempera said. ‚ÄúBut like Victoria said, it‚Äôs not the main point.‚Äù

‚ÄúOn the topic of pluses,‚Äù I said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm interested in who those guys were. So if you hear anything, I wouldn‚Äôt mind a heads up.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe guy who shot me did so of sound mind, no Kingdom Come in play. Independent, apparently. No money in his accounts, he didn‚Äôt have internet. He was just pissed off.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere were the villains, too,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThere were.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd we don‚Äôt know what they were after,‚Äù Crystalclear said.

‚ÄúMultiple conflicting stories,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúBlindside lied to me when I asked. It bothers me, and I worry it‚Äôll happen again.‚Äù

‚ÄúGive me your cell phone number,‚Äù Tempera said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll get in touch.‚Äù

There was a brief pause while we sorted things out, me getting the contact information from each of the others, and giving them mine. They already knew each other.

Reaching out, making and maintaining contact.

A part of me had hoped that Fume Hood was wrong, that the team wouldn‚Äôt have dissolved, that they‚Äôd be together, willing to give things another try. That it might have been a team I could join.

‚ÄúThe cards and flowers might have something to do with how you‚Äôre the topic of the moment,‚Äù I mused aloud.

‚ÄúI heard something about that,‚Äù Fume Hood said, indicating Crystalclear.

‚ÄúFrom me,‚Äù Crystalclear volunteered unnecessarily.

‚ÄúIf you guys were to try again, there could be more attention, more support,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúMore gunshots?‚Äù Fume Hood asked. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm stepping down and going into hiding. I‚Äôll recuperate, let the heat die down, and then figure out what I‚Äôm doing.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf it matters, I think more people are siding with you than not,‚Äù I said.

Fume Hood nodded a few times, taking that in. ‚ÄúWeird.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good,‚Äù Tempera said. ‚ÄúI think Crystalclear already accepted the offer from Foresight, though.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was a very promising offer.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôve been contacted by Attendant. I don‚Äôt know what I‚Äôll do with that. And Victoria—‚Äù

‚ÄúIs not having much luck,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúBut I want to do something.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou were thinking you might go independent?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhich doesn‚Äôt pay,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúNot in this environment.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow does that work?‚Äù Fume Hood asked. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre a crook, it‚Äôs easy, you take jobs at the villain bar, or you rob some place, or any number of things. You just‚Ä¶ go out on patrol?‚Äù

‚ÄúThere are a few other things to do,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúOne way is to essentially run a protection racket that isn‚Äôt a racket. It‚Äôs easy for that to go wrong. There‚Äôs a higher level effect, which is easier to pull off when, say, a city has a downtown area and the shop owners gather together to pay a wage to the hero that draws attention and has a positive influence on their area‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúThings have to be stable before that happens,‚Äù Tempera said.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not there yet,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs training and support. Offering powers for helping with the rebuilding, which Auzure was doing a bit of. There‚Äôs merchandising, but that‚Äôs a dead market right now, I think.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe fished in that pond prior to getting underway and we didn‚Äôt get any bites,‚Äù Crystalclear said.

‚ÄúI was selling my brain, I know a lot about capes and the community, having grown up with it. That job‚Äôs done, and I don‚Äôt know if there‚Äôs much more opportunity for that.‚Äù

‚ÄúTell you what,‚Äù Tempera said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll put out feelers. See what people say.‚Äù

I nodded. ‚ÄúSure. Thank you.‚Äù

‚äô

I was lost in thought enough that my retracing of my steps on the way out of the hospital turned me in circles. I approached the same nurse‚Äôs station for a second time, and I stopped at the desk, waiting for someone with a spare moment to give me directions.

I wanted to do something.

There weren‚Äôt any openings. I was pretty sure Advance Guard had turned me down because of my background, the two year gap prior to Gold Morning. Others had their reasons for rejecting me. As it was, the field was fairly cluttered. Villains were keeping their heads down. As much as there was always going to be the bad guys, like Tempera had said, we didn‚Äôt have the systems in place to identify them or address them.

No way to make money off of my powers, to pay the rent and get out of Crystal‚Äôs borderline uncomfortably cluttered place.

‚ÄúYes?‚Äù a nurse asked.

I blinked. I didn‚Äôt ask her for directions. My thoughts went in another direction, spurred to life by my thoughts of the unpaid cape work.

‚ÄúIf I said ‚Äòcrisis points‚Äô, would that mean anything to you?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been a long time since I heard that. Yes, it means something. Do you work with capes?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Ä¶ kind of am a cape. Would you be open to me giving you a hand?‚Äù

‚ÄúLet me look into it. I‚Äôm not sure what the usual methods are, and it‚Äôs not fresh in my mind.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôd want to identify the key patients, check with any parents, if they‚Äôre under eighteen, and they often are. Then with me, you‚Äôd want to check with legal, you can call my references, which I do have on hand‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚äô

The mask wasn‚Äôt the quality sort I was used to, more of a Halloween costume. The top I wore was a men‚Äôs small, a little too big in the shoulder, while it simultaneously squashed my chest.

From the ages of the patients in the pediatric wing, I wasn‚Äôt sure they would pay much mind to my chest, squashed or not. Most were twelve or younger. A few heads turned, people paying cursory attention.

I still wore the skirt I‚Äôd worn to the interviews, the belt.

Room 5, bed C.

I entered room five. There were four beds, one in each corner. One monitor was beeping, the other kids were lying down, looking bored.

Bed C was a little girl, with a face chock full of freckles, and sandy blonde hair. The curtains had been partially closed, blocking the views of the boy sitting to her left and the girl sitting across from her.

‚ÄúAudrey?‚Äù I asked, peering in.

I saw only a glimpse of misery on her expression, while she stared off out the window. Then she raised her head and the expression was gone. She assessed me, head to toe.

‚ÄúGreat,‚Äù she said, after she was done.

‚ÄúGreat?‚Äù

‚ÄúOoh, yay, it‚Äôs Legend, except he‚Äôs a girl now,‚Äù she said, sarcastic.

The t-shirt I wore was styled after Legend‚Äôs costume. The mask was the same. Something the staff had kept on hand from the past Halloween.

‚ÄúThe nurses pointed me your way,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWell, my day sucked, but now fake Lady Legend is here, so I‚Äôm all better. That‚Äôs great.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can take the mask off if you want,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúOh, no, you can‚Äôt do that, fake Lady Legend. Your secret identity might be compromised!‚Äù

The sarcasm ran strong through this one.

I pulled the curtain closed a bit more, then pulled off the mask, flying a bit as I said, ‚ÄúI never really had the secret identity.‚Äù

With that, at least, her eyebrows went up. No smart retort. She moved around her hospital bed, craning her head to see my feet, trying to spot the trick.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know you,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt matter,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThe nurses mentioned you‚Äôd had an especially bad day.‚Äù

Again, that momentary look of misery.

Yeah, I knew that.

‚ÄúBack before everything turned sour, when I‚Äôd come to the hospital, with, um—‚Äù I stopped, drew in a breath, and sighed. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs something heroes would do. Check in on people who had really bad days. And when I came to the hospital, sometimes I‚Äôd do that.‚Äù

Crisis points. More a PRT thing than a New Wave thing, but we‚Äôd done a small share. Looking out for the recent triggers, putting our faces and names out there, staying in touch with the public.

‚ÄúA nurse sat down with me for a while,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúNo offense, I appreciate it, but I‚Äôm kind of talked out.‚Äù

‚ÄúInstead of talking, um,‚Äù I said. I showed her what was in my hand, letting the straps dangle. ‚ÄúWhat would you say about going flying?‚Äù

I saw her eyes go wide.

‚ÄúThe hospital called your dad‚Äôs work. He said it was okay.‚Äù

‚äô

My feet left the hospital rooftop. Flying was unwieldy, especially with my burden. I was untrained. Having the benefit of my forcefield to protect me in the event of a crash would mean having my forcefield up, and that had other connotations, with my power as distorted as it was, the fact that I couldn‚Äôt necessarily control the movements or know what they would do. Not doable, when I held someone.

There was uncertainty too. The source of that flight, it had never let me down, but if push came to shove, in a crisis, would my maneuvering be sloppier? Would I decelerate or accelerate in a different way? I‚Äôd carelessly trusted my power, once, and now I wasn‚Äôt sure I could. I knew what the source of that power was, now, and what its goals were.

It was emotionally heavy, even as I felt almost weightless physically, to be reminded of what had changed so dramatically.

I could feel my charge‚Äôs intake of breath, as I held one arm across her lower ribs. I didn‚Äôt trust the harness we‚Äôd grabbed from the physio center. Not enough to hold someone for me. She was strapped with her back to my front.

The ground was a good ways below us now. I hadn‚Äôt even ascended that fast. I‚Äôd been a little lost in thought.

I felt her laugh, nervous and small, while I turned us around, giving her a view of the area. Norfair and its community center was off in the distance, one way. The farms were off in another direction. From here, it was easy to see the tall buildings of the city, the places that looked like a slice of the old world. To look to the fringes of those areas, where the tents and shoddily erected structures stretched off, so endless it seemed they reached to the horizon.

‚ÄúI got you,‚Äù I said, in answer to the nervous giggles. Had I laughed like that, on my first real flight?

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù was the response, a small, quiet voice. Then more giggles.

The giggle became laughter on her part, borderline hysterical.

‚ÄúYou okay?‚Äù

She nodded, fast and fierce, then drew in a deep breath.

‚ÄúWooooooooo!‚Äù she whooped, top of her lungs, loud enough to be heard on the ground.

‚ÄúHood up,‚Äù I said, reaching up to tug the hood of her hoodie over her head.

‚ÄúWhat? Why?‚Äù she asked, panting from the cheer.

‚ÄúJust in case it‚Äôs cold,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúCold? Why—‚Äù

Before she could fully catch her breath, I dropped from our position, diving, fast, hard, and surprising enough that even I felt my stomach‚Äôs contents lurch.

She didn‚Äôt have the ability to cheer, as the drop stole what little breath she had, but her arms went up and out, to either side of my shoulders, fingers spreading to feel the wind, the sun-warmed air.

I smiled, letting the swoop dash all of the other thoughts and feelings from my mind, vicariously enjoying the experience of flying for the first time. Of flying at all.

‚äô

‚ÄúJuan?‚Äù I asked.

Juan was younger than the other kids had been. Eight, if I had to guess, but he wasn‚Äôt well, so that might have screwed up my estimation. He was thin at the arm and wrist, and puffy around the face.

‚ÄúThe first time I came to the hospital, one of the nurses wore that costume,‚Äù Juan said. ‚ÄúHe was a guy though.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow does it look on me?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI think it looks really nice,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre very pretty.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs sweet.‚Äù

‚ÄúSome of the others were saying a lady superhero was going around taking people flying.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the plan. Your mom and dad said you might enjoy it, and you should be well enough.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey had to go to work,‚Äù Juan said.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what I heard.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey always have to go. Even when I have bad days. And there‚Äôs nothing on television. There‚Äôs only three channels and they‚Äôre real boring.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI really hate hospitals,‚Äù he said.

I took a deep breath. His words echoed my feelings, which only magnified the feelings.

Yeah. I really hated hospitals too.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs getting dark,‚Äù I said, ‚ÄúBut if you want to try flying, maybe that‚Äôd be a bit of a break from the boring stuff, and a break from the hospital.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù Juan said. ‚ÄúBut flying sounds like it‚Äôs very tiring.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt can be,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI can go slow if you like, or we can do something else. We could talk.‚Äù

He nodded at that last bit, then started looking around. I pulled up a nearby chair, and sat down next to his bed.

‚ÄúI got a lot of books,‚Äù Juan said. He deposited a stack of kids‚Äô books and comics on the edge of the bed, between me and him. ‚ÄúUh, before. I said I didn‚Äôt want to be stuck here and be bored, my mom went and came back with books and comics, and then they both left.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat was nice of them,‚Äù I said. I picked up one of the books.

‚ÄúMy eyes are tired today,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe letters are blurry.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you want me to read some out loud?‚Äù I asked.

That got me a firm nod, and the first smile I‚Äôd seen out of him.

‚ÄúGood Simon to start, then?‚Äù I asked. Another nod.

There were pictures, so he shuffled over to the edge of the bed, and I sat on the other side, my ass half on the bed‚Äôs railing, and I held the book between us, so we could both see it.

Two good Simon books, which were most likely aimed at someone just a bit younger than Juan was, but he didn‚Äôt seem to complain. I moved on to a comic involving the robot prison ship, peeking ahead so I could skip past the scenes which were aimed at someone much older than him, and then, to be safe, moved on to something aimed at a younger age again. Kids in animal masks getting into trouble.

There wasn‚Äôt much likelihood that Juan had powers, but he‚Äôd had a bad day, and this was okay.

I was halfway through that book when I saw someone look in at the door, peeking around. A boy. He stopped as he spotted me.

I finished the page, then paused, partially closing the book, and checking on Juan. Fast asleep. I checked his pulse, because I was paranoid, then fixed his blankets, and eased myself up off the bed with flight, to not disturb him.

I used a notepad by the side of the bed, and wrote a brief farewell:

Nice to meet you, Juan. The nurses have my number so if you want to go flying sometime, we might be able to arrange something. üôÇ
-Victoria

I walked over to the door. It wasn‚Äôt one of the ones I‚Äôd taken a flight with. Older, thirteen or so, with what might have been his first pimples.

I saw the hesitation on his face.

‚ÄúCome on,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs go to the cafeteria. It‚Äôs late, I don‚Äôt think many people will be around.‚Äù

He nodded.

‚äô

‚ÄúHello?‚Äù

‚ÄúTempera? Hi, it‚Äôs Victoria. I‚Äôm sorry to call you so late.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine. I don‚Äôt sleep much, and the call is more than welcome. Why the call?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm at the hospital, talking to someone—‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre still at the hospital?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes. I‚Äôve been talking to a teenager, he‚Äôs listening in on my half of the conversation right now. He‚Äôs got a friend with powers, but she‚Äôs not doing so hot. It‚Äôs new and it‚Äôs scary and neither he nor she know what to do.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been there.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been there. Yeah. I know you‚Äôre in touch with the Wardens. They‚Äôre decent, they have a lot of resources, they have some good people.‚Äù

‚ÄúAbsolutely.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe can describe particulars and you can let them know.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot a problem. Just so you know, it might be hard to get someone on the phone this late, but if it‚Äôs a problem, I know some people I can round up and we can go talk to her as a big supportive group.‚Äù

‚ÄúGreat. I‚Äôm going to hand you off now.‚Äù

‚ÄúWait, one second. Victoria.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes?‚Äù

‚ÄúCall me back when this is over, or call me first thing in the morning. I was sounding out some people, it‚Äôs not an invite to a team or anything, but with something this messy, we need all the hands we can get.‚Äù

‚ÄúMessy?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll explain later. For now, we help your buddy there.‚Äù

I handed the corded phone over. We stood at an empty nurse‚Äôs station in a hallway where the lights had been set dim. My hands were free, and I‚Äôd intentionally used their phone so my own would be free.

There were other calls I needed to make, including one to Crystal to let her know where I was. I put that one off. Crystal was easygoing.

I sent one to Mrs. Yamada.

Me:
I know your caseload is full, but found a kid with some power-related troubles. Contact is reaching out to Wardens soon. Maybe you can keep an eye out to make sure all goes smooth?

The boy was explaining in a hushed voice about his friend‚Äôs circumstance. An uncontrolled, messy power, and she had no place to go. He hadn‚Äôt given me many details, but I could tell he was scared, and I could infer from that that she must be terrified.

The reply came back.

Jessica:
Absolutely. I can‚Äôt promise I take them as a patient but I can help with initial moves.

I nodded to myself.

The boy was relaxing as he talked on the phone. A distant, authoritative, kind voice, and the promise of some answers or help.

My phone buzzed again.

Jessica:
A patient canceled for later this week. Do you want to meet for a late lunch? There‚Äôs something I‚Äôd like to talk to you about.

Flare — 2.3

It was dark as the boy and I stepped outside. It was a flipping of perspectives, in a way, that the city lights were going out and the tent villages off in the distance were lighting up with lamps and fires. The city had only a small fraction of the light it might have had in the old world when power rationing wasn‚Äôt in effect, only a tenth the normal number of apartments were lit up. Only the major roads had light, and that meant far less people were driving, which meant less head and tail lights.

It was cool out, not as cold as it had been last night, thankfully.

It was five minutes before Tempera met us at the door. She looked a little worn out, but then again, she‚Äôd gone to the hospital, gone home, come back to the hospital, and she was juggling something with the messy situation she‚Äôd talked to me about.

‚ÄúHi Victoria. Hi Sam.‚Äù

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù Sam said.

‚ÄúOn a scale of one to ten, how serious is your friend‚Äôs situation?‚Äù

‚ÄúUh. Six? She‚Äôs depressed, she‚Äôs scared, she doesn‚Äôt know how to use her power, and I can‚Äôt get near her to help her. She‚Äôs afraid people are going to take her away.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow immediate is the situation? Does she need help in the next five minutes, next hour, today? Is she or anyone else in danger?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs alive, but I‚Äôd like to get her help soon. She‚Äôs freaking out and I don‚Äôt know what to do.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm only asking like this because it‚Äôs an emergency, and since our talk on the phone it‚Äôs escalating. I‚Äôm going to take you to the Wardens headquarters, okay? I‚Äôm going that way already, I can walk you through the security and introduce you to some people, and they‚Äôll have ideas on what to do with your friend. Sound good?‚Äù

‚ÄúSounds alright.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the emergency?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúCitizen labor is going nuts. They‚Äôre massing, pulling in some outside help, a lot of other angry and frustrated citizens. I don‚Äôt have the full picture yet, but it‚Äôs all hands on deck. Wardens are coordinating Advance Guard, Foresight, Shepherds, the Attendant and others. They‚Äôre even bringing in the PRTCJ capes, which haven‚Äôt exactly been advertised to the public.‚Äù

Crystal‚Äôs group. The situation was bad enough to open the can of worms that was capes serving as a military-adjunct force? In this climate, no less.

Tempera went on, ‚ÄúI and some of the other prospective Wardens are being asked to go with the Wardens proper, to handle things where they‚Äôre getting out of control offworld.‚Äù

‚ÄúOffworld?‚Äù

‚ÄúI recommended you, said you‚Äôd help, they‚Äôve given a tentative a-ok on that. Things are expected to blow up when the city wakes up tomorrow, so it‚Äôs up to you if you want to help tonight or first thing tomorrow. I sent you the address?‚Äù

‚ÄúI got it,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI should go. Sam, with me.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood luck,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúSorry to pass the ball like this.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine. Good luck to you too, Victoria.‚Äù

I checked my phone, waiting painful minutes for sites to load.

She‚Äôd said I could help tonight or tomorrow. That things would get bad starting tomorrow.

The news sites already had multiple headlines with the word ‚Äòwar‚Äô followed by a question mark. And things were expected to get worse tomorrow?

No, I‚Äôd go tonight.

I‚Äôd fly, even. I messaged Crystal.

‚äô

I let myself into Crystal‚Äôs apartment through the balcony, using the key Crystal had given me on the sliding glass door.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm here,‚Äù I called out.

I was about to step from the living room to the hallway when a red-tinted forcefield appeared across the path, blocking my way.

‚ÄúOne moment!‚Äù Crystal called out.

I turned my back to the forcefield and leaned against it, my arms folded. ‚ÄúCan I talk to you from here?‚Äù

‚ÄúYep!‚Äù

‚ÄúThe headlines are saying war,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúAnd you‚Äôre being brought in.‚Äù

‚ÄúCould go that way,‚Äù Crystal said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs wonky. Two sides are butting heads and we‚Äôve got another world that‚Äôs pretty upset.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve only heard bits and pieces from some others and the news. Is it a strike?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot a strike. I‚Äôm dressed now, you can come through,‚Äù Crystal said. The forcefield disappeared, and I used flight to keep from falling, turning myself around before walking down the hallway and around the bend to Crystal‚Äôs room.

Crystal had already been in costume and with her group when she‚Äôd been ordered to get ready and be at the location within half an hour. She was using the opportunity to help get me organized. She‚Äôd showered while waiting for me, she‚Äôd donned her costume, and she was combing wet hair now.

Her costume was white, with her usual symbol on it, the arrow pointing down and to the side, with a stream of lines flowing from the back of the arrow, over one shoulder. She wore a jacket with it, a near-black gray, given a faint magenta-red tint. ‚ÄòPRTCJ‚Äô was printed on the back in big white letters. A lone stylized chevron was on the sleeve.

There were things to be said about it, about the militaristic tilt of the group, the way the PRT and the Protectorate had broken in such a way that the Wardens had sprung up from one large chunk of the image, presentation and ideals. Crystal‚Äôs parahuman miltary thing was crudely forged from another chunk of what the PRT had been: the PRT‚Äôs old laws, rules, and discipline. A military-esque force without a government to serve or a hard and fast system of law to back it up.

But it was Crystal‚Äôs call. Crystal‚Äôs thing. I held my tongue.

‚ÄúMy closet,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBlack trash bags. Never throwing things away pays off. It‚Äôs one of the sample batches.‚Äù

The bags made the clothes easy to find, even in the jam-packed closet. The contents were hidden within the trash bags, the hooks of the hangers poking up and through. Crystal indicated the bed, and I laid them out, peeling the plastic back. White costumes without icons or decoration, a variety of cuts and styles.

It was a familiar range. Back in the day, companies had periodically reached out to New Wave, wanting to pitch their product and get us to use them for our costuming. Mom had handled those talks and periodically singled out a family member to send a bunch of proto-costumes to. Later she would nag us for feedback that she could send the companies.

I didn‚Äôt want to think about mom.

I focused on the costumes, with some attention paid to the situation at hand. The leotard cut was a ‚Äònever ever‚Äô. The full-body suit was problematic because of how it resembled Scion‚Äôs, and I didn‚Äôt want to go there. Those were two I could eliminate right away. I pulled the black trash bags down over them and set them aside.

Crystal explained, ‚ÄúPeople have been noting how fast we got back on our feet, and how we have something reasonably stable in currency and economy. We kind of got our answer.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said, before guessing, ‚Äúpowers?‚Äù

‚ÄúI guess powers, probably,‚Äù she said.

I turned to look at Crystal. She was arranging her damp hair over her eye, a curved swoop that her hairband held in place. ‚ÄúOnly probably?‚Äù

‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt about powers,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBut I wouldn‚Äôt rule them out. They helped and they may be part of this. The key thing is that a lot of the building materials and resources we used to get started came from other worlds.‚Äù

‚ÄúAs in our people working in other worlds or—‚Äù I paused as Crystal shook her head. ‚ÄúOr other, alternate civilizations. Shit. You don‚Äôt get anything of that scale for free. What did we have to give them in exchange?‚Äù

‚ÄúI have no idea,‚Äù Crystal said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think many people do. There are two major groups heading the reconstruction that might have an idea but they haven‚Äôt shared. One of those groups was the one who put out the trading dollar a few months after Gold Morning, now our de-facto regular dollar. Same group that‚Äôs now looking at moving up into the greater political arena.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd those two groups are the ones butting heads?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúNo, the two construction groups are banding together, kind of. The workers who have been doing the actual construction work seem to think they were promised a significant discount and first opportunity to buy the houses they‚Äôve been building. They‚Äôve been living in a tent village, working long weeks, miserable conditions.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd if they think they have dibs on the houses, the work must have been a labor of love. They‚Äôll have a strong community too. If they didn‚Äôt kill each other working that hard in conditions that bad, they must be close.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Crystal said. ‚ÄúOne second, be right back.‚Äù

I glanced over the remaining outfits. Three more options. V-neck, long-sleeved, short skirt. Not bad, but very reminiscent of ‚ÄòGlory Girl‚Äô.

Round neck, low enough to have a touch of cleavage, short sleeves, and shorts that cut straight across the upper thigh. If any length were taken from them at all, they wouldn‚Äôt qualify as shorts anymore. Hard to pull off. I‚Äôd need to accessorize it and I wasn‚Äôt sure I could afford the time to dig for boots, belt, or other stuff I‚Äôd need, and still get filled in.

The last one had a high collar, a kind of truncated turtleneck, it was sleeveless, with leggings that ended in the mid-low calf. Not bad but not great, and again, I‚Äôd need accessories.

Urg.

‚ÄúThe two construction groups are collaborating, banding together, the areas rezoned, contracts reworked. They say workers signed and agreed, and there are no longer ‚Äòdibs‚Äô, as you put it.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor something that matters as much as home and shelter, with that many employees, you‚Äôd think someone would have read the contract thoroughly enough to figure that out.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have no idea,‚Äù Crystal said.

‚ÄúSounds like someone‚Äôs not being honest.‚Äù

‚ÄúAgain, Victoria, I don‚Äôt know,‚Äù Crystal said, sounding a little exasperated. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm— we‚Äôre, if you‚Äôre coming, we‚Äôre not going there or being invited there to arbitrate or negotiate. We‚Äôre not solving that particular problem. We‚Äôre there to stand between the two sides, keep the peace.‚Äù

I glanced at her jacket. ‚ÄúJust following orders.‚Äù

‚ÄúFollowing orders, keeping things simple, letting others handle things,‚Äù Crystal said. ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

I nodded. ‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

I picked up the second costume, with the low neck, short sleeves, and short leggings, and held it up against my front.

‚ÄúGo for it,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúYou definitely need to dress that up.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to go get changed and see if I can find footwear. If you have a minute, could you find any belts?‚Äù

‚ÄúUtility or regular?‚Äù

‚ÄúEither or. I like the idea of utility more, I think, for how I think I‚Äôll be dressing up.‚Äù

I stepped out of Crystal‚Äôs room, pulled the curtain closed by the balcony door and quickly stripped out of my top and the skirt. I picked both up and put them with my other clothes.

I experienced a brief moment of displaced emotion, as if my head and body were in Crystal‚Äôs apartment, and my heart was somewhere in the past. In an exposed, open area that wasn‚Äôt mine, wasn‚Äôt comfortable, where someone could happen to step in and see me exposed at any moment.

The latent feeling of the hospital room. Of being in the care home.

Pulling the costume on helped. Deep breaths, the pull of the zipper as it closed at my back and pulled material tight against my chest and stomach. I fixed the legs, checked for bunching and wrinkles, and deemed it satisfactory. Not perfect in the way a costume made explicitly for me would be, but satisfactory.

I dug in boxes. I‚Äôd packed my things with shoes and boots at the bottom, clothes on top.

‚ÄúBelts,‚Äù Crystal said. I heard the clatter as the things were tossed onto the couch. ‚ÄúMasks. Armband.‚Äù

The bag rustled as it bounced off the couch and landed on the floor. the armband landed on the couch near the belts. A black band with the Gold Morning symbol on it.

‚ÄúGood throws,‚Äù I said. Crystal was standing with her back to me. She‚Äôd tossed them over her shoulder. ‚ÄúYou can turn around.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt spend too much time. It‚Äôs late, it‚Äôs dark, people won‚Äôt care too much.‚Äù

‚ÄúI won‚Äôt. Where does the other Earth and the war fit into this?‚Äù I asked. I pulled out a pair of white boots. Shoes meant for a costume might have worked better, but I tended to prefer boots for the fact that they stayed on better with hard landings, kicks, and rough falls. Fourteen year old Glory Girl had learned that lesson: it was terminally embarrassing to have a petty criminal watch as you flew over to your lost shoe and put it back on.

‚ÄúThe workers called a stop to all work. They‚Äôre holding the houses, equipment, and building materials hostage, with some suggestion they‚Äôll destroy it all before they give up what they‚Äôre owed,‚Äù Crystal said. ‚ÄúThe last big convoy of materials and trucks were from another Earth, and they‚Äôre part of what‚Äôs being held hostage. The delivery folk from Earth-K aren‚Äôt budging because they aren‚Äôt abandoning their delivery, even though they‚Äôve been told they can go. The government from United States of K is getting upset because their people aren‚Äôt home, That‚Äôs where the murmurings of war are coming from. Workers aren‚Äôt conceding anything else, and construction groups aren‚Äôt either.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd our job is to make sure the stalemate stays stale and mate until people find a resolution,‚Äù I said, pulling on the boots.

‚ÄúOr mitigate the damage if it gets ugly,‚Äù Crystal said.

I did up the straps, reached for the belts, all arranged around a metal ring, and found one I was satisfied with almost right away. Utility-belt style with small pouches. I tore open the bag of masks.

The masks were ones that were meant to be stuck to the face. Remove protective tape, stick to face like cosmetic band-aids. Not my favorite, but I got why they did it when they sent out sample packs. The glue would wear out quickly, and the real custom masks for long-term wear would then be ordered. Quality was fine, though. All in white, again, some with lenses.

I found one that fit around my eyes and covered my eyebrows, with white lenses, and held it up to make sure the white lenses didn‚Äôt obscure vision any. A faint halo when I looked at sources of illumination, but nothing too bad.

‚ÄúWhat do you think?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI think you look more like you than I‚Äôve seen you in a long time,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúMaybe I‚Äôm meant to wear a costume,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBut what I meant, cuz, is that from the moment you stepped into my bedroom, well before you put anything on, you looked more focused and grounded in reality than you have in a while.‚Äù

I drew in a deep breath, and glanced at the curtains. Being told I looked better reminded me that I hadn‚Äôt looked well before, which reminded me of why I hadn‚Äôt looked well, which in turn made me feel less better.

It was easier if I didn‚Äôt focus on it. ‚ÄúThanks, I guess.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhatever you were doing, I think you should do more of it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI plan to. But for now, in the interest of time, since your formation is expecting you to hurry back, I just need to know if the mask makes me look like a dork.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good,‚Äù Crystal said. She picked up one article of clothing that I‚Äôd put aside while digging for my boots. A plain white sweatshirt. ‚ÄúTo cover up the road rash?‚Äù

I looked at my arms. I still had the raised red marks where I‚Äôd tumbled to the road.

‚ÄúOr maybe not. It wouldn‚Äôt work with your forcefield,‚Äù she said.

It would, but I wasn‚Äôt about to explain that whole situation.

‚ÄúNo, actually, it could work,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúDress up the upper body some.‚Äù

She smiled, enthusiastic that I was playing along. ‚ÄúExactly! I was thinking we could stick a quick heat-transfer design on this.‚Äù

The sweatshirt as part of my costume? It would be playing into that trend of working normal clothes into costumes. Fume Hood‚Äôs group had been big on that. A few of the villains in Lord of Loss‚Äô group had, too, but some of that might have been them trying to fly under the radar before launching their plan.

The most significant trends in fashion and style were often a symptom of external factors. It was hard to get good costumes with where things were at. There was a desire, too, to appear more down to earth, to connect to the people, when sentiment was where it was at.

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù I said. I smiled. ‚ÄúThat could work.‚Äù

‚ÄúQuestion is, do you trust me to do it?‚Äù she asked, raising one hand and producing a fan of lasers from her fingertips, shooting at a forcefield she‚Äôd created. ‚ÄúOr do you want to wait for the iron to get hot?‚Äù

‚äô

The battle lines were drawn, so to speak. At least it was quiet here, the forces gathering in anticipation of the coming day. At the center of this particular battlefield was a single tall building, lit from bottom floor to top, even in the evening, with the power rationing being what it was.

The masses of construction workers had clustered in groups, the largest mass of them arranged around three sides of the building, kept on the far side of the street by the emergency services and the capes. Surrounding one of the construction company‚Äôs headquarters.

Lights on poles, the lighting of the news crews talking to some key individuals, and the lights the workers were carrying served to illuminate that crowd.

From the bird‚Äôs eye view, we could see some of the construction sites around the area, each roughly illuminated by the lights within, that light contained by the fencing that surrounded each building in progress. Construction vehicles, people, and collections of things cast long shadows with the lights set where they were. Most had lookouts posted, keeping an eye out for trouble. A couple of those lookouts turned lights our way as we flew.

Laserdream and I touched ground.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve missed flying with you,‚Äù she said.

I smiled. My emotions were complicated enough in the moment that I didn‚Äôt want to say anything. I didn‚Äôt trust my tone of voice or the words I might choose.

Easier to stick to the shallow, surface response. It was nice to be around my cousin, nice that she was happy.

We walked down the length of the street, the building on one side, the crowd of workers on the other. Walking helped to get my blood pumping and my body warmed up, where flying felt like it had frozen my blood and chilled me. My hands were cold, and I kept them jammed in the pockets of my sweatshirt.

‚ÄúLaserdream. You‚Äôre cutting it close in getting back in a timely manner. Who‚Äôs this?‚Äù a cape in a jacket asked. He was a heavy guy with a very clean face, a gently curved visor covering his eyes and nose.

‚ÄúFamily,‚Äù Laserdream said. ‚ÄúThere was a call for more help, she was invited by someone named, uh‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúTempera,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúTempera. Right. We‚Äôre paying for the extra hands on deck?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe are,‚Äù the man said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a lot.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs fine,‚Äù I said.

He looked skeptical.

‚ÄúI can second the recommendation if it matters,‚Äù Laserdream said.

‚ÄúIt helps,‚Äù the guy said. ‚ÄúIf she causes trouble, you know it‚Äôs your ass in the fire.‚Äù

‚ÄúUnderstood, sir,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been doing patrols with her since before I could drive. I‚Äôd trust her with my life. I‚Äôm optimistic my ass will remain room temperature.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt get smart. I don‚Äôt want her with the formation. If she wants in, she needs to apply and train.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe doesn‚Äôt—‚Äù Laserdream said, at the same time I said, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt—‚Äù

Laserdream ceded to me.

‚ÄúNo disrespect intended,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThat isn‚Äôt for me. But I get the gist of the situation, I‚Äôll help keep the peace, I‚Äôll follow any orders.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou going to be alright if I send you out to help fill in the gaps at the flanks?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs why I‚Äôm here,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúSouth side of the building,‚Äù he said, pointing. ‚ÄúStand on the dotted line, try not to stare down the crowd or antagonize them. Be gentle if they get rowdy.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan do,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúShould be quiet tonight,‚Äù he said. He turned to Laserdream as he said it, but glanced at me. Including us both in the statement. ‚ÄúThis is one of three locations. The big demonstrations are supposed to start tomorrow, at another location. Tonight they‚Äôre mainly interested in holding their ground and organizing themselves. Holding a vigil, giving cameras something to record. Would be nice if they got over it or got bored before things get started tomorrow, but I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs going to happen.‚Äù

That would be why Tempera had said I could call in the morning. The workers wanted time and media attention to give their side some weight before they really took action.

‚ÄúGet yourself in position. I‚Äôll send someone your way with some cups of coffee in a short while.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù I said.

The parahumans along the road to the south of the building were spaced out along the painted divider in the center of the street. One parahuman every fifteen or so feet. There were no barricades, only the lights on tripods, connected to battery packs, helping to illuminate most of the road. The ambient light from nearby buildings contributed.

The crowd was noisy, but it was a low, constant noise. Talk, conversation, the occasional raised voice. There wasn‚Äôt a car to be seen on the street.

I could remember what had happened to Fume Hood. I closed my eyes for a moment, and I put my forcefield up, leaving it up. It made me uncomfortable, but a bullet would be even worse on that score.

The capes down the street to my left were all wearing Advance Guard icons on their sleeves and costumes. The stylized man bearing the ‚Äògreater-than‚Äô shaped shield, charging forward. The color of the icon changed, depending on the costume‚Äôs color scheme, but it was always such that it stood out, yellow on a red and orange costume, or purple on a blue-green one. The thick bold lines of the icon‚Äôs design tended to flow into the cape‚Äôs individual icon or the rest of the costume, the shield‚Äôs lines or the diamond-shaped frame of the icon joining the line running down the seam of the sleeve or the lines running across the chest.

‚ÄúWho are you with?‚Äù the guy standing to my left asked. He had a face plate, with the thick bold lines and angular edges that Advance Guard tended to have, and the ‚Äòears‚Äô of the plate swept back to cover his ears, giving them a pointed, elfin cast. His bodysuit was designed to accent his slim frame, a two —piece jacket and legging combo, with a very pronounced zig-zag at the waist where the upper body met the lower body. There was a slight curl at the toes.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm independent,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúFor now.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre Advance Guard,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Spright.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm between names,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúAnd between costumes. Don‚Äôt judge me too harshly.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan I see the emblem?‚Äù

‚ÄúJust a design, not an emblem,‚Äù I said, turning my back to him to show him the rush job we‚Äôd managed with the heat-transferred image, my sweatshirt lightly singed in places. It was a circle with lines intersecting it, almost like a sun, but with the lines running into the circle. The image was offset, so the lines were shorter to the left and top of the image. Crystal‚Äôs idea and design, and I‚Äôd had no objection.

‚ÄúBetween teams, between names, between costumes?‚Äù

‚ÄúMore or less sums it up,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIf you need to call me anything, you can call me Victoria.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm honored, Victoria,‚Äù Spright said, bowing slightly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad for the company. We might be here for a while.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe probably will,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI see you‚Äôve got the armband. You‚Äôve been around for at least a few years. Do you have any war stories you can share?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, a good few,‚Äù I said. And a lot I wouldn‚Äôt share.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre experienced, huh?‚Äù

‚ÄúA few years under my belt. A few years of semi-retirement.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can tell you I‚Äôm very experienced,‚Äù he said, with a bit of humor in his voice.

I looked at him, one eyebrow arched.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll tell you mine if you tell me yours,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúIs that how we‚Äôre doing this?‚Äù

‚ÄúCould be,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWhat I‚Äôm offering is long and thoroughly satisfying. Are you game?‚Äù

‚ÄúWow,‚Äù I said. I smiled despite myself, looking over the crowd instead of at Spright. ‚ÄúWhen they said Advance Guard rushes into things, they weren‚Äôt lying.‚Äù

‚ÄúOnce you get me going, I go all night. I might as well get started early.‚Äù

‚ÄúWith an audience, though?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got nothing to hide. I‚Äôd say they could join in, but I think that would get a little hectic.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt might just,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúWould be nice to steer clear of hectic for a while.‚Äù

‚ÄúI very much agree, Victoria Between-things,‚Äù Spright said. ‚ÄúYou have to find a good fit, strike the right rhythm, the right pace. Once you‚Äôre comfortable, you might be able to vary it up some.‚Äù

The woman standing to the left of Spright said something that sounded an awful lot like, ‚ÄúOh my god, Spright.‚Äù

I checked, but it didn‚Äôt look like the people on the sidewalk heard us. The buzz of conversation seemed to drown out our voices.

‚ÄúIs he always like this?‚Äù I asked, raising my voice a bit.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Spright said.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI dare say you‚Äôve inspired him. Unfortunately.‚Äù

Spright sounded almost energized by his teammate‚Äôs exasperation. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm intrigued more than inspired. I‚Äôd love to indulge in your, ahem, stories, Victoria with the stylish icon.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that great an icon,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúNice try, though. I appreciate it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wanted to work in the flattery somehow. There‚Äôs no shortage of things I could say, by the way, and I‚Äôm not messing around when I say that. I chose the icon because I do like it, and because when you say something nice about something like a girl‚Äôs hair or something else about their appearance, you tend to get that kneejerk resistance.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou do,‚Äù I said. For me, it‚Äôs for reasons other than the usual. It was a shame, but his moment of frankness had brought things home again. My tone of voice was audibly different even to myself as I said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm flattered, Spright, really.‚Äù

‚ÄúAw darn. But?‚Äù

‚ÄúBut while I‚Äôd be happy to share a few stories, I‚Äôm not up for the other stuff you‚Äôre driving for. It‚Äôs just not where I‚Äôm at. Wouldn‚Äôt be fair to you. I‚Äôve gotta figure myself out some, first.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can respect that,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI appreciate the wit. You were pretty snappy with some of that.‚Äù

‚ÄúThanks for letting me try, I—‚Äù Spright stopped as the woman standing to his left made a sound effect with her mouth. I didn‚Äôt hear the preceding sound, but I heard her make a sound like a small crash with her mouth. Spright switched tacks to say, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll throw things at you, Tandem.‚Äù

The woman laughed.

A moment later, another person joined us. A ripple in the road, and he appeared almost instantly out of the gloom. The cape I‚Äôd met early in the day the community center had been attacked, with the blades jutting from his costume.

He looked at me, sizing me up.

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúMmh,‚Äù he made a sound, not really a response. ‚ÄúHey, Spright, swap places with me for a bit.‚Äù

The ‚Äòmmh‚Äô bugged me. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm enjoying his company.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs enjoying my company, Shortcut,‚Äù Spright said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a good night.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to be a long night,‚Äù Shortcut said. ‚ÄúI think I know her from the other day.‚Äù

He paused, glancing back at me.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said.

Shortcut turned back to talk to Spright, then paused, glancing back at me. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs that sound?‚Äù

I listened, and I heard it. Scratching.

Without trying to look too much like I was looking down, I looked down. My forcefield, invisible to everyone present, was scratching at the road.

I took flight, lifting myself up enough that the arms couldn‚Äôt reach the ground. About eight feet up. From the angle, as I saw the light hit the road at a different angle, I could see the shallow gouges.

The good humor from earlier was spoiled a little at that.

‚ÄúEverything okay?‚Äù Spright asked.

‚ÄúYeah, just restless, bit of power quirkery,‚Äù I said. I realized the crowd had noticed me take flight, and the conversation had quieted a bit.

It was mildly surprising that, Spright‚Äôs flirting aside, nobody in a large collection of construction employees had called out to me.

I tested my luck, and used the opportunity to call out, ‚ÄúYou guys doing okay!?‚Äù

‚ÄúBit cool out!‚Äù someone called back.

‚ÄúYeah!‚Äù I called back. ‚ÄúBetter than the alternative, isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

That got me a fairly mixed response.

‚ÄúShoulder to shoulder in the heat, stinking of sweat? You don‚Äôt want that!‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre used to the smell of sweat, hon!‚Äù a woman called out. There were murmurs of agreement.

‚ÄúTake care of yourselves, okay?‚Äù

There were a few murmured and unintelligible responses, but a more emotional cry of, ‚ÄúGive us our homes and we‚Äôll be just fucking fine!‚Äù stood out. Some heads turned in that direction.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not up to us,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúSave that energy for tomorrow, alright? We‚Äôre here to keep you safe and keep them safe.‚Äù

There were a few mumbled replies.

‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt help,‚Äù Shortcut said.

‚ÄúI dunno,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúLetting them know we‚Äôre not against them, we care about their well being? Reaching out and talking can‚Äôt hurt, can it?‚Äù

‚ÄúI guess that‚Äôs why I‚Äôm here,‚Äù Shortcut said.

I looked his way.

‚ÄúReaching out and talking,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI just wanted to make sure there‚Äôs no hard feelings.‚Äù

‚ÄúAbout you not getting into Advance Guard.‚Äù

I‚Äôd emailed, they‚Äôd sent a reply a couple of hours later saying no.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt devote a lot of thought to it,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúSucks, but you guys have to do what you have to do. And so does everyone else, apparently. I‚Äôll figure something out.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey didn‚Äôt tell you it was me?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù I said. I frowned.

‚ÄúI told them to tell you no and to tell you it was me, and why.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThey just told me no.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell fuck that. I thought you needed to know, what you did back there, it was shitty.‚Äù

‚ÄúBeg pardon?‚Äù

‚ÄúI realized after your face came up on some of the events about the Norfair community center incident. You went up against Lord of Loss?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see what the issue is,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYou happen to beat me to the scene, and then you use your secret identity, condescension and anti-parahuman shit to take me down a notch? And then you want a place on Advance Guard?‚Äù

‚ÄúI happened to be there. I‚Äôm sorry, it was not my intention to come across that way.‚Äù I tried to help you out some.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúRight. I can guess what your intentions were.‚Äù

I was pretty darn confident my handling of the situation had been alright. I was inclined to chalk this one up to the guy having a screw loose or a few bundled up issues. It still bothered me, and it bothered me more that a nice conversation had been interrupted, and now this guy was apparently intent on keeping me company for the night, telling me how I was responsible for his problems and issues.

I pursed my lips, doing my best to filter what he was saying, tuning out what I could and responding where necessary, so he wouldn‚Äôt add me ignoring him to his list of grievances. He was talking about the community center now.

Voices were raised, a few shouts, both from capes at one of the other streets, and by people in the crowd. Phones were out.

It was almost a welcome interruption, in that solitary moment between the initial commotion and when I realized that it meant people were hurt.

I rotated myself in the air, looking, trying to figure out what had happened. I saw Crystal coming, and flew to meet her.

‚ÄúCome!‚Äù she shouted, barely pausing as she flew. I joined her, wavering as air ripped past my forcefield, lopsided in a way I couldn‚Äôt quite detect, moving.

I disabled the forcefield, and in the doing, I could fly straighter, but I flew against cold wind, unprotected.

Crystal didn‚Äôt explain. It was left for me to see.

Our site had been quiet. At least one of the other places workers were congregating wasn‚Äôt. People were more spread out, and I suspected from their arrangement that some had crossed the street, approaching the building. There were more emergency vehicles, more capes, and there was a large clearing in the center of the crowd.

Eight people were gathered toward the center of that clearing, with more scattered across the more open area. Among them, several had eyes that glowed, or glows emanating from their mouths. Shapes I couldn‚Äôt quite make out moved around them. A power at work, like the outline of something that glowed slightly in the dark, too abstract to make out.

I watched as two people broke from the edge of the clearing and ran toward the center group. A man and a woman, holding hands.

It hit me like a blow to the head. An image in my mind‚Äôs eye, a feeling, a sense of something greater. Forgotten in the same instant it occurred. I dropped out of the air, and I caught myself a moment later. Crystal did much the same.

‚ÄúGet back!‚Äù someone hollered.

A megaphone blared, ‚ÄúGet away from the center!‚Äù

The eight people were sixteen now, including the two that had run toward the center and some of the people that hadn‚Äôt retreated to the clearing‚Äôs edge. Eyes glowed, powers wreathed a few hands. A spike of power-generated material was stabbing skyward in front of a woman. A man had fallen to his knees, arms spread, and the ground was rippling around them.

People didn‚Äôt get away from the center. Realizing what was happening, or thinking they knew what was happening, others dashed toward the group, joining it.

‚ÄúGet back,‚Äù Crystal said. ‚ÄúIf we get knocked out—‚Äù

I retreated, looking for where the defending capes were. Lit by flashing, noiseless sirens, the capes were clustered not far from the building. They were getting organized.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a broken trigger,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúIs it?‚Äù Crystal asked.

I flew straight for the heroes on scene. I didn‚Äôt get the chance to hear two words out of the leader‚Äôs mouth before we were hit again. Every one of us winced and reacted as it hit us. Too brief to be a trigger vision, incomplete, fractured, it still made itself felt.

The sixteen had become thirty-two.

Flare — 2.4

‚ÄúEvacuate!‚Äù

One word from the parahuman in charge was all we needed. The clock was too short for anything more.

Capes fanned out, most of them on foot. I could leave the parts of the crowd closest to us to them. I flew, avoiding the sky directly over the group of affected people, circling around the periphery instead. The wind was cold against my face and legs.

The massed crowd of citizen workers was to my right, the people with powers to my left. Half of the light sources in and around the clearing had broken, and the only other illumination came from the effects of powers. A common thread ran through all of it. Energy spilled out and created matter where it splattered on the road, materials sprouted from nothing, streaked with thin streams of liquid that glowed like fire, and more abstract growths formed suspended in air, their images sticking to the backs of my eyes like the persistent afterimages of sparklers waved in the dark.

People were shouting. Some were screaming. I couldn‚Äôt make much of it out.

I flew to the far side of the clearing, which also happened to have some of the thickest gatherings of people. They had been citizen laborers, gathering to make their displeasure known to the construction groups. They‚Äôd been facing the building until the incident, they‚Äôd backed up, and there were places where the presence of buildings and parked vehicles made it so they had no place to retreat, leaving them now packed together, shoulder to shoulder, front to back, jostling.

I‚Äôd helped to evacuate before. I had attended the Leviathan attack on my hometown. I had been around for the majority of the Slaughterhouse Nine crisis. I‚Äôd participated in other, minor incidents, helping with fires and storms, though those had mostly involved helping the elderly and standing around.

The truism was that in a disaster, people were their own worst enemies.

Never this bad.

I‚Äôd never seen or imagined a situation where people would do the opposite of evacuating, throwing themselves headlong into the hazard. They thought the people in the center of the clearing were getting powers, and people were breaking away from the crowd at the clearing‚Äôs edge to run toward the affected individuals.

Crystal created a wall to block off a street as she passed it. She wouldn‚Äôt be able to keep it up as she got further away, but it bought time for others to get there.

She raked a laser across the road, a bright and noticeable distraction, to give people pause.

I dropped to the street, using a pulse of my aura to get people‚Äôs attention. Some stopped to look, while others ducked low, as if instinct drove them to shy away from the perceived threat.

‚ÄúRun!‚Äù I shouted, using my aura to play up my words. ‚ÄúOther way!‚Äù

I saw eyes widen, and turned to look. A man had opened his mouth, and had something that looked almost as tall and thick as a telephone pole spearing skyward from his mouth. Blood streamed from the sides of his mouth, his jaw clearly dislocated, and more fluids painted the length of the pole as it continued to rise. It reached its maximum height, and then forked, the upper half splitting out into two equally thick portions, a giant ‚ÄòY‚Äô shape. Each branch then forked into two, and forked into two again.

‚ÄúGo,‚Äù I said, sparing only a momentary glance for the people I‚Äôd been stopping. I saw them start to run away.

The man reached up, his fingers dragging along the blood-slick shaft of the trunk of the fractal tree he had vomited up. Each movement of his hands was slower and weaker than the last.

I flew toward him, to do what I could to help, even though I wasn‚Äôt sure what that could possibly be.

The ‚Äòtree‚Äô toppled, and it was only because I was already on my way toward him that I was able to intervene. I reached out for the falling tree, and my power was quicker to touch it. Phantom fingers bit into the surface, fracturing the chalky material. With flight, my bare hands, my power, and my aura pushed out to give people a little more incentive to get out of the way, I controlled the tree‚Äôs fall. It broke into chunks on contact with the ground. One of the people with new powers was pinned beneath branches, but it didn‚Äôt look like he was hurt by the contact.

I flew to the man who‚Äôd grown the tree. Even before I reached his side, I could see the damage that had been done. Jaw, throat, chest, and stomach had been torn away. Traces of the same material that had formed the tree had collected in his insides and pelvis, breaking into jagged pieces at some point before or during the tree‚Äôs fall.

He had no throat to feel for a pulse. I wasn‚Äôt about to rule anything out, even as I saw the remains of his heart in his splayed-out chest cavity. I pried one of his eyes open, and I saw no response.

I went from a crouch to airborne in a second.

That particular disaster had been dramatic and visible for a significant portion of the people nearby. Most were thinking twice about running toward the epicenter.

When was the next wave coming? The number of people to trigger all at once had seemed to double the last time. They didn‚Äôt look like multi-triggers either. One power each, some self-destructive. I could hear the screams and shouts of a lot of unhappy people and I couldn‚Äôt see one person who looked particularly happy about their new ability.

I flew to a new location, looking to see where I could get the most people away. The tree had done my work for me in one spot, Laserdream was standing at the intersection of two streets and walling them off with red-tinted, translucent fields.

I saw another group— people were pulling away from the crowd, which was actively trying to grab them and hold them back. Young people — older teenagers and twenty-somethings, that might have been a group of friends. Seven of them.

I shouted, but my voice was drowned out by the dentist-drill scream of a power somewhere nearby, by the hollers, the warnings, a dull explosion.

I used my aura again. Several people in the group stumbled, so caught up in reacting to my aura that they lost track of where they were going or how to put one foot in front of the other. Several others paused, helping their friends that had tripped, stopped, or fallen. The people at the edge of the crowd reacted too, pulling back away from me.

I‚Äôd hoped more of them would stop shouting and screaming. The affected people and the people at the edge of the clearing were making so much noise that it nearly drowned me out as I shouted, ‚ÄúGet back!‚Äù

A number of people listened. The crowd in particular was inclined to take my order, getting away from the scene. Two of the seven who‚Äôd lagged behind the others turned to go too.

Five, however, looked at me and then continued to run toward the scene.

I clenched my fist.

Rationally, I knew that they likely saw this as the simplest thing in the world. The people over there had powers; all they had to do to get powers was to head over there. Some might well have no idea what triggers were, or they might have bought into one of the various other theories out there, some intentionally obscuring the truth. They didn‚Äôt know better.

Well, the screaming should have given them pause, but that might have been balanced out by the fact that they felt especially powerless at this time in particular. Because we were only two years after the most catastrophic and traumatic loss of human life in history. Because as much as we were recovering, we were far from being where we‚Äôd been. We weren‚Äôt okay. The dispute between the citizen workers and the construction administrations only brought that home.

Rationally, I knew that.

Less rationally, I had a weak point that extended well before the Gold Morning, well before the hospital stay, well before the Slaughterhouse Nine, before the bad days against Empire Eighty-Eight, before my trigger, even. I‚Äôd spent a fair portion of my time post-trigger and especially in the hospital, thinking about it.

I couldn‚Äôt fucking stand being ignored.

I flew to intercept.

I hadn‚Äôt practiced with this power enough. Even using it was a hard reminder, with a mental and emotional cost. I knew I needed to come to terms with it, and my time at the hospital had been an early foray into that.

That had been flight, and my flight was more or less untouched.

I flew low, approaching a car. As with the tree, all of my powers were up and active as I reached out in the car‚Äôs direction. Phantom hands dug into the metal of the car‚Äôs body, invisible fingers stabbing through. A mass of something pressed down on the hood, caving it in.

If I had any control over those limbs, it wasn‚Äôt something that lent itself to fine touches. It didn‚Äôt work well with the careful, methodical, warrior monk approach. In this, in the instinct and the moment of frustration, I could only hope that what I wanted and what my power wanted were mostly in agreement.

I glanced up to make sure Laserdream wasn‚Äôt watching. I was close enough for my fingertips to brush the car‚Äôs paint as I swept my arm to one side, the holes and dents in the car twisting or opening wider as the phantom grip adjusted. The— the other Victoria, the phantom Victoria that had never left the hospital, the wretch, threw the car.

I canceled my power momentarily, to force it to release its hold, so it wouldn‚Äôt fling the car into the people I was trying to stop. I let it reactivate a half-second later, flying forward in the car‚Äôs direction. My defenses were up and sufficient to let me adjust the car‚Äôs trajectory with a sharp kick to the side. Just to be safe.

It crashed into a parked car, upside down, its roof and windows shearing into the top of the other. A loud impact, metal scraping metal, a dozen windows on the two vehicles breaking. It was raucous, chaotic, sudden and surprising, in a stark contrast to the massive, enduring weight that seemed to settle in me.

Harder than flying. I could tell myself I was helping people, keeping them clear of danger, and it helped much as it had with the flying, but it was still hard.

The fact that a car had flown into another car twenty feet in front of them was enough to stop them in their tracks. I had their full attention now.

‚ÄúGet away! It‚Äôs dangerous!‚Äù

Some backed away, then ran. Two backed off but didn‚Äôt run. The last of them was a man about my age, who stepped closer to the cars, intent on climbing over them.

‚ÄúGet away!‚Äù

I was prepared to grab him as he climbed onto the underside of the car I‚Äôd thrown. He continued to ignore me, finding his balance, stepping forward—

The fragment of a trigger vision hit me. The latest wave.

I saw only a flash of faces, and in seeing those faces, I saw the phantom self that clung to me. The impression lingered for only a moment before I realized the faces didn‚Äôt resemble mine.

The man had been springing forward from the car to the ground when the event had hit. I saw his legs swing forward, while his head remained in place. He dangled, suspended in the air.

I picked myself up off the ground, flying to him.

Gone already. No pulse, no light behind the eyes. He made a faint gurgling sound, but it was some biological process or symptom of what had happened, not a sign of life. He was pissing himself and shitting himself in death.

He dropped out of the air, and I caught him. It hardly mattered, he was gone, but it didn‚Äôt feel right to just let him fall. I eased him to the ground.

‚ÄúPlease help!‚Äù I heard a guy shout, amid renewed and nearby whimpers and sobs.

I flew. The two who had drawn back but hadn‚Äôt run— a boy and a girl. The boy was holding the girl, while she strove to stay on her tiptoes. Her face was turned skyward.

I flew to them, and I caught her, helping to hold her.

‚ÄúHold her steady!‚Äù the guy shouted.

I held her as steady as I could.

Another suspension?

‚ÄúMy neck!‚Äù the victim shrieked the words. A single glowing vein stood out on each arm, and glows on her legs suggested more of the same, but she barely seemed to care about it. Clear fluid was streaming from her nose, thinner than snot, with needle-thin streams of blood joining it.

‚ÄúWe got you,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre here, we‚Äôll support you. Stay calm.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt move my head!‚Äù she cried out. ‚ÄúEvery time— my neck!‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt try,‚Äù I said. The guy was looking to me for help, and I wasn‚Äôt sure what to say or do.

‚ÄúMy head hurts,‚Äù she said, sounding very far away. Her words dissolved into a stream of whimpers and cries of ‚Äòow‚Äô.

I was supporting her weight, but it wasn‚Äôt easy to do it from a strength perspective with my feet on the ground, and it wasn‚Äôt easy to stay steady while flying.

‚ÄúLaserdream!‚Äù I shouted the words, top of my lungs.

‚ÄúHeadache,‚Äù the victim said, her eyes wide. ‚ÄúMy brain.‚Äù

The guy looked at me again. This time I didn‚Äôt try to hide my expression. I knew I looked grim.

Her brain. The Corona Pollentia, the means by which powers were operated by the parahuman. Hers had been established, but not as a fluid, functional thing. It was a nail, taking her brain and fixing it to a specific position in reality.

Laserdream appeared beside me.

‚ÄúWhat happened?‚Äù she asked.

‚ÄúGive her something to stand on,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs stuck.‚Äù

The forcefield appeared below. The girl no longer had to stand on her tiptoes.

‚ÄúPeople are evacuating more now,‚Äù Laserdream said. ‚ÄúWe need to handle the people toward the center. The waves are random.‚Äù

I turned, looking at the guy. ‚ÄúDo you know her?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot really.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan you run? Go tell people to get away, as fast as they can. This is bad.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt want to get caught in it,‚Äù Laserdream said.

The guy nodded.

‚ÄúBye Anne,‚Äù he said. He let go of the girl, transitioning the grip entirely to me, then turned to run.

Anne.

She was making small sounds, guttural. One hand came up to touch the side of my face and my hair, clumsy, as if she didn‚Äôt have full use of her fingers.

One pat.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry Anne,‚Äù I said.

She made another of the gurgling sounds. She was vomiting, I realized, and with her face fixed in a skyward position, there wasn‚Äôt anything I could do. Anything I did to move her would add to the damage to her brain.

I hugged her, hard. After a moment, I felt her hug me back, clumsy but fierce.

It was only a moment later that she started to convulse, whole-body. I moved to try to seize her head and keep it from moving— a second too late. One wrenching, forced movement of her head and upper body, and the nail ripped through a good share of the material in its vicinity.

I caught her as she fell, and laid her out on the ground, placing her on her side.

‚ÄúWe need to help others, Victoria.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù
