Spooky, to take to the air again. I‚Äôd seen the numbers of people affected double, roughly, and this was another doubling, to look at it. More artificial sources of light had broken, as space folded in areas, as things grew to obscure them, or as tendrils of energy lashed out like living things, distorting geography with each impact.

Matter creation, matter manipulation, matter distortion.

Over fifty people, if I had to guess. It could well have been sixty-four. They were too spread out for me to effectively ballpark. Many might well have died from their power expression or the ‚Äònailing down‚Äô of the brain.

There was no being polite, now. One person hesitating at what could have been the edge of the affected area. I didn‚Äôt even pause as I grabbed him by the wrist, picking him up off the ground, dragging him with me, me barely six feet above the ground, him with toes and shoes scraping the road‚Äôs surface. I didn‚Äôt want the fall to be too rough if I was knocked out of the air again.

I half-deposited, half-threw him toward the crowd that still lingered. I pointed at the largest guy present. ‚ÄúYou. Make sure these people get away! Keep an eye on this one!‚Äù

He looked spooked, and I wasn‚Äôt even using my aura. He gave me a singular nod.

Another two, two men together. One of them fought me as I held him, trying to pry my hand free.

‚ÄúAssholes!‚Äù he screamed, twisting my fingers, trying to get leverage to bend one backward. ‚ÄúKeeping powers to yourselves!‚Äù

I didn‚Äôt reply. I tightened my grip to keep him from getting any one of my fingers, and I saved my breath and my focus.

If this was turning out as badly as it looked like it was, the aftermath would be answer enough.

The guy who‚Äôd fought me was deposited beside the first vehicle with flashing lights that was waiting at the edges. A fire truck.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt let him go back! And try to get further away, in case it expands!‚Äù

I was already leaving before they could answer me. I heard the shouts, though. The answers.

Crystal wasn‚Äôt using lasers or forcefields much anymore. Only flight, only manhandling.

I delivered two more armfuls of cargo, getting people clear of the danger. On my return trip, I saw the geography transforming. A culmination of everything up to this point. From matter generation, matter distortion, and matter transformation to‚Ä¶ something that made the entire area look as though it was being smudged and smeared around, streets widening, buildings pulling back from the street.

Except— no. No, this was a familiar smudging and smearing. One that worked with us.

You made it, little V, I thought. I felt emotionally numb from the series of events, the deaths I‚Äôd seen, my momentary use of my power and how the feelings I‚Äôd tapped in that moment weren‚Äôt easy to bring back into order.

There was only what needed to be done, the mission that stood front and center. It was difficult to execute effectively, but simple in how Glory Girl, Victoria, the phantom wretch and the capes I was working with could all agree it should be done.

Get people clear. Get them safe.

A woman screamed words that barely strung together, the heel of one hand pressed to her forehead. The other was pointed forward. She shot something that was only visible by the way light refracted at its edges. The projectile hit the ground, carrying forward like a cartoon mole and the elongated, humped trail of dirt it left in its wake. Unlike the mole, the hump was jagged, folded earth. Road folded up like complex origami. She was pinning people down, keeping them from exiting a building.

In the words I could make out, she wanted them to come help her, and in her actions she drove them away.

‚ÄúStop!‚Äù I shouted to her.

She shot one projectile at me. Barely visible, it cut through the air, wind shrieking.

I didn‚Äôt want to kill her, and if her hand at her head was any clue that she was in similar straits to Anne and the other man, a light push could do horrendous damage.

I drew closer to the ground, defenses up.

Work with me, I told my power. My agent. My flight wobbled as I experienced the lopsided drag of a hand reaching down at one side, clawing at the ground as I passed it.

It didn‚Äôt create nearly enough debris.

I changed angles. I flew for the hump of origami road, two feet across, two feet tall, jagged and menacing.

I passed within a few feet of it, and let my forcefield hit it.

The hump of ground shattered explosively, blades of road cutting at my legs. But it did create a cloud of dust and debris.

She shot at me, and I reversed direction, passing the hump again, striking it.

The two passes created enough of a mess to block the view. I flew to the people the origami road woman had pinned down. ‚ÄúGo, go, go!‚Äù

I stood by with my defenses up, positioned to intercept any incoming projectiles. They took the chance to run for it.

This whole thing was a clusterfuck. How many people were caught? How many were acting irrational? What options did we have? What the hell was I supposed to do?

The origami woman didn‚Äôt send any attacks through the cloud of shattered road that I‚Äôd created. The moment the group was out of sight and away, I was moving again.

A complete and total clusterfuck. I flew high, and I looked down, wishing we had more light on the scene.

I could see where the distortions were being utilized. The space between the people at the edges and the center of the effect was being extended, making the clearing larger. It made it harder for people to approach, carried fleeing people away. It meant the effect had to reach further if it wanted to catch anyone.

In the tension and the emotions that gripped me, I felt an isolated point of peace and calm I could grab onto.

Vista was here, Vista had made it through Gold Morning. She was one of the people I liked. A reason I was doing what I did. She was one of the good ones, she was doing good work here, and I wanted to help her on multiple levels.

In that line of thinking, I found both the focus to think beyond mere instinct, and to realize what I could do. I knew how Vista worked.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Vista,‚Äù Laserdream said. She‚Äôd appeared beside me again. She had a flying cape with her.

‚ÄúCome on,‚Äù I said. I flew for where the expansion of space seemed weakest, even pinched.

They weren‚Äôt on the streets. It was people in buildings.

I tore through a door, flew through a house. Nothing. I bumped into Laserdream and her PRTCJ friend on the way out. ‚ÄúSearch the buildings. Vista‚Äôs power is weakest when it has people in its area. There are people near here.‚Äù

We spread out. One building each, searching neighboring houses. I was midway through my search when I heard a whistle.

I flew to the sound. Vagrants, or just refugees from Gimel who had decided they‚Äôd be more comfortable squatting in unoccupied, recently built houses than they were in the tent cities.

The three of us carried them clear. We were delivering them to safety when the next pulse hit. We weren‚Äôt hit, but I could see a glowing figure in the sky flicker and drop briefly before they caught themselves.

We took to the sky again, looking for pinched areas where things hadn‚Äôt distorted enough. There were two spots, and both were already being addressed.

The area was clear. We found our way to where the Warden-affiliated capes had collected. They had gathered at the edge of the effect.

‚ÄúI think we‚Äôre clear, Rocketround, sir,‚Äù Laserdream reported.

‚ÄúWe should be shortly,‚Äù the leader said, glancing at a Foresight cape who stood nearby.

‚ÄúYes sir,‚Äù the cape said. A girl with a hood and blindfold.

‚ÄúHow many?‚Äù Rocketround asked.

‚ÄúNinety two, if you include the ones in houses,‚Äù she said.

Rocketround paused, staring down the length of the road toward the center of the vastly extended clearing. He spat. When he spoke, he managed a tone that pretty perfectly encapsulated what I and probably most of us were feeling, ‚ÄúFuck me.‚Äù

Ninety two. Ninety two, many like Anne. Many wanting help. I wanted to fly in, to do something.

‚ÄúI want everyone clear of the area. We wait, we see what happens,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe see if it expands in reach with further pulses, but I don‚Äôt want to give it anything. Not even any bounceback from reaching out and finding some of us. Let me know when the next pulse happens.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes sir,‚Äù the blindfolded girl said.

Something in the distance crashed to ground. Another fixture like the fractal tree?

Laserdream approached me, and she put an arm around me. I did the same for her.

There was small talk, people remarking on what they‚Äôd seen. Horrible things. People buried alive by their own powers. A few cases like what I‚Äôd observed.

‚ÄúIs Vista around?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúThat was her, right?‚Äù

I hadn‚Äôt expected Rocketround to be the one to answer, but he was the one who spoke up, saying, ‚ÄúShe is. Upstairs, top floor. She said she needed a view and no interruptions.‚Äù

No interruptions. I was disappointed.

‚ÄúWho‚Äôs she with?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúWardens,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúGood for her,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWho are you and who are you with?‚Äù he asked.

‚ÄúVictoria Dallon. Nobody, yet. I‚Äôve been interviewing for teams.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe did pretty good work,‚Äù blindfold girl said.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWhen you three got the homeless out of the house, Vista said something under her breath. I think it was ‚Äòthank you‚Äô. They were getting in her way somehow.‚Äù

I nodded. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm from her town. I was briefly her teammate.‚Äù

It was so mundane it was chilling and disconcerting, after the chaos we‚Äôd just weathered. A few moments of horrible, of stupidity and damage and madness, and now we waited to see what happened next, waiting to see what the aftermath would be. We talked about dumb things.

‚ÄúWhat do you think?‚Äù Rocketround asked. ‚ÄúNot just asking you, Victoria. Anyone.‚Äù

It was in that question that I saw the first real hint that he was shaken. He was doubting his own capacity in this.

‚ÄúThis is going to hurt,‚Äù another cape said. ‚ÄúPeople were already feeling pretty beaten down, and‚Ä¶ ninety people? We lost ninety?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt know if all of them are in trouble,‚Äù Laserdream said.

‚ÄúI think they might be,‚Äù blindfold girl said.

Laserdream didn‚Äôt have a response for that. She only hugged me tighter with the one arm.

‚ÄúI think—‚Äù I started. ‚ÄúJust speculation.‚Äù

‚ÄúAny clues or guesses about what‚Äôs going on would be good,‚Äù Rocketround said. He was gripping his upper arm as he stood with arms folded. He‚Äôd emphasized ‚Äòany‚Äô, which only served to emphasize how little a clue he and we had.

‚ÄúThe broken triggers are pretty out there. Not a lot of consistent points or facts‚Ä¶ except that they‚Äôre big,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúBig?‚Äù a nearby cape asked.

‚ÄúThey tend to cover a lot of ground. Shaker stuff.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Rocketround said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs come up in briefings.‚Äù

‚ÄúLocation, environment, and position matters a lot,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThe capes closest to the perimeter were least mobile. I think the further they got from the center, the less flex there was. Until their agents wouldn‚Äôt let them move at all.‚Äù

‚ÄúTyphlosis pointed that out,‚Äù Rocketround said, indicating the girl with the blindfold.

‚ÄúWe might want to make them stay put,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Rocketround said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll do that.‚Äù

Someone else spoke up. A remark about common thread through the powers they‚Äôd seen. Others chimed in.

I only half-listened. A lot of images stayed with me. The faces I‚Äôd seen midway through the one fragmented trigger, the indents in the car as the phantom limbs had reached out for it, Anne. The lingering sensation of Anne clinging to me, hard, the touch on my face. I didn‚Äôt know what she had wanted to communicate. A last kind gesture?

‚ÄúThere we go,‚Äù the blindfolded girl said. ‚ÄúPulse. Nobody else affected.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to approach,‚Äù Rocketround said. ‚ÄúRoadblock? I‚Äôd appreciate it if you came.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù a cape by the side said. A guy in heavy armor.

‚ÄúProtect me if we run into any trouble.‚Äù

‚ÄúOnly four left,‚Äù Typhlosis said.

‚ÄúFour?‚Äù Rocketround sounded surprised.

Laserdream‚Äôs head snapped around. Looking at me, looking at Typhlosis.

Typhlosis continued, ‚ÄúOnly four alive, still. The rest went down. Eaten by their powers, or they tried to move when they couldn‚Äôt, and their brains caved in.‚Äù

I squeezed Laserdream‚Äôs hand.

I might have been less surprised than her because I‚Äôd read up more on how these things tended to go.

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs go,‚Äù Rocketround said. ‚ÄúAnyone comfortable joining me, come.‚Äù

They speed-marched toward the center of the effect. One hand on another cape‚Äôs arm for support and guidance, Typhlosis directed us toward the nearest surviving cape.

‚ÄúThree,‚Äù she said, as we got close enough to see him.

He was a man, mid-twenties. His legs and stomach were buried in a writhing mass of something very similar to the origami road I‚Äôd seen earlier, materials made thin, folded many times over, until they didn‚Äôt quite seem to be three dimensions anymore. Some of those materials were the pieces of the twenty or so people in his immediate vicinity.

A lone figure, standing on a hill of the fallen citizen workers, caught up in the broken trigger‚Äôs effect.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt move!‚Äù Rocketround shouted. ‚ÄúAlright!?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot moving,‚Äù was the response, quiet.

‚ÄúNo using powers. Stay put, stay calm. We‚Äôre going to find out a way to help you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think I can be helped,‚Äù the man said. His head was bowed, and he couldn‚Äôt seem to move it. His hair was long, tied back into a low ponytail, and it covered much of his face.

‚ÄúWe can figure something out,‚Äù Rocketround said.

‚ÄúTwo,‚Äù Typhlosis said, quiet.

Two parahumans left.

The effect had caught over ninety over what couldn‚Äôt have been more than fifteen minutes. Now there were two.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm worried,‚Äù the man in the clearing‚Äôs center said. ‚ÄúI can feel all the others.‚Äù

He moved his hand.

Every body in the vicinity moved. A matching movement of hands, limp arms rolling off of sides or fingers digging into powdered sidewalk.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt move!‚Äù Rocketround called out.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm on a brink, and I can‚Äôt see it, but I can feel it,‚Äù the man said.

‚ÄúTry not to think about it,‚Äù Rocketround said. ‚ÄúOkay?‚Äù

‚ÄúI can feel it,‚Äù the man said. He wasn‚Äôt paying much attention to Rocketround. ‚ÄúAll the way down to this vast well, partially filled with potential energy. Like I‚Äôm on the lip of a volcano and it‚Äôs an impossibly long fall with only magma at the bottom. I don‚Äôt know if I‚Äôm better off throwing myself down into that or leaving it alone.‚Äù

‚ÄúLeave it alone,‚Äù I said, my voice joining more than one other person‚Äôs.

‚ÄúWhat if my thoughts and brain get made into a part of that? One piece in that thing‚Äôs construction. What if it makes me immortal, forever a part of this thing? A recording of me in there, how I think, how I do things.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve studied parahumans, powers and power sources a lot,‚Äù Roadblock said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre pretty sure that‚Äôs not a thing.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù the guy in the clearing‚Äôs center said. ‚ÄúBut‚Ä¶‚Äù

He trailed off.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a thing,‚Äù Rocketround‚Äôs voice joined Roadblock‚Äôs.

‚ÄúBut I‚Äôm standing closer to it than you are,‚Äù the man said. ‚ÄúAnd from where I stand, I feel like it might be.‚Äù

Nobody had a ready response to that.

‚ÄúOne,‚Äù Typhlosis murmured.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm the last one standing on the brink now,‚Äù the man said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think I can do this much longer. Do I embrace it or turn away? I wish I could see you, to—‚Äù

He reached up, to move his hair out of his eyes.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt!‚Äù I called out. My voice wasn‚Äôt the only voice of protest, but it might have been the first. Perhaps because I was most mindful of arms that weren‚Äôt mine, in my immediate vicinity.

The arms of people all around him operated as extensions of him. A matching, reaching movement, up and out. Some disintegrated as they moved, but one lying next to him reached up, out, and into the finely spun construction of road that cocooned the man‚Äôs legs.

As I‚Äôd done to the altered road, the reaching arm broke the construction like it was sugar crystal or a snow globe. There was a spray of blood, and the man dropped, jerking as his Corona Pollentia remained in place, briefly suspending him. He was dead in that instant, well before he sprawled to the ground, shattered from the waist down.

My hand held Laserdream‚Äôs tight.

I was thankful that Typhlosis didn‚Äôt give us an updated count.

‚äô

Crystal had backed me up for a good while. She‚Äôd been a friend, a support.

She had performed during the event. She‚Äôd been focused, she‚Äôd done what she needed to do. It had been after that she faltered. Hearing that the people who‚Äôd been touched by the broken trigger weren‚Äôt doing well, then hearing that only four remained. Hearing and seeing those four drop away.

It had been that way for Leviathan, too.

It had probably been that way after I went to the hospital.

Fine during, not so fine after.

It had been ten days, now. Ten days after the broken trigger with the citizen workers. One of the worst we‚Äôd seen for citizen casualties and damage.

I landed on the balcony, letting myself in. I took the carton out of the plastic bag and popped it into the microwave, lid ajar. Eighteen seconds.

‚ÄúVic?‚Äù Crystal called out.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm here. One second.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat had better not be what I think it is.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt is.‚Äù

Crystal groaned audibly.

I pulled the carton free, grabbed some spoons, and walked over to the living room. Crystal was sitting in the armchair, watching TV, a blanket on her lap.

She glared at me, but it was a mock glare, and it softened considerably as she saw the carton.

‚ÄúSlightly melted brownie caramel ice cream,‚Äù I said. I collapsed onto the couch, reaching high overhead to hold the carton and a spoon out to her. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll share it with you.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, if you‚Äôre sharing it‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll exercise with you too, to work it off. For now, though, it‚Äôs comfort food, staying cozy, and keeping each other company.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay. You‚Äôre mostly forgiven.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd a stupid-in-a-good-way movie to watch,‚Äù I said, pulling the movie case out of the pocket I‚Äôd wedged it into. ‚ÄúBecause it turns out TV sucks after the world ends, and I can‚Äôt watch you subject yourself to it.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre forgiven.‚Äù

I popped the movie in, then settled on the couch, pulling a blanket over my legs, arranging a cushion to sit up against. I fetched my phone and checked my messages. A second cancellation from Jessica.

After a disaster like that, too many people needed looking after.

I twisted my head around to look at Crystal, as she ate a spoonful of icecream from the carton. She passed it to me and I took a bite for myself, from the side she hadn‚Äôt dug into. I passed it back, watching as the movie started.

My turn to look after Crystal.

‚äô

The lights were off in the coffee shop, though it wasn‚Äôt dark with the light coming in through the windows. The majority of the customers were sitting on the outside patio, and the interior was quiet, empty, and cool.

It was eerie, to go from the disaster to the more or less quiet period after. To be back on this street, where the car had hit the pillar, and where I‚Äôd seen so much grief from one person, and to try and reconcile that with the broken trigger, the ninety dead, the fact that so many were dealing by ignoring it. Moving on a matter of two weeks after the fact.

‚ÄúVictoria?‚Äù the barista asked me.

My first thought was that she‚Äôd recognized me. ‚ÄúYes?‚Äù

‚ÄúYour friend stepped into the back. She said she‚Äôd be right out, but she asked us to keep an eye out for you so you didn‚Äôt think she was late.‚Äù

‚ÄúGot it. Thank you.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan I get you anything?‚Äù

I looked outside. Sunny, warm. The summer and its heat lingered in the daytime. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt bring myself to drink anything hot when the weather‚Äôs like this. Do you have any suggestions?‚Äù

‚ÄúIce coffee? Iced tea? Pop?‚Äù

‚ÄúIced tea, please,‚Äù I said, noting the use of ‚Äòpop‚Äô. A lot of people from a lot of regions had gathered in the megalopolis.

I didn‚Äôt have to sit down and wait for her to bring it to me. It was in my hands within a matter of seconds, and I took it to the seat furthest from the door, where Jessica and I would have some privacy.

She was out of the washroom before I‚Äôd fully settled in. Her blouse had buttons at the front and a collar, but was sleeveless, tucked into shorts. I wondered if she looked less at ease in casual clothing because she was a professional at heart, or if it was personal bias and years of knowing her as the therapist in the office that colored my perceptions. Her hair was damp, and she had what might‚Äôve been a folded paper towel, soaked with water, resting on the back of her neck. She collected a drink she must have ordered and paid for earlier.

‚ÄúDoing alright?‚Äù I asked.

Jessica smiled. ‚ÄúI was cooling down. I‚Äôll be glad when the weather is more comfortably cool.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that I mind the heat. It‚Äôs that I worry about how it affects people. I get antsy when the weather is like this.‚Äù

Jessica nodded. She glanced out the window. ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt help.‚Äù

‚ÄúBrockton Bay was always nice, weather-wise. It didn‚Äôt have a lot going for it, but it did have mild weather. Once upon a time.‚Äù

Jessica smiled. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good to remember the good things. At the risk of slipping into habit, I‚Äôll ask: how are you doing? You‚Äôre okay, after the broken trigger incident?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm okay. My cousin wasn‚Äôt, but she‚Äôs bounced back. I think it was a wake-up call.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow so?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe might be reconsidering if she wants to be with the PRTCJ. She might aim for something lower-key. Her mom did, after things went bad in Brockton Bay.‚Äù

‚ÄúI hope she‚Äôs happy and comfortable, wherever she ends up. I did like her, when she and I crossed paths.‚Äù

At the hospital. That fragment went unspoken.

‚ÄúHow‚Äôs the girl I found?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs managing. We‚Äôre getting her stabilized and figuring out her power. She wants to meet you at some point, to thank you.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs good, though?‚Äù

‚ÄúFar better than she was.‚Äù

I nodded.

‚ÄúThe broken trigger aside, how have you managed since we last talked? You talked about joining a team.‚Äù

I gave her a one-shoulder shrug. ‚ÄúPitched myself to a few. It didn‚Äôt take. I lost my job, the volunteer stuff feels empty. I‚Äôll survive in the meantime.‚Äù

‚ÄúI find it very interesting that you asked about Hunter, and you wanted to clarify that she wasn‚Äôt just managing, she was good. Then I ask you, and your response is that you‚Äôre surviving. You‚Äôre managing.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going therapist mode on me,‚Äù I remarked, smiling.

She smiled back.

‚ÄúHow are you?‚Äù I asked, before she could ask me the same.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm settling into my new role, trying to wrap things up and make sure there are no loose ends as I transition. Are you—‚Äù

‚ÄúYou said—‚Äù I said, inadvertently interrupting her.

‚ÄúGo ahead.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou said you were busy. Is busy a good thing, in Jessica-Yamada-land?‚Äù

It took her a second to answer. Not our usual one-sided dialogue, this, her talking, me waiting for a chance to communicate, already plotting how I could say what I wanted to say as efficiently as possible. I smiled at the observation, and I was left pretty sure she caught it, because she smiled again.

She replied, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking forward to when I have more time. Right now, it‚Äôs balancing out. Any exhaustion on my part is easier to deal with because the things I‚Äôm doing are new, exciting, a little terrifying, but positive overall.‚Äù

‚ÄúTerrifying? Because of the people you‚Äôre dealing with, or‚Ä¶?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen working with patients, the first and last meetings are the hardest, with the stakes greatest, and I‚Äôm having an awful lot of first and last meetings these days. Maintaining course after the initial connections have been made is easier. I know who I‚Äôm talking to and what I‚Äôm doing, there will be peaks, plateaus and valleys, but I can generally feel like there‚Äôs progress being made. The first meetings and the goodbyes? They‚Äôre critically important.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou want to make sure you‚Äôre laying good groundwork.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not just that. The wrong kind of connection or break can do a lot of damage. Failing to realize you‚Äôre hurting a patient when you say something or take an approach, failing to be strong enough from the outset with patients who need a hard line, being too hard on patients who need a soft touch‚Ä¶‚Äù

I nodded. I started to think about which I‚Äôd been, back then, but thinking back was hard and unpleasant.

‚ÄúI‚Ä¶‚Äù She‚Äôd started to say something, and then stopped.

‚ÄúYou?‚Äù

She sighed, leaning back in her seat.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve put myself in an awkward position here,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúActually a few, including you and me sitting here having this conversation. I want to get right to it so you‚Äôre not talking to me under the wrong pretenses, but I‚Äôm not sure how to navigate this, either.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs there anything I can do to help?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs just it,‚Äù she said. She frowned. ‚ÄúI wanted to have a conversation with you for another reason.‚Äù

That stung, in a way. That we weren‚Äôt meeting up for the sake of meeting up.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI might have made a mistake,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAnd I was thinking you might be able to help.‚Äù

Flare — 2.5

‚ÄúA mistake?‚Äù

‚ÄúI worry it‚Äôs the case. Time will tell, but I can make educated guesses and I have concerns.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have to admit, I‚Äôm not sure how to respond to that,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd say you‚Äôre only human or you‚Äôre only mortal, but doesn‚Äôt that sound condescending, coming from a parahuman?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all mortal, Victoria. Even Scion was.‚Äù

I nodded.

It was strange to hear that name spoken out loud. Nine out of ten times, people would avoid saying it out loud. As if they couldn‚Äôt reconcile the first hero with the thing that had ended the world.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd like to help,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúA couple of things are off the table, obviously, but you know what they are, I think. I wouldn‚Äôt be okay if you wanted me to reach out to my sister, or that kind of thing.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt ask you to do that, no. This isn‚Äôt anything of that scale, but‚Ä¶‚Äù she frowned. ‚ÄúGiven our relationship, with you having been my patient, there‚Äôs a power imbalance. I want to do what I can to ensure I don‚Äôt abuse it. I want to be fair to you.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said. After a pause, I added, ‚ÄúI appreciate the sentiment.‚Äù

‚ÄúEven if this turns out to be minor, it is hard to do without risking a breach of trust and damage to our friendship.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI want to ensure we‚Äôre on the same page, when it comes to expectations. I definitely don‚Äôt want you to feel obligated, whether it‚Äôs because you feel you owe me something, or because you feel you should. I know there‚Äôs a tendency among heroes to want to step forward and help. I‚Äôve counseled many a junior hero that they needed to learn to pick their battles.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have no idea what you mean,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI pick my battles. Except for the broken trigger last week, the community center, and, oh, everything else.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt is a concern,‚Äù she said. She matched my smile with a small one of her own, but it was fleeting, more an acknowledgement of the joke than anything. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre quick to say you want to help, before you even know what I‚Äôm going to ask.‚Äù

I nodded. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think you‚Äôd ask if you hadn‚Äôt thought over it. I trust you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd still be concerned, grateful as I am for your trust in me.‚Äù

I swished the ice in my iced tea.

‚ÄúI am sorry,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúSorry?‚Äù

‚ÄúIf I‚Äôve upset you, approaching this like I have.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid I give you that impression? That I was upset?‚Äù I was pretty sure my face hadn‚Äôt betrayed anything. I was reasonably sure my power wasn‚Äôt leaking, either.

‚ÄúYou did. And if I‚Äôm right about that, please don‚Äôt misunderstand me, I am sorry, and I wouldn‚Äôt fault you for being upset. I would like to have meetings like the one I think you were anticipating today. You and me, staying in touch to a degree, talking over iced tea and ice coffee. I‚Äôd hoped to have one of those meetings before getting around to this topic.‚Äù

So it wasn‚Äôt too urgent, then.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said. I took another careful sip of my iced tea.

She drew in a deep breath, reached back to where the damp, folded paper towel was laying against her neck, and set it within the lid of her iced coffee, which she‚Äôd put to one side. She stared down at it for a moment.

I waited. I had some ideas about what she was getting around to. I also had things I might have said, but I was worried that, depending on what she was going to say next, they could be things I‚Äôd regret. If her reasons were good, if they were personal‚Ä¶

I was so fucking done with regrets. I didn‚Äôt want to add more, especially any tied to Jessica.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to compound my mistakes elsewhere with one here. With that in mind, I want to make it absolutely clear that this isn‚Äôt an obligation. I‚Äôd like a bit of help, if you heard me out and were comfortable giving it. I‚Äôd explain the situation as best as I could, but the confidentiality of other patients makes things difficult.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat do you need?‚Äù

‚ÄúBefore we get into that, touching back on what I said before about wanting to be fair to you, I‚Äôve contacted a colleague. He‚Äôll be your therapist if you still want one. He‚Äôs waiting for your call and he‚Äôll make an appointment with you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt have to do that. I wouldn‚Äôt want to burden you guys more. What‚Äôs going on, that you‚Äôre going to all this?‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe it‚Äôs necessary, maybe not, but it‚Äôs my apology and my thanks to you for having this conversation with me, and for any compromise of the relationship. It doesn‚Äôt mean you have to hear me out, and it absolutely doesn‚Äôt mean you have to say yes. Alright?‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright, but it doesn‚Äôt matter,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll hear you out.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt matters to me,‚Äù she said, firm.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said, a little exasperated. It was clear Jessica was stubborn when she was bothered by something. ‚ÄúFine. You made a mistake, you want my help. I‚Äôll phone your colleague and possibly go see him. I‚Äôll weigh what you‚Äôre asking and I‚Äôll try to make an objective decision. Which may be no.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat do you need?‚Äù I asked, again, holding my iced tea in both hands.

‚äô

Mrs. Yamada wasn‚Äôt ‚ÄòJessica‚Äô anymore, not any more than capes went by their civilian names in costume. She was in her professional attire, a suit jacket over a blouse, a business skirt, minimal jewelry, minimal and tasteful makeup. Papers rustled as she paged through files and as the wind blew into the room.

She had told me to dress in a way that was comfortable for me. It was still hot out and I‚Äôd had to travel forty miles to get to a place where Mrs. Yamada could pick me up to drive me the rest of the way. Even though the heat persisted, the weather had broken, the humidity giving way to a light thunderstorm. I wore a white dress with a black hood built into it, the Brockton Bay skyline printed in what looked like black and grey watercolors across the breast, the city‚Äôs name below and to the side. There was a scribbling of more watercolor and lettering at the hem. The white fabric was a thin sweatshirt-like material, so the hood hadn‚Äôt been much use against the rain.

The windows were open and the blinds closed, periodically clacking against the windowsills. The wind wasn‚Äôt blowing in a direction that sent the rain into the room, but droplets still beaded the blinds closer to the bottom. The lights felt artificially bright, in contrast to how dark the clouds and sky were outside. The room was set up like a high school classroom, minus the ‚Äòclass‚Äô, no students, no mess, no bulletin board with scraps on it or whiteboard with weeks-old marks that hadn‚Äôt been wiped away. Eight chairs were arranged in a ring at the center, instead of five columns of six desks.

There was a teacher‚Äôs desk at the front, and Mrs. Yamada was there, looking over some files. I‚Äôd caught some glimpses of the pictures on the fronts, purely by accident. I could have pried more, maybe caught a name or a heading by reading upside-down, and I‚Äôd decided not to. She wouldn‚Äôt have wanted me to.

‚ÄúDo I have a file?‚Äù I asked. She startled a little, as if she‚Äôd forgotten I was there.

She‚Äôd been in the zone, I realized. She might have needed to be. She didn‚Äôt wear it on her face or in her body language, but there was a reason she was so immersed in what she was reading.

I could relate to that, in a way. During my hospital stay, I‚Äôd delved deep into my studies, struggled with the keyboard as I read everything I could find, while furthering my studies with long-distance education.

‚ÄúSorry to interrupt,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine. You did have a file. You don‚Äôt now, I‚Äôm afraid. Unless it‚Äôs somewhere in the rubble.‚Äù

I nodded.

She glanced at the clock. ‚ÄúOne of the group‚Äôs members tends to arrive early. She should be here momentarily.‚Äù

I looked up at the clock. One fifty in the afternoon. From how dark it was outside, I might have thought it was five hours later in the day. ‚ÄúGood to know.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt will be interesting to see how you two get on.‚Äù

‚ÄúHuh.‚Äù

I heard the footsteps and glanced at the clock again. Not even a minute had elapsed. Was this person that punctual?

I wasn‚Äôt sure what I‚Äôd expected. She wasn‚Äôt yet a teenager, or if she was then she was a late bloomer, but she wasn‚Äôt wholly a ‚Äòchild‚Äô either. ‚ÄòTween‚Äô. My first thought was that she was as cute as a button, and not in the pink princess way.

She was black, her arms and legs long and skinny, her eyes large in proportion to her face. She was studying me with just as much or more intensity than I studied her, as we sized each other up.

She was dressed or had been dressed with an eye for modern fashion, fitting to her age. She wore a blue corduroy pinafore dress with metal studs forming a star shape at the leg. Her top was a t-shirt, with an image on it in sequins, the kind that had two different images, depending on the direction the sequins were swept. The image depicted a blue heart if brushed one way, a yellow star if swept the other; I knew because it was a jumbled mix of both.

The reason I thought that she might have been dressed by someone else was that she was so very precise about how she‚Äôd put her outfit together. It was freshly ironed or fresh off the rack, and it was color matched from her shoes to the pins and ties in her hair. The star theme too. Kinky black hair had been fixed into place at the side of her head with a star pin, and carefully arranged into two small, tight buns at the back. Glossy and taken care of, not a strand out of place. It would have taken me twenty or thirty minutes to do the same, and my straight hair would have been easier to manage, even being as long as it was.

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù I responded.

‚ÄúGosh, you‚Äôre pretty,‚Äù she said.

I was momentarily lost for words. Very direct.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù I said, glancing back at Mrs. Yamada, hoping for a cue. She was focusing on her notes. She briefly met my eye, but communicated nothing.

‚ÄúI can tell you were a hero. You have that air about you,‚Äù the girl said.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù I said, a little caught off guard. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nice to meet you.‚Äù

She smiled, her enthusiasm renewed, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs amazing to meet you. I‚Äôm really interested to hear what you have to say. I really want to be a hero, so I‚Äôm trying to learn all I can.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat could be good. It‚Äôs better than the alternative, at least.‚Äù

‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt it? You were probably a good one, weren‚Äôt you? You give me that impression. You‚Äôre stylish, I really like your dress, and you have that posture, back straight, unyielding. Only the best and the true up-and-comers have that.‚Äù

‚ÄúKenzie,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said.

‚ÄúYes?‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no pressure.‚Äù

Kenzie only smiled in response.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay,‚Äù I said. I was glad to have a window to speak. ‚ÄúI like your outfit too, Kenzie. Good clothes are so hard to get these days, aren‚Äôt they?‚Äù

‚ÄúThis outfit was part of a birthday present, but I think it was expensive, yeah. I wanted to look nicer since we had someone new today.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no need to go to extra trouble. Not for me.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo trouble, no trouble,‚Äù she said, very cavalier. She looked at Mrs. Yamada, ‚ÄúHow are you today, Mrs. Yamada?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm doing very well today, Kenzie. How are you this morning?‚Äù

‚ÄúCan‚Äôt complain,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúDoes it matter where I sit?‚Äù

‚ÄúNothing‚Äôs changed from the prior sessions. Sit wherever you‚Äôre comfortable, it doesn‚Äôt matter.‚Äù

Kenzie smiled. ‚ÄúI think it matters. It means something. Can I sit here?‚Äù

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù I said.

She seated herself in the chair next to the one I was standing beside.

I snuck a glance at Mrs. Yamada, and I saw concern. Because of the others who were due to arrive?

‚ÄúYou probably caught my name, I‚Äôm Kenzie.‚Äù

She was extending a hand for me to shake. I shook it, then turned the chair a bit as I sat down. ‚ÄúVictoria. Some call me Vicky, but I‚Äôm using that less these days. You can use it if it‚Äôs easier.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you‚Äôre a heroine?‚Äù

‚ÄúI used to be. I‚Äôm on hiatus.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the coolest thing,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúCostumes, fighting bad guys.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt had its ups and downs,‚Äù I said. I glanced at Mrs. Yamada. Her focus was on her notes.

She noticed me looking and asked, ‚ÄúYou used to be her patient?‚Äù

‚ÄúI did.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs the best,‚Äù Kenzie said, leaning over and speaking with a voice quiet enough that Mrs. Yamada wouldn‚Äôt necessarily hear.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. Except for her apparent mistake here, which I wasn‚Äôt equipped to make a judgment call on. Not quite yet.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good here; I always look forward to coming. Everyone‚Äôs pretty neat. That might not mean a lot coming from me, though.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow come?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think everyone‚Äôs pretty neat,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúI see. That‚Äôs admirable.‚Äù

The papers rustled. Mrs. Yamada put the files in a filing cabinet beside the desk at the end of the room, locking them away. She spoke aloud, ‚ÄúCan I get you two anything? Water?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine, but thank you,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúNo thank you,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThe others may be a bit late, with the weather being what it is.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think we‚Äôll survive the wait,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúRight, Victoria?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll survive. Past years have taught me patience, if nothing else,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúFrom being a Ward? Were you a Ward?‚Äù Kenzie asked.

That wasn‚Äôt where or why, I thought, but I said, ‚ÄúVery briefly. My family had a team. Still does, kind of.‚Äù

Very kind of.

‚ÄúOh, wow, neat.‚Äù

I tried to find a diplomatic way to respond to that.

‚ÄúOr not so neat?‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúUps and downs,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI was with the PRT, but I wasn‚Äôt a Ward exactly,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThey had trouble sticking me anywhere, and then I went into training, and got to do a lot of really neat camps and exercises and travel, because they had to wait until I was old enough before they could put me where they really wanted to put me.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhich was?‚Äù

‚ÄúWatchdog, grrr,‚Äù she said. She‚Äôd made a pretty sad attempt at a growl, mischief in her eyes. ‚ÄúThat other branch that worked under the PRT that you almost never hear about. Oversight and investigation, powers, money, and politics.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know of Watchdog.‚Äù

‚ÄúCubicle superheroes.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre actually pretty badass from what I heard, and they do— did a lot of fieldwork and investigations, raiding offices, interrogations, talking to politicians, uncovering conspiracies.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs true.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs something about getting organized and going after that thinker or that tinker who‚Äôs been working behind the scenes, the guy that‚Äôs been subverting society for their own gain, when they‚Äôve probably spent months or years making contingency plans and anticipating the day their world and their plans come crashing down around them. I think that dynamic is pretty damn cool, the approach and the complexity of it.‚Äù

‚ÄúHmm, that is cool,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúExcept there aren‚Äôt any awesome costumes or monster fighting.‚Äù

‚ÄúLess monster fighting, I‚Äôm sure. I‚Äôm not sure about the costumes. There are probably masks, I guess?‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd there‚Äôs some cublical— bleh. Cubicle jockeying.‚Äù

She spoke so fast she had tripped over the word.

I replied, ‚ÄúProbably a lot, yeah. But from my short stint in the Wards, there was a lot of paperwork there too.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs so true. I was kind of a Ward, so I had to do some. I think I was good at the paperwork.‚Äù

I was starting to feel like she‚Äôd been the one who had fussed with her appearance, rather than any parental figure. Someone so fussy would‚Äôve somehow been mentioned in the life story to this point. It was very believable, too, to draw a connection between the fastidious appearance and her pride in the paperwork.

‚ÄúI think I was too.‚Äù

She nodded, the conversation momentarily, almost mercifully pausing, then she found her place, enthusiasm returning. ‚ÄúSo yeah. I was bouncing all over the place. The Youth Guard stepped in, I‚Äôm not sure if you‚Äôve had to deal with them.‚Äù

The Youth Guard or the Y.G. were the group that acted like the union that protected minors in Hollywood. That had protected minors in Hollywood. They were the group that made sure that Wards‚Äô education and options didn‚Äôt suffer as a consequence for them being superheroes, that they didn‚Äôt dress provocatively, that they were safe and sane, that nobody took advantage, and other stuff. They‚Äôd reached out to my parents at one point, because they weren‚Äôt limited to the PRT. They were a guillotine that had hung over the heads of any team with under-eighteen heroes or heroines.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve heard the horror stories,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThey weren‚Äôt a horror story for me. They said I was being moved around too much and I needed to go somewhere to stay. Not going to the fun camps and training sucked, but I went back to Baltimore, and I got to set up my workshop, fi-nuh-ly.‚Äù

‚ÄúWorkshop, huh?‚Äù

‚ÄúKenzie,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada spoke up. She still sat at the desk. ‚ÄúYou might want to be mindful of what you reveal. I‚Äôll get into that more when things get started, but take a moment and think before revealing things that might tie into your cape identity, or identifying parts of your background.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, Mrs. Yamada,‚Äù Kenzie said. Then she leaned close to me, whispering, ‚ÄúI took a moment to think and I think I‚Äôm safe telling you I‚Äôm a tinker.‚Äù

‚ÄúGotcha,‚Äù I said, mimicking her volume and whisper.

‚ÄúYep,‚Äù she said. She pitched her voice lower, ‚ÄúThe Youth Guard was good to me. I liked the people who I worked with there, even if the people in charge of me didn‚Äôt. Some of my favorite people next to Mrs. Yamada worked for them. Not that that lasted for long. That was only the spring of twenty-thirteen—‚Äù

As she talked, I glanced at Mrs. Yamada. It was clear she heard.

‚Äú—and then, well‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said.

Gold Morning.

I was a little caught off guard by Kenzie, on a few fronts. This wasn‚Äôt what I‚Äôd expected. I glanced at the other chairs.

‚äô

I got into a more comfortable position in the little booth, leaning against the window and taking a moment to digest what Mrs. Yamada had shared. Someone else walked into the dark little shop, going straight to the counter, their eyes on the desserts behind the display.

‚ÄúGroup therapy?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúWith the full-time position I‚Äôm taking with the Wardens, I have the chance to help a lot of critical individuals. The people I‚Äôll be helping will be people who can help a lot of people in turn. An incredible number, in some cases. As attached as I am to my current patient caseload, and as much as I would like to take you on as a patient, it made the most sense to go this route.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said.

She frowned a little.

‚ÄúBut?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúThe role I held between Gold Morning and now was always going to be a transient one. My patients and everyone else involved knew I was only seeing the patients I‚Äôm seeing now in a temporary way. I‚Äôm one of several therapists who are rotating through a patient caseload, and only half were my patients and mine alone. In making a transition, it is and was still my responsibility to look after those exclusive patients.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù I connected that thought to how she‚Äôd found a therapist for me. When it was a chore to get therapists to take new patients, it amounted to a pretty meaningful gesture.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm referring the ones I can to other therapists. I‚Äôm in touch with twelve people who work with parahumans and a few who are breaking into that field. Not a single one of us is working less than seventy hours a week. Some of my patients didn‚Äôt need counseling anymore, and I was only helping them to find their equilibrium after Gold Morning. Others are on their way to a new facility in this world‚Äôs Europe, which they‚Äôve been anticipating for over a year now. If you were still in the same condition as you were when I first met you, I would be recommending you go there.‚Äù

I nodded. I didn‚Äôt like thinking about it.

‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt find places for everyone, and I‚Äôd turn down the job before I abandoned patients in need. With the remainder, I saw common ground among them. Not all of them, but enough of them that it seemed like things could be workable. Some supplied, needed, or were looking into the same kinds of assistance, which is what prompted the line of thinking. I was going to introduce them regardless, I could see them talking, and I thought it would be best to have the initial and deeper talks in a supervised setting.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd from there, it was a short jump to thinking about group therapy.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes. Group therapy, interpersonal group therapy, seemed appropriate for what I wanted them to address with each of them. It meant that in the time before I took on my full-time role with the Wardens, I could devote more time to more of them. In an ideal world, if there were some who still needed attention by the time I was done, I could call in favors or find places for them.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúWas it group therapy like I was a part of?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe therapy you were a part of was encounter-driven. Different. More involved, more simulations, acting and role-playing, confrontation, learning assertiveness as opposed to, say, aggressive behavior, or overly passive behavior. Engaging with peers.‚Äù

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt really do anything except sit there.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut you wrote the scripts. You listened to the others, and you visualized ways you wanted the conversations to go. I got the impression it was pretty intense, even when you were a step removed in your participation.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù I said. A large part of what I‚Äôd contributed to those sessions had played into my last interaction with my mom.

Not that that interaction had gone well, but I could imagine that if I‚Äôd found myself in that same situation without the grounding of knowledge from those sessions, I might not have had the words to articulate as much of what I‚Äôd wanted to. It was even possible that, without the conflict resolution skills, I might have hurt someone.

The recollections of the therapy and of my mom were heavy, pressing down on me and my chest. I took a long sip of my iced tea. It was cold and sensory, pulling me away from that rabbit hole of dark thoughts.

‚ÄúThis group was intended to be slower-paced, less intense,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúEven with the time constraint?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, even with. Part of it is that, as I said, it was the most appropriate for what I wanted to address.‚Äù

‚ÄúPart?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe other part ties back to what I said about introductions, how the first meetings are the trickiest. It was a delicate balancing act to begin with, compared to your group, where we added someone new once every few weeks or months, while the rest of the group remained fairly stable. With this group, having them all meet at once, I thought it would be best to keep things calmer.‚Äù

‚ÄúMakes sense,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúMy colleagues like to say there is a truism with groups of parahumans. That the larger the group in question, the greater the chance of a schism or disaster. I‚Äôm not sure I like exactly how the idea is presented a lot of the time it comes up, but‚Ä¶‚Äù

I thought of my sister.

‚ÄúGroups of capes get pretty volatile,‚Äù I finished the sentence for her. ‚ÄúEach person you add is another chance for things to go wrong.‚Äù

‚äô

Three more members joined the group. An unknown boy and two people I knew, male and female.

When I realized who I was looking at, though, my jaw dropped. I stood from my chair.

She, for her part, was on a similar page. She stared at me, confused at first. Then reality dawned for her as well.

She was pale in a way that skin didn‚Äôt tend to be, and she had a mane of black hair. A small black tattoo marked her cheekbone, partially obscured by skin-tone makeup that had streaked in the rain. For all that she was almost monochrome from the neck up, she was a riot of color from the neck down. Sveta.

Her hands went to her mouth.

She closed the distance between us with a half-stagger, half-run kind of movement. I caught a glimpse of her tearing up before she threw her arms around me, colliding with me. I caught my bearings and hugged her back.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre okay,‚Äù she mumbled into my shoulder.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm—‚Äù I started, lost for words. I looked at Weld, who stood in the doorway, smiling as wide as I‚Äôd ever seen him smile.

My arms still around her, I reached out with one hand, groping in Weld‚Äôs general direction, as if I could get the words that way.

‚ÄúFantastic,‚Äù Weld said. ‚ÄúThis is perfect.‚Äù

He looked a little less neat than he‚Äôd been when I‚Äôd known him in Brockton Bay, but not as wild or ‚Äòmonstrous‚Äô as I‚Äôd seen in the pictures online, back when he‚Äôd been a member of the Irregulars. His skin was dark iron, his eyes silver, veins of more silver tracing from the corners of the eyes. His hair was wire, made to look more free and unruly. He was wearing a henley shirt, khaki shorts and sandals that looked like they were made of metal and what might‚Äôve been tire rubber. I couldn‚Äôt imagine any other material that would hold up when bearing the weight of someone that was heavy metal from head to toe.

Beside him was a guy, brown-skinned, with the sides and back of his hair cut short. The hair on top had to have been painted rather than dyed, because it was magenta, and I couldn‚Äôt imagine getting black hair dyed magenta without bleaching it to the point of destroying it, and the rolling curls retained their shape despite the droplets of rain that clung to it. He was smiling, but more because he looked like the type that very much enjoyed others being happy. The magenta-haired guy‚Äôs shirt was form-fitting to his upper body, showing off lean muscle, and looked like a surfer‚Äôs rash guard. He wore black shorts and sandals.

I turned my attention to the girl of the trio. I couldn‚Äôt believe it was Sveta.

Who was practically sobbing now, apparently.

Emotion was welling in my own chest. I put my hand on the back of her head, and I felt the hair stir, the tissues beneath the wig moving.

‚ÄúWell, I think this has made my everything,‚Äù Weld said.

‚ÄúYour everything?‚Äù the magenta-haired guy asked.

‚ÄúSaying it made my day, my week, or even my month wouldn‚Äôt be enough,‚Äù Weld said, still smiling. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre okay, Victoria?‚Äù

‚ÄúTwo arms, two legs,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs great,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSveta was so attached to you, she hated leaving you behind.‚Äù

Sveta nodded, head rubbing against my shoulder.

‚ÄúAnd we‚Äôd thought you‚Äôd died,‚Äù Weld said. ‚ÄúWhen G.M. happened. Hearing you were alive was amazing on its own, but you‚Äôre‚Ä¶ you‚Äôre back. Fantastic.‚Äù

Sveta made a sound, emotions pouring over, before hiccuping with a sob.

I stroked the back of her head, trusting that someone would tell me not to if it was dangerous.

Then again, I didn‚Äôt have my forcefield up.

I could have mentioned it. I didn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúYou have a body,‚Äù I whispered. I could feel it. It was hard, unyielding. She creaked in places, and the way she‚Äôd moved— the colors and textures I‚Äôd seen—

None of that mattered. She had a body.

‚ÄúIt took some doing,‚Äù Weld said. ‚ÄúIt took a lot of doing. It‚Äôs been a whole adventure to get even this far. It‚Äôs not even tinkertech. Regular prosthetics and some inventiveness from some really stellar people. Arms, legs, body, some stuff to keep it upright, some machine learning systems that adapt to meet her partway, and a lot of practice on her part, to operate everything internal.‚Äù

Sveta pulled away. She looked me in the eye, reaching up to wipe at her tears. The hands didn‚Äôt seem cooperative enough, almost like someone holding a baseball bat by one end was trying to wipe away tears with the other.

I hesitated, before indicating her face. ‚ÄúDo you want a hand?‚Äù

She nodded, and I wiped the tears away with my fingers. She smiled, even as more welled up.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre such a sneak, Jessica,‚Äù Weld said. ‚ÄúNot telling us?‚Äù

‚ÄúI did tell you Victoria was recovered.‚Äù

‚ÄúI thought you meant she was mobile enough to get to the meeting place on her own. I didn‚Äôt think you meant a complete and total recovery,‚Äù Weld said.

I wanted to turn to see Mrs. Yamada‚Äôs expression, but it was hard to move with Sveta hugging me. She was silent, though.

Behind Weld, someone else was ducking into the room. He looked like he was of a height with Kenzie, but given how boys developed slower, he might‚Äôve been a touch older. He had a mess of tousled brown hair that would have been over his eyes if he wasn‚Äôt wearing large headphones as a kind of hairband. He had a very flat expression as he walked around the perimeter of the room. His t-shirt was black with a logo I didn‚Äôt recognize, his cargo shorts had stuff packed into the pockets, but he mostly looked like a very average kid. Only his old fashioned braces really stood out to me— the kind that made it hard for him to put his lips together.

Sveta twisted around, one hand reaching out to me to steady herself. She looked over at Kenzie, then at the magenta-haired fellow, and then at the new kid. She failed on her first attempt at speaking, then managed. ‚ÄúShe was my first friend ever, that I can remember.‚Äù

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know that,‚Äù I murmured.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt have anyone, and— there was a time where I was cooped up in a sealed room in the hospital and stuff was going on outside, with the PRT and the other case fifty-threes. They introduced me to people who were harder for me to hurt. Victoria was one of them. I liked her, and she knew Weld, and she put up with me for some reason, so we kept talking and meeting.‚Äù

I leaned closer, whispering in her ear. ‚ÄúFor some reason? You helped keep me sane. You were my friend.‚Äù

‚ÄúStop it, dummy. You‚Äôre going to make me cry more,‚Äù she whispered back. ‚ÄúAnd I can‚Äôt believe I‚Äôm finally hearing your voice for real.‚Äù

And with that last statement she was tearing up more.

‚ÄúSince when are you this much of a crier?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm all emotionally open and shit now,‚Äù she whispered. ‚ÄúBlame Weld. And blame yourself, being all normal and stuff.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm pretty sure I just caught you saying my name just now,‚Äù Weld said. ‚ÄúMaybe that‚Äôs my cue to duck out before you start badmouthing me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd never ever badmouth you,‚Äù Sveta said, at normal volume. She‚Äôd turned to face him, and I held her arm to steady her as she swayed a bit. ‚ÄúWhat would I even say?‚Äù

‚ÄúI hear people coming anyway,‚Äù Weld said. He stopped, looking at Sveta and me, then smiled wide. ‚ÄúThis is fantastic.‚Äù

Sveta hugged my arm.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve said that a lot,‚Äù the Magenta-haired boy said.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt even begin to tell you,‚Äù Weld said. ‚ÄúIn more than one way. I‚Äôll leave it for Victoria to share.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe we can chat another time,‚Äù the boy said. ‚ÄúWe could hang out.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf Sveta, Victoria, and Jessica okay it,‚Äù Weld said, clapping a hand on the guy‚Äôs shoulder. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to throw any wrenches into the therapy or make anything awkward by blurring lines.‚Äù

‚ÄúSend me an email if you want to discuss it. It‚Äôs always good to see you, Weld,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll do that, and it‚Äôs good to see you too, Jessica. I‚Äôm sorry I wasn‚Äôt able to make the time to sit in.‚Äù

‚ÄúTotally understandable. Good luck. We may run into each other if you stick with the Wardens.‚Äù

‚ÄúExcellent,‚Äù Weld said. He glanced at us, delivering a wink probably more meant for Sveta than for me. ‚ÄúFantastic. I‚Äôll text you when I have an idea of what‚Äôs happening with my afternoon, Sveta.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood luck,‚Äù Sveta said.

With a parting salute, he was gone.

I took my seat, giving my hand to Sveta, as she collapsed into the chair on the other side of me. Now that she wasn‚Äôt bear-hugging me, I could see that a lot of the color on her was that the prosthetic body she wore had been painted. Bumps and collisions had chipped some of the paint, but from the neck down, everything that wasn‚Äôt covered in clothing was painted in rolling waves, in sea serpents, birds and reptiles. The colors were bright and bold, like graffiti, the living things hot orange, the background cool blues and greens. Her clothes were relatively plain, a black top and brown pants, and looked to be relatively thick and durable, but the plain-ness was marred by the small streaks and smudges of paint that she‚Äôd gotten on it, most of it in long, thin slashes.

The seating arrangement put me between her and Kenzie. Kenzie, for the time being, was leaning over to the new addition to the group, the boy with braces. She seemed to be filling him in on what he‚Äôd missed.

‚ÄúTristan,‚Äù the magenta-haired boy said, approaching. He extended a hand. I shook it.

‚ÄúVictoria.‚Äù

‚ÄúWill your brother be joining us today?‚Äù Mrs. Yamada asked.

‚ÄúI asked, he didn‚Äôt reply,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúBrother?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúTwin,‚Äù Tristan said. He pointed at his hair. ‚ÄúPart of the reason I make myself so easily identifiable. He‚Äôs Byron, he used to have blue-green hair to match me, but he quit doing that.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood to know,‚Äù I said.

Blue hair.

I thought of my youngest cousin. Where Crystal had always had the red-magenta look, Eric had gone with the blue, dying his hair. It was a sad, wistful thought. With so many losses in recent memory, so much tumult, it felt very distant. That distance didn‚Äôt make it it feel any less painful. If I‚Äôd been burned on an hourly, daily or weekly basis for the last four years, the death of Eric and Uncle Neil would have been the very first time my hand was shoved down and held to the oven ring.

Alarming and hard to process in how devastating and raw it had been, important, but still a very long time ago.

I changed up my focus, ‚ÄúYou all came in together. Are you friends?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo. Or kind of?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúKind of,‚Äù Sveta said.

Tristan explained, ‚ÄúI ran into Weld and Sveta on the way into the first session. He dropped her off at the front door because he had a place to be, and I offered my arm. Sveta and I geeked out together over Weld.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs geek-out worthy,‚Äù I said.

Tristan smiled. ‚ÄúDoes the impromptu Weld fan club have another member?‚Äù

‚ÄúNah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúNo, I‚Äôm just a fan in a very mundane way. I think he‚Äôs a good guy.‚Äù

Sveta nodded emphatically.

‚ÄúAt our first meeting, Tristan kept saying he was Weld‚Äôs number one fan,‚Äù Kenzie joined in.

‚ÄúOh, that. Don‚Äôt remind me,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúI won‚Äôt, then,‚Äù Kenzie said, deflating a little.

Tristan sighed, glancing at the rest of the room. ‚ÄúNah, it‚Äôs no good to leave our guest in the lurch, and I‚Äôm supposed to be holding myself accountable. You might as well share, I‚Äôll take my licks.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù Kenzie said, perking up considerably at the same time Tristan withered. ‚ÄúSo Tristan kept saying it, casually mentioning the posters he had before, and he had merchandise.‚Äù

‚ÄúWeld figurine, from his stint in the Boston Wards. One where he was wearing his first costume, too,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúI miss that thing.‚Äù

‚ÄúI want one,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúWould it be weird if I had one?‚Äù

Kenzie continued, ‚ÄúSo he kept saying all that, because he was so psyched he got to meet Weld. Then Sveta finally speaks up, and she was very quiet when she said it, but she said ‚ÄòI probably have you beat.‚Äô‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm competitive,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúSo I was pretty adamant that no, no she didn‚Äôt.‚Äù

Sveta looked like she was on top of the world, smiling to herself. She wiped at her face with one prosthetic hand— she still had tracks of tears on her face. I leaned closer, whispering. ‚ÄúWant a tissue?‚Äù

She nodded. I stood from my seat while the conversation continued.

‚Äú‚Ä¶And she says she‚Äôs his girlfriend,‚Äù Kenzie said.

Tristan sighed. ‚ÄúYep.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs living with him, and they sleep in the same bed, and they make each other breakfast,‚Äù Kenzie said.

I liked the mental image. I liked that Sveta was smiling as much as she was.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to beat that,‚Äù Tristan said.

I collected a tissue from Mrs. Yamada‚Äôs desk, glancing at her. She seemed pretty unbothered by this, so far.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs about winning,‚Äù Sveta said.

I handed the tissue to Sveta as I retook my seat, and she set about patting her cheeks dry. A little bit more of the cover-up makeup came away from the tattoo.

‚ÄúYeahhhh,‚Äù Tristan drew out the word. He added, ‚ÄúEasy to say when you‚Äôre the clear winner.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs fair,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a joke, by the way. I‚Äôm not being serious here.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI was wondering there.‚Äù

Another person had entered the room. A boy, Caucasian, with shoulder-length brown-blond hair. He had a cut under one eye and another cut on the bridge of his nose. His jeans were ripped at the knee and his shirt was baggy, a size too big for him. The sleeves were long, red where the torso was white, and they had been rolled up to the elbow. His sneakers had seen a lot of abuse, by the looks of it. The white parts were brown and grey in a way that made me suspicious that even a thorough cleaning wouldn‚Äôt get them purely white again. He looked sixteen or seventeen.

‚ÄúBut yeah, damn, I don‚Äôt look good enough in a dress, so I have to concede. Hey Rain,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúHeya,‚Äù the boy who was apparently called ‚ÄòRain‚Äô said. He took the empty seat next to Tristan. ‚ÄúWhy are you wearing a dress?‚Äù

‚ÄúJust joking around.‚Äù

There were still two empty seats. One would be Jessica‚Äôs. There‚Äôd be one more, then.

‚ÄúYou made it here okay?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúYeah. I got a ride.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow are things?‚Äù Kenzie asked Rain. She gestured at her head in a way I didn‚Äôt see, with her head blocking my view of the hand on the other side.

Rain seemed to take a second to ponder it. He frowned a little. ‚ÄúNot great.‚Äù

‚ÄúBetter or worse than last week?‚Äù Kenzie asked.

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs save the therapy-relevant stuff for the session,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada interrupted. ‚ÄúSmall talk and catching up for now, please. We don‚Äôt want to get started before everyone‚Äôs here, and I want to go over ground rules and expectations before we ask anything too personal.‚Äù

Kenzie smiled and shrugged, settling back into her seat, hands in her lap.

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù Rain said. He turned his attention to me. ‚ÄúThis is the heroine?‚Äù

‚ÄúEx—, kind of,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúBut yeah. Victoria.‚Äù

‚ÄúHi. I‚Äôm Rain. Spelled like the water that falls from the sky.‚Äù

‚ÄúCape or civilian name?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI hate that you have to ask. Civilian. And before you comment on it, yeah, I know. It‚Äôs unusual, I‚Äôve heard the jokes.‚Äù

He‚Äôd said it as if his patience on the subject had run short a long time ago. I threw up my hands in mock surrender, my mouth firmly shut.

He said, ‚ÄúYou said ex, but you didn‚Äôt sound sure. Are you taking a break? Or‚Ä¶?‚Äù

‚ÄúTrying to get back into it after a break, but ended up taking another short break to focus on some background stuff. Getting a handle on things.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he said, as if I‚Äôd said something very heavy, and he‚Äôd felt part of that weight. ‚ÄúI feel like I‚Äôve been trying to get a handle on things since I got my powers.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor a while now, then? If I can ask?‚Äù

‚ÄúJust under a year ago,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI think, along with Chris, I‚Äôm the rookie here.‚Äù

Post-Gold Morning. That helped put things in context.

Chris, too. By process of elimination, he‚Äôd be the boy roughly Kenzie‚Äôs age.

‚ÄúFamily thing. You said that once,‚Äù Kenzie said. Rain acknowledged that with a nod.

‚ÄúSecond gen?‚Äù I asked. I wondered if I had any kindred on that front.

‚ÄúThere are a lot of questions you can ask about the parahuman stuff,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWhen it comes to me, the answer to most of them is ‚Äòit‚Äôs complicated‚Äô.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs fair,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúFor a while now I‚Äôve thought that parahumans should get a membership card, materializing in our hands when we trigger, or arriving in the mail at the first opportunity. A warning on one side, ‚Äòhandle with care‚Äô, and then on the other side, ‚Äòshit is complicated, don‚Äôt ask‚Äô. Something that we can flash now and again, like a get out of jail free card.‚Äù

‚ÄúMine would be worn out, both sides,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúI could get good mileage out of the ‚Äòshit is complicated‚Äô side,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúNow I feel left out,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd like to think mine would be nice and neat, stored away as a just-in-case.‚Äù

‚ÄúReally?‚Äù Tristan asked. ‚ÄúReally?‚Äù

‚ÄúRuh-heally,‚Äù Kenzie said, with exaggerated emphasis and a roll of the eyes. Tristan mirrored her pose some.

‚ÄúI do like the idea,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúThe card.‚Äù

Rain wasn‚Äôt a smiler, by the looks of it, but he‚Äôd seemed to relax more as I talked to him.

‚ÄúBy the way, I should have asked, am I allowed to swear?‚Äù I asked, twisting around to face Mrs. Yamada.

‚ÄúSwearing is fine In moderation,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúBeing here wouldn‚Äôt be nearly as positive if you couldn‚Äôt say what you wanted to say. There‚Äôs a point where swearing takes away from the communication and expression I‚Äôm hoping to see, where you hide behind the swearing, or where it‚Äôs disruptive. I think you six have a good sense of where that point is. I may referee if we get close to it.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI remember the group therapy session we had back at the hospital,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. Sveta had only been there for the initial sessions. She‚Äôd left, I‚Äôd stayed. ‚ÄúPlenty of swearing. But it was different, and we didn‚Äôt have any kids in the group.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, not young kids,‚Äù Sveta said.

I looked over at Kenzie and Chris. ‚ÄúWill I be overstepping or bothering you if I call you kids? I‚Äôm not sure where the comfort zones are.‚Äù

Kenzie snorted. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine.‚Äù

‚ÄúNah,‚Äù Chris said, ‚ÄúHospital? You were at the Asylum?‚Äù

He‚Äôd barely hesitated a second. He‚Äôd been so quiet up until now, and then the moment I‚Äôd given him an avenue to join the conversation, he went straight from negation to asking questions.

Not pleasant questions either.

‚ÄúOh. Sorry,‚Äù Sveta said, to me. ‚ÄúI should have thought you might not want to broadcast it. I‚Äôm sorry. I kind of brought it up earlier, too.‚Äù

On its own, it was something I could handle most of the time, but it might have been a return to the group therapy session, the presence of Sveta and Mrs. Yamada, even, and possibly the fact that I‚Äôd had a few reminders and it was harder and harder to surface, while it almost felt like Chris was pressing down.

Dark, uncomfortable memories stirred. Being paralyzed, silent, the interminable restlessness. The way the things on the television and radio had been almost unbearable to see and listen to, not because of the subject matter, but because of my inability to change the channel or shut it off, even though I‚Äôd asked for it to be put on in the first place.

I had to take a second to swallow and remember normal breathing and cadence again, after thinking about it.

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs not put too much pressure on Victoria, please,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúI understand that you might feel the need to vet her or figure out if you can trust her, and that makes sense, given the degree of what‚Äôs shared here, but let‚Äôs be fair. Let‚Äôs keep the small talk small, I‚Äôll outline things as we start, and you can decide if you‚Äôre uncomfortable. If you are, then we‚Äôll figure out a way to move forward.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre sure.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine,‚Äù I said, glad I was able to find and use a normal tone of voice without any giveaway. I turned back to Chris, ‚ÄúYeah. I was there. Arrived midway through twenty-eleven, year and a half, and then the Asylum-supported housing after.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúBrockton Bay before that?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. I wondered for a second at his jumping to the conclusion, before I remembered I had the city and its name on my dress.

‚ÄúThere was a lot of Brockton Bay in the news, before,‚Äù he observed.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúNot a lot of it good.‚Äù

I wasn‚Äôt sure how to approach the conversation with Chris. He was hard to read, in fashion, in expression— I‚Äôd glance at his mouth to see if he was smiling or frowning and I‚Äôd only see the braces. He‚Äôd been quiet up until now, too, which meant I didn‚Äôt have a lot to go on.

Something about him bothered me. It wasn‚Äôt just the slant of his questions or the way it felt like they were pressing at me, but his demeanor, and little things about his appearance I couldn‚Äôt put my finger on. The messiness of his hair was one of those things. It looked like he had three cowlicks — two at either corner of his hairline and one by his temple. With his hair pushed back by the headphones he hadn‚Äôt taken off, they looked a little like small bald patches with the way the hair splayed out from those points. He held his hands with his fingers curled in. It was offputting in a mild way that lined up with how he came hitting me with those uncomfortable, prying questions and comments.

I wondered if he was one of the ones Mrs. Yamada had been worried about, as part of this group. One of the additions that catalyzed something volatile.

That might have been unfair.

‚ÄúWeld was there for a lot of it,‚Äù Sveta said, backing me up. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve heard some of what happened. Things got scary.‚Äù

In all fairness, as fond as I was of her, I did find something amusing in how it was Sveta saying that last bit. ‚ÄúScary‚Äôs a good way to put it.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut you‚Äôre still wearing the shirt,‚Äù Rain observed. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre attached to the city.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure. It‚Äôs my city. I grew up there.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut you admit it was scary?‚Äù Rain asked.

‚ÄúThe city isn‚Äôt defined by what happened to it. Just like we aren‚Äôt the bad experiences that happen to us,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúAren‚Äôt we?‚Äù Chris asked, leaning forward in his seat, elbows on his knees. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre the sum of the things that have happened to us, good or bad.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe aren‚Äôt,‚Äù I said, firmly. Then, on a moment‚Äôs reflection, I added, ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt be. There‚Äôs a lot of other things going into it.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre making me think back to science class,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI sucked at science. What was it? Nature or nurture?‚Äù

‚ÄúNature versus nurture, yeah,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs it,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI should have remembered that. Are you all about the nature, then?‚Äù

I thought of my family. I‚Äôm not sure that‚Äôs much better.

Amy had agonized over that one.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre getting into territory that‚Äôs close to being therapy again,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said, rescuing me from the line of thinking. ‚ÄúSo I‚Äôm going to interrupt. But it‚Äôs a good point to keep in mind for our discussions later today. I‚Äôm keeping an eye on the clock, and we‚Äôre ready to start.‚Äù

Sounds good, I thought. I glanced at the empty chairs.

She walked around the perimeter of the room, stopping when she stood behind one of the empty chairs. ‚ÄúLet me recap for our visitor and remind the rest of the group what I said at the start of the first session. This particular type of group therapy focuses on self-reflection, effective socializing, supporting each other, helping to problem solve, and examining the patterns we fall into, both the constructive and the problematic. Each of you has spent some time with me working on these things, and this is the platform where we put a lot of that into practice.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy role in this, Victoria, is to be the referee and the coach. I‚Äôll try to ensure everyone gets their turn and has a voice. I‚Äôll try to head off or steer the discussion if it gets into less constructive territory, and to keep things moving if needed. I‚Äôll be chiming in periodically to ensure that confidentiality is stressed. I‚Äôve had Victoria review the same materials I gave the rest of you.‚Äù

I nodded.

‚ÄúWhile I can promise you confidentiality on my part, and while I‚Äôll encourage you all to maintain it, I can‚Äôt guarantee it. If any of you were to pursue villainous activities, the other members of the group could be compelled to testify against you.‚Äù

The final member of the group entered the room. She was somewhere between eighteen and twenty, but her height might have been deceiving. Her white hair was long enough to reach the small of her back, her irises especially pale or similarly white, and she wore a black dress with a dozen straps overlapping in an intricate way at the shoulders and back. The hem of the dress was damaged at one end. Threads frayed, polyester melted, with a noticeable hole in it.

‚ÄúHi, boss,‚Äù Kenzie said, a twinkle of mischief in her eye as Mrs. Yamada gave her a stern look.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad you could make it, Ashley,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve spent the last minute or two going over the basics, reminding others about the aims of the group and how confidentiality works in a group session.‚Äù

‚ÄúTo fill in our guest?‚Äù ‚ÄòAshley‚Äô asked. She went straight to the table at the side of the room where a pitcher of water and paper cups were arranged, pouring herself a glass.

‚ÄúYes. Her name is Victoria. If you‚Äôll take a seat, I‚Äôll bring you anything else you need, but I‚Äôd like for everyone to be seated so I can continue.‚Äù

Ashley walked around behind me and circled the perimeter of the group to reach one of the empty seats. She swept her hand behind her to brush her dress to one side, so it wouldn‚Äôt bunch up awkwardly beneath her as she took a seat on one of the two chairs between Rain and Chris.

She stared at me. Maybe it would have been better to say she stared me down.

I, meanwhile, was left to digest the mistake of Mrs. Yamada‚Äôs that I was here to help address. I was ninety-five percent sure I knew who ‚ÄòAshley‚Äô was when she was in costume, and I was left to take that knowledge and see how it fit together with the issue at hand.

Mrs. Yamada continued, ‚ÄúUse your own discretion when deciding what to share. You‚Äôve all agreed to participate, knowing the risks and difficulties inherent. I‚Äôm hopeful this will be a positive set of exercises. I think that more or less sums it up. I suspect Victoria‚Äôs presence and the fact you‚Äôve all had a week to think about what we talked about last session means you‚Äôll have some questions.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs pretty late to be bringing her in,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúIs she joining the group?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe hadn‚Äôt planned on her joining, per se,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúI invited her because she‚Äôs exceptionally well equipped to address the topics that came up last session. We‚Äôll build on it and you can decide what you‚Äôre willing to share here. During our next and final session, depending on your comfort levels and how much you want to carry on today‚Äôs discussion, she may or may not be in attendance, or not for the full duration.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs it really an ‚Äòissue‚Äô?‚Äù Tristan asked, making air quotes.

‚ÄúI think it could be. Victoria can expand on why, shortly.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre we supposed to know who she is?‚Äù Ashley asked.

I glanced at Mrs. Yamada. She was taking her seat between Ashley and Chris. From the gesture in my direction, and the fact that she wasn‚Äôt stepping in, the ‚Äòreferee‚Äô was leaving the ball in my court.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm Victoria Dallon. If you study Parahumans, my family comes up, because it‚Äôs a literal textbook case of powers running in families. I‚Ä¶ believe you‚Äôve run into my family, Ashley.‚Äù

‚ÄúHave I? I‚Äôve met so many capes it‚Äôs hard to keep track.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you know New Wave?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúWhite bodysuits, symbols in colors?‚Äù

‚ÄúI know a few people like that. I didn‚Äôt always pay attention to names.‚Äù

‚ÄúWould‚Äôve been in Boston. The slang term in the ‚Äòscene‚Äô was the Boston Games.‚Äù

Ashley smiled for the first time.

For the rest of the room, I explained, keeping half of an eye on Mrs. Yamada, to make sure I wasn‚Äôt overstepping. ‚ÄúA series of arrests in Boston saw a shift in the power balance of local gangs. That‚Äôs a pretty common thing, but the Protectorate team followed up on it hard, toppling just about every major and most minor gangs and villains in the city, leaving a void that was bigger than usual. Villains of every power level and stripe flocked to the city, villains in neighboring cities had a vested interest in having a foothold there as a place to retreat to or a place to expand, and it became an entangled nightmare of villain politics and power plays.‚Äù

‚ÄúTime of my life,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúHeroes, like the PRT, and like my family‚Äôs team, followed, to try and keep the peace until things settled. My family‚Äôs team was Lady Photon, Manpower, Flashbang, Brandish, Lightstar and Fleur.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe heroes without masks,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI remember them. I was one of the villains who flocked,‚Äù Ashley said.

That confirmed that she was Damsel of Distress then. B-list villain, chronic headache for the PRT of yesteryear, unpredictable, dangerous, unstable, and fortunately, she‚Äôd been more of a problem for herself than for others. She had been recruited by the Slaughterhouse Nine, to pad their numbers, and had died shortly after.

Her history was one of self-sabotage punctuated by events every two or three years where she was cause for alarm. She had thrived during the Boston Games, in a sense, enough to get her name out there to capes in Northeastern America as a just in case.

She‚Äôd later found a place in the Nine. She was of a particular brand or species of cape, who somehow rose up when everything else was sinking. It almost made a degree of sense, then, that in following with that pattern, she‚Äôd risen up from the grave at the same time the entire world was plunged into chaos.

Kenzie was saying something, and I was having trouble tuning in.
