Slaughterhouse Nine meant Bonesaw. Crawler. That in turn led me to think about my last coherent, me moments, the blank in my memories, the aftermath. It made me think about actual monsters, and the very real possibility that Ashley was one.

‚ÄúWere you there?‚Äù

It took me a second to connect with Ashley‚Äôs question.

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre uncomfortable getting into it, we could change the subject,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said.

‚ÄúCould I just get some water, actually? Sorry, you meant Boston, Ashley?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes. During the Boston Games,‚Äù Ashley said, as Mrs. Yamada stood and went to get the water.

‚ÄúI was a little too young. I followed along back at home, where we made the dining room into a kind of headquarters, putting up a few bulletin boards. I colored in the maps and moved pins as the territories changed hands while doing homework and stuff. Is it a problem?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúWhat are your thoughts on the subject, Victoria?‚Äù Mrs. Yamada asked, handing me the water.

I drank before answering.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine. Boston was mostly fine,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúMy family didn‚Äôt get hurt. To me, she was just a pin on the map of Boston we had in the living room—‚Äù

I saw Damsel‚Äôs expression shift. A slight narrowing of the eyes.

‚Äú—And a few interesting and impressive stories my aunt, uncle, and dad brought home.‚Äù

That amended the narrowing. Lesson learned.

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad to hear that. Questions, thoughts, observations? Anyone?‚Äù

Ashley wasn‚Äôt done with the questions and comments. The words she spoke next were an accusation, and she was very good at sounding accusatory. ‚ÄúYou brought her here to change our minds.‚Äù

‚äô

Our conversation stalled as a waitress wiped down a table behind Jessica. I swished the ice around my now mostly empty glass.

‚ÄúI never liked the codenames,‚Äù Jessica said.

‚ÄúWe might be very different people in that. There‚Äôs something fun about them. They‚Äôre revealing.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey are, but they often reveal just how badly the patient wants to escape, to leave their humanity behind and dive into something well beyond humanity. Some don‚Äôt surface completely. Some hurt others on the way down. Some drown in that vast, incomprehensible sea.‚Äù

I drew in a deep breath, then sighed. ‚ÄúFeeling poetic?‚Äù

‚ÄúMy own kind of escapism, maybe. I think sometimes about a world where all of my patients can go by their real names.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not following the train of thought, I‚Äôm afraid.‚Äù

‚ÄúI arranged the group therapy. I thought for a long time about whether any of my patients were a significant danger to the others, or if they‚Äôd set the therapy of their peers back. I took precautions, I pored over the notes, trying to visualize how things might go, or the topics that I could safely broach or go back to. Like I said, the first meetings are hard.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah. I can imagine that.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd while I don‚Äôt like the way the idea is often interpreted or the conclusions it‚Äôs taken to, there‚Äôs the notion of volatility, and the exponentially increasing chance of trouble as the groups of capes grow larger. With parahumans, things are often exaggerated, both in weak points or the hot button issues they have, or their inclination to push certain buttons. The more you put in one place, the higher the chance of the wrong button being pushed. That was another concern of mine.‚Äù

I nodded. ‚ÄúHow long has the group been running?‚Äù

‚ÄúTwo months and a week, with one or two sessions a week, as situations allow. We‚Äôre not quite at the end, but it‚Äôs close. This was supposed to be the easy middle stretch.‚Äù

‚ÄúSupposed to be? You let your guard down?‚Äù

‚ÄúIn a way. Maybe from the beginning,‚Äù Jessica said.

She looked genuinely bothered. I held my tongue.

She went on, ‚ÄúI spent so much time anticipating and planning for disaster, that I failed to see the other side of that coin. I didn‚Äôt want to think of them as capes. I sought out the things that would help them connect and find reasons to listen to one another.‚Äù

I realized what had happened.

Jessica was nodding to herself. ‚ÄúThat was my mistake. We were approaching the end stretch, and I reminded them of the date we would wrap up and finish. The conversation took a turn, and I was caught flat-footed. They expressed interest in staying together. They want to found a team.‚Äù

‚ÄúA team of?‚Äù

‚ÄúHeroes, it sounds like.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs that so bad?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúWithout going into any particular detail, Victoria, several are troubled, vulnerable, or both. No, I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs good.‚Äù

Flare — 2.6

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not my intent to change your minds,‚Äù I said. I could see some skeptical looks on some faces as I looked around the circle. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here to give another perspective, and maybe to equip you guys with knowledge. If you change your minds because of that— and I think Mrs. Yamada might be hoping for that, then that‚Äôs fine. If not, then I‚Äôd hope you were all going into this with your eyes more open about what you‚Äôre doing.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve addressed my feelings with the group,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúAt the end of the session where the topic first came up, and for a portion of the last session. We had other things demanding our attention, so we weren‚Äôt able to cover it in any depth.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat would be me,‚Äù Rain said, raising a hand.

Jessica continued, ‚ÄúTo abbreviate what I said then, and to reinforce it in the here and now: if you each carried on as you have been until the final group sessions concluded, then moved on from there with the skills and perspective you‚Äôve gained, I think most of you would do fine. Most of you have reached the points in your journeys where you could continue on your own, without needing the one-on-one therapy or the group sessions. You could pursue more conventional therapy, I think anyone could, and you would have my number in case of emergencies or backsliding, but most of you would do fine.‚Äù

‚ÄúReady to be let loose into the urban wilds,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúNot all of us though,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúYou said most, a few times.‚Äù

‚ÄúMost,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúI also had private discussions with several members of the group. I won‚Äôt say what was discussed, or with whom, but no, I don‚Äôt think everyone is ready.‚Äù

The group was silent. I assumed nobody wanted to speak up because they felt like doing so would out them as one of the people who‚Äôd had one of those private conversations.

Mrs. Yamada went on, ‚ÄúMore to the point, beyond any and all of that, I don‚Äôt think the group would necessarily be healthy, taken outside of this setting and function.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou gathered us together so we could support each other,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI feel like we do a good job of that. We bring out the good sides of one another.‚Äù

‚ÄúIn this setting, yes, I have seen that,‚Äù Jessica said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm gratified it‚Äôs been so positive for most of you. But that‚Äôs in a controlled setting, with a mediator to keep things on course and help recognize the sensitive subjects and steer away from them.‚Äù

‚ÄúMay I?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúFeel free.‚Äù

‚ÄúTo build on what you said, I think the things I‚Äôve noticed on the those fronts are that, well, it‚Äôs a big leap from the controlled setting of a place like this to the wild, uncontrolled setting of superheroics. Things will get bad at some point, and when they do, there‚Äôs a tendency for the bad to snowball.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou lived in Brockton Bay,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúIs it possible your sense of normal is skewed?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs— that‚Äôs honestly hard to respond to,‚Äù I said. I didn‚Äôt miss the flicker of a smile on Tristan‚Äôs face at hearing that. ‚ÄúBecause there‚Äôs an answer that springs to mind that I could give you, but I don‚Äôt know where people‚Äôs limits are, I don‚Äôt want to step on toes or upset anyone by giving an example.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know about the others, but I can‚Äôt think of what you‚Äôd say that would potentially upset us,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúI can,‚Äù Rain said.

I raised an eyebrow.

Rain leaned forward, elbows on his knees. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm making a pretty big leap here, but it‚Äôs the response that jumped to mind for me, too. I‚Äôve been here from the start, I think I know where everyone‚Äôs at. I think it‚Äôs okay to say it, but do you mean Gold Morning? I could see where it would be sensitive, considering just about everyone lost someone, but I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs going to push anyone in particular over the edge, here.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah. That was it, thank you,‚Äù I said. I looked past Sveta to Tristan. ‚ÄúWhat happened in Brockton Bay wasn‚Äôt a break from the pattern. It was just the pattern playing out at an accelerated rate. What I‚Äôm talking about, the snowballing, the bad things happening and then compounding each other‚Ä¶ they still happened. A whole lot of individual factors played into the events of that day, and into the engagements and infighting that followed.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen they happen more slowly, there‚Äôs time to rest,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúWhen they happen slowly, there‚Äôs time to get used to the bad, to normalize it. You or people you thought you knew change in reaction to those external factors without anyone realizing it and‚Ä¶ things still compound. The bad days come, and the unresolved stuff from the last bad days catches up or demands resolution.‚Äù

‚ÄúLike Gold Morning, again,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúA lot of things caught up with us around then. Or a lot of things converged to bring it about, maybe. I wasn‚Äôt there so I don‚Äôt know.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was only there for the later parts,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúBut I think you‚Äôre right.‚Äù

‚ÄúThings are better this time,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve learned from mistakes. It‚Äôs a fresh start. The Endbringers are dormant, we‚Äôre finally building things without them being torn down all the time.‚Äù

‚ÄúI agree with Sveta,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúI really think there is a lot of work to be done before we get to a good normal, but that‚Äôs where I want to be out there doing some of that work in the best way I know how, with people I‚Äôve come to know, like, and respect.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like being on the opposite side of an argument from you, Victoria,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt feel good.‚Äù

I reached out for her hand. She met me halfway, putting the prosthetic hand in mine. I squeezed it, realized she might not be able to feel the squeeze, and gave it a waggle. She smiled.

‚ÄúNo hard feelings, okay?‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI get it. You want this. Believe me when I say I want to get out and do some heroic stuff too.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have a boyfriend I feel like I don‚Äôt deserve, and please don‚Äôt use that as a launchpad to get into another topic, Mrs. Yamada.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm keeping my mouth shut for the time being,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said.

Sveta nodded. She looked back at me. ‚ÄúI missed out on most of my teenage years, I don‚Äôt remember my childhood, and I feel so behind.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know. Believe me, I get it, not to the same degree, but I share some of those same feelings,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI know you do,‚Äù she said. She gave me a waggle back.

‚ÄúI think more than a few of us get it,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúLosing years or losing time because we have to deal with shit other people don‚Äôt, and falling behind because of it.‚Äù

Sveta nodded. ‚ÄúMy boyfriend is out and around and he‚Äôs doing great work. He‚Äôs been doing it for a while. He tried to build something with the Irregulars and it went bad. But now he‚Äôs out there again and he‚Äôs with the team, the top team I know about, he‚Äôs doing amazing stuff. I don‚Äôt know if I can ever catch up, but I don‚Äôt want to not try. I don‚Äôt want to let the gap widen.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt can‚Äôt be just about him, you know,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI think that would be more poison than help for a relationship.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not. Well, I mean, it is, but it‚Äôs not about him in a him-and-me romantic sense, it‚Äôs about me and him— sorry, I‚Äôm not making sense.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm following okay,‚Äù I said.

Mrs. Yamada said, ‚ÄúJust take your time, find the words.‚Äù

‚ÄúBack long before I even knew him, he was my reference point for figuring out where we are. We being the C-fifty-threes. If he was popular then we all had a shot at getting more popularity. That was something I could hope I could have one day. And I didn‚Äôt have a lot of hope, so it was important.‚Äù

I reached over, and gave her arm a solid pat. I was still holding her hand.

‚ÄúAnd we spent part of the summer touring other worlds. We were looking for our places of birth, but mostly we were looking for mine. I‚Äôm one of the only ones who remembers mine.‚Äù

She moved one hand over to tap a finger against her forearm. In dark green, almost invisible as a series of dark green images between dark blue sky and dark blue waves, framed by leaping fish in neon orange, were a series of huts.

‚ÄúI was waiting for some updates on my body and so we just had me in my hamster ball, and Weld is so great, so patient‚Ä¶ but I don‚Äôt like being that dependent. I want to be self-sufficient and I want to do it by being a hero.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think that‚Äôs kind of the opposite of the toxic path,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve talked about it before, Sveta, how you‚Äôre worried about how your world revolves around him.‚Äù

Sveta nodded. ‚ÄúWhen you‚Äôre disabled, and I see myself as disabled, then your world gets smaller. Things get harder. It‚Äôs easy to become dependent or let down your guard. Everything‚Äôs hard and it‚Äôs really easy to stop trying altogether, to rely on people who want to help, to do what Victoria said and normalize that behavior and let the toxicity seep into things, only to have it come to a head during an already bad day.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just going to cut in here,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI one hundred percent think what you‚Äôre saying is cool and good. It‚Äôs a good mindset. I did catch one thing you said and it made me think. You said ‚Äòself-sufficient‚Äô and one of the things I was thinking about mentioning was, you know, heroing is hard, and it‚Äôs kind of hard in part because it doesn‚Äôt pay. That can lead to self-insufficiency instead.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt can pay,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúIt can,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúBut it paid in part because people wanted to put money toward it. Because the governments backed it and put money into the PRT, which paid the heroes a decent wage with opportunities for more. I spent my entire life seeing my mom stressing out in front of the computer or in front of the paperwork, from the time I could walk to the time I went to the hospital.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt can absolutely pay, though,‚Äù Tristan said. He glanced at Mrs. Yamada and then said, ‚ÄúI was a member of a corporate team, I saw and participated in the fundraising and merchandising, and we did well. We made a good bit of money.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhich team?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúReach.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, kudos. I know Reach,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure I could list off the roster as of Gold Morning but I‚Äôm more than passingly familiar. Good team.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúI mean, I‚Äôm not so worried about the money. That‚Äôs the easy part.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs easy at all,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a saying, um, seventy percent of couples break up because of financial issues. The same number of cape teams break up because of the same.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs so hard about it?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre providing a service, and the fruits of that service aren‚Äôt immediately tangible. If you do everything right, get crime rates down, clean up the neighborhood, then people look at the clean streets and low crime rate and they wonder why they‚Äôre paying you. If the crime rate stays high and things are a mess, then they wonder why they‚Äôre paying you.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow do you get around that?‚Äù Chris asked.

‚ÄúYou show your work,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúAnd you show it in a way that makes people believe you‚Äôre doing a good job. Bringing in bad guys, getting on the front page, that‚Äôs a big one, but you have to factor in the work of maintaining a relationship with the media, marketing, on top of the work you‚Äôre already doing. You can also get into fights the public is aware of, while not putting that public in danger, because putting people in danger means getting sued.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhich detracts from the finances,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúIn a big way,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúLike prison rep,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúHaving to show you‚Äôre not to be messed with, without making such a mess that you add to your sentence.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúNot an analogy I would have jumped to, but it‚Äôs a good one.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt aware you went to prison,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt,‚Äù Ashley said, fixing Sveta with a level stare. ‚ÄúI watch tv and read books.‚Äù

I was going to reply to that, but Tristan was already talking. He said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not worried about the money side of things. P.R., rep, image, media, I had advice and lessons from masters in the field, when it came to that.‚Äù

‚ÄúFrom what I remember of Reach, I believe you,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI do think that there‚Äôs a ton of difference between launching a new team and capitalizing on an established brand like Reach had, and between being the man in front of the cameras and the person in the background paying the bills.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have to ask,‚Äù Ashley said. She waited for me to look at her before speaking. ‚ÄúWhat are your qualifications exactly? You were on a struggling team?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to bully Victoria, please,‚Äù Sveta said.

I was feeling the numbers disadvantage, with many things I was saying having two people responding, a number of changes in direction, and the periodic challenging questions. Mrs. Yamada hadn‚Äôt spoken up recently.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm a cape geek,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all cape geeks,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúIt comes with the territory of being a cape.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen I‚Äôm a cape geek of a tier higher,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúListen, my mom and dad were capes and they were talking shop around me since I was born. My aunt, uncle, cousins— my entire immediate and pretty much my whole extended family, they were all capes. I was giving interviews about what it was like to grow up with hero parents when I was ten.‚Äù

Tristan cut in, ‚ÄúOkay, but that doesn‚Äôt—‚Äù

‚ÄúHold on,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI was asked, I‚Äôm answering. I triggered at fourteen, I was patrolling within six months. I had three years of time as Glory Girl, one Endbringer fight, and—‚Äù

I paused.

Sveta squeezed my hand.

‚Äú—And one run-in with the Slaughterhouse Nine, followed by almost two years in the hospital.‚Äù

I glanced at Ashley. She hadn‚Äôt flinched at the mention of the Nine.

I went on, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve seen some of the worst. I had the best boyfriend in the world—‚Äù

‚ÄúYou had the second best,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll fight you on this.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll take you up on that another time,‚Äù I said. I smiled. ‚ÄúSome of my family members were some of the most amazing people, one of those family members is still with me, and I count myself lucky in that. I was a local celebrity, and I got letters from kids saying they were inspired or I‚Äôd improved their lives by reaching out to them, spending a bit of time with them, or helping them off a bad path through nothing more than me existing. With all of that, I think I can say I‚Äôve experienced some of the best that being a hero has to offer, too.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat happened to the others?‚Äù Kenzie asked. ‚ÄúThe other family members?‚Äù

‚ÄúKenzie,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs best to leave that be.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt mean to pry. I‚Äôm really sorry, Victoria, for your losses. I asked because I‚Äôve lost people too. I know it hurts, and I think you‚Äôre cool and you don‚Äôt deserve that hurt.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you, Kenzie. I‚Äôll share, because I think it‚Äôs important for context. We‚Äôve all lost people and that‚Äôs a big part of our shared experience here on Earth Gimel.‚Äù

I saw people throughout the room nodding, or acknowledging that. Interesting, to see the lone wolf villainess Ashley nod, too. Chris, Tristan, Sveta. Mrs. Yamada.

Rain was hard to read, but he looked introspective.

‚ÄúMy uncle, my cousin, and that awesome boyfriend, Leviathan, twenty-eleven. My— another family member, you could say she got herself. Or you could say the team dynamics, all that stuff I was talking about before, they played a role. I wasn‚Äôt paying enough attention, I let things pass by without remark when I should have pressed, pressed when I should have held back. And now she‚Äôs— she‚Äôs not family. My mom, recently, just‚Ä¶‚Äù

I sighed.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not here to be a downer,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really not. I do want to emphasize this isn‚Äôt a game. There‚Äôs a chance at greatness and there‚Äôs a chance, maybe a higher chance, of disaster. I experienced both.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot to belittle that, but each and every one of us has gone through shit,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúIf it‚Äôs supposed to be one part of good stuff for every ten parts bad, then I think most of us are owed some good stuff.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs supposed to be that way,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúAshley asked who I am. I‚Äôm a cape, born, raised, and learned. I‚Äôm a student of capes, I obsessed over them well before I had powers and I stepped up my game in a professional capacity after I got powers. I had date nights with my cape boyfriend where I studied and read his Wards handbook, because that‚Äôs how into it I was. I‚Äôve followed the trajectories of two hundred cape careers and I‚Äôve been part of a team trying to get off the ground. I looked seriously into what it would take to start a team back when my boyfriend was getting close to leaving the Wards, because I was worried he‚Äôd get moved to another city.‚Äù

I looked Ashley in the eyes. ‚ÄúThis is me. I know cape stuff. I know what goes into it and I know what comes from it.‚Äù

I looked at Tristan. ‚ÄúThe last thing it is, is fair. You‚Äôre not owed anything. If you roll the dice nine times and get bad results every time, you don‚Äôt have a better shot on the tenth roll because of that.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut,‚Äù Tristan said, and he said it with a bit of theatrical emphasis and a light in his eyes that made me really believe he had that experience in being in front of cameras and showing off for crowds. He was more into things as he continued, ‚ÄúYou have a better shot at getting an optimal result if you roll the dice a lot, than you would if you rolled it a couple of times, get bad results, and quit. You have to get back up after you get knocked down. You have to.‚Äù

‚ÄúOr stand up in the first place,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúOr stand up in the first place, yeah,‚Äù Tristan said. He glanced at Mrs. Yamada, then back to me. ‚ÄúWhat you were talking about earlier, with Sveta and it being toxic to not stretch yourself out enough, it applies here.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry to interrupt,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúTristan, can I ask why you keep looking to me? It‚Äôs not a usual habit.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúI barely noticed. I think I‚Äôm pretty used to you jumping in to tell me to back down or not get so into an argument.‚Äù

‚ÄúI see,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said.

‚ÄúI guess the fact that I‚Äôm checking means I‚Äôm already aware I‚Äôm doing it again, and I should self-moderate. Back down on my own instead of being told to.‚Äù

‚ÄúLook at that, Pavlov‚Äôs dog can ring his own bell now,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm all about the goats, thank you very much,‚Äù Tristan said. He touched a more pronounced lock of his magenta hair. ‚ÄúSee, like the curling horns of a ram, right?‚Äù

Chris rolled his eyes.

Team Reach and goats? ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre Capricorn?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI am,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúBonus point for you.‚Äù

Kenzie, though, piped up with,‚ÄúI like the hair-horns thing, Tristan. I never got it before now but I think it‚Äôs neat.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you, Kenzie,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúThis is part of why you‚Äôre awesome.‚Äù

Kenzie‚Äôs expression didn‚Äôt change much, but she had one leg crossed over the other, and the free-dangling foot bounced. Like a dog wagging its tail.

Chris said, ‚ÄúGetting an ‚ÄòI like it‚Äô from Kenzie is like getting a participation medal from a school event. Everyone gets one.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat doesn‚Äôt make it worthless,‚Äù Kenzie said. She flashed a smile at Chris. ‚ÄúI never lie, I‚Äôm always honest when I say I like something. What makes me different is that I say it instead of keeping it to myself, because I think the world needs more positivity.‚Äù

‚ÄúI like it,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI could never do it, because it takes a weird sort of social courage, but I like it.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúI think you lose this round, Chris,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúHow do I lose? I wasn‚Äôt playing.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd,‚Äù Tristan said. Again, that one word, almost a pronouncement, volume and emphasis shifted just a bit to get attention. ‚ÄúOn the topic of rounds and games, I feel like Mrs. Yamada is up to something, so I‚Äôm going to play this on a meta level and I‚Äôm going to shut myself up. I recognize I‚Äôve been trying to win this conversation with Victoria and I‚Äôve been monopolizing things by jumping in every time there‚Äôs an opportunity. I‚Äôm supposed to be listening more and trying to ‚Äòwin‚Äô social interactions less, so I‚Äôm going to shut myself up. The others should chime in, I trust them to say what needs to be said.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm proud of you, Tristan,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said.

Tristan nodded.

Rain said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm less proud and more amazed by the fact that your thought process went from ‚ÄòI need to try to win social interactions less‚Äô to ‚Äòthis is a meta-scenario I can win‚Äô in, what, twenty words?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat, did I?‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd the fact he used so many words to say he was going to shut up,‚Äù Chris said.

Tristan frowned at Chris. ‚ÄúYou guys are harsh.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs what we‚Äôre here for, isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù Sveta asked. ‚ÄúWe moderate each other. Hopefully while not being too harsh on each other.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs part of it,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúI think the ‚Äòparticipation award‚Äô comment was a little much, Chris. You have a tendency, which has been remarked on by others in the past, to think a clever put-down is a good thing because it‚Äôs clever, when most people will take away the fact it was a put-down.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think it was a good or bad thing. Sorry Kenzie.‚Äù

He didn‚Äôt sound very sorry, but Kenzie‚Äôs dangling foot wiggled, and she nodded, wiggling slightly in her seat a bit between the motions.

Mrs. Yamada said, ‚ÄúThe reason I‚Äôve been somewhat quiet, despite my referee role, is more or less what Tristan intuited. I‚Äôve done this in the past — taking more of a backseat, giving you all more of an opportunity to respond to one another and push back against one another rather than relying on me to keep things under control. In the early stages, I had to step in rather quickly. I‚Äôm glad that with minimal prompting, Tristan stopped himself before reaching the point where I had to tell him to stop.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre being toyed with,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúNot that,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúThe end goal is to get you all ready for the real world. Early on, the rudder needed a firm hand; as time goes on, I‚Äôm periodically hands off, seeing how you interact, until I see that you‚Äôre faring reasonably well on your own. It‚Äôs a gradual process that requires I give you more and more trust. Okay?‚Äù

Ashley nodded.

‚ÄúIt might be worth pausing to take stock in this moment. Snapshot the feelings and thoughts you‚Äôre experiencing. Some of you haven‚Äôt spoken up much at all. Depending on how you view the conversation, your participation or nonparticipation, some of you might be feeling frustrated, offended, worried, or even guilty.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs that last one aimed at me?‚Äù Tristan asked. ‚ÄúOh, wait, sorry, I‚Äôm supposed to have shut up.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not aimed at you, Tristan,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúI want each of you to think about where you stand right now. What are your feelings and where is your focus? Have you felt like you‚Äôve had a voice or that you‚Äôve taken things in a positive direction? Outside of the classroom, in a stressful situation with high stakes, these feelings could be magnified manifold. As Victoria suggested when she was talking about the slow progression of background negativity, the bad feelings aren‚Äôt always resolved or solved, and it would be very easy for a sliver of frustration to carry forward, nettling at you or being joined by other, similar feelings, until you felt compelled to do or say something you regret.‚Äù

‚ÄúHanding that irritation off to someone else,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúAnd, as a final comment on the topic from me, I brought Victoria here for several reasons. One of them is that I do believe she knows what she‚Äôs talking about. Another is that, from my position as a person with a measure of trust and power, with a strong feeling about what you‚Äôre committed to doing, it‚Äôs very difficult for me to both argue the points and also manage the discussion at the same time. If I tell Tristan to give others a chance to speak, it could be seen as me trying to shut down his side of the argument.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm here as a bit of a surrogate,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here saying what you can‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúIn part. I think we do disagree on some things.‚Äù

‚ÄúLike the value and importance we place in cape names, to quote a recent example,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI like them, you don‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes. I did, for the record, let Victoria know I would be sitting back more than usual.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou did. I didn‚Äôt expect to be ganged up on, though.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry about that.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was mild,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to gang up on Victoria. I‚Äôve done a lot of talking too,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúBut I think that‚Äôs because I know Victoria, even if this is our first time really talking properly. There‚Äôs a bit of trust.‚Äù

I nodded. ‚ÄúYep.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor what it‚Äôs worth,‚Äù Sveta said, ‚Äúthat trust means that much like Mrs. Yamada I do believe Victoria when she says she‚Äôs worried or she thinks this could go badly. I know she knows stuff. But I do want this. I want to stand on my own two feet. Sorry. I think the ones who‚Äôve been quiet up until now should say stuff. Ashley, Chris, Kenzie, Rain. Or, you know, maybe Victoria has more to say.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you for coming, by the way, Victoria,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre welcome,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI do want this to be a chance to share what I know and for you guys to gain, if that‚Äôs possible. Maybe there are places where you might realize there are gaps in your knowledge that you could then take time to brush up on. There isn‚Äôt a rush.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere is, kind of,‚Äù Rain said.

Heads turned.

‚ÄúI talked about this last session. There‚Äôs currently some people after me. I want to be part of a team because it‚Äôs backup. Having a squad of people with me when I‚Äôm out and about would throw a wrench into their plans. It could give me a fighting chance when I wouldn‚Äôt have one otherwise.‚Äù

‚ÄúPeople are after you?‚Äù I asked.

Rain held up his fingers in a way that made a rectangle. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs complicated.‚Äù

The rectangle was supposed to represent the card.

I smiled despite myself. ‚ÄúAnd these guys are okay with taking the risk involved there?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not scared,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm breaking my vow of silence again,‚Äù Tristan said, ‚ÄúBut I think I‚Äôm doing it for the right reasons here. I like, respect, and/or trust each of these guys who would be my teammates. But in particular, I consider Rain a friend. I‚Äôm already willing to throw my helmet into the ring and do what it takes to help save his life. We‚Äôve got some similar garbage going on with‚Ä¶ people we can‚Äôt get away from, and he‚Äôs had my back in the past when it came to my issue.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Rain said. He gestured vaguely toward his head.

‚ÄúPeople?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúSpeaking for myself, I‚Äôm part of a multitrigger cluster,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù I said. I paused, taking stock of that. ‚ÄúI can see where that warrants playing the ‚Äòcomplicated‚Äô card.‚Äù

Kenzie spoke up, ‚ÄúBefore you got in, Ashley, Victoria was saying we should all get a card saying ‚Äòit‚Äôs complicated‚Äô on the one side, and ‚Äòhandle with care‚Äô on the other. I wanted to make sure you got what they were talking about.‚Äù

‚ÄúI like that,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúIt could use rewording. ‚ÄòDo not fuck with‚Äô, instead of handling with care.‚Äù

‚ÄúReminds me of the old wiki entries,‚Äù Capricorn said, ‚ÄúThe red warning boxes for the scary capes.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid I have one?‚Äù Ashley asked.

‚ÄúYou did,‚Äù I said.

Ashley nodded. ‚ÄúGood.‚Äù

Was it? I decided to leave it alone.

‚ÄúYou were motioning toward your head before,‚Äù I said, to Rain. ‚ÄúAre you referring to bleed-over, kiss and kill? That sort of thing?‚Äù

‚ÄúHuh,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúYou weren‚Äôt lying when you were saying you‚Äôd studied up.‚Äù

I‚Äôd pulled my hand away from Sveta‚Äôs at one point, and I only realized it because she reached out and took my hand again, placing her hand over mine and giving it a congratulatory squeeze.

‚ÄúIs it part of it?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, honest to God,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúWhen I‚Äôm vague and I‚Äôm saying it‚Äôs complicated, it‚Äôs really because I can‚Äôt give a one hundred percent clear answer. I‚Äôm still figuring out the rules this works by. I‚Äôve wondered about the bleeding through. My personality changed after, but I don‚Äôt know how much of that is them and how much is how a trigger event is a wake-up call.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe like to give things hard labels, but sometimes they‚Äôre blurry around the edges,‚Äù I said.

Rain nodded.

‚ÄúIf your own cluster is coming after you, I‚Äôd say you could chalk it up to kiss and kill. Again, blurry, might as well throw it in that bucket.‚Äù

‚ÄúI won‚Äôt object,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúAnd while I‚Äôm on that subject, I‚Äôd feel compelled to stress that the term uses the word ‚Äòkill‚Äô for a reason.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúPeople die. Friends of people die. I‚Äôm still figuring out what you guys are doing, but‚Ä¶ you want to bring kids into that?‚Äù I asked. I looked over to my right, at Kenzie and Chris.

‚ÄúDefinitely not,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúTristan is saying he‚Äôd help, Ashley is offering a hand, and Sveta might do what she can? That‚Äôs a hell of a lot better, compared to the same circumstance with me alone.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs more peace of mind in talking to legitimate authorities,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThere is,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúIf things get bad, I‚Äôll go to them. I‚Äôve tested the waters and asked questions. It doesn‚Äôt seem like they‚Äôll offer help against a nebulous threat with an unclear window of time where it might occur, and villains I don‚Äôt know the names, locations or details of. It‚Äôs more like they want me to call them when I‚Äôve got a claw at my throat.‚Äù

‚ÄúEveryone‚Äôs busy,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúClaw?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúTinker claw?‚Äù

That got the room‚Äôs attention.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre thinking of the man with the tinker arms you ran into at the community center, Victoria?‚Äù Mrs. Yamada asked.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said.

She explained, ‚ÄúVictoria mentioned that she took him for a multi-trigger, given the powers he displayed and the common links to a woman with claws she‚Äôd read about. I was going to bring it up at the end of the session, to avoid the lengthy digression like we had last session, and I hoped to extend it to a discussion in another venue, possibly with less people.‚Äù

‚ÄúI derailed us early, it seems,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYou ran into a member of my cluster?‚Äù Rain asked.

‚ÄúBig guy, beard, heavy coat.‚Äù

‚ÄúLong hair, hood, rough voice,‚Äù Rain said, ‚ÄúAnd a glare, like if looks could kill.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo hood, glare‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt know. He wore a mask with a built in glare, but he seemed like the scowly type. Definitely on the voice.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúWhen did you fight him?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúUm. Thirteen days ago. First Monday of September. High school had just started.‚Äù

Rain held up one hand, counting on his fingers, his lips moving.

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúTiming matters.‚Äù It was Tristan who had replied, while Rain was busy counting.

‚ÄúHe was strong then,‚Äù Rain said, finishing his counting and dropping his hands.

‚ÄúHe was a bit of a bastard, if I‚Äôm being honest,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúNot fun to go up against. He‚Äôs one of the ones who was after you?‚Äù

Rain nodded.

‚ÄúWhy the counting?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs complicated,‚Äù Rain said. He must have seen the look on my face, because he added, ‚ÄúThe powers wax, wane, and shuffle around. I try to keep track. He was loaded to bear on that day, if I‚Äôm remembering right. The only power he didn‚Äôt have a lot of was mine, and maybe a little bit less of his own.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúWhich is yours?‚Äù

‚ÄúUh. Mine is a blaster power,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs pretty mediocre. I shoot things or people and they‚Äôre vulnerable to being broken for a short while after. To put it simply.‚Äù

‚ÄúMediocre is sort of the name of the game when it comes to clusters,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got a tinker power, I make extra arms and hands. They‚Äôre not very good. Barely above what I‚Äôd be able to make on my own, fragile enough that if you grab something wrong they can break, no strength, ugly. The prosthetic focus is part of why I was introduced to the group, I think.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúWe thought there was a chance of insights across designs.‚Äù

Sveta would be one, obviously. Ashley raised a hand, slender, with black-painted nails.

I couldn‚Äôt tell that her hand was prosthetic.

‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt much help, because I‚Äôm a really bad tinker,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI can also catch my balance or secure my footing more easily, that‚Äôs my version of the big guy‚Äôs mover power. It‚Äôs handy in a way, lets me turn on a dime or keep from falling over.‚Äù

‚ÄúWait, his power was the mover power? The arms and emotion power were his secondaries?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what I‚Äôm saying,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI think he had a bit less of his own power that day, with the way it was sorted. My last power is an emotion power. Guilt and doubt, over an area. It‚Äôs pretty tepid.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe hit me with it a few times,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúTepid is a good word for it. You can actually not notice you‚Äôre being hit by it.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd it waxes and wanes, you said?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúMy blaster power can get a bump some days. My others, no. They stay at about that power level. The others change it up more, they‚Äôll act on days they‚Äôre strong.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe may be getting distracted,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúI might suggest you carry on this discussion later. Victoria can fill you in on‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúSnag,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúSorry. This is actually really interesting though. I‚Äôd be happy to talk it over another time.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good to have a name for him,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúUh, okay. Getting back on topic, I know I‚Äôm a little selfish in why I‚Äôm doing this. Wanting people to have my back.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe all need people to have our backs,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs still selfish. It‚Äôs messy and I‚Äôm not sure I can pull my own weight with all of this. I do want to help people though. I‚Äôve been selfish for a long time. I‚Äôm trying to be better. I know I‚Äôm contradicting myself in what I‚Äôm doing here, but it makes sense to me, and so few things do.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou said—‚Äù Kenzie started. ‚ÄúOh, are you done, Rain?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm done. Pretty much where I‚Äôm at. I‚Äôll buy you a coffee or whatever you drink, Victoria, if you‚Äôll tell me about Snag.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou said you had info about hero teams, Victoria,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm interested in that because I do want to try to be a hero first.‚Äù

‚ÄúFirst?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm saying I‚Äôll try, maybe a few times, and if it doesn‚Äôt work out I‚Äôll try other things but if it doesn‚Äôt work out then I might try being a mercenary, or a villain.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou would be terrifying as shit if you were a villain,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúWould I? Is that a compliment?‚Äù Kenzie asked.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a neutral fact, and I don‚Äôt use the word terrifying lightly.‚Äù

‚ÄúBe fair, Chris,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm being fair. This is an objective fact,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúAnd be gentle, too. If you must levy a criticism—‚Äù

‚ÄúFact.‚Äù

‚Äú—there are nicer ways to say it.‚Äù

‚ÄúGot it,‚Äù Chris said.

Kenzie stuck out her tongue at him.

‚ÄúTerrifying is good,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúTerrifying slows the other guy down. It makes them make mistakes.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not wrong,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve used that to my advantage—‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd it‚Äôs fun,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúAh‚Ä¶ I used to think that,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve come to reconsider that sentiment. I regret how I employed it, a little, and I regret enjoying it a lot.‚Äù

Ashley sighed a little.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve talked about this at some length,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúHere in the group. The approaches that work. Fear comes at a cost.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt does,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúNot necessarily in the ways you‚Äôd expect, pushing people away or any of that. It makes a mess. It makes people unpredictable. I have an awe-fear aura so I‚Äôve seen this at work.‚Äù

‚ÄúI almost envy you,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúTo have something you can so casually employ.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not casual,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúBecause like I said, it‚Äôs complicated in terms of the mess it makes of things. I‚Äôve been trying to be more deliberate about how I use it.‚Äù

‚ÄúSee, this excites me,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúI want to learn from Ashley because I saw the camcorder footage from the Boston Games— I showed you that one right, Ashley?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou did,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll get you a copy because you liked it so much. There‚Äôs also a video I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve shown you but it‚Äôs mostly you walking through a club with someone and everyone gets out of your way. That was interesting.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you want people to get out of your way, Kenzie?‚Äù Sveta asked. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs good or fun.‚Äù

‚ÄúDefinitely no. It‚Äôs still interesting. But, um, I also want to learn from Victoria because I do want to be on a team, I want to be on this team of course, but whatever happens I want to be on some team. Then I want to be useful so I stay there. The more I know the more useful I can be.‚Äù

‚ÄúI am interested in hearing it too,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúAbout teams, making heroics work.‚Äù

‚ÄúI looked over my schoolwork and some old projects before I came today,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI typed up some bullet points and thought hard about what I wanted to say, and‚Ä¶ being here, I‚Äôm not sure it‚Äôs valid.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs valid. I want to hear it,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúI would too,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs why I‚Äôm here.‚Äù

I was caught a little off guard by that.

I could remember Ashley‚Äôs comments when the topic of the cards had come up. She‚Äôd liked the ‚Äòhandle with care‚Äô aspect of it, which was illuminating in its own way. More specifically, she‚Äôd liked it while interpreting it as a ‚Äòdo not fuck with‚Äô license.

The way it had been framed and what I knew of Ashley and Damsel of Distress made me imagine it as a ‚Äòwarning: volatile‚Äô label on her breast, worn much like a nametag.

She‚Äôd reacted to me belittling her even in a small way, earlier, when I‚Äôd reduced her to a pin on a map.

‚ÄúIt might be worth saying why you think it isn‚Äôt valid,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada suggested.

I tried to find the words to articulate what I wanted to say without getting on anyone‚Äôs bad side, my fingers twirling a lock of hair while I looked down at the floor. I looked up and looked her in the eyes, then looked at everyone else as I said, ‚ÄúI can come here and I can say, alright, finances. Being a hero team is tough financially. I touched on this before. How do you get funding, one source, many, or is it institutional? What‚Äôs your budget, what can you expect to pay, where are the hidden costs, like medical or needing a headquarters, and what are the potential costs or risks if you decide to save money by trimming the budget somewhere? And maybe that angle works for some of you.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt feels abstract,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI have a stipend, I pay rent, I have to budget, but when you talk about things in the big picture like that, I find it hard to imagine.‚Äù

‚ÄúBudgets and money make more sense when you root them in tangible things that are relevant to you. If you had questions about one area, I might have more to say about it, or I could expand on the idea, if that was a thing that worked for you guys, as a way to wrap your head around what you‚Äôre trying to do. I could do the same for objectives and goals, information gathering, costumes and presentation, allegiances and direction, liaisons, territories, methodology‚Ä¶ one or two others I‚Äôm not remembering off the top of my head. But as far as I can tell, you‚Äôre approaching this from several different directions, with very different priorities.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe definitely are,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt get the impression Ashley is prioritizing developing herself as a person, becoming independent, or catching up in life, like Sveta is. I don‚Äôt get the impression its about becoming less selfish or wanting or needing backup, like Rain. I‚Äôm not sure what someone of your pedigree would be doing here, Ashley.‚Äù

‚ÄúPedigree?‚Äù Ashley asked.

‚ÄúIt means aristocratic background when used to describe humans,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not calling you a bred animal. I‚Äôm pretty sure.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not bothered. I like the word choice,‚Äù Ashley said. She had half of a smile on her face.

‚ÄúIt was picked to be liked,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm here to learn, Victoria,‚Äù Ashley said. Her gaze with the narrow pupils and lack of irises was intense.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs positive,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúNo it‚Äôs not,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm here to learn how heroes operate, so I can be more effective against them when I return to being a villain,‚Äù Ashley said.

I looked at Sveta and Tristan, then at Mrs. Yamada.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not lying,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs positive, really,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs agreed to stick with us until we crash and burn.‚Äù

‚ÄúUntil you fail,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúUntil we crash and burn,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúWe went over this. If you leave at the first sign of failure then you‚Äôll be gone in the first week and you won‚Äôt have learned anything, and everyone loses.‚Äù

‚ÄúIrritating,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúReality is irritating,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre low-key confident we can get her to stick around on the side of the good guys, with sufficient friendship, ass-kicking of our opponents, and time to convince her of the upsides,‚Äù Tristan said, to me.

‚ÄúYou vastly underestimate how much I enjoy being a villain, Tristan.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou enjoy being a villain but you don‚Äôt like the life that comes with it,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúIt had its merits,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúAnd a lot of other misery besides that.‚Äù

Ashley sighed. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve already agreed. I‚Äôll join you. I‚Äôll defend you from your cluster. In exchange I learn about heroes, I get information about the cape scene, and I may get training. If it fails, I‚Äôll go back to what I know and enjoy. You‚Äôll have your chance to convince me that being a hero is great. I doubt you‚Äôll succeed. Most heroes I‚Äôve met have been imbeciles and nuisances.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said. I put a hand to my forehead, closing my eyes. Capes were so damn weird sometimes.

‚ÄúYou said it was better than the alternative, before everyone arrived,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúBeing a hero.‚Äù

‚ÄúI did,‚Äù I said. I might be regretting saying that now. The fact that Kenzie paid attention to what I‚Äôd said and was quick enough to bring out the salient points was good, objectively, but it was kind of a pain here. I could see where some of Mrs. Yamada‚Äôs worries were rooted, here. ‚ÄúYou have a strong drive to learn, then, Ashley?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat I want hasn‚Äôt changed. I want to be on top. I want to destroy my enemies and give potential enemies a reason to fear me. I‚Äôm going to do it right this time.‚Äù

This time. There were four different things I wanted to reply to there, and I settled on the easy one. ‚ÄúReports were that you died.‚Äù

‚ÄúI did,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúNow I‚Äôm back. My power isn‚Äôt holding me back anymore.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou get sparky sometimes,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúSo long as my hands are maintained, I‚Äôm fine. I have contacts. I‚Äôm eating well, I‚Äôm sleeping, I‚Äôm studying and I‚Äôm training. I‚Äôll do it right this time. I won‚Äôt die this time.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThat pretty much sums up what I‚Äôm trying to say here. You guys have your reasons. I can‚Äôt show you a spreadsheet or make a list that meets your needs because your needs are diverse. It‚Äôs not about hard stats like dollars and viewership.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs about dollars for me,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúRight. I‚Äôll note you do have a very different idea than I do about how much money there may be,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúKind of,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs that different.‚Äù

The thing I wanted to say that I couldn‚Äôt without offending people was that a lot of them were coming at things from an irrational or emotional perspective, from their self, and not from logic. To challenge Sveta‚Äôs approach on this was to challenge the woman she wanted to be. Challenging Rain meant putting his mortality at risk. Damsel was too volatile to push too hard, she had her motivations, and I couldn‚Äôt imagine scaring her off would do any good to anyone. The team would go forward without her, dejected and possibly upset with me or with Mrs. Yamada for inviting me.

My impression was that Tristan was looking at the money from an abstract, emotional perspective as well.

‚ÄúI barely have a high school education, it‚Äôs not like there‚Äôs a lot out there for me, and money is tight everywhere,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúI like the hero stuff. I like the notoriety, and I like being out there. We need a fix, and the two ways I see of us getting one would be if we get the money together to pay the right cape, or we chance into meeting the right cape.‚Äù

‚ÄúFix?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúSorry, I missed something.‚Äù

‚ÄúWith how quick you were about cape terms and names, and how you knew Reach, I thought you might have realized.‚Äù

‚ÄúI figured out you‚Äôre Capricorn.‚Äù

‚ÄúMore to it than that. You know how two brothers can get in a pissy fight over who gets to have the remote and decide what to watch on TV? We‚Äôre stuck doing that, except it‚Äôs way more fucking intense.‚Äù

Two brothers and one power? Or—

Oh, I was an idiot.

‚ÄúThat we are,‚Äù Tristan said.

We. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a case seventy?‚Äù

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt tell you how bummed I am that it isn‚Äôt case sixty-nine instead, but no, that number went to a bigfoot sighting or something stupid. A stupid bit of immature humor would‚Äôve been the one good thing in this mess of a thing.‚Äù

‚ÄúCase seventies in North America included Knot, Tandem, Zigzag was one, I think, there was House of Three in Quebec. And‚Ä¶ you, it seems.‚Äù

‚ÄúOne or two of them might not be seventies, but they get called seventies because they‚Äôre close enough. Blurred lines, like you said. When twins trigger, the powers are identical or nearly identical. When twins trigger and they‚Äôre touching one another, like you said to Rain, things get blurry, the agent is too stupid or careless to tell where one starts and the other ends, or it wants to fuck with us, and it jams everything in together. Two minds, two similar powers, and one body to be shared.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs he asleep?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúNo. He‚Äôs in here, he‚Äôs watching and listening. He sleeps when I sleep, or I sleep when he sleeps, if he‚Äôs in the driver‚Äôs seat. We trade out for two hour shifts.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan he communicate?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúTalk to you while it‚Äôs your turn?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat would be too easy,‚Äù Tristan said. His good humor was gone now. He just looked sad. ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

No.

Two brothers, and only one of them could be interacting with the world at a time. For the other, it was— picturing it made me think of being in the hospital again. Being stuck, immobile, locked in while the world went on around them.

Oppressive, that kind of thinking. Just as oppressive to be living it.

‚ÄúI like Byron,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúI really wish he would stay for the therapy sessions.‚Äù

‚ÄúI like him too,‚Äù Rain said. He leaned back in his chair, hands at his hair, pushing it away from his face as he stretched. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like talking about you like you‚Äôre not here, Byron. We‚Äôll hang out later, okay? Unwind.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been a long and rocky road,‚Äù Tristan said, to me. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not interested in the hero thing either. He‚Äôs on Mrs. Yamada‚Äôs side here. On yours, kind of, Victoria.‚Äù

On my side? I was trying to frame my argument, but it was an uphill battle for logic to win against the heart, and it did seem like their hearts were in this, to varying degrees.

I decided to say as much.

‚ÄúI might not be winning any points with Mrs. Yamada in this,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúAnd I don‚Äôt know enough about your individual situations, but you have personal, thought out reasons for wanting to do this. At this stage, I‚Äôm not telling you guys you shouldn‚Äôt do this. I‚Äôm definitely, definitely not saying you should. I think there are a few things to work out. I‚Äôm honestly really concerned about Ashley.‚Äù

‚ÄúAs anyone should be,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúThat would be why I‚Äôm concerned. I don‚Äôt know if you guys want to sit down as a group at a cafe or something, hammer out some basic plans. You‚Äôd probably want something like an outline or playbook that you can take with you when you‚Äôre talking to the Wardens or whoever‚Äôs managing the territory closest to you. I think the hero teams are covering different sections of the city, and you wouldn‚Äôt want to step on jurisdictional toes. If you want to do this.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat could be great,‚Äù Sveta said.

Kenzie nodded, very enthusiastically, as in most things.

‚ÄúChris and Kenzie,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been quiet.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve talked about wanting to pick Victoria‚Äôs brain and she listed some topics,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúI like this whole conversation as a recap, seeing where everyone‚Äôs at, instead of trying to think back to previous sessions and think about what people‚Äôs reasons are. I‚Äôm glad we‚Äôre talking like this and I want to have that meeting and figure things out.‚Äù

‚ÄúChris?‚Äù Mrs. Yamada prodded.

‚ÄúCan I just say I don‚Äôt want to share with the guest here?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúIs it the truth?‚Äù

Chris looked annoyed as he looked at her. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like talking about stuff. Digging into my thoughts for answers stresses me out and throws me more out of whack than it helps.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt exist purely on the surface level,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said.

‚ÄúI can. It might or might not be good for me, but something that could be good or could be bad is a lot better than no-win after no-win.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo win?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI could say it‚Äôs none of your business,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúYou could,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs your right.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see why you‚Äôre as defensive as you are,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm playing defense because paranoia is the only way to survive,‚Äù Chris said. He reached up to adjust his headphones, wincing mid-adjustment. ‚ÄúHow many sessions did it take before I gave you all the basics?‚Äù

‚ÄúFour or five,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúWell, this is session one with the new person,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúIf you want to drop me from the team because I‚Äôm not okay with that, fine. I‚Äôll figure something else out.‚Äù

‚ÄúNobody is saying that,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve come this far with us, don‚Äôt get shy now.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not shy, I‚Äôm suspicious. That won‚Äôt change,‚Äù Chris said. He sounded irritated, in a way his expression didn‚Äôt convey effectively.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think pressuring Chris will help anything. Again, however, I would really urge everyone present to periodically take stock. Pay attention to what you‚Äôre feeling, imagine this dialogue extrapolated out to a greater, higher-stakes situation. How will you handle your feelings, and will you feel have both a voice and the ability to affect the changes you need?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre worried we‚Äôll get railroaded,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm worried about a number of things, Rain. I wish you would be willing to put things off for six months or a year, maintain contact, see how you get along as simple friends and acquaintances, let the ties solidify or break as they will, and then move forward if it is what you still want.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere are a lot of issues to hammer out,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre coming at this from so many different directions‚Ä¶ how do you even get started in terms of the kind of team you end up being? In other things? I‚Äôd join my voice to Mrs. Yamada‚Äôs and urge you to take your time.‚Äù

‚ÄúLike I said, I‚Äôm feeling the pressure,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúMy cluster is homing in on me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can talk to people, if you want. If you need another cape to back you up, I might be able to help.‚Äù

‚ÄúI mean, that sounds nice,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúBut I can‚Äôt help but lie in bed some mornings, wondering if this is the day. If, in the next twenty-four hours, the other three members of my cluster come after me in an organized way, with a lot of money and a lot of resources poured into things. When I see it playing out in my head, I know they‚Äôre organized, and I worry we‚Äôre not. If we‚Äôre part of a team, if we‚Äôre training, coordinating, then maybe we can work together in an organized way too.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot that goes into making a team. You can stay together and watch Rain‚Äôs back, meet, talk, and plan.‚Äù

‚ÄúWithout getting the practice in?‚Äù Tristan asked. ‚ÄúSorry to butt in again, but it takes time to learn how to work with teammates. Some more than others.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat you‚Äôre wanting to do on the heroism front is hard enough without added complications. It‚Äôs a bad, bad climate for heroes to try to get started. That could end up being more distraction than the training is a boon.‚Äù

‚ÄúImagine how bad the climate would be if nobody new got started,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI won‚Äôt deny that. I just— I have serious reservations, but I also recognize I probably won‚Äôt be changing any minds. Instead of trying to get you to reverse course or stop, I‚Äôm saying maybe change trajectories a bit. Go slow, focus on what needs to be focused on, instead of getting distracted with the many, many side things that go into getting a proper team started.‚Äù

‚ÄúFocusing on keeping Rain safe, as the priority thing?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI can meet you guys at a coffee shop or somewhere, we can make it a regular thing. I can back you up, I might be able to introduce you to people, and we do what Mrs. Yamada suggested, and take months or a year to get a really good game plan put together.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre committing to a lot, Victoria,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúIt won‚Äôt conflict with your other plans?‚Äù

‚ÄúI like doing this sort of thing. I‚Äôll find a way to work it in. It gives me an opportunity to stay in touch with Sveta, too.‚Äù

I was elbowed, hard, from my left.

‚ÄúIf you think I‚Äôm letting you drift away or lose touch now then you need a reality check,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúWasn‚Äôt planning on it, don‚Äôt worry,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like it,‚Äù Kenzie said.

It was an abrupt statement, cutting into the dialogue, the serious tone different from the easy back-and-forth.

‚ÄúWe wouldn‚Äôt be leaving you out,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúYou said you were interested in what Victoria knew about heroes, and you‚Äôd be part of the team when we got started.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo I wouldn‚Äôt,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúBecause you all would be doing what you have to do to help Rain, and I‚Äôd be on the sidelines. You said you don‚Äôt want to have a kid there in a dangerous situation, so I wouldn‚Äôt actually be there when things went down. And if you thought there would be an attack soon you wouldn‚Äôt want me hanging around in case I got caught up in it, so you‚Äôd all meet and I‚Äôd stay home then, too.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt could be over in a couple of weeks,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúIt could not be over, too,‚Äù Kenzie said. She smiled. ‚ÄúCome on. I‚Äôve done this before. Again and again. I did it during the leadership camps and the exercises in San Diego. I did it during the branding in LA and I kind of did it with the Baltimore Wards.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid what?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúGot left behind. Or sidelined and ignored. The reasons were good, or maybe I‚Äôm a stupid, gullible idiot and the reasons are bad, and I believed them anyway.‚Äù

‚ÄúI liked your contributions to the group, I‚Äôd want you to stick around,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI know you mean well, Victoria, but this is the way it always goes,‚Äù Kenzie said. She shrugged. ‚ÄúThe compliments, the softening of the blow. I think you‚Äôre nice and you‚Äôre trying to do the right thing. But again and again, because I‚Äôm a kid, or because I‚Äôm small and weak, or because I‚Äôm a girl, or because I‚Äôm black, or because I have school, or because I‚Äôm vulnerable, or I‚Äôm annoying, or because they want to be careful around me because I have problems, or because I‚Äôve said the wrong things because I‚Äôm an idiot a lot of the time, or because— because whatever the reason, good or bad, hateful or kind‚Ä¶‚Äù

She trailed off there. She was staring down at the ground, head down where I couldn‚Äôt see it. She huffed out out a small laugh.

Her hands were on either side of her hips, gripping the sides of the plastic chair.

‚ÄúArticulate what you want, Kenzie,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúAssertive. Not passive, not passive-aggressive.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to be left behind,‚Äù Kenzie said. She was speaking more slowly, deliberately. A dramatic change of pace from her usual output. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm experienced in this, so when I say I think I see things going this way, it would be nice if people believed me.‚Äù

‚ÄúMore assertive, Kenzie,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said.

‚ÄúTrust me,‚Äù Kenzie said, with emphasis. She looked up, flashed a smile at me, then shrugged. ‚ÄúYou say you‚Äôre experienced in cape stuff and I think it shows and that‚Äôs amazing. I‚Äôm experienced in this and I‚Äôm really tired of this song and dance.‚Äù

‚ÄúI understand,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry to have touched on something that sensitive. I should have been more considerate.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not you,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs me. It‚Äôs a regular thing. I don‚Äôt blame you. It‚Äôs the way I am, it makes people act this way around me. And—‚Äù

She drew in a deep breath.

‚Äú—And I would like to be included from the beginning, in a way where I‚Äôm useful and participating and I‚Äôm not watching from the sidelines. I would like to do the team thing from the beginning. I don‚Äôt mind if it‚Äôs small or slow but I want to do something with progress. Or if not that, then tell me upfront so I can have my feelings hurt now right away instead of over a long time.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis is really important to you,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThere have only ever been three times in my life where people acted like they wanted me around. Not counting the adults who get paid to look after me, sorry Mrs. Yamada. The first one, it led to my trigger, so you can imagine how well that went. The second one was the couple of months I spent with the Baltimore Wards, and they don‚Äôt want anything to do with me anymore. The third is here. These guys.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell gee whiz, Kenzie,‚Äù Tristan said.

She smiled, ‚ÄúSorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúI like to win my arguments, but you can‚Äôt bring that kind of weaponry to bear. It‚Äôs just not fair on those guys.‚Äù

Kenzie smiled again.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad you like us,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI do want to include you, and I hope this thing works out the way you want it to.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll figure something out,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWe?‚Äù Ashley asked.

‚ÄúI was going to say,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not trying to step on your toes or insinuate myself into things,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúBut if you‚Äôll have me, maybe I could take on a role as coach or something. If you really want to do this—‚Äù

I could see the looks on their faces. Yeah, they wanted to do this.

‚Äú—Then maybe we avoid having you guys go from a mediated discussion in a controlled environment like this to‚Ä¶ something more loosely supervised and managed, for the mediation part of things, and we look for a shallower pool to dive into instead, where you can get started in some capacity sooner, we ensure everyone has something to do, but we keep it manageable and small.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre volunteering?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúIf Mrs. Yamada is okay with this idea. I don‚Äôt see you guys changing your minds, so‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúIt would bring me some peace of mind,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said.

‚ÄúMediated,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôd be babysitting us?‚Äù

‚ÄúCoaching, giving direction if it‚Äôs lacking, give you someone to turn to if you need someone to help resolve a dispute. I can‚Äôt promise you full time hours, it‚Äôd be a secondary or minor thing for me, but‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm trying to think of a good way to tackle this and this is the best idea I‚Äôve got.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúI want to hear more about the heroing stuff.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt object,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúAnd the shallow end?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll figure something out,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm thinking of a couple of possible places, we could put feelers out in one that‚Äôs close enough for everyone here to get to. A few of these places have small populations of B-listers, and I think it would be a good, easy place to learn the ropes.‚Äù

Flare — 2.7

‚ÄúI felt energized after,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúCan you elaborate on that?‚Äù Mrs. Yamada asked.

‚ÄúMy cousin remarked I looked better, more in touch with the world. Normally, I get these intrusive‚Ä¶ non-thoughts.‚Äù

‚ÄúNon-thoughts?‚Äù Rain asked.

‚ÄúLike, not intrusive thoughts, not ideas that I can‚Äôt get out of my head, but my mind has these places it tries to go, and I reflexively shut them out. Like, one thing, I spent two years in the hospital and in the care home, obsessing,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI know what you‚Äôre talking about,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúYeah. And I feel like I‚Äôve devoted enough thought to that. Two years of time, more than a lifetime‚Äôs worth. So I lock up, mentally, or trip over the subject. I get that a lot as my mood gets worse. I have it for things I do, like using my powers. I had it a lot less after the day at the hospital.‚Äù

‚ÄúSome people have physiological signs, feeling ill, headaches, breathing, when they‚Äôre trying to find an outlet for things they can‚Äôt otherwise express,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúOthers have habits, things or people they go back to, they could have needs or cravings.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat if the thing you turn to is also the thing that causes stress?‚Äù Kenzie asked.

‚ÄúThat is absolutely a thing that happens, Kenzie. It‚Äôs at the root of downward spirals like addiction or overeating. On a more subtle level, something like a panic disorder can self-reinforce because the panic provides relief, even as it makes the actual situations worse. I like that Victoria identified something that arrests or controls the downward spiral.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the sort of thing I plan to do again,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúPutting all the other stuff aside, distilling things down to the most basic route of helping people, in a way that‚Äôs good and healthy for me, too. Or—‚Äù

Mrs. Yamada had started speaking at the same time I added the ‚Äòor‚Äô. We both stopped.

‚ÄúGo ahead,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúOr where there‚Äôs bad, the good is enough to outweigh that bad and leave me better off,‚Äù I said. I shrugged.

‚ÄúHere in the group, we often discuss the issues we‚Äôre facing, how we relate to what others bring up, and we talk about solutions. I‚Äôll periodically try to turn things to more positive topics, but with six people here, it‚Äôs common for people to come to the session with something they want to delve into.

‚ÄúI like that you‚Äôre dwelling on the good things, Victoria, and that you‚Äôre giving me an excuse to turn things toward a better note as we wrap up. Does anyone else have something to share?‚Äù

Tristan raised one hand a little, and Mrs. Yamada nodded, giving him permission to say.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not positive,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if that‚Äôs alright.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine. Go ahead.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat Victoria was saying, how she was saying she was happy, seeing the kids happy, and how she felt energized after. I don‚Äôt have that. I don‚Äôt have a way to recharge when I‚Äôm not at one hundred percent.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou definitely have things you‚Äôre passionate about,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúI like people, parties, noise, really letting the walls drop away and having fun. There are things I‚Äôd want to go out and do which I can‚Äôt. Things I‚Äôm not comfortable talking about with Kenzie present.‚Äù

Kenzie smiled at him. ‚ÄúRude stuff. I‚Äôm not that young.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know you probably know, I‚Äôm still not comfortable talking about it like this,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúYou say Kenzie but you don‚Äôt even mention me,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm perversely pleased by that. You mean fucking, right?‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease, Chris,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said.

‚ÄúI mean stuff,‚Äù Tristan said, ‚ÄúStuff I can‚Äôt do because of my situation. I did some of it back before the trigger. More like sophomore high schoolers stealing their parents booze and having way too many people in a house while the parents are away, but that was the time of my life. It was when I was the most excited to be on this— on that planet. Now I can‚Äôt do stuff like that, the pressure release valve is screwed up for the same reasons I‚Äôm screwed up.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe case seventy stuff,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúNow me passing out drunk might mean I screw up the time window for passing back control, however many alarms I set, and I can‚Äôt do that to Byron. I can‚Äôt go have a one night stand because the way things are mean I‚Äôd be involving him in it as a bystander or voyeur.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan you find new outlets?‚Äù Sveta asked. ‚ÄúOne thing I‚Äôve learned over the past little while is that I still had a lot of growing to do. It‚Äôs easy when you‚Äôre in a bad place to think ‚Äòthis is it, this is me,‚Äô but there‚Äôs always more out there.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm trying,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúBut it sucks to know that the stuff I want to do and the people I want to do are out there and I can‚Äôt do that. I know it‚Äôs the same for Byron. It‚Äôs different for him, though, because he‚Äôs a quiet guy, he wants to take it easy, but you get the weird conflict where you want to chill out but you can‚Äôt because you also want to maximize your use of time, when you only get to live half your life.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd like to talk about that at a later point, when we‚Äôre not a minute away from wrapping up,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd also like to have a word with Byron and you after the session, make sure everything‚Äôs okay.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúOn a positive note, if nobody minds,‚Äù Sveta said, sitting up with the faintest of metal-on-metal sounds. ‚ÄúI got to recharge too, but it was a big one.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour trip?‚Äù Kenzie asked.

‚ÄúI know we talked about it last week, but we mostly talked about Rain staying safe and the hero team thing. It wasn‚Äôt a little pick me up. It was big, and I really want to find the chances to go and do stuff like that again.‚Äù

‚ÄúTraveling?‚Äù I asked. Her smile was contagious.

‚ÄúTraveling. We had a boat, and when we weren‚Äôt around people, I got out of my hamster ball. We stayed pretty close to the coasts, Weld sailing or driving the boat and me swimming. It was really, really nice.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can tell you got a lot of sun,‚Äù Tristan said.

Sveta smiled. Her face was so pale that her complexion was borderline impossible for a human. ‚ÄúI like swimming. I want to find a way to get out and do it more. It‚Äôs the first time I can remember moving and having there be resistance. Everything else is too hard or too reflex.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnyone else?‚Äù Mrs. Yamada asked. ‚ÄúFinal words? Thoughts?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad you had a good time,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúI really did,‚Äù Sveta said.

There was a pause. No responses, the only sound was a clack as the wind blew the blinds away from the window and they swung back into position. I wondered how bad the rain was.

Mrs. Yamada looked up at the clock, then said, ‚ÄúThen we should wrap up. Tristan, a word. Everyone else, have a good week. There won‚Äôt be a Friday meeting this week, so I will see you next Tuesday.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd like to exchange people‚Äôs contact information, if it‚Äôs okay,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre wanting to do this.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou keep saying that like you‚Äôre hoping we won‚Äôt,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúIt might make things simpler,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThe others have my number,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt keep track of it.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúDo you guys mind giving Victoria my number while you‚Äôre at it?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúCan do,‚Äù Rain said.

People were standing, now. Tristan gave Sveta a hand in getting to her feet.

The group, Tristan excepted, filed out into the hallway. A few people had coats draped or hooked on the the stacked plastic chairs along the hallway‚Äôs length. I‚Äôd left my bag on the ground. I pulled my phone out before I slung it over one shoulder.

A message from Crystal, asking if I was coming home for dinner.

‚ÄúPass me your number?‚Äù Rain asked. His phone was as battered as he was, with a crack running down the case.

I thumbed through the concentric rings, put my thumb on my phone number and profile information, and then flicked it in Rain‚Äôs direction.

‚ÄúGot it,‚Äù he said.

His info appeared on my phone, at the top edge. It was soon joined by Tristan‚Äôs, then Kenzie‚Äôs and Ashley‚Äôs, near simultaneously. Kenzie‚Äôs name was framed with colorful symbols. Chris‚Äôs and Sveta‚Äôs were the last to appear.

Rain had handled sending me Sveta‚Äôs, Ashley‚Äôs and Tristan‚Äôs, it seemed. Ashley was pulling on a raincoat, and Sveta‚Äôs hands were clasped in front of her.

Sveta might have sent me hers without using her hands, now that I thought about it. It was possible she had a phone in her suit.

I glanced back into the room, to see if Mrs. Yamada had anything she wanted to convey with a look or gesture. Instead, I saw her talking to someone who wasn‚Äôt Tristan.

Byron had black hair, shorter than Tristan‚Äôs, slicked back with something that shone in the room‚Äôs lights. He wore a jacket, a black v-neck shirt, and jeans. The contrast between him and Tristan in everything but facial features were striking— Tristan had been bright haired, his top and shorts all about contrasts with light and dark, color and lack thereof. He‚Äôd brimmed with confidence.

Byron didn‚Äôt. He looked distinctly uncomfortable, his hands in his jacket pockets, shoulders forward, a look of concern on his face. The muted gray-blue of his jacket, the black v-neck shirt, the jeans, there weren‚Äôt any of the intentional contrasts I‚Äôd seen in Tristan.

‚ÄúAre we going to wait for Tristan and try to have a quick chat about things?‚Äù Rain asked.

‚ÄúI have dinner,‚Äù Kenzie said. She looked at me. ‚ÄúI try to have dinner with my parents every night. We‚Äôre trying to reinforce that normalcy.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs that going alright?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going,‚Äù Kenzie said. She smiled. ‚ÄúWhich is better than the alternative.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm all people‚Äôd out,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúMost of you guys are better than some, but I‚Äôm done for now.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a good enough reason to put it off, then,‚Äù Rain said. He gripped the doorframe, leaning into the room a little. I heard Mrs. Yamada‚Äôs voice stop.

‚ÄúYes?‚Äù she asked.

‚ÄúWanted to let Tristan and Byron know we‚Äôre heading out. We‚Äôre not meeting today.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Byron said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôll have heard you.‚Äù

He sounded different, even. Quieter, in the way people talked if they were sure they‚Äôd be heard regardless, if they didn‚Äôt care, or, on the other side of things if they knew they wouldn‚Äôt be listened to.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll hang out,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúYou and me, we‚Äôll do something soon.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay. How‚Äôs Erin?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs good,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI could invite her to come with.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt mind.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, for sure,‚Äù Rain said.

Rain was still smiling when he stepped away from the door.

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs go,‚Äù Rain said.

I had to pause as Kenzie and Chris got out of my way and turned to head down the hallway, while Rain and Ashley led the way. I didn‚Äôt catch Ashley and Rain‚Äôs brief exchange of words.

I glanced back at the room, and saw Byron was looking at me while he was saying something to Mrs. Yamada. The up-down look, followed by the quick glance away when he realized I‚Äôd seen him.

You‚Äôre too young for me and you‚Äôre not my type, based on what little I‚Äôve seen and heard, I thought.

Sveta took my arm, squeezing it. My reminder to focus on the others.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre okay,‚Äù Sveta said, squeezing harder for a moment. ‚ÄúYou can talk.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou seem to be doing okay yourself,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm great,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúToday was a good day.‚Äù

We walked to catch up, and I could feel Sveta periodically leaning harder on me as she worked to maintain her stride. For all that she was in there, no doubt pulling on multiple components and relying on intricate machinery, she managed pretty darn well.

A little less so on the stairs to the ground floor, but I gave her my arm and plenty of support, and she did okay.

She hugged me with enthusiasm as we walked the five feet from the stairs to the side door, where the others were waiting under the rectangle of roof that jutted out from the side of the boxy building.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúBye.‚Äù

‚ÄúBye,‚Äù Sveta said, amid a few other scattered responses. I raised one hand in a token wave.

Chris removed his headphones as he walked away, stowing them in one pocket of his cargo shorts. He didn‚Äôt use an umbrella or wear a raincoat. He seemed content to get rained on.

Kenzie had a blue raincoat with duffle coat toggles on the front, and was standing a bit in the rain, head bent over her phone. Ashley stood on the sidewalk, her hood up. Rain had settled for an umbrella, but hadn‚Äôt opened it yet.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm walking to the bus station in Webster,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúNormally Tristan, Sveta, and I walk that way.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can head that way,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll walk with you guys for a bit.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll come,‚Äù Kenzie said, not looking up from her phone. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs still time before dinner.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou sure?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúYep,‚Äù Kenzie looked up from her phone.

‚ÄúAnd Ashley?‚Äù I asked.

She didn‚Äôt reply, turning away to look down the length of the road. She turned around, looking the other way. In that moment, a car appeared.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got a ride,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúSpending time with the the ol‚Äô guardians?‚Äù Sveta asked.

I didn‚Äôt miss the word choice. The forced cavalier attitude. Awkward.

‚ÄúI try to get as many of my appointments into the same day as I can,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nuisance enough to have my day disrupted with this inanity, I don‚Äôt want it taking over my weeks.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre inanity, are we?‚Äù Rain asked.

‚ÄúYou can be,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúCheckups and tests, therapy, group therapy, being supervised without it being official supervision, interviews, prosthetics tune-ups, work. It becomes inane.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all for good reasons,‚Äù Sveta said.
