‚ÄúI‚Äôd do better without all of the distractions,‚Äù Ashley said. She looked at me, and she did the up-down assessment too. It was something different from what Byron had done. ‚ÄúI look forward to learning what you have to teach.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was nice to meet you,‚Äù I said. I wasn‚Äôt sure if I was lying, but it seemed like the thing to say.

She walked down the little dirt path that extended through the grass from the building‚Äôs side door to the road. A black sedan. She opened the back door, climbed in, and closed the door with more force than was probably necessary.

‚ÄúI have so many questions,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWeld‚Äôs kind-of dad figure was the Director in charge of the Boston PRT,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúHe was also kind of in charge of looking after Ashley, because her town was close to Boston.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaking sure she didn‚Äôt do too much damage?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúYes. And gradually trying to get her used to the idea of cooperating with the good guys, making sure she was staying reasonably healthy. They reached out regularly, letting her know there were better options. Except that Ashley was a different Ashley.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs going to be on your team?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Sveta said.

I didn‚Äôt have a response for that.

She squeezed my arm. ‚ÄúI spent a lot of time with a lot of people who never got a chance, Victoria. I feel like it‚Äôs my duty to give her one.‚Äù

I drew in a deep breath, then sighed. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt disagree.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut you don‚Äôt wholly agree, either?‚Äù Rain asked.

‚ÄúI‚Ä¶ believe in second chances. Not necessarily in every circumstance, though, which seems to be the direction a lot of people are going.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe should walk,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúThe sooner we get where we split off in different directions, the earlier Kenzie can head back to her parents‚Äô and make it on time for dinner.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, please,‚Äù Kenzie said, still looking down at her phone.

Sveta had an umbrella. I held it so Sveta could walk while leaning on me, the two of us sharing it.

There weren‚Äôt many cars on the road, and even with the overcast sky making it rather dark out for the late afternoon, there weren‚Äôt many lights on either. The route we were walking put us on a long stretch of road with small businesses and restaurants on either side. Most of the illumination came from store signs in bright colors that were reflected in the puddles.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt get a great read on Chris,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs the other big set of question marks.‚Äù

‚ÄúI like Chris,‚Äù Kenzie said, without looking up. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs crazy smart about some things and adorkably stupid about others. He‚Äôs hard to figure out but when he lets you in it makes you feel special.‚Äù

She said something like that with no compunctions, no reservations. I almost envied her.

Sveta reached out and placed a hand on top of Kenzie‚Äôs hood. ‚ÄúIt would be unfair to share Chris‚Äô story when he didn‚Äôt want to share it himself, Victoria. I only said what I said about Ashley because she‚Äôs open about it.‚Äù

‚ÄúIn fairness, I wasn‚Äôt asking or prying,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI was remarking.‚Äù

‚ÄúRemarking with a question mark at the end?‚Äù Rain asked.

‚ÄúInviting an answer, but not pressing for one,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI can drop it.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Kenzie said. She put her phone away. ‚ÄúAll caught up. Stir fry for dinner, I‚Äôm going to pick up broccoli, and my workshop is warming up for later.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got a workshop, like a proper tinker,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúAbsolutely,‚Äù Kenzie said, dead serious.

‚ÄúAre you hiding a jetpack inside that raincoat, or are those rocket boots?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI wish,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt do that stuff. I make cameras and inconveniently big boxes. My best stuff is inconveniently big, box-shaped cameras.‚Äù

‚ÄúBig boxes?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúThe term in my file is emplacements. Terminals, tech, and computers big enough they‚Äôre hard to move around. Like turrets, but I can‚Äôt really make good weapons or defensive things.‚Äù

‚ÄúI see. I can see why Watchdog wanted you.‚Äù

‚ÄúGrr, arf.‚Äù

And I might be able to see why your supervisors wanted to keep you away from the front lines.

‚ÄúOut of curiosity,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúWhere are people? I‚Äôm trying to figure out where you guys are situated and what locations might work.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm from Norwalk Station,‚Äù Kenzie said.

Norwalk Station would be off to the west end of Norfair, where we had the community center incident. The ‚ÄòNor‚Äô part of Norfair. It was a nice-ish area. I‚Äôd passed through it a few times. ‚ÄúAnd you‚Äôre in school? Are you in the morning or afternoon block?‚Äù

‚ÄúMorning. I joined the study block for afternoons, I keep good grades so they let me, and I have paperwork from before that says they‚Äôre not supposed to give me too much homework, so I don‚Äôt have too much to do in the afternoons.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey might expect you to check in,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThey might.‚Äù

‚ÄúWeld and I are in Stratford, so is Ashley,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúChris lives somewhere around here. Tristan is close to here.‚Äù

Here being Fairfield.

‚ÄúBridgeport span, here,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm closer to you guys in Stratford than not.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course I‚Äôm the furthest out,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúAlmost,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúAlmost,‚Äù Kenzie echoed him.

‚ÄúWhere are you situated?‚Äù I asked Rain.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs complicated,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúUh huh. That‚Äôs starting to sound like a catchphrase.‚Äù

‚ÄúI hate saying it as much as people hate hearing it. Locationwise, I‚Äôve always liked saying I‚Äôm from everywhere that isn‚Äôt anywhere.‚Äù

I gave him a look.

‚ÄúStop being vague and teasing Victoria,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not teasing. I‚Äôm in the middle of nowhere, it‚Äôs hard to pin down. North of Greenwich. It‚Äôs a trip to get here.‚Äù

That put Tristan, Byron and Chris close to center, Kenzie out west, Rain out to the far northwest, me a bit to the east, and Sveta and Ashley a bit further to the east. With the trains I was figuring it might take about four or five hours for Kenzie to get to where Sveta and Ashley were situated. It would take Rain another couple of hours, depending on how far north he was.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a pretty significant logistics problem,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúEven in the best case scenario, if we found a place close to here, that‚Äôs a two hour or more trip for people to get here?‚Äù

‚ÄúI could build something,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt make promises.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow confident are you?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúKind of confident,‚Äù she said, sounding anything but. ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt done teleportation or breaking movement devices before, but if I made it a series of emplacements and built them big, then if I traveled once a week or so to visit the send-receives and make sure they don‚Äôt break down, it might work.‚Äù

‚ÄúTinker stuff breaks,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúIt does,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúIt would also be liable to break or break down when you needed it to work the most. During disasters, or times when there aren‚Äôt a lot of downtime.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs very true,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm wondering if there‚Äôs even a good way to go about this. I‚Äôm not trying to screw you guys up, I‚Äôm genuinely wondering.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt might not be as complicated as it seems,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI can move quickly if I have to, Ashley doesn‚Äôt have much occupying her days, when she doesn‚Äôt have her appointments, and I don‚Äôt think she minds much. She‚Äôs happy to wake up early and read on the train, she even goes to the New York hub a lot, and that‚Äôs a full day trip. As for you, you can fly again—‚Äù

She squeezed my arm as she said it, rocking a bit side to side as she did it. I rocked a bit with her.

‚Äú—and the way you were talking about things, this wouldn‚Äôt be a full-time thing for you,‚Äù Sveta finished. Her enthusiasm had risen as she talked, and only dropped with that last part.

‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIt seems you‚Äôd want a location that was closer to Kenzie and Chris then. Closer to Rain.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Rain said. He was looking around a fair bit. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt mind the trips, either.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou okay?‚Äù I asked him.

‚ÄúYeah. Forgot for a short while that I have an attempt out on my life. I really should dwell on it more, to be safe, especially with Kenzie in tow.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can hold my own,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an attempt on my life,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúLives could be lost. I don‚Äôt want yours to be one of them. I would feel insanely shitty if you jumped in to help and you got hurt or killed.‚Äù

‚ÄúInsanely?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to call my ride, I think. See if she can catch me en route instead of me going to her,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúShe? Erin the lady friend?‚Äù Kenzie asked.

‚ÄúErin the friendship I‚Äôm not going to mess with,‚Äù Rain said. He pulled out the phone and stepped a bit away, walking at the road‚Äôs edge instead of on the sidewalk.

We reached an intersection, and Rain stepped away, one hand to his ear while he held the phone to the other. His eyes roved, looking at nearby rooftops and the dark spaces between buildings.

The building at the corner of the intersection was a bar, and a group of ten or so people were standing outside, smoking. The place and the people smelled like the cheap alcohol that was barely a step above moonshine, that was being sold on the cheap in a lot of places. Made to fill a need, now a surplus, with cheap, shitty beer available to fill the need instead.

Their attention was on Sveta.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù one called out.

She glanced at them, then set to ignoring them. I took her cue.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù the guy called out again, drawing out the word. ‚ÄúHey, you with the paint.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhatever you‚Äôre going to say, I‚Äôve heard it before,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúWhat the fuck‚Äôs going on with you, huh? What‚Äôs wrong with you?‚Äù he called out.

I turned my head to look at him. Sveta squeezed my arm, then shook her head a little.

‚ÄúHey, you‚Äôre weird,‚Äù he called out. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre freaky.‚Äù

The light changed. We crossed, Rain trailing a bit behind, still on the phone, periodically responding. He shot the guys a dark look.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like it when people are mean to you,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúThank you for that,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúAnd thank you, Victoria. I know you probably wanted to say something. I‚Äôm glad we didn‚Äôt make it into a thing.‚Äù

‚ÄúDoes it happen a lot?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúSome. It beats people running away and screaming, and the running and screaming part beat people dying because of me,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúThis is an improvement. Things will improve more in the future. I believe that.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúMe too.‚Äù

‚ÄúMe too,‚Äù Kenzie said.

Sveta put a hand on Kenzie‚Äôs hooded head, squeezed my arm.

‚ÄúMy ride‚Äôs here,‚Äù Rain said, catching up with us, waving at a distant vehicle with its headlights on. I got a better view of it as it pulled up beside us. It wasn‚Äôt a pretty vehicle — a van with rust around the right headlight. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got a good long drive back. Was good seeing you guys, good to meet you, Victoria.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood to meet you, Rain,‚Äù I said.

The driver stuck her hand out, waving. We moved around to where we could see her through the passenger-side window.

Erin, Rain‚Äôs friendship he wasn‚Äôt intending to mess with, was not the kind of person I imagined driving a van like that, or spending time with someone of Rain‚Äôs somewhat grungy, not-inclined-to-smile presentation. There were women where someone‚Äôs first thought might be ‚Äòthey could be a model‚Äô and there were women where the first thought was ‚Äòthey have to be a model, it‚Äôs not fair if they aren‚Äôt‚Äô. She was the latter. Short black hair with a long swoop at the front, dangly jewelry, more piercings in one ear, and one of the memorial shirts, much like how the dress I was wearing served as a way for me to represent and remember Brockton Bay. She was from New York, it seemed, or she wanted to represent it.

‚ÄúErin, you‚Äôve seen Kenzie and Sveta before.‚Äù

‚ÄúHi again,‚Äù Erin said.

‚ÄúAnd this is Victoria. We were talking about having her be our coach.‚Äù

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù Erin said, leaning toward Rain to get a better view of me, extending her hand in another wave. Rain looked momentarily like a deer in the headlights with Erin‚Äôs face close, with Erin doing a very good job at not noticing or not looking like she‚Äôd noticed. ‚ÄúYou look a lot like Glory Girl.‚Äù

‚ÄúI am,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI was.‚Äù

‚ÄúHuh,‚Äù Erin said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs really cool. Maybe I‚Äôll see you around?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs likely,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYou guys have a good night.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou too,‚Äù Kenzie said. She held up her phone, like she was trying to get a signal. ‚ÄúDrive safe.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe good to go?‚Äù Erin asked.

‚ÄúYep,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúYou want a ride somewhere convenient, Kenz?‚Äù

‚ÄúSure!‚Äù

Kenzie climbed in behind Rain, giving us a wave before the door was closed.

Just Sveta and me left.

We watched as the van pulled away.

‚ÄúI have a lot of sympathy for Rain,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúAre you talking about the attempt on his life or the long car trip with the girl he very clearly likes?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, yeah, the dangerous thing too,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúMostly the long trip.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs all negative. We‚Äôre going in the same direction, right? We can catch up?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe can definitely catch up. I want to hear more about that vacation.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you can come over for dinner, right? Sometime? You‚Äôre not far. I can‚Äôt promise a good dinner, because I‚Äôm still trying to find food that Weld can really taste that won‚Äôt make the neighbors evacuate their apartments, but there‚Äôs takeout! Or delivery. I‚Äôm sure there‚Äôs something we can do.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou couldn‚Äôt keep me away,‚Äù I said.

‚äô

Sleep eluded me. I stood on the balcony, I stared out at a city without nearly enough lights or light in it, a jagged and incomplete skyline, and I tried to shake a persistent melancholy I couldn‚Äôt put my finger on.

The day had been a good one. My friendship with Sveta rekindled, with Sveta doing as well as I could hope for, possibilities for the future, interesting puzzles to work out, and I‚Äôd been able to do favors for people I cared about.

A part of it was the therapy. It was strange, to be in a place mentally and emotionally where therapy had a cost to it, in a way. The voice of Mrs. Yamada and the tone of the conversations reminded me of the darkest period in my life. Those reminders were probably responsible for the nightmares that had torn me from sleep.

Maybe it would be good if I called the new therapist, a new voice.

It wasn‚Äôt the nightmares that kept me from getting back to sleep, but a restless nagging feeling. I liked problems I could decisively solve, things I could tell myself I had an answer for, something I could handle in the dawn, and then I could go back to sleep. The feeling that had settled with me wasn‚Äôt that sort of answerable question.

It was the restless nagging that had me carefully and slowly open the sliding door of the balcony, step into the living room, and gather some things. A bag with my wallet and things, fresher clothes, the mask I‚Äôd worn for the broken trigger incident.

I went flying, and my destination wasn‚Äôt one that would answer the nagging feeling, but one that could answer other, more concrete questions. With luck, I‚Äôd be able to distract myself.

There were cities and areas I‚Äôd considered for the therapy group‚Äôs expedition. Ones in need, ones I knew didn‚Äôt fall neatly in one jurisdiction or another. I used the highways and major roadways as my waypoints, so I wouldn‚Äôt pass them or find myself flying too far north or south.

The sun was rising by the time I reached the first. Sherwood span. Too low a population, I could tell right away. Too many farms, the houses too spread out.

It took me twenty minutes to reach the next. The area was slow to wake up, which was a surprise, given the amount of construction sites I could see from above. Usually the work started first thing.

It was a nice slice of city, with a view of the water, tall buildings, shiny, modern, with nice, large houses, but it was only halfway erected. There were cars in driveways, but there wasn‚Äôt much life.

I flew low, stopping at one of the gates to a construction site for a taller building.

Laminated sheets had been put up on the gates.

Construction suspended until we‚Äôre given what we‚Äôre owed.

The same was on display in other places, with laminated sheets of paper and graffiti. Some of it was angrier.

I was reading a very bold, large bit of text about how certain people should be choking on cocks, when I saw I had company, standing in the corner of my field of view. A cape.

I turned to face them.

Not anyone I recognized. A man in armor with spikes on it. Plate mail, and plate armor was hard to get done right, especially in this modern day. He carried no weapon I could see. Spiky plate armor wasn‚Äôt exactly original or new, either.

He didn‚Äôt say anything or do anything, but he was holding a piece of paper.

I approached him, my forcefield up. He didn‚Äôt budge.

When I was in arm‚Äôs reach, he put his gauntlet toward me, paper in hand. I dropped my forcefield to take it.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs this?‚Äù

He wasn‚Äôt someone who sounded more intimidating from the inside of a helmet. His voice was very normal as he said, ‚ÄúWe saw you fly in, we discussed, we called some people, this is our message to you.‚Äù

‚ÄúGot it,‚Äù I said. I looked around. ‚ÄúQuiet town.‚Äù

When my head was turned, he reached for my throat.

I put my forcefield up, and I knocked his hand aside, forcefully enough I almost put him on his ass. The sound rang in my ears.

‚ÄúOur town,‚Äù he said.

That said, he trudged off.

I watched him go, and then I walked in the opposite direction. People were watching from doorsteps with coffee in hand, or standing by cars, now.

I didn‚Äôt want to back down or look weak, not if this was possibly a place I might be visiting with any regularity, so I walked slowly, like I wasn‚Äôt bothered.

With all that in mind, I still stopped in my tracks when I read the note.

Turn around and fly home, Glory Hole
-TT

They‚Äôd asked around, huh?

I folded the paper up, and I held the folded square as I walked, thinking, observing. A slice of city, paralyzed, a clear villain presence.

The guy with the spikes might have been Cleat. A low-tier cape with some background in fighting rings and mercenary work. Unlike most in fighting rings, he‚Äôd never found enough success to get traction in other circles. Ironically.

I‚Äôd left Brockton Bay in the middle of a situation, or I‚Äôd been taken from the city during. I‚Äôd put in the hours and put heart and soul into trying to combat the badness that was taking over the city, and at the end of the day, I hadn‚Äôt ever enjoyed a resolution to that situation. I‚Äôd never felt like I‚Äôd made enough of a difference in the end result.

It was tempting, the idea of coming here to a place like this and somehow completing that journey or using a success here to convince myself I could have made a proper difference if I‚Äôd been given a chance.

But this wasn‚Äôt about me. It was about those teenagers and kids in Yamada‚Äôs group.

A sign was erected by one construction site. It was covered in graffiti. ‚ÄòCedar Point Apartments‚Äô was written at the top, but ‚ÄòCedar‚Äô had been covered over in paint, and ‚ÄòHollow‚Äô had been written in its place.

Cute, and from some cursory investigation, the rebranding had been performed elsewhere, throughout the district. Graffiti and other signs of anger were clear as day, much of it vile and senseless.

Did I really want to pit those kids against this? They might give it a shot, and if it was insurmountable, Mrs. Yamada might be happy, and if it was surmountable, everyone would be happy.

I wasn‚Äôt sure.

I looked at the graffiti, getting a sense of the atmosphere here. Vulgarity, vulgarity, obscenity, drawing of vulgarity, hate, anger, vulgarity, possible gang tag, ‚Äòhollow point‚Äô appearing again.

I stopped in front of another piece of graffiti. It wasn‚Äôt crowded in with anything else, so it stood out, almost a piece of art in how it was spelled out on a ruined wall, half-toppled.

THIS IS HOW THINGS ARE NOW

I had the paper in my hand, I had my doubts, but the nagging feeling ceased being nagging and became acutely clear as I looked at the statement.

‚ÄúFuck that,‚Äù I said.

Flare — Interlude 2

‚ÄúLong coat, long hair, just got through the door, has a gun,‚Äù Crystalclear said, thumb on the button of his walkie-talkie.

The reply from the officers was almost impossible to make out.

The status quo in quiet periods was for there to be two thinkers on duty at all times. They were meant to be in communication and watching each other‚Äôs backs, and they were meant to be cooperating with the officers stationed at the portal.

During the quieter times, it would have been less than perfect for his partner to be in the midst of the crowd, where it took effort for Crystalclear to keep track of him and watch the man‚Äôs back.

Relay, one of his new teammates.

It wasn‚Äôt a quiet period, as one of the day‚Äôs bigger trains had just arrived. There were supposed to be four people on duty, one shift nearly over, another just beginning, for twice the number of eyes and powers on the scene.

Yes, it could have been an accident that the other two had yet to arrive. But accidents and coincidences could just as easily be contrivances at the hands of masterminds. The radios acting up didn‚Äôt help matters.

‚Äú—ot the gun, good ca—‚Äù the voice on the other side of the walkie talkie reported, the static cutting off the very beginning and the ending.

Sure enough, the officers had the woman in the coat. One of the officers had the gun, now.

Red jacket, jeans, pointed boots, group of three, Relay communicated. Words and ideas conveyed without being spoken. Not telepathy, not sound, but impressions.

Crystalclear‚Äôs vision didn‚Äôt give him color that wasn‚Äôt the blurring around the white outlines that defined everything. Red jacket meant nothing to him. But he could see the crowd, seeing everyone at once, and he could check the shoes. It took some focus to narrow things down, to look for the pointed shoes, to observe for another few moments to see who was grouped up.

Three people, all about the same age, all men. Their heads radiated with distortions. Their focus— not on anything in particular. He saw what they were dwelling on as a series of fractures, distorted angles, and breaks that surrounded them. These things suggested things about what was going on in their heads that were more limited to the moment, covering stresses in every sense of the word.

Stress as in emotional upset, stressing the importance of something, stress as in tension and wear.

He was glad he could use the landline for this. The little room was separated from the portal and train platforms by two walls, one with a one-way pane of glass set in it. The third wall was open, so he was free to step outside and be in the thick of things within seconds, without having to worry about doors or counters. Beside him was a phone and a computer he hadn‚Äôt bothered to fiddle with — he couldn‚Äôt see the contents of the screen without pulling a crystal from his face.

He hit the button for channel one on the phone, then picked up.

‚ÄúRelay reports there‚Äôs three people incoming. He got a low-level bad feeling about them. They seem stressed to me. Not an imminent danger. You might want to pull them out of line and have a chat. One in the lead has a red jacket, pointed shoes. I‚Äôll give you more information on their positions once they‚Äôre settled in line.‚Äù

‚ÄúGot it. Thank you, Crystalclear.‚Äù

‚ÄúLet us know if you need anyone to sit in,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúWill do.‚Äù

He was aware as heads throughout the crowd turned, their focus shifting to Relay, to the train, to the officers. For most, the light around them refracted into kaleidoscopic structures, cone or beak shaped, pointed this way and that. At the ends farthest from the points of focus, the open ends of the cones splayed out into nimbuses, auras, fractures.

He had been one of them, a year ago, a refugee stepping off the train to enter Earth Gimel, finding his luggage, walking up the short set of stairs to the desks, where people clustered in families and groups of friends, rather than in single file. They would be interviewed, they would be given temporary identification, and they would get their packages with information and resources.

Unlike many of them, he had waited nearly six months for access, because he‚Äôd been open about the fact he had powers. A mistake, because they had wanted to be careful, it had meant he had needed weeks and months of screens, of interviews and background checks, while other people passed through.

It wasn‚Äôt the first time something like that had happened, where he had taken too long to put the pieces together. All thinkers had their weaknesses and catches — all powers, probably, but thinkers were what he was most familiar with, and thinkers almost always had their issues with the mind. The problems of the mind were difficult to identify and fix, because they were so invisible, and the tools for diagnosis were often what part of what was broken or altered.

He had taken a considerable length of time to figure out the nuances of his power, too. The most obvious aspect was that he could see through walls, but he lost the ability to see and understand people, to see their faces or easily grasp the clothes they wore.

There was so much more to it, and he was learning more of it every week and month. The colors meant things, and he had only worked out the blues and the reds. Other colors separated from the white at times. There were a lot of greens in the crowd and along the station, pulling away from the outlines. He had ideas about what they meant, but he couldn‚Äôt say anything with confidence.

The fractures and formations in distortions around people were another part of it. There were elements to the way things broke up and distorted that had deeper meaning, things he didn‚Äôt understand in a way he could explain, but which made it easy for him to relate one personality and personality type to another, familiar one.

The portal took up much of the station in front of him. His multifaceted senses covered the tract of Gimel surrounding the portal, and the areas of Bet on the far side. His view encompassed the surroundings on the other side, the people, the terrain, and the different colors that bled out from the sharper white outlines.

You‚Äôre in the weeds, Relay communicated.

Crystalclear lifted his walkie-talkie to his mouth. ‚ÄúWeeds?‚Äù

Not entirely with us. Lost, or in a bit of a daze.

Crystalclear looked out beyond the portal. At the people amassed around it, human-shaped outlines with the outlines of clothes, blurs smearing around the white lines, their heads replaced with fractured, kaleidoscopic messes. A large group were in eerie unison. Singing together, possibly, or chanting.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he replied, one more word for what others would perceive as a one-sided conversation.

It was his perpetual reality. To be mundane, or to be lost. The knowledge out of his reach, there if he could find out how to reach for it or connect it.

He focused more on the crowd.

His difficulty wasn‚Äôt in tracking everyone, so much as it was finding the right angles. He didn‚Äôt have eyes with his power deployed like this, and he wasn‚Äôt limited to one point of view. He set about making sure he could investigate everyone and their carry-on baggage without anyone being hidden with their outline closely matching someone they were standing in front of or behind.

He didn‚Äôt move his head as he looked back, up the stairs and out at the loosely organized lines of people. The trio had joined the line.

He used the phone, ‚ÄúThe three people Relay wanted you guys to keep an eye out for just joined the line. They‚Äôre behind a shorter, elderly couple. One of them‚Äôs agitated.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you, Crystalclear,‚Äù the voice on the phone replied.

While more of his focus was dwelling in that direction and area, making sure he was seeing everything from the necessary angles, he became aware of two people who others were paying a great deal of attention to.

One of them was tall, somewhat muscular, but what stood out was the storm of fractures around his head, overlapping without connecting to one another. A crown of thorns, fashioned from something that looked like especially precise breaks in glass or deep-etched frost.

The other was smaller, hunched over. She was almost the opposite, the breaks vague, cracking out to reach like a whip, aimed at nothing in particular.

He used the walkie-talkie, ‚ÄúI think our relief just turned up.‚Äù

Making my way to you.

Relay and the two individuals reached Crystalclear‚Äôs booth at the same time. Crystalclear stepped out, aware of the number of people who were turning to look. He tried to keep an eye on the crowd.

Relay made the introductions. ‚ÄúCrystalclear, this is Big Picture, and this is Ratcatcher.‚Äù

‚ÄúHello,‚Äù Big Picture said. More tight loops of breakage encircled his head rapidfire as he turned it to look at Crystalclear, and the loops bled like purple watercolor paint.

‚ÄúHello,‚Äù Crystalclear said.

‚ÄúHello. We‚Äôre the reinforthmenth,‚Äù Ratcatcher said, with a heavy lisp.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre new to Foresight?‚Äù Big Picture asked.

‚ÄúI am,‚Äù Crystalclear said. ‚ÄúOnly positives so far.‚Äù

‚ÄúI thought about joining,‚Äù Big Picture said. ‚ÄúI decided it was better to wait until things settled down. For now, I get paid for this, I keep it simple.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeth. Thimple ith good,‚Äù Ratcatcher said.

‚ÄúI like the costume,‚Äù Big Picture said.

Crystalclear touched the tunic portion of his outfit.

It wasn‚Äôt anything like he‚Äôd worn with the Norfair Neighborhood Heroes. A single shoulderpad, a piece of cloth forming a kind of shawl or mantle as it extended from one corner of the shoulderpad near his heart, over his shoulder, and around to the back corner of the shoulderpad near his shoulderblade. The shoulderpad, the armor at his wrists and the armor around his legs had chunks of crystal, closely matched to the crystal that he naturally produced. Lightweight as armor went, limited to a few pieces that were as decorative as functional, but it was still armor. A band of metal ran along his chin‚Äôs edge, and that took some particular getting used to.

‚ÄúAppreciated,‚Äù Crystalclear said. It was odd to reply when he was only aware of the outlines of the outfit. He had seen it in the mirror when he had been getting ready, but that memory felt faint, and he had yet to see how put together he looked with the crystals at the upper half of his face.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to go get back to work,‚Äù Relay said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be in communication.‚Äù

Crystalclear returned to his seat. Big Picture stood out in the open, his arms folded.

Ratcatcher joined Crystalclear in the booth, sitting on the counter by the phone.

‚ÄúWhat do you do, Crythtalclear?‚Äù Ratcatcher asked.

‚ÄúI see through walls. I can see contraband.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can too,‚Äù Ratcatcher said. ‚ÄúI thee thmall thingth, wherever they are.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe might be redundant then.‚Äù

‚ÄúRedundancy can help,‚Äù Big Picture said.

‚ÄúCan you share your power, Big Picture?‚Äù

Big picture turned his head. Crystalclear wished he could see the big guy‚Äôs face. Knowing if the guy was frowning or smiling would help a great deal.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs redundancy,‚Äù Big Picture said. He made a sound, almost a laugh. ‚ÄúEverything I want to focus on, I clone my brain and my mind. I can give each and every detail every bit of my attention, and I can slow down my perceptions if I want to study it more. There are a few other nuances, other things I can do with the parallel takes, sharing, but you don‚Äôt need all of the details.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can spend the equivalent of a few minutes studying every possible clue?‚Äù Crystalclear asked.

‚ÄúWeeks. Months, if I want.‚Äù

‚ÄúSounds as if it could have its drawbacks.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt we all?‚Äù Big Picture asked.

Crystalclear was aware that Ratcatcher wasn‚Äôt alone. He turned his head a little, then pointed at the pocket of Ratcatcher‚Äôs top. It was a sleeveless top, tight-fitting in the way a costume was supposed to be, but it had a hoodie-like pouch in the front. There was a small life form in there, the thing‚Äôs perspective fuzzy in a way that suggested it was asleep, in whole or in part.

Ratcatcher made a pleased sound, then reached into the pouch. The disturbance woke the creature, but she didn‚Äôt act like it was upset as she held it in her two hands.

Crystalclear could guess what the thing was from its dimensions and Ratcatcher‚Äôs name. ‚ÄúDoes it have a name?‚Äù

‚ÄúRaththputin,‚Äù Ratcatcher said. She picked up a walkie-talkie, ‚ÄúThe attractive older gentleman in the peacoat, hairy earth and eyelatheth to die for. Thomething thown into the coat. Naughty.‚Äù

‚Äú‚Ä¶I can see Ratcatcher has joined us‚Ä¶‚Äù the walkie talkie buzzed in response. The buzzing turned into crackling. ‚Äú‚Ä¶nimize colorful commenta‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúRadio‚Äôth garbage today,‚Äù Ratcatcher observed.

‚ÄúIt is.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry we‚Äôre late,‚Äù Big Picture said. ‚ÄúFeels like we took a step backward, citywide. There‚Äôs word of a potential transportation strike. Our usual bus driver didn‚Äôt show, we had to wait for the next. Construction sites between NYC and Boston are locked down, they aren‚Äôt doing anything except getting in the way.‚Äù

‚ÄúFeels like we should be out there, not here,‚Äù Crystalclear said.

‚ÄúI know that feeling. It‚Äôs often a trap.‚Äù

Crystalclear turned toward Big Picture.

‚ÄúI joined the military, before I got powers. I was thinking something similar when I did. That things at home were shit, but I was needed out there. We didn‚Äôt fix anything out there, and we came home to find things were worse.‚Äù

Crystalclear was going to reply, but he was interrupted by the lisping young woman.

‚ÄúBuckthom lady thtepping off the train,‚Äù Ratcatcher said. ‚ÄúBra that doethn‚Äôt fit, run in her thtocking. Cavity thearch, if you pleathe.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt you being funny again, Rat?‚Äù Big Picture asked.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm being good, thank you very mush.‚Äù

Crystalclear looked. There was something suspended in the middle of the blur that was the woman. He held up his walkie-talkie. ‚ÄúSeconding Ratcatcher on this one. She‚Äôs got something stowed.‚Äù

I see her, Relay communicated. Noise surrounding her is similar to a few others we spotted earlier.

‚ÄúI remember,‚Äù Crystalclear said, through the walkie talkie. He‚Äôd noticed but he hadn‚Äôt been sure how common it was or how much of a thread ran through it all until he‚Äôd had it point out. That weakness of his again. ‚ÄúThere have been one or two of these small-time smugglers on every train, all day.‚Äù

Big Picture said, ‚ÄúIt might be worth checking what‚Äôs going on in Bet. Could be a gang, strong-arming people into going through, or offering a head start in Gimel if they‚Äôll smuggle something through.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt might not go that well,‚Äù Crystalclear said. ‚ÄúToo easy to get sucked in right from the start, not being allowed to leave once you‚Äôve made that delivery.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe ugly kid with the runny nothe hath clutter in hith bag. Thyringeth.‚Äù

‚Äú‚Ä¶heckin‚Ä¶‚Äù the radio crackled.

Big Picture picked up his walkie talkie, ‚ÄúThe woman with him isn‚Äôt his mother, either. Better to have them get picked out of line and taken away for an interview.‚Äù

The radio crackled with the affirmative.

Slowly, the train and the platform emptied. They kept an eye out for the drugs, for the violence, for the people who were especially angry or scared.

One of the train cars remained filled. Crystalclear looked through, and saw the people within sitting, calm, not reaching for their things.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the status of car five?‚Äù he asked. ‚ÄúThere are a few guns in there.‚Äù

Ratcatcher pulled the keyboard closer to her, she typed and then responded, ‚ÄúThpecial cathe. VIP.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôve got a case fifty-three in there.‚Äù

‚ÄúWeld, according to the computer. Ethcorting.‚Äù

‚ÄúWeld,‚Äù Crystalclear said. He was familiar with the name. ‚ÄúGood to know.‚Äù

Crowd is thinning out, Relay communicated. I‚Äôll go say hi.

Crystalclear watched as people sorted out. The platform emptied, and the officers on the scene did what they could to get others moving along, helping with bags and pointing people in the right direction.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre bleeding,‚Äù Ratcatcher observed.

‚ÄúMe?‚Äù Crystalclear asked.

‚ÄúAt the corner of your eye,‚Äù she said.

He checked, touching the spot in question and finding the bead of blood with his sense of touch. Sure enough, she was right. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a thing that happens. Doesn‚Äôt mean anything. Excuse me.‚Äù

‚ÄúEckthuthed,‚Äù she said.

He touched one of the crystals that was sticking up and out of that eye socket, gripped it, and hauled it free. He could feel the glass edge slide against the inside of his eyelid, the root of it hauling free of the floor of his eye socket, and he could feel the fluids inside his eye stir.

‚ÄúYou jutht made it worth,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine. I never bleed for long. I try to be careful, so I don‚Äôt scare people, but it doesn‚Äôt bother me much.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood to know,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI know all about that.‚Äù

He pulled it free, a foot-long block of crystal, and laid it carefully down on the counter. He blinked a few times with his one eye, noticed that Ratcatcher had taken off her mask, gray furred and full-face, and decided to keep his gaze averted, for privacy‚Äôs sake, and because looking at her would let her see his face.

He concentrated, and he produced another chunk of glass, feeling it stab from the underside of his eye and out, sliding through everything in the way without doing real damage. He was careful to shape it in his mind so there wouldn‚Äôt be any sharp edges resting against his eyelid or brow.

He turned his face Ratcatcher‚Äôs way. ‚ÄúHow do I look? Symmetrical?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeth.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù she said, with emphasis on the ‚Äòyou‚Äô.

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot many people look me in the fathe when my mathk is off and keep from flinching,‚Äù she said.

Crystalclear‚Äôs response was cut short.

Weld wants us, Relay said. Diplomatic thing.

‚ÄúWeld is asking for me,‚Äù Crystalclear said. ‚ÄúGood luck, guys.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll get to know each other, I‚Äôm sure,‚Äù Big Picture said.

‚ÄúGood luck,‚Äù Ratcatcher said.

Relay was already coordinating the officers. The path that led from platform to the intake center was being closed off, a metal shuttered door sliding closed. Another set of doors were being unlocked and opened.

VIPs indeed, it seemed, and from what Crystalclear could see, they were only human.

Crystalclear approached the train car, standing beside Relay. Weld and Narwhal were standing nearby.

Narwhal looked rather spectacular to Crystalclear‚Äôs vision, given the emphasis on outlines, and her having dressed up in very small, outlined objects.

‚ÄúLook after them,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll see the way is clear.‚Äù

‚ÄúGot it,‚Äù Weld said. ‚ÄúYou would be Crystalclear?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood to meet you. I didn‚Äôt think you were one of us.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, I‚Äôm not. I can go from this to‚Ä¶ not this,‚Äù Crystalclear said. He was suddenly aware he wasn‚Äôt sure what terminology was okay or not okay with the C-53s.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs good to hear. Closer to Narwhal than anything, then. I‚Äôve heard good things, Crystalclear. Foresight is lucky to have you.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you. Likewise, with you and the Wardens.‚Äù

‚ÄúWere you around for that broken trigger incident a week and a half ago?‚Äù

‚ÄúI was,‚Äù Crystalclear said. ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt in a position to do much.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis situation here follows from that. We‚Äôve got visitors, and we want to keep things calm and safe. Foresight said we should make use of you and Relay to help keep an eye on things.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Crystalclear said. ‚ÄúAlright.‚Äù

There was a pause. ‚ÄúAre you okay to do this?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Crystalclear said. He realized he didn‚Äôt sound confident, and tried again. ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

He wasn‚Äôt sure it was alright. He‚Äôd been volunteered for something and he hadn‚Äôt explicitly been told. It was a level of disconnection from the authority that felt uncomfortably familiar and disconcerting.

It made him think of his aunt. It also made him think of Big Picture‚Äôs statements about it being better to wait.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre bodyguards and protection for the Gimel side of things. The other guys brought their own protection.‚Äù

The other guys? Crystalclear thought.

All thinkers had their weaknesses. Most hated not knowing things. Most, by way of how their powers gave them an edge in one respect, had a way of missing other things. Crystalclear‚Äôs vision gave him a lot, but it made some obvious things impossible to grasp.

Crystalclear‚Äôs focus broadened as he tried to take in everything necessary to keep an eye on things. He looked at the crowd, noted who was reacting to the shutters being closed, and tried to keep tabs on them. He watched the other heroes, tracked the officers, and tried to wrap his head around the fractured messes that were their heads and the ever-shifting contents of those heads.

‚ÄúRatcatcher seemed to take to you,‚Äù Relay commented.

‚ÄúDid she?‚Äù Crystalclear asked.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the impression I got. You didn‚Äôt seem too bothered, either.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe seemed like a nice kid. Weird but good.‚Äù

Relay made a small sound. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt, uh, say that around her. She‚Äôs older than you. Heh.‚Äù

Crystalclear smiled, but he felt just a little anxious. There were things he had liked about the NNH group with Tempera, Longscratch and Fume Hood. Big Picture had talked about the merits of simplicity.

Thinker issues. He hated being out of the loop. It constantly felt like he was. Even when it was with things that pertained to himself.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Relay said. He‚Äôd apparently picked something up.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay,‚Äù Crystalclear said.

The group was departing the train, now.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be using the emergency stairwell,‚Äù Relay said. ‚ÄúWe go upstairs, we‚Äôll find a vantage point, they‚Äôll have their meeting with the people who are already waiting there, then a few of them are going to go tour Gimel. Things are out of our hands once they do, they‚Äôve been warned about that. The newcomers want to see the city they‚Äôve been helping to build.‚Äù

‚ÄúI heard about some of this,‚Äù Crystalclear said. ‚ÄúThese are people from an alternate Earth?‚Äù

He didn‚Äôt get his answer, as the people approached.

Three men, with their entourage, men with guns. Their heads were interesting. Leader and soldier, they were very in sync, much like the group that was still gathered outside the Bet portal were of similar minds as they chanted or sang together. They felt like an odd fit. Foreign worlders?

Leaders of Earth Cheit. Abrahamic theocrats. They‚Äôre our guests, here about the people of theirs who died in the broken trigger incident.

A serious subject. Crystalclear was aware of a few other things that had come up in regard to the group, until the broken trigger had consumed everyone‚Äôs attention. The discussions in the late-night media had been derailed by the deaths of the ninety-two individuals caught by the broken trigger.

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôll follow us,‚Äù Weld said.

They walked up the stairs, with Weld in front, and Relay and Crystalclear toward the rear. The armed guard trailed even further behind, with one waiting at the base of the stairwell.

They had a bit of a distance to walk to reach the room at the top. It looked like a ball room, with fancy curtains, a lacquered floor, and lots of empty space. A table was set to one side, and there were curtains closed that didn‚Äôt stop the light from passing through. Sheers, possibly, to obscure the view of the world outside, or perhaps more importantly, to obscure those on the outside from seeing those within.

People were seated at the table already, paperwork around them.

The one closest to the door was a serious looking woman, slender, in a blouse and a skirt that highlighted how narrow she was. The belt of her skirt cinched in at the waist, emphasizing her figure. She had a lot of the anxiety that the refugees departing the train had had, but she didn‚Äôt show it in how she sat or how she moved as she stood to greet the men.

Sierra Kiley, Relay communicated. Board member of Rock Bay Reconstruction Group. That‚Äôs one of the biggest construction firms, with its roots in Brockton Bay. She‚Äôs a candidate for mayor of the Megalopolis, but she‚Äôs not expected to win. Foresight thinks she has her hat in the ring for other reasons. Access, possibly. We know she has ties to organized crime, if you couldn‚Äôt guess from her background in Brockton Bay. She doesn‚Äôt necessarily know we know.

Next were a couple, male and female. She wore a nice suit-dress. He wore a dress shirt, slacks, and carried the paperwork. Their focus was sharp, they clearly worked well together from how well they coordinated. As with Big Picture, there was something else going on with the man‚Äôs perceptions. He wasn‚Äôt a cone— his perceptions were covering a lot of ground, and his fractures were very different from the norm. They were closer to being etches.

Jeanne Wynn and her assistant. CEO of Mortari, second of the large construction groups. Jeanne might be too. She‚Äôs a more serious candidate for mayor, she‚Äôs running, she and a lot of others think she‚Äôll win.

Crystalclear was bothered that he was getting filled in on things he already had some knowledge of, but felt disconnected in other things. He‚Äôd known about Jeanne. She had recently put up her proposals online, for how she wanted and expected to run things if she won.

The person who won mayorship of Gimel, if they weren‚Äôt killed in an uprising, would likely go on to be leader of Gimel as a whole.

We suspect the assistant is a parahuman.

He was, Crystalclear knew. He resolved to communicate that when he could.

Others were named and identified by Relay. Mr. Nieves, another prospective mayor, though he didn‚Äôt have the footing the others did, his chances were better than Ms. Kiley‚Äôs. Mr. Buckner was at the forefront of the burgeoning media enterprise in Gimel, bringing television to the masses.

Stay put and stay silent.

The voice wasn‚Äôt Relay‚Äôs, but it was easy to imagine as Relay‚Äôs, with it being so vivid.

Crystalclear had a confused and fractured memory of his early childhood. The woman he remembered growing up with was not the woman he‚Äôd spent his late childhood and adolescence with. His aunt had explained the situation for him, saying his mother hadn‚Äôt been well, he‚Äôd been taken away from her for his safety.

She had said a lot of things over the years. He had believed most, and because other things had occupied his attention, he hadn‚Äôt given the remainder enough focus.

Normally, trigger events emphasizing isolation, loss, cut ties, and betrayal tended to lead to master powers. Or, rather, master powers tended to go to people who were going to deal with those situations.

Any attachment he had felt to his aunt had faded over the years, long before he had triggered. She hadn‚Äôt cared. So long as he behaved and didn‚Äôt cause a fuss, she had been happy to not have to devote much attention to him. There was nothing lost, so that aspect of things hadn‚Äôt factored in.

So, naturally, he had avoided causing a fuss.

It had only been later that their fragile reality had come crashing down around them. The police were closing in on him, he was no longer young, and where a young, clean cut white boy had flown under the radar, a teenaged white boy with pimples hadn‚Äôt. It had turned out that his aunt wasn‚Äôt his aunt at all. Her only relation to him was that she had stolen him from his real mother.

The questions had come, hours of interrogation, his lawyer guiding him. Hadn‚Äôt he put the pieces together? Hadn‚Äôt he seen? Why hadn‚Äôt he asked more questions? He hadn‚Äôt looked at what he was delivering to homes even once in the past few years?

No, he‚Äôd said. No, he‚Äôd never looked. He had never really considered. He had only wanted to exist.

The police had been upset, angry, hostile. His lawyer had been frustrated, because anything, anything at all could have led to a plea deal or him getting off free. His ‚Äòaunt‚Äô and her boyfriend were upset, because they blamed him for their being arrested, and they had used a proxy to threaten him.

He had been sufficiently scared and lost to trigger.

Now he stood guard. He was trying to exist, to do what good he could, and he wanted to pay a little more attention than he once had, even as his power made that very easy on the surface and very difficult when it came to the deeper analysis.

The initial introductions were wrapping up. The theocrats of Cheit were saying a brief prayer, heads bowed.

People settled into their seats, empty seats between groups, serving as a kind of separation.

‚ÄúWar.‚Äù

One word. It had been said by the lead theocrat, no preamble, and it was enough to be followed by silence.

‚ÄúI say it not because I believe in it or want it,‚Äù he went on, ‚ÄúBut because the people at home wanted me to convey it.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve had a strong working relationship thus far,‚Äù Jeanne said.

‚ÄúWe have,‚Äù the theocrat said.

‚ÄúForgive me,‚Äù Nieves said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm lost. It came up before, but things got in the way. What exactly is the working relationship?‚Äù

Jeanne explained, ‚ÄúCheit has graciously provided Earth Gimel with supplies for reconstruction. They supplied us with food and other things that enabled us to weather the first winter. A hard season.‚Äù

‚ÄúI remember,‚Äù Nieves said. ‚ÄúI know this much. But what exactly did Cheit get in the bargain?‚Äù

‚ÄúGoodwill,‚Äù the theocrat said.

‚ÄúGoodwill?‚Äù Nieves asked.

‚ÄúWe have an awful lot of very awful people at our disposal, to put things lightly,‚Äù Kiley said. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt really think anyone wants actual war, do we?‚Äù

‚ÄúAs I was instructed, I brought it up,‚Äù the theocrat said. ‚ÄúIt is officially on the table.‚Äù

Crystalclear was still, listening. He didn‚Äôt miss the glance that Weld and Narwhal shared. Neither of them budged an inch.

‚ÄúGoodwill is a matter of faith,‚Äù Jeanne said. ‚ÄúThe understanding was that they would share their excess, out of the goodness of their hearts. We, in turn, would manage our own.‚Äù

‚ÄúSix of Earth Cheit‚Äôs citizens are dead. Five godly men and a woman, all with their families. By all accounts, they died in a terrible, protracted way.‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause of a broken trigger,‚Äù Jeanne said. ‚ÄúOutside of our control. Surely you understand.‚Äù

‚ÄúThese ‚Äòtriggers‚Äô, as we understand it, are the result of strife and upset. Your people were upset because of how Mortari and RBR have handled your subordinates.‚Äù

Crystalclear watched carefully, his eyes on all of the people present, on the nearby rooftops, and on the area below, to make sure nobody was attempting entry.

Jeanne and the theocrat seemed to be the ones in control over this conversation. Jeanne had a parahuman with her, and the parahuman was studying the room, but nothing suggested he was communicating with his superior. Nothing about the way things refracted and moved around his head, nothing about the colors. Purple here and there, but spotty, brief.

If she was a superior at all, that was. It was very possible the ‚Äòassistant‚Äô was the one truly in charge.

‚ÄúWhat would you have us do?‚Äù Kiley asked.

The theocrat answered, ‚ÄúWe want you to be in control. Control your people, organize, avoid similar situations. We are happy to be generous to our less fortunate neighbors, but we cannot have your troubles become our troubles.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre working on that,‚Äù Kiley said.

‚ÄúAre you married, Ms. Kiley?‚Äù the theocrat asked.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see how that‚Äôs relevant.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat would be a no, then. I prefer to work with married individuals, like Mrs. Wynn here. They understand the difficulties of a long term relationship, the compromises and deeper knowledge it takes to make things work.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt be where I am if I wasn‚Äôt competent. Trust me, Mr. Aguirre, I‚Äôve earned my place.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo I‚Äôve heard,‚Äù the theocrat answered. His tone was such that it was as cutting a response as an outright denial or dismissal. ‚ÄúMrs. Wynn, you‚Äôre prepared to organize and control things?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve already taken steps. You‚Äôll see measurable change in coming weeks.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood. Ms. Kiley, you‚Äôre welcome to prove me wrong in my judgment about you. A lot depends on this. We are happy to keep supplying you with everything you could need, we believe in generosity, but it‚Äôs contingent on your successes. We know which pies each of you have your fingers in. If one of you succeed, we‚Äôll gladly back you. If both succeed, we‚Äôll back you both. If others step up and prove themselves, we‚Äôll back them.‚Äù

‚ÄúProvided we do well enough at making the most of what you provide.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease don‚Äôt disappoint,‚Äù the theocrat said. He placed his hand on the paperwork in front of him. ‚ÄúYou know what‚Äôs on the table.‚Äù

Ms. Kiley said, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm in your good books, Mr. Aguirre, I think I don‚Äôt lower myself any further in your eyes by saying this—‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat you say or don‚Äôt say has little to do with what I feel about you, Ms. Kiley. I believe in deeds.‚Äù

‚Äú—You do not want a war with Gimel. We have so very little to lose, and I can tell you, I know this very well. We have some very awful people at our disposal. You can threaten bombs and armies. We can threaten nightmares come to life and life turned to nightmares.‚Äù

‚ÄúI believe you,‚Äù Aguirre said. ‚ÄúI know the kinds of people you interact with, Ms. Kiley. Part of the reason I‚Äôm here is that I‚Äôve worked directly with some individuals and situations of that breed, who appeared in Cheit. I wish I could say with confidence that I could make the people I report to believe the same. They would need to see it with their own eyes, and by then it would be too late.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs possible,‚Äù Kiley said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve laid out what the people in charge believe. I can report your feelings on this and come back another day, but I don‚Äôt think this is liable to change. They want security, you want supply.‚Äù

‚ÄúSuccinctly put,‚Äù Jeanne said.

‚ÄúTell me what you would need, if we were to extend good faith and renew supply for your construction.‚Äù

‚ÄúConstruction is stalled. Transportation is stalling. Crime is surging,‚Äù Nieves said.

‚ÄúWhich are things we‚Äôll get a handle on,‚Äù Jeanne said, tersely. ‚ÄúYes, please, let‚Äôs talk supply. Concrete, lumber, and food, to start with.‚Äù

‚ÄúLet me see, paperwork, papers, thank you, Charles.‚Äù

The discussion continued.

Crystalclear held his tongue, but he could see the way the constructions around the other parahumans‚Äô heads were operating, the cracks that were forming and gathering, and the bleeding of the colors. Blue-green tints, for many.

‚äô

‚ÄúThey‚Äôve been giving us supply for nothing?‚Äù Nieves asked, raising his voice. ‚ÄúYou idiots. You‚Äôve profited off of their so-called generosity, but you‚Äôve been selling us out.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey were going to look for a foothold, whatever we did,‚Äù Jeanne said. ‚ÄúThey wanted security, and that wouldn‚Äôt change whatever we did. Allowing them to help provided some of that security.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt provided them leverage and the impression they have a say in how Gimel is run!‚Äù

‚ÄúThey do have a say. They‚Äôre our neighbors, and they outnumber us,‚Äù Kiley said. She sounded tired.

The theocrats had departed. The people had changed seats, to sit closer together. Jackets had been removed and hung on the backs of chairs, waters and coffees obtained. The discussion continued, on a different front. A scattered, small group of people trying to find a way forward against a very large, united group.

The argument continued, heated, terse. Standing around the edges of the room, the parahumans exchanged looks, then walked over to where the coffee and water was being supplied.

‚ÄúWhat do you think?‚Äù Weld asked. Narwhal stood beside him.

‚ÄúJeanne has been in contact with Cheit for a long time,‚Äù Relay said. ‚ÄúSince Gold Morning?‚Äù

‚ÄúHer assistant is a parahuman,‚Äù Crystalclear said. ‚ÄúSomething about the way his head is put together. Thinker. They may have been communicating, maybe not.‚Äù

‚ÄúKiley was communicating with people throughout. Earpiece,‚Äù Relay said. ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt see?‚Äù

‚ÄúHeads and surrounding objects get murky,‚Äù Crystalclear said, his voice quiet.

‚ÄúWe asked you two here for a reason,‚Äù Narwhal said. ‚ÄúYou have strong backgrounds, and people see you as trustworthy.‚Äù

‚ÄúForesight is taking on a role as Wardens adjunct,‚Äù Weld said. ‚ÄúA‚Ä¶ discreet role.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou want us to be your watchdogs,‚Äù Crystalclear said.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre keeping too close an eye on the Wardens themselves. We could use observers and more covert operatives.‚Äù

‚ÄúWatching them?‚Äù Crystalclear asked, tilting his head toward the window. He tilted his head toward the table. ‚ÄúOr watching them?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat you asked proves we were right to ask,‚Äù Weld said.

Crystalclear bit his tongue. His instinct was to say Weld was wrong. That he was the wrong person. He missed critical things, by consequence of his power being what it was.

He‚Äôd joined the NNH to change things, to be a real piece in something greater, rather than a cog in the machine, and that had fallen to pieces.

But by saying all of that that, he would be relegating himself to Big Picture‚Äôs small-picture view of the world. Subsisting, looking after refugees, doing small things, instead of what he‚Äôd hoped for with the NNH. He would be saying he didn‚Äôt have what it took.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm in,‚Äù Relay said. ‚ÄúBut you already guessed that.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Narwhal said. ‚ÄúCrystalclear?‚Äù

Crystalclear nodded. ‚ÄúI will. One question, though.‚Äù

‚ÄúAsk.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you have us doing this, what do you have Advance Guard and the Attendant doing?‚Äù

Glare — 3.1

Cities, like people, got their second chances. Few cities had needed one so badly as this. I was left hoping the other cities were doing better with their second opportunities, because nothing I was seeing was very promising, here.

The four teams under the Wardens‚Äô umbrella, now condensed down to three, were divided into those who wanted to return to the way things had been and those who wanted to forge a new way forward, learning from the mistakes of the past. The appeal of returning to a semblance of what we‚Äôd had was clear— we missed the foods, the places, the familiar businesses and media, the familiar faces.

We wanted normal and even now every meal, every soap we used, every piece of clothing, it was a reminder of how far from normal we were. It was different and often less because we had less, and we had less of a footing. I wasn‚Äôt the only person who felt their stomach sink when we saw the news two weeks after the broken trigger had decimated the reconstruction workers‚Äô protest, saying that the transportation strike was imminent, and that factory workers were contemplating joining in, an across-the-board attempt to demand stability and structure.

It was important, a line had to be drawn and the endless talks about what our government would look like needed to end, but I still saw the reports and I knew the foods, clothes, and routine I wanted were going to have to wait that much longer.

That was one of the prevailing arguments for normal, for going back. This section of the city, this settlement, was the counterpoint.

Brockton Bay had been a port, growing as the industry did. A lot of what made it work as a fledgling port city made New Brockton work as one of our first footholds in Earth Gimel. Lumber, quarrying, some surface level minerals, and geography protected from the harshest sweeps of cold weather from the north.

The industry had become a prominent part of the city, and then the greater industry had outgrown it. Things had reached the point where it was easier to take one big ship and go to Boston and transport goods from there than to take two smaller ships and go to Brockton Bay, even if Brockton Bay was closer to the goods‚Äô destination. The factories and goods went where the ships went, because it wasn‚Äôt sensible to ship raw materials from Boston to Brockton Bay to do manufacturing when Boston could handle it.

New Brockton felt like it sat on that brink between relevance and ruin. As a settlement, it was defined by tall buildings and the edifices of heavy industry. There were ships finding their way past each other on the water and big brick buildings with black plumes of smoke rising from their chimneys. Already back to the ways of an era that predated me, cutting corners to produce more at a cost to tomorrow. It was crowded and bursting at the seams, and it had been for a while now, trying to grow despite the constraints of water and mountain around it.

It didn‚Äôt escape me that the settlement continued to chug along while the gears and belts of the greater megalopolis were grinding to a stop under strikes and shutdowns.

I walked, rather than fly, because the directions I‚Äôd been given mandated it. I suspected it was intentional. I knew there were eyes on me, I knew who some of those eyes belonged to, and I had strong suspicions about others.

The racist graffiti no longer dominated downtown, though I did see some, with half of it partially painted over or altered. Many of the people who had lived and thrived in Brockton Bay had made their way here, after all. An attempt had been made to use wall space, to give the tenements-and-factories color when mirrored windows on skycrapers didn‚Äôt steal it from the sky or water. Murals now decorated many of the walls and building fronts, no doubt an attempt to leave less open wall space for the gang tags and symbols. Animals and symbols of humanity like clasped hands covered residential areas. Green trees, branches, and lush mountains painted almost ironically on the sides of factories and power plants.

There were places that mirrored home, in layout and the buildings that had been placed. The area that had been the Towers at the southwest corner of the city was still the Towers. Downtown was still where Downtown had been. A Lord Street stabbed north-to-south through the settlement. Despite the attempts, it wasn‚Äôt home. It came from something different.

Such was the counterpoint: in attempting to paint a picture of home, we might distort or create a caricature of that picture. If we rushed it or forced it, we risked making some of the same fundamental mistakes we‚Äôd made before, building on cracked foundations.

Seeing the murals, the directions I‚Äôd received started to make sense. The path was byzantine. Go the way the wolf and his cubs are looking. A wolf and three cubs that looked like they were made of white smoke were painted on a concrete wall. They stood facing one way, but their heads were looking back.

Walk beneath the leaping rabbit. A rabbit decorated an arch at the edge of a children‚Äôs park. The park felt small and lonely amid larger, taller buildings, partially fenced in, with room for two swings, a slide, a sandbox and one basketball half-court that would have to be vacated if a car came through to use the parking garage or if the dump truck came for the dumpster at the back of a building.

Follow the snake.

If I hadn‚Äôt known it was a snake, I might not have realized what it was. It was sectioned off, the skeleton of a winding serpent with each vertebrae several feet from the other. Three white pieces along one wall, a white-painted drain cover, then more segments on the wall opposite.

The painted lines of a crosswalk took me across the street. I followed more segments of the snake to reach one of the larger apartment complexes, four identical L-shaped buildings framing a plaza. The bottom floors of the buildings and the lowest floors along the inside of each ‚ÄòL‚Äô had some basic stores.

Two years ago, this would have been one of the nicer areas in Earth Gimel, if a little basic. No-name grocery store, clothing store, and home-goods store. It was dated already, and I could already imagine two years from now, when various murals might be faded or defaced, when the metal chairs and tables would be rusted, the stores closed or forgotten. The snake cut through the plaza, which could have seated two hundred people, but currently had six. Any earlier and there would have been people having a late lunch. Any later and it would be time for an early dinner or an after-work bite to eat.

A tunnel led through the body of one of the apartment buildings, leading from plaza to parking lot. The mural of a cat with its back twisting and arching was painted on the walls and roof. Its paws stuck out and across the footpath firmly pressed down on the snake‚Äôs neck.

‚ÄòWait‚Äô was the last instruction.

I checked my phone. One message:

K:
K.

I flicked my thumb, spun up the music player and then fished my earbuds out of the pocket of my jacket. I put only one in, so I could keep one ear out for trouble.

I waited long enough for five songs to start and stop. A pair of people arrived at the plaza, got their food, ate, and left, before anything happened. I wondered more than once if I‚Äôd been baited to come here as a way of making me waste time.

‚ÄúYou get fifteen minutes.‚Äù

I turned my head in the direction of the parking lot, turning off my music and pulling the ear-bud free. I moved my hand in a circle to catch most of the length of cord in a loop.

Tattletale had reversed her costume colors from black on lavender to a more royal purple on black. The same pattern of lines slashing across her costume remained— horizontal line across the upper chest, vertical line slashing down from that, to form a stylized ‚ÄòT‚Äô. Another horizontal line jutted out from halfway down, followed by another vertical line piercing that line, a smaller ‚Äòt‚Äô nestled under the right arm of its big brother. She wasn‚Äôt the type to get photographed or caught clearly on video, and it was painted in such broad strokes that I suspected many people missed it.

It kind of smacked of narcissism, I felt, to wear one‚Äôs initials. The more black costume, at least, looked more distinguished. Her hair needed a bit of combing, like it had been tousled by the wind and it hadn‚Äôt been fixed.

She was followed by a flurry of small birds that settled on the street by the exit of the alley, and by one bodyguard. The cape was burly, wearing a skintight suit that showed off his muscles, and wore a heavy cloth hood with eyeholes cut out, a series of ‚Äòx‚Äô stitches forming a frowny-face. The lines around his eyes were cut deep. Very weary. He stood with his hands clasped behind him.

On the other side of the tunnel, one of the men that had been eating in the plaza had approached. He now stood with his back ramrod straight, his hands clasped behind him. Very clean cut, hair short and styled, recently shaved, t-shirt, black slacks, and shiny black shoes.

I knew Tattletale knew how my forcefield worked. If the man had a gun, he was potentially a danger to me.

‚ÄúI like the cat,‚Äù I said, pointing. ‚ÄúSubtle.‚Äù

‚ÄúFifteen minutes, Vicky,‚Äù Tattletale said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to be a lot less if you want to make small talk. If this becomes you wagging your finger at me and acting all holier-than-thou, I‚Äôm walking. I‚Äôm busy these days. The only reason I‚Äôm giving you time out of my day is hometown respect.‚Äù

I fished in my pocket. I pulled out the paper. ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt because you wanted to talk to me?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen you‚Äôre positioned like I am, you can‚Äôt ever do one thing. That message was intended to do a few things at once.‚Äù

‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt help but notice your use of ‚ÄòGlory Hole‚Äô. Seemed unnecessarily antagonistic.‚Äù

She leaned against the wall by the cat‚Äôs head and smiled at me. ‚ÄúOne, I‚Äôm unnecessarily antagonistic. Two, it serves to let you know who the letter is from, it pushes you off balance if you‚Äôre in a position to be easily put off balance, which I would want to know about, and finally, three, if the messenger is the type to ignore my instructions, read the letter and try using that phrasing against you, then they‚Äôre liable to get hurt. That makes it clear I‚Äôm to be listened to. Cleat isn‚Äôt the brightest, and he could stand to learn that lesson.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you wanting to talk to me wasn‚Äôt one of your reasons?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs something else entirely. I offered Hollow Point three asks at a significant discount. Three times they can reach out to me and get info, now that they‚Äôve paid. I did this to get them into my debt, to see if they were intelligent enough to ask good questions, and to get them used to paying me money for intel. If that tide somehow rises, I want my fortunes to rise with it. You turned up, and they wanted to know, were you the first of a larger group of heroes who were going to make a move? Who were you, and what role did you play?‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd your response was this?‚Äù

‚ÄúMultiple purposes, Vicky. Keep up. If you don‚Äôt care enough you decide it‚Äôs not worth it and leave. Unlikely. You could get a little upset, and in the doing you reveal what you‚Äôre up to. Or you‚Äôre invested on some level, and you reach out, and the dialogue is opened. If the dialogue is opened, I‚Äôm better equipped to deal with you and to deal with Hollow Point. How the dialogue is opened tells me a lot, too. You could have come charging after me. You didn‚Äôt. You asked around for how to contact me, used a liaison, and you respected my direction and my rules in my part of the city.‚Äù

My part of the city, I thought. Yeah. Impressions verified — New Brockton had retained many of the problems of its predecessor.

‚ÄúCedar Point isn‚Äôt yours?‚Äù I asked.

She shrugged. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll see what it ends up being. For now, you‚Äôve got people of Cleat‚Äôs caliber there.‚Äù

‚ÄúI asked around a bit before leaving.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe construction work dried up, people are moving elsewhere. Nothing was drawing people in. Then, in the span of a few days, a large number of people buy apartments, homes, and other properties. Never mind the fact that there isn‚Äôt a lot going on there. Now a lot of supervillains are making themselves comfortable, figuring out who‚Äôll work with them and who won‚Äôt. Some places and people might be open to them doing business, others are already feeling the pressure to leave, scary people hanging around and intimidating them. People of Cleat‚Äôs caliber, maybe, but an awful lot of them.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not the only place. It‚Äôs the biggest of them,‚Äù Tattletale said. ‚ÄúAll the itinerant and teamless villains needed to settle somewhere eventually. Hollow Point is just loose enough they won‚Äôt necessarily kill each other, but self preservation keeps them together and following some basic rules. Some charisma here and there steers them.‚Äù

‚ÄúNew Brockton doesn‚Äôt count?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúDifferent thing. Hollow Point is the largest place without a major player heading things. So far. New Brockton obviously has its major players securely in place.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd even though that neighborhood isn‚Äôt yours and isn‚Äôt even close to yours, you want me gone?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúYou want you gone, if you know what‚Äôs good for you. You don‚Äôt want to get involved with that. You might make headway, but it won‚Äôt last. You‚Äôre outnumbered, they‚Äôve got better resources, and if you ever succeed to any measurable degree, they can do things like call in the second of the asks they bought from me. Then they get an answer, and you have a bad day.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù I said. I glanced back. The man standing at the edge of the plaza hadn‚Äôt budged. The brute with the bag over his head hadn‚Äôt either.

‚ÄúIf it‚Äôs not me they ask, then it‚Äôs someone else, and you potentially have an even worse day. I know you hate my guts, but the reality is I‚Äôm one of the nice ones.‚Äù

There were a lot of responses I could give to that. I bit my tongue.

I released my tongue and said, ‚ÄúHypothetically, if you don‚Äôt mind hypotheticals‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm a great fan of the hypothetical.‚Äù

‚Äú‚Ä¶If I asked you where you suggested going, if Cedar Point isn‚Äôt workable or if it‚Äôs untouchable because someone like you is going to step in before any heroes make headway‚Ä¶ what places would you suggest? Outside of the established jurisdictions for teams.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt suggest anything. It‚Äôs a wild west out there and there‚Äôs no place for you out there. Not anymore.‚Äù

I folded my arms. I‚Äôd expected an answer like this.

‚ÄúThe people who win are the people with clout. While you were teaching school kids which direction a gun should point or hauling water out to the refugees still back on Bet, the rest of us were working. I and people like me were getting our hooks in and laying groundwork to build something behind the scenes. Taking over corner worlds, finding footholds in this world, starting up businesses, establishing reputations. The big hero teams have some influence because they‚Äôve been recruiting and they staked out their territory. Hero and villain, we‚Äôre the major players, but we operate the same fundamental way. We‚Äôre scary. The thinkers, the masters, the masterminds, and the people with the biggest guns.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd Cedar Point?‚Äù

‚ÄúCedar Point, if you want to call it that, and its sister locations are late to the game. They have some clout because they have numbers and a bit of organization, and because they can all scrape together enough money to call in a big gun if they really truly need it. They probably won‚Äôt last. Someone nasty will step in and take over what they‚Äôre trying to build and it‚Äôs probably going to be ugly. The only reason they‚Äôve lasted this long is that the rest of us have bigger fish to fry. They‚Äôre still a few rungs up the totem pole above you, mind you.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs too hard so it‚Äôs not worth trying?‚Äù

‚ÄúGo home, Vicky,‚Äù she said, almost sighing the words. ‚ÄúGo back, figure out your family thing, keep trying to sign on to one of the big hero teams, you‚Äôre bound to find a position somewhere eventually. Some cape will die in battle, and a seat will open up for you and you‚Äôll do fine. Or retire. After what your sister did to you, nobody would blame you.‚Äù

I closed my eyes.

‚ÄúDo what any self-respecting twenty-one year old would do after failing to get into university, get a job waitressing or making hero sandwiches. Talk to your kids about the old Glory days.‚Äù

I opened my eyes. ‚ÄúAnd what happens to Cedar Point, in this hypothetical?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm talking reality, Vicky. It‚Äôs going to be the same thing that was going to happen before the villains turned up, and it‚Äôs the same thing that‚Äôs going to happen when and if you try and summarily fail to change things there. The area struggles, it withers, it becomes irrelevant. This isn‚Äôt your fight, and it‚Äôs not what you‚Äôre equipped to do. You hit things. You can take a bullet, unless you‚Äôre doing something peculiar like keeping your forcefield down while standing between a man with a gun and Snuff here.‚Äù

‚ÄúHeya,‚Äù Snuff said, raising a hand.

I didn‚Äôt move a muscle, didn‚Äôt react. Tattletale smiled.

‚ÄúI know what you‚Äôre doing with your forcefield, Vicky. Just like I did back then. I know why you‚Äôre doing it, too. I know you don‚Äôt belong in Cedar Point, and I know you‚Äôre just going to cause headaches for me and the actual heroes if you try anything. It‚Äôs not your skillset, it‚Äôs not your powerset.‚Äù

I still had the paper in my hand. I tapped it against my upper arm, my arms still folded. ‚ÄúFour years, and you haven‚Äôt changed a bit since you raided that bank.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen we robbed that bank, I was doing multiple things all at once, laying groundwork for moves I wouldn‚Äôt make for weeks and months. If I haven‚Äôt changed from that, I think I‚Äôm doing okay,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúAre you, though?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúYour hair is messy, and you look tired.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to pretend you‚Äôre actually asking out of a concern for my well being, because if I didn‚Äôt pretend, I‚Äôd walk away, and I might even give some free-of-charge advice to those Hollow Point ruffians, telling them how to beat you if they run into you.‚Äù

‚ÄúEntirely out of concern for your well being,‚Äù I said, with as little warmth and concern in my voice as I could muster. ‚ÄúHometown respect, you know.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm one of the major players now. The other major players call me for a hint when they‚Äôre stuck on something. I‚Äôm wealthy, well-positioned, and safe. I‚Äôm now sharing the love and bringing some of that security, stability, and safety to others, in my very, very roundabout way. It‚Äôs part of why I‚Äôm having this conversation with you.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù I said. I paused. ‚ÄúSpeaking of you showing up, I‚Äôm surprised the rest of your old team didn‚Äôt turn up too, for old time or camaraderie‚Äôs sake.‚Äù

She turned. With the way the light came through the tunnel, I could see the eye symbol on her chest in a slightly different shade of purple, hidden where the vertical bar met the horizontal, and the shadows meant I could no longer see her eyes or expression. Maintaining the same tone, she said, ‚ÄúNo, you‚Äôre not surprised. You know full well they‚Äôre well positioned too. They‚Äôre doing their own things. They‚Äôre still a resource I can and will tap.‚Äù

‚ÄúGotcha,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúBut I think you were trying to get a jab in, and that‚Äôs a good sign this conversation has run its course. I‚Äôll wish you good luck in your endeavors, whether you join a big team or end up making those sandwiches. So long as you stay out of my way.‚Äù

‚ÄúOut of curiosity,‚Äù I said. I saw her pause, just as she was about to turn to walk away. I continued, ‚ÄúDo you regret your part in what happened with my sister?‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you?‚Äù she asked, without missing a beat.

‚ÄúAbsolutely,‚Äù I said, without any more hesitation than she‚Äôd shown.

‚ÄúBe sure to call before you set foot in my neighborhood again. You and your friend have a nice flight home.‚Äù

Friend? My first thought was that she meant my autonomous forcefield, that she was personifying it.

Then I realized who she really meant. Just as surprising that she would be aware, but not as alarming.

She hadn‚Äôt answered my question, but I hadn‚Äôt expected an answer. She and Snuff walked to the parking lot, turning the corner there. Behind me, the gunman was walking back to his table.

My impression was that I was better off heading the way I‚Äôd come than I was leaving.

The moment I didn‚Äôt have the roof of the tunnel over my head, I took to the air.

I was high enough that I could see the entirety of Tattletale‚Äôs realm, and where the city was bleeding into and through the mountains and forest to connect to other areas and the remainder of the megalopolis. I could see the boats on the water, like ants on an anthill, the black smoke, and the patches that gleamed with a forced luster.

It wasn‚Äôt home. The worst of the fucking racists were gone, I had to hope, but the rest of the bad stuff seemed to be firmly entrenched in there.

I drew my phone from my pocket. I put the one earbud in, some music to drown out my thoughts while I steadied myself.

Me:
