Did you record all of that?

A dark shape flew within a foot of me. For an instant, I thought it might have been one of the small birds that had arrived with Tattletale.

It was a sphere, consisting of several layers like an onion, alternating blue and red. The lens was a white circle, and as it roved, the layers moved to accommodate it looking around. Several fins extended out from the two most external layers, moving independently of one another to correct its position and hold eerily steady in the wind.

‚ÄúRecorded it all,‚Äù the camera said, Kenzie‚Äôs voice with some synthesizer mixing things up.

‚ÄúYou got the sound, too?‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúCan I listen to it?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúNot yet. Not when Tattletale operates the way she does. I‚Äôve got a long flight back. Any way you can replay the conversation for me so I can listen to it on the way back, and figure out if anything needs redacting?‚Äù

‚ÄúWithout listening in?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd prefer if you listened in with the rest of the group. I‚Äôm concerned Tattletale can say something to me that affects one of you. She touched on some personal subjects, and I need to think about how much I‚Äôm comfortable sharing.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot a problem. Give me a minute.‚Äù

I started my flight home, the camera flying alongside me.

I expected the camera to speak, when Kenzie was ready. I was a little surprised when it came through my ear-bud instead.

‚äô

‚Äú‚Ä¶you‚Äôre bound to find a position somewhere eventually. Some cape will die in battle, and a seat will open up for you and you‚Äôll do fine. Or retire. After what your sister did to you, nobody would blame you.‚Äù

I was still, listening to this. The others, Rain excepted, were gathered around the table. The library had picnic tables and benches strewn around, and some patio chairs for reading outdoors when the weather was good. They had arranged themselves on a mixture of seats, with Ashley standing. Kenzie‚Äôs laptop was sitting on a patio table, with Rain watching in through a halting, low-res webcam.

I‚Äôd been periodically pausing the conversation, to fill in gaps with basic knowledge and context, but I left things alone for this one.

‚ÄúDo what any self-respecting twenty-one year old would do after failing to get into university, get a job waitressing or making hero sandwiches. Talk to your kids about the old Glory days.‚Äù

‚ÄúPause,‚Äù I said.

The recording paused.

‚ÄúIt took her a little while to get around to it, but it‚Äôs worth stressing that this is who she is. I thought about redacting these parts, but I think it‚Äôs important you know. The PRT thought she had the ability to sense weak points, primarily psychological ones. I agree with that assessment.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour sister is Panacea, right?‚Äù Chris asked.

I tensed a bit.

‚ÄúChris,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI think Victoria would prefer it if we glossed over that part.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs for context. Like she just said, it stresses who Tattletale is.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe was a healer,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúTattletale‚Äôs words caught her in a bad way at a bad time. Two months later, she had a mental breakdown. In part because of what Tattletale said. She put me in the hospital. Let‚Äôs leave it at that.‚Äù

‚ÄúResume recording,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúAnd what happens to Cedar Point, in this hypothetical?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm talking reality, Vicky. It‚Äôs going to be the same thing that was going to happen before the villains turned up, and it‚Äôs the same thing that‚Äôs going to happen when and if you try and summarily fail to change things there.‚Äù

‚ÄúPause,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúShe likes to act like she knows what‚Äôs going to happen, but it‚Äôs worth saying she can be surprised. She was surprised at the bank. She and her team pulled it off regardless, but‚Ä¶ she was surprised by my arrival, and by my sister being there.‚Äù

‚ÄúWorth keeping in mind,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúIf we wind up fighting her.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm giving you all the info I can, so you can make an informed decision,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúResume.‚Äù

‚Äú-The area struggles, it withers, it becomes irrelevant. This isn‚Äôt your fight, and it‚Äôs not what you‚Äôre equipped to do. You hit things. You—‚Äù

Kenzie‚Äôs voice chimed in with a cheerful, synthesized, ‚ÄúRedacted!‚Äù

‚ÄúPause. Redacted because it‚Äôs a weak point,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúPower-related.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think I know,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúIf this makes you doubt Victoria at all, I hope me vouching for her helps.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt helps,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúNot that I was doubting her.‚Äù

‚ÄúResume,‚Äù I said.

‚Äú-I know you don‚Äôt belong in Cedar Point, and I know you‚Äôre just going to cause headaches for me and the actual heroes if you try anything. It‚Äôs not your skillset, it‚Äôs not your powerset.‚Äù

There was a small chime as a message appeared in the corner of the laptop. The recording paused in response to the message appearing.

Rain: Is it ours?

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a conversation I want to have shortly,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúPowers.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking forward to this,‚Äù Chris said.

Behind him, pacing a little, Ashley smiled.

Right.

‚ÄúResume,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúRedacted, redacted,‚Äù Kenzie‚Äôs synthesized voice played. Then Tattletale‚Äôs voice came up again. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm one of the major players now. The other major players call me for a hint when they‚Äôre stuck on something. I‚Äôm wealthy, well-positioned, and safe. I‚Äôm now sharing the love and bringing some of that security, stability, and safety to others, in my very, very roundabout way. It‚Äôs part of why I‚Äôm having this conversation with you.‚Äù

‚ÄúStop,‚Äù I said. The recording paused, and Kenzie hit a keyboard shortcut to close the window. ‚ÄúEverything that followed was small talk, some threats from her, and stuff about my sister I don‚Äôt want to get into. That‚Äôs Tattletale. That‚Äôs how she sees the world. I do believe her when she says there‚Äôs no good way to break into this scene. There are a lot of people who want to hold their positions and the power they‚Äôve taken for themselves, and when you‚Äôve cornered them, they‚Äôre going to call people like Tattletale for backup.‚Äù

‚ÄúOr worse,‚Äù Ashley said. That was apparently what she‚Äôd fixated on, during the earlier part of the conversation.

‚ÄúOr worse. People who are good at the roles they‚Äôve taken on, well-proven by years of experience, people who can and will casually destroy you.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo matter what we do,‚Äù Sveta said, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to run into trouble. So we do nothing or we plan for it.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe plan for it,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúAshley and I were talking about this. Something that might fit our niche, and gives key members of our team what they‚Äôre looking for.‚Äù

He looked at Kenzie as he said the last bit, and Kenzie visibly perked up.

‚ÄúYou have a game plan?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúThe start of one,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúMaybe.‚Äù

I thought about that for a moment. The others exchanged a few words, and a chime signaled Rain‚Äôs comment for the convo — he and Tristan had apparently exchanged some messages about the plan.

‚ÄúDid you guys bring costume stuff?‚Äù I asked, when there was an opening. ‚ÄúThose of you that have it?‚Äù

That got me confirmation from about half of the group.

‚ÄúI have spare, basic masks for those that need them,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI also have the start of my team outline written up on my laptop. What do you guys say we move to an area with some elbow room, you can show me enough of your powers that I know what to put in the document, and we talk about what you‚Äôve got in mind?‚Äù

It might as well have been a rhetorical question. None of them were about to say no to that.

Glare — 3.2

‚ÄúHey, Victoria, you‚Äôre strong right?‚Äù Kenzie asked.

‚ÄúKind of,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd be worried about breaking whatever it is I‚Äôm handling.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs pretty durable.‚Äù

I thought about my forcefield. ‚ÄúI totaled the last car I lifted.‚Äù

‚ÄúI brought things, and I thought maybe Chris could lift some or Tristan could, but Tristan doesn‚Äôt think he‚Äôs strong enough and Chris doesn‚Äôt want to.‚Äù

She turned stick out her tongue at Chris.

‚ÄúLimited duration,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúI can take a look, where is this?‚Äù I asked Kenzie.

‚ÄúAt the street. Black van. I‚Äôll show you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, that‚Äôd help. I‚Äôll probably have questions.‚Äù

I turned to the others, pointing at the treeline. ‚ÄúIf you guys want to head over that way, stop at the rocky outcropping on the hill. We‚Äôll meet you there.‚Äù

Kenzie walked with me. She was wearing black overalls and a pink tank top, a red apple clip in her hair, and red sneakers. Her hair was in much the same style as before, but the buns were set higher.

I paid more attention to her fashion choice because so much about it seemed deliberate, from color scheme to running theme. During the last meeting it had been a star on her dress, partially on her shirt, and in her hair.

‚ÄúMy dad gave me a ride today, because he needs to buy a suit and more work clothes,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúPlease don‚Äôt judge me too harshly if he acts really lame.‚Äù

‚ÄúI won‚Äôt,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúYou said Tristan and Chris could have helped. Tristan has increased strength?‚Äù

‚ÄúJust a little. Very very little.‚Äù

‚ÄúI guess we‚Äôll find out soon.‚Äù

‚ÄúSveta could have helped too, we think, she‚Äôs really strong if she uses her real body, but it would have meant dragging it and that would have hurt the grass.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow big is this thing?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll show you,‚Äù she said. She sprinted the last little way to the sleek van that was parked on the street in front of the library, hopping up to the passenger side window, clinging to the bottom edge of the open window so she could stick her head in. The back door of the van popped open, and Kenzie‚Äôs father stepped out, walking around the van to the sidewalk.

He was almost as meticulous in appearance as Kenzie. He was very lean, with pronounced cheekbones and a long face that was made to look longer by the goatee that extended an inch from his chin. He wore a short-sleeved work shirt with a pinstripe pattern on it, and slim jeans that looked like they had cost a pretty penny. Shoes, belt, and watch, all expensive-looking.

The beard and his longer hair weren‚Äôt as tidy as Kenzie was, but I was hardly about to judge, given how it was probably a day off for him and he was sitting in the sun.

‚ÄúDad, this is Victoria. She‚Äôs the coach I was talking about. Victoria, this is my dad.‚Äù

‚ÄúHi, Mr‚Ä¶‚Äù I extended a hand.

‚ÄúJulien Martin,‚Äù he said. He shook my hand. Both handshake and his tone were stiff, but it was a different kind of stiffness than I was used to seeing in Dean‚Äôs family. I was well aware of how easily I‚Äôd slotted him onto that same mental shelf.

‚ÄúYou can call him Julien,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúNice to meet you. What do you do?‚Äù

‚ÄúRealty.‚Äù

‚ÄúDad only got into realty a year and a half ago, but he‚Äôs really good at both the buying and selling sides of things. I don‚Äôt really get it all, but his boss seemed pretty happy with him. You got a promotion, right?‚Äù

‚ÄúI did.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs doing it ethically, too, which is so important, with so many shady people out there.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm trying,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúI can respect that,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThanks for bringing Kenzie out this far, and for bringing her stuff.‚Äù

Kenzie rolled her eyes. ‚ÄúWe should go take a look so we don‚Äôt keep the others waiting.‚Äù

Julien followed us around to the back of the van, standing back while we opened the doors. A black box that was a bit larger than a washing machine was sitting in there, strapped down ten ways from Sunday, to keep it from sliding around when the vehicle moved. More boxes were sitting at either side of the van, with straps to keep them flush against the wall, but they weren‚Äôt any larger than a backpack or suitcase.

‚ÄúWe got the van because some of my stuff is hard to move,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said. The box had a metal frame around the edges, with a crossbar running diagonally along each face. ‚ÄúWhat do I need to know?‚Äù

‚ÄúPick it up and move it.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs tinkertech, right?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt is.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs there a chance of a misfire if it‚Äôs moved in the wrong way, if something‚Äôs crushed or broken?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúWill I hurt anything if it‚Äôs turned on its side?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúHm. It‚Äôs best if you don‚Äôt turn it upside down.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhere should I grab it, to best carry it?‚Äù

‚ÄúGeeez,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not going to blow up or anything. Or if it did, it wouldn‚Äôt be a big enough explosion to hurt anyone. Not unless very specific conditions were met.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù I said. I had an issue with my power, where I wasn‚Äôt sure I trusted the forcefield to simply hold the box and not crush or dig into it. It was only about a minute of flying to get to where I wanted to go, but even if everything went according to plan, I was worried that handling the box for more than a couple of seconds would leave handprints or gouges in it.

While I investigated, Kenzie climbed in beside me, peering at the box and watching me.

‚ÄúGive me some space?‚Äù I asked.

Kenzie grabbed some smaller things on her way out.

It took a few minutes, but I unclipped the straps that were securing the box in place, and laid them across the ground. I lifted the box, and set it down on the straps. I connected them, wrapping them around the box, then slid it around so I could reach the ones at the back. There was a ramp built into the truck, and I could see where the box could slide along the tracks, but it seemed like more of a hassle to use the ramp and unload that way.

‚ÄúHow dangerous is this team business going to be?‚Äù Julien asked, behind me.

‚ÄúDad,‚Äù Kenzie protested. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt embarrass me.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf I thought it was going to be a serious danger, I wouldn‚Äôt be helping,‚Äù I said, still working on the straps. ‚ÄúBut I can‚Äôt guarantee anything.‚Äù

I fastened the straps, then hauled the entire thing out, forcefield up, gripping the box. It thudded against the street. Dense.

‚ÄúIs it a problem?‚Äù I asked Julien.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a problem,‚Äù Kenzie said, firm. ‚ÄúI can handle myself. I‚Äôve trained more than a lot of heroes, because I did a year going to all the practice events and stuff.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm more interested in what your dad has to say. I don‚Äôt want to step on toes, and your parents get the last word.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine,‚Äù Julien said. ‚ÄúIf it wasn‚Äôt this, she would be doing something else. I prefer this team idea.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou should,‚Äù Kenzie huffed.

‚ÄúDo you need to be picked up?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, please. In‚Ä¶?‚Äù Kenzie looked at me.

‚ÄúTwo hours?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúIs that okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine,‚Äù her dad said. He still had that tone, which came across curt, inflexible. I had a hard time imagining him as a salesman. Accountant, maybe.

‚ÄúBefore you do anything, can you go to the train station? Rain had to take the train and he‚Äôs running late. Bring him here?‚Äù Kenzie asked.

Her dad frowned.

‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúWhere am I going?‚Äù he asked.

‚ÄúGive me your phone, I‚Äôll put it in there.‚Äù

While they fussed, I checked and fixed the remainder of the straps.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll be right back,‚Äù I said.

The straps served to let me hold the box without actually holding it. I flew, holding the length of straps that I‚Äôd wound together and attached at the tail end. The box made for unwieldy flying, swinging below me.

Could the forcefield potentially claw through them? Yes. I hoped I‚Äôd be able to see it before it managed to succeed.

I flew in the direction I‚Äôd sent the others, leaving Kenzie behind.

My phantom self gripped the length of straps, scratched, squeezed, and twisted it, periodically making the ten foot length of cords bend in unusual shapes.

I hadn‚Äôt interacted with it much. I hadn‚Äôt seen the limits of its intelligence or lack thereof. This one minute of flying might have even been the longest period I‚Äôd properly used my strength in two years.

I sighted the others, sitting on the rocks and talking. I dropped low, and I set the box down on the ground. Even with the care I was taking, it made a noise on landing.

‚ÄúWow,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúHow heavy is that thing?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo idea,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIf I had to guess, maybe three hundred and fifty pounds?‚Äù

‚ÄúI can see why she has a hard time moving those things around.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe described them as being bigger,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúOthers, I think. I think they start at that size and get larger.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid her dad leave?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúNot yet,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre figuring out logistics. He‚Äôs going to go pick up Rain at the station. Be right back.‚Äù

I flew over to where Kenzie and her dad were. Kenzie‚Äôs dad was in the driver‚Äôs seat, and Kenzie was closing the rear doors. A series of bags and boxes were unloaded, all packed together.

As I landed, her dad pulled away. Kenzie raised a hand in a wave.

I was aware of the lack of a wave in response. From the way she lowered her hand and glanced at me, Kenzie was too.

‚ÄúWant to fly over?‚Äù I asked.

Her eyes lit up with excitement as she nodded.

There were very few people in the world who didn‚Äôt like flying.

It was, in a way, almost as much of a pain to bring Kenzie, two cases and two boxes without my strength active, as it had been to move the one cube. I ended up lifting her by the straps at the back of her overalls, my hand also wrapped around the strap of one bag, while Kenzie held other things.

We arrived at the hill with the rocks. There was light overgrowth, a fairly loose distribution of trees for the fact that it was untamed wilderness, and thick grass. A surveying team had passed through at one point, and they had disturbed earth here and there, felled a few trees, and spray painted the face of one of the larger rocks before leaving.

A bit of a shame, but I could understand the need for a quick and easy label. No minerals or stone of any particular value here.

Chris, wearing his headphones again, was wearing what looked like the same shorts as he had worn at the meeting, and a different t-shirt. He was examining the box, while keeping at least two feet away from it at all times. He had a bag with him, a travelers‚Äô backpack that was packed full, but he‚Äôd put it down.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to keep your distance,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not dangerous.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs tinkertech. It‚Äôs science that gets at least some of its functionality from interdimensional fuckery, built by cooperation between you and the unfathomable, menacing thing that chose you as its host.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a camera, Chris. It records and projects.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a camera built with collaboration between you and a unknowable, violence-driven multiversal horror.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy multiversal horror is pretty tame, I think. She just likes to build things and gather information,‚Äù Kenzie pressed buttons on the side of the box. A triangle between reinforcing bars lit up.

A hologram appeared a number of feet away. A potbellied rat with a crooked nose.

‚Äú‚Ä¶And you‚Äôre using it to make cartoons,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúPlump Rat King,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúSome of the kids at the hospital liked that one.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúOnly the first season was really any good.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs it good for?‚Äù Ashley asked. She was taking things a step further than Chris‚Äô wearing of the same shorts. She wore the same dress she had worn at the meeting, the damage at the corner mended imperfectly. One of the straps, I realized, had been damaged and patched, but her hair masked much of it. She had a black mask in her hand, but she hadn‚Äôt put it on.

‚ÄúStuff. Loads of stuff. I‚Äôll show you some later,‚Äù Kenzie said. She started opening boxes.

Tristan, much like Kenzie, was unpacking a bag. His costume was armor. It struck a balance between function and appearance, but it looked like it was a pretty good quality. Each segment was framed with goat‚Äôs heads and horns, spirals and ridges. Where it wasn‚Äôt brushed metal, things were painted or tinted red or light red. He saw me looking and smiled.

‚ÄúByron is the fish theme, then?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúWater as much as fish. Yeah,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúYou have some kind of superstrength, right?‚Äù

‚ÄúA very small amount. Helps when you‚Äôre wearing armor as heavy as this, or when you‚Äôre using a power that can make heavy things.‚Äù

‚ÄúSeems like a good place to get us started,‚Äù I said.

Tristan turned around, seating himself firmly on the sloped ground, his armor partially unpacked and arranged beside him. Some bits were already fastened into place on his arms and legs, over a bodysuit that seemed designed to go between him and his armor.

He held up his hand, and produced three motes of orange-red light. As each one moved through the air, it left a trail behind it, like the afterimage of a sparkler waved through the darkness. They traced a circle and as the moving points of light connected to the end of each trail, a shape came to life. A discus, with a slight peak on one side.

I extended a hand, and he passed it to me.

Dense, heavy, very solid. Matter creation.

‚ÄúYou can throw it,‚Äù he said.

I threw it. It wasn‚Äôt as aerodynamic as a frisbee, but it did catch the air. It wobbled mid-flight and veered off course, crashing into a tree before disappearing into a patch of grass.

Tristan was already making something else. Twelve or more motes of light traced the shape. ‚ÄúRequires a bit of concentration, I can rush it or force it to come into being early, but you get weirdness like‚Ä¶ this.‚Äù

It materialized. A hammer or a mace, long-handled. The weirdness was in how the shape finalized its form, drawing pretty creative curves and hooks. Spikes, horns, thorns, and other slightly curved growths stood out. It looked unbalanced.

‚ÄúAre they permanent?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúThey can be. Depends if I keep the sparks alive or not. I can create a lot of sparks, but it requires more time, more concentration.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the difference between keeping it alive or not?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù he said. He pushed himself to his feet, shifting his footing to make sure he wouldn‚Äôt slide down the hill. He held out the mace, and started to form the motes for another. He rushed this one even more than he had the last. The shape was more unwieldy, less balanced. ‚ÄúByron, you want to help with demonstrations today, or do you want to be left alone?‚Äù

Tristan blurred, features distorting, his eyes flaring with the same light as the sparks had. The light turned blue, and then he was Byron, wearing a hooded sweatshirt and jeans.

One of the two maces exploded into a spray of water. Sveta made a noise of surprise, and Chris, still mostly fixated on examining Kenzie‚Äôs cube, jumped back from the cube in surprise.

Byron turned his head so the backspray hit him in the side of the face, rather than right in the center of it. He dropped the still-intact mace he held with his other hand.

‚ÄúHi Byron,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù I added my greeting to Kenzie‚Äôs. ‚ÄúWe haven‚Äôt formally met.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe haven‚Äôt. I got the basics,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúSo I gathered.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis is a terrible idea,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúTristan being involved, this team concept, the potential for disaster, and this thing with Tattletale?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see anyone changing their mind. Mrs. Yamada couldn‚Äôt convince them, I don‚Äôt think I can. If they‚Äôre going to do this or something like this, isn‚Äôt it better that they do it smart and informed?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut if you‚Äôre enabling them, you should know you own a share of what happens.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs fair,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúIt might be fair,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúMy voice doesn‚Äôt matter either. I tried, nobody listens. Maybe I own a bit of what happens for not trying harder to stop Tristan from going forward with this.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou sound pretty certain something bad is going to happen.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was there for all the therapy sessions, even if I didn‚Äôt participate,‚Äù he said. He looked at the others. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry, I‚Äôm not going to say anything. But I am going to say, again, this is a trainwreck waiting to happen.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe got it,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúSaying it over and over doesn‚Äôt change anything.‚Äù

‚ÄúBe kind, Chris,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot playing into Byron‚Äôs concerns.‚Äù

Byron shook his head. He glanced at me.

‚ÄúYou need anything, while we‚Äôre talking?‚Äù I asked.

He shook his head. ‚ÄúNo. Um. You seem alright, so‚Ä¶ be safe. Be wary. And for the record, since you‚Äôre going to ask‚Ä¶‚Äù

He showed me his power. Motes of light, like Tristan‚Äôs, blue. He drew them in the air, two expanding, abstract shapes, not closed like Tristan‚Äôs had been. He positioned them so there was one on either side of him, then clenched his fist. The lines that were drawn became water, buckets worth, spraying out in the direction the lines had been drawn. He had drawn them out as expanding spirals, and the resulting water flew out in circular sprays.

‚ÄúYou can use me if you need to clean up, Tristan,‚Äù Byron said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll do the quick swaps if you need them.‚Äù

The water was still spraying when Byron blurred, features distorting and smearing together, the two lighted eyes peering through the shadows between folds and smears, going from blue to orange-red.

One of the sprays of water lost all of its oomph, the remaining water striking the ground to flow through grass and between rocks. The other diagram became a solid object, a wheel spikier and cruder than what Tristan had made. It hit the ground and stuck there.

The water that Byron‚Äôs power had produced rained down on us for several seconds.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not going to hurt the box?‚Äù Chris asked.

‚ÄúNope,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúWaterproofed just in case Byron visited. It was good to see you, Byron, by the way. I hope to prove you wrong.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a good way of putting it, Kenzie.‚Äù

Tristan‚Äôs face was at an angle that saw him looking down at the ground. At first I thought he was trying to keep the water out of his face. Then, as he changed the angle of his head a little, I saw his face.

‚ÄúFor the record,‚Äù Tristan said, ‚ÄúIf it‚Äôs my two hours and I ask you a question and then pass the baton, I‚Äôd really appreciate it if you didn‚Äôt take up extra time and use it to try and sabotage me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI did say hi to him,‚Äù I said.

Tristan shrugged. ‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt have to say all that. He‚Äôs quick to say there‚Äôs a problem but he doesn‚Äôt suggest alternatives. He whines about the circumstances but he won‚Äôt attend the therapy and he doesn‚Äôt want to work on figuring out better courses of action. It pisses me off sometimes, especially when he elbows into my time to make what I‚Äôm trying to accomplish harder.‚Äù

His tone was hard. Pissed off seemed like an apt description. I‚Äôd seen Tristan, casual and smiling some before he‚Äôd changed, and now this felt like a complete, sudden shift.

It was easy to forget that he was in there while Byron was out here, feeling things, thinking, his mood changing during that short conversation.

I could see the expressions of others. The sympathy on Sveta‚Äôs face, the tilt of Chris‚Äô head.

Ashley looked especially focused and attentive, her pacing around the hill having come to a stop. One of her hands was at her hair, pushing it back out of her face, the water helping it stay there.

‚ÄúIt seems like hard feelings are inevitable,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Tristan said. He looked away. ‚ÄúI can keep my shapes ‚Äòalive‚Äô. If they‚Äôre still alive when I change, they become water. If they aren‚Äôt, they‚Äôre there to stay. Same for Byron‚Äôs water. It‚Äôs effective if he makes water, sloshes it over someone, and then changes, to make it solid. We‚Äôve tagged a good dozen villains that way.‚Äù

‚ÄúA dozen is a really good number for a teenage hero.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre pretty lucky, getting a name that fitting for a power like that.‚Äù

‚ÄúConstellations forming rock and water?‚Äù Tristan asked. He snorted air through his nostrils. ‚ÄúWant to know the hilarious thing?‚Äù

‚ÄúI do,‚Äù I said. I wasn‚Äôt sure whatever he was going to say was ‚Äòhilarious‚Äô, given his tone, but I‚Äôd hoped today would be a lighter endeavor, and any humor would help.

‚ÄúWe weren‚Äôt even rock and water, originally. Reach bought the name from the last Capricorn. She got wounded in battle and she retired. Win-win. We got settled into the role, got our name, our armor, our brand, and‚Ä¶ power changed to match.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs really interesting,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of potential there.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere is. Absolutely. And not all of it‚Äôs good,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúBut some of it is,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúSome of it is, yeah,‚Äù Tristan said. He offered her a small smile.

I could see the concerted effort he was making to pull out of the funk. A few words from his brother and he was upset enough that it showed in his tone and the direction of what he was talking about.

Tricky, that kind of negativity sitting just under the surface.

‚ÄúSveta,‚Äù I said. Change of topic. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm guessing you‚Äôve worked on control enough that you feel okay letting loose in limited ways?‚Äù

‚ÄúKind of,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to go all-out in a combat situation. I don‚Äôt want to do anything that would risk people getting hurt.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI figured I would mostly stay in the suit. I can do this‚Ä¶‚Äù

She didn‚Äôt touch or move anything external, but the joints of her elbow shifted, and the forearm and hand dropped. Ten or so tendrils extended between elbow and forearm, like a muscle with gaps between strands.

She moved it, tendrils bending, flinging her hand and the attached segment of arm out fifty feet. She tried to grab a branch, missed it, grabbed another, and seized it, before pulling her body to follow. I saw her turn her head away as she pulled herself through the intervening twigs and leaves.

She twisted around, pointed a hand, and used tendrils to push her fist out.

She seized the wheel that Byron had left embedded in the earth, and pulled herself to it.

There was a bit of gracelessness to the landing, her pants leg and the side of her body rubbing against the grass, a few clumps of earth flying, but it served to put her in our midst again. She wobbled as she stood and Tristan and I caught her between us.

She made a small ‚Äòphew‚Äô sound.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre made of grappling hooks, basically,‚Äù Chris said. Kenzie, sitting on her box, stuck out her toe to jab Chris in the shoulder.

‚ÄúI can get things for my body. Weld and I were talking about getting a second body for cape things. If I had hooks I could unfold I could more reliably grab things. And I‚Äôll get better with practice,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúAnd I really want extra shielding for my joints because they‚Äôre the easiest part to break, and I don‚Äôt want to have to send it out to be repaired and be unable to walk or do things in the meantime.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat happens if the suit gets broken?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúAs in broken enough that it doesn‚Äôt keep you contained?‚Äù

‚ÄúUm. I have a collapsed hamster ball in here. I can spit it out, unfold it, shove myself in there and bring the lid behind me. It‚Äôs a bit cramped, it‚Äôs not the biggest, and it might not always work, but I‚Äôve also been working hard at keeping myself under control.‚Äù

I suppressed a wince. Sveta had worked hard for as long as I‚Äôd known her, and I knew that the anxiety was tied into the lack of control in a feedback loop, and that her being so much more confident and happy would mean she had more control, but all it took was one bad incident.

‚ÄúWorkable,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôd have to be really, really careful.‚Äù

‚ÄúAbsolutely,‚Äù she said, with dead seriousness. ‚ÄúThe way I see it, my body is pretty hardy. To break containment, it would take something that would maim an ordinary person.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. But if they think you‚Äôre durable, they might not hold back.

We‚Äôd address that when it came to it.

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúSo, my line of thinking was that instead of explaining, we‚Äôd do a little bit of a team exercise.‚Äù

I heard a faint groan from Chris.

‚ÄúIt should be fun, and it should be relatively low-key,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúWe split everyone into teams of three, and we play a small game of capture the flag, here.‚Äù

‚ÄúSee, that‚Äôs playing dirty,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre playing into my love for competition, here.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fun,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúI really like this.‚Äù

It seemed Kenzie could be counted on to be positive. I said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm hoping it‚Äôs fun. Does anyone else need to explain their powers or cover anything before we get into it? I know what Ashley can do, unless something‚Äôs changed.‚Äù

Ashley shook her head.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll see you in action when we have our competition, then. That leaves Chris and Kenzie, kind of.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got some things,‚Äù Kenzie said. She opened a case. ‚ÄúTwo of these things I had as just-in-case things when I was a Ward. I got them fixed up recently, and I even made an improvement. Eye hook—‚Äù

She pulled out a coil of metal. She stuck it on the corner of her cube, then held her phone in one hand, moving her thumb around. The coil unfurled, prehensile, and its tip unfolded from its teardrop shape. Three claws, extending from around a circular lens with a pupil. Kenzie moved her head and body in time with the movements of the thing.

The thing moved closer to me, until it was two feet from my face, the three claw-blades opening and closing a little. It blinked at me, shutter closing momentarily.

‚ÄúIt was made to look through vents, to start with. it‚Äôs delicate enough it can turn screws and drill holes, and I can swap out the lens for others. And I‚Äôve got this flash gun too.‚Äù

She held up something that looked like a child‚Äôs toy, squat, blunt, with a lens on the front.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs for when I had to get closer to the scene when I was with the Baltimore Wards. They wanted me to be able to protect myself and they wanted nonlethal.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat does it do?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúMakes light,‚Äù she said. She aimed it off to the side and pulled the trigger.

It looked and sounded like a camera flash going off.

‚ÄúAnd the other stuff?‚Äù

‚ÄúMask with a few settings,‚Äù Kenzie said. She pulled out a high-tech mask, metal around the edges to give a general circular shape to the clear pane for her face, but she didn‚Äôt put it on. She held up a disc, then clipped it to the front of her overalls, so it was directly over the pocket at her chest. ‚ÄúThis is kind of a costume thing I haven‚Äôt finalized.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúGreat.‚Äù

‚ÄúI transform,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúChanger.‚Äù

I made a motion for him to continue.

He sounded aggrieved, like it was my fault he had to explain at all, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what else you want. I have a few different forms. They‚Äôre inspired by my moods and mental states.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou give them names based on what mood or state they‚Äôre from,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúLike Creeping Anxiety and Wistful Distraction.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúLook, the rest of you know. Explain. I‚Äôm going to go change.‚Äù

He grabbed his bag and hefted it over one shoulder, then began trudging uphill.

‚ÄúThese forms reflect the feelings?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúVery much so,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúIt sounds like he has more than a few forms,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúEight or more, as far as I‚Äôve counted,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúHe said a few, but I think he loses track. There‚Äôs wiggle room in each form, too. It depends on a lot of factors. Diet, time since he last used a form, if he pushes for something in the middle.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs strong,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúHe might be,‚Äù Tristan said.

Kenzie continued to volunteer information. ‚ÄúThe forms tend to come with pretty heavy weakness. Anxiety is quick but fragile. That sort of thing.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think I get it,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúCan I ask why he‚Äôs in the group?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe drawbacks,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúThe fragility isn‚Äôt a drawback?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs one. He doesn‚Äôt change all the way back.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù I asked.

Tristan explained, ‚ÄúHe changes to one, he gets a little taller, a little stronger, a little more sluggish. He changes to another, gets better eyes, ears‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúThus the headphones,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚Äú‚Ä¶and less responsive in hand-eye coordination to go with it. He tries to balance, but lately it‚Äôs been getting worse.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat happens if he doesn‚Äôt change?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe body stays the same,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt change physically.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhich is good.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut he doesn‚Äôt change mentally either. He says he can‚Äôt tap those emotions he‚Äôs not using, he can‚Äôt think as clearly, his thoughts go in circles.‚Äù

‚ÄúLose-lose,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúSomething like that,‚Äù Ashley said.

I could hear Chris‚Äô approach, now. The sound of branches breaking underfoot, the rustling of under— and over-growth.

He‚Äôd grown. He‚Äôd shucked off his clothes and he‚Äôd donned what looked like an oversized pair of shorts in a coarse cloth. They had to have taken up most of the bag‚Äôs space. He was twelve feet tall, with skewed proportions. Large legs, large around the middle, large hands, all with coarse hair. His shoulders seemed somewhat narrow, his neck long, his head only a little larger than normal, with faintly pronounced tusks. His hair, wild before, was just a bit longer than it had been.

‚ÄúHe chose one of the more pleasant looking forms,‚Äù Kenzie said, cheerful. She grabbed her stuff.

How in the fuck was I supposed to make someone like Chris marketable? How was I supposed to wrangle Ashley or handle Tristan‚Äôs issue?

‚ÄúTwenty minutes,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúThen he changes back. We should hurry.‚Äù

Capture the flag. Right. A part of me wished I hadn‚Äôt brought it up. I could have left things at this, with powers explained and demonstrated in brief, and then I could have taken a few days to think.

I needed a few days to think, so feelings wouldn‚Äôt be hurt, damage wouldn‚Äôt be done.

I didn‚Äôt have it. I‚Äôd lose too much stock with these guys if I changed my mind. Chris and Ashley especially.

‚ÄúWho wants to be team leaders?‚Äù I asked.

Tristan raised one hand. Ashley raised another.

‚ÄúAshley, you want to pick first?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúKenzie.‚Äù

‚ÄúWoo!‚Äù Kenzie cheered.

‚ÄúSveta,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôd be my second pick, after Rain. Weld fan club.‚Äù

‚ÄúChris,‚Äù Ashley said. She pulled on her mask. It was v-shaped, covering the nose, ears, and eyes, leaving just a hint of her eyebrows visible above.

‚ÄúYou guys set up over there, opposite side of the hill, then,‚Äù I said. Ashley and the two youngest members of the team.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre filling in for Rain?‚Äù Tristan asked me.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm mostly interested in seeing how you guys operate, so I‚Äôll mostly stick to playing defense and keeping an eye on things.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright. I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôll be a problem,‚Äù he said.

I wasn‚Äôt so sure. I could see the way he set his jaw, before he pulled his horned helmet on. I had an idea of his disposition already. I could see the look of Ashley‚Äôs eyes behind her mask, too. She wanted to be leader, by the looks of things, and that meant she had something to prove. I saw Chris as the giant, properly smiling for the first time since I‚Äôd met him, as he looked back over one shoulder, lumbering away. It made me more concerned, rather than less.

Sveta took my hand, squeezing it. Off to the side, Tristan was drawing something out of motes of light, ten feet tall and twenty feet wide. A wall.

I‚Äôd wanted to test them, to see how they functioned as discrete units, and possibly to highlight difficulties.

The more I saw, the less sure I was that these guys were equipped to handle even a friendly contest. There were so many messy parts to this. Above all else, the ones with the power seemed least suited to wield it.

‚ÄúBelieve in us,‚Äù Sveta said, her voice soft.

I wanted to. I really did.

‚ÄúI think,‚Äù I said, and I said it to Tristan, ‚ÄúYou should take this opportunity to explain your game plan.‚Äù

Glare — 3.3

‚ÄúYou want a game plan?‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúDo you mean for here or for the big picture?‚Äù

I was thinking big picture, I thought, I have doubts right now and a plan would help.

Without voicing that, I said, ‚ÄúHere, but I‚Äôm open to hearing about either. If you have something in mind.‚Äù

‚ÄúI want to wait on the big picture stuff so we can include Rain into the discussion. He and I chat regularly, and he‚Äôs heard some, but Ashley and I were talking while we waited for you and there‚Äôs bits to discuss. Comfort levels.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll focus on this for now.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm in charge, then?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúIf Sveta is okay with it, you can give it a shot.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm okay with it,‚Äù Sveta said.

He made a small amused sound, his face obscured by his helmet, his hands busy adjusting the fit of his armor as he paced. ‚ÄúThere was a time I thought I might end up being in charge of Reach. Things fell through before then. I don‚Äôt know if my current mindset works for it, but let‚Äôs give this a try.‚Äù

I had my own bag, which I‚Äôd brought with me. My computer, masks, and the flags, one red and one blue. I fished out the flags, holding both in one hand, and put on one of the masks.

‚ÄúVictoria, you and I are on defense, then,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAshley is going to go hard offense, that‚Äôs who she is, and I don‚Äôt see Chris holding back. Sveta, you‚Äôre going on the attack. You loop around, go the long way if you have to. You might have to dodge Kenzie, but I think you can manage that okay. It‚Äôs only her hook thing and flash gun.‚Äù

‚ÄúSounds like a plan,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI think the benefit here is that we all have some experience,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúKind of,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre young. Ashley too, in a weird way. They‚Äôre led by Ashley and we know how she thinks. I can put my confidence in you, Sveta, if you‚Äôre going for their flag.‚Äù

‚ÄúI hope I deserve it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm confident in myself and my ability to hold up against a two-person rush, assuming that‚Äôs what they do, and I know you‚Äôve got a background, Victoria.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah. Confidence goes before the fall, though. I think one of the things I regret most in the past is my overconfidence.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis is just an exercise. If I‚Äôm wrong on this, I‚Äôll own it. Let me plant our flag and get my stuff to adjust my armor, I‚Äôll be right with you.‚Äù

As he said it, another wall materialized behind us. A fort with ten foot walls was slowly forming. Tristan wasn‚Äôt even focusing that much on the construction, attention-wise. He took the flag before walking off.

I had intentionally chosen a less level area. We were on a hill, playing on a bit of a slope, roughly a ten degree decline with taller grass, weeds, and some pebbly dirt covering the area. Some trees and rocks dotted the space between where their group would set up and where we would.

I had a few reasons for choosing the area. Part of it played off something I had experienced with New Wave. The team had always been split between the fliers and the people on the ground. Me, Aunt Sarah, Crystal and Eric had all been airborne, while my Uncle Neil, Mom, and Dad had all been landbound. It created a dilemma in logistics, and this slightly sloped ground and uneven terrain emphasized that logistics in a way that having to go through and around buildings might in the city.

Sveta functionally had a mover ability, I wasn‚Äôt sure about Chris‚Äô capabilities, and Damsel and Rain both had some capabilities in that realm. Supposedly. I wanted to see how the more mobile members of the group worked in coordination with the others.

It was interesting that Tristan had picked both Sveta and me. We were both mobile and Tristan wasn‚Äôt. Ashley‚Äôs team had three people on foot.

Another reason for this particular location was Rain‚Äôs power. It helped him keep his balance, and that was supposedly the extent of it. When he arrived, I wanted to see if it factored in here.

Finally, there was the fact that it put us out of the way. No bystanders, no property to damage.

Kenzie had her head down, her attention on her phone. Ashley and Chris were both smiling. All three were talking. I waited a short bit for them to finish.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm so unbelievably nervous,‚Äù Sveta said.

I glanced at her, and confirmed that Tristan had stepped away, rummaging in his bag. He was out of earshot.

‚ÄúI definitely hear you on that,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI really want this exercise to work somehow, like Tristan said, but for different reasons. The way you were brought in, you might have come in looking for the bad, and it‚Äôs‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs not all bad. Really. I always wanted a team and the idea of finding one and fitting myself to that team with all of my problems, it seemed impossible or far away.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúYou talked about it in the hospital. That you‚Äôd talked to Mrs. Yamada and other people about how, putting aside all your issues, you wanted to be a hero.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd I wanted a boyfriend, and I wanted to be functional again, and I wanted friends,‚Äù she said, staring off at the other three. ‚ÄúAnd I have almost all of it, but I feel like it could slip out of my grasp if things go wrong. If this goes wrong. I don‚Äôt know what I can do if that happens. I‚Äôm worried this is going to be a disaster, and that‚Äôs making me so anxious.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat can I do?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want you to be unhappy.‚Äù

‚ÄúLike I said before, I really want you to believe in us here. I want you to give us a chance. Even if this is bad to start.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúAnd— I‚Äôm sorry if this is pushing a line or if you have reasons, but don‚Äôt be so stiff?‚Äù

She sounded so uncertain as she said it. I drew in a deep breath and smiled at her.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm the one with a prosthetic body. We‚Äôre friends, right?‚Äù She smiled, uncertain, and I smiled at her. ‚ÄúSo I don‚Äôt want you tense around me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm nervous in my own way, and I think that‚Äôs how it shows,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not you. Can I give you a bit of a hug, here, emotional support?‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease.‚Äù

I put one arm around her shoulders and squeezed. Sveta moved her head in my direction, I moved mine in her direction, knocking heads with her a bit.

Off in the distance, even though she was more than a hundred feet away, I could hear Kenzie cooing and ‚Äòaww‚Äôing over the hug, as she looked at us.

‚ÄúWhat did I miss?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm anxious,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúMe too,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúYour control gets bad when you‚Äôre nervous, right? You have more reflexive movements?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt gets so fucking shitty,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry. I‚Äôm worried I‚Äôll be terrible because I‚Äôm all over the place inside here. I don‚Äôt know if you can hear it, but I keep fumbling because I‚Äôll reflexively reach out to grab something off in the distance and hit the wall of the suit instead, and then I have to reach for the right control ring again.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo the best you can,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt about grading you as an individual,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs about the team,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to let the team down. Can we start? I‚Äôll get more nervous if we wait.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù I said.

The other three weren‚Äôt wrapped up in their discussion anymore. I called out, ‚ÄúYou guys want your flag?‚Äù

‚ÄúHere,‚Äù Sveta said. She held out her hand. I passed her the blue flag.

She passed it to the others, hand and forearm gripping the flag, tendrils pushing the hand and forearm. She stopped short, relying on only the momentum so it only punched Chris lightly in the man-boob. He caught her hand and arm in one large hand, plucking the flag free before releasing her hand. He smiled as he held it up, then he reached low to hand it to Kenzie. The two of them went to plant it, with Chris picking up a fallen tree on the way.

It seemed Chris and Kenzie got along better like this.

Ashley didn‚Äôt join them. Instead, she started walking toward us, picking her way through weeds and grass. She still had a partial smile on her face from before.

I flew to meet her partway.

‚ÄúGround rules?‚Äù she asked, when I was closer.

‚ÄúPlace your flag. You grab ours and bring it to yours, or vice-versa. Whoever has both flags at their starting point wins. Try to avoid hurting the trees. No personal injuries that aren‚Äôt going to heal in a day. Bruises and scrapes are inevitable, but let‚Äôs avoid them if we can.‚Äù

‚ÄúUnderstood.‚Äù She turned to walk away, one hand raised to give me an over-the-shoulder salute as she did.

Tristan began altering the battlefield behind her, drawing out fifty little sparks to move along the surface of our side of the hill.

The other team was just on the other side of a trio of trees. The nervousness we all felt was apparent as Kenzie‚Äôs cube lit up, making a deep beep sound.

All three faces of the cube that I could see had lit up. Numbers were apparent. ‚Äô10‚Äô‚Ä¶ ‚Äò9‚Äô‚Ä¶ ‚Äò8‚Äô‚Ä¶

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs worth remembering that she can remotely control the cube,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúHm.‚Äù

‚ÄúJust the flashlight gun and the eyehook, right?‚Äù Sveta asked, giving Tristan a look.

Tristan moved his hand, and finalized his alteration to the slope between our fort and the halfway point of the battlefield. Uneven ground, raised segments and lowered ones. Most of it was flat, the spikes sticking out of the sides or toward the ground at an angle. The material was solid, white with orange-red in the crevices, running through it like ore in rock.

The timer continued. ‚Äò3‚Äô‚Ä¶ ‚Äò2‚Äô‚Ä¶ ‚Äò1‚Äô‚Ä¶ ‚ÄòGo‚Äô.

They came out of the trees. As Tristan had suggested, Ashley‚Äôs plan was to go on the attack.

All three of them. Kenzie had changed, overalls gone, replaced with a skintight suit that mirrored her outfit in color and where it changed from black to pink to red. Chris had his head turned, and he was using one hand to cram the last few feet of the dead tree into his mouth.

Ashley was on foot. White eyes were wide open behind her mask, the pupils not visible from this distance.

‚ÄúThis is fine. Same plan,‚Äù Tristan said, not sounding bothered in the least.

Two versus three, while Sveta grabs their flag.

Sveta reached for a tree and found her grip, hauling herself away.

Tristan began creating barricades and obstructions, aimed at being knee-height, to slow them down.

Ashley hurdled the first two. Chris trampled his way through the three that had been put in his way.

Kenzie turned, aimed, and fired her flash gun in Sveta‚Äôs direction. She missed, aimed again, and fired. The second shot caught Sveta in its area.

‚ÄúYou take Chris and Kenzie, I‚Äôll work on Ashley,‚Äù Tristan said. He sounded confident. ‚ÄúKeep an eye on Kenzie, make sure she doesn‚Äôt fall.‚Äù

I flew to intercept. Chris had one hand full with the tree, mouth distended with a fat tongue sticking out, apparently to keep the tree from rubbing against his lower row of teeth; his hand served to protect the other teeth.

I was put in mind of the man I‚Äôd seen during the broken trigger, who‚Äôd had a tree come out the other direction.

Chris laughed, deep and booming, tree digested. He lowered his chin, mouth closed, hands and arms up to protect his face and guard Kenzie.

I could deal with big and strong. I flew closer— saw Kenzie turn, aiming her gun at me, and changed course, covering my face and head, my forcefield up.

Even turned partially away, my arms up, the momentary flash of light blinded me. A full second passed, and my sight didn‚Äôt return. I could hear Chris‚Äô laugh, Kenzie‚Äôs amusement. My forcefield hadn‚Äôt helped.

I felt the forcefield meet resistance, and I forced it to shut off before Chris‚Äô hand could close around me. I pushed out with my aura to try to throw him off balance and buy myself a second, and changed course. I felt his fingers graze my back, dragging against cloth and not finding enough slack to get a grip.

Blindness was disorienting. Blindness when flying made it hard to tell which way was up and which way was down, and I knew it would get worse before it got better.

I flew away and at the ground, forcefield up, and landed hard. I felt Tristan‚Äôs creation shatter under and around me as my power absorbed the hit, fragments bouncing off of me, dust collecting on me.

‚ÄúAre you okay!?‚Äù I heard Kenzie call out.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine!‚Äù I replied.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt give away your position if you‚Äôve blinded them!‚Äù I heard Ashley.

I heard a noise, and at first I thought it was Chris dismantling the fort. It sounded like someone was tearing the world‚Äôs largest sheet of paper, nails on a blackboard, an alien‚Äôs scream from a science fiction movie that echoed far more than it should, a sharp explosion, and any number of other things, all overlapping and working against one another.

I opened my eyes and tried to make out the surroundings despite the spots of light that were exploding against the backs of my eyeballs.

Chris was large enough for me to make out his general shape. I could make out Ashley and Tristan‚Äôs positions, but the only reason I could distinguish the two was because Ashley dressed in black and Tristan had more color to his costume.

Right. I had a few tricks up my sleeve I‚Äôd been considering. This was an opportunity to try one.

I took off, and I activated my forcefield momentarily as I did it, pushing out at the cracked chunks of stonelike ground, sending pieces rolling and sliding in the wake of my takeoff. I needed their attention. I saw Chris slow momentarily, mid-stride as he walked toward the fort.

I didn‚Äôt fly straight for them, but around, circling closer to the fort. I paused, giving them time to see me, and then flew straight for Chris‚Äô face, full speed.

I stopped only a few feet short, hitting him with my aura instead of my fist. Full-strength, point-blank, a hit to the emotional rather than the physical.

The reaction was much the same as if I‚Äôd punched him. Forward movement stopped, reversed, an off-balance stumble backward.

‚ÄúHoly fuck,‚Äù I could hear Tristan.

I heard Damsel‚Äôs response, but I had other focuses than making out the words. It might have been ‚Äòpay attention to your opponent‚Äô or ‚Äòpay attention to who you‚Äôre fighting‚Äô.

I was busy flying around Chris, one hand extended so it maintained contact with him, let me gently push him, all while helping me to navigate while still partially blind. Before he fully had his balance, I caught him by the shoulders and pulled him back and down toward the ground.

He walked backward rather than topple, helped by the fact that his head was small, his shoulders and neck narrow relative to his lower body. It was part of why his center of balance was low to the ground, with his weight gathered around gut, butt, and legs.

Kenzie‚Äôs pincer-claw grabbed for my arm, then pulled my arm away from Chris. I let it, grabbing the prehensile length of it between Kenzie and me. Not a huge factor. One hand still on Chris‚Äô shoulder, I activated my forcefield, using the added strength to pull at Chris. He continued his backward walk until he stumbled into one of Tristan‚Äôs sections of raised ground.

He toppled, and I shifted my position to guide his fall for the first half of the way. The focus on the latter half of the way was letting my forcefield down and catching Kenzie.

Chris fell flat on his back. Kenzie wriggled momentarily, and I deposited her on Chris‚Äô chest, to make getting to his feet just a little bit harder. The claw slipped free of my arm.

My vision was clearing enough for me to see vague expressions, without precise detail. Chris was grinning, shaking with a laugh or chuckle.

‚ÄúCome on, get up, get up!‚Äù Kenzie goaded him.

‚ÄúGet off me then!‚Äù Chris boomed.

Orange motes were starting to surround them.

‚ÄúVictoria!‚Äù Tristan called out. ‚ÄúSwitch with me!‚Äù

The words were barely out of his mouth when Ashley used her power again. It was noisy to the point I worried my ears would be ringing an hour after this exercise. I could see it as a visible blur of shadow aimed behind her and toward the ground. She used the recoil to launch herself off to one side, to help her get around and past Tristan. More orange motes appeared in the direction she was going.

She used her power again, changing course to fly straight for Tristan. She planted one foot on his shoulder, stepped down so her back grazed against his, her long hair draping over his head and shoulders, aimed forward with both hands, and used her power a third time just as she touched ground, her back to his.

A power-augmented body-check. The recoil of her power pushed her in the opposite direction she fired, but because she was in contact with Tristan, she pushed him too. She stumbled, but he sprawled to the ground, his armor striking the hard platform he‚Äôd created on the slope, metal screeching and clashing against stone.

The orange motes that had started to appear around Chris and Kenzie came to life around them, an especially spiky, irregular outcropping with a thin ridge extending out to the growth he‚Äôd been making in front of Ashley‚Äôs original course, which became its own vaguely pineapple-shaped formation.

He‚Äôd wanted me to deal with Ashley. Okay. She was rolling her shoulders, rubbing at one, while she stalked toward the fort.

I could see better, so I could possibly pull this technique off better. I flew at her, and she barely seemed to pay me any mind.

My feet touched ground, helping to stop me as I reversed my direction of flight to cancel out my forward movement. I‚Äôd wanted to avoid all physical contact, but I did bump my shoulder into hers as I went from flying at near-top speed to a full stop, my face a couple of inches from hers, well inside her personal space.

As with Chris, I used my emotion aura.

As had been the case with Chris, the effect was immediate and profound. She stumbled back much as if I‚Äôd flown into her and given her a strong shove, her eyes wide.

I‚Äôd barely found my own footing when she found hers. Another blast, jarring for my ears. My vision was already suffering, and it was made worse by the plume of dust and debris around and to one side of her. She used the blast and a push of her legs to throw herself at the wall.

The moment she made contact with it, she used her power again, flinging herself out into empty space, hair and dress fluttering.

My first instinct was that she was going to have a rough landing, that I might need to catch her. Before I‚Äôd even figured out how I might do it, she used her power once more. She was aiming up at an angle, so that meant she was pushed down by the recoil.

It wasn‚Äôt a mere drop-kick or a fall, but a spearing plunge. I did much as she‚Äôd done, pushing out with my legs in conjunction with a use of my power, my flight, to get out of her way.

With the speed and general profile of a pickaxe head driven into the ground, she landed on hard ground, in the same spot I‚Äôd been standing. There was a second where she stood there, hair draping down, hands out at her sides with fingers splayed, and then one of her legs wobbled and she dropped to one knee.

‚ÄúAre you—‚Äù I started. I thought I saw her move and paused. ‚ÄúAre you okay? That landing looks like it hurt.‚Äù

She raised her face and looked up at me. White eyes behind a black mask, behind white hair.

She used her power again. Cords, columns, and shaped explosions of lensing, bending, and darkening within the roughly cone-shaped area, over the one or two seconds that she was creating each blast. She didn‚Äôt even rise from her kneeling position. She threw herself at me, and this time she caught me entirely off guard. Her knees hit my shoulders, at least one of her arms caught me around the head, the fabric of her dress pulling against my face as she tried to fold herself around my head.

Holy shit, was my first thought. She was not letting up. Every time she acted, it was with the energy of a sprinter taking off from their starting position, except her power gave her more of a push, and the jarring noises only magnified the surprise of it.

My second thought was that she had seized my head. She wanted to take me down to the ground, much as I‚Äôd toppled Chris. There were two ways I could go. To roll with the movement and use it, or to fight against it.

My instinct was to fight against it. I used my flight, going up when she wanted to take me down. I used my aura, which was more effective when people were close, and she was wrapped around my head. I used my forcefield, only for one moment, while reaching up, putting my forearm against her ribs, and pried her off of me.

She used her power in the same instant she was pried off— fast enough that I was left with the feeling she had expected to use it while still holding onto me. Her landing looked like a rough one, sprawling, one shin, one foot, one hand bracing against the ground as she skidded.

I saw her slowly clench and unclench her hands, rolling one shoulder. She didn‚Äôt stand.

‚ÄúHoo,‚Äù I said. My heart was pounding, and I fanned myself a bit with my hand. ‚ÄúYou do remember this is a training exercise, right?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou do realize my team is going to win this?‚Äù she retorted. Her hands shifted position slightly.

Her face gave away nothing, I realized. It didn‚Äôt help that with the dust, her hair across her face, and the last remaining spots of light in my vision, I couldn‚Äôt make out her pupils. Her hands and where they were pointing were one of her tells. Her shoulders another. She was thin, but especially as she crouched there, hands slightly behind her and at her sides, shoulders pointing forward, I could see the muscles underneath the skin around her shoulder and shoulder blade.

Was there power or Manton protection there, keeping her from dislocating her shoulders when she used the recoil to move around like that? Was it just strength and practice?

I‚Äôd relied on instinct to respond to her, and I didn‚Äôt love that I‚Äôd relied on that instinct. I wanted to be careful and thoughtful about the moves I made and Ashley‚Äôs approach allowed absolutely none of that. I was left to digest that I‚Äôd reacted to her by fighting, going the opposite direction instead of the Judo-like approach of using the enemy‚Äôs strength against them.

Was I okay with that? If I had to rationalize my choice, I‚Äôd fought her because I could only use the enemy‚Äôs momentum against them if I knew which way they were going, and Ashley was hard to predict.

Well, just a bit less difficult now, as I stopped looking for more obvious tells. She had stopped rolling her shoulder. I saw the muscles tense.

‚ÄúVictoria!‚Äù

The shout interrupted both of us, as she planned her next move and I readied my response. It was Tristan calling. Ashley and I both looked.

‚ÄúCome and help!‚Äù he called out.

I flew back and away, out of Ashley‚Äôs reach, looking.

Chris, legs embedded in spiky rock, was using both hands to haul what looked like a long, thin rod out of his throat. He‚Äôd swallowed the length of the dead tree like a sword-swallower swallowed a blade, and now he was drawing it back out, changed.

Narrower, thinner, smoother, and slick with fluids.

Chris, it seemed, wasn‚Äôt just the kind of changer who could adapt his form. He was the kind of changer who gained new sorts of powers while in an alternate form.

He hauled the last of the tree free of his mouth. Fifteen feet long, thicker at the end he had just removed than at the end he held, now that he was turning it around to get it in a position he could wield it. Too long to be a proper club, not quite a rod either.

Kenzie had her flash gun out. Tristan had thrown up a short wall, just tall and wide enough that he could hide behind it. Kenzie‚Äôs eyehook extended from her belt, through one of her hands, and out to Tristan, with a grip on his leg. She was simultaneously trying to circle around to get at an angle where she could shoot and blind Tristan and she was using the claw at the end of the prehensile arm to try and drag him out of the cover, helped by tugs with her hand.

Kenzie‚Äôs efforts left Chris entirely unmolested as he brought his weapon down, shattering Tristan‚Äôs created ground, freeing his legs.

‚ÄúLeave her!‚Äù Tristan ordered. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll let her get the flag, deal with these two, and catch her on her return trip!‚Äù

I flew a little further away.

Sveta— I looked off in the direction of the enemy‚Äôs camp.

Little blue flags decorated the landscape on their side of the playing field. They were situated on every rock, in every crevice, on every flat expanse of ground, on every tree branch. Sveta was perched on a rock in the midst of it all.

I looked at Kenzie‚Äôs cube. One face of it was glowing. The projector.

That would be why they had been smiling, then.

I started my flight toward toward Tristan.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll regret ignoring me,‚Äù Ashley said, behind me.

Pride, respect, they were key factors here. I could remember the meeting, the narrowing of the eyes. I knew Tristan was in a tough spot, but I paused, turning around in the air. I had to raise my voice to be heard with the distance between Ashley and me, as I said, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not ignoring you. We‚Äôre dealing with you two against one.‚Äù

I left her to limp toward the wall while I flew to Tristan‚Äôs side. I landed beside Kenzie, hard, pushing out with my aura.

She twisted around, gun in hand, and I caught the gun, snatching it out of her hand.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù she said. She reached out with her hand, and I pulled the gun away. She let go of Tristan and reached out for the gun with the eye-hook. I grabbed the eye-hook, and then wrapped the length of the prehensile arm around her upper body, tying her up with it.

‚ÄúHey!‚Äù she said, again. She laughed. ‚ÄúChris help!‚Äù

I didn‚Äôt need to ask, and I liked that I didn‚Äôt need to ask. Orange motes began to surround Kenzie.

‚ÄúNo, no, no, no!‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúChris, Chris, Chris, Chris!‚Äù

The head of the long club was poked out between Kenzie and me, separating us. Kenzie started to back away, and the orange motes became solid rock, encapsulating her legs. Tristan lunged forward to catch her before her upper body came down and her head cracked down against his rocky terrain.

I flew up a little ways, putting myself between them and Chris. Chris drew the fat end of the club back, and then smacked it against his palm. He laughed, deep and low, and pointed at Kenzie.

‚ÄúStop laughing at me and help, you doofus!‚Äù

I had Kenzie‚Äôs gun in hand, I could have shot Chris, but I had my deep reservations about using a tinker‚Äôs stuff, even a nonlethal gun that temporarily blinded.

Ashley used her power. I could hear the sound of it, and I saw the wall break.

‚ÄúBy the way,‚Äù Tristan said, looking in that direction. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not catching her on the return trip.‚Äù

He blurred, and with that blurring, the rock blurred too. White with orange-red veins became clear water, reflecting the blue of the sky and the green of the trees above and grass below. The front wall of the fort that Ashley had just penetrated and the platform that Kenzie and Chris were standing on became frothing water.

With the slope, that water flowed downhill, carrying Ashley and Kenzie down to the base of the hill, amid branches, mud, and sticks. Ashley used her power at the start and toward the end, to little effect.

Chris brought his rod down, stabbing it deep into the ground, and held onto it for leverage. It had to be sturdier than the dead tree had been, because it didn‚Äôt bend and it didn‚Äôt break. Condensed down, maybe, shaped to be hard.

He reared back, and he blew. He‚Äôd broken down and processed more of the dead tree than what he‚Äôd used to condense it into a giant club-staff. He exhaled a cloud of wet sawdust.

I didn‚Äôt want to put up my forcefield if it would catch the sawdust, so I endured it, flew closer, and used my forcefield for only as long as it took to kick the stick he was holding onto with all of my strength.

It broke, and with it breaking, Chris fell down the hill, rolling over wet grass and weeds, until he came to a stop against a cluster of two trees that had grown next to one another.

He began to pick himself up, working his way up the hill, stabbing down to pierce the ground with his half-stick and plant it there like an ice-climber might use a piton. The slope was just a little steeper at the base of the hill, and the water had become rock again, smooth and with the spikes all pointed downward, not good grips.

He swallowed hard, giving me a suspicion about what he was about to do. He spat out a ball of wood pulp and phlegm, and I flew to one side, letting it sail past me.

I was put in mind of Crawler — the changer power, the spitting, the joyful monster. Crawler had laughed too.

Crawler had critically injured me with his acid spit, and that had let Amy get her hands on me the second time.

It was a dark, unpleasant thought.

Tristan was focused on a point off to the side. I turned to look, and I saw that he was creating orange motes around the projector box.

The motes solidified, and the box was encased in a thorny encasement of rock.

I turned to look, keeping one eye on Chris, and I saw the flags were still there.

‚ÄúNope! That‚Äôs not going to work! Good luck finding our flag!‚Äù Kenzie called out. She loosed an over the top, mocking laugh.

Tristan turned the encasement to water.

‚ÄúI said it was waterproofed before! That‚Äôs not going to do anything!‚Äù Kenzie called out, before doing her level best to laugh harder, even though she had already been laughing at her limit.

‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt matter,‚Äù Tristan said, loud enough for them to hear.

Sveta made her way back in three moves, from the other team‚Äôs camp to a rock, rock to tree, tree to our camp.

She hauled herself up to the top of one of Tristan‚Äôs walls and she held up the two flags.

Ashley and Chris, who were making their way up the hill, stopped climbing.

‚ÄúYes! Yes! That was so great, that was fun, we have to do this again!‚Äù

From what Kenzie was saying, she didn‚Äôt seem to mind losing much. She practically bounced with excitement.

Tristan created stairs on the slope.

Sveta joined Tristan and me as the others climbed the stairs. Tristan put out one gauntlet, and she tapped her prosthetic hand against it. I offered my own fist to her, and she tapped her fist against it, before wrapping her arms around me in a brief hug.

A stoic Ashley had Kenzie clinging to her as she reached the top.

‚Äú—were so cool, it was like how you were in the videos—‚Äù

‚ÄúEase up, Kenzie,‚Äù Tristan said.

Kenzie let go of Ashley, bouncing on the spot before reaching up to her lens-mask and pulling it off. With the mask‚Äôs removal, her costume flickered in places, like an image that had been badly compressed, with heavy artifacting.

‚ÄúThis was everything I wanted it to be and more,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe you found the flag.‚Äù

‚ÄúI—‚Äù Sveta started.

‚ÄúWaitwaitwaitwait,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúWait. Um. Okay. I have this covered.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Sveta said.

Kenzie pulled out her smartphone.

The projector made a sound, and then images streaked the hill, before correcting. Ghostly images of all of us, life-size. The images included the constructions Tristan had made.

It looked like where we had all been standing earlier in the match, when I had been facing down Ashley.

The images zipped around as Kenzie changed the time, blurring and streaking before correcting into their proper shapes.

‚ÄúI saved everything, so we can look back and watch how things played out or compare notes,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúSo we can do stuff like this‚Ä¶‚Äù

The images blurred and moved, then shifted, so the scenes that were projected no longer lined up on the battlefield.

It was Sveta, perched on a branch, flag in hand. Another blur, moving the clock back.

Sveta removed one of her prosthetic hands. Fifty or more tendrils snapped out.

‚ÄúYou grabbed every flag,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúI grabbed at every flag,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI had to reposition a few times, so I probably grabbed at some fake ones several times. It didn‚Äôt help that I couldn‚Äôt see that well after being shot.‚Äù

Kenzie cackled. Chris smothered her cackling with a large hand. Kenzie fought back, trying to get out from under Chris‚Äô hand, and she did a pretty poor job of it.

It was weird and good to see her finally acting like an actual kid. Too much excitement in her system, but that wasn‚Äôt a bad thing.

Once Kenzie had settled down more, we walked through the entire fight, focusing on each person. Sveta was first, easy enough.

Tristan was next, and he made mention of the platform, and how he‚Äôd wanted to make sure nobody had footing when the rock turned to water, so he‚Äôd raised the ground some. He had obviously plotted the trap from early on.

‚ÄúKenzie? Do you want to report what you were doing?‚Äù Tristan asked, once he was done explaining what he‚Äôd done to Sveta.

‚ÄúWait,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúRain‚Äôs here. I‚Äôll point the way.‚Äù

It took a couple of minutes before Rain and Kenzie‚Äôs camera-drone arrived at the base of the hill.

Chris was half the size he had been, and his proportions were returning to normal. As he shrank, he rearranged the voluminous shorts he‚Äôd been wearing, ensuring his modesty was protected. His old outfit was contained within a pocket on the inside of the shorts, and he gathered it together, folded up, the clothes piled on his lap, along with what looked like a pencil case.

Even though he was returning to the person he‚Äôd been, physically, his smile lingered.

‚ÄúRainnn!‚Äù Kenzie called out, while Rain was still making his way to us. ‚ÄúDid you bring tinker stuff!?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah!‚Äù Rain responded.

‚ÄúYusss,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúThis is the best day.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou could have waited twenty seconds for Rain to show up and asked him in a normal volume,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúI wanted to know now.‚Äù

Chris groaned at her, putting his face closer to hers.

Kenzie groaned louder, exaggerated, putting her face closer to his.

Chris groaned even louder, guttural, using some of the residual transformation to play up the sound. His forehead pressed against hers, hard enough she had to push back to avoid being pushed over.

Rather than try to top it, Kenzie sat back down. ‚ÄúI like you when you‚Äôre like this.‚Äù

‚ÄúNaked?‚Äù Chris asked.

‚ÄúNo!‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúGeez.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy does it feel like every time I enter a conversation, it‚Äôs a weird topic?‚Äù Rain asked, joining us where we sat on Tristan-created seats and benches.

‚ÄúI like you when you‚Äôre happy,‚Äù Kenzie said. She fussed with her hair, looking down. ‚ÄúI like you a lot like this.‚Äù

I was put in mind of her comments about Chris before she‚Äôd gotten in Erin‚Äôs car, after leaving the group meeting. Like she didn‚Äôt have the worldly experience to know people didn‚Äôt say stuff like that in such an unguarded, dead obvious way.

‚ÄúI still think you‚Äôre annoying as shit,‚Äù Chris said.

Sveta kicked him.

Kenzie snorted, smiling as she looked up at him. ‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

‚ÄúNah. I‚Äôm joking. You‚Äôre fine. I think we did pretty good.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think we did too. It would have worked except Tristan and Byron are strong and Victoria is oof and Sveta was the best counter to what we were doing. We should fill Rain in.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat would be nice,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúIt was you two and‚Ä¶‚Äù

He turned to look around the group, saw Ashley, and didn‚Äôt finish the sentence.

‚ÄúAnd me,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúHere, I can show you the replay,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúBut I want to see your tinker arms too, before we run out of time.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs plenty of time,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúWait, here, you take the remote, and Rain, you can hand me the arm, I won‚Äôt break anything, I promise.‚Äù

Rain rummaged in his backpack, ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt blame you if you did, it‚Äôs fragile and shitty. You think it would help your eyehook?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt might! But I‚Äôm really interested in the interface. You like to have multiple arms, you said?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah. For what little it‚Äôs worth.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you control it with your brain, once it‚Äôs plugged in?‚Äù Kenzie asked. When Rain nodded, she asked, ‚ÄúHow does the brain know how to control it?‚Äù

‚ÄúI map the brain patterns for input and output and the panel here, between the attachment and the actual arm, it acts like an extension of the brain.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat doesn‚Äôt make any sense,‚Äù Sveta said.

Tristan was fiddling with the remote, and seemed to be having trouble with the progression of time, with images jumping all over the place. Sveta, Kenzie, and Rain were all focused on the arm, with Ashley periodically joining in when prodded.

Chris was sitting on the bench, cloth around him as he shrunk down to a more ordinary size. He was smiling more than before as he rummaged for his headphones and a chocolate bar.

‚ÄúYour mood seems better,‚Äù I said to him.

The smile dropped away. He looked at me and shrugged. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs different. I feel more human, mentally and emotionally.‚Äù

The change hadn‚Äôt seemed to make any difference in how he looked, either. Were the changes subtle?

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure I grasped it all,‚Äù I told him. ‚ÄúOnce you change, it‚Äôs‚Ä¶?‚Äù

I trailed off.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like a hit of a drug,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúFocus, surprise, sadness, appreciation, disgust, fear, anger, and then this one.‚Äù

‚ÄúJoy?‚Äù

‚ÄúI call this particular flavor of it Wan Indulgence,‚Äù he said. He bit down on the chocolate bar, then closed his eyes, clearly enjoying it. He talked with his mouth full, ‚ÄúCan be enjoyment. I‚Äôll feel it more normally for a few days now that I‚Äôve changed.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh my god,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúTristan, give that back, you suck at it.‚Äù

Tristan was still fiddling with Kenzie‚Äôs remote for the projector box.

‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt make any sense. Why isn‚Äôt it easier to move forward and back in time?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause the box doesn‚Äôt perceive time, you dummy. It perceives images.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy not have it perceive things like time, so you can go backward and forward in time without doing‚Ä¶ whatever arcane thing you‚Äôre doing right now?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause if it perceived time,‚Äù Kenzie said, patiently, her focus on the smartphone remote, ‚ÄúThen it wouldn‚Äôt perceive images. And that would be a dumb thing for a projector box that works with images. Dummy.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can stop calling me a dummy now.‚Äù

‚ÄúI will if you stop being dumb. This stuff is obvious.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really not,‚Äù Chris said.

Kenzie sighed, very dramatically. ‚ÄúWho are we following next?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôd be nice to show Rain the entire thing,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúIt works best with a point of view,‚Äù Kenzie said. She looked at Tristan and rolled her eyes a little.

‚ÄúIf you keep that up, you‚Äôre going to see orange lights swirling over your head. Then a rock is going to fall on you or, more likely, I‚Äôll swap out and you‚Äôll get a spray of cold water.‚Äù

Kenzie stuck out her tongue at Tristan.

I was aware that Ashley hadn‚Äôt participated enthusiastically in the conversation. I suspected why. I hesitated, then ventured, ‚ÄúI‚Äôd really like to see how Ashley approached things.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù Ashley asked.

My suspicions were stronger. I went on, ‚ÄúFrankly, I hope this isn‚Äôt taken the wrong way, but you‚Äôre really intimidating to go up against.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the intention.‚Äù
