‚ÄúA big part of the reason I swapped out with Victoria is that I had no idea what to do,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt catch you with my power, and you‚Äôre faster than me on foot.‚Äù

Kenzie was changing the perspective. She created a projection of the hillside and shrank things down, then created more projections, showing an image off to one side of our gathering, showing a zoomed in portion of what the little diorama-sized projection was showing as a whole. The focus started with the three emerging from the trees, trampling through and hurdling the barriers Tristan created.

She jumped to Tristan trying to deal with Ashley.

‚ÄúThose blasts are as scary as shit,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúEvery time you used one, even if you were five feet away and you weren‚Äôt aiming at me, I was flinching. I saw what it was doing to my powerstuff, and I did not want that to happen to my bodystuff.‚Äù

He‚Äôd realized what I was doing, and why, I realized. Ashley was dejected at losing and we could give her a bit of a morale boost. She seemed to like being scary.

I wasn‚Äôt wholly sure it was good to feed her ego on that front, but I wasn‚Äôt sure I liked the alternative, either.

‚ÄúI have better control than that. I‚Äôm not an idiot,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not saying you are,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs obvious you have control,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúKenzie, can you show the walljump?‚Äù

‚ÄúThere are two.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe one with me,‚Äù I said.

Kenzie jumped to the scene. Ashley leaping off of the wall with one foot, her power just starting to explode out from her hands. The power looked more solid in projection than it did in reality.

‚ÄúFor the record,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúIf I was moving through this recording in time and not space, then I‚Äôd have to fast forward and rewind and skip around to find this, but I don‚Äôt, so I hope people are realizing why this is better.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm fully in support of dumping water on Kenzie‚Äôs head,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúThe walljump,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThe sequences of blasts to maneuver and the whole-body coordination it must take. That, to me, says control.‚Äù

‚ÄúAll for nothing,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúIt was not for nothing,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI got to see and experience what you do, I respect the spatial awareness. The instinct—‚Äù

‚ÄúI fell for a trap,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI knew there would be water and I thought I could avoid it if I used my power in time, I didn‚Äôt expect there to be so much.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve never seen each other‚Äôs powers in action,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúSurprises are inevitable. You surprised the shit out of me, many times, and I got one good surprise off. When we do it again, we‚Äôll know each other‚Äôs powers better. It‚Äôs part of why we‚Äôre doing the exercises in the first place.‚Äù

‚ÄúI failed,‚Äù Ashley said. She stood up, and she rubbed one shoulder. ‚ÄúI was tested and I failed.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight from the start,‚Äù Sveta said, jumping into the conversation ‚ÄúWhen we were standing around figuring out what we‚Äôd do, Victoria told me that this wasn‚Äôt a test of us as individuals. It‚Äôs a test of our coordination as a team.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can find that on the recording,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôll be hard to find, though.‚Äù

‚ÄúHah,‚Äù Chris said. Kenzie pushed his shoulder.

‚ÄúMy team failed,‚Äù Ashley said, oblivious to the pair. ‚ÄúNo. My team was set up to fail.‚Äù

‚ÄúWait, woah,‚Äù Tristan said.

Ashley clenched one hand into a fist. ‚ÄúYou realize if I hadn‚Äôt been holding back, I could have annihilated each and every one of you?‚Äù

‚ÄúWoah,‚Äù Tristan said, with emphasis. ‚ÄúAshley—‚Äù

She whirled on him, pointing, and he flinched, going silent. I stood from my seat.

‚ÄúAshley,‚Äù I said, because I wanted her attention off of Tristan.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not Ashley,‚Äù she said, her voice hard. ‚ÄúNobody has called me that in a long, long time. I‚Äôm only Ashley because the therapists insisted and the others needed an actual name to put on the paperwork. I‚Äôm Damsel of Distress!‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúCan we—‚Äù

I was spoken over. ‚ÄúI was a member of the Slaughterhouse Nine. They selected me. They had me kill and maim people. I didn‚Äôt mind doing it then, and I could do it here without blinking.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt believe you,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve died and I came back with only the vicious parts of me intact! All of the warmth, the good memories, the family, they‚Äôre just a fuzzy, indistinct dream. Those memories have no hold on me. The killing? Taking people‚Äôs arms and legs and watching them bleed out? That‚Äôs clear as anything. I could do the same to any of you.‚Äù

I wanted the younger and more vulnerable members of the team to back away, to get clear of trouble, but I worried that if I tried to indicate that, it might provoke her. Everyone was still, and nobody, myself included, was really breathing.

‚ÄúThis was an idiotic game, and I. Don‚Äôt. Play. Games.‚Äù

‚ÄúCount down from ten,‚Äù Rain said.

Ashley whirled on him. I left the ground, flying closer, stopping when things didn‚Äôt escalate further.

‚ÄúCount down from ten,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what Mrs. Yamada says, isn‚Äôt it? When you‚Äôre wound up.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine when she says it.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt should be fine when any of us say it,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúCount.‚Äù

Ashley tensed. I could see it in her shoulders and the way the tendons stood out in her hands.

Everyone was silent.

I waited. Ten seconds passed. Then the fifteenth, then the twentieth.

‚ÄúFeel better?‚Äù Sveta ventured.

Ashley turned, staring Sveta down. ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúCount down from a hundred,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to—‚Äù

‚ÄúCount,‚Äù Rain said, his voice soft. ‚ÄúPlease. You‚Äôve said before, when you get like this, there‚Äôs a part of you that‚Äôs saying you don‚Äôt want to act this way, and you can‚Äôt listen to it. So listen to the numbers first, then listen to that part of you.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that easy.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs—‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that easy,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm going to walk away. You do your thing. Let me do mine.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Rain said.

She limped away, hands in fists at her side. We were silent as we watched her go.

She walked up the hill, found a rock, and leaned against it, her back to us, and I let my feet touch ground.

‚ÄúWe knew it was coming sooner or later,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúSpooky,‚Äù Sveta said.‚ÄùI expected a small outburst to start with. That was—‚Äù

‚ÄúMedium-small,‚Äù Tristan said.

Kenzie stood up, gathering her things.

‚ÄúStay, Kenzie,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe wants to be left alone.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis thing?‚Äù Kenzie asked. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not you guys being the adults and me as the kid, listening to what adults say. We‚Äôre all equal members of this team. And this is what I‚Äôm going to do, and if I get hurt that‚Äôs fine, but this is right for me. You can tell me what to do with some other stuff but not this stuff.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs dangerous,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúLeave her be.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Kenzie said, voice firm. She put her hand on her flash gun. She looked at all of us, then said, softer, ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay, Kenzie,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúGo. Be careful.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre sure?‚Äù Tristan asked Sveta.

But Kenzie was already jogging off in Ashley‚Äôs direction.

When Kenzie was out of earshot, but before she had reached Ashley, Sveta raised one hand and said, voice quiet, ‚ÄúIf there‚Äôs a problem, I‚Äôll haul her back.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat takes a second or two,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúSparring with Ashley, I gotta say she moves faster than that.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd your grip isn‚Äôt a hundred percent,‚Äù Tristan said.

Sveta set her jaw, hand pointed at Kenzie.

Kenzie reached Ashley, and with Ashley‚Äôs movement, we all tensed, preparing to act.

Ashley turned back to look out at the distance, and Kenzie climbed up on the rock Ashley was leaning against.

A moment later, Kenzie had her headphones out of a pocket. She plugged it into her phone, reached down, and put an earbud in Ashley‚Äôs ear, then put another in her ear, before lying down on the rock.

Slowly, Sveta lowered her hand.

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI gave my reasons before, so did Rain, so did Kenzie,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve had this discussion. This isn‚Äôt news.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs one thing to know it and see it in therapy, it‚Äôs another to experience it in the wild,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù I asked, again. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt— I understand reaching out to people, but can you really reach out to people who aren‚Äôt reaching back? Can you give forgiveness and understanding to someone who isn‚Äôt looking for it?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think she is,‚Äù Sveta said.

Tristan said, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what you guys talked about, but I discussed this with the others, and I have an idea what they probably said. Do you know how many appointments and meetings she goes to?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt came up,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúOkay, good. But did you talk about why?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause she needs careful handling?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúBecause,‚Äù Tristan said, ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs a special case. She‚Äôs not the original Ashley, I‚Äôm not sure if you picked up on that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI got the gist of it.‚Äù

‚ÄúLike she said, her memories aren‚Äôt hers. She was cloned, they took her and they made up composite memories, but they had no reason to give her those fuzzy memories of other, nonconfrontational stuff. That wasn‚Äôt Bonesaw‚Äôs work. It‚Äôs the agent.‚Äù

I drew in a breath and I sighed.

‚ÄúThe world ended, and it ended because of them. We can‚Äôt have a sit-down talk with Scion because we killed him. We have a shitton of questions and the only kinds of people who can answer them are the people who got really close to the agents, like Bonesaw, who made Ashley—‚Äù

I felt a chill.

‚Äú—and the people like this. Who are very little of the human, shadows of the human, and a lot of the agent. All of us have problems, and a big part of those problems are the agents, handling their side of things. I know I‚Äôve talked to Rain about this, I don‚Äôt know about the rest of you guys, but when I‚Äôm talking to her I‚Äôm also talking to the agent that‚Äôs very close to the surface. I feel like if I can get along with that agent, I can get along with mine.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúI want to get along with the human,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to define her as the monstrous half.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs fair too,‚Äù Tristan said.

I folded my arms. I looked down at Chris, and I saw that he was half-asleep.

He saw me looking, and he said, ‚ÄúThe world was invaded by aliens. People don‚Äôt know it, we don‚Äôt like to think about it, but they‚Äôre here, they‚Äôre a part of things. Getting along with the most accessible of them makes sense.‚Äù

I didn‚Äôt like it, but I wasn‚Äôt sure how to articulate it. My own agent had a hand in my life. It was the wretch, the sapience behind the forcefield. I had seen what Amy‚Äôs had done to her.

Thinking too hard about it stirred up countless ugly feelings, and those feelings choked out and clouded the words I wanted to articulate.

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs leave them be,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs assume we‚Äôre not going to have our second exercise, and walk me through how things went.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù Tristan said.

As the discussion continued, I didn‚Äôt take my eyes off the pair in the distance.

Glare — 3.4

Kenzie sprinted toward the wall, and took a flying kick at it. The wall broke, split at a diagonal, the upper half sliding down the split until the corner stabbed the ground. Kenzie backed up swiftly before the section of wall toppled and fell to the ground.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm clearly the strongest member of the team,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the lamest,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúCan I try it again?‚Äù Kenzie asked, ignoring Chris. ‚ÄúRain?‚Äù

‚ÄúBe careful,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúI will. I want to test stuff. Can I try it again?‚Äù

Rain stood from the rock he was sitting on, and held one hand out to the side. The silver-white blade he created had a slight crescent shape to it. He swung his arm and threw it, for lack of a better word. It traced an arc, more a boomerang in flight than an arrow or thrown weapon, and cut deep into the wall that Tristan had left as a permanent fixture. A silver-white line was left along the length of the wall.

Kenzie raised her flash gun, and she shot the wall. Nothing happened.

She approached the wall, and she had her eyehook snake out from where it was attached to her belt, pincers open, slapping against the wall. She pushed with the eyehook.

‚ÄúHurry,‚Äù Rain said.

Kenzie continued using the eyehook to push, to no avail. She moved the hook around to the wall‚Äôs edge, grabbed the length of the eyehook, and pulled, adding her strength to the mechanical arm‚Äôs.

Stone slid easily against stone, and the wall was pulled down, cleanly cut where the silver line had been drawn.

‚ÄúI could do this all day,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a bad power,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI never said it was bad,‚Äù Rain said. He sat back down. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs mediocre. On certain days, it‚Äôs a little better.‚Äù

‚ÄúBetter how? Size, speed, effectiveness, number you can throw?‚Äù

‚ÄúAll of the above, except maybe effectiveness. And duration, I‚Äôd say. Ten, twenty percent increase, if I had to guess.‚Äù

‚ÄúDuration?‚Äù

‚ÄúHow long after I shoot stuff the line lasts.‚Äù

I turned to my laptop and I started typing that up.

‚ÄúNot effectiveness?‚Äù Kenzie asked, as she rejoined us. She had her phone out and walked without looking where she was going.

Sveta and Tristan were having a conversation off to one side, Ashley had gone back to the library to use the washroom, which had freed Kenzie to rejoin us, and Chris was getting dressed again while under the cover of the giant-size shorts.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs kind of one thing or the other,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúEither it breaks or it doesn‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking at the data from my eyehook,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúIt didn‚Äôt work with your power until after I started helping it. Twenty point two pounds of force total, that‚Äôs nine point one six kilograms, and then the break happened. What if it‚Äôs easier to break things when your power is better?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt could be,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good thinking,‚Äù I said.

Kenzie nodded, eyes still on her phone, and said, ‚ÄúCan you throw another?‚Äù

‚ÄúMore tests?‚Äù Rain asked.

‚ÄúNo. Breaking stuff like this is a ton of fun,‚Äù Kenzie said.

Rain stood, looked around, and then created another blade of silver-white light. He threw it at the half-stick Chris had left impaled in the hillside. The blade passed through the dead-tree stick, leaving a white line in it a good few feet above the ground, and continued forward as two separate segments flying in parallel, with a narrow gap in the middle. One hit a tree, and the other hit the ground.

Kenzie ran off, handing her phone to her eyehook.

‚ÄúWhat happens if you hit a person?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI tried on livestock, a goat. Silver line.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe goat ran off, jumped up onto a tractor tire, then jumped down. The impact as she jumped down was what did it. Clean cut.‚Äù

‚ÄúPossibly over twenty pounds of force in that impact?‚Äù

‚ÄúI guess,‚Äù Rain said.

Kenzie had reached the rod and found the silver line was higher than she could reach. She began rolling a nearby rock closer, to give herself a leg up.

Chris, barefoot, wearing his t-shirt and shorts, broke into a sprint. As Kenzie climbed up onto the rock, Chris threw himself at the rod, hard, body-checking it. It broke in two at the silver line, the top half toppling.

Kenzie made the kind of high-pitched noise only a prepubescent girl could, and drew her flash gun. She began shooting Chris repeatedly, while he rolled in the grass, laughing, arms around his face.

‚ÄúWhat happens when you hit the ground?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúNot much, most of the time. I guess you get a fissure, but it doesn‚Äôt really do much, because the line is so clean.‚Äù

‚ÄúKenzie!‚Äù I called out.

She stopped shooting Chris and turned to look.

‚ÄúStomp on the line on the ground? I‚Äôm curious!‚Äù

She ran off, leaving Chris where he was.

‚ÄúCan you explain the schedule, then? The powers wax and wane?‚Äù

Rain sighed.

‚ÄúSorry, if I‚Äôm grilling you a little too much. I‚Äôm trying to get my head around this.‚Äù

‚ÄúI see them in my dreams. I never get a good night‚Äôs sleep, never dream normally. Just‚Ä¶ them. And they see me. We take turns, and when my turn comes up, I get a bit of a power up.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs how you knew Snag‚Äôs description, before you knew his name.‚Äù

Rain nodded.

Off in the distance, Kenzie stomped on the silver line in the grass. There was a bit of dust, and some grass stalks fell, but I didn‚Äôt see anything else. She looked at us and shrugged.

‚ÄúEvery five days, I get my turn, and I‚Äôm a little bit stronger. There are other times I‚Äôm stronger, but it‚Äôs complicated.‚Äù

‚ÄúEvery five? There‚Äôs four others?‚Äù

‚ÄúThree others,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs‚Ä¶?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe day in the rotation after me, it‚Äôs a blank space. My running theory is that there was a fifth member of the cluster, but they died before the powers set in. Free power-up, goes to someone random. Doesn‚Äôt always line up with our power, so on those days, I can sometimes have more tinker power, or more mover power, more emotion power. A taste of what I could be.‚Äù

‚ÄúOnce every twenty days, on average.‚Äù

‚ÄúNever lining up with my days,‚Äù he said. He sighed. ‚ÄúThrough the dreams I‚Äôve seen them unmasked and they‚Äôve seen me. They hate me and I‚Äôm not overly fond of them. They‚Äôre always there, every night, and it‚Äôs pretty obvious how much they despise me. It‚Äôs where Tristan and I have that shared experience, kind of.‚Äù

‚ÄúPeople you can‚Äôt get away from,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre talking about your cluster?‚Äù Tristan asked, joining the conversation. Sveta was behind him.

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

Tristan sat down on the rock beside Rain. I scooted over so Sveta could sit beside me.

‚ÄúThese people want you dead? How likely is it they go forward with this hit?‚Äù

‚ÄúNinety-nine point eight percent likely,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the point two?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúThey all die or get arrested before they get around to it,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúYou seem pretty cavalier about traveling into the city,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúYou caught a train today?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúAgain, it‚Äôs the dreams, I can pick up a little, and I can throw them off a little. The thing about being outnumbered in this situation is that I have a lot of opportunities to pick up details. One clue from any of them can help a lot.‚Äù

‚ÄúDetails like?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe woman is injured, and Snag wants to repair the arm you trashed. That buys me a few days. So, uh, thank you.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe third one won‚Äôt come after you alone?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a guy, a little older than me. Glasses. He‚Äôs the person with the tinker power. I haven‚Äôt picked up much about him, but he doesn‚Äôt interact with people much. Less than Snag or the woman, and Snag is an asshole and the woman is mute, so that should tell you something.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs an advantage in that,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúIf they aren‚Äôt socially adroit and you are—‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre better off than they are and that counts for something,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúThey have money and resources, and that more than makes up for it,‚Äù Rain said. He looked at me. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre suspicious they hired Tattletale to track me down.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù I said. I thought about that. ‚ÄúI honestly can‚Äôt think of someone worse to have on your trail.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs good enough to take over a city and get away with it,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not even it,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúShe destroys people.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre we talking about group members behind their backs?‚Äù Kenzie asked, as she joined us.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre talking Tattletale.‚Äù

Over near the staff that had been made with the dead tree, Chris was lying in the grass, arms and legs spread, staring up at the sky.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs okay?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs fine,‚Äù Kenzie said.

As if responding, Chris chuckled to himself, lying in the grass near the base of the hill.

‚ÄúThe Undersiders took over Brockton Bay, and they did it with Tattletale on point for most of it. I‚Äôm not a hundred percent sure on any of this, but you can look at the events in the city starting with her taking power. Bank robbery, Undersiders succeed, they run into the Wards, me, and my sister. Tattletale insinuates knowledge of my sister‚Äôs deepest secrets, and mine. My sister goes off the deep end. ABB are provoked following an arrest of their leader and an interaction with the Undersiders, with Tattletale. They‚Äôre toppled with a concerted effort on the part of the villains, with intel passed to the heroes by the villains.‚Äù

‚ÄúBy Tattletale,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúIn large part. Empire Eighty-Eight get outed, secret identities revealed. Undersiders are the focus of the blame, and a number of people die in the ensuing rampage. Weeks and months of violence and chaos in Brockton Bay feed into the Endbringer attack on the city. Half of my family died because of that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry,‚Äù Sveta said.

I reached out for her hand and gave it a waggle. ‚ÄúIt should be noted that in the hospital after the attack, Tattletale talked to the leaders of various hero teams about Leviathan‚Äôs strengths and weaknesses. Info that was then used to beat down Behemoth enough to let Scion finish him off.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat could be a coincidence,‚Äù Rain said.

He didn‚Äôt say it in a dismissive way. He said it like he was a little scared, and he wanted something to cling to.

I wanted to drive reality home, though. Better to scare him and have him alive than the alternative.

‚ÄúPossibly. But I‚Äôm more inclined to see her as a force multiplier or a kind of thinker version of what you do with your power, creating weak points for others to capitalize on. We see a lot of these coincidences. After the Endbringer, the Slaughterhouse Nine visit and do a hell of a lot of damage, but they also lose several key members. The weaknesses of several key members are revealed and the members are removed.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou might want to go easy on talking about those guys when Ashley gets back,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just one data point in a series. The last remaining mastermind of the city falls, Coil. The PRT directors die. Twice, in quick succession. Weaknesses are targeted and capitalized on. Alexandria dies in Brockton Bay, at the hands of a girl who had apparently wanted to be a hero, but who was converted to the villains‚Äô side. Flechette, a hero, a minor friend of mine? Apparently converted. Accord edges into the Undersiders‚Äô turf. He dies when the Behemoth fight happens. What do you think happens with his resources and power? Because I‚Äôm betting it‚Äôs the same as what happened with Coil‚Äôs.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd now she runs one of the major settlement points,‚Äù Rain said. He still sounded spooked.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have all of the information, but she got to that point by being one of the masterminds and playing the game well. She was aggressive when the city was vulnerable and she was passive when it wasn‚Äôt. The moment Gold Morning came around, I get the impression she mobilized hard, she was ready to expand and capitalize on the situation with more of that aggression. Again, I‚Äôm not 100% on all of that. But I can say with reasonable confidence that she‚Äôs one of the most dangerous, capable people on Gimel.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat am I supposed to do, then?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù I said.

Sveta elbowed me. ‚ÄúYou have to give him more than that. You can‚Äôt scare him and not give him something.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù Rain said.

I thought for a few seconds.

‚ÄúShe bleeds,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúShe gets tired, and she looked really fucking tired when I saw her. She has a lot on her plate, and I don‚Äôt think you‚Äôre a primary focus. Which is good. You don‚Äôt want to be her primary focus, because people who are tend to end up in pieces, one way or another.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù Rain said, sounding anything but.

‚ÄúShe‚Ä¶‚Äù I started. I bit my tongue.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to jump to conclusions. I don‚Äôt want to give you the wrong impressions, either.‚Äù

‚ÄúAny impressions help,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúBut what she said when I talked to her, the way she wanted to make herself out to be one of the good guys, bringing good things to others‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù Kenzie said. She fiddled with her phone.

‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt necessarily jibe with her working with people who are out for blood and murder. She seems to want to be a very low-key villain or even a Robin-Hood type desperado while simultaneously leaving a trail of bodies in her wake, or she wants to portray herself as such,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm now sharing the love and bringing some of that security, stability, and safety to others, in my very, very roundabout way,‚Äù Kenzie‚Äôs phone said, in Tattletale‚Äôs voice.

‚ÄúYeah, that‚Äôs it, thank you,‚Äù I said. Kenzie gave me a thumbs up. I felt a bit of the heebie-jeebies at having heard Tattletale‚Äôs voice without being braced for it. It took me a moment to gather my thoughts before I added, ‚ÄúIt makes me wonder what she would say if she were told that Snag and the other two were out for your head.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe could be full of shit,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúShe could be,‚Äù I admitted. ‚ÄúTrouble of dealing with masterminds is you can‚Äôt ever know.‚Äù

‚ÄúMakes me think,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúWe really should have that talk about our group‚Äôs game plan.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt have that talk without Ashley,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúOr Chris,‚Äù Sveta said.

Kenzie turned to look at Chris, before giving us a very unenthused, ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúPretty quick turnaround on your opinion of Chris,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not turned around. It‚Äôs a love-hate relationship,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúSometimes I really like him and sometimes I really don‚Äôt. Right now is one of those times I really don‚Äôt. I was having fun.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere will be other times you can fool around with my power, and with others,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Kenzie said. She looked at Rain and smiled. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre gonna help you with your thing.‚Äù

A bit of a non-sequitur, but I wasn‚Äôt going to draw attention to it. ‚ÄúDo you want to call Ashley or see what‚Äôs holding her up? If she‚Äôs not up to having this conversation, that‚Äôs okay too.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll call her,‚Äù Kenzie said, hopping up from her seat. She wandered off, her eyehook holding her phone to her ear.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll get Chris,‚Äù Sveta said.

As Sveta vacated the space on the bench to my left, I turned to the laptop to my right. I typed up a few things about Rain‚Äôs power, then paged up and down some to look at the entries for the individual powers. There was a lot more to write up before I had an actual outline I could pitch to the Wardens. If they were even interested in working with the overarching cape community on that level.

I hoped they were. The villains had a lot of advantages, from the fact they often had the initiative to the fact that their work often made money, and the fact that the chaos and damage they wrought often created more opportunities, henchmen, and money for them. Heroes who did well, conversely, often put themselves out of work.

One of the few advantages our side had was that the heroes tended to work together. If we did it right, we walked away with allies. I had people like Gilpatrick, Crystal, and Mrs. Yamada.

‚ÄúHow‚Äôs Erin?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs good. She‚Äôs applying for jobs today. We‚Äôre in an awkward spot for it, though, not many locations, a lot of people around our age want those jobs, and it‚Äôs a long drive in to get to work. I think those places open at six. It might mean waking up at four to get to work on time.‚Äù

Sveta dragged Chris to the collection of rocks, benches, and seats. Chris climbed up to his seat, sitting on the rock Kenzie had been using. I was pretty clear he was still blind, from the way he stared off into space.

‚ÄúThere are times I don‚Äôt get to sleep until four,‚Äù Chris said, talking to the open air.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not good,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt do that.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a chance to be independent,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúIf she can get the job. She gives off a good impression, so I can imagine it happening.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúWho is she?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúCan I ask?‚Äù

‚ÄúJust a friend,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve always grown up in the middle of nowhere, so when my family was getting settled after Gold Morning, we saw all the incentives they were offering to people willing to get a headstart on agriculture and it seemed natural, you know?‚Äù

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúErin‚Äôs parents were kind of the opposite. City people through and through, something in them broke after Gold Morning. They couldn‚Äôt bring themselves to join the rat race again, I think. They were given the option for the simple life and they took it. Erin got dragged with.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you connected.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe was having a hard time, because y‚Äôknow, she stands out when a lot of people are hurt and angry and looking to lash out. She went looking for a hiding place and she stumbled on my workshop. She‚Äôs been a real help, from before I even had the therapy, helping me get figured out, listening to me, helping me research. I‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt really know what she gets out of the deal, from me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can think of a few things she gets from you,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúI appreciate you saying that, I‚Äôm not sure I see it though,‚Äù Rain said.

I saw Kenzie react to Ashley‚Äôs appearance before I saw Ashley. She made her way up the less sloped side of the hill, holding a pair of water bottles.

‚ÄúHaving a friend with powers is pretty neat,‚Äù I said to Rain.

‚ÄúYeah. For sure,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúAnd while I don‚Äôt know you that well, you seem very thoughtful.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd there‚Äôs the brooding, mysterious part of it,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúGirls like that. You and Chris are similar like that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI see,‚Äù Rain said. He frowned a bit.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm picturing the expression on your face,‚Äù Chris said, before laughing.

‚ÄúHow long‚Äôs he going to be blind?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúCould be ten minutes, could be an hour or two,‚Äù Kenzie said, as she skip-walked over to sit down at Ashley‚Äôs side as Ashley took her seat.

An hour or two?

‚ÄúYou got anywhere to be, Chris?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúNo family, nobody that cares that much,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm one of the lost boys, living in the institution.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know what that‚Äôs like,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúThe institution. It‚Äôs not fun.‚Äù

‚ÄúPersonally? I don‚Äôt give a shit, and they don‚Äôt give a shit about me, I could disappear tomorrow and nobody would blink.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôd blink,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúYou would,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúBut you‚Äôre lame like that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry to hear about your situation,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine,‚Äù Chris said, with emphasis, still staring off into space. Blindly, he rummaged in one pocket, pulling out a plastic kit. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs— it‚Äôs freeing. All I care about is that I eat three square meals, since nourishment matters for my power, and having a place to sleep. Strip away everything else, and it‚Äôs all any of us want.‚Äù

‚ÄúSome of us want people to keep close to us,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúNot me,‚Äù Chris said. He opened the kit and drew out a pair of pliers.

‚ÄúYour opinions may change as you hit puberty,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm already started on that, I‚Äôm not going to go into any details, and I really don‚Äôt think my feelings are going to change,‚Äù Chris replied. He seemed to reconsider, then said, ‚ÄúI really hope they don‚Äôt.‚Äù

I glanced at Ashley. She‚Äôd been quiet since sitting down. The last time I‚Äôd reached out hadn‚Äôt ended well. Was I supposed to ignore her now, leave her alone while she wound herself down?

‚ÄúHow about we talk about your idea, Tristan?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs getting later in the afternoon,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúAnd Kenzie has dinner with her parents. It would be good to get it out of the way.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can skip it if I have to,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúYou shouldn‚Äôt,‚Äù I said.

Tristan shifted position, metal sliding against smooth stone. ‚ÄúThe plan. We‚Äôve only got the broad strokes worked out, so if you want to help hammer it out, Victoria, it would really help.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

‚ÄúProtecting Rain in the coming weeks is essential. My starting point for thinking about this plan was thinking how we might cover all the bases we want to cover. We need to keep the older members of the group free enough to help Rain with whatever he needs help with. Kenzie wants to do something integral to the group, and while she can help keep an eye out, it‚Äôs easy for her to take too much of a backseat role.‚Äù

‚ÄúAm I taking a frontseat role then?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm— not exactly. There‚Äôs a lot about this that‚Äôs counterintuitive. My first instinct is to think, hey, I want to make money, I want to be out there doing things. But that leaves us open to interference and distraction. So‚Ä¶ what if we go covert?‚Äù

‚ÄúCovert?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúNobody knows Ashley is on the side of the good guys for the time being. She‚Äôs really good at the villainous persona and atmosphere.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúAnd then there‚Äôs Chris, who can be monstrous, appear, disappear, then show up again as someone or something else.‚Äù

I glanced at Chris. Chris had two sets of pliers in his mouth. He was readjusting his braces.

‚ÄúThe masterminds and the organizations are masterminding and getting organized. Hollow Point is one example of that, and Tattletale‚Äôs degree of involvement, that‚Äôs another example. I didn‚Äôt get the impression Tattletale was really aware that we were a team, so I think this works.‚Äù

‚ÄúTake all things mastermind with a grain of salt,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù Tristan said, quickly enough that I wondered if he‚Äôd bothered with that grain of salt. ‚ÄúOkay, so what if we do like— actually, it‚Äôs like Victoria was saying a few minutes ago, about creating and capitalizing on weak points—‚Äù

‚ÄúShe was telling us more about Tattletale,‚Äù Kenzie told Ashley.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúLook, no rush, we do this slow and careful. We put you guys out there, Ashley and Chris can plant cameras, Kenzie handles backend, we gather all the data we can, and we find out what the masterminds are doing and where the organizations are most vulnerable.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen we hit them,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúMaybe. We assess the situation, we maybe even spread disinformation, and then we have discussions, involving other cape teams, maybe. If it seems doable, we hit them. We have a lot going for us if we want to blitz the enemy or ruin a plan in progress. When it‚Äôs time to make our play, we can do big, we can hit hard, and we can move fast. If it doesn‚Äôt seem doable, we sell the info to another cape team.‚Äù

‚ÄúI like that you‚Äôre thinking about the money,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúHow do you sustain things if you‚Äôre going ahead and handling the mission on your own?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm thinking we don‚Äôt,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not wanting to set up a headquarters, we wouldn‚Äôt necessarily have employees or staff, we can figure something out for costume.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a long, hard road to gather that kind of intel and then act on it at just the right time. It‚Äôs a test of patience,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThat patience gets tested further when your pockets are empty.‚Äù

‚ÄúI hear you,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúIt helps some that we have a lot of people here who are subsidized or not entirely out on their own. Kenzie gets money from her parents, Chris has his meals and shelter through the institution.

‚ÄúI think we have an advantage there,‚Äù Sveta said, quiet. ‚ÄúBecause the thing that defines us, and I don‚Äôt think it defined the Irregulars like this, and it didn‚Äôt define the Wards, like Weld described them‚Ä¶ we all need to be out there. We need this. That makes us stick it out.‚Äù

There were nods around the group. Even Chris. The heads that weren‚Äôt nodding were smiling, like Ashley‚Äôs, or looking very serious in a way that made me sure they were in agreement, like Rain was.

I allowed myself to nod as well.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI might be able to make some recommendations about funding, so you won‚Äôt be too starved. If you think you can gather intel that others might be interested in, I can talk to other teams on your behalf, or I can point you in the right direction if you want to handle that yourselves. You‚Äôd tell them you have the capacity to get intel. You may or may not want first dibs on these villains, but whatever happens, if they‚Äôll pay a token amount, you‚Äôll give up the info. It serves a double purpose if you set it up as a dead man‚Äôs switch. Worst comes to worst, the authorities get an email letting them know what you were up to and who you were up against.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôd pay for that, you think?‚Äù Rain asked. ‚ÄúEven if it‚Äôs us saying we‚Äôre taking first dibs, but we‚Äôll give the info anyway?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think it could be sold to them,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúInformation comes at a premium, and every single team out there is wanting as clear a picture of where things stand as possible.‚Äù

‚ÄúI do my thing, Chris does his thing, Kenzie does her thing,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúSveta, Tristan and I help Rain in the meantime. When we have the intel, we hit them. Take out key players, interfere with a key part of their business, and we leave them ruined.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe maybe hit them,‚Äù Tristan said, with emphasis on ‚Äòmaybe‚Äô.

‚ÄúIf we spend the time to get that far, you‚Äôll be itching to see it the rest of the way through,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúAnd then what?‚Äù I asked, before they could get in an argument.

‚ÄúHm?‚Äù

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs assume it‚Äôs a success, or you hand off the intel. What follows?‚Äù

‚ÄúDepends on a lot of factors,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúWe could take another piece of data collected on the way and jump off from there, or we don‚Äôt just take money, and we go to another team and we trade intel for intel. They tell us if they‚Äôve got more tough nuts or tricky areas to tackle, and we use that as our next starting point.‚Äù

I nodded.

‚ÄúWhat are you thinking?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúI‚Ä¶ admit this makes a lot of sense. It may be harder than you‚Äôre picturing. Masterminds cover their asses, organizations have a lot of tools at their disposal.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf we get six pieces of a twenty-piece puzzle and we realize we can‚Äôt take things any further, we can still sell that intel,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúAbsolutely,‚Äô I said. ‚ÄùI‚Äôm trying to think about how that plays out in the long-term.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs the stuff I just said, but I was mostly thinking about the next few steps. I‚Äôd rather make calls based on the now and adapt later, depending on what comes up.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs fair,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm trying to be mindful of consequences, these days. You‚Äôd be making enemies, once people realized what you were doing and the role you‚Äôd played. If you‚Äôre not careful, Ashley and Chris as background observers are cards you can only play a few times, in a limited fashion.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can play me eight times,‚Äù Chris said, pulling the pliers out of his mouth, ‚ÄúAfter that they‚Äôll probably catch on.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt change your head that much, then they‚Äôll catch on sooner than that,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúOn that topic, I‚Äôm not sure I like Chris being out in the field like that,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúI can handle that much.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm thinking Chris gets involved as a distraction. A few minutes at a time, a monster shows up, overturns the status quo. The kind of thing we do once every two weeks or once a month.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah. I‚Äôm good with that,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúI like it,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI hate that I‚Äôm a burden at this stage.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry about that,‚Äù Kenzie said. She reached out to give Rain a pat on the knee with her eyehook. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all burdens in our own screwed up ways.‚Äù

My expression might have betrayed something, because Tristan looked my way.

‚ÄúYea or nay?‚Äù he asked.

‚ÄúIt reminds me of the Las Vegas capes,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúAnd a bit of Watchdog.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs that a bad thing?‚Äù Tristan asked.

Las Vegas had been damned effective, as had Watchdog. But where Las Vegas had been a subtle, careful player with a few questionable, mysterious individuals in their ranks making the most of their backgrounds and skills, much like this team in disposition and direction, they‚Äôd also been a team that had turned villain at a critical time. Watchdog had been careful and scrupulous, making measured moves with the best intel and agents they had at their disposal, and Watchdog hadn‚Äôt survived Gold Morning as an organization.

Those were the only two data points I had, for teams like this. Corruption and annihilation.

I couldn‚Äôt say for sure that it was a bad thing, but I couldn‚Äôt say it was a good thing either.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a thing,‚Äù I said.

Glare — 3.5

The van bobbed with the added weight as I set Kenzie‚Äôs projector-recorder box down. As I moved back, I nearly tripped over Kenzie, who had climbed into the van right behind me.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got the straps, I‚Äôll tie it down,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThank you for doing the heavy lifting. It really helps.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù I said. I squeezed past her and climbed down from the back of the van. ‚ÄúFor the future, if I‚Äôm using my strength, you probably want to keep more of a distance. I wouldn‚Äôt want to bump into you with my power up.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, okay.‚Äù

With Tristan having laid out his plan, the meeting was done, Tristan‚Äôs creations had been dismantled, the rocky walls and barriers broken down and placed with other rocks, and I had my laptop with my gathered notes in my bag.

Kenzie‚Äôs dad was standing by the door to the van. The others were gathered on the sidewalk in front of the library.

‚ÄúAre you going to be okay going home alone?‚Äù Tristan asked Rain.

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôd asked me earlier, I‚Äôd have said yes. I‚Äôm less sure now,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúNo need to be.‚Äù

‚ÄúI want you to know what you‚Äôre up against. I didn‚Äôt do it to scare you, exactly.‚Äù

‚ÄúKnowing what I‚Äôm up against and being scared go hand-in-hand,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúRight now I‚Äôm telling myself we don‚Äôt think Tattletale is free enough to be tracking me down right now, and the others are injured or preoccupied. I‚Äôm probably safe to get home like this, right?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd think so,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd offer to come with you, but it‚Äôs a bit of a long trip.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt want you to go to that trouble, either way.‚Äù

‚ÄúHave you given any thought to moving?‚Äù Tristan asked.

Rain shrugged. ‚ÄúEvery day. Being where I am is tolerable for now, I think. The commute to the city is a pain, but if I imagine they‚Äôre hiring a dozen mercenaries and a few others, then it could be a bigger pain for them.‚Äù

‚ÄúHey Flays-Alive-Man, for this job, we‚Äôre going to need you and your ten superpowered friends to catch a train and spend three and a half hours traveling to the middle of nowhere, and then you have to find our target,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúGod,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt fire up my imagination with names like that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI do want to focus more on your situation,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve talked about the team and what the group is doing, but your situation is pressing. We can‚Äôt keep assuming they‚Äôre preoccupied.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúWe should figure something out, cover any surprises in the short-term while plotting out something workable in the long-term,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI agree. You can send them the wrong signals, but they could try tripping you up too,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúI know, really,‚Äù Rain said. He shifted his weight from one foot to the other, like he was about to say something, then said, ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúI could come with and fly back, or fly over the train and keep an eye out for trouble,‚Äù I said.

I could see Rain‚Äôs reaction, the kneejerk resistance.

‚ÄúOh! I have cameras,‚Äù Kenzie said, ‚ÄúAnd you could use them to communicate. They‚Äôre not too obvious.‚Äù

‚ÄúI could carry a camera,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúJust so long as I could turn it off when I need to.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy would you need to turn it off?‚Äù Kenzie asked.

‚ÄúBecause I have to go to the bathroom sometimes.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy would anyone use a camera to watch someone go to the bathroom?‚Äù Kenzie asked. ‚ÄúNo, wait, I don‚Äôt want to know. I‚Äôve learned my lesson about those sorts of questions. But you can trust me, that‚Äôs not what I‚Äôm about.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad. I still want an off switch.‚Äù

Kenzie rummaged in the back of the van and pulled out a bag. She handed over something looked like a smoke detector in brushed black metal, with a lens in the center. ‚ÄúHere. A camera. You can press down on the lens in the middle and it will alert me. I‚Äôll set it up so it lets the others know too, but I can pick up sound and visuals and pass it on to the others if you need it. This is the battery pack. You can pull it out and the camera won‚Äôt work.‚Äù

‚ÄúSeems simple enough.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhatever you do,‚Äù Kenzie said, reaching out to touch Rain‚Äôs forearm. ‚ÄúDo not put the battery pack in backward, when you re-insert it.‚Äù

Rain looked down at the camera he held with a little bit of trepidation.

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúBecause then it won‚Äôt work,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúYou said it in an ominous voice,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôll help Rain to remember not to put it in backward. Duh.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not going to misfire or blow up?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúWhy do you keep asking that? No. It‚Äôs a camera. There is a very small chance of it blowing up, and if it does then it‚Äôs going to be a very small explosion. Unless you‚Äôre very unlucky and a lot of the things that could make it blow up all happen at once.‚Äù

‚ÄúI guess I trust your tech more than I trust the people who are after me to leave me alone,‚Äù Rain said. He held up the camera. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll hold onto this, then. Thanks.‚Äù

‚ÄúCool,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre welcome.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not going to be looking through it and checking in on me at random, right?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot if you don‚Äôt want me to,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want you to,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúNo offense. It‚Äôs just that the less you know, the less likely it is that one of the people after me decides to come after one of you to try to get info.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúNot a problem.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a bit of a problem, I thought. But not like you‚Äôre imagining.

Kenzie looked back toward her dad. ‚ÄúAnd I should go. You know how to get in contact if you have questions. Do you want a ride? Does anyone?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo thanks,‚Äù Rain said.

Kenzie double and triple checked with the rest of us, then looked over at her dad, who was waiting with barely any change in expression. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to head out then. Bye guys.‚Äù

‚ÄúBye,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúTalk to you again soon,‚Äù I said.

Kenzie climbed into the passenger seat. Her dad glanced over the group, briefly making eye contact with me, before taking a seat behind the wheel. She stuck her hand out the window to give us a bit of a wave as her dad pulled away.

‚ÄúMost uncomfortable car ride,‚Äù Rain said, watching them go.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs that?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúJulien Martin, giving me a ride earlier. Kenzie sent me a text letting me know he was on his way to pick me up. I would have said no if she‚Äôd asked beforehand. He turned up, let me into the car, then the entire way here, didn‚Äôt say a single word. I didn‚Äôt say a thing either.‚Äù

‚ÄúAm I missing context?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs context for Kenzie to share,‚Äù Sveta said, her voice firm.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Rain said, again.

‚ÄúFair,‚Äù I said, even though I wasn‚Äôt sure it was. Not a hundred percent. There was a point where I couldn‚Äôt do everything I needed to do if people were keeping secrets. I didn‚Äôt want to press any buttons or tread on anything sensitive, and there were a lot of buttons and a lot of sensitive points.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll get you up to speed soon,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúBut we have to be fair.‚Äù

‚ÄúOut of curiosity, Sveta, how much wear and tear did your body take out there? Or is it bad of me to ask?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not bad at all,‚Äù Sveta said.

The conversation turned to armor and costumes. I listened with one ear, but my thoughts were on Sveta‚Äôs defense of Kenzie‚Äôs background, and how careful Tristan was in asking about Sveta‚Äôs body.

There was something I‚Äôd noticed with the group, and it was something I‚Äôd fallen prey to myself. When the group was talking, it was almost always in a guarded way. Even Chris did it to a small degree. Ashley too. Conversations were meted out with care, not necessarily so each person was protecting themselves, but so they protected each other. We often slipped back into talking like we were in therapy.

There were cases where individuals protected themselves and cases where individuals were also protected by others. Kenzie had a role as the baby of the team, in a way. There were things she didn‚Äôt disclose and things she was intentionally or unintentionally coy about, despite her overly open personality. That was compounded by how others were ready to step up for her and defend her. That was the security they‚Äôd given her.

I glanced over my shoulder at Ashley, who was hanging back, finishing the second of the bottles of water she‚Äôd brought back with her after going to the library. Ashley was very similar to Kenzie in that department. Unguarded in terms of how open she was about many things, but she had things she didn‚Äôt talk about, and she benefited heavily from the group‚Äôs defense of her.

It was the contract between them, the language they used and their habits, it carried over from the group. It was going to change over time, I was sure, especially if their therapy with Mrs. Yamada ran its course. I wasn‚Äôt sure if that meant the dialogue would become natural, if the contract would be betrayed in small ways, or both.

I was, as much as they‚Äôd asked for my help, the interloper. They protected each other from me, even if it meant Sveta was protecting someone as troubled as Ashley from someone she saw as a friend. I suspected it ran deeper than her wanting to see Ashley‚Äôs humanity win out over the monster.

Getting the information on powers and on the most important things like Ashley‚Äôs situation was easily doable, because it was need-to-know. Where I ran into a stumbling block was that their view on need-to-know and my view differed.

I worried they had too light a view of things. The ones who didn‚Äôt were among the more guarded, and they were being guarded too.

It all knotted together. Was I supposed to be patient and wait for the information to come out? Would it come out only as each crisis reared its head? Or did I push and risk doing damage?

I could push lightly. I waited for Tristan to stop talking about his armor, and the tools he used to fix the scuffs.

I wasn‚Äôt the only one waiting for a break in the conversation. ‚ÄúI should probably go or I‚Äôm going to miss my train.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy offer stands,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúAn eye in the sky, if you think you‚Äôll need it.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd rather—‚Äù

He stopped at that.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Tristan asked.

Rain went on, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs my experience that when you‚Äôre in trouble, people are usually pretty good about offering help and support. People are good like that. I‚Äôve seen it with family members that had babies, and people who lost loved ones. Everyone turns up and offers their support, they bring food, they say they‚Äôll be there. And they are, at first.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou think we‚Äôll get bored of this and not help you later?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúNot bored,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúShit happens. Everyone has their issues, things come up, and then they lose sight of the promises made to new parents, the bereaved, or whoever else.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think that‚Äôs pretty unfair,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs reality,‚Äù Rain said. He looked at me, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nice of you to offer, Victoria, but I‚Äôd rather have you come and keep an eye on things when I feel like I‚Äôm actually in danger, instead of coming now, realizing what a huge pain in the ass it is to fly that far out of your way, and then feeling reluctant when it counts.‚Äù

I thought about reassuring him, pointing out that I‚Äôd traveled from the Bridgeport span to the portal in New Haven to Brockton Bay, several times a week, to get notes, check on the wreckage of the house and visit Crystal‚Äôs family. I didn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúGotcha,‚Äù I said. I‚Äôd pushed, I wasn‚Äôt going to push harder now that the boundary had been raised.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre still blind, Chris?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúYep. It‚Äôs starting to come back, though. Thirty minutes to an hour, I think.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you want someone to stay with you?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúNo. Hell no. Then I‚Äôd feel obligated to make conversation and shit,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a sunny day, there‚Äôs a breeze, the weather is perfect. I‚Äôm going to sit outside and wait and then I‚Äôll make my way back to the institution.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey won‚Äôt be bothered if you‚Äôre late for dinner?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúSo long as I‚Äôm there by lights out, they don‚Äôt care. They‚Äôve got twenty staff and over a thousand kids in the building with dead or missing parents. I eat or I feed myself, I mostly do the chores I‚Äôm assigned, I‚Äôm there when I‚Äôm supposed to be. There‚Äôs lots of others who demand more attention than I do.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt sounds like the children at your institution are pretty vulnerable,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúNobody paying attention to what they‚Äôre doing with their days. Any of you could be pressed into work or preyed on or you could end up disappearing, and nobody would know.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot me,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôd regret it if they tried with me. With triggers being a thing, they might regret it whoever they try it with.‚Äù

I was put in mind of my mom. ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt mean the damage isn‚Äôt done before powers come into the picture.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, well, I dunno,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to relax and wait until my vision comes back. If it takes too long or if I run into trouble, I‚Äôve got another change I was wanting to make today. Keen Vigilance. Perception focused. It‚Äôll give me a fresh set of eyes.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said.

The others got themselves sorted out. Rain, Sveta, and Tristan started their walk to the train station. Chris retreated toward the library.

Ashley remained by the sidewalk, drinking her water. She‚Äôd been dead quiet.

‚ÄúYou good?‚Äù I asked her.

‚ÄúI was dead for years. I‚Äôve been operated on, feeling every last movement of the scalpel, several times. This is nothing, so yeah, I‚Äôm good.‚Äù

She put a curious inflection on the word.

It was eerie to think of Bonesaw‚Äôs involvement in things. Her handling of Ashley here, how the Slaughterhouse Nine had got Blasto which had led to Fume Hood‚Äôs downward spiral. It made me think of Crawler, and it made me think of what had happened to my home town.

To my home, my living room shattered with monsters left lying in places where childhood memories were supposed to be. Monsters that had once been people, a few of them genuinely good and decent.

Heroes, even.

To my family. To the person who had once been closest to me.

‚ÄúRight. Good to hear,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre similar, I think,‚Äù she said.

I paused. I‚Äôd been taking a second to think about how I would gracefully exit. Now I was left to process what she‚Äôd said, and figure out how to gracefully answer that.

‚ÄúShould I take that as a compliment?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúTake it however you like. Them? They‚Äôve experienced hurt. They‚Äôve known horror. Maybe not so much for Kenzie, but she experienced enough hurt that it balances out.‚Äù

‚ÄúI probably shouldn‚Äôt be hearing this,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThey haven‚Äôt seen the worst of it. They haven‚Äôt seen rock bottom and then had someone or something reach up from below and drag them deeper. The Slaughterhouse Nine were that for me. I got the impression from how you talked about Tattletale that she was that for you.‚Äù

No, I thought. Only in small part.

‚ÄúMy first take on you was that you knew enough to be useful. Then you talked about Tattletale, and your reaction to someone who has the information, who‚Äôs careful, and who has resources? You‚Äôre afraid.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm concerned,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI respect it, that fear.‚Äù

‚ÄúConcern,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIf it was just fear for myself, that would be one thing. But I‚Äôm concerned about the others here.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a very concerning world, isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù she asked. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot to be concerned about. You and I, we have our eyes open about that, even if we‚Äôre taking it in very different directions.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre we?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúAren‚Äôt you giving this hero thing an honest shot?‚Äù

‚ÄúI am. It‚Äôs not going to work out, but I‚Äôll be here until the end.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou sound pretty sure about the fact that it‚Äôs going to go south.‚Äù

She tipped back her water bottle, finishing it off, and without even lowering the bottle from her mouth, used her power. Shorter than her prior uses, abrupt. It made its usual cacophony of noise, my ears ringing faintly in its wake, and it pushed her hair up and back, so it took a second to fall back into place.

She caught her balance, taking a second before she stood straight again. Then she looked at me with eyes that had no pupils, no irises, only the white, and only the dark makeup to draw out the eyelashes. Slowly, her pupils faded back in.

All to dispose of a water bottle, apparently, or to make a point.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not even the most fucked up person on this team, Victoria,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI might not even be in the top two. Our therapist knows, and that‚Äôs why she was concerned enough to reach out to you. They, the really fucked up ones, they probably know. But I know it too, which makes me pretty certain.‚Äù

‚ÄúYet you‚Äôre still here,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúSo are you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm cursed with an impulse to help people,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an epidemic,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúGuess so,‚Äù I said. I used my flight, my feet rising an inch or two off the ground. ‚ÄúI think I‚Äôm going to take off.‚Äù

She gave me a small salute, her expression dispassionate.

I didn‚Äôt want to give the impression I was running, so I asked, ‚ÄúSee you in a couple of days, then?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

I flew skyward, at the speed and angle that made even my stomach do that overly light flip-flop at the distance between myself and solid earth. I came to a stop when I couldn‚Äôt see the library anymore.

I didn‚Äôt fly home. I had too many thoughts in my head, and after seeing the others, seeing personalities and outbursts from Tristan‚Äôs comments for Byron to Ashley‚Äôs more dire threats, the powers, the secrets that were being kept or barely suppressed‚Ä¶

I remained in the air, the ground a blur beneath me, the clouds not all that far above me. The city was painted in its golds, its concrete and pavement with yellow paint, its grassy patches, its fields of wheat and corn.

Just me up here, the wind in my ears.

I believed Ashley. It wasn‚Äôt that she was honest, she wasn‚Äôt. She bluffed and she bluffed often. I suspected the bluffs were because she‚Äôd been telling me the truth when she‚Äôd remarked on the common thread between us: we‚Äôd seen some of the worst the world had to offer and we had reason to be afraid.

I believed her when she said there were people on the team who she saw as more ‚Äòmessed up‚Äô than herself. I had my suspicions about who.

Something was up with Chris. Mentally and emotionally he was compromised. Physically, compromised. Socially, in terms of where he fit into the world, again, he was compromised. He‚Äôd almost revealed the least of himself of anyone present.

Rain was another issue.

The team supported and insulated its members, they protected one another from the interlopers and the outside stresses. There were times and places that could be good, but I could just as easily see things go in a direction where outsiders weren‚Äôt sufficiently protected from the group, while the group carried on like this.

My job, in a way.

I‚Äôd keep an eye on all of them, of course. Kenzie could be a danger, and I could see even Sveta going to a bad place, however much I liked her. Tristan was strong, and he spent half of his life locked away in a lightless, motionless prison, only a window that looked out through his brother‚Äôs eyes and listened through his brother‚Äôs ears. It would be so easy for him to go off the deep end. Ashley was unpredictable and dangerous, pure and simple.

Chris I could only keep an eye on. Rain—

I didn‚Äôt fly back to Crystal‚Äôs.

I flew to the train station, and I held a position where I couldn‚Äôt make out the people, but I could make out the train.

I was paranoid, and too many things today had prodded at my paranoia. There were many I was helpless to do much about, but I could act on these suspicions.

A train came, traveling west-to-east. I knew Sveta and Tristan would be boarding it. Had I been on foot, it was the one I would have caught.

When the other train came, traveling the opposite direction, I followed it. I had a pit in my stomach, doing it, but I had a gut feeling that this was part of why Jessica had reached out to me, and why she had been relieved that I was keeping an eye on things.

Yes, they knew things about each other. But they kept secrets. There were evasions, walls that were thrown up.

I just didn‚Äôt understand what Rain was doing. To have a hit out on his head and reject an escort, holding firm to that rejection even after having the danger driven home?

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs going on, Rain?‚Äù I asked. Where I was, suspended in the sky, wind rushing past me, there was nobody to hear.

I was prepared to follow him to Greenwich. It was a lengthy trip, and it left me to think about grabbing dinner, possibly on the trip back. I tempted myself with thoughts of a burger or a good souvlaki roll. Something warm, as I thought on it. This high up, there was no heat radiating up off the ground or nearby surfaces, less sunlight bouncing around with light energy dissipating and becoming heat, and the steady wind flowed past me to swipe the warmth that my body put out. As stakeouts went, this was liable to be cold, and I‚Äôd have to figure out something for bathroom breaks.

As self-imposed missions went, it wasn‚Äôt just hard for me to justify doing this, it was a pretty rough experience. The mind-numbing dullness of a sit-and-watch stakeout combined with the hypnotic nature of a long-distance drive. Drivers, at least, had to watch the road and be mindful of other drivers. I had nothing to help keep my thoughts centered.

From Stratford to Bridgeport. I had my binoculars out, and I watched for trouble, studying the people boarding the train.

Nothing obvious.

The train carried on its way, traveling from the Bridgeport neighborhood to Fairfield span, past the community center that had been attacked at Norfair, and then onward to Norwalk station. Kenzie‚Äôs neighborhood.

There were stops where only a pair of people left, stops where only a few got on, and Norwalk, unfortunately, was one of the major stations. I couldn‚Äôt track everyone that boarded.

My thoughts were preoccupied, thinking about what I was doing, my doubts, my frustration that I couldn‚Äôt effectively watch out for trouble while doing this the way I was doing it. It was too easy for someone with powers to board the train and go after Rain while uncostumed. Was it likely? No. But I wanted to justify what I was doing.

There was a chance, though, that when Rain got off the train, he would be followed by fellow passengers until he was in a place where he could be attacked. I could watch out for that.

I could watch out for any unexpected stops, and I could keep an eye out for the old staples of railway robberies and ambushes — trains moved slowest when they went around corners, so I could keep an eye out for ambushes and unexpected boardings that took place in those locations.

With my thoughts caught up in things as they were, I nearly missed it.

The train was old-fashioned in look, cars linked by couplings, and passengers could move between cars, with the space between each car being open to the air. Periodically passengers would step out to smoke or get fresh air. Most were parents with kids.

At the caboose, a figure had stepped out onto the back. Rain.

He climbed over the railing and jumped, while the train was going well over a hundred miles an hour.

Hands out to his side, his bag in one hand, other empty, his feet touched the slope, and he stopped. No momentum, nothing to suggest he‚Äôd been on a speeding train a matter of seconds ago. The fact he stood on a slope didn‚Äôt seem to matter, as he didn‚Äôt slide, slip, or fall.

He looked around, but he didn‚Äôt look up, and I wasn‚Äôt sure he would have seen me if he had. He jogged down the slope, and walked across a field. Past the field was mostly wilderness and dirt road.

Rain walked for ten minutes to get where he was going. Erin had parked under a modest little bridge in a town with one gas station.

I didn‚Äôt feel good, watching them interact. I felt guilty for spying, even though his actions proved he was being dishonest. I watched Rain make conversation with his friend. Minutes, where he did most of the talking, pacing some, while Erin leaned against the side of the vehicle.

He must have asked something, because Erin shifted position, reaching through the window. A second later, she drew her hand out. She had a handgun.

It didn‚Äôt mean anything. This was justifiable, given his situation. Lying about where he lived and where he was going was justifiable. Even his friend carrying a gun made sense, when he was being hunted.

His story about how they met and where she came from‚Ä¶ I wasn‚Äôt sure. It didn‚Äôt feel like I knew the whole of it.

If they‚Äôd traveled again, I might have watched to see where they went. If they‚Äôd gone to one of the smaller equivalents of Hollow Point, it might have told me something. If they met certain people, it might have proven out my suspicion.

They went to get ice cream in the dinky one gas-station town, and I couldn‚Äôt conscience staying to watch.

I flew home.

‚äô

I let myself into Crystal‚Äôs apartment through the sliding balcony door.

‚Äú‚Ä¶ave site?‚Äù a male voice.

‚ÄúWhenever I‚Äôm traveling in that direction,‚Äù Crystal said.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs good to hear. I keep meaning to travel out that way, but‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a universe away. I can go with you sometime, if you want.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat might be nice.‚Äù

I shut the balcony door. I could have closed it silently, but I didn‚Äôt.

Crystal, standing at one corner of the living room, had the door open, but she stood in between the door and doorframe in such a way that her body filled the gap. She twisted around to look at me, and I saw a forcefield start to be painted out.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay,‚Äù I said.

The forcefield winked out.

‚ÄúYou sure?‚Äù she asked.

I nodded.

She opened the door wider. My dad was in the hallway, wearing a sleeveless top with a hood, in a very light fabric, and yoga pants of similar light weight. A gym bag sat on the floor by his feet.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been flying,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs good,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs really positive.‚Äù

‚ÄúI guess,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúHow are you?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm noticing how empty my apartment feels, a lot. That‚Äôs not me trying to guilt you. It‚Äôs me realizing where I‚Äôve wound up and wondering how I got myself here.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúDo you want to invite him in?‚Äù Crystal asked. ‚ÄúI can fuck off if you need me to. Or you can take over door duty?‚Äù

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt ask you to fuck off in your own place. Are you getting tired of standing guard?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúA bit.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe can invite him in.‚Äù

My dad entered the apartment. ‚ÄúSorry to drop in.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs that what this is?‚Äù

‚ÄúI worry, when you drop all communication. I thought I would at least ask Crystal if you were okay.‚Äù

‚ÄúI see,‚Äù I said. I walked around behind the couch, putting it between myself and him, and leaned forward on the back of it.

He took a seat on the armrest of the armchair, one foot on the ground. ‚ÄúI want you to know that what happened at your mom‚Äôs house, I‚Äôm sorry about that. It wasn‚Äôt right.‚Äù

‚ÄúI appreciate that. I‚Ä¶ I wish I could tell you that I was sorry for how I reacted there. But I don‚Äôt know if I can.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt ask you to,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI think any and all of us should be understanding when it comes to old wounds.‚Äù

Old wounds, I thought.

Were they that old? Didn‚Äôt ‚Äòold‚Äô presume they‚Äôd healed over or that things had been addressed or mended somehow?

‚ÄúI guess,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúWhat mom did, I was pretty vocal about why I was upset about it. Did Crystal explain why I was bothered by what you did?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe deflected my question when I asked.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you noticed it was a deflection,‚Äù Crystal said, ‚ÄúI need to work on my patter more.‚Äù

‚ÄúJust a bit more,‚Äù my dad said, smiling slightly.

‚ÄúSorry to interrupt,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay,‚Äù I said. I paused. ‚ÄúYou realize, dad, the reason I felt betrayed wasn‚Äôt that I thought you were in on it or anything, right? I felt betrayed because you let yourself believe mom‚Äôs words more than you believed everything you saw in years of living with me, after visiting me in the asylum, after seeing how I function and how I don‚Äôt function.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to try to defend myself,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre absolutely right. I let myself be stupid. I have a way of doing that when I‚Äôm around your mom.‚Äù

‚ÄúI just don‚Äôt understand how you wouldn‚Äôt just stop and realize it doesn‚Äôt make sense. When you know about the nightmares and the fact I hadn‚Äôt flown in months, and the fact I don‚Äôt even want to talk about her, you‚Äôll believe I‚Äôd be willing to meet her face to face and have a meal?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that clear cut. Your mother is a clever woman, to the point she can outsmart herself. She has good instincts when it comes to getting people on her side, too. I‚Äôve been missing home, the past few years, and seeing the woman I still love being warm for the first time in‚Ä¶‚Äù

He trailed off.

‚ÄúSince twenty-eleven,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù my dad said. ‚ÄúWith food I‚Äôve been aching for for just as long already cooking, the kitchen and barbecue rich with that smell. Things, like I said, that make me stupid.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat food was it?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúLaser seared kebabs,‚Äù Crystal said.

I bit my lip. Family recipe. With my lip still between my teeth, I said, ‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not making excuses,‚Äù my dad said. ‚ÄúI should have clued in. When Amy turned up and I knew you were coming, it wasn‚Äôt framed like a reconciliation. It was framed as you knowing everyone was coming and you would have things to get off your chest. Carol said she would referee and I knew it would go poorly if it was just her, so I offered to help. While I was offering I wasn‚Äôt stopping to think.‚Äù

‚ÄúWas a part of it you just wanting things to be normal again? The four person nuclear family back together?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not about to lie here. I— yeah. Yes.‚Äù

It hurt, hearing that. Knowing my dad and where he wanted to be were that far away from where I was and where I wanted to be.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI let my guard down when I should have had it up to protect you. I wanted you to hear that apology, and I wanted to make sure you were alright.‚Äù

‚ÄúCrystal and I are looking after each other,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúAbsolutely,‚Äù Crystal said.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs great,‚Äù my dad said.

I rubbed my arm, wrist to shoulder. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm giving some limited direction to a team of heroes right now. It‚Äôs messy.‚Äù

‚ÄúAny team is bound to be. It‚Äôs good that you‚Äôre doing that.‚Äù

‚ÄúMessier than most,‚Äù I said. I paused. ‚ÄúTop one percent of messy.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh, I see,‚Äù my dad said. He rubbed his chin. It was late enough in the day that the stubble he usually had on his chin was more of a shadow. ‚ÄúThe Dallon-Pelham family never does anything the easy way, does it?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo we don‚Äôt,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúCan I help?‚Äù he asked. ‚ÄúAdvice, support? I don‚Äôt have a lot of money, but‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got the team outlined on my laptop. Six people, either under eighteen or in the vicinity of eighteen. One complicated case, age-wise. Um, this doesn‚Äôt leave this room, right?‚Äù

Nods from both Crystal and my dad.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôll probably go covert. Gather and sell info. I think I can pitch that to the big teams and get the initial funding. I might be able to get costumes through them as well.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey have the infrastructure set up for costumes,‚Äù my dad said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôve got most current members outfitted, and I‚Äôve heard rumor of them branching out to supply other teams and heroes. I would be very surprised if they said it wasn‚Äôt doable.‚Äù

‚ÄúPerfect,‚Äù I said. That helped if and when it came to negotiating. I held up my hand. ‚ÄúFunding, costumes, target‚Ä¶ target is hard to pin down. A lot of low-level threats out there, banding together.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre keeping an eye out for the criminal populations that aren‚Äôt joining larger groups, the places you want to keep an eye on are the Cabin, the Tea-Shop, the Pitstop, the Rail, and the Greens. Those last three places are pretty seedy and traditional villain bars. The others are villain bars without the bar part.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat about the ones who are hooked into bigger groups?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúThat gets more complicated, and it‚Äôs less about the places to watch and more about the names to keep an ear out for,‚Äù my dad said. ‚ÄúMarquis, Goddess, Lord of Loss, Mama Mathers, the Crowley brothers, Deader and Goner, Barrow.‚Äù

I knew the names and I knew where they were situated. No big surprises there. I nodded to myself. Marquis. So casually mentioned.

‚ÄúHow messy is it?‚Äù my dad asked, his voice softer.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre young, some of them are kids, and I‚Äôm not positive they‚Äôre all going to survive the next two weeks,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs not even— there‚Äôs enough other mess I could almost forget about that danger hanging over their heads.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve taken them under your wing?‚Äù

‚ÄúYep. I‚Äôm going to at least point them in the right direction, I hope. I might be the wrong person for the job, but someone has to do it, right?‚Äù

‚ÄúWow,‚Äù my dad said, barely audible.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

He shook his head. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to articulate.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm trying to play this slow, keep it calm. I know a lot and I‚Äôve been down some of these roads. I‚Äôm hopeful I can at least keep things from getting out of control.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat may be a tall order,‚Äù Crystal said.

‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIf they absolutely insist on getting out there and mixing things up, I‚Äôll point them in the direction of the asshole villains who are ramping up their activity and taking things over. The nascent Tattletales and Marquises. Kneecap them or their plans before they can get too big.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou really are your mother‚Äôs daughter,‚Äù my dad said.

My eyebrows went about as high up as they could as I turned my full attention toward him.

‚ÄúWhat you said before, and what you said just now. Those words could have come from her mouth in a different time and place.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt winning points with me,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not here to win points,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI want to make sure you‚Äôre safe, sane, and healthy.‚Äù

I noticed the implication of what he was saying. That taking this course might not be one of those three things.

‚ÄúWhat should I be doing different?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think any of it is wrong, but I haven‚Äôt always been the best judge in the moment. I‚Äôd say CYA.‚Äù

‚ÄúOn what front?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúDo you have counsel on call?‚Äù

‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt aware we even had a legal system yet.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt, but it‚Äôs coming soon.‚Äù

Counsel on call. It was common for new teams of heroes to have a lawyer available, who they could call and outline the situation to before they took action. Covering their asses, making sure the arrests could stick, that there was a voice with the authority and knowledge to talk to the police and courts if and when the heroes‚Äô actions were questioned in more depth.

It wasn‚Äôt a bad idea. It hobbled things, slowed them down, it was a bit of a headache‚Ä¶ but having a lawyer as a hoop to jump through could restrain some of the more impulsive parts of the team. I‚Äôd have to run it by them, but it made sense.

‚ÄúI could ask around,‚Äù my dad offered. ‚ÄúBut if you really wanted a good perspective on who you could talk to, there are better people to ask.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou mean mom,‚Äù I said.

My dad nodded.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. I clenched my fist and relaxed it. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll talk to her.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou really want this.‚Äù

I thought of the team when it had been operating together, playing off one another, being good at what they did. I thought of Tattletale and her version of my hometown and how much I really wanted her and people like her to lose every reason they had to be smug and confident.

I wanted to bring those two ideas together into a concrete reality, and I wanted it badly enough I was willing to go have a conversation with my mom when I was really fucking pissed at her.

If it meant wrangling this team that was going to do what they were doing whether I was involved or not, I‚Äôd do that.

‚ÄúI feel like whatever I say, you‚Äôre going to say I‚Äôm just like mom again, and then I‚Äôm going to be mad at you,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúCan‚Äôt have that,‚Äù my dad said.

‚ÄúPutting all of that stuff aside,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIf I walked away, if I left it alone, I‚Äôm scared of what would happen to people who didn‚Äôt deserve it. I can‚Äôt do that. I don‚Äôt know if that‚Äôs the Carol in me talking, but it‚Äôs the truth.‚Äù

My dad nodded to himself. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not your mom talking, I‚Äôm pretty sure. Similar, but‚Ä¶ not your mom.‚Äù

He didn‚Äôt even need to say it. The moment I‚Äôd seen the look on his face as he‚Äôd opened his mouth, I‚Äôd realized who I‚Äôd been echoing.

Glare — 3.6

Group Text (@ Ashley Stillons, Chris Elman, Kenzie Martin, Rain Frazier, Sveta Karelia, Tristan Vera)

Me: Morning, everyone. I‚Äôm planning to swing by the Wardens HQ today. Some Qs for people, going to talk to a family member about what you guys might need to do legally.
Me: In interest of not taking over your thing, anyone want to come with? You can make calls & be involved

Ashley S: I have appointments

Sveta K: I can come. I know my way around.

Kenzie M: I‚Äôll come! are you going in the morning or afternoon?
Kenzie M: I can have my parents call in to school and get me out for the day if I have to

Sveta K: I don‚Äôt want your schoolwork to suffer

Me: Afternoon

Kenzie M: I‚Äôm an A+ student I can miss a day

Sveta K: No you can‚Äôt.

Me: It‚Äôs best to stick to the rules of the old days. Try to keep grades where they were before you joined a team. If you can miss your study group for this that‚Äôs ok. We meet at 2

Kenzie M: coo

Rain F: Can‚Äôt make it

Tristan V: count me in

Me: Sveta, Tristan, Kenzie, & me then. Chris is welcome if he wants. 2pm at the front doors. Take extra time to travel, P.transportation strike may futz things up

‚äô
