I‚Äôd had to take the train to get to the Wardens‚Äô HQ. It was a fortress of a building, indomitable, and it was situated near the largest cluster of portals in Gimel, very possibly the largest cluster of portals in all the known worlds.

I looked up at a knight in plate armor with his bowed head, both hands on the pommel of a sword, with the tip resting on the ground. A cloth wrap partially covered the legs, like a flag worn around the waist, long enough to reach the knees in front, and to drape near the ankles at the back. Two shields stood behind the figure, hanging in the air at a height and position reminiscent of folded wings.

It was typically simplified when shrunk down for website images and badges, the position of arms, hands and shields suggesting the lines of a ‚ÄòW‚Äô for the first letter of ‚ÄòWardens‚Äô. Here, it was four stories of statue, built into the front face of the building.

It put me in mind of Gilpatrick‚Äôs speech. Five pounds of gun, fifteen pounds of armor? No. Here, at this scale, it was fifty tons of sword, a hundred and fifty tons of armor and shield. Every inch and pound of its composition was symbolism.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs something, isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs something.‚Äù

I turned to look at him. He‚Äôd just walked up to stand beside me. He‚Äôd tidied his hair some. I had the impression he‚Äôd started to dress up for the occasion and his other impulses stylewise had taken over. His shirt was a button-up, red silk, with buttons in twos at the regular intervals. He wore it very casually, with the sleeves rolled up and the buttons undone at the collarbone. He‚Äôd paired it with a nice pair of black jeans, and he‚Äôd painted his hair a red that more closely matched his shirt.

‚ÄúReminds me of that video that circulated online for a bit. Chevalier and the last fight against Behemoth,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúAbsolutely,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúProbably intentional. It‚Äôs a good mental image to have, the hard fight and the great improvements that follow.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd the disaster that followed that?‚Äù Tristan asked.

I frowned at him.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs reality,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a little pessimistic,‚Äù I said. I glanced back. I spotted Sveta making her way up the steps from the sidewalk to the raised bit of ground in front of the building. ‚ÄúHey!‚Äù

She wore a black dress that gathered together as a halter neck, with tights covering the legs. She‚Äôd redone some of the paint on her arms and shoulders, the paint around the ball joint and along the shell that encased each arm fresh and glossy.

‚ÄúYou guys dressed up a bit,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWe exchanged some texts,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúI think we psyched each other up some.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was redoing my paint after all the running around and tree climbing yesterday,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI started overthinking things.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou look good,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThank you. You too.‚Äù I was wearing a very similar outfit to when I‚Äôd been job hunting.

Kenzie was last to catch up to us, running up the stairs. Knee-high socks, a skirt with overlapping stripes, and a blue sweater in a light material, worn over a shirt with the collar poking up through the neckhole. The pin in her hair looked like a bow, but it was two-dimensional and metal.

‚ÄúDid you go home to change?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúYou actually wore that to school?‚Äù he asked.

‚ÄúIt looks nice, thank you very much,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúI agree,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI might have worn something similar when I was around Kenzie‚Äôs age.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can understand you not getting bullied,‚Äù Tristan told me. ‚ÄúYour parents are superheroes.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt get bullied either,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt mind if I did. It would at least mean my classmates would pay attention to me.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúFeels like everyone‚Äôs busy with their own thing,‚Äù Kenzie said. She looked up at the statue that stood in relief from the front of the Wardens‚Äô headquarters. ‚ÄúStill hurting from recent losses.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll see what we can do to keep future losses from happening,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúAbsolutely,‚Äù Kenzie said.

Inside the building, statues of key members stood off to either side of the lobby. Chevalier, Narwhal, Valkyrie, Legend, Cinereal, Stonewall, Topflight and Miss Militia. The building was set up so the people on the second, third, and fourth floors could stand at the glass railings and look down at the lobby, and vice versa. People in business clothes were walking every which way, upstairs, and people on the ground floor were free to peruse the gift shop or wait for tours.

There were larger display boards set up around the edges of the lobby, much like the maps that were stationed around malls, but these showed off the icons for each of the teams under the Wardens‚Äô umbrella. They might have been touchscreens. There were screens for Advance Guard, Foresight, the Attendant, the Shepherds, and smaller teams like the Kings of the Hill, the Wayfinders, and the Navigators. The screen for the Attendant was still up, but it was dark, only the faint outline of the Attendants‚Äô icon on the screen. The Shepherd‚Äôs screen had been moved forward and to a position of more prominence.

It was darker than the PRT offices had been. The aesthetic of the PRT of yesteryear had always been predominantly white, with black stenciled letters and icons, the periodic bit of chrome or mirror when tech was required. Here, it was dark stone, lined in gold or brass, and the lighting made me think of a cinema with lights set on high ceilings and tuned to be unobtrusive. It was transparent and open in layout and the suggestion of there being very few barriers, like with the glass railings, or the way that it really looked like anyone on the ground floor could go anywhere without checkpoints or security.

‚ÄúWhere are we going?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúI should check on my mom first, see if she‚Äôs free for a short conversation.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhere is she?‚Äù

‚ÄúLegal or Liaison. I‚Äôve been here twice before, but the first time they were still getting everything put together, and I don‚Äôt remember much from the second.‚Äù

Sveta turned around slowly, then pointed.

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you on good terms with your parents these days?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm‚Ä¶‚Äù I started. ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs she going to help?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that kind of bad terms, where she‚Äôd say no, I don‚Äôt think.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs it the kind of bad terms where you invite someone to come with you so you don‚Äôt have to worry about the ‚Äòrents being super embarrassing and lame?‚Äù Kenzie asked.

‚ÄúIf I had any idea on what she might say or do then this would be easier,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôll be fine.‚Äù

The stairs led from either side of the front desk to the second floor, going around the statue-in-relief that mirrored the one on the front of the building. The security checkpoint was on the second floor, more or less hidden behind the statue and the slab it stood out from. Glass walls separated the walkway from the offices and departments around the building exterior.

‚ÄúNames?‚Äù the man at the desk asked.

‚ÄúVictoria Dallon, Sveta Karelia, Kenzie Martin, Tristan Vera,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúIntentions?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe have an appointment with Foresight on the fifth floor. I was also hoping to stop in and see my mom at her workplace. I‚Äôm not sure if she‚Äôs at Legal or Liaison right now.‚Äù

‚ÄúHer name?‚Äù

‚ÄúCarol Dallon.‚Äù

‚ÄúOne second.‚Äù

The person made a phone call. I waited, a little nervous, emotions stirred up. Anger, frustration, disappointment, worry.

Kenzie had her chin at the top of the railing, as she looked down at the lobby. Sveta stood next to her, with Tristan off to one side.

‚ÄúIs Weld getting a statue?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúNot for a while,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs more for people who‚Äôve put in the years, and he only just got in. He‚Äôs got a preliminary thing in the gift shop.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo shit? Awesome. We should stop in at the gift shop before we leave.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre such a kid,‚Äù Kenzie said, sticking out her tongue at Tristan. He reached out to muss up her hair and she ducked back out of the way.

‚ÄúVictoria, was it?‚Äù the person at the desk asked.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYour mother says you can go up. She‚Äôs at Legal on the third floor. She‚Äôll take her break when you arrive, so you‚Äôll have about fifteen minutes.‚Äù

I resisted the urge to wince. Fifteen minutes was too much. Still, saying that would cause problems. ‚ÄúGreat.‚Äù

‚ÄúGive me five seconds, and I‚Äôll give you your guest ID cards. Can your friends come to the desk?‚Äù

We lined up in front of the desk. The printer didn‚Äôt take long, spitting out four cards in four seconds.

‚ÄúCheck your names are accurate, please, and— there seems to be a problem with miss‚Ä¶ Kenzie?‚Äù

He turned the card around. A slash of distortion masked Kenzie‚Äôs face, tracing from her cheekbone to one corner of her forehead. It looked like the heavy compression artifacting that came with any image that had been compressed too many times, but it was dense to the point that her eyes, nose, and cheekbone were almost completely covered.

‚ÄúDo you want to try again?‚Äù Kenzie asked. She had her phone in her hand as she clasped her hands behind her back. I saw the screen momentarily light up.

The man tapped at the keyboard for a few seconds, then turned around to grab the card as the machine spat it out. He gave a singular nod and passed the card with its attached lanyard to Kenzie. Picture normal.

We headed for the stairs up to the third floor.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know they were going to take our photos,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúWhat are you even doing, obscuring your face like that?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not on purpose, obviously, it‚Äôs a byproduct of tech I‚Äôm wearing.‚Äù

Once we reached the third floor, there was less in the way of civilian-facing offices, and there were more people in suits and business clothes. The glass wall had letters applied to it. Just ‚Äò303 — LEGAL‚Äô.

My mom had had a study back at our house, with the hundred or so legal tomes with all of the case history, precedent, and whatever else, on top of the books we‚Äôd fashioned ourselves, binding in a variety of ways, saving team stuff, parahuman case files we‚Äôd printed off the net, and more.

This was that, it was the same kind of heavy oak desks that my mom had had in her study, the shelves, the desk lamps and the scattered paperwork that had yet to be gathered together and bound. It was files and filing cabinets, a storm of legality as if a giant had sneezed in a legal office.

My mom might have been one of the older people around. A lot of the lawyers looked young, and at two in the afternoon, jackets were off and slung on the backs of chairs, sleeves were rolled up and perfect hairstyles were just a little bit messed up. She was doing a lot of the talking, taking charge and getting people organized.

A young lady approached us at the doorway. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre wanting to lay charges against the Wardens, or if you have witness testimony to give, you‚Äôll want to go to Casework on the second floor. I know it‚Äôs confusing.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy mom is Carol Dallon, I‚Äôm just stopping in to ask a question. The people at check-in said it was okay.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh wow, yeah, look at you. I definitely see the resemblance. Your mom is awesome, you know.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù I said, my eyebrows going up momentarily.

The lady stepped away to fetch my mom.

The feeling of trepidation got worse as I watched my mom walk toward me. It was hard to divorce this scene and image with my memory of being on the street outside my mom‚Äôs house, the hurt and the feelings there.

My mom smiled, acknowledging the other three. ‚ÄúVictoria. This is a pleasant surprise.‚Äù

‚ÄúI had a conversation with dad last night. He suggested that you might be the person to ask for this thing these guys are doing.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù my mom said. She barely seemed fazed by that. ‚ÄúJust business?‚Äù

‚ÄúMore or less,‚Äù I said.

Man, I was still so pissed at her. I was more pissed somehow that she was being nice and casual.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm happy to help however you need it,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThe only issue is I can‚Äôt step away right this minute. We‚Äôre waiting on a phone call from some people in the would-be government, and my coworker is away on a late lunch.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need you to step away,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThese guys are starting up a team. Dad suggested they‚Äôd do best if they had someone legal to call up before any big moves. Make sure charges stick.‚Äù

My mom looked over at the three. Kenzie put her hand up in a small wave.

‚ÄúIs that Sveta?‚Äù

‚ÄúHi, Mrs. Dallon.‚Äù

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt recognize you at first. I can‚Äôt believe it,‚Äù my mom said. She approached Sveta, taking Sveta‚Äôs hands and lifting them up. ‚ÄúWhat beautiful work.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm pleased with it,‚Äù Sveta said, ducking her head a bit.

‚ÄúAnd the art— is this yours? It reminds me of what I saw you working on during one of my visits.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs mine.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs stellar,‚Äù my mom said.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt suppose you‚Äôd know someone you could put us in touch with?‚Äù I asked, more tense than I‚Äôd wanted to sound.

‚ÄúI can ask around. Are you paying them?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think we‚Äôd have to,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre pretty overloaded right now. I can‚Äôt make promises.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think the team has any major moves planned for early in their career,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúHaving someone available a month from now or two months from now might be good.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll see what I can do, but I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if we‚Äôre still moving at this clip two months from now.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat do you do?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre lobbying on behalf of the Wardens. The government is figuring out the law as we speak, and we‚Äôre trying to figure out the most effective approach to handle law and parahumans and how they interact in the new world. A lot of precedent, citing past history, pulling from the law of Earth Bet.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt sounds heavy,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre deciding the legal fabric of the new world. It is,‚Äù my mom said.

‚ÄúCan you sound some people out?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúHaving someone we could trust to be discreet would be ideal. It wouldn‚Äôt be heavy.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll ask around. I know we‚Äôve got a few ex-law students who are in limbo,‚Äù my mom said. She gave me a look. ‚ÄúThey could use the extra funds, and they should have enough knowledge of the system as it stands. They‚Äôre even on the ground floor for the legal system we may end up with, if we‚Äôre successful here.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll discuss and I‚Äôll look at the books, and we‚Äôll see if we can pay them something fair.‚Äù

Keep it business.

‚ÄúWould you come to dinner tonight?‚Äù she asked. ‚ÄúWe can talk. If I have a better idea of what you‚Äôre doing, I can find you a better fit.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd really rather not,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúCommunication is key. We should talk.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnother time,‚Äù I said. Weeks or months from now.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd like to invite your sister to a sit-down.‚Äù

My dignity and grace were dashed away, just like that. A startling, painful jar from reality to somewhere else. The lights of the brightly lit legal office seemed too bright and the dark shadows and the dimly lit building interior of the Wardens HQ and its lobby seemed too dark.

It was very, very hard, in the moment, to separate my recollection of being outside the house with her inside that house, from this, and to convince myself that she wasn‚Äôt here, somewhere nearby.

‚ÄúNah,‚Äù I said. My voice too soft.

‚ÄúVictoria—‚Äù

‚ÄúMom,‚Äù I said, my voice sharp. ‚ÄúDo you want this conversation to go in the same direction as the one at the barbecue?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs up to you,‚Äù she said.

I thought about saying something regrettable.

‚ÄúBye mom. Good luck with your thing.‚Äù

She looked like she might say something, but she smiled instead, and said, ‚ÄúGood luck with yours.‚Äù

I turned to go, and the others followed.

We walked a little way around the circumference of the floor, between the offices to our right and the railing to our left, until we were a distance away from the legal department. I leaned on the railing, and wrapped one of my hands around the other, squeezing it.

Sveta put an arm around me, and then Kenzie walked up to the other side of me and put a hand on my back.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm okay,‚Äù I said.

There wasn‚Äôt an immediate response.

‚ÄúShe was never my favorite person,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúYou seemed to get along with her before.‚Äù

Sveta shook her head, hair flying out a little ways. ‚ÄúYou were always really down when she was due to visit, and you were down when she missed visits. And you were down after she came.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was down all the time.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was different kinds.‚Äù

‚ÄúFamily‚Äôs hard,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúIt really sucks sometimes.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúFamily can be the best and it can be the worst.‚Äù

Sveta let her arm slide off my shoulder. It settled on Kenzie‚Äôs head with a faint clack.

‚ÄúOw,‚Äù Kenzie said.

Sveta‚Äôs fingers lifted up, then came down, in a pat.

I stood straighter, and Sveta moved a bit away, her arm reeling in, giving me freedom to stand back. ‚ÄúHopefully this gets you guys one step closer to being a team with everything you need. We should go talk to Foresight and see if we can get you the rest of the way.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôre we talking about with Foresight?‚Äù

‚ÄúJurisdiction,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThere might be a few other pieces of ground to cover, finances, selling info.‚Äù

‚ÄúSounds good,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúYou up to talking about the kind of info you can gather, Kenz?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think so.‚Äù

The fifth floor wasn‚Äôt built around a hole in the floor like the bottom four were. There wasn‚Äôt a view of the lobby, a railing, or anything of the sort. Another security checkpoint was set up at the base of the stairs. With our lanyards and guest IDs, we were clear to go. Our arrival was preceded by a shift in lights visible from the stairwell.

Masks on.

The floor plan was closer to a proper office building, with hallways studded with posters and pictures of team members and leaders, teams, and framed news articles. The hallway to the right of us had ‚ÄòSHEPHERDS‚Äô and a shepherd‚Äôs crook running down the length of it, a burgundy stripe of paint lit up by lights on the underside of the crook. Red-brown colors to the wall, and the articles and pictures were all for the Shepherds.

In the hallway to our left, Foresight, blue and black paint and lights, Foresight members and victories on the wall opposite.

A door opened and a few Shepherds stepped out into the hall.

‚ÄúHoly shit,‚Äù one said.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù Tristan said, under his breath.

It was the moon girl, from my job interview with Attendant. She was the one who had urged me away from the Fallen. I was hardly enthused to see her either.

‚ÄúTristan,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúTell me you‚Äôre not interviewing for a team.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got the team already.‚Äù

She pursed her lips together.

‚ÄúHistory, Moonsong?‚Äù someone asked.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Moonsong said. ‚ÄúTribute knows.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù the guy who was apparently ‚ÄòTribute‚Äô said. He wore what looked like a hypermodernized version of the suit of armor with the cape over one shoulder. It wasn‚Äôt old fashioned armor, though. It was panels on a bodysuit, and the cape was cut to cling close to his body, angular for flowing cloth, with glowing lines where the sharp angles were. ‚ÄúHistory is putting it lightly.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre late for an appointment,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the guys who are talking to Foresight,‚Äù someone else said. ‚ÄúThey mentioned something like that.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. Then, aware of the opening in the conversation, I elaborated with, ‚ÄúHello again, Moonsong.‚Äù

‚ÄúHello,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWhat was your name again?‚Äù

‚ÄúVictoria.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou seemed cool, Victoria. What are you doing with this bastard?‚Äù

‚ÄúWow,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúJust helping out,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt need it, and he doesn‚Äôt deserve it.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhatever‚Äôs in the past, he gets his second chance, like anyone. He wants to help people, and I‚Äôm going to help him do that.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs one of the monsters you help save people from,‚Äù Moonsong said. ‚ÄúYou get that, right?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not fair,‚Äù Kenzie said.

She stopped as Tristan put one hand out in front of her, keeping her from jumping forward in his defense.

‚ÄúTribute and I arrested him,‚Äù Moonsong said. ‚ÄúYou know that, right?‚Äù

I could see the lines in Tristan‚Äôs jaw standing out. He said, ‚ÄúI know. I remember.‚Äù

‚ÄúI want to see Byron,‚Äù Moonsong said.

‚ÄúNot your call. His turn isn‚Äôt until later.‚Äù

There was a shudder, and then my hair started to move. The light further down the hallway seemed to grow darker, and my stomach lurched in a sensation that I connected to a lot of aerial acrobatics.

‚ÄúYou want to pick a fight here?‚Äù Tristan asked.

Tribute shifted his footing, stepping forward a little, and clasped his hands in front of his groin. With his head bowed slightly, he was faintly reminiscent of the Wardens‚Äô emblem.

I stepped forward, ready to put myself between them, and I felt the stomach-lurching sensation again. My leg buckled, and I nearly fell.

My hair was floating now, and my legs were straining, almost locked in position with the stress of keeping me upright.

Gravity manipulation, but somehow a mix of zero-grav and enhanced gravity.

I flew instead of walking, and it was hard to keep my position. I stopped when I was between Tristan and the other two. ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt helpful.‚Äù

‚ÄúVictoria,‚Äù Moonsong said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to tell you how this goes.‚Äù

I felt the gravity shift again, an attempt to put me down against the floor, and threw up my forcefield to avoid twisting my ankle or hitting the ground too hard. I was glad my skirt wasn‚Äôt the kind that could flip up, as it hugged my thighs, but my midriff was exposed now.

‚ÄúTristan joins the team, and he charms the pants off of everyone he meets. He‚Äôs good at the stuff he does in front of the camera, he‚Äôs good at the hero stuff, he‚Äôs strong. He gets decent grades, he makes friends, he finds allies and he works on them. Because that‚Äôs what sociopaths do. He doesn‚Äôt actually care about them.‚Äù

‚ÄúSociopath?‚Äù Tristan asked. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre as deluded as ever.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe jokes and acts all cute about how he‚Äôs competitive, he likes to win, and he tends to win so you don‚Äôt really see how sore of a loser he is when things go bad. He sets his sights on something he wants, he gets it. Sets his sights on something else, he gets it. Until he doesn‚Äôt get what he wants. Like being team leader or getting a key role in an event that‚Äôs coming up. That‚Äôs when he starts using the people he‚Äôs been working on. They‚Äôre usually desperate people. Vulnerable ones.‚Äù

I thought of Rain, who Tristan had called a friend. Or did the whole team count?

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs called leaning on people when you‚Äôre struggling.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs called manipulation. And you‚Äôre good at it,‚Äù Tribute said.

‚ÄúFuck off,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúDrop the power use and let us go. We‚Äôve got things to do.‚Äù

‚ÄúMoonsong,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think you know Tristan as well as you think.‚Äù

‚ÄúSame,‚Äù Moonsong said. ‚ÄúI feel really sorry for you if he‚Äôs already got into your good graces. Because that bastard is the kind of guy who hires someone who kills people by looking at them to cover his ass, and uses them against teammates. He likes to win and he wins at any cost.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe know the story,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúI doubt you know the entirety of it. Have you split the discussion fifty-fifty between listening to him and Byron?‚Äù Moonsong asked. She didn‚Äôt even wait for a response before deciding, ‚ÄúNo. Because it doesn‚Äôt work that way.‚Äù

‚ÄúI gave Byron the opportunity,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Moonsong said. ‚ÄúI know how that goes. Like with Team Reach‚Äôs therapist, right? You get your turn, Byron gets his, you go in for extra advice, you take over, and somehow the team‚Äôs therapist gets weird ideas in his head about Byron. You suggest things and then when Byron gets his turn he‚Äôs having to play defense, get rid of these preconceived ideas. He gets no time of his own with the therapist, because he‚Äôs stuck trying to undo the damage Tristan did during his time.‚Äù

‚ÄúAll I did,‚Äù Tristan said, lines standing out as his neck, ‚ÄúWas try to figure shit out. There‚Äôs a lot to figure out with the situation being what it is, and somehow I end up doing the legwork.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a lot of work to manipulate everyone around you, isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù Moonsong asked.

‚ÄúStop,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúStop this. Now.‚Äù

I pushed out with a faint hit of aura.

‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù Sveta said, adding her voice to mine.

‚ÄúI want to hear that Byron is okay, from Byron‚Äôs mouth. I don‚Äôt give a shit about Tristan‚Äôs time.‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck this,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúFine.‚Äù

He blurred, his eyes becoming crimson points, then transitioning to become teal.

Byron, wearing a sweatshirt and jeans.

The gravity effect dropped away.

‚ÄúHi Byron,‚Äù Kenzie said, her voice small.

‚ÄúHi Kenzie.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou okay?‚Äù Moonsong asked.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve had better weeks, but things with my brother are as tolerable as they get,‚Äù Byron said. He slouched, sticking his hands in the pocket of the sweatshirt. ‚ÄúYou kind of went overboard.‚Äù

‚ÄúI had to check.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù Byron said.

There was a noise behind us, and I turned to look.

Foresight. Anelace and someone I hadn‚Äôt met.

‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you come on in? Step into the office,‚Äù Anelace asked. ‚ÄúMoonsong? Can I have a word?‚Äù

Foresight‚Äôs administrative office wasn‚Äôt the same office I‚Äôd been in when I‚Äôd interviewed with them. Their headquarters was situated elsewhere, and this was something else, a space set up for meetings, for paperwork, interactions with other teams and more. Much like the hallways had, it looked like an office.

Right away, Moonsong, Tribute, and the member of Foresight stepped into an office, closing the doors. The blinds were at an angle where I could see where they stood, but not their expressions or what they might be saying.

Anelace stepped into the back, then came back to the sitting area. He looked at us, then at the other members of Moonsong‚Äôs group. ‚ÄúCome on. Let‚Äôs keep everyone separate until things are settled.‚Äù

Our group walked into a back room, a single table and some nice chairs in a room with a coffee maker and microwave.

‚ÄúI was looking forward to seeing you again, Victoria,‚Äù Anelace said. ‚ÄúSorry it‚Äôs not under better circumstances.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to go talk to the others. There won‚Äôt be a problem if I leave you guys here?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot at all,‚Äù I said.

Anelace left us in the room. Kenzie flopped forward, forehead hitting the table, arms extended all the way in front of her.

Byron changed back to Tristan.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Tristan said, quiet. ‚ÄúSo long as I‚Äôm here, Moonsong is going to be frothing at the mouth. I‚Äôm trading out until she‚Äôs good and gone.‚Äù

They swapped back. Byron slouched into his seat.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know that about the therapy, Byron,‚Äù Sveta said.

Byron shrugged.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs why you don‚Äôt want to sit in for Mrs. Yamada‚Äôs?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs part of it,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúLook, I don‚Äôt want to demonize Tristan or anything, like Moon is so good at doing. He has his good side, but a lot of the time, I‚Äôve got to conserve my strength for dealing with the rougher patches. Minor, basic stuff.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you think he‚Äôs a sociopath?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Byron said. ‚ÄúBut I think‚Ä¶ he‚Äôs got to be the worst possible person to end up sharing a body with.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs there anything I or we can do to make it easier?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm working on a camera that looks inside Tristan to find Byron, or vice-versa,‚Äù Kenzie said, without raising her head. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not going so well but I‚Äôm going to figure it out.‚Äù

‚ÄúThanks Kenz. No, nothing makes it easier. You can‚Ä¶ tackle the broad strokes, you can be careful not to talk past my face to say something to Tristan and never do the opposite when Tristan‚Äôs the one in front. It doesn‚Äôt make a difference with the stuff that really matters. That‚Äôs my stuff to deal with.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat stuff?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs‚Ä¶ stubborn, destructively stubborn, he holds this idea of what should happen in his head, and if that doesn‚Äôt work for you then you‚Äôre probably going to be pretty unhappy, because you aren‚Äôt going to change anything about it.‚Äù

‚ÄúReminds me a bit of my mom when you describe it that way,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYeah, but you can walk away from your mom, can‚Äôt you?‚Äù Byron asked.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. I sighed.

‚ÄúI really appreciate that sigh. Maybe you get it,‚Äù he said, leaning his head back until it rested against the wall, his face turned skyward. ‚ÄúHe thrives on competition, you know. He‚Äôll be a terrific hero, probably. Put a challenge in front of him, and he‚Äôll give his all to kick its ass.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs him. That‚Äôs who he is, intrinsically. I don‚Äôt know if there‚Äôs a but. It‚Äôs reality, and it‚Äôs reality that I‚Äôm the challenge and he‚Äôs energized when it comes to the tug of war over this one body we share. He thrives on it in a way, and I‚Äôm‚Ä¶ drained, beaten down.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe have your back,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúNot just Tristan‚Äôs. We‚Äôre backing Capricorn, and we‚Äôre invested in finding answers for both of you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI appreciate that. But I don‚Äôt like this. At best, it‚Äôs‚Ä¶ more draining. More of me being beaten down and left more exhausted. At worst‚Ä¶ Moonsong might be right.‚Äù

‚ÄúAt best,‚Äù I said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Tristan doing what he‚Äôs good at doing. What happens if he doesn‚Äôt have that outlet?‚Äù

I didn‚Äôt get a response.

There was a knock on the door. Anelace, the dagger-themed member of Foresight.

‚ÄúCan you join us?‚Äù he asked.

We migrated from the team‚Äôs lunch room to the office where the team leader, Moonsong and Tribute were seated.

The leader stood by his desk, one foot on his chair. He looked larger of frame, and had Foresight‚Äôs symbol on an eye patch. A bit of a corsair look, with a jacket and lots of belts, and long black hair tied back into a sailor‚Äôs ponytail. Veins of gold decorated his costume.

‚ÄúSorry for the hassle,‚Äù Tribute said. ‚ÄúHistory. Things never really resolved so much as we all walked away with the situation left halfway through a disaster.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs alright,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been having a conversation with the Shepherds,‚Äù the leader of Foresight said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôve explained some of the history. It muddies the waters.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe understand,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúSorry about this.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey had the suggestion that we make sure both of the Capricorn twins are on board with this plan of yours.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy‚Äôd you have to drag me into this, Moonsong? This doesn‚Äôt help. I don‚Äôt want to own any part of this, whatever they do.‚Äù

‚ÄúI will always fight to give you your voice.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to speak,‚Äù Byron said. ‚ÄúI want to ignore this side of my reality and conserve my strength for the fights that need it.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs that a no, then?‚Äù the leader of Foresight asked.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Byron said. He seemed to flounder for a moment. He looked at me. ‚ÄúFuck.‚Äù

He didn‚Äôt break that eye contact with me as he said it. My eyebrow went up.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt let me get in the way of you giving these guys their chance,‚Äù Byron said.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre vouching for them?‚Äù the Foresight leader asked.

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

Byron punctuated the sentence by changing into Tristan.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm good with this,‚Äù Tristan said, shifting his posture to avoid looking at Moonsong.

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù the Foresight leader said. ‚ÄúThank you for your time, Shepherds.‚Äù

Tribute and Moonsong left the office. Just Anlace, the leader, Kenzie, Byron, Sveta and I, now.

I looked around the office and saw an article. The leader was on the cover, with the name ‚ÄòBrio‚Äô.

‚ÄúYou really want to do this?‚Äù Brio asked.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre suited for it,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThey have the ability to gather the information and figure out how to crack the toughest nuts. Tinker devices and people on the ground who won‚Äôt get a second look hanging around Hollow Point. They get the info, they sell it to you guys, and if you want it, they work with you on the actual cracking of the nut. Joint operation, or it can be solo, one way or the other.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you participating?‚Äù he asked.

‚ÄúIf I‚Äôm wanted, I‚Äôll add my strength to theirs for the big plays.‚Äù

‚ÄúTo be honest, there‚Äôs a lot about this that could work,‚Äù Brio said. ‚ÄúWhen the Wardens gathered us all together, they assigned territories by lottery. We‚Äôve got other things we‚Äôre focusing on, and Hollow Point is in a bad way.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôll pay a modest fee, enough to cover their lawyer, buy the info, keep them supplied, they‚Äôll bring you in for the actual arrests. It‚Äôs a win for you guys, while these guys do the leg work.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf it works,‚Äù Brio said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre hard workers,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre really good at what we do.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt doubt that,‚Äù Brio said. His voice had a tone shift that suggested he was used to talking to kids in a certain context. ‚ÄúYou have a lot of hurdles.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been doing our initial research,‚Äù Anelace said. ‚ÄúFiguring out how we might fix Hollow Point. They‚Äôre tied into some bigger-picture stuff.‚Äù

‚ÄúTattletale,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúHer on one end,‚Äù Anelace said. ‚ÄúBut she‚Äôs more the kind of person you have to deal with further down the road. Once you scare them, they‚Äôll call her. They already called her once about us, and she reached out to try to convince us to leave the area alone.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúAnd we‚Äôre leaving it alone, or we were, until you sent your proposal,‚Äù Brio said.

I nodded. Not good to hear, but understandable. I wondered what played into that decision.

‚ÄúOn the front end, you‚Äôve got some others to deal with. You‚Äôll have to get past them before you can even start on the project.‚Äù

‚ÄúWho?‚Äù

‚ÄúSpeedrunners,‚Äù Anelace said. He turned around, reached for a file, and put it on the desk, pushing it in our direction.

‚ÄúI know them,‚Äù I said. I left the file for Sveta, Tristan and Kenzie to look at.

‚ÄúA couple of times a day, they use their time powers. Sweep the area, search every nook and cranny. You won‚Äôt be able to set up shop.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôd be Secondhand,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThey use Final Hour to cover other business. Even if you avoid being caught in the sweeps, you won‚Äôt be able to look or listen in if they‚Äôre conducting meetings in banked timestreams.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd Last Minute is still with the group?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

Fucking time manipulators. ‚ÄúSomething to work out in advance then.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôve got two thinkers, Braindead and Birdbrain, working as a team. You won‚Äôt be able to have undercover agents if they‚Äôre checking things. You will be tracked and your agents will be thoroughly investigated.‚Äù

More folders hit the table.

‚ÄúPowers complicate things, and they‚Äôve got a lot of powers there,‚Äù Anelace said.

‚ÄúBitter Pill, tinker,‚Äù Brio said. ‚ÄúA lot of the people in Hollow Point are expected to partake, and that means truth serums, just to start with.‚Äù

I looked at the other members of the group.

‚ÄúYou really think you‚Äôre up for this?‚Äù Brio asked.

‚ÄúJust speaking for myself, I‚Äôm more excited to do this than I was before you started talking about what we‚Äôre up against,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúI already have some ideas,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúNot about the time guys, but I have ideas.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe knock the time guys down first,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúWithout a question. We‚Äôll have to. We can do this.‚Äù

I looked at Sveta, who had been quiet.

‚ÄúI want to do this,‚Äù she said, meeting Brio‚Äôs eyes.

‚ÄúThen we‚Äôll give you our files as starting points. You guys own this if it ends up being a disaster, you keep us informed, and—‚Äù

‚ÄúIn exchange,‚Äù I interrupted, ‚ÄúYou guys give us access to your costume sourcing.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can do costumes,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúWithout battery lives?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúOh.‚Äù

‚ÄúGive us access to your costume manufacturing. I know you have it and I know you‚Äôre branching out to share it.‚Äù

Anelace and Brio exchanged a look. Brio nodded. ‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you give us your blessing to operate in this territory,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if I like what I saw earlier,‚Äù Brio said. ‚ÄúBlessing might be a strong word.‚Äù

‚ÄúAll parahumans have their issues,‚Äù I said.

Brio seemed to consider for a moment.

He extended his hand to shake.

We shook it, each of us in turn.

No name yet, costumes to be decided, codenames to be determined.

But we were a team with a mission. We were doing this.

Glare — Interlude 3

Dot moved slowly and carefully through the store. She placed a hand on the floor for the added balance and weight distribution, then slid the hand left to right and back again, pushing it through a layer of dust that gathered and tumbled onto the back of her hand.

She was glad for the fingerless glove she wore, because it let her feel the finer details while keeping it clean and warm. The floor was cool and moist. The exterior wall of the store was letting the rain in, and the rain traced a path through one portion of the store, cutting thin rivers through the dust. Wet in places, dry in places, but persistently clammy and dirty. Perpetually colorless.

It was the lack of color that got to her the most.

It was one of the big stores, where everything was gathered together into tall stacks and piles beneath and on metal racks. The lights were fluorescent, and they flickered. The buzzing sounds the lights made were more constant than the light.

A menacing sound. Menacing, glaring lights.

It was safer to climb on the stacks of cardboard boxes than it was to walk on the floor or to make contact with the wood and metal of the shelves.

She paused as she climbed to a higher shelf, figuring out how best to ascend while minimizing dangerous contact. Finally, she decided to take a risk by grabbing a metal cross-bar, hauling herself up, and setting her feet on a series of plastic bottles in cardboard trays, stacked higher than a man was tall.

She couldn‚Äôt read well, but she could recognize the labels. Pills. Vitamins, probably. If these were here, then there might be better offerings close by. She searched the nearby piles until she found cardboard boxes with cartoon characters on the front. Pictures of cartoon character heads were beside not-cartoon images in shiny monocolor shapes.

Dot opened a box, careful not to make noise, and fished inside. A plastic bottle within, and inside the plastic bottle‚Ä¶ a colorful assortment of gummy vitamins.

She fished out the contents and pushed them into her mouth until she could barely close her jaw. The artificial taste overpowered her nose and mouth. Her eyes rolled back into her head with the effort of chewing.

A loud noise made her freeze.

The doors had been opened. She heard loud footsteps.

She climbed deeper into the stacks of vitamins, listening and watching.

‚ÄúHellooooo!‚Äù the call was drawn out. Dot tensed, listening as the greeting bounced around the building interior.

Dot waited.

‚ÄúAnyone here!?‚Äù

She waited, silent, peering through the gaps between the cardboard boxes and plastic bottles.

Another voice could be heard saying, ‚ÄúLights are on and nobody‚Äôs home?‚Äù

‚ÄúThey could be out, or a group of refugees might have stopped in on their way to the portal. They could have set up power and scavenged before leaving things behind for others.‚Äù

Dot winced with every tromp of boot on tiled floor. She could hear people rummaging, pulling down boxes and tearing into the contents. Things fell to the ground.

She changed locations, putting some distance between herself and them. It didn‚Äôt help; their explorations meant they drew nearer to her as she lurked on a high shelf.

‚Äú‚Ä¶names you can‚Äôt pronounce, grab that first.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy? Preservatives?‚Äù

‚ÄúPreservatives, yep. Keep a close eye out for the products with the wrong names.‚Äù

‚ÄúWrong names?‚Äù

‚ÄúIf it‚Äôs not called soap, but a ‚Äòcleansing bar‚Äô that means it‚Äôs so loaded with crud that they weren‚Äôt legally allowed to call it soap. That shit is gold to us, because the chemicals in it mean it lasts. If it lasts, it can be resold back home.‚Äù

‚ÄúSoap goes bad?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt can. I‚Äôd rather take the misnamed shit that lasts than take something more legit home and find out it went bad.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood point.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll teach you all the tricks. It‚Äôs a good gig, believe me.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah. Hey, are those fridges?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah. I wouldn‚Äôt get your hopes up. Power was probably out for months to a year before someone got this building back on line.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou think they have ice cream? Or those push-freezes?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt want ice cream, remember? You want—‚Äù

‚ÄúFrozen dairy-like desserts or something.‚Äù

‚ÄúNow you get it.‚Äù

Dot watched as the younger man jogged across the floor to what was almost certainly his imminent demise. He opened the glass door to the fridge display and began picking his way through cardboard boxes.

She could see the green lights appearing in the background of the display, flicking on one by one, apparently at random.

The older man noticed, stopping in his tracks.

‚ÄúJackson!‚Äù he screamed the word.

The machine rammed through the wall. Six feet tall, six feet wide, with two legs, it slammed past metal racks, past food in cardboard boxes, through the glass doors, through the metal that the doors were attached to, and into Jackson.

Both legs broken. From the way he hit the ground, his arm might have been broken too.

One mechanical leg thrust out, then dragged Jackson back into the hole in the wall. Another reached out and began depositing a thin white fluid on the bloodstain.

Jackson‚Äôs mentor was running and the machine was just starting to clean up the blood when two more belatedly thrust their way out through the walls. They paused where they were, seemed to decide what they were doing, and then used wheels on their underbellies to roll along the floor, the two forelimbs out and ready.

Gaps appeared in the face of each machine as they drew closer. Jackson‚Äôs mentor shouted to friends elsewhere in the building as he rounded a corner in the shelves and stacks.

He made the mistake of grabbing onto a metal strut at the edge of one set of shelves. The face of the strut moved, changing in angle, and jerked upward. A machine had taken a blade and camouflaged it to look like the red-painted metal surface, and it managed to carve deep into Jackson‚Äôs mentor‚Äôs hand. The machine that controlled the blade moved. It wore a cardboard box.

Dot made a mental note of that as she remained frozen, watching.

The people were running, gathering together. They narrowly evaded the machines, using corners and their small size to stay clear as the machines from the fridge wall careened down the wide aisles.

It didn‚Äôt matter. They were already dead.

She could hear the gasps and shrieks. Here and there, weapons were deployed. Sprays of darts, more blades from innocuous surfaces, wire.

The gasps became more numerous, the sounds strained, and the activity of the scavengers slowed. The ones who realized what was happening didn‚Äôt have the words to report it to the others.

Gas. Invisible, odorless. They gasped and used everything they had to try to draw air into their lungs, but the machines were putting something heavier than oxygen on the ground floor of the store. Now they drowned.

Dot had lost family to this very same thing. She had seen how painful it was, and she had known how painful it was to watch someone she cared about die that way.

She took her time picking through the boxes of vitamins, putting them in her bag. It was nice that the gummy vitamins didn‚Äôt rattle. She picked up other things as she navigated the shelves, including bandages and some random bottles.

An explosion drew her attention.

Someone in a costume.

Another explosion, followed by two more, and one of the big machines from the fridge wall collapsed.

Apparently alerted by one of the dying, the woman in costume climbed up onto the shelving units, to get to higher ground where there was air. She threw a blue light out of her hand, and it detonated on impact with the next machine.

Back at the fridges, some of the fridges and surrounding wall had already been reconstructed. Two more of the large cube-shaped machines squeezed through the gaps in the wall that were still there, before getting their wheels under them and hurrying in the direction of the woman in costume.

Dot moved closer to the ground to get a look. It was important to know just how far gone this building was.

The entire area behind the fridges was gone. Green flashing lights, wires, computers and metal twisted into shapes that helped it to provide a framework. Machines were working slowly and steadily to refine and develop things.

In the opposite corner of the building, the hero climbed behind a stack of cans. A spray of flechettes punctured the paper with no resistance— there was no tin to the cans, only the labels and the haphazardly perched tops. The machines had already collected everything and then put things back so it looked like it hadn‚Äôt been touched.

The heroine fell and hit the floor. She had been darted, punctured across the face and shoulder.

You die too, Dot observed.

Against all odds, though, the heroine had managed to hold her breath. She got to her feet and she ran.

Dot climbed carefully, avoiding suspicious surfaces as she navigated the piles. She kept one eye out for things she could use and one eye on the heroine.

A box cutter, left on the surface by a past employee. Useful. Dot grabbed it.

One of the machines shifted position. Two legs on the ground in front of it, backside resting on the ground. Its face opened wide, and a salvo of missiles fired forth. Ten, twelve, metal canisters with streams of vapor painting the air in their wake as they flew in lazy arcs or even tumbled through the air before getting their bearings.

However haphazard they looked, they didn‚Äôt hit anything they weren‚Äôt supposed to. They traced courses between stacks of pasta and boxes of cereal, through the struts of metal shelves, and through the two-inch gaps between shelf and the floor below.

The heroine shot at shelves, bringing down the contents in showers that might block the missiles. Some missiles detonated. Others navigated the falling debris, and the heroine shot at those next.

Some missiles didn‚Äôt detonate, but they weren‚Äôt missiles in actuality. They were tricks.

The heroine backed up, then saw the two new arrivals, two more of the big ‚Äòsoldier‚Äô machines. She ran for the door.

But the machines had had her since she had let them know she existed.

The heroine made it to the door, and then a metal skewer harpooned her hand.

Blow it up. Lose the hand, Dot thought. She realized she was rooting for the heroine despite herself.

The heroine fought, and she‚Äôd had to stop running to fight. More skewers impaled her forearm, then her other hand.

She used her power, she shot at shelves, but she lacked the angle. The machines reeled in, using the wires attached to the skewers, and the heroine was hauled into the air, arms out to either side, legs dangling.

Dot sat, and she waited. She ate more gummy multivitamins and she observed the machines. She watched as the mess was slowly cleaned up, boxes pulled back into position, products lined up, and sections of floor that had been shattered by missiles were fit together like jigsaw pieces.

Here and there, deep in the craters and crevices, the ‚Äòtrick‚Äô missiles had delivered payloads that weren‚Äôt explosive. They looked like veins of metal in rock. In weeks and months, they would ‚Äòhatch‚Äô, revealing the machinery that had built itself within. For now, they were paved over. Smaller machines filled in cracks with something white that would harden, with daubs of black for the speckles in the tile. A blade scraped away the excess, and a small nozzle provided a covering of dust to match surrounding floor.

A close eye would notice where the floor was different, but it would have to be close and careful.

The machines weren‚Äôt too challenging to destroy. Dot‚Äôs groups had sometimes destroyed them. The trick was that they set in roots wherever they went. Each time they reached a new place, they would keep emerging from that place, from walls and floor and rock and tree. It took care and attention to get the machine out of each of those things, and while that care was being taken, machines elsewhere would emerge, march, and make inroads along the flanks.

Green lights here and there went dark, the machines hibernating. Dot deemed herself safe to move.

She stuck to the high ground, while the still-active machines continued their work below. She eased herself closer to the heroine, and paused, observing. Here and there, the woman kicked or struggled, and the machines didn‚Äôt respond. Blood streamed down and dripped from her toes to her floor. Each time blood accumulated enough to drip and make a small splash on the floor, a machine zoomed out to spray at it and then wiped it away before returning to its hiding place beneath a shelf.

Dot leaped. She landed on the woman‚Äôs shoulder, and the woman‚Äôs face twisted, contorting into a wordless scream at the sudden, added weight on her injured arms and hands.

Then the woman looked at Dot, and her expression changed again. Fear, alarm.

Dot was small, only about as large as the woman‚Äôs head, and she was colorful. Her clothes had been stolen from dolls and pieced together with diligent care. Her tail with its fur tuft on the end swished with the box-cutter it held..

‚ÄúHelp me.‚Äù

Dot shook her head.

‚ÄúI have people who are counting on me. I have a sick sibling, they need me to bring in the money from this work.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have people too,‚Äù Dot whispered. She stuck her tongue up to pick her nose, then drew it back into her mouth. ‚ÄúSome sick too.‚Äù

The heroine made a small sound, bowing her head. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll help you, I‚Äôll— I‚Äôll convince people to give you medical care. We can trade.‚Äù

Dot reached out with one hand, and she pushed the tab that extended the blade from the box-cutter.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll do anything,‚Äù the heroine said.

Dot paused.

‚ÄúAnything,‚Äù the heroine said, seizing on the pause.

‚ÄúMy king,‚Äù Dot said. ‚ÄúWhere?‚Äù

‚ÄúYour king?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can take you.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo you can‚Äôt,‚Äù Dot said. She hugged the box cutter against her chest with two spotted arms, red spots on yellow-white flesh. ‚ÄúYou die here. I‚Äôm not big or strong. Machines are. If I go for help then you dead before I‚Äôm back.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease.‚Äù

‚ÄúTell me where my king is and I‚Äôll be fast. Merciful.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt— this isn‚Äôt about me. Can you— can you let them know the Machine Army is this far north? They shouldn‚Äôt be on this side of the Raleigh chasm.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey kill me on sight.‚Äù

‚ÄúFind a way? Please? I‚Äôll tell you where your king is, I help you, but you need to tell them. We need the Wardens to stop them before they get their roots in.‚Äù

Too late, Dot thought to herself.

The woman seemed to take it as assent, when it wasn‚Äôt. ‚ÄúThe Wardens‚Äô headquarters, probably. It‚Äôs— it‚Äôs on Gimel, where a lot of the trains go. The train nearest here goes there. You‚Äôll want to look for a building with a statue of a knight with a sword at the front.‚Äù

Dot took a two-handed grip on her box cutter.

‚ÄúTell the Wardens. Let them know, so they can take measures. Tell them Burnish said it. It might save your King‚Äôs life.‚Äù

Dot paused.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù she said.

Then she cut into the woman‚Äôs throat, until blood sprayed from the artery. She opened her mouth wide, until the teeth on the upper half of her mouth pointed in the same direction as the teeth on the lower jaw, and bit in deep, locking her mouth in place. She swallowed the blood, gorging herself.

Vitamins, protein, nourishment. She would fill herself here, then visit her brothers and sisters. Then she would set out on her quest.

A distance below them, machines washed away the blood. After the heroine had been kept up and out of the way long enough to ensure her power wouldn‚Äôt be a problem, she would be cleaned up too.

Dot felt energized, her focus as sharp as the box-cutter. She knew where their king was.

King Rinke. Nilbog.

‚äô

She clung to the underside of the train. The ground was a blur beneath her, periodically studded with rocks and branches.

Those of her kind who ventured into the human‚Äôs civilization didn‚Äôt tend to return. She knew it was a risk. She knew she had a one percent chance when it came to this. She‚Äôd said her goodbyes accordingly.

Blackspot would be left in charge. He‚Äôd been unwell lately, and he might be too unwell to lead their group. He was thirteen and that made him old, and after their discussion, her communicating in broken English and gesture and him communicating in chirp, he‚Äôd agreed. She suspected he‚Äôd made the decision because he hoped she would bring their king back somehow. It was Blackspot‚Äôs only chance at being recycled and made into new life.

Lump would be second in command. Lump had been injured a year ago, after running into humans. He barely moved now. When he died, the group would be more free to move, but they wouldn‚Äôt leave him behind until then.

Lump was one of the only big ones that were left.

Dot used her tail to fish out a gummy vitamin from inside her tunic where it sat close to her belly. It stuck to her skin and had to be peeled away. She chewed it slowly and carefully.

She was thirsty. She hadn‚Äôt anticipated how dehydrated she would get. The chewing got her saliva flowing, though some unfortunately flowed out through the corners of her wide mouth.

There was a hole that smelled like shit, leading into the train interior, but she didn‚Äôt want to climb up into there. Shit didn‚Äôt bother her, but the smell would hurt her ability to stay undetected.

She was a scout and a spy, a messenger to a king in captivity.

She would endure. She clung to the bolts and bars, arching her back when she saw a branch or rock that might scrape at her, and she chewed.

The train slowed. She shifted her position, ears reorienting to catch more sound. Every detail she could pick up would matter, now. She was in hostile territory.

The train rolled to a stop. Doors hissed as they opened, and the crowd began to make their way out. Dot peered between the wheels and up, to see the refugees and the scavengers, as well as the men and women and boys and girls in uniforms who came and went.

She dropped to the tracks, and she moved to the dark corner, crawling through the dust and grime to help cover up the color of her spots and outfit.

Too many for her to slip across the platform. Would she have an opening? She crept along, looking for vents, for cracks, or anything where she could slip through.

Too new a building, too maintained. This was nothing like the kingdom or the ruins she had known during her five years of existence.

The only time she had seen this many humans was when their kingdom had been invaded. She had been aware as each set of humans boarded at different stops, but for all of them to get off here, for there to be no more tracks? This had to be the end. Their destination and hers.

She trembled with anticipation as the stream of people from the train slowed.

Boots were more serious than shoes. Matching boots were most serious. She associated matching boots with the men with guns that worked with the people in costume. When men with matching boots and people in costume got together, it was often to kill her kind.

She would save her king.

She crept along the underside of the ledge, where the platform jutted toward the train. When the train left, would she be exposed?

She would do anything for her king.

Her weapon was ready. The box cutter. It still smelled like the blood of the heroine. Of Burnish.

Thinking of the blood made her think again about how thirsty she was.

‚ÄúChrist,‚Äù one of the boots said. ‚ÄúIncoming.‚Äù

Someone else groaned.

‚ÄúGood afternoon,‚Äù a woman said.

‚ÄúAfternoon,‚Äù was the curt response.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got a thtowaway.‚Äù

Dot froze.

‚ÄúA thtowaway?‚Äù was the response. There was a sound of an impact, light.

‚ÄúThomething thmall.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs this like when you had us stop the train, put the entire city on hold, made us get the bomb disposal bot under the train with a camera, all to show us some squirrel roadkill caught in the machinery?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm here for a reathon. Thith ith what I do.‚Äù

‚ÄúEvery time you jerk our chains you lose trust, and you‚Äôve jerked our chains a lot. You haven‚Äôt done much to regain that lost trust.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt jerk your chain, Adam,‚Äù the woman said. ‚ÄúI thpecialithe in noticing thmall thingth, and I know how thmall and thort your chain is.‚Äù

There was laughter.

Dot wondered if she had any options. There hadn‚Äôt been anything she could use to disguise herself as roadkill. What would she do if the train started moving?

‚ÄúCan you actually see short, uh, chains?‚Äù another woman asked.

‚ÄúNo comment.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think we have a camera we can drop to the track. It should be up at the station proper. We can do a quick search. You want to grab it, Adam?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, sure.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll make a call, ask them to keep the train put while we search. Stay close, Rat?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe name‚Äôth Ratcatcher. I‚Äôll thtay clothe.‚Äù

Dot made her way along the car, until she found one of the holes near the shit-hole. This hole didn‚Äôt lead up into the car, there was a grate barring her way, catching hair and other gunk, but it was just wide enough for her to squeeze most of the way into.

She waited, listening, until she heard the clatter.

Her role in the community had been a scout, to start with. She had ended up a leader after a while, but she was still a scout at heart. Exploring new places, figuring out ways to deal with traps, with the enemies that lurked out there.

She had dealt with the Machine Army. This little toy wouldn‚Äôt stop her.

With clawed toes and the opposable toe on her foot, she clawed some of the hair out of the drain.

Patience. Care. Machines were predictable, once they had revealed their tricks. The challenge was to find the tricks without being discovered or caught.

She watched as the machine passed under her. Dropping from her hiding place, almost noiseless, she landed right behind it. She used all of her strength to tip it over, then wrapped the hair around the wheel and reached up, tying it to a bit of metal at the base of the hole, where a passing rock or branch had made the metal rougher.

Snagged, caught, but in a believable way.

She darted away, as voices commented on the situation, trying to riddle out what had happened. A human dropped down between the platform and the train itself, ducking low to peer between wheels, looking for the little camera drone.

The platforms were mostly empty, and most of the watchful eyes were focused on the little drone and the issue.

She stuck her head up, ears low and close to her body, tail swishing beneath her, and then made a break for a vent.

A human moved, making a run for her. Shoes slid on the smooth floor of the station platform as the human put herself between Dot and the vent.

‚ÄúNot so fatht,‚Äù the woman said, as Dot skidded on the floor, stopping.

The woman was small, as humans went, and she wore a costume that covered most of her body. Her mask was roughly cone-shaped, but the paper or wire that kept the mask pointy had been dented or damaged at one point, and the nose drooped a bit. Rodent-like, with ears sticking out and back at the side, flat against the side of her head. The eyes behind the eye-holes were large, dark, and moist. If Dot unfocused her eyes a bit, it looked like there was nothing behind the eyeholes. Dark hair draped around in front of the ears and down the back of the woman‚Äôs head. As pointy as the mask was, she wore a hood or a hat with a point going the opposite direction.

She wore a jacket, denim, with a threadbare collar, a striped shirt beneath, and a thin chain belt with mousetraps dangling from it. Her socks were striped as well, extending high enough that they just barely met her denim cut-off shorts.

Dot was willing to admit that if she was going to die, at least it was at the hands of someone with a good aesthetic.

‚ÄúYou thall not path,‚Äù Ratcatcher said.

Dot remained where she was, frozen.

‚ÄúCan you talk?‚Äù Ratcatcher asked.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Dot said.

‚ÄúI like your colorth.‚Äù

Dot stretched out her hands in front of her, looking at her arms.

‚ÄúI bet you‚Äôre beautiful when clean,‚Äù Ratcatcher said.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Dot said. She was. She wasn‚Äôt interesting looking, but she could talk and she could use her hands, feet, and tail, well, and she had some pretty patterns: her namesake spots.

‚ÄúI want you to go home,‚Äù Ratcatcher said. ‚ÄúIf we fight, I‚Äôll win. I thpecialize in dealing with your type.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm here to deliver message,‚Äù Dot said. ‚ÄúThat all.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat methage?‚Äù

‚ÄúBurnish. She went to a store. Machine Army was there. She wanted me to tell. North of the Raleigh chasm. They were surprised.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe thought it was your people,‚Äù Ratcatcher said.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Dot said. ‚ÄúI watched.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt help?‚Äù

‚ÄúToo small, too weak.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôth no ekthuthe. Burnith was a good one. Nice to me. I‚Äôll mith her.‚Äù

Dot remained where she was. She looked back. No sign that the men who were investigating under the train even realized she wasn‚Äôt there anymore.

‚ÄúThank you for your methage.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll go now,‚Äù Dot said. ‚ÄúBut can I have water? I‚Äôm so thirsty.‚Äù

‚ÄúCome. Vending machine. Have you theen thethe?‚Äù

Dot had, but she shook her head.

Ratcatcher held out a hand. Dot was wary, but she ventured closer.

‚ÄúThay hello to Raththputin,‚Äù Ratcatcher said. ‚ÄúThtay in my pocket for now.‚Äù

In another time, another world, Dot might have stayed.

But she had a king to rescue. A king adored by his people. A truly great man.

As Ratcatcher reached into a pocket, change jingling, Dot saw opportunity. She leaped for the ground, went under the vending machine, and then ran along the wall, darting for the vent.

Big people were often slow. Ratcatcher wasn‚Äôt. Fast reflexes. Fast in general.

But Dot was faster. Had the vent not already had a corner peeled away, Dot wouldn‚Äôt have been able to make it inside. As it was, she ducked inside, and Ratcatcher‚Äôs gloved fingers only managed to seize the ends of the hairs at the end of Dot‚Äôs tail. Dot hauled herself free.

Ratcatcher moved her mask aside, fingers going to her mouth, and then whistled. ‚ÄúTrouble!‚Äù

But Dot was already in her element.

She ran through dusty vents, navigating the guts of the building. Flashlights periodically shone into the vents, illuminating areas. She avoided most of those beams of lights, going this way and that, until she found another convenient point, where two pieces of metal weren‚Äôt flush together. She squeezed through and pulled her bag after her.

It was another minute until she realized two things.

Ratcatcher had friends.

The convenient openings in the vents and leading from vent to the inside of the walls of the station were there because of those friends.

Dot had dealt with rats before, but these rats were the sort that were very ugly and very large. In the right light, they might have been mistaken for very ugly, small dogs. Dot had always liked that story when the King read it from the scary children‚Äôs book. The children got the dog and the dog turned out to be a Mexican sewer rat.

These rats were that sort, apparently, and they smelled like Ratcatcher‚Äôs pocket had.

She drew her box-cutter, extending the blade, and sized up her opponents.

Three rats against her and her boxcutter.

It might have been an even fight, but she had her devotion to her king on her side.

She would rescue her king.

‚äô

The building that held her king was fitting for the stories. The statue lacked color, but it had the right atmosphere. She was bleeding but she told herself that this was how things were in those stories. The heroine at the foot of the castle of the evil empire, the king in captivity. She hurt from the battles already fought and faced the greatest challenge yet.

Getting inside wasn‚Äôt hard, but getting up was. The vents were barred and had cameras, and people were already on guard when she arrived, keeping a close eye on those same vents.

She could only wait.

Patience was essential to a scout. The fact that every inch of her hurt from her fight with the sewer rats made the patience a little different. She had been hurt before, and she had been hurt in a way that made each breath an effort.

Breathe in, breathe out. If she did that once, she was one step closer to being better and being okay. She knew it was a long journey, but surviving was important.

Surviving was especially important now.

He was close.

She would free him, and he would usher in a new age of greatness for her and her people. She might even have a place at his side, where she could be close to him at all times.

She wasn‚Äôt even sure what that would be like. She had been ecstatic when she had seen mere glimpses of him, back in the old Kingdom.

Breathe in, hurt, breathe out, hurt again, feel the scratches and the bites when she shifted position. Breathe in, breathe out, double check she wasn‚Äôt anywhere she might be found.

She licked at her wounds, and she licked at the dust and grit, so her colors would be bolder. She licked her hands and ran wet hands over her hair, smoothing it.

She had arrived early in the morning, on the train, and now she waited until the sun was high in the sky. Each breath was a step closer to wellness and moving again.

She dug in her small pack for the bandages. They were the small kind, with sticky sides. She had brought the colorful ones with cartoons on them for luck, and now she placed them over her wounds, along with little bits of cotton and fabric to soak up the blood.

It seemed like there were more people who came and went than there were stars in the sky, but her senses might have been playing tricks on her.

The trickle of people slowed. When some made early returns, they smelled like food. Midday meals, then. She waited until everyone was back and working, sluggish from the food in their bellies, and then she made her move.

Up the underside of the stairs to the second floor. Into a crack between a booth and the wall. Up to the third floor, in a similar way.

There was security guarding the way from the fourth floor to the fifth. A commotion gave her a chance to slip through. It helped that she was small and it helped more that she was experienced.

Now she explored. The fifth floor didn‚Äôt seem much like a prison. The sixth was closer, with more security, more computers, more monitors.

She heard a voice, and she caught a familiar name.

‚Äú‚Ä¶Rinke.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see the point. He‚Äôs a broken man.‚Äù

Dot clutched at her chest, just over her heart.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a great man. Him being broken or not broken doesn‚Äôt change that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see the point, Riley. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôd gain anything, and I don‚Äôt think the people I care the most about would be very happy about me hanging around with him.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou hang around with me.‚Äù

‚ÄúSomeone has to check your work.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhatever. I‚Äôm going to go talk to him. I think you should join us. You can check my work after, we‚Äôll make it fast.‚Äù

The pair started to walk away. Dot checked the coast was clear, then followed.

Up to the seventh floor, then higher. Her body ached, every one of her movements harder than they had been before she had started climbing up to the top of this monstrous building, but she knew she was close.

A dining hall, with lots of tables, and a kitchen off to one side. It smelled like a hundred different foods.

The two girls didn‚Äôt talk much as they walked. The younger one was on the cusp of adulthood, but she smelled like blood and sickness. She was blonde, wearing a dress.

The older one had crossed the threshold to adulthood. Her arms were striped or marked somehow, almost completely covered with freckles, and her brown hair was tied back into a ponytail. She wore jeans and a top with spaghetti straps, and had a jacket folded over her arms, which she held close to her body.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt find it sad? Spending time around him like this?‚Äù

‚ÄúSad?‚Äù Riley asked. ‚ÄúNo. It‚Äôs‚Ä¶ reassuring.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a crazy, fucked up, upside-down, inside-out world. I think he understands that. He lives in that world. Not in a fantasy version of it.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt seems to me like he lives entirely in the fantasy.‚Äù

Riley chuckled.

There was another security checkpoint. The two passed through, and Dot was forced to hang back, watching them go through. She couldn‚Äôt pass herself. It was sealed off like the old kingdom had been. What was the word?

Quarantined.

She found vents, and she climbed through the vents. The vents, too, were quarantine-sealed.

She hated that she was so close. Her king was in arm‚Äôs reach, and she couldn‚Äôt touch him. He was talking, right this moment, and she couldn‚Äôt hear him.

Patience, she told herself.

Patience. A scout had to know patience. She was here to free him, to give him power again, even if it meant him taking her apart and turning her into another kind of life that he could use. Achieving that goal had always been something that would take time.

She searched vents, and she found one that had a gap she could use. She worked at it, wedging her box-cutter into the gap and wiggling it until she could get fingers in the gap. She used strength to widen it further, felt air escape through the rubber seal she‚Äôd peeled away, and knew she‚Äôd broken through the quarantine protection.

With more work, she was able to get an entire arm through. Screws scraped against metal as she worked them through.

She found her way into the walls, and from the walls, she found her way to a double-layered window with wire mesh between layers. She could see glimpses of the scene from an angle, distorted, by peering through the side of the thick glass pane.

The girl and the woman sitting at a table, separated from King Rinke by another thick glass wall.

Almost frantic, Dot searched the interior of the walls, looking for gaps, anything she could use. Everything was sealed, everything secured.

The answer ended up being the power outlet. She worked at the outlet, clawed at the seal that cemented it to the wall, and moved it enough that sound could get through. Later, when it was quiet, she could get through too.

‚Äú‚Ä¶a Red Queen and an Alice, then.‚Äù

‚ÄúOr you could call me by my name.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm quite fond of Alice. She was a chaotic force in the worlds she visited, you know. She questioned, she challenged. A revolutionary in absurd worlds held captive by their own conventions and riddles.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis supposed Red Queen and I are friends, you know,‚Äù Alice Riley said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôd go that far,‚Äù the Red Queen said.

‚ÄúThey were friends and enemies both in the story,‚Äù King Rinke said.

‚ÄúYou know, Jamie, I told the Queen here that you were one of the people who really got it. I drew comparisons to our friend Valkyrie. The Queen and Valkyrie know each other, you know.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm flattered by the comparison, my Alice. I‚Äôm not surprised they know each other. Queens are well-connected.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm getting sort of sick of being called a Queen.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy dear, you have all the power in the world. You can move in any direction you choose.‚Äù

‚ÄúLess than you‚Äôd think.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre here, aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm‚Ä¶ I think if I‚Äôm here, it‚Äôs because I‚Äôve been checkmated by her. She implied she‚Äôd waste my time if I didn‚Äôt go along with this.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very, very easy for even a Queen to be checkmated, if she doesn‚Äôt act like a Queen.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm starting to think I‚Äôm not smart enough to keep up with this conversation.‚Äù

Riley the Alice laughed.

‚ÄúYou should visit again, Red Queen. Have tea. Keep an old man company.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre more than an old man,‚Äù the Alice said.

‚ÄúA king without a kingdom,‚Äù King Rinke said.

‚ÄúA fallen king is still a king,‚Äù the Alice said.

King Rinke tittered. Dot, hiding in the wall, smiled at the expression of joy.

‚ÄúYes, I do remember that,‚Äù King Rinke said.

‚ÄúWe should go soon,‚Äù the Alice said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve finished our tea, and we‚Äôve got work to do. The Red Queen needs to check over the, ah, vial I‚Äôve created that says ‚Äòdrink me‚Äô, and make sure it‚Äôs safe.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease don‚Äôt make anything like that,‚Äù the Queen said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd hate to see it go wrong.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy work doesn‚Äôt go wrong. Thank you very much. It was wonderful to see you, Goblin King. I‚Äôm sorry the visit was short. I mostly wanted to introduce you two.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been an experience,‚Äù the Queen said.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs next for you, Red Queen? What will you do, once you‚Äôve seen what our Alice has been up to?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll‚Ä¶ I guess I‚Äôll be at my father‚Äôs side while talking to some of the most powerful people in all the known worlds, and I‚Äôll see my parents, trying to say goodbye and yet unable to pull away, or making my greetings and being pushed away, and I‚Äôll continue to feel like I‚Äôm in the wrong places every step of the way.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a queen. You have such power. You can go anywhere you want, if you‚Äôre willing to wield that power. Your struggles are because you‚Äôre trying to be something you aren‚Äôt. Take that as advice from a king who has lost his kingdom to a Queen who has yet to claim hers.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like what happens when I try to use power to claim anything.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen use position. The fact that you‚Äôre a queen affords you power by default. If you stand in the right places, things will change as a result. Use that. Recognize it. Things may start going the way you hope they might.‚Äù

There was a pause.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve said similar things,‚Äù the Alice said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù the Queen said. ‚ÄúI worry because the only people willing to talk to me say similar things, but I‚Äôm not sure they‚Äôre people I should listen to.‚Äù

‚ÄúA king without a kingdom,‚Äù King Rinke said.

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs go with that,‚Äù the Alice said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs probably it.‚Äù

There was a slight commotion, chairs moving, dishes clacking against surfaces, as the girl and the woman gathered themselves together and stood from their seats.

‚ÄúCome again, Red Queen.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt make promises, but I‚Äôll be in the building a lot, and it‚Äôs not out of the realm of possibility.‚Äù

There were more noises, and then doors shut.

Knees pulled to her chest, tail wrapped around her, Dot felt warm and happy, her king‚Äôs words wrapped around her, filling her up.

She barely dared to move the outlet, to force her way past it, to break the spell and to try to have more.

But she had to save her king.

The King had a bodyguard, a strong soldier of a man, taller than the King, muscular, and clearly dumb. The bodyguard noticed her before the King did, and reached out to touch the King‚Äôs arm.

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù King Rinke said. He had a sad expression on his face. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôve been watching me closer for the better part of the morning. I suppose you‚Äôre why.‚Äù

Dot wasn‚Äôt sure what to say or do.

‚ÄúCome. Can you talk?‚Äù he asked. He seated himself, his bodyguard reaching for the chair to steady it as the King sat. The King stuck one leg straight out in Dot‚Äôs direction.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù she said. She leaped forward in the same way and lurching way her heart leaped into her chest. She ran up and along his leg, up him, to him. Clawed fingers and feet clutched for the fabric of his shirt. His gray-touched beard tickled her head and back.

She could smell him and he smelled like home, like family and love. She felt his hand on her back, and she felt it pet her.

She could have cried, if she weren‚Äôt so dehydrated, if so much of her body‚Äôs energies and fluids hadn‚Äôt gone into bleeding and healing. Every ache and pain, from hours of clinging to a shuddering train to fighting rats and scaling a building interior, prying her way past sealed building fixtures, it became a dull, throbbing reassurance that she‚Äôd done right.

‚ÄúYou worked hard to get here.‚Äù

She nodded. ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the third to get this far. One of only two that could talk.‚Äù

Third? She wanted to ask, but she was worried about the response.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt make you, did I? You were birthed. You look like Polka‚Äôs get.‚Äù

She nodded, hard, head rubbing against his shirt as she clutched tighter. He knew her. He didn‚Äôt know her but he knew where she was from and so he knew her.

‚ÄúPolka the third?‚Äù

‚ÄúFourth,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBut thank you for thinking I‚Äôm like the third. She was the most beautiful and clever.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe fourth was clever too,‚Äù he said. He stroked her.

‚ÄúI come to save you,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúYou can use me for material.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt do that,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúNot for one as beautiful and noble and brave as you. No.‚Äù

She felt the tears well up. Noble. Highest of praise.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he said again. He gave her a stroke, from head and ears to tail, and then he reached down, hands on her arms and shoulders, and he moved her back and away.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he said, a third time.

With that, she understood what he was saying no to.

‚ÄúWe need you.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe others get sick and die. They want to be recycled.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúNo, daughter of Polka. I‚Äôm too old, and I‚Äôm watched too closely. They‚Äôre watching and listening even now. We had our chance, and as our Kingdom stood on the brink of war, your king chose the wrong allies. The Alice that just visited me was one.‚Äù

Tears flowed now, but they weren‚Äôt tears of joy.

‚ÄúWe lost. I‚Äôm firmly in check.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut—‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he said. He stroked her, then held her firm with one hand around her shoulders, while he reached for his tea. Gently, carefully, he tipped it to her mouth. ‚ÄúDrink. You‚Äôre thirsty. You look exhausted. The caffeine will help.‚Äù

Dutifully, she drank.

‚ÄúAnd then you should go. Go back. Find the others. Take care of them. Be gentle with humans you meet. So few of them understand power, and so many of them have so much, now.‚Äù

He moved the cup again, and she drank again.

She shifted her feet, placing them under her, and then stood, one foot on each of his legs.

She embraced him, arms in his beard, clutching at his shirt. His hand pressed against her back, and her tail wrapped around his wrist.

As quiet as she could manage, she whispered, ‚ÄúYou say this because they‚Äôre listening. You must want to be free.‚Äù

She felt the hand at her back move, pulling her back and away again. She leaned against it, moving back so she could see his face.

She understood now, why the Alice had used the word ‚Äòbroken‚Äô.

‚ÄúThere are things I‚Äôve talked to my Alice and the Valkyrie about, but reclaiming my kingdom or starting another anew isn‚Äôt in any of the many realms of possibility or fancy.‚Äù
