‚ÄúBut—‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he said, one last time, and the look of pain in his eyes was proof to the word.

As she‚Äôd jumped to him as her heart had leaped with joy, she jumped away at the pain, both his and hers.

‚ÄúYour name, child?‚Äù he asked.

‚ÄúDot.‚Äù

He smiled. ‚ÄúFitting, for the daughter of Polka.‚Äù

She nodded, but she didn‚Äôt feel like smiling.

‚ÄúGo home, noble dot. Do us all proud. Tell the others whatever they need to hear.‚Äù

Her hand clutched at her chest, over her heart, and then she turned to go. Into the wall. Back the way she came. Every ache and cut and scrape felt magnified as hurt radiated through her.

Going down was as hard as going up had been, but this time she didn‚Äôt have anything to go to.

Back to Blackspot, with his sickness and his hope of being reborn? Back to Lump, who got weaker every day?

To tell them what?

More rats waiting for her, probably. Other things. More pain. More machines, inching into their territory.

As much as she hated to admit it, the others were dead. She was one of the strongest who were left, that she knew about. There were other tribes and groups, there were armies, but they fought for a kingdom that hadn‚Äôt had a king for a very long time.

Hurt and pain turned black and angry inside her.

She thought of the machines and she thought of Burnish‚Äôs words. The fact that warning people of the machines might save her king.

By the time she‚Äôd reached the sixth floor, moving slowly, the idea had found its root in her head, much like the the machines found root in rocks and metal, seeds of machinery that spun out and made it so a rock could crack like an egg, revealing gears and a thousand moving pieces. Machines that made machines, all hiding and deceiving and inching forward with endless patience.

Small things were capable. She had power of her own.

She needed purpose to drive her forward, and her purpose, the goal in her mind, was to go back to that store, to find a piece of machine, and then to put it on the train.

The machines would hatch in the heart of all the known worlds and the humans would lose their kingdom too.

It was that hate and thirst for vengeance that pushed her forward, now that she didn‚Äôt have her king to serve that role. Those feelings boiled up, leaving wet streaks on her cheeks as she crept forward, from hiding place to hiding place, shadow to shadow.

The stairs were tricky. From the sixth floor to the fifth floor, it was open area, trick to navigate. Someone sat on the stairs.

The Red Queen.

Dot settled in, finding a place to sit and wait. She watched the one the King had called a Queen, and she licked her wounds, both real and metaphorical. She wished she was interesting enough in design to lick her own heart.

Something, a huff of pain, a wheezing breath, a scuffle, it made the Queen look.

The pair locked eyes.

‚ÄúWe got a warning about you,‚Äù the Red Queen said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not getting up to trouble, are you?‚Äù

Dot shook her head.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre hurt. Come here.‚Äù

Dot hesitated. Then she crept closer. She flinched as the Queen moved her hand.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay. Move your hair aside. I‚Äôll touch the side of your neck.‚Äù

Dot pawed at her hair, moving it. She felt the touch at her neck.

The pain around the cuts and the bites faded. The aches and sore joints sang with euphoria as they became normal and the endorphins that had flooded her body to help remained.

She reached out, with arms and tail, and wrapped herself around the Red Queen‚Äôs arm. She stared at the tattoos, black and red, tracing one hand along the ray of a sun. Not colorful enough, but‚Ä¶ not bad. She had spots, too, but of a very different sort.

‚ÄúWhy are you sad?‚Äù the Red Queen whispered.

‚ÄúMy king doesn‚Äôt want me,‚Äù Dot said.

‚ÄúCan I?‚Äù the Red Queen asked, moving her hand, and Dot saw. Dot nodded, and closed her eyes as the Red Queen stroked her. A different, lighter touch.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm stuck too,‚Äù the Red Queen said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve finished my work for the day, but someone I‚Äôm supposed to stay away from is just downstairs. I think I know how it feels.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf I could have one thing only, I would have him close.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúAs a friend or a master or a King or anything.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut I can‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd that anger of yours? What are we going to do about that?‚Äù

Dot might have been surprised, but King Rinke had called this woman a Queen and Queens were supposed to be capable of great things.

She kept her mouth shut. Amazed as she was, she wasn‚Äôt dumb.

‚ÄúHow about‚Ä¶ in exchange for that healing I just gave you, you keep me company for a little while?‚Äù

Carefully, slowly, Dot crawled into the Red Queen‚Äôs lap.

The Red Queen stroked her, and each stroke was like the inhalation, the exhalation, the single step toward feeling a little bit better.

Even when the hand stopped moving, and rested on Dot‚Äôs shoulder, when Dot stared at the missing fingertips, she felt a little more okay.

They sat there, long after the coast was clear for the Red Queen. It was only when people came up the stairs that they were forced to move. The Red Queen moved Dot closer, putting on her jacket, and closed up the jacket so Dot was held close, and it was good, Dot‚Äôs ear pressed down to the Red Queen‚Äôs heart.

The Red Queen started down the stairs, one arm helping to keep Dot in position within her jacket.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll help you with your anger if you help me with mine.‚Äù

Shade — 4.1

Ashley took her time exploring Hollow Point. Much of her attention was on the stores and the people within them. A store with supplies for those living on the fringes and in the tent cities, a used bookstore that was selling books taken from homes in the old world, ten dollars for a cardboard box full, a closed children‚Äôs clothing store.

The people that noticed Ashley were quick to avert their eyes or mind their own business.

She paused at a manicurist‚Äôs, looking within. There were rows of comfortable looking chairs with small tables beside them and foot baths below each seat. Ads in the window showed a variety of nail art.

Ashley held out her hand in front of her, her black nail polish contrasted with the colorful ‚ÄòChevalier‚Äô pattern, mimicking the delicate gold flourishes on a silver background. She moved her hand to compare to the ‚ÄòAlexandria‚Äô image.

She stepped away and walked a little ways down the street. She peered into more closed buildings, passed a bar where the man at the counter pretended not to see her, and then walked by a clothing resale store. She paused at a clothing store, and then entered.

She looked through a series of black dresses and skirts, taking some off the rack and draping them over one arm.

‚ÄúMa‚Äôam?‚Äù the store employee asked. The young woman looked terrified. ‚ÄúCan I help you with anything?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll let you know.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease do. I‚Äôll be at the counter.‚Äù

Ashley continued browsing, picking out an assortment of dresses, until she had eight gathered. She approached the change room and paused, looking at the sign that said only three articles of clothing could be brought into the changing area.

She entered the area, but didn‚Äôt step into any of the booths. Instead, she stood before the mirrors, holding dresses against her front. She paused as the front door opened, the bell jingling. A male voice asked a question, and the cashier said something in response.

She left six of the dresses where they were, and took two with her as she returned to the woman‚Äôs side of the store.

‚ÄúDamsel of Distress,‚Äù the man said. He wore a mask with antlers at the corner, forking and extending into the wild locks of hair. He‚Äôd used face paint to blend his face into the mask, but the paint mixed multiple colors, with a golden sheen to the paint above his eyes and black on his lower eyelids and lower eye socket. He wore a jacket that wouldn‚Äôt have looked out of place in Robin Hood, with a stag‚Äôs head and a singular antler in gold, running from the collarbone, along the collar, and over one shoulder. ‚ÄúWhat brings you to Cedar Point?‚Äù

‚ÄúIs it Cedar Point or Hollow point?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat depends on who you ask. Some of the more colorful locals prefer the latter.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe capes.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe capes. Yes. I‚Äôm guessing you‚Äôre here for them more than you‚Äôre here for the shopping.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm here to see what‚Äôs here,‚Äù she said. She turned away from him to pick through some clothes. She lifted the sleeve of a dress that was still on the rack, the dress was opaque, but the sleeve was sheer with a lace pattern worked into it.

‚ÄúAnd?‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm not impressed so far.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat did you expect to find that you‚Äôre not seeing?‚Äù

‚ÄúOrganization. A timely response to my arrival. I‚Äôve been walking around for nearly half an hour and you‚Äôre the first person to show their face.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe prefer discretion.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt feels toothless. A sanctuary for villains, and you let people walk in here without stopping them?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been keeping a close eye on you.‚Äù

‚ÄúEyes aren‚Äôt teeth.‚Äù

‚ÄúSome are, when you add powers to the mix. Shall we take this discussion outside?‚Äù

Ashley looked at the two dresses in her hand. She put one back where it belonged, and then approached the counter.

‚ÄúUm,‚Äù the salesgirl said. ‚ÄúYou can have it. It‚Äôs on the house.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs it?‚Äù Ashley asked.

‚ÄúStore policy. The owner hopes that you‚Äôll have a positive view of the store, in case of future trouble. Would you like a bag?‚Äù

Ashley looked at the dress, then shook her head, slinging the dress over one shoulder. She looked at the villain with the antlers. ‚ÄúWe can talk outside.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll be right with you.‚Äù

She walked out of the store, glancing over one shoulder to see him discreetly passing some bills to the salesgirl, who ducked her head in acknowledgement.

The streets were mostly empty, without many cars, parked or otherwise. Some of the stores had tunnels or alleys that led to parking lots, but even those didn‚Äôt have many vehicles. Employee parking, when many stores had only one employee on average.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm Prancer, by the by,‚Äù Prancer said, as he exited the store.

‚ÄúThe messenger.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm— no. Not a messenger,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIf Cedar Point is anyone‚Äôs, it‚Äôs mine.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was there when you first raised the idea of a gathering place.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen you know what we‚Äôre doing.‚Äù

‚ÄúI walked away halfway through your speech.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Prancer said.

A car pulled out of the alley, turned a corner, and then drove through the neighborhood, not slowing as it passed the pair.

‚ÄúNormally when one villain visits another‚Äôs territory, there‚Äôs a token show of respect.‚Äù

‚ÄúNormally,‚Äù Ashley said, ‚Äúthe person holding the territory does something to earn the respect. Normally, when someone brings up respect, they‚Äôre prepared to back up their words. Are you going to back up your words and give me some evidence that you deserve even a token show of respect?‚Äù

Prancer didn‚Äôt immediately reply. The two stared each other down.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to be one of the difficult ones, it seems,‚Äù Prancer said.

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre relying on convention and expectation then yes, I am. If you show me you deserve my time and respect, I‚Äôll give you it. If you think I‚Äôll give it to you because you run this territory, you‚Äôll be sadly disappointed. I might even supplant you.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a dangerous game, Damsel of Distress. Making threats, forcing people to play their hands. You don‚Äôt know what cards someone has up their sleeves.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have ideas. You appeared alone, no bodyguard, no backup. You appeared late. You can‚Äôt back up your reputation.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou might have the wrong ideas about the kind of territory this is.‚Äù

‚ÄúEnlighten me,‚Äù Ashley said. It almost sounded like a threat.

‚ÄúCome. Walk with me,‚Äù he said.

They started walking down the sidewalk, in a neighborhood where a third of the businesses were closed.

Prancer did the talking for the first leg of their walk. ‚ÄúAny community of capes will have its rules. Standards and things it does that benefit everyone in it. I‚Äôm not a warlord. I manage a very diverse group. If someone causes a problem, if someone tests us, I can and will give that diverse group direction or adjust the rules. I can and will point one of the many, many powers we have at our disposal here at that someone. Some are dangerous, some are devious, and some aren‚Äôt even parahuman kinds of powers.‚Äù

‚ÄúPolitical.‚Äù

‚ÄúEconomic. Social,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúI might not be a warlord, I might not even be a warrior, but I have reach. A few words from me, and you might find it very hard to find work with a parahuman group. You might find that people won‚Äôt recruit you or do business with you.‚Äù

‚ÄúAm I supposed to be concerned? I‚Äôm not looking to join any team, Prancer. I‚Äôm not looking to buy or sell petty drugs or prostitutes. When I decide to act, I‚Äôll be leading a team, not joining one, and people will flock to me regardless of what you say. They‚Äôll do business with me because there‚Äôs no other choice. I‚Äôm ready to call that bluff of yours.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd be the first I make an example of? No. I‚Äôm something of a schemer, a bit of a politician, and I‚Äôm a very good businessman. But if you‚Äôre going to deal with me, you should know that above any and all of that, I‚Äôm a salesman. If we‚Äôre talking about bluffs, I know bluffs when I see them, Damsel of Distress. I know you came here because you want something.‚Äù

‚ÄúI did. I finished some shopping and I have your measure, and I have the measure of your neighborhood.‚Äù

‚ÄúSomething drew you away from your cozy apartment in an unassuming neighborhood, away from your regular appointments with therapists and the Wardens. Your years of history before Gold Morning are a pattern of laying low, being quiet, committing crimes to get food and clothes, and then getting restless and bored. That‚Äôs when you traditionally start stirring up trouble. Are you restless?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou read my files. If you‚Äôre expecting that level of access to intimidate me, you‚Äôll be disappointed.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think you‚Äôre bored. I know you‚Äôve been hanging around the Cabin, or the Lodge if you want to call it that. I know you like spending time at the tea shop. I know that when you get restless you often look for people to spend time with. The Jewel of Boston, the Slaughterhouse Nine. We know how those stories ended.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm alive and many of them are dead.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not how I would have put it, but alright,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúIf you want something here, you should ask.‚Äù

‚ÄúI thought I might want to find a place around here, but if you‚Äôre slow to respond to my arrival, you might be slow to stop heroes from getting in my way.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou want a place in the community?‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd security, assurance I won‚Äôt be harassed. You know about the appointments. They‚Äôre why I‚Äôm left free when other ex-members of the Slaughterhouse Nine are still under lock and key. They study me then, I let them, and I want to leave it at that, for those days and those times only. I don‚Äôt want to be surveilled or scrutinized when I don‚Äôt have to be.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe have a variety of security measures in place. If you chose to move here, if we allowed you to, I think you‚Äôd be satisfied.‚Äù

‚ÄúEmpty assurances.‚Äù

‚ÄúMore robust assurances would come only when we knew we could trust you to some degree. Obviously, we‚Äôre not about to share particulars with a stranger. You could turn around and join a rival group and share that information with them.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd if I became less of a stranger, it would require an investment of time and trust. At that point it would be hard to escape. Sunken cost.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen it seems we‚Äôre at an impasse.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo it seems.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd I can expect you to leave promptly, then.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll leave when I‚Äôm ready,‚Äù Ashley said. She turned to walk in another direction, heading for another clothing store.

‚äô

‚ÄúSwitch to the overhead camera. I want to see what Prancer says and does.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll project onto the other wall,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúI want to keep the main camera on Ashley.‚Äù

She struck a few keys. One face of the projector box behind her desk lit up, projecting onto the wall. The image was blurry and badly affected by the light around the room at first, as any projector screen could be, but it swiftly clarified, crystallizing into an image as sharp as any flatscreen television. It was an overhead of the street.

The overhead image split, until that screen showed two camera views of Prancer at the same time, one directly overhead, and another that gave something of a view of his face.

The main camera, on the wall in front of and above Kenzie‚Äôs desk, showed Ashley‚Äôs point of view. The view bobbed with every step Ashley took, and was periodically obscured when Ashley blinked.

Tristan was bringing things into the room. The team‚Äôs temporary accommodation. Rain was in the corner, where a table had been set up, laying out parts of mechanical arms while Chris watched.

In the center of the room, Sveta, Natalie the law student and I watched things on the cameras.

Natalie had her arms folded. Her hair was shorter than most boys wore theirs, with a curl at the forehead, her glasses seemed oversized for her face, and her forehead was wrinkled in worry or concentration. She dressed in clothes that made me think she‚Äôd picked clothes out of a magazine without reading the rationale behind those clothes. She wore a blouse that fit her body closely, made of a faintly reflective material, with a black ribbon tied where it drew the collar together. She wore a straight-cut skirt that started at the waist and ended at the knee, and dark hose, with tidy, heel-less business shoes. It was the kind of thing that made a model in a magazine look stunning, but Natalie was five-foot two, she didn‚Äôt really have a waist, and the outfit made both of those things very obvious.

‚ÄúWhat do you think?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI think it would be very hard to explain to a judge why your agent took the free clothes from the store,‚Äù Natalie said. ‚ÄúI think you could explain it, but it feels like an implicit protection racket and that‚Äôs something that would be thrown in your faces.‚Äù

‚ÄúHey Tristan. Can I grab one of those whiteboards?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúSure.‚Äù

The whiteboard didn‚Äôt have the legs or rollers attached yet, so Sveta held it upright for me. I wrote down the bit about taking the dress ‚Äòon the house‚Äô.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like the threatening tone, either. Entrapment has a pretty high bar, but if your agent threatens the targets, implicitly or explicitly, to insinuate herself into that environment, it casts a lot of it into jeopardy. They‚Äôll turn around and say they had to do these things because a woman in black who can kill people by pointing at them was telling them to.‚Äù

I wrote it down. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll tell her to tone it down. How long until we can communicate with her, Kenzie?‚Äù

Kenzie spun around in her computer chair, pulling her legs close to her chest to keep them out of the way of the desk‚Äôs edge. She stuck out a foot, kicking one of the boxes to the right of the desk. A bar appeared diagonally across it. ‚ÄúSixty percent. Ummmm. Fifteen minutes until we can be totally sure they‚Äôre not tapped into cell towers or internet.‚Äù

‚ÄúI actually have a lot of concerns about her as an undercover agent.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not an undercover agent,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs just there. Keeping an eye on things, keeping an ear out.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs an undercover agent,‚Äù Natalie said.

‚ÄúShe isn‚Äôt joining any team or participating in anything,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúNo espionage, no immediate risk,‚Äù Chris added his voice.

‚ÄúI have concerns,‚Äù Natalie said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll just say that.‚Äù

Ashley was investigating a bookstore now, on the main screen. Our testing of the waters.

On the other screen, Prancer was meeting a trio of others.

Kenzie glanced at it and hit a key. Windows popped up, with three-dimensional models of each face, mask included. A young woman with a purple hood with nascent antlers sticking up through it, a skinny woman with rusty nails instead of teeth, and a woman in a white jacket with a doctor‚Äôs face mask.

I named them. ‚ÄúVelvet and Nailbiter. That might be Bitter Pill, but she hasn‚Äôt shown her face or been photographed any for the files. Is there sound?‚Äù

Kenzie hit a key on her keyboard. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to kill the flying camera‚Äôs battery. We get a minute or two and then I need to bring it home. Or we get three minutes and I bring it halfway home, and someone has to go over to pick it up wherever I land it.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright.‚Äù

‚Äú‚Ä¶up to?‚Äù Velvet asked, her voice playing from a speaker.

‚ÄúLooking around. She was thinking of moving in, but she didn‚Äôt like how long it took us to turn up,‚Äù Prancer said.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs aware we were watching her, isn‚Äôt she?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo. And she doesn‚Äôt give a shit, either. I outright told her and she was more concerned about the fact we hadn‚Äôt shown ourselves sooner. She‚Äôll be a problem if she sticks around.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat kind of problem?‚Äù

Tristan, Rain, and Chris had stopped what they were doing and drew close, to listen and watch.

‚ÄúShe was quick to talk about supplanting the local leadership. We operate with a soft hand and she seems like the sort that respects only firm ones. There‚Äôs more to it, ties into something we‚Äôve heard from‚Ä¶ key voices. I‚Äôd rather have that conversation somewhere more private than this.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you want me to deal with her?‚Äù Nailbiter asked, her words whistling through her teeth.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Prancer said.

‚ÄúWhy am I here then?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause I think you and her are similar. You respect strength, you know how power works. You‚Äôve dealt with scary customers. If we end up interacting with her more, and especially if she moves into the neighborhood, I think we want you to be on point, interacting with her more.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can do that. She was Slaughterhouse?‚Äù

‚ÄúBriefly, and you were Birdcage. I think a lot of the same principles apply.‚Äù

Nailbiter chuckled, a wheezy, whistling sound. ‚ÄúI never thought of that. Probably.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf this visitor of ours winds up being a problem, I don‚Äôt want you stepping into the fray against her.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy not?‚Äù Nailbiter asked.

‚ÄúBecause I don‚Äôt know how it would turn out. I‚Äôd rather make moves where I know the result in advance.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhatever,‚Äù Nailbiter said.

Velvet made a sound, then drew closer to Prancer, putting her arm around him. He put his arm around her. ‚ÄúNot whatever. I like that kind of thinking.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù Prancer said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm curious what that thing is that you don‚Äôt want to talk about in the open,‚Äù Velvet said. ‚ÄúCan we go inside?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe can. You‚Äôre free to carry on with your day, Nailbiter. Thanks for coming. Pill, I want to ask you about some import-export work. Can you come?‚Äù

There was no sound from Bitter Pill, only a nod that the camera caught.

The group split up, Nailbiter walked away. The trio headed into an alleyway. The airborne camera moved, trying to get a view of the alley interior, and only saw a door close.

The image changed, as Kenzie typed. It showed an overhead map of the area. Kenzie marked the building they‚Äôd entered with a red highlight and a little flag icon, then began typing out a note.

‚ÄúCan you get sound of building interiors?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúKind of not really,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs real clear,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got one camera with good aerial camouflage that I really don‚Äôt want to get damaged because it took a whole weekend and a lot of stuff to put it together. I have two more that don‚Äôt have special camouflage, they‚Äôre just painted to match the sky, and I can only use them if the sky is the right color, or if I don‚Äôt mind them being spotted. They could get destroyed and I wouldn‚Äôt mind them breaking that much. It would take me something like two days to get more advanced sound built into any of them, and then I‚Äôm putting a lot of eggs in one basket or I‚Äôm making a disposable camera not so disposable.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut you can do it?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm better with visuals, but yeah, I can do it.‚Äù

‚ÄúEven if we decided it was worth building, it would take a while before you had that kind of microphone online,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a sound camera, not a microphone,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúBut yeah. And I‚Äôm trying to figure out the teleporters and the longer ranged cameras and I‚Äôve got to fix up some old stuff so it‚Äôs ready if we need it, and that‚Äôs all stuff I really should do, and if I‚Äôm doing that I‚Äôm not doing any of the fun stuff.‚Äù

Ashley, on her screen, paused to write something down.

LEAVING SOON

She used a small burst of her power to destroy the paper shortly after writing it down.

Kenzie snapshotted the note, then typed it up, adding it to a log in the sidebar, where it joined two other brief notes that Ashley had written on her way into Cedar Point.

‚ÄúOne thing I‚Äôll say about Ashley?‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs provocative. From what I saw of that conversation, she impugned Prancer‚Äôs leadership right off, forced him to prove himself, gave us a sense of the power structure. She almost had him talking about anti-surveillance measures, but he‚Äôs being smart about keeping that mostly under wraps.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe probably has some we haven‚Äôt heard or talked about,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúShe didn‚Äôt make any friends while she was doing all of that,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt need her to make friends,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not going undercover. Not explicitly. She‚Äôs just‚Ä¶ there. Keeping an eye on things.‚Äù

I said, ‚ÄúMy instinct is that if she keeps pushing on the level she was, people will get antsy or suspicious. It might be good to have her hang back, wait a bit before making contact or visiting again.‚Äù

‚ÄúI could swing through,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúWe should wait until we‚Äôre more settled,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúThere are actually a few obstacles to figure out,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúSorry to take over the one whiteboard here.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe got a lot of the whiteboards because we thought we‚Äôd have one for each member of the team, and one for you, Victoria,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúTwo for Kenzie and two for me because we‚Äôre tinkers and you can never give tinkers too many surfaces to write stuff down on.‚Äù

‚ÄúYus,‚Äù Kenzie said. Her legs were kicking a mile a minute as she focused on her computers, a box to her right and the projector box on the far side of her desk, the camera images playing on the wall. One of the split-screen images showing the overhead of the building Prancer had entered turned red, blacked out, and then disappeared, shrinking down to leave the other image, which was tracking Nailbiter.

‚ÄúCan you project the faces you had onto one of the whiteboards?‚Äù Sveta asked.

Kenzie brought up images, then moved the projected image until it overlapped one side of the whiteboard. She had to look over one shoulder as she moved the mouse to make sure the image was in place.

Sveta dropped her hand, and used a tendril-wrapped marker to slowly trace out major facial features, hair, and the outlines of the masks for Prancer.

I looked at Natalie.

Natalie‚Äôs forehead, perpetually wrinkled, wrinkled further as she raised her eyebrows, looking from whiteboard to whiteboard, screen to screen. ‚ÄúI recommend moving slowly at first. I‚Äôll give you some general, not-a-lawyer advice on things for free. It‚Äôs interesting and it‚Äôs relevant to what I want to do in the long run.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs great. I‚Äôm not sure how slow the initial moves are going to be, though. The team needs to get some things out of the way before they have more freedom.‚Äù

Sveta turned her head. ‚ÄúThe stuff Foresight said?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre situated on the very outskirts of Cedar Point, here, and you can‚Äôt move into the area until a few hurdles are crossed. You can‚Äôt really have Ashley or Chris spend any extended time in the area until the Speedrunners, Birdbrain and Braindead are dealt with, and we can‚Äôt move this headquarters into enemy territory if they‚Äôre going to find it and trash the place. In an ideal world, you‚Äôll want to do something about Tattletale‚Äôs involvement too.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been thinking of Tattletale as an inevitable thing we‚Äôll have to deal with,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúThere are things you can do,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúWe can discuss those things when Natalie is gone.‚Äù

‚ÄúActually,‚Äù Natalie said. ‚ÄúI should probably go. I have a class tomorrow morning and then work at the Wardens‚Äô building tomorrow afternoon.‚Äù

A class. I felt a tiny bit of resentment over the fact that she had that.

‚ÄúAlright. Thank you for coming and saying hi,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs interesting,‚Äù she said, forehead wrinkling in that worried way. ‚ÄúI really recommend you be careful.‚Äù

‚ÄúAs careful as is possible,‚Äù Sveta said.

Natalie nodded. ‚ÄúIt was nice to meet you all. You have my number if you need it.‚Äù

There was a chorus of farewells. I walked Natalie to the side door of the building, where the fire escape was. The way down was steep, and she kept one hand on her little messenger bag and the other on the railing as she made her way down, bringing one foot down to a step, then bringing the other foot down to the same step.

Her entire demeanor made me feel faintly anxious. I didn‚Äôt have a great read on her yet, she‚Äôd spent ten minutes at the temporary headquarters here, and most of it had been spent observing.

It was something of a relief to have her available if we needed her, and it was a different kind of relief to have her gone. The others, too, seemed to relax a bit.

‚ÄúNatalie seemed nice enough,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúShe did,‚Äù I said.

I took a moment to get Natalie‚Äôs number off my phone and put it on one corner of the whiteboard I‚Äôd been using, the whiteboard leaning against the wall. I then wrote down Gilpatrick‚Äôs, with a note beneath it. For emergencies only.

The Patrol was a resource, Gilpatrick was one too. I didn‚Äôt want to overuse that card, though. Gilpatrick had already been too kind with being a reference for me while I hunted for work.

With those numbers in the top corner, joined by my own, I wrote down ‚ÄòHurdles‚Äô.

We‚Äôd already covered the basics of the major players on the scene. Speedrunners, Birdbrain, Braindead, Bitter Pill. There were others that we‚Äôd learn about, I was sure. Prancer was the closest thing we had to a kingpin that needed toppling.

In a hypothetical world where everything went perfectly, I wouldn‚Äôt have minded getting Tattletale as a part of things. I wasn‚Äôt sure my hopes were that high.

I put them down as the people the group needed to knock down before they could fully set up.

I wrote down ‚ÄòTeam: Needs name & brand.‚Äô

‚ÄúOoh,‚Äù Kenzie said.

She was watching me write stuff down, her attention no longer on her computers.

‚ÄúHere,‚Äù Tristan said, approaching my whiteboard. He held it up, and then created the orange sparks. They solidified, becoming the legs that raised the whiteboard up to a convenient level.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no rush to name ourselves,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúNo rush,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúBut it needs doing. It‚Äôll be easier to interact with other heroes once you have something. Are you taking a cape name?‚Äù

‚ÄúProbably,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure I want to go the doll route. A little too similar to Mannequin. A lot of the reaching, grabbing names are already taken.‚Äù

‚ÄúBrainstorm, think about it, see what feels comfortable,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúKenzie and Tristan, you guys too. You probably can‚Äôt use your old cape names.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was Optics,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt use my old name, I don‚Äôt think. PRT owned it.‚Äù

‚ÄúExactly,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI think I can use Capricorn,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúWhen we reached out to the first Capricorn for permission, they signed over the rights to Byron and me, not to Reach.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre sure?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúNinety-nine percent sure.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat simplifies things,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúObserver, Pupil, Scrutinizer,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúThose are terrible,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúUm. Watcher. Eyewitness, Gape?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh yeah,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúGape. That doesn‚Äôt have connotations at all.‚Äù

‚ÄúBeholder?‚Äù Kenzie asked, her eye on her computer screen. ‚ÄúSpectator. Specs. Voyeur?‚Äù

‚ÄúVoyeur. Perfect,‚Äù Chris said, filling his voice with sarcasm. ‚ÄúLittle Kenzie watching through the window while you change. We could make that a thing.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat kind of thing?‚Äù Rain asked.

‚ÄúYou could be Groper,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúSveta could be Hentai or Tentacle Love or something.‚Äù

‚ÄúEw,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúAnd lame to go there.‚Äù

Chris smiled, seemingly not bothered that he‚Äôd bothered Sveta. ‚ÄúI could be‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúShort and curly?‚Äù Rain asked.

There were a few chuckles.

‚ÄúAnd Victoria, she needs a name and she‚Äôs sort of a member of the team,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm shocked, just shocked, at how Chris finally starts participating more when the rude stuff comes up,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúThat seems like it‚Äôs one hundred percent Chris.‚Äù

I smiled. Chris had given me an in, and if I was going to get along with these guys, I needed to put something out there. ‚ÄúIf you want to give me a vaguely rude name, tie it to my attention-grabbing aura, me being hard to crack when my defenses are up?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou have an idea?‚Äù Chris asked.

‚ÄúPearl,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs‚Ä¶ really subtle,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúKind of wimpy.‚Äù

I shrugged.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt get it,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúI like it because Kenzie doesn‚Äôt get it, so I don‚Äôt feel weird saying it around her,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a good line of thinking,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI approve.‚Äù

She‚Äôd stuck out her fist, and I stuck out mine to meet it. ‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI actually agree with Chris,‚Äù Kenzie said. She‚Äôd turned around and was looking something up online. ‚ÄúPearl is pretty lame as innuendo goes.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut it works,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIt fits. That has to count for something.‚Äù

There was a throat-clearing noise, interrupting the back-and-forth. All heads turned toward Tristan.

‚ÄúI think I have all of you beat,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúOf course you do,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúEven if you didn‚Äôt have us beat, you‚Äôd say you had us beat,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúAnd then you‚Äôd ruin the joke by insisting you win even when yours is lame.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm one hundred percent positive I win,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúI have the best rude name. Guarantee you.‚Äù

‚ÄúOne hundred percent is pretty confident,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm one hundred and ten percent confident, even,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúOut with it, then,‚Äù Chris said.

Tristan straightened, fixed his armor at the front, and cleared his throat, drawing it out.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre setting us up for disappointment,‚Äù Rain said.

Tristan cleared his throat again, exaggerated, until everyone from Sveta to Chris was rolling their eyes.

‚ÄúWet and Horny Teens,‚Äù Tristan said.

It said something that nobody wanted to give him a laugh at that. It was Chris who cracked first, falling out of his seat before the impact let the initial guffaw loose. I chuckled, half at Tristan, and half at how much Chris seemed to be enjoying this.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs atrocious,‚Äù Sveta said, but she was smiling.

‚ÄúTristan is pretty atrocious, so it makes a lot of sense coming from him,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúIt says a lot that that‚Äôs his idea of subtle.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs subtle like a brick through a window,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúCome on,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúYou guys give me so much shit, you don‚Äôt give me any credit. I deserve a win for this one. It‚Äôs great.‚Äù

Chris was on the floor still, pounding one fist on the floorboards while holding in his laughs.

I looked over at Kenzie, who had her back to the group, her face in her hands as she held in her laughs.

Immature, stupid, but so valuable to have the little bonding moment. I had a smile on my face as I returned to the whiteboard.

My eye returned to the people the group needed to take down, the ones who were in the way, or who were set up in such a way as to make the covert information gathering fail from the get-go.

I wrote down ‚ÄòRain‚Äôs situation‚Äô.

He needed protection. I added the three members of his cluster, and then drew an arrow, looping back to Tattletale.

The smile dropped away from my face as I stared at her name. It kept going back to her. She was a massive obstacle.

Sveta came to stand next to me, looking at my whiteboard. ‚ÄúDistract me from these perverts.‚Äù

I stuck out my marker, putting a dot beside Tattletale‚Äôs name.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got a bit of a grudge,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got a lot of a grudge,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúA lot of things would be simpler if we could do something about her. I‚Äôm thinking‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúYou have an idea?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. I turned around. ‚ÄúI have an idea. I don‚Äôt suppose you have any contacts or favors you can pull in? With capes, specifically?‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúWeld, and Weld‚Äôs friends. I‚Äôm kind of reluctant to go there though.‚Äù

I nodded. It made sense that she was reluctant. Sveta wanted to stand on her own. Going that route would be the opposite of what she wanted.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs this?‚Äù Rain asked.

‚ÄúFriends, contacts,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúCapes we could reach out to. Victoria has an idea.‚Äù

‚ÄúI do,‚Äù Kenzie said, perking up some as she caught wind of our conversation. ‚ÄúOr I might. I can try. What‚Äôs this for?‚Äù

‚ÄúMaking a first move, in a way that won‚Äôt give the lawyer headaches,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not going to make us any friends though.‚Äù

‚ÄúSeems to be an emerging pattern, that,‚Äù Rain said.

If we aren‚Äôt in a position to behead the snake, maybe we can de-fang it.

Shade — 4.2

‚ÄúClassify the following angles as obtuse, acute, or right,‚Äù Kenzie said. She sighed.

‚ÄúYou know this?‚Äù I asked.

She looked up from her homework and rolled her eyes. ‚ÄúYes, I know this. I didn‚Äôt have the words to describe what I knew before taking the class but I get this.‚Äù

‚ÄúMake it interesting,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúChallenge yourself, try to answer as fast as you can, and try to get past where you‚Äôre having to think about it and get to where the knowledge is automatic.‚Äù

‚ÄúAcute, acute, obtuse, right, acute, obtuse, acute, right, right,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really tempted to sit down and make up my own questions to leave on the worksheet for the teacher, except I‚Äôd have to look things up to make sure some mathematician didn‚Äôt already give it a name. What‚Äôs it called when it‚Äôs a full circle? Three hundred and sixty degrees of angle?‚Äù

I frowned. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre asking me to think back about seven years right now. Complete, I think?‚Äù

‚ÄúFull, complete, or perigon,‚Äù Chris said.

All heads craned around to look at him. He was sitting in a corner, a table to his left, with so many things piled up that the bag, costume, snacks and notebooks loomed well over the top of his head. He sat on a chair with his feet up on the seat, a comic and phone on his lap. He had his headphones on, but only one was covering an ear.

He realized people were looking and frowned. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou actually have a brain?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúI studied it a few weeks ago,‚Äù Chris said, shrugging, turning his attention back to his comic.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm pretty sure I don‚Äôt remember studying that when I was your age,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúI self-study. There aren‚Äôt enough seats in schools so they gave us the option of doing these workbooks and handing them in. I‚Äôve lost track of how far ahead I got,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs why I don‚Äôt have homework. My regular schoolwork is the homework and I get that done earlier in the day.‚Äù

‚ÄúPerigon,‚Äù Kenzie said to herself, hunched over her worksheet and books, a pen in hand. ‚ÄúThat one sounds best. Let‚Äôs call this one a‚Ä¶ hyper-perigon angle.‚Äù

‚ÄúMore complete an angle than a circle?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIf you want to get into multidimensional space then you have to get there somehow. So you make a circle that‚Äôs more closed than a regular circle and that gives you an in, right? It can be theoretical if you want but obviously this is one of a hundred ways I can start pushing the boundaries.‚Äù

‚ÄúUh huh.‚Äù

She drew on the paper with her pen, drawing out a perfect circle and then scribbling out extra lines and numbers.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre aware you can‚Äôt hand that in now, right?‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine, it‚Äôs fine,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúOnce you‚Äôre there you can start thinking about lenses positioned to use the excess space you‚Äôve given yourself and play that out. I heard somewhere that images that hit the back of your eye get flipped upside-down, and the brain turns it back upright. So we write something down that lets us toy with that concept‚Ä¶‚Äù

Her pen moved as she wrote out a mathematical formula.

‚Äú‚Ä¶And from there we get the reflected extra space on the other side of the lens constant. In brief, we start talking about hyper-hyper-perigon angles.‚Äù

‚ÄúHyper is right,‚Äù Chris muttered.

‚ÄúShh, leave her alone,‚Äù Sveta said.

Kenzie looked up at me, ‚ÄúThis is where I have to leave you behind, Victoria, because I get stuff that‚Äôs hyper-hyper but I can‚Äôt help you get it.‚Äù

‚ÄúFrankly, you left me behind a minute ago,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúWhat are the hearts, stars, and apples you‚Äôre writing down?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs algebra, duh. You don‚Äôt have to use X and Y or A and B. You can use anything to represent the variable. I like hearts and stars and apples.‚Äù

‚ÄúI feel like if you autopsied Kenzie, she‚Äôd have a bowl of breakfast cereal instead of gray matter.‚Äù

Kenzie spun around, sticking out a hand to grab the desk so she didn‚Äôt keep spinning. She stared at Chris, ‚ÄúI feel like if we autopsied you, Chris, we‚Äôd find you have one of those tumors with teeth, eyes and hair in it instead of a brain.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a good chance you actually would,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôd be cool.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes it would,‚Äù Kenzie said, very seriously. She spun herself around, grabbing the desk, now facing her defaced homework.

Sveta walked over from the whiteboard, where she‚Äôd finished tracing the faces that had once been projected onto it. An artist‚Äôs sketch of the players we‚Äôd seen and been involved with. Another part of the whiteboard had some name ideas.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt hand that in,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúI said that already,‚Äù I said.

Kenzie looked up at me. ‚ÄúPeople often ask how the tinkering stuff works. It‚Äôs real easy. All it takes is closing a circle extra closed and having the right lens to use the wrinkles and bulges that result.‚Äù

‚ÄúEasy,‚Äù I said, smiling a little.

She continued drawing out math and lines. She had a steady hand when it came to drawing out the geometry. I idly wondered if her tinker power played into that. She began drawing out a gun, similar to her flash pistol.

The drawing of a woman‚Äôs face was comparatively, almost ludicrously crude compared to the gun she‚Äôd drawn out. Kenzie scribbled out the eyes, then wrote out ‚ÄòI gave boring angle homework and now I‚Äôm blind foreverrrr‚Äô.

She wrote out a few more ‚Äòr‚Äôs and then paused, scribbling out ‚Äòboring‚Äô and writing ‚Äòobtuse‚Äô above the scribble.

‚ÄúKenzie,‚Äù Sveta said, with a truly impressive amount of disappointment in the one word.

Kenzie turned her head slightly, looking up at Sveta with one eye that twinkled with mischief. She looked back at her work, writing down an extra ‚Äòoh no‚Äô by the teacher‚Äôs head.

I cocked my head, listening as Kenzie worked with renewed energy.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre getting carried away,‚Äù Sveta said.

I looked at the boxes near Kenzie, saw the projector box to Kenzie‚Äôs right had a face lit up. It was pointed at the whiteboard Sveta had been working on, but no longer projected the camera images of the faces.

Reaching down, I plucked the pen from Kenzie‚Äôs hand.

She didn‚Äôt protest or stop me, only leaning back as I picked up the paper.

I walked a few paces away, holding up the sheet, glanced back at the projector box, and then walked another two paces.

The projected image of the scribblings, tinker notes and doodles disappeared. I turned it around to show Sveta.

She took the sheet, then experimented with moving it inside and beyond the boundaries of the projector box. Kenzie perched on the edge of her seat, watching, her tongue sticking out between her teeth, where she lightly bit it.

‚ÄúWell played,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI said it was fine,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúYou did.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe filled in some of the right answers with real pen marks while scribbling,‚Äù Sveta observed. She turned the sheet around, moving it through the air.

The scratched out word with ‚Äòobtuse‚Äô over it had been cover for putting ‚Äòobtuse‚Äô into one of the blanks.

‚ÄúVery well played,‚Äù I said.

Sveta handed the sheet back. Kenzie put it down and moved her hand. The projector moved the image of the scribblings on her whiteboard, leaving the sheet normal. She flipped it over and sighed, head lolling back. Without looking at the sheet, she said, ‚ÄúAcute, right, obtuse, acute, acute, obtuse.‚Äù

Sveta approached, putting a hand on Kenzie‚Äôs head. ‚ÄúHow about instead of doing the math homework you could do in your sleep, you take advantage of having us here to help you with stuff you aren‚Äôt as strong with? What do you struggle with?‚Äù

‚ÄúI get As in everything and A pluses in some stuff. But I work on English for the longest and I‚Äôm a little less good at gym. Mostly when I get bad marks it‚Äôs because I lost marks because my teachers are fed up with me.‚Äù

‚ÄúFed up?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúMrs. Beyer docked my grade because I wanted to stay inside at recess to talk with her about a project and she said I couldn‚Äôt and she needed a break from me. She said no ifs ands or buts and I said but, so she penalized my grade. Then when I tried to argue she took off a mark for every word I said. Five marks for five words, and one for the but— don‚Äôt even say it, Chris.‚Äù

Chris was talking with Tristan and Rain. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre so self-important you think I‚Äôm listening to you?‚Äù

Kenzie smiled, rolling her eyes a bit.

‚ÄúEnglish, then?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúIt takes me the longest,‚Äù Kenzie said.

Sveta looked at me. ‚ÄúHow were you in English?‚Äù

‚ÄúB minus or thereabouts,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI did better with the courses I took at the hospital than I did in high school.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow come?‚Äù

‚ÄúI write good papers and I‚Äôm good with themes and symbolism, but the classes I took in high school spent so long on each thing I felt like my brain was turning inside out with boredom. I‚Äôd start resenting the books and I sabotaged myself by not doing the related work or reading it myself. Don‚Äôt do that, Kenzie.‚Äù

‚ÄúI do well in English, even with the parts we sit on forever,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll take point in helping Kenzie, you help?‚Äù

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù I said.

My role ended up being even more backseat than that. Sveta had read the book, and I hadn‚Äôt. I stood back, watching, glanced back at the others, where the three boys were talking video games, which they had been doing since before Kenzie had started on her homework, and I rolled my eyes.

Rain stepped away from the conversation. Grabbing a marker from the packet, he wrote ‚ÄòRain‚Äô at the top corner of his whiteboard.

Below that, he wrote, ‚Äònames‚Äô, followed by ‚ÄòBracer‚Äô, ‚ÄòClasp‚Äô, and ‚ÄòPinch‚Äô.

I approached, looking.

‚ÄúNo homework?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI like to do it late. My family mostly leaves me alone while I‚Äôm doing it, and I get to tire out my brain and distract myself from what sleeping actually involves. I can go straight from that to bed.‚Äù

I nodded. ‚ÄúSounds like you have a system then. If you ever need help with studying, I‚Äôm happy to help.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm a pretty crummy student, but I get by. I think I‚Äôll be okay.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre sure?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah. I can‚Äôt see myself doing anything that leans too heavily on the school thing anyway.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôd be surprised at how it comes into play,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúMaybe. But‚Ä¶ I dunno if I see myself being alive and well a few years from now. That might be some of it.‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause of your cluster?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause capes don‚Äôt tend to live that long. Because things were going south well before Gold Morning and it doesn‚Äôt feel like anything‚Äôs over or stopped. Every day, I think about the fact that there are still Endbringers out there. Broken triggers. Dangerous people with too much power.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs heroes. People stopping those things. Maybe you‚Äôll be one of them. People die— it sucks but not all of them die. Not all of us.‚Äù

‚ÄúI guess,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt might sound like I‚Äôm trying to ask for a pep talk, but I‚Äôm really not. Right now, I‚Äôm focused on things I gotta do. Like a name.‚Äù

That was my signal to back off. Fine.

‚ÄúClasp is a fairly decent name. Could work with the right costume. I‚Äôm not sure it feels right with the blaster power.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was thinking of seizing something, as a prelude to something, or unclasping as‚Ä¶ it sounded better in my head. Don‚Äôt laugh at my terrible names or reasoning, please,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúMaking a name that captures all of your powers when you have four is a pain in the ass. I‚Äôm just brainstorming.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to make fun,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI have no idea what I‚Äôm going to call myself when I get back to the costumed heroics.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI was trying to think of names that might sound like they refer to the hands and the set-up, knock-down part of the power. Kind of. I don‚Äôt know.‚Äù

‚ÄúBracer‚Äôs taken, by the way,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure of the others.‚Äù

He reached down to the pile of stuff at the foot of his board and picked up one of his tinker arms. It was just a bit thinner than his regular arm, just a bit shorter. Kenzie‚Äôs picture of a gun had looked more ‚Äòtinker‚Äô than this. It was wires with sheet metal bent into a crude, hand-like shape around it. He brought the textured plastic pad up to his shoulder and bound the straps around his shoulder, armpit, and upper arm before tapping it twice. He winced, showing his teeth momentarily.

‚ÄúHurts?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúNervous connection, and a bit of excess energy with the switch-on. I could fine tune it so it doesn‚Äôt shock me, but I might break something in the process. Ashley‚Äôs hands are made by someone who doesn‚Äôt even focus on prosthetics and they‚Äôre better than what I make.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou might be better than you think.‚Äù

‚ÄúMrs. Yamada thinks I have self esteem problems, but I do suck, so it‚Äôs more like I‚Äôm too aware of my reality. My blaster power is okay, because it‚Äôs mine, but it‚Äôs kind of all or nothing, leaning just a bit toward nothing, especially if I‚Äôm avoiding trying to kill, which I am.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said. I thought of him jumping off the train. I wondered how honest he was about it. ‚ÄúThe mover power, it lets you‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúStop.‚Äù

He stepped back, then jogged a few steps, stopping mid-run, as if he‚Äôd frozen in time. He hadn‚Äôt, though. While suspended at an angle someone else would have tipped over, he twisted around and put a foot out to one side. He moved in another direction, back to his board.

‚ÄúAny limitations? If I used my full strength and threw you, would you only slow down?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo. I‚Äôd stop. If I timed it right, I could fall from a plane, hit terminal velocity and then stop myself just before hitting the ground. It‚Äôs— it‚Äôd be useful then, it‚Äôs useful if I want to not fall over or if I want to maneuver a bit. But it‚Äôs not that amazing as powers go.‚Äù

He wasn‚Äôt lying, then. Not about that. There were uses, but it did sound somewhat limited for even a secondary power.

He seemed to read something in my expression, because he had further protests, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really not that amazing. I have to wait between each use of it, and it‚Äôs not something I can build a name or identity around. The emotion power has no impact or visual side to it, so it‚Äôs out too.‚Äù

‚ÄúA few of the multi-triggers I‚Äôm aware of tend to have more‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm not sure what the word is. Esoteric or abstract names. The one villain in my town was Circus. The solution to a disparate set of powers is to just create something more out there that has its own identity, and then fit your powers to match, instead of trying to fit your identity to a random set of powers.‚Äù

‚ÄúIdentity like what?‚Äù

‚ÄúLike‚Ä¶ if you‚Äôre standing back and using your blaster power, maybe something like a warlock aesthetic. You could have a robe, multiple arms, you‚Äôve got your ‚Äòmagic‚Äô, both with the blaster power and the emotion one.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he said, quieter than before. He stared at the board. ‚ÄúNot like that. That‚Äôs not me and I don‚Äôt want to go there.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said. I folded my arms, looking at the names he‚Äôd put down. ‚ÄúIf you like video games‚Ä¶ is there an aesthetic or character or kind of game you could tap into?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd be worried about choosing something I get tired of a month from now.‚Äù

‚ÄúJust‚Ä¶‚Äù I started, trying to think of a good argument. ‚ÄúJust as a starting point, to get you thinking.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe space opera game I got from Chris, one of the things he gave me to keep me sane when I‚Äôm out in the middle of nowhere and I don‚Äôt want to bother Erin. Chris, what‚Äôs the Void class I played, the worker one?‚Äù

‚ÄúThere are three. Miner, welder, and rigger. You played either of the last two.‚Äù

Rain nodded to himself, then looked at the board.

He started to write something down. He got as far as Rig when I said, ‚ÄúRigger and Rig are taken.‚Äù

Rain threw down the marker and he clenched both his tinker and regular hands into fists. ‚ÄúSon of a‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry to be the bearer of bad news,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWhat does it matter?‚Äù Tristan asked. He was still hanging with Chris at the one end of the room. ‚ÄúNames are taken, so what? It‚Äôs not like there‚Äôs a system out there enforcing that stuff. Kenzie could call herself Optics, it‚Äôs not like there‚Äôs a PRT.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to though,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúIt gets complicated.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay, but for the sake of argument,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúWhy couldn‚Äôt she if she wanted to?‚Äù

‚ÄúRigger or Rig could still be alive,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúAnd we don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs going to happen in the future with people picking up where the PRT left off. Finding a good name and identity you‚Äôre comfortable with is hard, and capes tend to be protective of their names as a result. Mix-ups and headaches used to be common and we don‚Äôt want to go there. People travel to your town to literally fight you over a name.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm still not sold on the PRT issue,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre gone. They aren‚Äôt coming back.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe remnants of them are. Organizations using their files and methods. A military-esque group following the rules and regulations of the PRT‚Äôs code of justice. There are headaches involved.‚Äù

There was a knock at the door. Sveta started toward it, but Kenzie leaped out of her chair and beat her to it, opening the door.

Kenzie saluted as Ashley entered. Ashley had a plastic bag with books and her dress in it. She moved those things out of the way, holding them while Kenzie fished the two camera drones out of the bottom of the bag.

‚ÄúGood work,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúLawyer-person left some tips, but I liked a lot about how you handled that.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was very natural,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll probably like the headaches you gave them, putting them on the spot like you did. Kenzie got some of their conversation after.‚Äù

Ashley smiled.

‚ÄúHow was the train ride?‚Äù Sveta asked. ‚ÄúYou might have to go back and forth a bit, I hope it isn‚Äôt too boring.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was fine. I read a book. A baby cried after looking at me and I was amused.‚Äù

‚ÄúA baby cried?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúI look intimidating, apparently.‚Äù

‚ÄúOr it cried because it‚Äôs a baby,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúBabies cry about everything. They‚Äôre stupid like that.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt cried because of me,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve made enough people cry to know when it‚Äôs because of me.‚Äù

Chris shrugged. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll defer to the expert.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt could be because you‚Äôre different,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúThe first house I was in growing up, there were mostly only black people in my neighborhood, and I remember my aunt had a baby and the baby cried whenever he saw a white person. It might be like that. Except you‚Äôve got the cool eyes and hair.‚Äù

‚ÄúOn that topic,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúEye. Mine‚Äôs bothering me.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, sure, I‚Äôll get it,‚Äù Kenzie said. She ran to her desk, then ran back to Ashley, who bent down, one hand on Kenzie‚Äôs shoulder.

Sticking a pair of tweezers into Ashley‚Äôs eye, Kenzie grabbed and withdrew the camera. It had a flat head like a nail, but the camera‚Äôs body more closely resembled a pin in how thin and long it was, with wires encircling its length in a double-helix.

I winced a little, watching it come out. Ashley didn‚Äôt seem to mind.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt stand that,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúMaybe it‚Äôs because eyes are one of the only things I have, but eeesh.‚Äù

She rattled a bit as she shuddered or mimed a shudder.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs phased out, you wimps,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not actually stabbing anything. It treats the eye as a portal and a model and unfolds in non-space using that framework.‚Äù

‚ÄúI felt it moving around,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs mostly not actually stabbing anything,‚Äù Kenzie corrected her statement. ‚ÄúOne to three percent in reality at most, stabbing at things. Sorry. I‚Äôll fine tune the phase. It might be responding to your power.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have regular appointments with someone who can give me a replacement if you destroy my eye,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not worried. I trust you.‚Äù

‚ÄúAwesome,‚Äù Kenzie said, wiping the camera-pin with a tissue.

I wasn‚Äôt sure it was ‚Äòawesome‚Äô. I knew who that person was. Bonesaw.

‚ÄúWe watched what we could before you left and the flying cameras ran out of battery,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThen we talked about plans and did some homework.‚Äù

‚ÄúThinking about names,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúRude jokes about names too,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúTristan had a good one.‚Äù

‚ÄúGlad I missed that,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúYou have a board, just so you know,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúYou can make notes.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúWhat plans were you talking about?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe wanted to wait until you were here to do anything,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúTattletale‚Äôs a persistent issue. She‚Äôs lurking in the background, and she‚Äôs hard to shake. Instead of having her looming, it might be nice to rattle her a bit. It might be possible to do it in a way that doesn‚Äôt tip her off about who you guys are or how you‚Äôre operating.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow?‚Äù Ashley asked.

I explained, ‚ÄúKenzie can call her old teammates. We‚Äôll offer an exchange. A favor for a favor. We know that the people in Cedar Point are easily spooked. This is new, untested ground, and thanks to you, we know that Prancer is the closest thing they have to a boss and he‚Äôs inexperienced. We can put them on the back foot.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll give you the transcript and a recording so you can check it out on your own time,‚Äù Kenzie told Ashley.

‚ÄúBack foot?‚Äù Ashley asked.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre easily spooked and Tattletale gave them free questions they can ask. They‚Äôve used some already, and they might have used them all,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúSo‚Ä¶ we leverage hero groups and some secondary people. They do a one-loop patrol or light investigation, show their faces.‚Äù

‚ÄúPressure,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúPart of why you patrol in the first place, but we‚Äôre using other people.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe can apply pressure on our own,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúWe have me, and we have Chris.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe law student said you should back off a bit,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúYou did a good job of being intimidating and believable. It would be better if we stirred the pot some, let them focus on other things, heat dies down. There‚Äôs less of a chance they‚Äôll investigate you if they‚Äôre focused on heroes.‚Äù

I jumped in, ‚ÄúSeeing how you were in Prancer‚Äôs face, I think it might be better to have you keep doing that, than to have you inexplicably be nicer or calmer. We just drop you back into Cedar Point when they‚Äôve already got their hands full, you get to make them miserable and blindside them. They might even turn to you for help.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd that gives us power,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúAnd we have a trump card,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúThe recording of the conversation with Tattletale. That‚Äôs endgame stuff, but if it turns out she‚Äôs digging and she‚Äôs on our trail anyway, we can use it to mess with her. We can give them the impression she wanted us to pressure them so they‚Äôd use questions and keep buying her services.‚Äù

Ashley smiled.

Hm. Maybe not the best thing if Ashley was that pleased with my idea.

I decided I had her on board and I had her playing nice. Time to sell her on the more cautious, moderated part of things. ‚ÄúWe play this slow, but we can maintain power, we can put them on the back foot, and we have a way of screwing up one of the major players on the bad guy‚Äôs side. That last one is the kind of thing we‚Äôll want to consult outside parties for. Tip off the Wardens or one of the big teams that we‚Äôre messing with Tattletale, in case they want that to coincide with something else they‚Äôve got going on.‚Äù

‚ÄúMore people involved is more chances a spy gives up the wrong info,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúVery true,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs where it‚Äôs good to make it so we‚Äôre only calling people we know and trust. Former teammates. I think we can reasonably assume the likes of Chevalier are fairly legit. Others, we control the information we give them. We do this smart.‚Äù

‚ÄúI like it,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúI can call my old teammates,‚Äù Kenzie said, collapsing back into her computer chair. She put the eyeball-pin camera into a jewelry box. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if they‚Äôll say yes, but I can try.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf everything else falls through, I can call Weld and ask if he knows people,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúThere are options,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI met some people at the community center. They might help me out.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know people too,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúFrom my appointments. I can try asking when I next run into them.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre sure? You actually have hero friends?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúNo. But they‚Äôre heroes other people trust to work with someone like me, we talk, and I can exchange favors with them.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs awesome,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll call mine, first?‚Äù Kenzie asked.

The others agreed. Chris was still in the corner with his phone and comic, and Tristan walked over to grab him, wheeling him to the center of the room so he‚Äôd participate. Chris did crack a smile at that.

‚ÄúStill feeling that hit of joy from the other day?‚Äù Rain asked.

‚ÄúIndulgence, not joy. I‚Äôm indulging myself or other people if I smile.‚Äù

‚ÄúShhhh!‚Äù Kenzie shushed people. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm on the phone.‚Äù

There was a pause.

‚ÄúHi, Houndstooth,‚Äù she said.

Pause.

‚ÄúI found it online.‚Äù

Pause. Sveta used the break in Kenzie speaking to shoot me a worried look.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs technically online. It didn‚Äôt take much to figure it out.‚Äù

Pause.

‚ÄúNo, I don‚Äôt want to bother you. I‚Äôm part of a different team now and we‚Äôre doing our thing. Yeah. We‚Äôre calling people we know and trust and exchanging favors for favors, and I thought I‚Äôd ask you, since you seemed like you might be interested based on how the last conversation went.‚Äù

Pause.

‚ÄúI thought it went okay,‚Äù Kenzie said, smiling and rolling her eyes.

Pause.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine. Really. I‚Äôm not—‚Äù

Pause.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù she said. She pulled the phone away from her ear. ‚ÄúHoundstooth wants to talk to the person in charge of the group.‚Äù

I saw Ashley and Tristan exchange looks.

‚ÄúI hate phones,‚Äù Ashley said.

Tristan reached for the phone.

‚ÄúHoundstooth. I‚Äôm Capricorn. Yeah. Team Reach. Group of six with a coach that‚Äôs a partial member, kind of.‚Äù

He glanced at me as he said it, and I shrugged.

‚ÄúEveryone‚Äôs here. We‚Äôve got a thing going on, we were thinking of cooperating with other groups. Can I put you on speaker?‚Äù

There was a pause.

Kenzie turned around, and hit a key on her keyboard.

An image appeared in the center of our group, and most of us backed away.

A still image of a person. He had a sleek, Anubis-like helmet or mask that encapsulated his head. His actual outfit was sleek as well, but Western. Nothing of an actual houndstooth pattern, ironically.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre on speaker, I think,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúHi guys,‚Äù Houndstooth said. He sounded more adult than ‚Äòkid‚Äô. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got to admit, I‚Äôm wary.‚Äù

‚ÄúUnderstandable. I get that this comes out of nowhere,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúListen, this is a take-it-or-leave-it thing, we‚Äôre fine if you decide it‚Äôs too much of a question mark and pass. Offer is a favor for a favor. There‚Äôs an area we‚Äôre interested in, and we‚Äôre hoping to get some other people showing up there, patrols. Maximizing pressure and seeing what we can shake up.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat area?‚Äù

‚ÄúCan‚Äôt say until you agree, but it‚Äôs not too dangerous.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can think of a few places it could be, especially if you‚Äôre a new team operating in open jurisdictions. New Brockton, or one of the Fallen camps, big or small.‚Äù

Kenzie wrote something down. She held up the paper.

he‚Äôs smart

‚ÄúLess dangerous than that, even,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúWe show up, we‚Ä¶ patrol, make our presences known. What‚Äôs the fallout?‚Äù

‚ÄúTwenty percent chance they pick a fight?‚Äù Tristan asked. He looked around at the group.

‚ÄúTen at most, and only if you stick around. I visited and they took half an hour before showing their faces,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúThey won‚Äôt go for the jugular, either. Worst case is they bruise your pride.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm feeling more like this is one of those places the B-listers are moving to, now.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo comment,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúAnd we can call in a favor in exchange? What sort? You patrol somewhere or help us pull off a complicated arrest?‚Äù

Kenzie pointed to herself.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got Optics, who‚Äôs not calling herself Optics anymore, for one thing,‚Äù Sveta spoke up.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre lucky,‚Äù Houndstooth said. Kenzie sat up straighter.

‚Äú‚Ä¶but I‚Äôm thinking in other directions.‚Äù Houndstooth finished. Kenzie slouched in her seat.

‚ÄúWhat kind of directions?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm thinking. Capricorn, can I hold onto this favor without naming it?‚Äù

Tristan looked around. There were a few nods. Tristan said, ‚ÄúSure. That was my original take on how this would go. The others seem cool with that. I‚Äôll give you my phone number.‚Äù

Tristan gave his number. There was a break while Houndstooth took it down.

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre game, I think we can let you know where we‚Äôre thinking of,‚Äù I said. The others nodded, so I added, ‚ÄúCedar Point. Hollow Point in villain vernacular.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou know,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúIt bothered me that it wasn‚Äôt being looked after.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat was my feeling too,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWho‚Äôs speaking, can I ask?‚Äù

‚ÄúVictoria Dallon. I used to be Glory Girl, and I‚Äôm the coach, so to speak.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know the name. Hi. You‚Äôre wanting to rattle these guys?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the basic idea,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúBasic idea? Even before you said that, I had the impression there was a less basic part to the idea. Am I right about there being more to this?‚Äù

‚ÄúSome. Nothing that impacts you negatively,‚Äù I said.

Tristan spoke up, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre hoping to tap some others, maintain pressure, and hold off on getting personally involved until we know how much reach these guys really have.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre bit players. This thing happens now and again. It tends to self-combust.‚Äù

Tristan looked at me.

Passing the ball to me? I said, ‚ÄúWe know how much reach they probably have, and there‚Äôs some.‚Äù

‚ÄúInteresting.‚Äù

I went on, ‚ÄúPersonally speaking, I don‚Äôt want this to combust. Some skirmishes are probably inevitable, but these guys aren‚Äôt, as was said earlier, going to go for the jugular. I want to keep it limited to that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to see any places combusting either. If you think it‚Äôs safe and if you want to help save Cedar Point, I think I can sell my team on a patrol or two.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôd be great,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúIf something happens and we get in over our heads, you back us up or call the bigger names?‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúProbably the latter. We‚Äôve got kids and stuff, and we‚Äôve been urged on multiple fronts to keep on the down-low.‚Äù

Ashley looked annoyed at that.

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúHm. I know another team that might be okay doing something similar, if you‚Äôre wanting to get others on board. I can put you in touch with them, but I‚Äôd want a minor favor. One I already have in mind.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf they‚Äôre trustworthy and won‚Äôt spill our role in things or why people are showing interest in Cedar Point. What‚Äôs the favor?‚Äù

‚ÄúThey are trustworthy. Before I commit my team, I want to meet you guys face to face. Grab a coffee or something. Glory Girl and Capricorn and whoever else is in a leadership position.‚Äù

Kenzie sunk further in her seat, so low her head couldn‚Äôt roll backward off the back of the chair. Instead, she slid to one side, her head closer to the armrest. She indicated herself, pointing, eyes rolling back so the whites showed.

‚ÄúI think that should be fine,‚Äù Tristan said. He looked at Kenzie, and she nodded, exaggerated. ‚ÄúYeah. That‚Äôs good.‚Äù

‚ÄúGreat. The team I‚Äôm thinking of is Auzure. Corporate.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know them,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure they‚Äôre my top choice.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt recommend them lightly,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre by-the-book, serious, they‚Äôre strong for a small team, they stick to their word, and they‚Äôre looking for opportunities to get out there.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat last bit is what concerns me,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre looking for exposure and this team wants more subtlety. We want the villains in Cedar Point wondering why heroes are there and tapping their resources.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you get to see what resources they have.‚Äù

‚ÄúBasically,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYou keep using that word and I keep realizing you‚Äôve really got a plan. Okay. I think I like this. Auzure is out, then? That‚Äôs your gut feeling?‚Äù

‚ÄúCan I put you on mute while I confer?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just the coach, I don‚Äôt want to make decisions.‚Äù

‚ÄúYep.‚Äù

Kenzie sat up and hit a key on her keyboard. A red ‚Äòx‚Äô appeared over the mouth and ears of the hologram image of Houndstooth.

Really weird that she had that, I noted.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs up?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúI interviewed for Auzure. They were just a bit sleazy. Greedy. Their reason for interviewing me was to get at my family, just as one example of a red flag that came up. My feeling is if you guys bring them in, they‚Äôll try to do something flashy or get more involved than you want them.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf that‚Äôs the case, I‚Äôd rather avoid them,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúThey sound like the bad kind of corporate team,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúBut I might be biased. Okay. Any thoughts? Objections?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe could use them in a limited capacity,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúHave them make a phone call, instead of actually showing up.‚Äù

‚ÄúPhone call?‚Äù Rain asked.

‚ÄúYeah. Can I just see what Houndstooth says to this?‚Äù

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúUnmute.‚Äù

‚ÄúHoundstooth,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm here.‚Äù

‚ÄúIn the interest of keeping Auzure involved in only a limited capacity, what if we had them call someone and ask about renting space? No commitment, just see if the person reports it to the villains in town. The villains would probably stress over the notion.‚Äù

‚ÄúStress you want. Yeah. Could work.‚Äù

‚ÄúIdeally, we‚Äôd ask Auzure to call when Auzure is busy.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt want them in your jurisdiction?‚Äù

‚Äú‚Ä¶Yeah.‚Äù I said. I almost said ‚Äòbasically‚Äô.

‚ÄúI hear you. Yeah. I think they‚Äôve got something going on right now. Rumors of war on the horizon. Earth C. If you used them in the next week, I don‚Äôt think they‚Äôd pick up on hints.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôd need to figure out who we want Auzure to call, so that the person called might tip off the villains. It might be tight to get that information in a week, but yeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got Kenzie. I think you‚Äôll do just fine on that front.‚Äù

I looked at Kenzie, expecting her to perk up. She smiled, but she didn‚Äôt really show much more enthusiasm at the praise.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll have that face to face meeting,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúWe can hammer out particulars then.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes. I‚Äôll call you after I‚Äôve raised the idea with my team, and we‚Äôll figure out a time to meet. I‚Äôll keep quiet on it being Cedar Point until they‚Äôre on board.‚Äù

‚ÄúGreat,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll let you go now.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright. Another day, Capricorn.‚Äù

The phone call ended.

‚ÄúI like him,‚Äù I said. I looked at Kenzie. ‚ÄúGood recommendation.‚Äù

‚ÄúYup,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs going to want to dish out all the super embarrassing dirt on me from two years ago. Uggh.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe know the dirt,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúMost of us.‚Äù

‚ÄúUugh,‚Äù Kenzie groaned. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like having friends over and your parents bringing out the photo album. Except way, way worse, because I wasn‚Äôt a baby when I messed up with Houndstooth around, and it‚Äôs so much worse than being in the tub or having food on my face.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe know your history, we know you‚Äôve made great strides,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt speak for the others, but to me, you‚Äôre about those strides and those successes. You‚Äôre not defined by your worst days.‚Äù

‚ÄúUuuuuuggh,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúRight?‚Äù Sveta pressed.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúIt didn‚Äôt sound like that call was easy to make. If Houndstooth is on the up-and-up, then it was a really, really good recommendation,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúHe is. He‚Äôs one of the best true-blue heroes I know,‚Äù Kenzie said, smiling a little.

‚ÄúTwo teams we can use to apply some pressure and get Cedar Point to reach out to Tattletale,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúEven if they catch on, they‚Äôll be left wondering. Heroes on your turf aren‚Äôt something you can ignore. Ignoring that makes you look weak,‚Äù Ashley said.

I nodded.

And one way or another, we would strain the relationship with this group and Tattletale, and make them less likely or able to call on her when we made our play.

This worked.

Kenzie stood from her seat, walking over to her board. She began copying down a redacted version of the scribbled-down tinker notes from before.

She was bothered, that much was clear. Now she was stepping away to dwell on the tinker stuff. That didn‚Äôt seem like the worst thing in the world.

On one wall, the one operating camera drone was showing a view of Cedar Point. Sunny, largely abandoned, and a little rough around the edges, covered in graffiti with broken things here and there from a riot or protest that hadn‚Äôt been cleaned up after.

The group was talking amongst themselves, about what needed to be done and arranged.

‚ÄúRain‚Äôs thing needs some attention,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúWe can talk some about that tonight, and talk more tomorrow. Offer for an escort stands, Rain.‚Äù

‚ÄúNah,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to play that card yet.‚Äù

‚ÄúKenzie said she could do some of the surveillance from home, but we‚Äôll probably want to meet here if we meet,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúKenzie will be a regular. I can come once in a blue moon.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll be here when I‚Äôm not there,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúIf I‚Äôm holding off, then I‚Äôll be here for the next bit.‚Äù

‚ÄúCool,‚Äù Kenzie said, turning. She‚Äôd added something to the board. ‚ÄòName? Look-see / Looksee‚Äô.‚Äô

‚ÄúI‚Äôll be here too,‚Äù Chris said. He‚Äôd stood from his chair and was walking around Kenzie‚Äôs desk, peering at the tinker stuff. ‚ÄúOr around here. Sometimes I just sit around outside or find a place to read comics or watch stuff on my phone.‚Äù

I saw Kenzie nod to herself, glancing back over one shoulder at Chris.

‚ÄòCool‚Äô, she‚Äôd said. I wasn‚Äôt sure it was. I hadn‚Äôt quite anticipated this, but with people being where they were, with the older members helping Rain, Ashley being available for surveillance, it meant Kenzie and Chris and Ashley would be spending more extended periods of time together.

Or, put another way, the ex-Slaughterhouse Nine member and the two ‚Äòkids‚Äô of the team.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll stop in regularly,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúKeep an eye on things.‚Äù

‚ÄúYep,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúRotate or something? With overlap, because you and I need to hang out.‚Äù

‚ÄúNaturally,‚Äù I said, smiling. She‚Äôd picked up on the same concerns I had.

‚ÄúA few of us here at any given time,‚Äù Tristan said.

There was a bit more conversation, hashing out particulars of schedule, as well as who was available on what days.

‚ÄúI could stop in at Cedar Point. They know I was poking my head in before, but there‚Äôs no reason to let them think I‚Äôm gone and dealt with,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got the hero itch,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not the hero itch,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs that Tattletale told me to go away and it means something if I don‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the—‚Äù

‚ÄúChris!‚Äù Kenzie raised her voice.

Chris froze. He was leaning close to her projector box. Stuff was piled on top.

‚ÄúDo not touch my bag!‚Äù she said, way louder and more intense than was necessary.

‚ÄúNot touching a thing,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúRelax.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to relax! Back off!‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat, is it going to blow up or something?‚Äù he asked, with a chuckle.

Kenzie strode forward, through the group, ‚ÄúStep back and leave my stuff alone!‚Äù

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt touch anything. Really.‚Äù

‚ÄúKenzie,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt touch anything.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd stop saying my stuff is going to blow up!‚Äù Kenzie said, volume still raised. She shot Chris a look and smiled. ‚ÄúPretty please? It‚Äôs really not funny.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat was my fault,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI brought it up first. I‚Äôve dealt with tinkers and hyperdimensional tech makes me nervous.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre fine,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been cool. I like you. I have more mixed feelings about Chris. And I have very strong feelings about things like my bag being messed with.‚Äù

Chris threw his hands up, retreated to the chair that Tristan had initially brought to the edge of where everyone was standing, and kicked at the ground, wheeling himself back to his corner.

I met Sveta‚Äôs eyes. We communicated more or less telepathically: more supervision would be needed.

Kenzie was now rummaging, gathering her stuff and getting it organized. She had what looked like a gym bag, white with pink piping as trim, and big plastic zipper tabs. She put stuff in it and then picked it up.

‚ÄúWant to have a chat, Kenz?‚Äù I asked.

She drew in a deep breath and sighed heavily, bag held close. ‚ÄúFine.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not obligatory,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine. Yes. Chat. You‚Äôre cool. Some people aren‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúReferring to yourself?‚Äù Chris asked.

‚ÄúNot helping, Chris,‚Äù Tristan called out.

I led Kenzie out the side door, to the fire escape that was the access to the mostly unfurnished apartment. The air outside was far warmer than the air inside. It was late in the afternoon.
