‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Kenzie said. She put her bag down on one corner of the fire escape, then leaned against the railing, looking down as she wound her foot around the strap.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm really glad you‚Äôre here,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAnd I kind of like that you don‚Äôt know all the bad stuff.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre worried about what Houndstooth is going to say?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like being embarrassed,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAnd it‚Äôs really, really embarrassing.‚Äù

I didn‚Äôt like standing over her, so I walked over to where the stairs met the little platform of rusty slats and sat down sideways with my back to the exterior wall of the building. Not facing her directly, but I could comfortably look her way.

‚ÄúI hear you,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI said it before, but I‚Äôm grateful you were willing to get closer to that territory to help everyone out. I have things I don‚Äôt like thinking about or getting into and I know what it takes to go there.‚Äù

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt even really think about it so it‚Äôs not all that,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúAre you okay?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúIs there anything I can do?‚Äù

‚ÄúTalking is good,‚Äù Kenzie said, eyes on where the strap was wound around her ankle and foot. ‚ÄúYou ever— have you ever been so humiliated that you wished the earth would open up and swallow you up?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think everyone has. It‚Äôs part of being young, that you fumble your way through things.‚Äù

‚ÄúUrgh,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Ä¶ I once embarrassed myself really, really badly.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd it wasn‚Äôt just one earth that split open but a multiverse of them. I was so humiliated an alien actually noticed and reached between those earths and into my head. And now I— everything‚Äôs messy and hard.‚Äù

‚ÄúSveta and the others seem to think you‚Äôre doing better.‚Äù

‚ÄúI am. I‚Äôm mostly good. I backslide now and again, but I get a handle on things and I have people who help when I do.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs good,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs an achievement, especially when you‚Äôve got an alien tied to you. You‚Äôre swimming with an anchor around your waist, and you‚Äôve reached the shallow water. That‚Äôs incredible.‚Äù

Kenzie nodded. She didn‚Äôt smile.

‚ÄúHe saw me not long after everything went wrong. And then he saw me a while later when I joined his team and I wasn‚Äôt exactly great then either. Even if he saw me at my best now I don‚Äôt know if he‚Äôd be able to look past all the bad he‚Äôs seen before.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou might not be giving him enough credit,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúBut I might be giving him just enough credit, and I might be really worried that this cool heroine who‚Äôs helping us out might see or hear about the bad and then she not be able to see past it, either.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe others have heard some of it, haven‚Äôt they?‚Äù

‚ÄúFrom my mouth. That‚Äôs different.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôve heard it and they want you on their team. They respect you. Whatever happens, I don‚Äôt think Houndstooth can say anything that‚Äôs going to have more weight than what Sveta says, because Sveta‚Äôs awesome and I respect her a ton.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs great,‚Äù Kenzie said, staring down at her feet. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs the best.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd,‚Äù I said, pausing. ‚ÄúWhatever he says, I don‚Äôt think it should have more weight than what you say, either. Not when people like Sveta trust and respect you and I trust and respect her. Okay?‚Äù

Kenzie sniffed. A slightly runny nose, now. She wasn‚Äôt crying that I could see, but she might‚Äôve been close.

‚ÄúCan I give you a hug?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù She said. She stooped down and picked up her bag. She craned her head around, and looked through the window.

The window was opaque, the surface blurred. Kenzie‚Äôs tech, I realized.

‚ÄúCome,‚Äù Kenzie said. Bag in her arms, she hauled the door open, and held it for me as I followed.

The others were watching. Sveta was on her way to the door, no doubt to let us know what was going on.

Two people were in the center of the camera‚Äôs focus, walking down the streets of Cedar Point.

I recognized one as Snag, and I could guess the other was the woman of Rain‚Äôs cluster.

Rain turned his head, looking at me.

I had an idea of what he was going to ask. He couldn‚Äôt leave this opportunity to get information alone. He couldn‚Äôt afford to.

Shade — 4.3

It was Sveta who said it, not Rain. ‚ÄúIf they go inside, we‚Äôre going to lose track of what they‚Äôre saying.‚Äù

‚ÄúHave they said anything yet?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúThe woman doesn‚Äôt talk so it would be a one-sided conversation. If they‚Äôre here, they‚Äôre here for something. I want to know what.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnything you guys do risks blowing your surveillance,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúYou might gain more information if you leave it alone. Just saying.‚Äù

‚ÄúI might miss something vital,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúYou might,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really up to you guys. If you need help, I‚Äôll back you up.‚Äù

Tristan walked forward, and half-sat on the desk, head turned so he could keep one eye on the image. ‚ÄúHypothetically, if we did act on this, what would we be doing? Picking a fight?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe could,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúRain said they were injured and needed maintenance. It would be timely, it would keep them injured and out of the picture.‚Äù

‚ÄúOn their turf?‚Äù Tristan asked. ‚ÄúWith who knows how many villains in the immediate area?‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd it would blow our surveillance, like Victoria said,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been quiet on why they‚Äôre after you, Rain,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúYou never talked about your trigger event.‚Äù

‚ÄúAs a rule, it‚Äôs not good to ask people about their trigger events,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúAs a rule,‚Äù Chris said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs vital information about who we‚Äôre fighting and why they‚Äôre doing what they‚Äôre doing.‚Äù

‚ÄúChris,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúSveta,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúDetach from your emotions, focus more on their emotions. Are they passionate? Driven? Is it personal? If any or all of the above are true, it changes the rules of how they act. They might act even if they are injured or needing to do some maintenance.‚Äù

‚ÄúPeople don‚Äôt act by rules,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúSome people do,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúByron does, or did, based on what you said. They might. But we need more of what Rain knows about who and what they are and where they come from to know that.‚Äù

Kenzie turned around in her seat. ‚ÄúI was just telling Victoria I didn‚Äôt like the idea of her prying into my past or where I come from. It would feel pretty gross and unfair if we pushed Rain to do it now, when he obviously doesn‚Äôt want to.‚Äù

‚ÄúHypocritical might be the word you‚Äôre looking for,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm learning so many words today,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúPutting all that aside, is there any way to listen in, if they went inside?‚Äù Rain asked. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre a block away from where Prancer went before. If they go there, what can we do?‚Äù

‚ÄúI could rig something,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúBut it would be fragile and iffy.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt help but notice we‚Äôre changing the subject,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúLook. Just— I need this,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve told Tristan everything and I‚Äôve told Sveta some of it. If Tristan thinks it needs to be said, he can say it. He‚Äôs more objective. But I really want to know what they might say, I want to start making preparations now.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been keeping my mouth shut,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm in a weird place, knowing what I do, not wanting to betray a friend. I feel like if I said anything at all, even if the reasons were good, it would still be betraying Rain.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can take apart things,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúKludge it together for an emergency thing. It won‚Äôt take long but we‚Äôd need Sveta to hurry over there to plant it and that‚Äôll take a few minutes. If that‚Äôs what we‚Äôre doing. I don‚Äôt want to break my things down if we‚Äôre not doing this, though.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm probably going to regret saying this, but I‚Äôll stand up for Kenzie,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to be shitty if she starts taking apart good work so she can get it done in time, and then Rain doesn‚Äôt hold up his end any. That‚Äôs not fair and it‚Äôs going to lead to resentment.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt care about fair,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúBut thank you, Chris.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt thank me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to anyway. It means a lot.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo it doesn‚Äôt. I just don‚Äôt want the headaches,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúAnd Rain is being the biggest headache on the team. Maybe except for me, but I don‚Äôt have anyone trying to kill me and I‚Äôm not really asking for anything, so I think I can get away with it.‚Äù

Rain ran his fingers through his hair, turned and took a step to one side, like he was going to walk away or pace, and then stopped, because he couldn‚Äôt take his attention off the screen.

Tristan was in a hard place, knowing what he did but having a friendship on the line, Sveta maybe wasn‚Äôt as much of a friend to Rain but she was also more sensitive and kind, and she didn‚Äôt know as much. Rain didn‚Äôt really have other allies in the group he could turn to. Certainly not Ashley. Not Chris. Kenzie just wanted to know if she should get started building her thing.

Somehow, he ended up looking at me. He looked spooked.

‚ÄúIf Kenzie builds the thing, I can fly over and plant it,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt mind showing my face there, it fits with the plan, there‚Äôs a lower risk of the surveillance operation getting discovered, it works.‚Äù

Rain nodded, tense.

‚ÄúBut I do think Chris may be right. If the group is extending a hand to you and you‚Äôre not extending trust back, that may not be fair. You should share something.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Rain said.

Kenzie spun around. She grabbed one of her flying eyes and pried open the side, pulling out a black rectangle. She swapped it with a spare.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs personal,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs emotional. Not helped by the dreams, by the possible personality bleed across the cluster. Some things I‚Äôve caught lately made me think there might be some.‚Äù

I listened, my expression still, arms folded, mostly watching what Kenzie did while Rain talked. I was going to have to deploy this thing.

Kenzie popped open the jewelry case with the camera she‚Äôd put in Ashley‚Äôs eye, then tore off the section under the lens. She flicked at parts with her fingers to get them spinning and then held onto others, unscrewing them in the process.

‚ÄúThey blame me, for the events around the trigger. I‚Äôve told Sveta all of this. The dreams are biased, selective, cherry picking from my perceptions. They make me out to be more of a bad guy than I am.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think you‚Äôre a bad guy at all,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a good guy either. And maybe that‚Äôs because of the bleed coming the other way. I feel like a completely different person than I was then. And I know — I think Snag is too. I‚Äôve seen his perspective and his dreams, and he‚Äôs willing to murder now? Maybe the agent took half of my anger from back then and divided it among them, aiming it back at me.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat happened?‚Äù Ashley asked.

‚ÄúI fucked up. I had a chance to save them and I didn‚Äôt,‚Äù Rain said.

I looked away from where Kenzie was spinning things to screw in the eye-camera beneath the major lens of the flying eye, looked at Rain, and saw how miserable he was.

‚ÄúHow does Erin fit in?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúShe doesn‚Äôt. She knows the story but she hasn‚Äôt seen the dreams. I think if she saw the dreams like the three members of the cluster did, she‚Äôd hate me too. But she doesn‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd ‚Äòof 5?'‚Äù Chris asked.

I turned my head.

‚ÄúMy username, online,‚Äù Rain explained. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what happened to the fifth. It‚Äôs complicated. I can think of a few people it might be. People that didn‚Äôt make it.‚Äù

Kenzie turned around. The camera looked worse for wear. I realized it was the nice one, with the adaptive camouflage or whatever it was. Panels were missing and wires exposed. She beckoned me to approach. I did.

‚ÄúPut the lens side against the wall or the roof. There‚Äôs a plunger on the side here, you see?‚Äù

In a groove along the side, normally meant to aid in aerodynamics or something, the metal rod ran flush with the body.

‚ÄúI see,‚Äù I said. I looked at the screen. They‚Äôd walked past the place where Prancer had gone inside.

‚ÄúPut it up against the surface, then slowly, super slowly push that in. There‚Äôs no resistance built in, so you could push it in in half a second if you weren‚Äôt careful.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat would happen?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôd lose it. That‚Äôs four days worth of work and the eye camera is six days worth of work, and some of those parts were hard to get. Please don‚Äôt push it in fast.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow slow do I depress it?‚Äù

‚ÄúUm. Take, like, a minute, to get it from here to here, if you can. Be ready to stop if I tell you to.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow are we communicating?‚Äù

‚ÄúPhone?‚Äù Kenzie asked.

‚ÄúPhone,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúGot it.‚Äù

I checked I had my phone with me, that it had battery, and then got my earbuds, plugging them into the phone and then putting one into my ear. I collected the football-sized camera.

‚ÄúGive me something to eat?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúGranola bar or something?‚Äù

Chris walked over to his bag, fished for something, and then tossed me a bag of chips. I caught it, then caught the paper-wrapped meal he threw my way. I put everything into a bag. My mask, computer and notebook were in the bag already, which was good.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not kiss-kill,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúOr, like Victoria said a few days ago, it‚Äôs kiss-kill with good cover. I‚Äôm weaker than them, and the dreams give them a reason to hate me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm good to go?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI think so. Thanks for doing this,‚Äù Sveta said.

I gave her a pat on the shoulder as I passed.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù Rain said, with sincerity.

I was at the door when Tristan said, ‚ÄúMight not need the camera after all.‚Äù

I looked back.

They hadn‚Äôt gone indoors. They were in a parking lot. A group of people was standing around a van. They had masks on.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm still going to go,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt know where they‚Äôll go or what they‚Äôll do. Patch me in somehow?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll video call you,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll talk to you and you can look at your phone to see what‚Äôs happening.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThat works. That‚Äôs going to do a number on my monthly limit. I might have to get an unlimited plan.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt have any of those anymore, not after the end of the world,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúI checked. And they get peeved at me when I borrow anything, so I have to be really careful with my cameras and junk.‚Äù

I could have responded, but I didn‚Äôt want to get stuck in a conversation. I let myself outside, then flew from the top of the fire escape.

Might have to have a conversation with the big hero teams to see if they have any options, I thought. It would be nice to have the fancy earbuds that the Wards used to have, or just a special phone plan that let us handle higher-bandwidth operations.

My phone rang in my ear, startling me even though I‚Äôd expected it. I thumbed at my phone to answer it. Rather than any of the others, it was the audio from Kenzie‚Äôs camera, observing the interaction between Snag and the group in the parking lot.

‚Äú‚Ä¶Snag. This is Love Lost,‚Äù Snag said. Recognizable enough. His voice was a deep growl. That was his ordinary voice, it seemed.

‚ÄúLove Lost? Shouldn‚Äôt it be No Love Lost?‚Äù

There was a brief pause.

‚ÄúShe doesn‚Äôt talk,‚Äù Snag said.

‚ÄúThat might make negotiations hard.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be fine,‚Äù Snag said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll cover things.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour friend isn‚Äôt coming? Cradle?‚Äù

Cradle was the potential third, then.

‚ÄúHe isn‚Äôt. Just me, just her.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm Secondhand, this is Last Minute, Final Hour, and End of Days.‚Äù

Still flying, I pulled my phone from my pocket, being careful not to drop it. I hated using my phone while airborne. It was so easy to let my guard down.

‚ÄúYour name doesn‚Äôt match,‚Äù Snag said.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt mind,‚Äù Secondhand said.

I could see the image on my phone. I made the reel gesture to zoom in on the one I wasn‚Äôt familiar with. Tall, with an elongated face and head, bald, with an elaborate waxed mustache, and round sunglasses. He wore suspenders over a shirt that was rolled up to the elbows. The arms crossed over his chest were muscled. A bit of a steampunk vibe, even though his clothes weren‚Äôt that old fashioned.

The time manipulators had another teammate, then.

‚ÄúYou wanted to meet. Here we are,‚Äù Secondhand said.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre similar in how we approach things,‚Äù Snag said. ‚ÄúMaybe we can trade, teach each other something.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù Secondhand said. ‚ÄúSounds good.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe the deal‚Äôs lopsided in your favor, but you give us a hand when we need it.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh, I thought that was coming. We heard you were recruiting.‚Äù

‚ÄúMm hmm,‚Äù Snag made the sound, and it came off more like growl than agreement.

‚ÄúThe more the merrier?‚Äù another member of the Speedrunner‚Äôs group asked. It might have been End of Days.

‚ÄúThe more the merrier,‚Äù Snag repeated, sounding the furthest thing from merry.

‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you take a look and tell us what this means to you?‚Äù Secondhand asked.

There was a pause. I looked at my phone. The back door of the van opened. Snag approached, with the woman —Love Lost?— hanging a bit back. She had curved claws at her fingertips and thumb, with a thin framework of rods and bands at the back of her hands to keep those claws in place. She had more glittering around her feet and ankle. A mask covered her lower face.

‚ÄúVictoria?‚Äù Sveta asked, through the phone.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs up?‚Äù I asked, holding the phone to my ear, so I could use the mouthpiece there.

‚ÄúKenzie‚Äôs handling the camera and things. I‚Äôm hanging back, Tristan‚Äôs close. We‚Äôll be your people, mostly. Can you tell us anything about the Speedrunners?‚Äù

I was glad I‚Äôd checked my books and notes.

‚ÄúSeattle. B-list villains, but that‚Äôs partially because Seattle was setting a really high bar around the time they were active,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúPartially. They‚Äôre time manipulators, but complicated by the fact that they have at least one tinker in the group. It could be that they‚Äôre all tinkers. A family thing like how forcefields run in my family.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt look like family,‚Äù I heard a voice. It might have been Chris, or Rain speaking with a funny tone. Probably Chris.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what they‚Äôre talking about sharing, then,‚Äù I heard Tristan. ‚ÄúTinker know-how.‚Äù

‚ÄúProbably. Um. Each of them has a power, but they augment that by having tinker stuff they wear. Secondhand can cover a lot of ground really fast, but can‚Äôt affect anyone or do much while he‚Äôs doing it. Can‚Äôt hurt you, can‚Äôt move stuff, can‚Äôt set traps. But we already talked briefly about him earlier. He‚Äôs the one doing regular sweeps of the area, looking for trouble. The tinker stuff he wears reduces the strain on his body and lets him operate like that for longer. And it means that when he pops out of that mode, he does it with a boom. It gives him some offensive ability.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat doesn‚Äôt feel B-list,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll get to that momentarily. I‚Äôm doing these guys out of order. Final Hour, he has a targeted slow. One target at a time, if he‚Äôs aware of them, he can slow them, as an ongoing thing. He can swap it with a moment‚Äôs notice. Tinker gear applies other effects to slowed targets. Makes it so being slow also crushes you and makes it hard to breathe, or chills you. Makes it so he can target a friend and make it so they fall slow, and reduce the impact of their landings. He had a thing which screwed with—‚Äù

‚ÄúThis works,‚Äù Snag‚Äôs growl interrupted me. ‚ÄúI could do something with this, if I had time to study it. I could use the engines you‚Äôve got here to make emotion effects I channel through my tech last longer, or prolong battery life.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù Secondhand said.

A pause. A metal on metal sound.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs she saying?‚Äù Secondhand asked.

‚ÄúLove Lost likes that. She thinks she could do something with it. Right? Yeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright. Doesn‚Äôt tell me much,‚Äù Secondhand said. ‚ÄúHow about you show us something?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs damaged, but you should get the picture,‚Äù Snag said.

I checked the phone. He was using one of his overlong, mechanical arms to pull off his other arm, holding it out by gripping it at the midpoint, the shoulder near End of Days and the hand near Secondhand.

It was my first clean look at the whole group of Speedrunners, as Kenzie zoomed in the camera.

Secondhand was fairly normal in build, with goggles and a flat-top cap. He managed to not look old-fashioned.

Last Minute was shorter, stout, with a lot of muscle and fat both. His gadgets hung from a high-tech belt.

Final Hour was more muscular, with tech wrapped around one of his arms, ending in a blunt design that resembled a brass hairdryer, with red smoke pouring from the fans and vents along its length. Aside from the brass helmet he wore, which covered his entire head the armor covered only half of his body.

End of Days, well, I‚Äôd already gotten a look at him. He wore a mask that wrapped around his head in a broad band, from eyebrow to cheekbone, with the black sunglasses on top of that, but it was hard to imagine how he‚Äôd be less recognizable when his facial shape, lack of hair, and mustache were all so apparent.

‚ÄúKeep going,‚Äù Tristan said.

Where had I been? Final Hour, right. ‚ÄúHe could attach an EMP thing to his slow that slightly hampered powers, made machinery grind to a halt. All through this oversized thing he wore that covered his arm and hand.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs wearing it now,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúOkay, right, can‚Äôt see while I‚Äôve got the phone to my ear. Foresight said they were using Final Hour to mask their business dealings. He was their heavy hitter and he might still be. I was thinking he might be using the EMP thing or something like it to keep people from looking in.‚Äù

‚ÄúI hope they don‚Äôt use it,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúProbably wouldn‚Äôt work outdoors,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúLast Minute moves things backward in time. Emphasis on things. Not people. Carries an assortment of tinker boomerangs, bombs, weapons. If Secondhand didn‚Äôt have the tinker-ish name, and if there wasn‚Äôt a chance they were all lesser tinkers, I‚Äôd say Last Minute was a contender for the team‚Äôs tinker, with his arsenal.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the catch, or what‚Äôs the tinker component?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúFrom what little I remember, his gadgets don‚Äôt act the same when moving in reverse, or it has added functionality while being reversed.‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck me,‚Äù someone said. I thought I heard someone else groan, too.

‚ÄúYeah. Boomerangs fly a different path, or split apart so one version carries forward and one retraces its path,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThat sort of thing.‚Äù

I‚Äôd slowed while flying, and now I stopped. I didn‚Äôt want to enter the territory and draw attention when it wasn‚Äôt quite time. I had a sense of what Birdbrain and Braindead did, and there was a risk Secondhand would do a patrol when the meeting concluded, to see what their potential business partners were doing.

I settled on a roof, walking as I landed, then stopping to stand on the corner of the roof. Cedar Point was on the other side of the water, on a peninsula across from me.

‚ÄúEnd of Days?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have a clue,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúNothing about name or appearance stands out to me.‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù I heard a voice. Rain, I was guessing.

‚ÄúWhy are they B-list?‚Äù Tristan asked. Not the first time he‚Äôd touched on that.

‚ÄúBecause the tinker stuff is limited. The batteries take time to charge,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúWhen they were active in Seattle, they had something like twenty days between the jobs they pulled, and they had weaknesses. The batteries ran out if engagements were prolonged and once that happens they lose a lot of their muscle.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey might have recruited End of Days to cover that weakness,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not out of the question.‚Äù

The Speedrunners took longer to examine Snag‚Äôs arm than Snag had taken to examine whatever they‚Äôd shown him. I watched through my phone, grieved a bit for my monthly limits, and waited.

On the screen, Love Lost stepped away from the meeting, walking down the length of the parking lot. She stood with her back to the group, hands at her sides, fingers and claws spread.

‚ÄúI like her,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúGood style. It‚Äôs going to be a shame to smash her face in.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf we engage her,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúIf we even go that far.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs she doing?‚Äù I asked, more to myself than to the group.

It took a few more seconds, but someone walked down the street. A woman with a purple hood and antlers.

Prancer‚Äôs partner.

‚ÄúLove Lost saw her coming,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúSensed,‚Äù I corrected.

‚ÄúThe woman— Love Lost, she has the emotion aspect of the power,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúMaybe it includes some emotion sense. Detecting people.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf so, I‚Äôm glad I didn‚Äôt just drop in nearby,‚Äù I said.

Velvet said something. The camera didn‚Äôt catch it.

‚ÄúSorry!‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúSorry! I didn‚Äôt have the sound camera turned that way. It‚Äôs finnicky.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt turn it toward those two, stay focused on Snag‚Äôs group,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúVelvet‚Äôs already walking away.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was brief,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI think she‚Äôs just checking on things, making sure it‚Äôs all peaceful.‚Äù

Love Lost rejoined the group.

‚ÄúWhat did the queen of Hollow Point want?‚Äù Secondhand asked.

Love Lost was silent.

‚ÄúRight.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you done with my arm?‚Äù Snag asked.

‚ÄúOh, yes. Go ahead.‚Äù

‚ÄúMm.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have a question, and it‚Äôs one I‚Äôd regret not asking,‚Äù Secondhand said. ‚ÄúWho are you with?‚Äù

‚ÄúWith?‚Äù Snag asked. ‚ÄúOurselves.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll elaborate. We‚Äôve got a few cliques forming already. Bitter Pill in charge of the brains, watching, listening, planning the longer-term plays. Not necessarily here, mind you. Could be jobs elsewhere.‚Äù

‚ÄúMm hmm.‚Äù

‚ÄúBeast of Burden in charge of the hostiles, the ex-cons, ex-birdcage, ex-covert military, ex-cage fighters. The ones who are good or even eager when it comes to hurting people.‚Äù

Snag commented, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve had conversations with a few of them already. Beast of Burden included. We‚Äôre looking for people who are good or even eager to deliver the hurt.‚Äù

‚ÄúGreat. We‚Äôll keep that in mind. Final clique worth talking about, you‚Äôve got Prancer in charge of the organization side of things. The diplomacy, recruitment, and a lot of the lower-key, ongoing business.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd?‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre going to divide up into factions and end up fighting each other. I say clique because like attracts like and sooner or later, you‚Äôll get pulled into one of the major groups. Each serving a role.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre our own group,‚Äù Snag said. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt care what clique you belong to. You want access to our stuff to study and see what you can learn?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôd have to talk about it among ourselves, but I think we‚Äôre leaning that way.‚Äù

I looked at the phone, as the Speedrunners exchanged looks.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Secondhand said, after assessing the others. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs assume we‚Äôre good to go forward with this, but we won‚Äôt set anything in stone until my friends and I have had a conversation.

‚ÄúPreliminary offer: we pay you fifteen thousand dollars, and we give you access to our tech for study,‚Äù Snag said. ‚ÄúYou give us access to your tech, and you lend us a hand when the time comes.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor this job you‚Äôre planning?‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you want to discuss it, I can invite others who‚Äôve pledged to help. We‚Äôll discuss in one of Prancer‚Äôs venues.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe. We‚Äôd have to talk it over. What timeline?‚Äù

‚ÄúSoon,‚Äù Snag said. ‚ÄúAnything more should wait for the discussion.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow difficult?‚Äù

‚ÄúHard to say. I don‚Äôt want to tell you something and have it reach the wrong ears, and there are a lot of wrong ears.‚Äù

‚ÄúGive us some idea.‚Äù

‚ÄúEight or nine young people with powers, is our best guess. Mostly teenagers. We don‚Äôt know who else, or what the exact number of adult capes, allies, or other resources they might have. Teenagers are easiest to track, because they move more.‚Äù

Someone spoke, and I had to view my phone to check who it was. Last Minute. ‚ÄúHard to say? That sounds easy to say. A minimum of eight or nine people with powers is difficult.‚Äù

‚ÄúWith the recruitment we‚Äôre planning, we‚Äôll outnumber them three to one,‚Äù Snag said, in his characteristic growl.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre talking people with powers? Not mooks, not henchmen?‚Äù

‚ÄúPeople with powers. All going well, we‚Äôll have them outnumbered three to one even if they call in help.‚Äù

‚ÄúPulled from Cedar Point?‚Äù

‚ÄúPulled from many places. We have a thinker contact and that contact is calling in friends. This contact and their friends are capes with names you‚Äôve heard of, that everyone has heard of. We have Lord of Loss committed to the job. We have one or two others of similar caliber who may or may not participate, but who will contribute meaningful resources if they don‚Äôt show up personally.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt do things by half measures,‚Äù Secondhand said.

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt believe in half measures,‚Äù Snag said. ‚ÄúIn the bigger job, or in our deal with you. Tech for tech, fifteen thousand for the job, but I‚Äôd like the two things bundled together. We establish a working relationship and even a mutual dependency before the job starts.‚Äù

‚ÄúMutual dependency?‚Äù

‚ÄúA reason for people to second guess themselves before wondering if they can drop away at the last minute and they won‚Äôt be missed because the crowd is big enough. It was known to happen at events like Endbringer fights, before Gold Morning.‚Äù

‚ÄúSpeaking for myself, not having consulted the group‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt mind that approach. We‚Äôd have to discuss the money. Spread across a four person team, it doesn‚Äôt amount to that much.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen I did the community center job‚Ä¶‚Äù Snag started. He paused, letting the statement hang.

‚ÄúYou did it with stipulations and expectations. Stipulations handled, expectations met,‚Äù Secondhand said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre aware.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat counts for something,‚Äù Last Minute said. ‚ÄúIt needed doing, and it was done well.‚Äù

‚ÄúTrust that we intend to do this well,‚Äù Snag said. ‚ÄúThe three of us have spent a year steadily working toward this. If you want more money, we could discuss it. We‚Äôd want references to justify it, a guarantee you‚Äôll earn your keep.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think we could manage that. Instead of money, though‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúHmm?‚Äù

‚ÄúCradle. He‚Äôs your best tinker?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe can be.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe you sweeten the pot. Include his work.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat can be arranged. You give us your references and recommendations in exchange.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright. I like the sound of that. We‚Äôll talk.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù Snag said.

Secondhand put out a hand. Snag reached out with his giant mechanical hand, enclosing it around Secondhand‚Äôs hand and forearm.

They all shook hands. Snag‚Äôs giant mechanical hand made for a peculiar image as it met Final Hour‚Äôs hair-dryer stub of a limb and the two shook.

When steampunk-ish End of Days gingerly took Love Lost‚Äôs clawed hand in his bare hand, he bent down, kissing the back of it. With her back to the camera, it was impossible to see her reaction.

The Speedrunners split up into two groups, two getting into an older car, and two getting into the van with the tech in the back.

Snag and Love Lost walked back the way they came. Love Lost turned her head to watch as the cars pulled out of the parking lot and then drove past the pair of them. The camera that was perched on the edge of the building slowly turned to follow the pair.

As the camera zoomed in, the sound clarifying, the metal noises of Snag‚Äôs hands periodically touching the road and Love Lost‚Äôs claws clicking were very audible.

Kenzie must have changed something, because the sound faded into the background.

‚ÄúGood?‚Äù Snag asked.

Love Lost gave him a singular nod.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre good to have. Versatile, and it‚Äôs good to have that tech. I can think of ten things I could do with that.‚Äù

Another nod.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre good for the meeting at the pub?‚Äù

A final nod.

‚ÄúPub,‚Äù I heard Tristan say. ‚ÄúKenzie? Do we deploy Victoria?‚Äù

‚ÄúI have an address. Only pub in Cedar Point, I think. Across the street from where Prancer went inside.‚Äù

I brought the phone up to my face. ‚ÄúLove Lost might be able to sense people, and there‚Äôs Birdbrain and Braindead to account for.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs up to you, Victoria,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúBut it would really, really help if we could get more of this kind of exchange.‚Äù

I stepped off the roof, realized that someone was standing on the sidewalk on the far side of the street, staring at me, and saw the alarm on their faces. I gave them my best heroic salute as I started flying instead of falling from the roof of the two-story building.

‚ÄúAshley and Rain are kind of quiet,‚Äù I said, to the phone.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like phones, where I can‚Äôt see faces or reactions,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine. This is good.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not so fine,‚Äù Rain said.

Understandable.

Right. I‚Äôd maybe talk to him after, or encourage him to reach out to Yamada. Even better, he could get around to making that call to the hero teams.

But for now, going into enemy territory, I needed to look after myself and the mission. I now needed to make prompt decisions for things that I‚Äôd hoped I‚Äôd have a few days or weeks to think about.

‚ÄúRadio silence unless it‚Äôs an emergency, or you need to tell me to stop deploying the camera, Kenzie,‚Äù I said.

I heard a faint ‚Äòboop‚Äô.

No assistance, now. Just me and my intel. I put the white mask on.

Primary concerns: Braindead and Birdbrain. Clairvoyants both.

Braindead was a tactical thinker, who could designate a set area in three dimensions, setting out a rectangular prism where he sensed everything in the area. He could cover a small town with his power and have a general awareness of everything that happened in that town, but if he designated a smaller area, he got more clarity, more attention of simultaneous things at once, and he was aware of stats. Non-numerical values for abstract things like physical wellness, martial combat capacity, and run speed, for everyone in the area. Smaller area, more and more accurate stats.

The drawback was that he was a twenty-something guy that spent an awful lot of time sitting in a chair with a diaper on, drooling, mumbling, and feeling acutely uncomfortable. When his power was active, and for a time after, he was unable to act on his knowledge himself, or even to effectively defend himself. He had been on the side of the good guys, once, which was why his power information was such common knowledge. Something had changed or snapped.

I flew just over the rooftops. It wasn‚Äôt me flying at a height where I could pull my phone out, because there was a very real chance I could fly into something like a power line or chimney.

Braindead‚Äôs power operated in three dimensions. X, Y, Z. A set area of north, south, east, west, up, and down. If he wanted all of the stats and information, and if he wanted to minimize the other drawbacks of his power, like the recovery time, up and down were often the variable he could sacrifice. He could cover an area three city blocks wide along the west-east axis and three city blocks long along the north-south axis, while only covering six to ten feet of up and down.

Against Braindead alone, flying high and sticking to rooftops was a really safe bet, to stay out of his realm of awareness.

Against Birdbrain, that was a weakness. Birdbrain was a tactical clairvoyant of a complementary stripe to Braindead. Top-down clairvoyant awareness, much like if Kenzie operated solely through tinker eyes-in-the-sky pointed straight down. She also had thinker powers of another sort, worked into the main clairvoyant power, but she wasn‚Äôt an ex-hero, and the information wasn‚Äôt in files.

She was really good with a gun, highly mobile, and thus she was very good at defending Braindead while he was incapacitated.

If I stuck to rooftops, Birdbrain would detect me quickly. If I went to the ground, I‚Äôd be in Braindead‚Äôs realm.

I flew under things when I could, just to try to throw Birdbrain for a loop. It took me a second to orient myself and find the buildings I was looking for, even when I knew they were part of the downtown strip.

No sign of Snag or Love Lost. They were already inside, I hoped. With luck, I would be able to get the camera online shortly.

I set down on the roof, my forcefield down, and put my bag down in the corner of the roof, against the raised lip.

Fully aware that it was very likely that an eye in the sky was watching my every move, I used my body to block the view of the bag‚Äôs contents, and pulled the camera out, placing it against the corner, where the bag would shield it. I got my notebook out, opened it to an empty page, and put it across the corner of the roof, before pulling out the chips and what turned out to be curry in a pita wrap.

Curry in a pita was not a mix I‚Äôd run into before, but I wasn‚Äôt going to complain. I put the wrap on my notebook, weighing it down, and the chips by my bag, against the ledge of the roof.

My backpack shielded most of the camera from view, the notebook‚Äôs placement shielded any view of it from above.

I had to take it slow. I sat on the roof, leaning against the ledge, opened the bag, and adjusted the plunger. I reached into the bag, and discovered they weren‚Äôt chips, but a salted pork rind thing.

Urg.

I ate a few, penned down some general observations of the neighborhood, and then adjusted the plunger slightly downward, as part of the process of reaching down to fish for another mouthful of overly-salted pork things.

It took maybe a minute and a half to two minutes, because of the regular pauses here and there. I heard the ‚Äòboop‚Äô through my phone, took that as my signal, and pulled my phone out to cancel the call, being sure to keep it at an angle where someone watching from above me couldn‚Äôt see the phone‚Äôs face or display.

I was nervous, remaining where I was. Every moment I was here, I was guarding the camera, the camera was presumably filming, and we were getting information.

Every moment I was here, I was being watched. My forcefield was down, because having it up risked it damaging the roof, building, or the camera. The locals were getting time to figure out what to do with me.

We wanted to stir the hornet‚Äôs nest, to keep it stirred to exhaust resources and keep them from being particularly effective villains. Those same hornets could sting.

I ate some of Chris‚Äô curry in a pita, just to look like I was on a typical stakeout or patrol, and I wished I‚Äôd brought a drink. I took notes, with an eye to graffiti and symbols, to names and sayings. Things I could look up later, to see if I could divine any other names or personalities that had settled in Cedar Point.

It was maybe five minutes in total before they decided they were uncomfortable with me being where I was. Across the street, a big guy in costume emerged. Blond haired, a metal mask with fur on it, and a combination of metal and what looked like horn or natural armor plates on a brown costume. His gauntlets looked menacing, with fur, metal, and studs.

He looked pretty B-list, all in all.

He beckoned for me to come. I wondered if I should gather my bag.

I decided to take a risk, leaving it where it was. I flew down to the street below.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm Moose,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre unwelcome.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe last time I came, you guys called Tattletale. She told me to get lost.‚Äù

‚ÄúYup,‚Äù Moose said.

‚ÄúTo me, hearing that, I‚Äôm inclined to think I should show up more,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúAhh, nope,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúNo, I think you‚Äôve got the wrong inclination there, Glory Girl.‚Äù

I shrugged. ‚ÄúWhat can you do, Moose?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat I‚Äôm going to do, Glory Girl, is I‚Äôm going to tell you how this is going to go down.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo tell,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúTwo brutes, like you and me, heavy hitters, we‚Äôre liable to have a brawl. I‚Äôll avoid breaking anything breakable because I have an investment in Hollow Point here. You‚Äôll avoid breaking stuff because you‚Äôre one of the good guys. You don‚Äôt want that bad PR.‚Äù

‚ÄúMakes sense,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll have a really polite knock-down brawl, as such things go, and you‚Äôll trounce me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll trounce you?‚Äù

‚ÄúI said I‚Äôd tell you how this was going to go, and I‚Äôm pretty sure that‚Äôs how it‚Äôs going to go.‚Äù

‚ÄúThinker power?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúOnly thinker power I got is decently good common sense,‚Äù Moose said.

I nodded.

‚ÄúSo you‚Äôll trounce me. Thoroughly. You‚Äôll embarrass me, even. Not because you‚Äôre a girl and I‚Äôm a guy, but because you‚Äôre strong and you have more experience, and because fighting someone who flies is a massive bother.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou could surrender.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan‚Äôt. Invested in this place. But there‚Äôs more to it, Glory Girl.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot my name anymore, by the way.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, really? Sorry about that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have another to give you, not yet, but I thought I‚Äôd let you know.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre going to stay, I gotta fight you and I gotta get trounced.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a shame,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúBut there‚Äôs more to it. I‚Äôm pulling from that common sense, now. You‚Äôll trounce me, I‚Äôll be embarrassed, and in the time it takes for that to happen, others are going to show up. They won‚Äôt interfere, but they‚Äôll stand around and they‚Äôll be ready to fight you if you‚Äôre insistent on staying. You‚Äôll be outnumbered and they won‚Äôt be inclined to play fair, except that they‚Äôll let you leave if you‚Äôre willing to leave.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhich I will.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood to hear. Except‚Ä¶ can we just skip straight to the part where you leave? I don‚Äôt want to be embarrassed and you don‚Äôt want to run scared from a group of menacing looking capes.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm supposed to run scared from you instead, Moose?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can knock me around as you make your exit, if you‚Äôd like.‚Äù

‚ÄúReally?‚Äù I asked, a little incredulous.

He shrugged.

‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt a trap?‚Äù

‚ÄúNope.‚Äù

I used my flight, and rose up off the ground. He didn‚Äôt react.

I flew at him, forcefield up, fist out.

He met my fist with his, moving faster than I‚Äôd expected. The shockwave from the impact knocked me back and up into the air. I righted myself and hovered on the spot, ten or so feet off the ground.

The shockwave was weird. Intense, and focused. There was more to that Brute power.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt embarrass myself too badly,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs an audience.‚Äù

I looked.

In the window of the pub, Snag had risen to his feet. Love Lost was sitting, still, watching through the window. There were a handful of others.

I met Snag‚Äôs eyes momentarily, and tried to look a little surprised.

Then I flew at Moose again. I pushed out with my aura.

His reaction to the fear and awe was to strike out, a solid punch, not a reckless one like most would throw reactively. I didn‚Äôt follow the awe with an attack, and I was glad I hadn‚Äôt, because the chances were good that I would‚Äôve been hit.

Instead, I used his momentary bewilderment to fly over his head, because it was easy to do, it required him to turn around. Better yet, it involved a lot of readjustment of footing and balance, at the same time he was recovering from the emotional hit.

Watching, waiting, feeling more like the warrior monk as I used this approach, I tried to identify the time his footing was still off, his awareness of me imperfect, and I dove, striking him with one foot in the collarbone.

In the process, the wretch decided to strike out too. It hit him across the face, knocking the mask off. I saw blood, and the tracks of fingernails.

He fell, and he sat there, his head turned away from me, one gauntlet-covered hand moving to his face.

‚ÄúYou okay?‚Äù I asked, flying up and looking away. I didn‚Äôt want to be accused of peering beneath the mask.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll mend,‚Äù he said.

I didn‚Äôt wait, and I didn‚Äôt look back. Back to my notebook, to my bag and book and Chris‚Äô meal. I packed it up, collecting the camera.

When I‚Äôd crossed the water and reached the edge of the neighborhood where the hideout was, I called the others.

‚ÄúThanks for that, Victoria,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúHow‚Äôd we do?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt get the very start and we didn‚Äôt get what would‚Äôve been the end, but we got some, and I think everyone‚Äôs happy with that,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúYou okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm alright.‚Äù

‚ÄúCome back. We‚Äôll talk, and you can see what we got.‚Äù

I flew back. I didn‚Äôt fly in a straight line, being mindful of any possible pursuers, and I flew lower to the ground as I drew closer to the building where the place we were renting was. I landed at the edge of the lot and walked to the fire escape.

Ashley, Sveta, Kenzie and Chris were all present. They were watching a distorted and monochrome image of the inside of the pub, projected on the wall.

I noted the absence of Tristan and Rain.

‚ÄúHe ran,‚Äù Ashley said, her voice low.

‚ÄúRain?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe got spooked,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúTristan went after him.‚Äù

‚ÄúTo reassure,‚Äù Sveta said.

Chris reached past Kenzie to hit keys on the keyboard. The image on the projector screen changed.

‚ÄúYou suck at that,‚Äù Kenzie said, elbowing him. ‚ÄúHere.‚Äù

The image was distorted, as if viewing something underwater, with a film of grime on the lens. The sound, however, was only slightly muted.

‚ÄúYou really want this kid to suffer.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe want him to face a fate worse than death,‚Äù Snag said. ‚ÄúBut we can‚Äôt have that and have him dead at the same time, and we need him dead. If he suffers as much as possible along the way to that conclusion, we‚Äôll be satisfied.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre paying, we can satisf—‚Äù

The message cut off as Kenzie hit a key. She looked back at me, shooting me what might‚Äôve been an attempt at a reassuring smile. Not so reassuring.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll figure something out,‚Äù I said, to myself as much as them.

Shade — Interlude 4a

It‚Äôs his turn tonight.

They ran, they pushed forward. A crush of people.

Smoke billowed, and it smelled like burning rubber. For all the chaos, the noises seemed muted, dulled in how the individual elements mixed, the bodies absorbing the sound. Shouts here and there cut through the cries, the noise of people, the sound of something falling down, but people further ahead in the crowd were actively grabbing others and shoving them to the side, dragging them out of the way.

Even with the high ceiling, the haze of smoke made the exit sign above the door hard to see. The point of view blurred, blacked out for an instant as the person blinked.

‚ÄúLancaster fire—‚Äù the point of view said, more to himself. His voice soon rose to a bellow. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt— don‚Äôt stampede! Don‚Äôt shove! We‚Äôll get crammed at the exit!‚Äù

The smoke got to him, and he coughed, hard.

He tried to slow, as if he could influence the crowd. The force of people behind him pushed him forward, as heavy as he was. He was a big guy. Big around the middle, more. Only a bit taller than average. It was enough that he could almost see over the heads of the crowd.

He saw a young girl fall, and very nearly tripped over her. To do so might have killed them both. He fell to his knees beside her, grabbing at the edge of a sign on the wall to brace himself, one arm around the girl. He became a barrier, battered by those behind him. Feet scraped at his back, trying to climb over him.

He watched as the people pushed further down. He knew what was happening as it happened. That the press of bodies was keeping people from being able to get the door open, that by the time people realized there was no way forward, the people behind them would keep them from retreating. There would only be the inexorable, forward pressure.

Straining, every movement made harder by people leaning against him or pushing past him, nearly being knocked over to crush the girl in front of him on three occasions, he rose to his feet. For what seemed like a minute, it was all he could do to hold his position.

He looked back, and there was only smoke, people pushing toward the exit. He looked toward the exit sign, and there was only the press, people crammed together until they were chest-to-back, shoulder-to-shoulder.

He looked around, at the trash cans, at the signs that were built into the wall, frames sticking an inch or two out, locked plexiglass doors protecting the contents from vandalism. He looked up, and he saw the windows and the glass ceiling above the corridor that led out of the mall. There were high windows that let the light in, and there were latches on those windows.

He reached down, and the young girl shied away.

‚ÄúUp!‚Äù he said. He seized her arm, and as he leaned down, someone bumped into him. He nearly fell on her. Only his grip on the side of one of the sign-frames kept him from falling.

He drove an elbow back, striking at the person who had pushed him. With more energy, desperation, he reached down to seize the girl‚Äôs arm, lifted her bodily into the air, and shifted his grip, grabbing her body to lift her.

‚ÄúGrab on and climb!‚Äù he called out. ‚ÄúGet to the window!‚Äù

She tried. Sneakers slid against the plexiglass. Fingers gripped the ledge, and even with him boosting her, she couldn‚Äôt get up. She wasn‚Äôt even looking at what she was doing, as she turned her face down and away from the thicker smoke.

Further down the hallway, a group of people fell like dominoes. For those who wanted to get away, get to the exit, people who couldn‚Äôt necessarily see past the smoke or the people immediately in front of them, it was an opening, a way to get forward. The mob moved forward. A woman screamed, a multi-note sound.

Seizing the opportunity, only seeing the gap, people pushed past him, bumped into him. He was holding the girl as he stumbled, and he dropped her. He doubled over, coughing, trying to keep from getting dragged forward. He was a big guy and the movement of the crowd was such that his feet left the ground at points, when people pressed closer.

The girl, too, coughed. She looked at him, wide-eyed, until the smoke forced her to close her eyes, and then she ran for the exit, slipping from his reaching fingers, dodging into a gap of bodies, toward the press, where people were barely able to move. People were panicking in places, voices reaching high pitches.

‚ÄúNo!‚Äù he bellowed at the girl. His voice was lost in the chaos.

She nearly fell to the ground amid trampling feet as someone stumbled into her. Then she was gone.

He looked up at the sign, and he reached, digging fingers in where the sign and the wall were. He stepped on someone, tried to climb toward the window, eye on the latch, darting over to look at the smoke behind him, then up to where the smoke was thick near the ceiling. The plexiglass front of the sign was a hinge, so it could be opened, and he dug his finger into that gap for the leverage it could afford.

The climb would have been hard on its own, but he was jostled. His hand slipped, and both his fingernail and the tip of his finger tore off as his hand came away from the hinge. A thin streak of blood was drawn on the plexiglass.

Someone slid between him and the wall, and he was no longer able to hold himself up. He landed on the ground, and people walked over him. His efforts to stand were defeated by the feet trampling him. He couldn‚Äôt stop coughing, and his vision distorted from the effort.

Behind them, the fire and smoke were getting worse.

He looked up, vision warped to the point that up and down and left and right were no longer clear, he looked at the walls that stretched skyward, the glass ceiling high above, the bodies pressed around him and over him. The view blurred with the tears in his eyes, growing dark as the people closed in above him.

The image distorted, going black, and he saw stars, flying past him, as if he was being buoyed elsewhere.

‚äô

A scene faded, unremembered. Points of light became light. Darkness became shadows in a large, dark room.

There was no skylight, no corridor, no crowd or mall. In the center of the room was a spike of twisted metal and glass topped by what looked like a sundial without a marker. Light shone through the glass as if it was coming through the other side, but no source could be seen. The different tints of the red-blue-purple light divided the room into four sections, with a fifth left dark. Each section was littered with debris of different sorts.

Without even needing to look to check the position, Rain reached down for the chair. Always in the same place, the same position. The floor in his section was dilapidated. Uneven floorboards with spaces between them. There were scattered books, tools that looked like they hadn‚Äôt been touched in a while, and some assorted branches and dry pine needles, as if it was a space that had been exposed to the elements. He put the chair down on the ground.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt suppose you guys are willing to talk?‚Äù he asked. Again, he didn‚Äôt even need to look or check the position of the others. He knew where they would be.

There was no reply.

The memory had been Snag‚Äôs, and Snag was the first to really move. Snag wasn‚Äôt as big as he had once been. Still tall, but he had lost a lot of weight. The beard he‚Äôd had before was longer now, shaggier. So was his hair. There were streaks of paler hair at the corners of his mouth. The hood of a sweatshirt and the lack of clear lighting masked much of the man‚Äôs face, so only the beard was visible. Snag‚Äôs area was a store without things. Empty display cabinets, cracked glass, metal shelves, a lacquered floor, and more diffuse light than the other spaces.

Snag reached the table, and slammed one hand down on the surface. He gripped the edges, hunched over.

Someone else spoke, quiet enough he was almost inaudible. It was how he usually talked. ‚ÄúYou two should know I‚Äôm looking into our situation here. I‚Äôll be experimenting soon, so you should know things might get weird.‚Äù

A young man. Nondescript. Boring. Blond hair, average weight, clothes without labels, a bit older than Rain at eighteen or so. The slabs of concrete and tile made his space look like a hall of mirrors after an earthquake, if the glass was opaque concrete instead. Shattered, dark, claustrophobic, devoid of the human touch. The only thing about him that stood out was that his glasses were scratched up, to the point where it wasn‚Äôt possible to see his eyes. He held his head at funny angles to see through the less scratched part, chin high, looking down, or head bent, looking up and out.

Rain had taken to thinking of him as the recluse. The guy had talked before about not spending much time around people. He was quiet, weird, and his dreams weirder still.

He hadn‚Äôt been including Rain in the ‚Äòyou two‚Äô.

‚ÄúWhat experiment?‚Äù Snag asked, his voice hoarse enough to be a growl.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm reaching out to someone. They do interesting things with people and sleep. I have no clue what‚Äôs going to happen, but it‚Äôs possible I won‚Äôt show up, or I‚Äôll have a guest. Tomorrow.‚Äù

The woman approached, standing from a sitting position in a squat, small armchair. She stepped over stuffed animals and broken toys.

She was elegant, wearing an ankle-length dress with a slit up one side. Her hair was styled into waves and curls. She wore earrings and a necklace, heels, and her nails were painted. None of her tinker gear was present.

Her lower face was covered in the mask that could have been described as a muzzle, it clung so tightly to her face, covering nose and mouth. It was black leather, and it had real teeth set into it. Fangs.

Her eyes were more vicious than the snarling maw. She stared Rain down until she‚Äôd reached the plate of crystal at the center of the room, and turned around to sit with her back to the thing. To Rain. Her head turned toward the recluse, and she tapped one long fingernail to one of the teeth of her mask, her muzzle, before pointing it down, knuckle resting against the mask.

‚ÄúYeah, actually,‚Äù the recluse said. ‚ÄúYou know ‚Äòem?‚Äù

The woman offered one, singular nod.

‚ÄúAny advice?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy ask? She doesn‚Äôt talk,‚Äù Rain said.

The recluse ignored him.

The woman turned, reaching down to the dias. Rain drew closer to watch as she picked her way through the assorted debris on the table. The wood was burned and as delicate as charcoal, breaking apart at a touch, crumbling into dust as it fell to the five-sided plate. Almost everything on the table was similarly fragile. The glass, the rusty scraps of metal.

She picked out three human teeth, and slid two of them in the recluse‚Äôs direction.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs dangerous?‚Äù The recluse asked.

Another nod from the muzzled woman. She tapped a finger on the one remaining tooth on her part of the table.

‚ÄúI really appreciate that,‚Äù the recluse said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll keep that in mind.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have a suggestion,‚Äù Snag said. Growled. He was pacing a little, hand brushing against his edge of the plate as he walked beside it. One of his fingers was still damaged from the event a year ago.

‚ÄúSure.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt do it tomorrow night,‚Äù Snag said, stopping.

‚ÄúWhy not?‚Äù

Snag turned his head, staring at the darkness that separated his section from Rain‚Äôs. He was almost but not quite looking at Rain, shadows heavy around his eyes as he glared. ‚ÄúTomorrow is your night. The night after is hers.‚Äù

The recluse turned to look at the muzzled woman.

Snag said, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs do it the night after hers. In case something goes wrong.‚Äù

‚ÄúMakes sense,‚Äù the recluse said.

On my night, Rain thought.

Rain approached the table. He kept a wary eye on the others as he picked up the debris, destroying it in his hands. Almost everything was so old, burned, water damaged or rusty that it disintegrated with firm contact. He cast it aside, letting it litter the floor. The items scraped and cut his hands on contact, but he didn‚Äôt mind.

There were only three items he couldn‚Äôt destroy. Scraps of metal, too dull and thick to be knives, too flat and featureless to be of any particular use. Like rectangular pieces of a broken glass, but not glass.

The others were sorting themselves out. Five shards of glass for Snag, three coins for the recluse. The muzzled woman stared him down. She‚Äôd already handed out two of the teeth that served as her token, keeping one for herself.

Even the others, when they glanced at him, radiated hostility.

‚ÄúI need to update up one of my arms,‚Äù Snag said, his voice low. He glanced at Rain and turned his back, leaning against the table as he leaned closer to the recluse, lowering his voice further. ‚ÄúI made a replacement, I want to make the other match it.‚Äù

‚ÄúToday?‚Äù the recluse asked, picking up one of the tarnished coins.

‚ÄúHmm. I‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôll have time.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine either way, for me. You?‚Äù The recluse turned toward the muzzled woman for that last bit.

The muzzled woman nodded.

Snag slid a piece of glass across the table, to the recluse‚Äôs side. His fingertips stopped at the boundary, and the recluse reached over to slide the glass the rest of the way.

‚ÄúI guess I get to be pretty strong today,‚Äù the recluse said.

‚ÄúYou won‚Äôt need your workshop,‚Äù Snag said. ‚ÄúAnd we could use a better sense of tech, for reasons we discussed on the phone. Give me your share tomorrow, too, and I won‚Äôt need it for a while.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt mind,‚Äù the recluse said. He passed the coins over to the others. Two for Snag. One for the muzzled woman.

Rain looked down at his rectangles of metal. They hadn‚Äôt asked, and he hadn‚Äôt offered. He had, once, trying to curry favor. He‚Äôd given them his tokens and he‚Äôd never received a thing in return.

He kept the three rectangles of metal in his section of the table.

Rain took a seat in the creaky wooden chair and he waited for dawn, listening and hearing nothing of consequence while the three people talked, or, well, two of them talked and the muzzled woman listened.

He‚Äôd tried to reason. He‚Äôd tried to talk. He‚Äôd tried being angry. There was no use. The only option left was to wait until dawn, and try to listen, to act dumb, and drop comments here and there that could mislead.

He looked over to his left at the dark fifth of the room. No details, no debris, no light. No tokens on the table.

He gripped the three pieces of metal in his hands until the edges cut into his fingers and blood oozed out between them.

‚äô

‚ÄúRain. Wake up.‚Äù

Rain‚Äôs eyes opened. No dreams, not really. Only someone else‚Äôs recollections and then the room. He felt more tired than he had when his head had hit the pillow. He had a headache and every part of him felt heavy.

‚ÄúSchool,‚Äù his aunt said, from the bedroom door, her face peering through the crack.

He sat up.

‚ÄúGo downstairs to eat before you shower, if you‚Äôre going to shower. The girls are making breakfast.‚Äù

‚ÄúI will,‚Äù he said, before adding an automatic, ‚Äúthank you auntie.‚Äù

She left the door open as she left. Rain was annoyed, but held his tongue.

Swinging his feet over to the side of the bed, he looked at his hands, turning them over. There was no sign of the dirt, grit. No damage from moving the objects on the five sided table, no cuts on his fingers or blood on the back of his hand.

As he often did, he reached out for his individual powers. His own power was at its ordinary strength. The scythes of shimmering, flickering light appeared in each of his hands. It felt right.

The emotion power— he reached for it and cast it out over the empty space in the middle of his room. He was aware of it like he‚Äôd be aware of a patch of shade. The effectiveness wasn‚Äôt much sharper than creating the shade would be.

When he reached for the tinker power, the ideas that came to mind were paltry, barely much better than how he might manage setting up a snare or the steps for forging a knife. He wasn‚Äôt even especially good at those things.

That left the mover power. He used it to get to his feet, pushing himself out of bed and using the power rather than his balance to steady himself.

He‚Äôd slept in a t-shirt and boxers, and felt exposed as he canceled out the arrested movement of the mover power, stepped over to the door and shut it. He pulled on a dirty pair of jeans and ran his fingers through his shoulder-length hair until it was reasonable.

His family tended to subscribe to the notion that the kitchen was the center of the home. The buildings that had been erected for the settlement were set up in a way that made for large kitchens. Wood was burning at a massive brick stove with room for six frying pans on it, and there were two girls Rain‚Äôs age handling food there. He couldn‚Äôt quite remember their names. Heather and Lauren, maybe. Or was one of them Jean? He‚Äôd seen them around, but they didn‚Äôt go to the school and they‚Äôd never talked to him.

Rain‚Äôs auntie was at the counter, grating potatoes. Her daughter, Rain‚Äôs cousin Allie, stood talking to one of the men that was sitting at the table, while she took her time drying a dish.

Rain knew only one of the men at the table— an uncle, who had said ten words at most in all the time Rain knew him. There was no introduction made for the other two men who sat there.

As good as the food was, as much as the stove was warm and the family close and busy, it wasn‚Äôt warm in atmosphere. There was no small talk. There were some glances from Allie, who was washing and drying, and from the girls at the stove. The glances were reserved for when they thought he wasn‚Äôt looking.

They weren‚Äôt kind looks.

Hash browns, ‚Äòmade properly‚Äô, his Aunt would say, and french toast cut in thick slices from homemade bread. The bread that wasn‚Äôt being used to make french toast was sitting in a basket on the table, with jam and butter sitting nearby. With the production that went into cooking, there was a lot of pressure to eat, to get full. For most, it was necessary, with long days of hard work on the farms.

Not that Rain worked on the farms much.

‚ÄúThank you for breakfast,‚Äù he said.

The girls didn‚Äôt respond.

‚ÄúYou gonna have a shower?‚Äù his aunt asked.

‚ÄúA quick one,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúStomp when you‚Äôre done,‚Äù she said, turning the knob at the base of the sink‚Äôs faucet, cutting off the water. The plumbing in the house wasn‚Äôt great, and the cold water being turned on meant the shower water would scald.

He gathered his dishes.

‚ÄúYou can leave that for the girls.‚Äù

‚ÄúI already got it,‚Äù he said.

He collected a few more things, aware of the looks from the men sitting around the table, and took them to the side of the sink where the dirty pans and dishes were waiting to be washed.

Allie, standing next to him, pulled a knife out of the drying rack. The metal made a sound as it ran against the side of the rack, singing slightly in the wake of it. Between that, the weapon, the hostility he felt from the two girls at the stove, he shivered slightly. He looked out the window.

Those people I saw in my dream want me dead.

He‚Äôd paused too long, lost in thought, being as tired as he was. He was very aware of the stares, of the long looks from the men at the table, his uncle excepted. The girls had paused in their work.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù his aunt asked, her voice sharp. She glanced at the girls. Her voice was sharper as she asked, ‚ÄúWhat, do you need someone to come up and wash you?‚Äù

‚ÄúGross,‚Äù one of the girls at the stove said.

‚ÄúHey!‚Äù one of the men barked the word. The girl jumped. A rebuke without any elaboration.

‚ÄúNo, auntie, I was just thinking,‚Äù Rain said, feeling his face get hot.

‚ÄúThen save the thinking for school and get going. We need the sink free to finish the dishes.‚Äù

He got going.

The shower was hot, even with the cold water cranked all the way around, and he rushed through the process of getting clean. The soap, spooned out of a jar with a wooden spatula to his hands, then applied to the critical areas, was a gooey mess derived from animal fat and ash. He had no idea what the shampoo was, but it was harsh enough to make his scalp hurt, so he only used it every two or three days.

He had scratches and bruises, only some of them from his time with Victoria and the team. He was ginger with them all, checked for the redness of infection, and dabbed them dry instead of toweling more roughly as he finished showering and started getting dry. He stomped hard on the floor, three times, as he stepped out of the shower. The pipes knocked as the water downstairs was turned on again.

The recluse was planning something for three nights from now. He needed to plan, conserve strength. It was possible he would be incapacitated, if the others found a way to hijack the rotation or interfere with his days.

His thoughts were occupied with the logistics and conversations he‚Äôd need to have as he wrapped a towel around his waist, checked for chin scruff, and then crossed the hall to enter his room. Clean clothes, bag, shoes.

He did his best to stay out of sight of the kitchen as he headed downstairs, ducking into the front hall and out the door.

The dirt road cut a zig-zagging line between homes and fields. Things had been situated in a way that had been convenient at the time, but the layout didn‚Äôt make for good town planning otherwise. Other students were walking to school, older siblings watching the younger ones, friends meeting to talk. Some parents walked with their children to supervise. Other adults were around to supervise. The notorious and inevitable Mrs. Sims was bitching at a group of the fifth graders, splitting up groups of friends to make the boys and girls walk on different sides of the road.

A truck came down the road, and the students moved to the muddy sides where the ground was far softer. It was Jay, stopping periodically to let friends hop into the back.

A short distance behind Rain, Jay stopped in plain view of Mrs. Sims to ask Brianna and Kaylyn Barr if they wanted to ride in the truck, which was already mostly packed with senior boys.

The sisters climbed into the back of the pickup truck. Mrs. Sims scowled, but she kept her mouth shut.

The truck moved a little bit further down the road and stopped beside Rain. Jay leaned past his girlfriend. He had thin facial hair, a baseball cap, and a sweatshirt with a logo on it. The sweatshirt and cap looked brand new, and they also looked like they were from Bet, with the quality and logos. Expensive.

‚ÄúYou want a ride, rain man?‚Äù Jay asked.

‚ÄúNo thanks. Walking with a friend.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know who you‚Äôre talking about. You know you don‚Äôt have the slightest chance with her, right?‚Äù

‚ÄúOf being her friend?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, right,‚Äù Jay said. He rolled his eyes. ‚ÄúEnjoy that walk.‚Äù

The wheels spun against the dirt road before finding traction. The pickup truck bucked a little with the uneven transition, nearly tossing Kaylyn Barr out the back as the back end came up. Only a quick grab by one of the older boys saved her from a tumble.

A cloud of dust followed behind it. If it was meant to annoy Rain, it didn‚Äôt. He turned his back to the worst of the cloud, looking out at the farmland.

‚ÄúRain!‚Äù Mrs. Sims called out. Some of the smaller students on the road flinched.

Rain looked more her way.

‚ÄúGet yourself straight to school. Don‚Äôt dawdle,‚Äù she said.

He could have said something about that. Jay might have. If he hadn‚Äôt had the experiences he had, he might even have called her an evil person, said she deserved it. She was an artifact of a prior era, the kind of person who had lived in every small town and rural community he‚Äôd known; she was someone who used morality as a stick to beat others with. He could have asked what she was implying, or challenged her.

He didn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúYes, ma‚Äôam,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúJust waiting for the dust to settle so I‚Äôm not walking face-first into it.‚Äù

Someone else might have made a comment, empathized. Mrs. Sims only said, ‚ÄúGo to school. Be a better example for the little ones.‚Äù

He walked.

The people like Mrs. Sims and his aunt were easier to deal with than many of the alternatives. He could understand the people who‚Äôd reacted to hurt and loss by becoming harder. He wished he‚Äôd been able to do the same, a lot of the time.

Erin emerged from her house as he reached the mailbox staked out in front. He waited while she made her way down, her little brother following.

It was hard not to have his eyes linger on her. She wore a plum colored muscle tank with a cross in black on the front, a black choker with a steel buckle, and black jeans. The jewelry in her ears matched the buckle of the choker, a series of rings in her left ear and a single piece of jewelry in the right, glittering in the sun as she steered her brother along the path.

He‚Äôd come to dislike the muscle tops with those oversized armholes on principle, after seeing so many girls he couldn‚Äôt stand wearing them as a trashy sort of look. Seeing Erin wear it and look so stunning, he found himself doing a one-eighty on the position on the spot.

‚ÄúHey, Erin, hey bruiser,‚Äù he said. He stuck out his hand, like he might for a handshake, and Bryce slapped it in a high-five. He and Rain reversed the directions their hands were moving to lightly slap the backs of their hands together, and Bryce moved forward to mock-punch Rain in the hip, then thigh. The third punch missed Rain‚Äôs groin only because of a timely twist to one side.

‚ÄúCareful with Rain, Bry. He looks a little battered, he doesn‚Äôt need you giving him more bruises,‚Äù Erin said, putting one hand on Bryce‚Äôs forehead, pulling him back while Bryce continued punching at the air.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs coming to school with us?‚Äù Rain asked. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think he went to school.‚Äù

‚ÄúNext year,‚Äù Bryce said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got to drop him off at church. He‚Äôs being punished, and somehow my parents think a sermon is going to give him direction.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat did you do, Bry?‚Äù

‚ÄúI said mean things about Elijah,‚Äù Bryce said. ‚ÄúMr. Jean heard and tattled.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou need to be careful who you talk about and how,‚Äù Erin said. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt want to upset anyone. What if Elijah heard?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, I know,‚Äù Bryce said.

Erin gave Rain a look, from an angle Bryce wasn‚Äôt meant to see. Worried, unsure. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to come.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a problem,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù Erin said.

Bryce spotted his friends walking down the road with their older siblings, and started to walk that way. Erin bent down, putting her hands on Bryce‚Äôs shoulders to catch him. ‚ÄúNuh uh, Bry. You‚Äôre supposed to be in trouble. You walk with us.‚Äù

She steered Bryce in the other direction, toward school and church, and as she turned, bent over, Rain saw through the oversized armhole of her top. Stomach, ribs, lacy black bra strap, bra, and a bit of what the bra was meant to support. The look had been automatic, and the moment he realized what he was looking at, he looked away.

He had very complicated feelings on those tops, now, as he found himself simultaneously trying to memorize every detail of what he‚Äôd seen and prepared himself so he wouldn‚Äôt be an asshole and look again at what she didn‚Äôt necessarily intend to show him. He was well aware of how the two things conflicted.

‚ÄúAre you doing okay?‚Äù she asked him. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a little scraped up.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm always a little scraped up. I‚Äôm used to it.‚Äù

They walked, Bryce between the two of them.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve officially watched the last of the videos from the library. Even the bad ones, like E.T.3,‚Äù Erin said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm stuck reading and rewatching stuff until they get more.‚Äù

‚ÄúReading isn‚Äôt so bad,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúThere were five years where my family didn‚Äôt even have power at the place we were staying.‚Äù

‚ÄúEvery time you talk about your past my heart hurts a little. No TV? No music?‚Äù

‚ÄúReading by candlelight. Hobbies. You figure out how to entertain yourself. There was a summer some other kids and I dug a hole and covered it with slats of wood, and we called it our hideout.‚Äù

Erin pressed the heel of her hand to her heart.

‚ÄúIt was a good hideout. Really.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou were so deprived you couldn‚Äôt even build a treehouse.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe could‚Äôve. We wanted to dig a hole. We covered it with dirt and sticks so people wouldn‚Äôt know it was even there, if they didn‚Äôt see the hole.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow old were you?‚Äù

‚ÄúTen? Eleven? About Kenzie‚Äôs age, I think.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen I was eleven? I think we went to Disneyworld at the start of summer. And I had six weeks of camp with the most irresponsible camp counselors. Tons of food we shouldn‚Äôt have been allowed to have, swimming, mud Olympics. One of the boys fell on the mud slide and broke two of his fingers.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to imagine you being eleven.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was the most awesome eleven year old. Man, I really wanted to go back there the next year, but I think our parents all shared notes and realized how dangerous it was.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen I was twelve, I think I spent the summer hunting with my dad‚Äôs best friend.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat sounds neat.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt— no. No, it really wasn‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúAw,‚Äù Erin said.

‚ÄúDull, wet, buggy. I got to shoot the gun once in three months. I missed.‚Äù

‚ÄúAww.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was so excited to get back home and see my friends, get back to my routine. Then‚Ä¶ no home to go back to. The trip with my dad‚Äôs friend was just to buy time for my parents to get everything sorted out for me to go live with my aunt.‚Äù

Rain was caught between a yawn and something that might have actually reflected his feelings, and decided to yawn.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù Erin said.

Rain shrugged.

‚ÄúHow‚Äôd you manage last night?‚Äù

She was asking about the dream, as much as she could with Bryce listening in.

‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt too bad. Pretty usual. I‚Äôm tired.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah. You gonna grab a nap later?‚Äù

‚ÄúI might. Have to get through school first, and I‚Äôm already feeling like I‚Äôll doze because I have a full belly. I woke up to three girls around my age cooking breakfast.‚Äù

‚ÄúBarefoot in the kitchen? Not going to school?‚Äù

‚ÄúPretty much,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúSpending time with you, seeing how you stack up?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm the one that‚Äôs supposed to be studying or showing interest in them,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúCreepy as—‚Äù Erin paused to put her hands over Bryce‚Äôs ears, ‚Äú—shit.‚Äù

Bryce pushed her hands away, nearly hitting her with the stick he held. He was drawing a line in the dirt road as he walked, with an apparent system in mind about how he did it.

‚ÄúCreepier when one of them‚Äôs my cousin. I‚Äôm pretty sure she‚Äôs my actual cousin, too. It‚Äôs hard to keep track.‚Äù

‚ÄúAllie?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not so bad. She played the guitar at one of the campfires a bit ago, she was good, and she‚Äôs nice, she was nice to Bryce when she was helping out the teachers during a nature hike, even though she hates me.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs my cousin, Erin.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just saying, if you‚Äôre going to have cross-eyed underbite babies, you could do worse.‚Äù

‚ÄúUgh.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs better to stick to the ones you aren‚Äôt related to,‚Äù Erin said.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to stick to anyone,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not interested.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey can apply a lot of pressure. You might end up having to choose one of them.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt even know the names of the other two girls.‚Äù

‚ÄúSounds like another point in Allie‚Äôs favor, then.‚Äù

‚ÄúStop. Please. Have mercy.‚Äù

Erin stretched, fingers knit together, hands turned outward and up over her head. The black band of her bra jumped into Rain‚Äôs attention and shook him the same way a wildcat leaping in his direction might. What kept his attention was her profile: the way the sun outlined her face, throat, chest. He looked away, his heart now thudding.

She was so beautiful he couldn‚Äôt believe they were talking together. Her and him? What the hell had he been saying before about spending a summer sitting in a hole? What was wrong with him?

She sighed heavily as she stopped stretching.

‚ÄúMy family‚Äôs been making those noises,‚Äù she said.

Rain glanced at her. For someone who had been joking a moment ago, Erin looked so sad.

‚ÄúHow bad?‚Äù he asked. He swallowed hard.

‚ÄúThese days? Bad. It‚Äôs all they think about. Every conversation, if it runs for more than a minute or two, turns to how pretty I am, and if I have any suitors.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre talking about the marriage thing?‚Äù Bryce asked.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúOur parents talk about it a lot,‚Äù Bryce said. ‚ÄúWith Erin, I mean. I‚Äôm too young to get married.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo are Rain and I,‚Äù Erin said.

‚ÄúRain?‚Äù

‚ÄúRain‚Äôs getting bugged too,‚Äù Erin said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm getting hints. Girls showing up with chaperones, when they really don‚Äôt want to be there, but it‚Äôs subtle. Nobody really talks about it,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúLucky you,‚Äù Erin said.

‚ÄúAre you managing okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been going over to the junkyard to shoot at bottles. That helps,‚Äù Erin said. She had a serious look on her face. ‚ÄúMight be good to have the practice if you ever need help.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to get you involved.‚Äù
