‚ÄúGetting caught up in your thing would be a relief,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not so sure it would,‚Äù he said. He glanced at Bryce, to see if the boy was listening.

Nope, drawing wiggly lines in the dirt with his stick.

They were close to the church. There was no parking lot, so the cars and trucks were parked haphazardly. Some were moving at a crawl as they tried to navigate the parked vehicles and the people who were gathering.

Rain glanced at Jay‚Äôs truck as they found a path between cars to reach the church. Jay was here, then. Rain was left to wonder whether the Barr sisters had hopped out and headed on their way to school, or if they were attending the morning service, now.

Erin drew looks. She stood out, and not just because she wasn‚Äôt a usual for the morning service. It was in moments like this that Rain knew he wasn‚Äôt letting feelings color his views on her. He could see the way people acted around her, the way they looked at her.

He was spooked, seeing it. He knew who these people were, he‚Äôd grown up with them, and he knew how they functioned. On a level, he was one of them.

Erin took Bryce to one of the moms of one of Bryce‚Äôs friends. They exchanged words, and the mom scooted over, having Bryce sit next to her.

Rain was acutely aware of the looks he got too. The opposite of the ones Erin got, really.

Erin joined Rain at the door. People were still filing in.

At the front of the church, a shirtless man climbed up onto the stage and walked back to the sanctuary, where the altar was. The light shone through the stained glass window behind him. He was skinny, long-haired, and tattooed.

‚ÄúYo, faithful,‚Äù he said, leaning over the altar.

There was a murmur of responses from the congregation.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been watching, and I‚Äôve been thinking. You guys have been asking me when I‚Äôd speak again, and I think it‚Äôs time I say a few things.‚Äù

There was a louder murmur, with a few hoots and whistles from certain locations.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve had some hard days,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúLess jobs, the strikes, the talk of war, it‚Äôs getting colder out, and I think that reminds us all of winter. Last winter sucked.‚Äù

There were more murmured responses.

‚ÄúIt was cold, there wasn‚Äôt enough shelter, there wasn‚Äôt enough food. Not everyone made it. We did better than some, but we lost six. We remember them. Jack, Josh, Georgia, Kiara, Christian and Rhys. We remember them, and we remember the cold, hunger, and sickness that took them from us.‚Äù

The responses were more animated.

‚ÄúMay they be with the Lord.‚Äù

It demanded a response. More of a response than the last.

‚ÄúWe remember the bad days, we remember the end. While I was doing that watching, listening, and thinking, I could tell. People are scared.‚Äù

His tanned face was expressive as he emphasized words like ‚Äòend‚Äô and ‚Äòscared‚Äô, lines crinkling in around his eyes, betraying him as thirty-something. He gripped the podium as he talked.

‚ÄúAll through the city, through the many worlds, people are scared shitless. Bad days are coming. Everyone knows it. You know it, am I right?‚Äù

There was a more vocal response.

‚ÄúYeah, you know it,‚Äù he said, his chin rising a bit. ‚ÄúYou fucking know it. Sorry parents, you can cover your kids‚Äô ears if you‚Äôre shy, but this is how I talk. Honest. I‚Äôm gonna be honest with you.‚Äù

Rain looked at Bryce and the woman he sat with. She wasn‚Äôt covering Bryce‚Äôs ears.

He looked at Erin, and saw how tense she was.

The speaker continued, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre scared and you‚Äôre scared with good reason. It‚Äôs going to get messy. People are going to die. People are going to deal with worse than death, because that‚Äôs where we‚Äôre at. That‚Äôs how it is in the worlds we dwell in. It‚Äôs inevitable.‚Äù

He remained where he was, lean muscular arms bristling with sun-bleached hair as he gripped the altar, letting that hang there.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre gonna be okay,‚Äù he said, his eyes narrowing. ‚ÄúI memorized a passage. This king Sihon would not allow Israel to pass through his territory. Sihon gathered all his people together and went out against Israel in the wilderness, and he came to Jahaz and fought against Israel. Then Israel defeated him with the edge of the sword, and took possession of his land.‚Äù

He pulled his hand away from the edge of the altar and struck it with his hand.

‚ÄúYou know what that says to me? It says you get in our way, you pick a fight with us? You‚Äôd best be prepared for the edge of our fucking swords. You‚Äôd best be prepared for us to take possession of your land. Do not get in our way, am I right!?‚Äù

There was a vocal response.

He raised his voice to be heard as he preached, ‚ÄúCover your kids ears if you‚Äôre raising pussies, parents, but I‚Äôm going to say things that gotta be said, and if your kids haven‚Äôt heard this yet, you‚Äôre doing something wrong. This is the credo we live by. There are fuckers and there are the fucked, and we are fuckers of the highest order!‚Äù

Cheers. Bryce reacted, joining in. Erin started to move, to enter the church, and Rain stopped her. He glanced around to make sure nobody had seen.

‚ÄúWe are right and we are righteous!‚Äù

Cheers.

‚ÄúWe saw the end, we preached the end, and we survived the end!‚Äù

Some people stood from the pews, which forced others to stand if they wanted to see.

‚ÄúThey can shake and sweat and worry about winter and war, but we‚Äôre going to fucking thrive!‚Äù

Bryce stood on the pew, his high voice joining the crowd‚Äôs. He probably didn‚Äôt even understand.

Erin didn‚Äôt repeat her initial impulse of trying to go in, pulling her little brother away. Rain let his hand drop.

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt get cold, we set our enemies on fire!‚Äù

Erin leaned close to Rain to be heard over the roars. ‚ÄúCan we go?‚Äù

He nodded.

‚ÄúIf we get hungry, we raid, we pillage, and we‚Äôll eat them alive!‚Äù

Cheers. The sound of the mob made Rain think of the mall, of Snag‚Äôs dream.

‚ÄúNone of that pussy skipping of the impolite parts. We go Old Testament on the asses of our enemies! Slaves, war, and disaster! We‚Äôll go full Revelations with a rod of iron, and dash nations to pieces! Anyone who‚Äôs read that far knows, the end ain‚Äôt gonna be pretty, it ain‚Äôt going to be kind!‚Äù

Rain turned to go. He was aware that people were casting glances his way, that they were seeing him leave. It would be remarked on.

But he‚Äôd heard variations of this ‚Äòsermon‚Äô for all of his life. If pushed, he could probably write one.

For now, his focus was on Erin, as he saw how deeply unhappy she was, leaving her brother behind. He caught up with her, walked at her side.

She saw him looking at her, and said, ‚ÄúHis behavior gets worse after they make him go to church.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not surprised,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt make sense. It‚Äôs idiocy.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not about sense. It‚Äôs about feeling like they have power.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey have it.‚Äù

‚ÄúSome.‚Äù

She flinched at that, then looked over her shoulder. She slowed.

‚ÄúI could go in there, drag him away. But they‚Äôd get upset with me, and it‚Äôs just‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúYou have to pick your battles,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt get to pick any,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWhen do I get to pick a battle and get one I can win?‚Äù

He didn‚Äôt have an answer for her. The question echoed something he‚Äôd felt for some time.

He clenched his fist, feeling the frustration and anger boil up.

In the distance, in the background, he could hear the preacher raising his voice.

‚ÄúThis is the end and the ending has always belonged to us!‚Äù The acoustics of the church magnified the voice.

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs go,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúWe are the Fallen!‚Äù

The church shook with the furor of the crowd and Rain shook in what felt like equal measure, as he saw the hurt on his friend‚Äôs face and clenched his fists with a force that should have seen blood seeping between them, as it had in the room he‚Äôd dreamed of.

‚äô

‚ÄúThirty-five, forty people?‚Äù

‚ÄúAs a rough estimate,‚Äù Snag said. ‚ÄúBut you‚Äôre not a soldier or a team player, from what I heard.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúBeast of Burden recommended you as more of an assassin. Thirty five to sixty individuals with powers. Plus armed henchmen, drones, minions. We go to war, we do it with the sanction and assistance of the major names, and we intend to leave no room for any result except the one we need.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou want them wiped out?‚Äù

‚ÄúBroken, scattered to the wind, if need be. But this one‚Ä¶‚Äù

The distorted image projected on the wall of the headquarters shifted. Snag pushed a piece of paper across the table.

‚ÄúSeventeen years old, by our best guess. We don‚Äôt know his name, but we have an idea about his powers. Breaking things, primarily. Mover ability. Tinker ability. Emotion power. The last three are weak.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre asking me to kill someone young.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat hasn‚Äôt been a problem for you before.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhatever happens in the chaos, whether they‚Äôre scattered, broken, arrested, killed, the result we want you to ensure is that this one doesn‚Äôt walk away.‚Äù

‚ÄúMakes sense.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe could have reached out to someone else. We reached out to you. You should know why.‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause you want this kid to suffer.‚Äù

A rustling noise, muted.

It was Love Lost who handed the thin slip of paper over, her claws glinting.

The man at the table investigated the check.

‚ÄúYou really want this kid to suffer.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe want him to face a fate worse than death,‚Äù Snag said. ‚ÄúBut we can‚Äôt have that and have him dead at the same time, and we need him dead. If he suffers as much as possible along the way to that conclusion, we‚Äôll be satisfied.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre paying, we can satisfy.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe check will clear.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen you‚Äôll get that satisfaction you‚Äôre after.‚Äù

The conversation paused as something grabbed their attention.

‚ÄúWhat in the fuck did you do to them?‚Äù Chris asked.

‚ÄúShut up, Chris,‚Äù Sveta said. She gave Rain a worried look, and Rain flinched away from the compassion.

‚ÄúVictoria‚Äôs in a fight,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúI hope she‚Äôs okay.‚Äù

Rain pushed his hands through his hair, backing up.

‚ÄúI hope we‚Äôre okay,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúThis is a bit much to deal with just us.‚Äù

It‚Äôs not to deal with you, Rain thought.

He could see the way Sveta was looking at him. Putting pieces together.

He couldn‚Äôt blame her. He was just now realizing what he was up against. For a year, he‚Äôd seen them at night. He‚Äôd seen them talk, getting everything in order.

For this. To destroy him.

Even hiding among the Fallen wouldn‚Äôt protect him. He‚Äôd clung to that reassurance and now it was gone.

He turned to go, grabbed his bag.

‚ÄúRain,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúI gotta go,‚Äù Rain said. He collected more things. The key he‚Äôd been given. ‚ÄúYou look after Victoria. Tell her thanks.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt panic,‚Äù Tristan said.

How was he not supposed to panic?

‚ÄúThanks for everything, Tristan,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be in touch, but I gotta go. I can‚Äôt—‚Äù

He couldn‚Äôt. He wasn‚Äôt sure what to do. There was no answer. He had three people after him and they were stronger, more capable. He couldn‚Äôt do anything. He couldn‚Äôt breathe.

Choking on the sentence he hadn‚Äôt finished, he hauled the door open, stepped out to the fire escape, and made his way down at a run, trusting his power to catch him if needed.

He ran until he couldn‚Äôt run anymore. He walked, feeling the full force of dread catch up with him as he slowed down. Then he ran again.

‚ÄúRain!‚Äù

Rain turned. With the panic firmly set in, his first instinct was fear. Even at a familiar voice.

Tristan. Tristan had run after him, and the guy barely looked winded.

‚ÄúThere you are,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúOof. I turned down the wrong street back there.‚Äù

Rain was silent, except for his hard breaths. He felt like he was going to throw up.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt run. Don‚Äôt panic. Trust me, shitty things happen when you panic.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm dead,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a dead man walking. Holy shit. They‚Äôre going to torture me to death.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got to tell people, Rain. You‚Äôve got to tell Victoria, you‚Äôve got to tell Sveta. Kenzie. Chris. Even Ashley— she won‚Äôt blink either way, but you should tell her.‚Äù

Rain shook his head.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm surprised you didn‚Äôt already say,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt. I can barely admit it to myself.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat were you going to do if Snag or Love Lost mentioned the Fallen while negotiating?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt— wouldn‚Äôt it be easier?‚Äù

‚ÄúEasier? Yes. Better? No. It‚Äôs best if it comes from your mouth first, Rain. The others think this is all lined up against us. But it isn‚Äôt. We‚Äôre just liable to get hit with the collateral damage.‚Äù

Rain wasn‚Äôt sure what to say or do. He shook his head.

‚ÄúNo? No what?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou tell them.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to tell them. I‚Äôve been in situations like this before, trying to be an ally, ending up only hurting. Talk to them. Tell them. Write them a letter if you need to put the words in order. I‚Äôll back you and argue on your behalf.‚Äù

‚ÄúI heard that the Fallen attacked Victoria‚Äôs hometown. What if they hurt someone she cared about? What if she says she‚Äôll only help the team if I‚Äôm not on it?‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you think she would? I‚Äôm not so sure.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat if?‚Äù Rain asked, stressing the question. ‚ÄúThey attacked people who were evacuating. There were groups that kidnapped people on the absolute worst day in history, raided them. What if it turns out they hurt people Kenzie cares about? Sveta— do you know what they say about people like Sveta? What I‚Äôve said about people like Sveta?‚Äù

‚ÄúI know what they‚Äôve said about people like me,‚Äù Tristan said, setting his jaw. ‚ÄúWhat you‚Äôve probably said about people like me.‚Äù

Rain flinched, breaking eye contact.

‚ÄúLook at me, say it, and I‚Äôll tell you it‚Äôs okay. Because you‚Äôre working on it. You‚Äôre better.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think you‚Äôre really underestimating how little I want to face that side of me, that said those things. Or how little progress I‚Äôve made from being a sack of shit.‚Äù

‚ÄúLook me in the eye,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúSay something like, ‚Äòhey Tristan, I used to be the kind of guy who‚Äôd call you a faggot or look down on you because you really like the dick.'‚Äù

‚ÄúC‚Äômon, man,‚Äù Rain said, cringing.

‚ÄúThen you say you‚Äôre sorry, and I say it‚Äôs not a problem, I figured as much, and I reaffirm that you‚Äôre a friend. Really easy script. Then you say it to Sveta. We‚Äôve talked about so much shit, we‚Äôve worked through so much. You have to know we can be cool with this. All of us.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI get it. Fuck. But—‚Äù

He was interrupted as Tristan‚Äôs watch started beeping.

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚Äú—But I don‚Äôt want you to be cool with it. I‚Äôm not cool with this,‚Äù Rain finished.

‚ÄúI gotta change.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúLook after Rain for me, Byron,‚Äù Tristan said, then blurred.

Byron wore a long-sleeved, slate-blue shirt with a snake on the front, and jeans.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to go,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúWhat are you going to do?‚Äù Byron asked.

‚ÄúHide. Figure things out. Think.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Byron said. ‚ÄúI think all three of those things sound pretty reasonable.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan you tell the others? Fill them in?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think if Tristan is saying no, I should say no too. Especially when I‚Äôm not part of the group.‚Äù

Rain sighed.

‚ÄúGo. Hide. Think. Spend time with that ridiculously awesome friend of yours,‚Äù Byron said.

Rain allowed himself a small smile.

‚ÄúMaybe call Mrs. Yamada.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe.‚Äù

‚ÄúSeems like a big enough emergency to give her a call.‚Äù

Rain nodded. It helped, knowing he could do that.

It helped, hearing Byron calmly lay things out, agree that it was right to get away and get safe. Tristan understood a lot of the other stuff, the fighting, the struggle, the— even trying to come back from being a scumbag. But Byron understood other things.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù he said, without even really realizing he‚Äôd intended to say it.

‚ÄúYou have allies,‚Äù Byron said. ‚ÄúFriends. Me included.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey have thirty-five to sixty people with powers, a hired assassin, and a grudge.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd we have a bit of time. We‚Äôll use it.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe?‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck off,‚Äù Byron said, without smiling or even sounding like he was amused or annoyed. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a friend. Of course I‚Äôm in this.‚Äù

Rain swallowed hard.

‚ÄúToday was valuable. The team has a sense of what they‚Äôre up against. Mostly.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou think I should tell them,‚Äù Rain said.

Byron shrugged. He was Tristan‚Äôs inverse, in that he wasn‚Äôt one to push, even when he had strong feelings one way or the other.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to hide out at the compound for a day or two. I, uh, I‚Äôll think, and maybe I‚Äôll explain when it‚Äôs time to come back. When there‚Äôs a clearer picture of what‚Äôs happening. Make sure they don‚Äôt do anything in the meantime?‚Äù

‚ÄúSure. Tristan heard too, and I think he‚Äôd agree.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre going to hide, you should go before they wrap up that meeting and decide to catch a train heading in the same direction you‚Äôre going.‚Äù

Rain nodded, swallowing hard again.

He turned to go. Not running, this time, but walking as fast as he could.

To seek sanctuary amid monsters.

Shade — 4.4

I was being watched.

I was being watched at a time when Rain was gone, hiding, when Tattletale was in play. We had enemies, I‚Äôd drawn attention. These things, though, weren‚Äôt at the forefront of my attention. It said a lot that they weren‚Äôt.

The slash on Moose‚Äôs face lingered in my mind‚Äôs eye, when I wasn‚Äôt careful about where that eye was turned.

The train was noisy as it rolled along the tracks. With the longer train journeys, I was primed to expect that the urban would give way to the rural or the buildings on either side would stop. It didn‚Äôt. Like a car driving down the highway at night, the streetlights reaching into the vehicle interior and then dropping away, the sun‚Äôs light did much the same when it reached in at a low angle, extending between buildings to light up the dark train car.

It was just late enough in the morning that most students had made their way to school, but the students with classes in the afternoon block that had stopped in to check in or change were now leaving the schools. They were heading off to work, to do light construction work, for academic clubs, study halls and to join the patrol block, and many were dressed accordingly. They looked so young.

The train car was packed, and I was glad I‚Äôd managed to get a seat, even though it was one of the narrow, tiny ones by the door that flipped up to be flush with the wall, when a wheelchair or baby carriage needed the room.

I‚Äôd first noticed the person watching me because her face had a lot of freckles, and out of the corner of my eye, I‚Äôd thought she was someone else. On closer look, though, I could see that her hair was jaw length and straighter, her facial structure was different, and she was wearing the clothes of a student athlete, with bare shoulders and arms, gym shorts, and a towel around her neck.

I might have dismissed her then, but she‚Äôd been looking at me, looking away when I glanced her way. I found myself looking again a few moments later, because one look wasn‚Äôt enough to dismiss the unease I felt in response to a freckle-covered face looming in my peripheral vision, peering past the crowd. The same thing happened the second time I looked at her. I caught her staring, and she looked away.

There had been a time that I would have automatically assumed it was positive. I was recognizable, I‚Äôd been a hometown celebrity in a town with a fair number of prominent people, and that had led to me getting recognized by at least one person each time I went out. I‚Äôd reveled in it.

Now? Traitorous instincts made that the second or even the third rank option in a list. The first thought in my head on realizing I was being stared at was to go straight to the hospital room, to people staring at wretched me in a vain effort to try to comprehend what they were looking at. They wondered how I even functioned, how I worked, tried to understand the configuration. When I moved automatically, the movements caught the eye.

Even with the most polite and iron-willed of them, they struggled to find which eye or eyes they should look at to make and maintain eye contact, and in the search for that common, natural thing, they ended up staring at the rest of me.

At the rest of the wretch, the sideshow freak, the monster.

How had Byron put it, at the meeting with Foresight? Tristan was nourished by the hardheaded struggle. Byron was recharged by periods of rest. It gave Tristan a natural advantage in their endless struggle over a single body.

I was closer to Byron in that. I was recharged by attention, by adulation, encouragement, worship. It was a natural progression of the fact that I‚Äôd been built to be a hero, because I could put on a costume and do great things and get that attention and encouragement.

Had I done things in a different way, it could have even been constructive and healthy. But I‚Äôd been a stupid kid. Arrogant. A little worship was good. I‚Äôd worshiped Dean. He‚Äôd worshiped me. On a level, I‚Äôd reached for the wrong things in places, prioritized certain things over others in how I handled the adulation and the public. There were a lot of things I wished I‚Äôd done differently.

That wasn‚Äôt even the biggest part of why, much like Byron, I couldn‚Äôt go to my most natural ways of finding recharge. Like how mental illness obscured the ability of the person in question to even see the problem at hand, my capacity to recover was distorted and damaged. Tainted.

Tristan had remarked on it too, now that I thought about it. Needing people. He wanted to party, to abandon restraint. I wanted‚Ä¶ I supposed I wanted not to illogically, automatically, inevitably think of the wretched thing that had occupied that hospital room, anytime someone paid particular attention to me.

I wanted to not feel a deep sadness sinking in when I caught someone staring.

In the places my head went, the wretch loomed in first place, the hero celebrity in second. The third place possibility was that this girl looking at me was something nefarious, and that the young, freckle-faced athlete was an agent of Tattletale or a hire from Cedar Point. Not impossible, but not likely.

Then the fourth place possibility, that she thought I was attractive, not impossible. The fifth place possibility that I had a piece of my breakfast stuck to my cheek or something in my hair. The sixth place possibility, that she was staring off into space and I was somehow always in the way‚Ä¶

My thoughts were mired in something so minor, my heart ached indistinctly, and I was just making myself anxious and upset.

I checked my phone. I could focus on the job. The mission at hand.

You have 49 unread emails.

It was rare for me to have more than three.

(Unread) Kenzie Martin (38 minutes ago)

[Attachment: costumedoodlewoo_1.i — Touch to open in a new window]

[You have 39 more unread emails. Touch to continue reading]

If they‚Äôd been texts I would have been alerted with each one, but I hadn‚Äôt, and they‚Äôd accumulated. I was prepared to continue browsing, wrapping my head around reading through the emails in reverse order, but the train slowed, brakes squealing.

The signs above the exits changed. Car 3: Blackrock Station.

Students departed, then more entered, but the end result was that things were far less crowded. I got a look at the girl who was staring at me, and she glanced away, reflexively.

As people exited, seats here and there were freed up. There was a bit of a shuffle as people hurried to claim seats. A sixteen-ish year old boy claimed the vacated seat next to me.

In that same moment, though, Ashley moved between train cars, entering mine, spotted me, and approached. She wore sunglasses and the black dress she‚Äôd picked up at Cedar Point. Strapless, with sheer black fabric enveloping the shoulders and arms, decorated with a lace-like pattern of feathers. The sleeves disappeared into fingerless black gloves. Her little black shoes looked like dancer‚Äôs shoes, which fit with the dress she wore.

I raised my hand in a little wave.

‚ÄúI thought you‚Äôd be around,‚Äù she said, lifting her sunglasses.

‚ÄúI messaged you when I boarded,‚Äù I said, touching my phone. I saw her expression change. ‚ÄúAnd you don‚Äôt like phones.‚Äù

The seat I was sitting in was positioned such that the backs of the actual booth seats were to me. Ashley leaned against the back of one of the other seats, facing me, and the boy just beside me lifted his bag from his lap and used the room she‚Äôd given him to vacate the seat.

‚ÄúDo you want my seat?‚Äù I asked him.

He glanced back, looked at me, looked at Ashley, then shook his head. He nearly lost his balance as the train resumed moving.

Ashley took the seat, pulling it down from the side of the train and then sitting on it, crossing one knee over the other and placing her hands on top. Posed, in a very deliberate, conscious way. Even the angle of her head.

I looked past her to the freckled observer, who again looked away. Was it my frame of mind, sitting with Ashley, that made it so the wretch wasn‚Äôt as close to the surface, the look not nearly as bothersome?

Or was I overthinking it? Was it that I‚Äôd seen the look enough times and seen her reaction enough times that it didn‚Äôt feel so heavy, pressing, or potentially hostile? Less about me and more about her, now.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs sensible,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôll go far.‚Äù

She might have thought I was looking at the boy who‚Äôd run.

‚ÄúDid you take off your sunglasses just to intimidate him into giving up his seat?‚Äù I asked.

She put her sunglasses back into place and gave me a small smile.

‚ÄúYou shouldn‚Äôt,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWhy not? If there was a chance I‚Äôd see him again, maybe I shouldn‚Äôt, but I won‚Äôt. The city is too big.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe little things ripple out. If you make a positive or negative impression, people mention them to others, those people mention them or carry them forward. You‚Äôre not just interacting with him. You‚Äôre interacting with everyone he‚Äôs potentially going to interact with in the future. To lesser degrees, sure, but I absolutely think it matters.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs he going to say? I didn‚Äôt do anything, and he willingly gave up his seat. Is he going to tell all of his friends and family that he saw a lady with scary eyes and he ran away like a stray with its tail between its legs?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think it matters,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI wanted to learn from you all. I‚Äôll have to take that sentiment and think on it—‚Äù

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù I said.

‚Äú—because you‚Äôve only given me sentiment. Not one good argument yet.‚Äù

I turned my head her way, frowning. She smiled a little more.

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs say you entered the scene, you‚Äôve gathered all your info, you have a nice costume, you‚Äôve trained, you‚Äôre badass,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúMm,‚Äù she made a sound.

‚ÄúYou have your first big job. You make a splash, there‚Äôs some media attention, video, something like that. It appears on TV briefly, but people talk online. They‚Äôre the ones who create your online profile and fill in your info, they apply the labels, describe things, set the tone. What if the guy you scared off ends up being one of them, and he ends up sitting at his keyboard, remembering you as he decides what to write?‚Äù

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt do a thing to him.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut did he leave with a good impression of you?‚Äù

She shrugged.

‚ÄúWhat happens if this guy finds himself in that situation, ready to make a call about you or share his thoughts, and he describes his horrible encounter with you on the train, how you intimidated him and said odious things?‚Äù

‚ÄúI said nothing.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd he‚Äôs a teenager, he‚Äôs a guy, you‚Äôre a girl, he‚Äôll think about this scene again, he might be bothered, and he‚Äôll want to resolve that feeling. Maybe he lies and badmouths you online.‚Äù

Ashley looked like she was the very definition of unimpressed.

I shrugged.

‚ÄúI hate the internet,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúDespise it. When I become a villain, I‚Äôll move out to a border world where the internet isn‚Äôt established and I‚Äôll take over. I‚Äôll rule as a queen, without any need to concern myself with teenagers who could lie about me without fear of reprisal.‚Äù

‚ÄúSounds like a plan,‚Äù I said. It was my turn to shoot her a small smile.

‚ÄúYes, yes,‚Äù she said. She brought her head back, leaning it against the wall behind her. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been brought low, relying on sentiment over fact. How the tables have turned.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat wasn‚Äôt actually what I was thinking,‚Äù I said.

I didn‚Äôt get a chance to elaborate. The girl with freckles approached. She looked spooked, arms close to her body as she held a notebook, but the ‚Äòspook‚Äô was aimed more at me.

Too petite to be the person I‚Äôd worried I‚Äôd seen out of the corner of my eye, earlier. Years younger — fourteen, if I had to guess. Timid, yes, fidgety, that was similar, but in other ways, she held herself differently. This girl dressed different, sporty and confident.

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúAre you— you‚Äôre Victoria Dallon.‚Äù

‚ÄúI am.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm a fan. I‚Äôve been a fan for years.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs your name?‚Äù

‚ÄúPresley.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou know, Presley, I was just thinking about how I missed the days of living in Brockton Bay, when I‚Äôd get to make connections with people. I missed that, and you might have just made my day.‚Äù

Her smile was tentative at first and then solidified into something more confident.

‚ÄúI lived in Brockton Bay for a year when I was nine. My family was going through stuff. That doesn‚Äôt really matter but it‚Äôs why I was there, and I saw this picture of you and I loved it. I didn‚Äôt even know you were a real person or what your name was until a month later. I got a poster of the same picture for my birthday.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhich poster?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, it had a yellow background, and you were flying, and you had your arms out and behind you, like—‚Äù

She took a bit of a pose, chest pushed up and out, arms back with fists clenched near her butt. Well, one fist. She held the notebook, still.

‚ÄúI know the one,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThat was a magazine cover first, I think.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have the magazine too. And a bunch of other things. Even after I moved to Portland I did everything I could to collect each thing that came out. But the poster was important to me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm really glad,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúIt was one of the first things I put on my wall every time we settled into a new place. Later, whenever I was feeling lost I‚Äôd look at it. I got into sports because I read you were an athlete before you were a hero, except it‚Äôs soccer, not basketball, because I‚Äôm too short.‚Äù

She looked disappointed as she said it.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre in the athletics block,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt let just anyone in. I‚Äôd bet you‚Äôre better at soccer than I was at basketball.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she said, with an expression like that was impossible to fathom, even upsetting, eyes wide.

It seemed she needed me as an idol more than she needed me as a connection or someone she could relate to.

‚ÄúI got a lot of extra flack and attention from the enemy team because I came from a family of heroes and a lot of people knew my name,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúMaybe that was why.‚Äù

Presley nodded very quickly. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs someone on my team who‚Äôs really good, she gets something like that. I really look up to her too.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you going to keep hugging that notebook or are you going to hand it over for her to sign?‚Äù Ashley asked.

Presley looked startled at that, afraid. She‚Äôd been working her way up to it, and the issue had been forced.

‚ÄúBe nice,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm being nice,‚Äù Ashley responded. ‚ÄúThe way this is going, this girl—‚Äù

‚ÄúHer name is Presley,‚Äù I interjected.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs going to finish telling you how awesome you are, she won‚Äôt work up the nerve, and she‚Äôll kick herself for not getting the autograph.‚Äù

I rolled my eyes slightly and turned to Presley. ‚ÄúDo you want me to?‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù she breathed the word more than she said it.

I took the notebook and I took the pen. It had been a little while since I‚Äôd done this.

‚ÄúWhen I looked at you in the poster I told myself that was everything I wanted to be, fearless and fair and strong and poised. Every time I entered a new part of my life or moved to a new place, I looked at it in different ways.‚Äù

I wrote my message on the inside cover, listening while the pen scratched.

‚ÄúWhen we had to evacuate because of Gold Morning, we had to leave everything behind.‚Äù

I looked up. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut we went back, after everything calmed down. We went back to the house and it was mostly intact, except for broken windows and water damage. We could only bring what we could fit in the car, but I made sure to bring that. I wanted it with me for whatever comes next.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can only encourage and inspire, and I‚Äôm really glad if I‚Äôve helped with that. The strength, the fairness, the poise, though, that comes from you. Everything you‚Äôve triumphed over, surviving the bad days, getting to here, then doing well enough to be part of the athletics block,‚Äù I said. I closed the book, the pen still between the pages. I passed it to her, and put my hands over hers as she took the book. I met her eyes. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs you. That‚Äôs your power. Pretty much what I wrote, but I wanted to say it too.‚Äù

As I moved my hands away from hers, she smiled and hugged the book.

A moment later, she turned to Ashley. She lowered her voice, ‚ÄúDo you have powers?‚Äù

Ashley nodded.

‚ÄúCan you?‚Äù Presley held out the notebook.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Ashley replied.

‚ÄúOkay, I‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù Presley said, too quickly, too defensive in how she pulled her book back, how she held it. She looked at me. ‚ÄúThank you so much.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre very welcome,‚Äù I said.

But as I said it, Presley was already retreating, fleeing back to her spot by the doors, amid all the other students who were standing in the seatless area that would have bikes and prams in it at different stages of the journey.

I could have pressed, even taken issue with how Ashley had handled that.

Instead, I gathered my thoughts. On a level, I did feel refreshed. It had been a really nice moment, the minor issue at the end souring it slightly, but nice all the same.

I was having to get used to having the nice moments be routinely touched with those sour notes.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt hold a pen,‚Äù Ashley murmured.

I looked at her.

She moved her hands from where they rested on her knee. She turned one over, moved a finger. It trembled throughout the small movement. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll have my appointment after we talk to Houndstooth, get tuned up. Until then, it hurts to move my hands and I don‚Äôt trust my power. That‚Äôs why.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou could have explained.‚Äù

She gave me a look.

‚ÄúYou could have,‚Äù I said.

The look was maintained. Even with the sunglasses she wore, the disdain was clear. ‚ÄúRipple effects, you said. I wouldn‚Äôt be revealing it to her alone. I‚Äôd be risking revealing it to everyone she meets from here on out.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe good things have a way of rippling out with more strength than the bad things do,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúSo you say,‚Äù Ashley said, ‚Äúwhile riding on a train through a city in the post-apocalypse. Just one of many shattered, damaged worlds.‚Äù

‚ÄúCute.‚Äù

The train slowed. Presley was at the door, joining the group that was ready to depart.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd like to tell her,‚Äù I said, my voice quiet. ‚ÄúEven if we called it an injury, so you weren‚Äôt revealing something vital.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou really care about this.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you?‚Äù

‚ÄúI care,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to lie and look weak while you lie to look better.‚Äù

I tensed.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre strong, yes,‚Äù she said, her voice barely audible. She took off her sunglasses. ‚ÄúPoised? I think it‚Äôs an act. An effective act, the kind that becomes reality after enough time. But not enough time has passed. Fair? We‚Äôll see. But fearless?‚Äù

She made the smallest of scoffing sounds. The train came to a stop.

I started to respond, but there was a hollow feeling in my mouth and throat, where the words were supposed to be. I closed my mouth, then said, just as quiet, ‚ÄúShe needs that lie.‚Äù

Ashley stared me down.

‚ÄúFrankly,‚Äù I said, still quiet, angry now, ‚Äúyou come across worse and smaller as a person when you say no to something that costs you nothing than you do by admitting you‚Äôre disabled.‚Äù

‚ÄúTemporarily disabled,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre wrong. I can‚Äôt think of anything worse than groveling before a child and telling her I‚Äôm weak when I‚Äôm the very opposite. I could kill everyone on this train if it came down to it. One after the other. By the time I made my way to the next train car, they would be ready for me, and it wouldn‚Äôt matter.‚Äù

I tensed as heads turned. They weren‚Äôt responding to the words. Only the emotion behind them.

Had I just provoked her into another rage on a relatively crowded train?

Would my next words? Would my silence? Would leaving? Staying?

‚ÄúShe doesn‚Äôt know that it‚Äôs only temporary,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúShe just thinks there‚Äôs something wrong. With you or with her.‚Äù

‚ÄúLet her,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúDo what you want, but don‚Äôt make me regret telling you anything.‚Äù

I looked over to the side. The people had departed the train, Presley included, and the ones boarding had mostly filed in.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs too late anyway,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúAnother face we‚Äôll never see again, that probably won‚Äôt make any ripples.‚Äù

I stood from my seat. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be back.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhatever.‚Äù

Glancing back, making sure she wasn‚Äôt about to go on a rampage as she had threatened, I ducked and pushed past the crowd, hurrying to the door. Tristan touched my shoulder as I passed him.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll be right back. Can you watch my bag?‚Äù I said, turning to face him and walking backward as I said it. I pointed in Ashley‚Äôs direction and mouthed ‚Äòand Ashley‚Äô.

He gave me a short nod.

The doors closed behind me as I stepped onto the train platform. I took to the air.

Why was this so important to me?

With a bird‚Äôs eye view, I could search the crowd, looking for the right hair color, the right height, the clothes, freckle-covered shoulders, chin-length hair.

Was this ego?

Was I just seeking out perverse, self-centered worship, after going without so long? Tantalus finally getting a drink of water after centuries without? A parasitic, sad wretch of a vampire like in those bad Maggie Holt movies, finally with a willing victim?

I‚Äôd found her and I hesitated.

But the train was getting away from me. I had to act.

Instinct, rather than action. I wasn‚Äôt thinking things through. I wasn‚Äôt acting according to the mission I‚Äôd planned and set out, was I?

I landed, forward momentum becoming a brisk walk, then a slower one. I saw the surprise on her face. People nearby were startled.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm in a rush. I don‚Äôt suppose I could get your email?‚Äù

She looked around, possibly looking for Ashley, or at the crowd.

She still held her notebook, and she opened it, scribbling something down. She tore off the corner of the page, then handed it to me.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll send you something,‚Äù I said.

She nodded, wordless.

I left the ground much as I‚Äôd landed. The train was already pulling away. I flew after it.

Had I made a mistake, leaving Ashley, when she was riled up? I had no idea how well she and Tristan got along. Were my perspectives straight?

It wasn‚Äôt even nine o‚Äôclock in the morning, and I was mired in a week‚Äôs worth of doubts and second-guesses. That wasn‚Äôt me. It wasn‚Äôt supposed to be.

I checked my phone as I flew.

You have 52 unread emails.

I‚Äôd had thirty nine or forty, after browsing the initial selection.

I was here for a reason. Kenzie was one. Ashley another. Tristan, Chris, even Sveta‚Ä¶ and Rain in particular. Rain who was taking a day off from everything.

They needed help. That was the job, the mission. Given to me by someone I cared about, involving another someone I cared about and the team and place in the world she so desperately wanted.

I could do that. But I didn‚Äôt want to do it at the expense of people like Presley.

The feelings and the ideas took on a different light when I framed things that way.

It played into how I carried myself, after I touched down on the back of the train, on the same kind of little platform at the rear that Rain had used to jump off.

It played into how I walked, how I organized my thoughts.

I could remember going home after my first official arrest. Bad guy beaten, caught, delivered to authorities. Everything official, with my mom attending. I‚Äôd walked in the door, and my mother had told my dad that I‚Äôd had two firsts. My first arrest, my first war wound— a cut to my forehead, already stitched up. She‚Äôd used her fingers to move my hair, to show my dad.

He‚Äôd looked very tired as he bent down, kissed the top of my head.

He‚Äôd offered me cookies and milk and I‚Äôd rolled my eyes, even though I‚Äôd really wanted the cookies.

I wasn‚Äôt sure at all about why or if the cookies played into things, but I did remember how I‚Äôd stood straighter, how I‚Äôd felt taller, more focused.

That was the feeling I wanted to capture, as I walked down the train car, entered the next, walked down that train car, and then entered the car I‚Äôd been in before going after my fan.

Tristan was in my seat, talking to Ashley. Ashley was tense. She didn‚Äôt look as if she‚Äôd calmed down in my absence.

Tristan wore a black jacket over a red t-shirt in a material that looked like it was meant to have sweat wick off of it. He‚Äôd painted his hair again and the color reached to the roots.

He moved over from the seat as I approached, leaving the one between him and Ashley empty. Ashley didn‚Äôt move, her eyes hidden by the sunglasses she wore. A thin beam of light swept through the length of the train car. Not as pronounced an effect as it had been earlier, with the train slightly lower to the ground, the train at a different angle.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve come to believe you‚Äôre more deluded than the rest of us,‚Äù Ashley said, as I took the seat. ‚ÄúThinking any of that matters.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù I said. I fiddled with my phone, typing in the email.

‚ÄúDid you tell her?‚Äù she asked.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI got her email, and I flew after the train. Hi Tristan.‚Äù

‚ÄúFrom what I gather, you have a fan, and you and Ashley had a disagreement,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said, still typing. ‚ÄúAny word on Rain?‚Äù

‚ÄúScared as shit but safe.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIs he going to be okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo idea. But if they go after him, we‚Äôre not in a position to do anything. I‚Äôd like to ask Houndstooth for advice, see what resources we can tap.‚Äù

I nodded.

I paged through the phone, the email entered, and found myself at the home screen for the mail.

You have 55 unread emails.

I checked nobody was in earshot. There were people in the chairs just beside Tristan‚Äôs seat, but they had headphones on. I figured we were pretty safe.

‚ÄúKenzie might be melting down,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúOr something. I don‚Äôt know how to interpret this.‚Äù

I showed Ashley. I went to show Tristan, and he was already pulling his phone out of his pocket.

He showed me his.

26 unread emails

‚ÄúShe likes you more,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúI told her I don‚Äôt use my phone. She was bothered at first, but she accepted it,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúNow I‚Äôm glad.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat is this?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a part of me that‚Äôs weirdly glad for the stream-of-consciousness insight into who she is and how she thinks, even if this isn‚Äôt good, but‚Ä¶ this isn‚Äôt good. It‚Äôs not healthy.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt isn‚Äôt,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúBut it could be worse. If anything, it‚Äôs a good prelude or warm-up for our discussion with Houndstooth. We‚Äôll talk with him, we‚Äôll send Kenzie a message, if she hasn‚Äôt had her phone confiscated, and we‚Äôll see how things go from there.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre sure.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure of anything,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut we all have our weaknesses, and Kenzie‚Äôs wrestling with hers. We‚Äôll figure it out.‚Äù

I nodded. I took my seat between the two. ‚ÄúCan I ask you two a favor?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat favor?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúWhy not?‚Äù Ashley asked. ‚ÄúI made the mistake of going along with an errand with the two most stubborn people I know. I deserve whatever I‚Äôm subjected to.‚Äù

‚ÄúCould be we‚Äôre the two most stubborn members of the group,‚Äù I said. I found myself reaching for that part of me that stood taller, that focused on the mission and the role. ‚ÄúBut we‚Äôre the three most style-conscious people in this whole exercise. We might be missing Kenzie in that. Three of the four most style conscious.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt say Kenzie‚Äôs style-conscious,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs a conversation for another day. What‚Äôs this about style?‚Äù

‚ÄúI want to take a picture. Lean in close,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúPlease.‚Äù

Ashley gave me a look.

‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúAnd since you don‚Äôt have masks, you can use my hand, Ashley. Tristan, cover up a bit with your hand. Look photogenic.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve only had my photo taken twice,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúThey were basically mugshots.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid you look good for the mugshots?‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen look good for this. Come on. This could be your equivalent to a poster. She thought you were cool enough to ask for an autograph, let‚Äôs give her a good picture.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Ashley said.

The two leaned in close, my hand in front of Ashley‚Äôs eyes, fingers parted in the middle to reveal one of her eyes. Tristan used one hand, positioning himself so his hair wouldn‚Äôt be in the camera‚Äôs frame.

I winked and hit the button to take the picture.

‚ÄúNone of this matters,‚Äù Ashley said.

I applied a caption to the picture.

Thanks for coming and saying hi. Picture just for you— keep an eye out for us in the future.

I showed the others the picture and caption. I got an okay from both, and sent it.

I held the phone where everyone could see it. With the first excited response, half of Ashley‚Äôs tension seemed to dissipate. With the second and third, she smiled.

Doing this, helping, functioning in my role, I felt less like a vampire. Less like I was serving myself, because the feelings were set aside to where they were secondary.

It felt like a good warrior monk frame of mind for my discussion with Houndstooth.

‚äô

We had to walk a little ways to get to where Houndstooth waited. He was in costume, and his appearance at the station would have risked a disruption.

All through the short walk across Greenwich, there were signs of the protests and strikes. Crude posters had been put up, with slogans and rallies to the cause.

It was too early in the day for a real protest, though. Just groups on street corners, some scattered people making a mess and some cleaning up. Stasis.

Houndstooth waited on a hill overlooking the city sprawl. He looked as he had in Kenzie‚Äôs projected image. Anubis writ Western, with a shorter, blunter snout and a costume of mixed panels that straddled the line between being a bodysuit and being armor.

‚ÄúThank you for making the time,‚Äù Tristan said. He shook Houndstooth‚Äôs hand.

‚ÄúIt was my request,‚Äù Houndstooth said.

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù I said, as he shook my hand.

‚ÄúThank you for coming, Victoria.‚Äù

He turned to Ashley. She stood with her hands clasped behind her.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nice to meet you,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nice to meet you as well,‚Äù he said, taking the lack of a handshake in stride.

The conversation hung there.

‚ÄúThis is hard,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúWe appreciate you helping out with Cedar Point,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúWe can open by talking about that,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve visited?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúTwo of us. One of us more covert.‚Äù

His snout moved more in Ashley‚Äôs direction, then he nodded. ‚ÄúHow bad is it, once you‚Äôre there?‚Äù

I answered, ‚ÄúProtection racket in full swing. Villains moved in en masse. People moved away when they could. Those that couldn‚Äôt are paralyzed now, helping to maintain the very thin veneer of normalcy while paying what little they can to the villains in control. Prancer and Velvet are some of the most prominent drug distributors right now and they‚Äôre in charge, so it‚Äôs likely serving as a hub for that.‚Äù

‚ÄúSome very violent capes are active there,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúA few of them we have a tenuous relationship with seem to be gathering soldiers with an intent to go to war. It looks like that might include us, but we don‚Äôt know one hundred percent what they‚Äôre up to.‚Äù

‚ÄúAs expected, then,‚Äù Houndstooth said.

Ashley said, ‚ÄúThey have rooms to rent, but they cornered that market. They‚Äôre welcoming newcomers, but only capes, only ones who will help them out. The businesses are struggling or closed, and nobody outside of Cedar Point is moronic enough to buy in. Cancer at the roots, the tree will die.‚Äù

Houndstooth said, ‚ÄúI remember back on Bet, we had a system we used for the areas where the good guys couldn‚Äôt win, or where things were too bad to recover. It was mostly small towns. Evacuating, shutting off all power and water from the outside, closing down and blockading the roads, making living there as difficult as possible, perimeter blockades, regular raids, visits from big name capes. There was serious consideration given to giving Brockton Bay that H.O.S.V. designation.‚Äù

I had to assume his attention was on me as he said that last bit.

‚ÄúThey said no in the end,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs your feeling on that?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think I would have made peace with it if they‚Äôd said yes,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIt wouldn‚Äôt be what it is now.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a pretty mixed thing right now.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt is,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs a right or wrong answer. As it is, it has its positives, it‚Äôs meant a lot to some people that it recovered as much as it did, it was a huge part of us rebuilding after the end. But I‚Äôm not at peace with it either.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat happens to Cedar Point in the end, then?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe weaken their hold, we leave room for more established parties to settle in and act as a counterbalance, instead of things all going the wrong way. You mentioned Brockton Bay. We saw what happened when the scale tipped too far one way. Too many heroes out of the picture, myself included, not enough coming in.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf we uncover anything particularly bad, and we might have already found something bad, we‚Äôll strike at them as we make our big play,‚Äù Ashley said.

Tristan and I looked at her.

She added, ‚ÄúWith the help of other groups and forces.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe can be one of those other forces,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúKings of the Hill aren‚Äôt big or strong, but we‚Äôve got our territory and we‚Äôre helping to keep the peace. In exchange, we could use help when it comes to tackling some of the other problems. Ideally, it would be you three. Not‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúKenzie?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd prefer to say kids,‚Äù Houndstooth said.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to have to get around to talking about her,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt dodge the subject forever. I‚Äôll get irritated and walk away if you try.‚Äù

He folded his arms, walking over a little. The hill had several trees on it, and his armor panels glinted here and there as dappled light touched it.

‚ÄúYou said this was hard,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúDid she touch any of you before you came here?‚Äù Houndstooth asked.

‚ÄúShe went to school this morning. We came here,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúI suspected that would be the way it went. It‚Äôs why I wanted to meet when she was in school. Minimizes the chances.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy does it matter?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre bugged?‚Äù

‚ÄúTrackers, cameras, microphones, or—‚Äù he paused, and his mask meant that if he was making an expression or trying to convey something with the pause, it was more or less lost. ‚Äú—Sound cameras.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs a lot better than she was when you knew her,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs great,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúI really do want things to work out for her. It‚Äôs just hard. I need to protect myself, my old teammates. I want to protect you. I want people in general to be safe. All that aside, again, I do want positive outcomes for her.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúBut the Kenzie I know didn‚Äôt allow for that,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúSo I had to prepare for this meeting, trying to figure out what to say and how to frame things while not hurting anyone.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs been in therapy for a little while,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs improved by leaps and bounds from even the first time I met her. I really want to reinforce that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI hear you,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just worried you‚Äôre not going to listen, and if that‚Äôs the case, then it‚Äôs a bad replay of me, our Protectorate leader and our PRT liaison talking to her school. It‚Äôs a replay of us having a meeting with her new foster parents. It‚Äôs a repeat of us talking to the parents of a new friend she‚Äôs made.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat happened?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúWe explained, they heard us, but they didn‚Äôt listen. They didn‚Äôt take it to heart, because she is— was nine. She‚Äôs cute, she‚Äôs precocious, and she has a really skewed skillset where she‚Äôs really good at getting close to people and she‚Äôs really, tragically bad at staying there. Messes follow.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs moving in a more measured way as she relates to the people around her now,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs more easygoing. And so far, staying close? She‚Äôs doing okay. Fingers crossed.‚Äù

Houndstooth‚Äôs hand moved, thumb tapping against the side of his finger, and it looked like he was going to say something.

‚ÄúCapricorn, was it?‚Äù

‚ÄúOr Tristan.‚Äù

‚ÄúTristan. I hear you. I‚Äôm listening. She‚Äôs in therapy, she‚Äôs better. She‚Äôs made strides. If you had to give her a number, how much better is she? Throw a number at me. Eighty percent?‚Äù

‚ÄúNinety five,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúNinety,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúFive or ten percent of what I saw? Still pretty fucking bad. I‚Äôd like to give you some advice and double check some things. As the person who‚Äôs been there and crossed his fingers before.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not fair, you‚Äôre—‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúTristan,‚Äù I said, cutting him off.

I was focused on Houndstooth. I was pretty sure I‚Äôd beaten him by a hair in responding.

‚ÄúI asked you to have this chat as my side of our mutual agreement,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm asking you to let me convey this to you. A lot of it is pretty mild. Give me a chance to say my piece, and you decide what to do with the knowledge.‚Äù

I glanced at Tristan.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll shut up,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm here to listen,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúThen I‚Äôll say my piece.‚Äù

She had a piece to say? I hadn‚Äôt known this when she‚Äôd invited herself along as one of the group‚Äôs ‚Äòleaders‚Äô.

‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù I said, to Houndstooth.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll give you some of the same advice my bosses gave to us and the people who interacted with Kenzie. Minimize the homework she does. That includes work-homework. Cape homework, if you want to call it that.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúBecause she‚Äôs so eager to please she‚Äôll hurt herself in the process. She had an art project in fourth grade, it was supposed to be done over the course of a month, following the instructions from regular handouts the teacher gave. Eight or ten handouts, I think it was. She asked kids a grade older than her what they‚Äôd done for the same project, and she pulled two consecutive all-nighters to do it. Her foster parents didn‚Äôt even realize she was doing it, because it turns out a surveillance-countersurveillance tinker is really good at sneaking out to the garage and being quiet.‚Äù

‚ÄúSurveillance-countersurveillance,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúShe went that far because she wanted to wow her teacher and see the expressions on their face,‚Äù Houndstooth said.

‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt good,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúTheir reactions.‚Äù

‚ÄúShocked, almost horrified,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúAnd Kenzie was devastated to the point of being broken when it didn‚Äôt get the reaction she wanted it to. She was so stressed out over it in the days after that that she threw up in class, which— it didn‚Äôt win points with her classmates, and it led to her being transferred to another class. Devastating on both fronts, because she had classmates she liked and she loved her teacher.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow do you get ahead of that?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúWhat do you do to balance it?‚Äù

‚ÄúTreat it like a full-time job?‚Äù Houndstooth asked. ‚ÄúPreventative measures, like the ones I‚Äôm recommending. She‚Äôll go the extra mile unless you set up a roadblock to disallow that progress. So you have to stay ahead of that. She‚Äôs a headache in that.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe mentioned she has a slip for study hall that gets her out of homework. It sounds like they‚Äôre letting her use it,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúGreat. I‚Äôm glad that‚Äôs there. It goes beyond just school. She‚Äôs working on this job of yours at Cedar Point?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWhat limits did you set on that? On her schedule?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe needs to do her schoolwork, she doesn‚Äôt let it impact her grades or attendance. Standard rules of conduct for Wards, carried forward.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs one step, but it‚Äôs not enough. She‚Äôs ninety-five percent better? That five percent says she‚Äôs losing sleep, sitting in her bedroom or bunk in the dark, checking cameras and feeds or searching old footage. She‚Äôll work herself to the bone trying to uncover that gem that she can turn in to earn your affection.‚Äù

I looked at Tristan, then Ashley.

I looked at Houndstooth. ‚ÄúYou think this is likely? Even with her doing better?‚Äù

‚ÄúI would bet you real money. And I‚Äôd be thrilled to, because my team is in a bad spot for funding, and it‚Äôd help.‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúWe can narrow the window, set time restrictions.‚Äù

‚ÄúOr we have her keep the majority of the tinker stuff at our place,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúDo both,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôll be working on other projects, possibly surprise projects, very similar to her art project in intent and execution.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs working on some side projects,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThe eye camera. A teleporter.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou do realize she doesn‚Äôt build teleporters, right?‚Äù Houndstooth asked.

‚ÄúShe doesn‚Äôt lie,‚Äù Ashley said, stern. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt imply she does.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt implying,‚Äù Houndstooth said. His voice softened, ‚ÄúI framed that wrong. I think she can build Teleporters. But she doesn‚Äôt. For the same reason she doesn‚Äôt build guns, mechs, A.I., chemicals, bio-stuff. She can do that stuff, but she‚Äôll make half a percent of progress in the time it takes her to complete a whole project in her skillset. She‚Äôll spend hundreds of dollars in materials to get that half a percent.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd the way you describe this—‚Äù I started. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôll actually, genuinely try to complete the teleporter project, even at a glacial pace, at a massive cost to her well-being?‚Äù

‚ÄúExactly,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúAt least as far as I understand it. She‚Äôll try to finish the project, she‚Äôll believe it and make others believe she can do it, but I‚Äôd bet she‚Äôd self-destruct before getting a fifth of the way.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor all this talk of self-destruction and sacrificing health and sleep, she seems to be doing okay,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúFreaked out after her call with you, weirdness, but‚Ä¶ nothing that can‚Äôt be handled, I don‚Äôt think.‚Äù

‚ÄúAfter the art project thing? When she threw up in class? Didn‚Äôt cry before, didn‚Äôt cry after. Not that we saw. I saw her cry once, and we were all crying then. Somewhere along the line, she learned that being troubled means people pulling away or pushing her away.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs gotten better at showing it,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúThe bag. That was positive.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs really, really good, then. Because before? It took the world ending to crack her. Outside of that, you‚Äôd have a nine— she‚Äôs eleven now?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúThereabouts.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôd have an eleven year old, then, who‚Äôs internalizing so much that she loses hair in patches or makes herself sick. She didn‚Äôt ever cry, she didn‚Äôt signal how upset she was. Even if she‚Äôs doing better, you have to pay attention.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor ten percent of what you dealt with?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúVictoria,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúThe school stuff, the Wards stuff was structured. There was natural pushback when she stepped over lines. Punishments, rules for the classroom, rules for the Wards, oversight, teams of people having hours-long meetings about her. The art project, moving classes, her being bullied because of her behavior and her visceral reactions to that, the bullying in school, all of that was the easy stuff.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan I ask about the hard stuff?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can ask, but I don‚Äôt know if I can summarize it. We had a nine year old girl with no stopping points when it came to anything social. No brakes, a practically nonexistent sense of boundaries, and zero emotional defenses.‚Äù

‚ÄúAn acquaintance of ours described her as a bull in a china shop with a profound love for dishware,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt joke,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs pretty apt,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúAnd I don‚Äôt think anyone‚Äôs laughing.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat happened?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúOne of her classmates‚Äô families moved away, in large part because of her. One or two other families were seriously considering it. At least one of her teachers from the training camps was being investigated with a job and career on the line. Most people who were involved knew what the reality of Kenzie was, but procedures had to be followed, and when you have someone as vulnerable as she is, you can‚Äôt ever be one hundred percent sure. We had a similar thing with our Wards team leader, early on, but we were more proactive in anticipating it, and they were allegations of a different tint. I wish I could convey the trail of destruction.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúNo?‚Äù Houndstooth asked.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not a bull in a china shop. She‚Äôs not a headache, she‚Äôs not a bringer of destruction, a tinker, or Ward, a nine year old, or an eleven year old. You keep reducing her down, you make her small, and you make the problem big.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe problems were big,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúThe problems threatened to end several careers, derailed others, and uprooted a family from their lives and hometown. She likes and falls in love with everyone and it‚Äôs only because of us being attentive that she didn‚Äôt actively let herself be the prey of a villain group or dangerous lunatic in some desperate hope of finding a connection with them.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not prey either,‚Äù Ashley said, more heated. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs Kenzie Martin. She‚Äôs a person. You may have only seen her cry once but I‚Äôve seen her cry more times than I can count.‚Äù

‚ÄúReally?‚Äù Tristan asked. ‚ÄúWhen?‚Äù

‚ÄúDuring the meetings. After. During private conversations.‚Äù

‚ÄúCrying is good,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a step forward. It‚Äôs very possible she‚Äôs made a lot of steps forward. It‚Äôs clear you guys care about her and believe in her. But I‚Äôve met and interacted with Kenzie Martin, and I have a really hard time envisioning a Kenzie that‚Äôs fixed.‚Äù

‚ÄúLike she‚Äôs a broken machine,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to say better because better can mean partway. What I‚Äôm saying is that I can‚Äôt see a Kenzie that was that badly off, who‚Äôs‚Ä¶ normal now. Or ever.‚Äù

‚ÄúI hate that word,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think there are any good words for something that hard to encapsulate,‚Äù Houndstooth said.

‚ÄúWhat do you advise?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúAbout the non-school, non-Ward stuff?‚Äù

‚ÄúPay attention when she talks about new friends or people in particular, get ahead of that, introduce yourself, keep a close eye on things. Talk to her teachers. Talk to her foster parents, or the people at whatever institution she‚Äôs at. They‚Äôre probably pretty overloaded, but make them pay attention. Get everyone on the same page. Same rules for everyone, boundaries, sticking to those boundaries, limit physical contact and gestures of affection unless okayed by the therapist.‚Äù

My eyebrows drew together. I glanced at Tristan, and he gestured, hand moving as if to dismiss, urging me to move on. I was pretty sure Houndstooth saw it too.

He didn‚Äôt speak up or act on it, though.

I made a mental note about the emphasis on foster parents. I‚Äôd need to have a conversation with others and pay more attention to Julien and his wife.

‚ÄúFrankly, I‚Äôd really lock down the school thing. See if you can have her rotate classes or do something non-classroom. Discourage friendships with classmates, because that‚Äôs not going to go well. If she starts showing true romantic interest in anyone, shut it down hard. I wouldn‚Äôt advise her being on your team, frankly.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs extreme,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs dehumanizing and disgusting,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúUntil she‚Äôs better, no human contact or relationships. Nobody can get close to her, nobody can show kindness, nobody can help her or accept help from her? Just a breath or two away from you saying you don‚Äôt ever think she‚Äôll be normal. You‚Äôre disgusting.‚Äù

She was starting to walk away, toward the path that had led us up the hill.

‚ÄúAshley,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI get what you‚Äôre saying, but we did agree to hear him out as a favor.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou hear him out then,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúTell me what you think I need to hear when you tell the others. But I‚Äôm not going to stay here and listen to this degenerate imbecile reduce her to a problem that can be solved like that. She‚Äôs human.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan I tell an anecdote?‚Äù

‚ÄúCould I stop you without killing you?‚Äù Ashley asked.

‚ÄúCan you wait for us at the station, Ashley?‚Äù Tristan asked.

She stalked off, and we were left with Houndstooth.

Houndstooth looked toward me and Tristan. ‚ÄúThere was a time, about a year back, where I was talking to a teammate. He said a food addiction was the only addiction that you couldn‚Äôt go cold turkey on. You can‚Äôt not eat, and that‚Äôs hard, when the addiction makes dealing with food in moderation next to impossible. Immediately, I thought of Kenzie. I thought, within a second or two of him saying that, he was wrong, there was another addiction like that. You say she‚Äôs human, but she‚Äôs a people addict. She‚Äôs addicted to humans. You can‚Äôt expect a young girl to not interact with people, and you can‚Äôt expect her to deal with people in moderation.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you think the way to solve that is to‚Ä¶ minimize that interaction to the barest bones?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúOver months and years, gradually loosen that belt. If the therapist okays it.‚Äù

I sighed.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs doing exceptionally well,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúYou could hold a gun to my head, and I wouldn‚Äôt say she lacked a work ethic,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs brilliant for her age, she‚Äôs good-hearted in her way, and she doesn‚Äôt deserve a thousandth of what she‚Äôs gone through. It‚Äôs heartbreaking and worrying.‚Äù

Kenzie had named Houndstooth‚Äôs team as her second big heartbreak.

‚ÄúFuck the agents.‚Äù

‚ÄúPowers and agents don‚Äôt even really play into this,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúIf you took away her powers and the influence of her agent today, I‚Äôd give you all the same warnings tomorrow.‚Äù

‚äô

We let ourselves into the headquarters.

Sveta was on her way. Chris was taking the day off for more Indulgence, not Wan, and that last part was supposed to be important.

Rain‚Äôs absence in particular was very much felt, now that his situation had been painted in stark relief. Everyone was a little bit worried, now.

Ashley had her appointment. Tristan had to give Byron his turn.

Kenzie sat in her chair at the table-turned desk, the projector showing the camera‚Äôs image of Cedar Point.

‚ÄúDid you skip class to get here as quick as you did?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Kenzie said, not turning around. ‚ÄúI went to class, I stopped in at study hall at the start of lunch and asked if I could go early. They said okay. You can call if you need to check.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need to check,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre honest.‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry for all the emails. Sveta yelled at me. Well, she didn‚Äôt yell, but she came close. I sent her almost as many as I sent you.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid you eat lunch?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs in my bag, in case I get hungry.‚Äù

‚ÄúToo nervous?‚Äù I asked.

She turned around in her computer chair and smiled. ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúHoundstooth wanted to make sure you were okay first. Making sure you weren‚Äôt getting too much homework,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúHe had some tips about how we should make sure you aren‚Äôt tinkering yourself to the bone after hours.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt helps sometimes. Distracting myself with it.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe should figure out a balance. He was suspicious you were staying up late, watching and rewatching camera feeds.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen I can‚Äôt sleep it‚Äôs nice to be able to watch that stuff with my laptop beside me in the dark room. I doze off.‚Äù

I nodded.

‚ÄúDid he say the embarrassing stuff?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what qualifies as embarrassing,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúProblems with teachers, school. Tristan and Ashley defended you pretty fiercely.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you?‚Äù

‚ÄúI just want to figure out what needs to be figured out,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúSo everyone‚Äôs happy and healthy, and the team stays together and positive overall. I shared some of the good stuff I know of.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid he mention the old lady?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe was on the internet and she wanted a replacement for her dead daughter and I almost went with her, and then later we started thinking she killed her daughter. Embarrassing.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat did come up.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd how I fell asleep watching TV on my friend‚Äôs couch?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat didn‚Äôt, I don‚Äôt think.‚Äù

‚ÄúSuper embarrassing,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAnd my foster parents?‚Äù

‚ÄúVery briefly.‚Äù

She nodded. She smiled. ‚ÄúThanks for telling me.‚Äù

I put my hand on the back of her chair and spun her in circles, my arm passing over her head on each rotation. ‚ÄúSveta‚Äôs on her way. I think the others are mostly getting sorted out. With Rain hiding out, they‚Äôre resting up and getting prepped. Did you get the email?‚Äù

‚ÄúI had my phone taken away. I‚Äôm supposed to go to the principal‚Äôs office with my mom or dad tomorrow if I want it back.‚Äù

‚ÄúI suspected it was something like that,‚Äù I said. I smiled. ‚ÄúLess emails, and no using your phone in school unless it‚Äôs an emergency. Houndstooth is going to make a move late this afternoon.‚Äù

Kenzie put her hand out and stopped herself from spinning.

‚ÄúHow‚Äôs that?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt want to see me or say hi?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúHe probably had a good excuse. He‚Äôs good at those. It took me a while to figure out.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt want to tip off the villains about his relationship to us.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt makes sense,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúDo you want help with homework while we wait? And you can eat your lunch?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúIf that nervousness has eased up.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll eat,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúHelp with homework would be a good way to kill the time, too.‚Äù

‚ÄúPerfect,‚Äù I said.

I stepped away to look at the whiteboards while Kenzie got ready.

Her voice small and quiet, I heard Kenzie remark, ‚ÄúAt least I get to see him on camera.‚Äù

Shade — 4.5

I watched over the group.

We were getting settled in. Tables were moved, whiteboards arranged, and chairs put together. It was starting to look more like a hideout. Sveta was doing her name in a fancy script on her board, Kenzie was doing homework, and I had plugged my laptop in, with my notes up, but it wasn‚Äôt my focus in the moment.

Byron had taken his turn. Two hours and fifteen minutes after we‚Äôd parted ways, Tristan was back at the hideout. He‚Äôd taken off his black jacket and folded it over the back of a chair, and was doing some of the setup stuff, while wearing a red t-shirt, jeans, and chukka boots. He was athletic, and I remembered Byron hadn‚Äôt given me that impression when I‚Äôd seen him.

‚ÄúHey Tristan,‚Äù I said.

He‚Äôd moved over to his whiteboard, and stepped back and away to look my way.

‚ÄúHey, what do you think?‚Äù he asked. He extended a hand, indicating his work: he had sketched out a rough floor plan of the room. The area was an open-concept apartment, a bathroom closed off, the rest of it without walls, which gave us our room to maneuver, and it looked like Tristan was trying to figure out where the other things we needed might go. A list of bullet points said ‚Äòcot‚Äô, ‚Äòmini fridge‚Äô, and ‚Äòteam sign‚Äô.

I frowned a bit as I saw that last one.

‚ÄúTeam sign?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúSure. I figured it would be good for morale. We could have Sveta paint it and put it up on the wall. Something nice to remind ourselves that we‚Äôre a team.‚Äù

‚ÄúI could paint something,‚Äù Sveta said, looking away from her work. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm kind of anxious to have a name, and we‚Äôd have to decide that first.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat could be neat,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúMy take on reading that was that you wanted to hang the sign outside.‚Äù

Tristan smiled. ‚ÄúSomething nice and big, colorful, with a by-line saying something about how we‚Äôre a covert team of heroes.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt sure,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúBelieve it or not, I‚Äôm not a dumb guy,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúStubborn, maybe—‚Äù

‚ÄúDefinitely,‚Äù Kenzie called out, sitting at her desk. She was leaning over her homework.

‚ÄúMost definitely,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúFine. But I‚Äôm not dumb. I‚Äôm thinking about the things we need to get in terms of things we can fold up or pack away, since we may be moving a lot. We can fold up the cot, I can carry a mini fridge, these tables have legs that can fold up to the underside, and for the sign, I was picturing getting three separate canvases and having us put them up there so it connects or lines up.‚Äù

‚ÄúCould work,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThree part name?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúNo idea,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúSorry, Vic, you were going to say something?‚Äù

‚ÄúI was going to ask if you train, or if the extra strength is from the powers. Biokinesis or whichever.‚Äù

‚ÄúI train,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúI was just thinking of setting up a punching bag or something, actually.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI usually end up with restless energy to burn. I lift, I run on the treadmill, and I had a class I took with Reach, but obviously it‚Äôs been a while. Works with my enhanced strength.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo it does help, then.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou look like you do something,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúI do,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúOr I did. I don‚Äôt have access to my dad‚Äôs equipment or the stuff I had while helping out with the Patrol Block.‚Äù

‚ÄúDoes it help? Powerwise?‚Äù

I shook my head. ‚ÄúForcefield derived strength. I‚Äôm strong enough to tear apart an engine block with my hands. That wouldn‚Äôt change if I didn‚Äôt get off the couch and weighed three hundred pounds or if I was a bodybuilder.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy bother if you can tear apart engine blocks?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúWhy do I walk when I could fly? I‚Äôd atrophy, for one thing, and I can‚Äôt always use my strength. I don‚Äôt have the control to do something more delicate. I— I honestly don‚Äôt trust my power, a lot of the time.‚Äù

Sveta came to stand beside me, to get a look at Tristan‚Äôs idea of a finished floor plan and join the conversation.

‚Äú‚Ä¶There‚Äôs a middle ground, and I‚Äôd like to be able to function in it,‚Äù I finished.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs kind of where I‚Äôm at,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúExcept I‚Äôm not trying to find a middle ground between one hundred miles an hour and a standstill. I‚Äôm using this body to bring myself to a point five percent of the way between zero and a thousand miles an hour.‚Äù

‚ÄúVroom,‚Äù Kenzie said, without turning to look at us.

She‚Äôd been just a little subdued.

‚ÄúAnd it doesn‚Äôt change, then. It is what it is?‚Äù Tristan asked. ‚ÄúFor both of you, I guess?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúOr— I don‚Äôt know, but I‚Äôm strong enough. I‚Äôm not going to go try to figure out what I can do to make these things stronger.‚Äù

As Tristan glanced at me, I made a rectangle with my fingers. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs complicated. It fluctuates. I could name some terms and things that apply there, but I don‚Äôt want to bore you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been bored enough times. I know a lot of the terms. Sechen ranges?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs one of them. Powers often get stronger with certain influencing factors. You read up on that?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe did a ton of testing with Reach, and we saw a lot of parahuman science people while we were trying to figure out a solution. They think it‚Äôs a straight multiplier. I have one point three to one point six times the strength and overall fitness.‚Äù

‚ÄúHandy,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúAnd Byron?‚Äù

‚ÄúA bit of resistance to temperature extremes. He gets a higher percent, he‚Äôd probably remember his specific numbers better than I do, but unless it‚Äôs winter or we‚Äôre dealing with a heat wave, it doesn‚Äôt apply as often.‚Äù

‚ÄúOn the note of Byron‚Ä¶ the second part to my question is, how does the exercise thing work for Byron? Because exercise is monotonous enough when you‚Äôre getting something out of it.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe commented on that a while ago, actually. We negotiated something. He made a short list of movies, and I watch his movies while I work out. Similar thing with the trips here and back. I sometimes give him extra time, especially if I have something to think about, which is most times these days.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat sounds pretty good.‚Äù

‚ÄúWasn‚Äôt always good,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúMoonsong had some things right, back at the Wardens‚Äô place. I wasn‚Äôt always good at being fair. It went the other way, Byron—‚Äù

Tristan stopped there.

‚ÄúI won‚Äôt finish that thought. Byron is Byron, and I‚Äôm me, and I‚Äôve got to own my shit without comparing. I wasn‚Äôt always good at being fair,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm good at a lot of things. I can kick ass and look pretty great while doing it, I‚Äôm tenacious, I tend to finish what I set my mind to. But fair is hard.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt is,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard enough figuring out how to be fair to ourselves,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúToo true,‚Äù I said. I glanced over at Kenzie.

‚ÄúPunching bag?‚Äù Tristan asked. He pointed at the corner, next to Chris‚Äô whiteboard. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need to do anything special for you guys?‚Äù

‚ÄúRegular punching bag for me,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll use it. It‚Äôs going to be a chore to move if we change locations, though.‚Äù

‚ÄúNoted,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúMaybe we should all get one pain-in-the-ass contribution to the hideout and this can be mine.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve already got mine,‚Äù Kenzie said, from the other end of the room. She kicked her box and the images projected on the wall changed.

‚ÄúBag‚Äôs good,‚Äù I said, as I started walking over. ‚ÄúNo objection.‚Äù

I approached Kenzie. The image was projected onto the wall in front of her, moving between the two cameras. An addition had been made, and as each person walked down the street, stylized crosshairs tracked their faces. Most had logos and names. A lot of them were just things in the vein of ‚Äò[New31]‚Äô with the number changing, not names.

One of the cameras moved. It focused in on a scene where two people wearing aprons were smoking by the back stairs of a restaurant.
