The little space between four buildings didn‚Äôt really qualify as an alley, as it looked like back doors and fire escapes were the only way to get down to the area. An enclave, maybe. The camera moved until it tracked a person in costume. The guy‚Äôs mask looked like it covered all but a third of his face, the bottom right of his jaw and the top left of his forehead exposed, with ceramic shards framing each ‚Äòhole‚Äô. Curved metal bars reminiscent of piping extended around to the back of his head, holding the mask in place.

The camera seemed to recognize the mask, and labeled him as ‚Äò[Kitchen Sink]‚Äô. We‚Äôd seen him before, but the label thing was new.

Off to the side, as part of a sidebar with data and labels, there were a series of countdown timers.

HT & Team: 8:21

Ashley Train to Station: 0:45
Average Ash Walk Time: 4:10

When I stood behind Kenzie‚Äôs chair, I saw that even with a dozen workbooks and pieces of homework strewn in front of her, she wasn‚Äôt doing her schoolwork. She had a projected image in front of her, drawn out in three dimensions, with the same image drawn on a paper in front of her in marker. The lines of the three dimensional image looked similar to a marker‚Äôs. With gestures and prods of a pen, Kenzie adjusted the particulars.

‚ÄúWhat do you think?‚Äù she asked. She used her hands, gesturing, and made it bigger. Turning around in her chair, bringing the drawn object with her, she moved her hands and superimposed the image over her head.

A mask, or a helmet. Eyeless, in a way, with a flat pane extending from the eyes, over her nose, down to a pointed chin. Three round lenses were placed along the line of her eyebrows, one round lens was on each cheekbone, and she had two spherical attachments, much like the buns she tended to wear her hair in. Probably intended to fit over the buns.

‚ÄúI like it better than the one you wore for the training exercise,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIt does make me think of a spider, with all of the eyes.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs that a bad thing?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think you make me think ‚Äòspider‚Äô at all. It‚Äôs a bit too inhuman. What if‚Ä¶ can I draw? I don‚Äôt want to ruin your drawing.‚Äù

‚ÄúGo ahead. Use my pen. Squint one eye when you want it to draw.‚Äù

The countdown timers marked Ashley‚Äôs departure from the train. The ‚Äòwalk time‚Äô timer was highlighted and started counting down.

I tried my hand at drawing little triangles at the side of each of the round lenses. A tiny triangle to represent eyelashes.

‚ÄúOh, cute!‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúCan you draw a second, smaller one? And leave off the eyelashes on the cheekbones, because I‚Äôm doing something different there, and—‚Äù

‚ÄúHere,‚Äù I said. I passed her the pen.

She began to change things, keeping all but two of the eyelashes I‚Äôd drawn.

Someone labeled ‚Äò[Joe]‚Äô walked down the street, a bag slung over his shoulder. He entered the same bar I‚Äôd encountered Moose outside of. The one where Snag and Love Lost had gone inside.

I looked at some of the other names.

‚ÄúFifi?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúHuh?‚Äù Kenzie asked. She looked up, and I pointed at a blonde girl with hair that looked like she‚Äôd just about destroyed it with bleaching. Frizzed out to the point I doubted she could get a comb through it. She‚Äôd resorted to using a headband and hair tie to try to get it in order. The headband and hair tie didn‚Äôt match her outfit.

‚ÄúOh. She looked like a Fifi. I named some of the ones I see a lot.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe does look vaguely poodle-ish, and Fifi seems like a poodle name to me.‚Äù

‚ÄúExactly,‚Äù Kenzie said, with satisfaction. She returned to writing down something that looked like code and formula, periodically poking her pen at her projected image of her mask.

I looked at ‚ÄòFifi‚Äô. ‚ÄúPoor her. When I was a little younger than you are now, I tried dying my hair to be like my cousin, and it went badly. I was so inconsolable.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat happened after?‚Äù Kenzie asked.

‚ÄúMy mom hired a professional to get me back to normal, and it was mostly fixed. We bought some products to keep my hair from ending up like that after. I can‚Äôt imagine the professional or the products were cheap, and we were pretty tight on cash back then. She knew it was important to me.‚Äù

My heart hurt a little, thinking of that.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the way it should be,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said.

She turned my way, putting on the projected helmet so it was superimposed over her head. When she took her hands away and moved her head, the helmet moved with her head.

Now, though, the eyes of the mask widened and closed, as camera-like shutters closed around the edges. The eyelashes moved up and down a little, and shutters moved in lopsided ways, with only some of the shutters closing. Coming down from the top, curved forward, angry. Coming in from the bottom.

‚ÄúAre you changing your expression?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes! It worked. Awesome. Okay, and let‚Äôs try this.‚Äù

Her eyelashes moved, until one was pointing straight up, one was pointing straight down. The eyes all briefly turned white.

‚ÄúI think that worked. White eyes and‚Ä¶ targeting mode?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot targeting mode. I could build something like the flash gun into it. I can strike a pose and do the eye thing, like they‚Äôre crosshairs, and flash. There‚Äôd probably only be room for one shot. Okay, colors—‚Äù

She tapped her pen on her desk. The mask changed from shades of gray to pink and sky blue. I winced, and she immediately changed to the next. Seafoam green and black. Through each change, the circles at her cheekbones remained a slightly different shade, more muted.

‚ÄúSomething less garish, maybe?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúThat one looks a little villainous. Cute, but villainous.‚Äù

She tapped her pen a few times, then made a mark on the paper.

Lemon-lime and dark gray, with green-gray circles for the cheekbones.

‚ÄúBetter.‚Äù

‚ÄúOoh, I know a thing. I can do a thing.‚Äù

She turned, and she started scribbling. She seemed energized.

But as she turned, the image at one of her cheekbones broke up, becoming transparent, like a few squares had been cut out of the image. It flickered as I moved my head to view it at another angle.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got a distortion,‚Äù I said. I pointed.

‚ÄúSilly me,‚Äù she said.

The entire helmet disappeared.

‚ÄúSomething similar happened when your picture was taken at the Warden‚Äôs HQ,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre wearing a projection?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot really,‚Äù she said. She scribbled. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm wearing tech, and it conflicts with stuff so it can be hard to coordinate. I wouldn‚Äôt call it wearing.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo?‚Äù

‚ÄúWearing makes me think full-body, or covering my head and I mean, I had that costume thing for the training, and that didn‚Äôt last that long. How could or would I wear something else and have it last all day or whatever? I mean, I wish I could.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wish I could,‚Äù I said. I didn‚Äôt want to press or be harsh, but I didn‚Äôt want to let this lie either. I went easy, instead. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm slightly concerned if you‚Äôre using projections like that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not that devious,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt bring something and pretend to have a short battery life so I can hide that I have a longer battery life for something else I‚Äôm secretly using. That‚Äôs not what I do and that‚Äôs not how I am.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt get the impression you‚Äôre devious or that you‚Äôd go to those lengths.‚Äù

Kenzie looked up at the clock.

Average Ash Walk Time: —1:13

‚ÄúShe‚Äôll turn up,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI know. I just want her here before Houndstooth calls,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúOne second.‚Äù

She kicked the cube. It went dark, and the camera image dropped away.

‚ÄúVictoria!‚Äù Tristan called me from the far end of the room.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúCan we use your computer?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

Tristan and Sveta gathered together at my computer, Tristan‚Äôs hands at the keyboard.

‚ÄúThe tech you‚Äôre wearing. The distortions. I want to make sure you‚Äôre taking care of yourself. That you don‚Äôt have dark circles under your eyes, or bruises, or anything like that.‚Äù

She turned her head to look at me over her shoulder and smiled. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs off. I turned my tech off to synchronize everything across all fields. This is me.‚Äù

She showed me her phone, where the progress bar was filling up.

‚ÄúGotcha,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI know Houndstooth said stuff. I think he said it in a caring way because he‚Äôs one of the best guys out there. True blue hero, like Weld. Like you.‚Äù

I was reminded of how I‚Äôd handled Presley on the train. I‚Äôd recognized how she‚Äôd needed me to be more than human, because she idolized me, she‚Äôd seen me as something to reach for.

I wondered if Kenzie wanted me to be the same thing.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if I am. I‚Äôm pretty angry about things. I‚Äôm‚Ä¶ really concerned about a lot of things. Negative emotions drive an awful lot of what I do.‚Äù

The lock on the door clicked. Ashley let herself in, then locked it behind her. She smiled at Kenzie and me, then gave the other two a small salute.

Kenzie had visibly brightened at Ashley‚Äôs appearance.

‚ÄúThe things you do are good,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúAt least as far as I‚Äôve seen and researched.‚Äù

She researched me.

‚ÄúAnd I think that‚Äôs what counts,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nuanced.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf Houndstooth sat you down to tell you about me and he didn‚Äôt say I‚Äôm bad at nuance, he screwed up,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúAnd he doesn‚Äôt screw up.‚Äù

The projector box lit up, and the video image popped back up. Kenzie‚Äôs phone changed from the progress bar, and her helmet reappeared, floating just over the paper where it had been drawn.

‚ÄúRoughly one minute until Houndstooth!‚Äù Kenzie reported.

‚ÄúGot it,‚Äù Tristan said.

Ashley approached, standing by Kenzie‚Äôs chair, and laid a hand on Kenzie‚Äôs left shoulder.

‚ÄúYou good?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúWorking hands. No pain. We‚Äôre still working with this cretin?‚Äù

‚ÄúCretin?‚Äù Kenzie asked.

‚ÄúHoundstooth,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt impress me.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay, wow. Let me start by saying you impress me,‚Äù Kenzie said, looking up at Ashley. ‚ÄúI love those videos you‚Äôre in, and I loved seeing you train. You‚Äôre awesome. And you‚Äôre totally, one hundred percent wrong, this once. Because Houndstooth is awesome and impressive too.‚Äù

‚ÄúHoundstooth‚Äôs concerns seemed to come from a well-intentioned, good place,‚Äù I said, interjecting. Kenzie‚Äôs head whipped around to look at me over her other shoulder. I added, ‚ÄúAnd despite that, he seemed to come to some extreme conclusions. There‚Äôs nuance, between where you‚Äôre coming from and where you end up. Like we were just talking about.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen I called him a cretin I was being gentle. He‚Äôs a disgusting, disappointing, subnormal excuse for a hero, cape, or human being.‚Äù

‚ÄúI will fight you over this,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôd lose.‚Äù

‚ÄúI will go to war with you. Houndstooth was one of the coolest people to me at one of my uncoolest times.‚Äù

Tristan and Sveta had noticed things were a little hairy and were approaching at a jog. I interjected, saying, ‚ÄúWe might want to drop this. Let the topic lie.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúNot if she‚Äôs going to say anything more like what she just said.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe talked about you like you were nothing more than a problem.‚Äù

‚ÄúI am a problem!‚Äù Kenzie said, raising her voice.

‚ÄúEasy,‚Äù I said. Tristan and Sveta joined us.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm a problem,‚Äù Kenzie said, quieter. ‚ÄúI was.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre more than the problem,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúThat waste of space didn‚Äôt—‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you want to go to war?‚Äù Kenzie asked, rising out of her seat. ‚ÄúI can build an army of camera drones. I have advantage in the air. I have battlefield awareness. And I‚Äôll fight you on this until you explode me all over the place or you say you‚Äôre wrong about him. Don‚Äôt say bad things about him. Not when he‚Äôs someone that counts. Not when you‚Äôre someone that counts. Okay?‚Äù

Sveta reached out and pushed Kenzie back down into her seat. Tristan was closer to Ashley, facing her, ready to get between the two.

‚ÄúKenzie,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúAshley‚Äôs coming from a good place here.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know that,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúI also know that Houndstooth is.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre better than he makes you out to be. You can‚Äôt put so much faith in the words of someone who so clearly knows so little,‚Äù Ashley said.

Kenzie shook her head, smiling like she couldn‚Äôt believe the conversation she was a part of.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs weak, and he‚Äôs a loser. He‚Äôs the lowest of the low.‚Äù

The phone trilled with a rising series of beeps. The projected image on the screen showed the person calling: Houndstooth.

Kenzie leaped forward, swatting aside Sveta‚Äôs hand and dodging mine. She grabbed the front of Ashley‚Äôs top, and hauled it down, making Ashley bend down.

Ashley‚Äôs hand moved, and Tristan grabbed her wrist, stopping it from going wherever it was going to go. He grabbed Kenzie with the other hand, ready to pull her away if need be.

‚ÄúWoah,‚Äù Tristan said.

I moved closer, putting my hands on Kenzie‚Äôs shoulders, freeing Tristan to focus more on Ashley.

So small. Her shoulders were narrow.

Kenzie raised her free hand, and pressed it against Ashley‚Äôs mouth, so her fingers were on either side of Ashley‚Äôs nose. Had her fingers been longer, the tips and nails might have been near Ashley‚Äôs eyes.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt say anything,‚Äù Kenzie said.

The phone trilled its beeps again.

‚ÄúPlease don‚Äôt say anything. Please.‚Äù

There was a pause, silence.

The phone spat out its series of beeps.

‚ÄúPlease let this go okay,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúThat will do more than anything.‚Äù

The silence hung. The phone could only ring so many times.

Kenzie started to smile, and the smile faltered. ‚ÄúPlease? I‚Äôll do anything.‚Äù

Ashley straightened, pulling away from Kenzie‚Äôs hands. She turned away, folding her arms.

The rest of us relaxed. Kenzie, too, turned away, stepping away from my hands. She grabbed the phone off the table and tossed it to Tristan.

The phone was mid-ring when Tristan answered.

‚ÄúSorry about the delay. Capricorn here. Four of the six members of the team are here, and our coach is here too,‚Äù Tristan said. He backed up a few steps, until Ashley was in front of him, facing him. ‚ÄúI think we‚Äôre going to put you on speakerphone if that‚Äôs okay.‚Äù

Ashley nodded once.

‚ÄúGreat,‚Äù Tristan said. A response for both Houndstooth and Ashley, it seemed.

Kenzie hit a key.

‚ÄúHello again,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got my team here, and we‚Äôre north of Cedar Point. We‚Äôre getting sorted out, costumes already on, but there‚Äôs other stuff to do. Minions to summon, ammo to load. I‚Äôm really hoping that none of it is needed.‚Äù

‚ÄúSame here,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been keeping an eye on things and I think it‚Äôs pretty quiet right now.‚Äù

‚ÄúPerfect.‚Äù

I raised my hand a bit to signal I was going to speak, then stepped forward a bit. ‚ÄúVictoria here. I think there are three villains—‚Äù

Kenzie‚Äôs hand went up, four fingers extended.

‚ÄúFour villains out and about around the city. A few left on a road trip earlier in the afternoon. There are also a couple you‚Äôll want to be aware of.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnything you can give us is great.‚Äù

Kenzie hit a key. The camera moved to Kitchen Sink, with his ceramic mask.

‚ÄúKitchen Sink. He‚Äôs the closest to you, big, minor brute aspect, but his thing is he acts as a blaster. Long and sustained series of junk being thrown at high velocities. Everything but the kitchen sink, as the saying goes.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs so bad a schtick it‚Äôs great,‚Äù a voice on the line said. One of Houndstooth‚Äôs subordinates, feminine-sounding.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs in the company of Hookline. Minor mover, has a hundred-foot long cable he telekinetically controls. It can‚Äôt be broken or damaged, short of some very select powers, and it will shake off or slip free of a lot of things that would snag or impede another weapon. Frost, hands that try to grab it. So don‚Äôt try. It moves faster and acts like a whip, so be super careful if a fight happens. There‚Äôs a hook on the end, and he‚Äôs most dangerous if you‚Äôre at or just inside that hundred foot limit of his range where the hook is flying around. Which brings me to my next point.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre willing to hurt people?‚Äù Houndstooth asked.

‚ÄúKitchen Sink and Hookline are. They‚Äôre part of one clique in Cedar Point that‚Äôs more violent than the others. Aggressive, violent, even borderline bloody. They might be acting as enforcers for others.‚Äù

‚ÄúBreaking kneecaps,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúGot it,‚Äù Houndstooth said.

‚ÄúHookline and Sink,‚Äù the feminine voice said. ‚ÄúOh my god.‚Äù

‚ÄúMoose seems to be going around between groups, passing on messages or checking on things. Strong brute, something to do with shockwaves. He hits hard, he moves a lot faster than you‚Äôd expect from someone that big, and he has decent combat sense. I wish we could give you more information on him, but all I know is from a brief scrap with him.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou said the other two might pick a fight. What about this guy?‚Äù

‚ÄúLow odds the other two pick a fight without checking with the leadership, but if someone was to pick a fight, it‚Äôd be people from their group. Moose would sooner negotiate or look to talk than fight, and he‚Äôd only really fight if he thought he needed to or if he was certain he could win. I think your worry is going to be having something in mind to tell Moose that passes the sniff test.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre curious what‚Äôs going on, the Hill is a mess, and we‚Äôre wondering if these are greener pastures than Greenwich.‚Äù

Tristan said, ‚ÄúIf others are going to show interest, we want to drop a hint. Something that makes them wonder. You could mention sponsorship and a reshuffling of jurisdictions.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs talk of war,‚Äù Sveta interjected. ‚ÄúI know someone who‚Äôs having to spend time away, and they‚Äôre bringing people in from other teams to fill holes.‚Äù

‚ÄúI heard about that,‚Äù Houndstooth said.

‚ÄúYou could use that. It happened with villain communities in the past. A void appears, villains rush to fill it, there‚Äôs upheaval, and then things settle.‚Äù

She looked at me as she said that last bit.

I‚Äôd said something like that at the group therapy meeting, hadn‚Äôt I?

‚ÄúIf Moose challenges us, I‚Äôll say something like that.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs also a woman that‚Äôs collecting protection money right now. Bluestocking. From the brainiac clique.‚Äù

‚ÄúThese guys are so lame, I love it,‚Äù Houndstooth‚Äôs subordinate said.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs something to keep in mind,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThese guys congregated here. If something happens, and I don‚Äôt know if Moose would let it unless you forced the issue, then you‚Äôll have a lot more in your hair. They‚Äôre banding together and as lame as any individual might be, they‚Äôre finding a lot of people who match up with them. Thematically or in style.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre seeing that more in general,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúLots of capes condensed into a relatively tight geographic area.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to see it in effect here. Two clairvoyants are keeping an eye on the area. One of them is a clairaudient, so they‚Äôll have an ear on the area too. I could go into detail, but I think it‚Äôs better and easier to just say that once you enter Cedar Point they‚Äôre going to be fully aware of everything you say or do. Be careful what you say, and be aware we can‚Äôt communicate with you unless it‚Äôs an emergency.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat also means no mockery or jokes,‚Äù Houndstooth said, his voice quieter, like he didn‚Äôt have his mouth near the phone. ‚ÄúAnd as far as we‚Äôre concerned, your team doesn‚Äôt exist.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt would mean a ton if you could be especially careful about that,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be careful,‚Äù Houndstooth said. ‚ÄúI trust my guys. Give us a couple of minutes, and we‚Äôll move through, make our faces known. I want to plan what we do if we run into the guys you talked about.‚Äù

‚ÄúCall us again when it‚Äôs time,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúWill do. I like this a lot, good briefing, great intelligence. This is great stuff, guys.‚Äù

The call ended.

Tristan huffed out a breath, glancing at Ashley.

‚ÄúGreat stuff, and he likes it,‚Äù Kenzie said, quiet. Her legs kicked, just barely scuffing the plastic rim that the wheels of the computer chair stuck down from. ‚ÄúNow I get to see Houndstooth on camera. Wooo.‚Äù

Her voice was so quiet it might have sounded unenthusiastic, but the speed her legs kicked at doubled with that last utterance.

‚ÄúWe should get people out there in case things go bad and we need to extract,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúI can fly out,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll go,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúI can be there in ten minutes if I need to be, maybe as few as five,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll hold down the fort here until then. Ashley— I‚Äôd rather keep you in reserve. If everything falls to pieces, we‚Äôll bring you in to great effect.‚Äù

She nodded, and then she walked away, approaching the empty whiteboard that was supposed to be hers. Some of her things were in a bag at the base of the board.

Sveta and I stepped out, and I used my flight to lift up off the fire escape.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm worried about them,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúAnd I wish there was a flagpole or tree close by I could grab.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can help a bit with that last part,‚Äù I said. I rose up and away, then extended a hand.

She shot her hand and arm at me, and I caught it. She pulled herself my way, not at her fastest, but fast enough I felt my heart jump in my chest.

I flew back and away, as she hauled herself in, and matched her general direction. It made for a tiny bit more slack.

She let go of me, and she pulled herself to a tree. From there, she moved to a roof.

Like a frog‚Äôs tongue, snapping out, seizing something. But the frog went to the fly, rather than the other way around. To the branch, to the railing, to the fence, then to the chimney.

She was faster than me for short distances, and only a bit slower for the sustained movement. We didn‚Äôt have far to go, so she did pretty well at getting ahead of me. Only the escape from the fire escape had slowed her down.

‚ÄúHold up,‚Äù I called out, as she started to move northward. ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs good.‚Äù

We parked ourselves near where I‚Äôd been the day prior, on a rooftop with the water separating us and Cedar Point.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad it‚Äôs you and me,‚Äù she said.

I bumped her shoulder with mine.

The phone rang. I pulled it from my pocket, connected my earbuds, and put one bud in my ear, one in Sveta‚Äôs.

‚ÄúOne camera on H.T., one in Moose‚Äôs general vicinity,‚Äù Kenzie announced. ‚ÄúThe valiant H.T. is leading his team in. Five of them.‚Äù

I touched the button on the screen to mute my end of the conversation, so we‚Äôd only hear, not say anything.

‚ÄúWe tried to get ahold of Rain and we couldn‚Äôt. I‚Äôm worried,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI know he‚Äôs impossible to get ahold of when he‚Äôs with his family, they‚Äôre off the grid but I don‚Äôt know.‚Äù

The phone flicked between a view of Houndstooth and the villains.

‚ÄúToday‚Äôs the third time Chris chose the optimism-indulgence route in five days, I think.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat do you mean? He‚Äôs not balancing it out?‚Äù

‚ÄúI asked what he was doing to balance it out and he said I should mind my own business.‚Äù

I could see the thread of what Sveta was getting at.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre worried about things as a whole.‚Äù

‚ÄúAren‚Äôt you?‚Äù she asked.

I nodded.

Except maybe worry was the wrong word. It implied hand-wringing. Sweating, nervousness.

It wasn‚Äôt that I was afraid or that it was worse than worry, either. I was becoming far more aware of the problems, for things as a whole.

‚ÄúWhat the mother-loving hell?‚Äù Moose‚Äôs voice came through the earbuds. It sounded weird, captured by cameras at a great distance, sent to Kenzie, sent to us, passed through the earbuds. He‚Äôd just received the news. The video on the phone showed him sending people away on errands. Fetching others.

‚ÄúWe have movement,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre getting organized.‚Äù

We watched. I carried on with my conversation with Sveta. ‚ÄúAshley has had a couple of serious episodes that I‚Äôve seen now. Many lesser episodes, too.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a big part of me that was waiting for the other shoes to drop and that part of me feels‚Ä¶ not worse, now that those shoes have dropped,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt feel not worse.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can see flashes and hints of what you‚Äôre trying to bring out in Ashley,‚Äù I admitted. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not someone I would have spent time with, in another context. I don‚Äôt know how to handle things when she casually mentions her capacity to murder people, as if it‚Äôs a way to win an argument.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe threats are usually empty,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a plus.‚Äù

‚ÄúI want to figure this out,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI want to help. It‚Äôs like Kenzie is a distillation of every vulnerable person I‚Äôve ever tried to help, and Ashley is a distillation of every really fascinating branding exercise where you take a random villain and try to paint them as a hero and even bring out the hero inside them. Tristan and Byron are this really fascinating problem with powers and I‚Äôm a power geek and I really wonder if there‚Äôs a solution.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow do you parse Rain?‚Äù Sveta asked quiet.

‚ÄúI mean—‚Äù I stopped. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm doing exactly what Ashley got so angry at Houndstooth for doing. I‚Äôm reducing people down to conveniently sized problems. I get that, you know? They aren‚Äôt just that. Kenzie is really complex and intelligent, she‚Äôs clearly been through a lot, and I one hundred percent believe Houndstooth when he says she‚Äôs good hearted. The fact that she clearly adores Ashley and she fought her that hard on things to stand up for someone else she holds close to her heart? That‚Äôs amazing. I could say similar things about Ashley, Tristan, Byron.‚Äù

Sveta nodded. ‚ÄúAnd me?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm so caught up in everything I‚Ä¶‚Äù I tried to find the words, and felt a pang. I tried to make sense of that feeling as I said, ‚ÄúI find myself missing you, even though you‚Äôre there.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know. We should have talked like this sooner.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre doing amazing and my biggest fear with you is that I‚Äôm going to be an obstruction, not a help.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, I can‚Äôt ever see that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI worry. I don‚Äôt want to tamper with something that‚Äôs working.‚Äù

‚ÄúI need help. I‚Äôm anxious, and there are things I need. Not from a teammate, but—‚Äù

‚ÄúFrom a friend?‚Äù I asked.

She nodded, something in her rattling slightly with the movement.

‚ÄúAs one part of that, then, I really want to take you shopping, that needs addressing, because this—‚Äù

I touched her top. She was wearing a beige top with a blue anchor on the front. The top was in two pieces, knotted above the shoulder, with smaller bits knotted along her sides.

‚ÄúThis is cute, but I really want to see more sides of you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI want you to take me shopping too,‚Äù she said.

I reached for her hand, and I gave it a waggle.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm thinking about Rain a lot,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúHe has me worried. Not just because of the hit out on his head. But because he‚Äôs not telling the truth about everything. The lies make sense, it seems to make sense to hide things when in his situation. But I‚Äôm not getting to see that good side of him either. So for now, I want to help him. But my motivations are somewhat selfish. My hometown got wiped out by a seemingly insurmountable, inevitable, unstoppable force. We lost. I— I don‚Äôt think I ever fully came back from those losses.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd now we have Rain being targeted by a seemingly insurmountable, inevitable, unstoppable force. I‚Äôm being selfish, but I want to help him and get a win this time around.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs selfish.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy entire hero career before the hospital and the years leading up to that career were a fantasy or exercise in me having powers and being a hero, and I‚Äôm not sure I was ever heroic about it. I just see that past me as wholly motivated in selfishness, ego, pride, and a drive to be celebrated.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs selfish,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not that. You‚Äôre here, doing this. You‚Äôre helping.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe ends justify the‚Ä¶ possible justifications?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúI just had this conversation with Kenzie. I‚Äôm not sure it‚Äôs a good thing if I‚Äôm having it again.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs where your head and heart are at.‚Äù

I shrugged, looking at the video feed.

Moose and Prancer were meeting up. Prancer had two friends with him. On the other feed, the heroes were walking through the neighborhood. Talking to shop owners and residents. Sink and Hookline watched from the sidelines, Houndstooth‚Äôs subordinates hanging back and watching them in turn.

‚ÄúWhere are you at?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúWeld has been telling me things about what‚Äôs going on elsewhere. Things he shouldn‚Äôt be telling me, but I think a lot of it is the kind of thing like a husband with a certain position might tell his wife, sometimes, even when those things are confidential.‚Äù

‚ÄúWife?‚Äù I asked. I raised an eyebrow.

‚ÄúShut up,‚Äù Sveta said, lifting her chin a bit, looking mock-affronted. ‚ÄúNot another word about that.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the one who said the word.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnyway,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt repeat those things, but I worry more than I used to. I get anxious. There‚Äôs a part of everyone else in the group in me, and when they struggle it feels like I‚Äôm struggling.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can sort of relate to that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI need people and I scare them away. Tristan told me what Houndstooth said. None of it‚Äôs too surprising. There are people who know a dangerous amount about me and I think they‚Äôd hurt me if they had a chance. I‚Äôm a killer. I‚Äôm constantly at war with another side of myself. I‚Äôm perpetually off balance and I don‚Äôt know if I‚Äôll ever have that balance.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat kinship might be why you‚Äôre able to connect to the others.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt say it. Don‚Äôt sound like Weld.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs true,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the team‚Äôs mom.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh no,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs so much worse than what I thought you were going to say. I thought you were going to call me the team‚Äôs heart, like Weld does. I can‚Äôt be a mother. No!‚Äù

I was about to respond, but Sveta reached up with a hand. Her prosthetic finger tapped the side of the phone.

Moose and Prancer. They‚Äôd wrangled three others. I didn‚Äôt recognize any of the three. Bluestocking was way off to the side, just barely in earshot. Almost half of Houndstooth‚Äôs group had turned around and were keeping an eye on Hookline and Kitchen Sink.

‚ÄúWhat brings you here?‚Äù Prancer asked.

‚ÄúPassing through,‚Äù Houndstooth said.

‚ÄúTo where? This is a peninsula. It‚Äôs why Hollow Point is a point.‚Äù

Houndstooth shrugged, radiating smug, a lack of concern.

‚ÄúThe Kings of the Hill. You‚Äôre a long way away from where you normally hang out.‚Äù

‚ÄúChanging times. Some other people might be looking to take over the Hill.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat doesn‚Äôt explain why you‚Äôre here,‚Äù Prancer said.

‚ÄúMaybe they want to be Kings of the Point,‚Äù Moose said.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing to be gained here,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôll take you twice as long and five times as many fights to get half as far.‚Äù

Houndstooth laughed. One or two members of his group were almost simultaneous in laughing as well, but Houndstooth was louder, more confident, and probably the focus of the camera‚Äôs microphone, to boot.

The villains shifted their footing. There were no laughs. They didn‚Äôt seem impressed.

Houndstooth explained. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre aware you just described an uphill battle to a group called Kings of the Hill?‚Äù

‚ÄúThen you should know all the better,‚Äù Prancer said. The force of the response was hampered a bit by the fact that Houndstooth‚Äôs group was chuckling again.

Points to Houndstooth, he was doing pretty well here. This wasn‚Äôt the first time I‚Äôd seen him interact with someone and not really have the presence or power to stand up to the people he was facing down.

‚ÄúWhat a theme. The hunting hound, nipping at the fleeing deer‚Äôs heels,‚Äù Houndstooth said.

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre going to nip, I‚Äôm going to gore,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not going to come out ahead in this.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù Houndstooth asked. ‚ÄúWould you like to have a little skirmish right here? Your eight to our five. Or are you going to let us pass through?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt pass through,‚Äù Prancer said, exasperated. ‚ÄúIts a peninsula. You can turn around and go back the way you came, though.‚Äù

Houndstooth chuckled. He put a hand on a teammate‚Äôs shoulder, and turned the guy around. The five members of his group turned to go.

‚ÄúFaster response,‚Äù I said. I touched the button on the phone to unmute myself. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd like to keep a camera on Prancer‚Äôs group. I want to see their response.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the plan,‚Äù Tristan‚Äôs voice came through.

A few seconds passed, as Houndstooth‚Äôs team headed back the way they‚Äôd come.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a mom,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said.

There was conversation on the phone.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want them in here,‚Äù Hookline said. ‚ÄúFuck that.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt know what they‚Äôre doing,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine. Go easy.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey made a mockery of us.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey made a mockery of themselves,‚Äù Prancer said.

‚ÄúI think you‚Äôre the only one that‚Äôs dwelling on the peninsula thing,‚Äù Velvet said.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre fine,‚Äù Prancer said.

‚ÄúWere they related to the blonde, Victoria?‚Äù Moose asked. ‚ÄúPretty much the first thing I said to her was that she‚Äôd end up outnumbered and having to skedaddle. Someone hears that, they might call friends.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre still outnumbered,‚Äù Velvet pointed out.

Prancer replied, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, Moose, but yes, we will always have the numbers advantage. For now I‚Äôm content to wait and see what happens. If they move in, we have the resources to answer them. Bluestocking? Can you tell Bitter Pill I want to talk to her about her team? I want to keep a closer eye on things.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can,‚Äù the woman with glasses said. The one that had been collecting protection money.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be fine,‚Äù Prancer said.

‚ÄúWhat I‚Äôm wondering,‚Äù Kitchen Sink said, ‚ÄúCould this have to do with the truck of—‚Äù

‚ÄúShut up this very second,‚Äù Prancer said.

There was silence.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Prancer said, ‚ÄúI doubt it does, and you shouldn‚Äôt talk business unless we‚Äôre inside with the Speedrunners or Caveat helping to ensure things are private.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre doing a lot of talking,‚Äù Sink said. ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôm thinking you‚Äôre not doing a lot of doing. Those guys walked in and walked out. They might come back and they‚Äôll be a headache. Speaking as someone who‚Äôs been collecting rent—‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you want to talk business, you do it inside,‚Äù Prancer said.

‚Äú—it‚Äôs going to impact that,‚Äù Sink said. ‚ÄúWe have to explain. You have to explain, really, because I‚Äôm saying fuck this conversation.‚Äù

He punched Hookline lightly in the shoulder, gestured. The pair of them turned to walk away.

‚ÄúCracks and clues,‚Äù Tristan‚Äôs voice could be heard over the phone.

‚ÄúAnd two of the locals following Houndstooth‚Äôs group,‚Äù Kenzie reported. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre aiming to catch up.‚Äù

I took off. I paused in the air, hand out.

Sveta sent out her hand. With the wind currents above the water, the hand moved off-course. I flew over to catch it in the same moment she flexed her tendrils and sent the hand to where I‚Äôd been.

We coordinated, I caught her hand before it dropped into the water, and she pulled herself to me. She had a silly smile on her face when she drew close.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll work on that,‚Äù I said.

I flew over the water. When we reached the first tall building, I dropped Sveta, before changing course again.

She went low to the ground, pulling herself straight to the street level. I flew high, to the point where Birdbrain shouldn‚Äôt have a high enough perspective to see me, much like with Kenzie‚Äôs high-flying cameras.

I retrieved my phone. ‚ÄúDo we act?‚Äù

‚ÄúAct,‚Äù Tristan said.

I drew closer.

Hookline‚Äôs hook was out, and Kitchen Sink had a machete in one hand and a gallon tank of probably-kerosene in the other. He kept the large red plastic can, tossed away the machete, tossed away the textbook, tossed away the manhole cover—

I was guessing, hoping they wanted to count coup, injure and disappear.

It didn‚Äôt seem terribly bright. I didn‚Äôt want to let them count coup or do worse. We‚Äôd made a pledge to Houndstooth‚Äôs group.

Sveta‚Äôs hands appeared out of nowhere, grabbing Hookline by the ankles. He fell hard on the initial tug, and was then dragged beneath a parked car.

The hook moved, lashing out. It caught on the corner of a building, Hookline‚Äôs attempt to haul himself free.

My focus in the moment was on Kitchen Sink.

I landed so I was a foot behind him, pushing out with my aura.

‚ÄúRun,‚Äù I said.

He turned, wheeling around with hand drawn back, a rather large, full bottle of alcohol gripped by the neck—

I smashed my forehead into his nose. When he didn‚Äôt immediately go down, I did it again. I didn‚Äôt give him a chance to recover from there. My forcefield was down throughout the process, as I stayed within a foot of him, my aura buzzing with the range pulled closer to me, active and focused on him.

I could fly, so I didn‚Äôt need footing. I used it when I had it, to give a little more oomph when I punched him in the stomach, but at the times I would have needed to pause to get my feet in the right places under me, flight drove me forward. Punch, knee to his stomach, a shove against his shoulder, as he drew the connected arm back to swing with the bottle or use his power to throw it point-blank.

He realized he couldn‚Äôt draw either weapon back, and dropped the plastic jug, jabbing at me instead. He hit me in the ribs, and it hurt.

I hit him in the nose, and I was willing to bet it hurt more.

He realized what was happening, and compensated with an exaggerated step back, anticipating he‚Äôd be pushed away, the foot would arrest that movement.

I brought my hand close to his face as I flew up, and he shielded it.

He was trying not to fall down, but with his feet planted far apart—

I flew down, my foot striking on his thigh, close to the pelvis. It forced him into awkward almost-splits.

My hand on the back of his head, I pushed his face down toward the road. He didn‚Äôt try to stop the movement with his arms out, instead folding his around his face, to shield it.

The impact was hard, elbows striking the road, and from the sound he made, his nose hit the arms that were around his face, and that hurt enough.

Sveta had moved across the street. She stayed low, and her hand snaked out, snatching for Hookline‚Äôs ankles, trying to once again drag him beneath the vehicle, forcing him to clamber or squeeze out.

As I landed on a car roof, intentionally making a sound, he glanced back at me. His face was bound in ripcord or something like it, with a gap for his eyes. It pulled his teeth back so they stood out, perpetually bared.

At least he brushed.

The distraction meant Sveta could get a hold on him. He stabbed an engine block with the hook, to try to arrest his movement, hands on the chain.

I walked over to the hook, and slapped it free. By all rights, I should have destroyed it, but his thing was that he made his weapon invincible, untouchable.

He tried to catch me with it, but Sveta had him and the hook didn‚Äôt reach out as fast as Sveta pulled him beneath a dusty construction vehicle.

I collected a mailbox and a pallet of construction material, and set to blocking off his exits, so he would be stuck beneath the truck until someone got him out.

There were others approaching already.

The fastest of them arrived. Moose. Love Lost. A mismatched pair.

Sveta put out her hand, not extending her arm, and I caught it, clasping her wrist as she clasped mine.

Braindead and Birdbrain had no doubt clued in the local villains. They would also let people know what Hookline and Sink had been intent on doing.

Others sounded like they were just around the corner.

I glanced at Love Lost. The woman who wanted to kill Rain. Who wanted to torture him to death.

Rage. Anger. Hate.

There was so much I didn‚Äôt know about that scenario, but I could see that the sentiment was very much real.

Her claw went to her mask. I had just about no interest in seeing what she could do. I flew skyward and out of reach, bringing Sveta with me.

Hopefully, for just a little bit longer, we would leave them wondering who we were.

Shade — Interlude 4b

Rain climbed down from the back of the pickup truck, slinging his bag over his shoulder with the contents rattling. Two older guys departed at the same time. The truck puttered as Rain walked around to the driver‚Äôs side door. He handed over some bills. The inside of the truck was choked with the smell of cigarettes, and the man at the wheel was partially obscured in the dark and smoke, his features lit by the changing colors of the radio display.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù he said. He didn‚Äôt sound like himself.

He only got a grunt in response. The driver counted the money before putting it aside.

The two older guys approached the window, one of them with a twenty-four pack of beer that looked badly weathered, as if it had sat out in the rain for a month. It was the other that went to the window to pay.

With the settlement being so off the beaten track, the only way to get in and out was to either have a working vehicle or to pay someone to make the drive. Rain was pretty sure that his comings and goings were being reported to people higher up the food chain.

He didn‚Äôt have alternatives, not unless Erin gave him a ride.

He kept his head down and made the walk along the side of the road. Here and there, the packed dirt was loose, not held together by weeds or grass, and his footing slipped. It made the walk a trudge.

It was late, and houses were lit by candle and lamps. Across the field, a tall bonfire blazed. The two guys with the beer were making their way there, climbing over a fence to take the shortest path possible. Were Rain to visit, he‚Äôd see people like Jay. Old enough to mess around and get into trouble, but not yet married. There had been a time when he‚Äôd wanted to be one of the older boys at those little parties.

Were he to visit, he‚Äôd be grudgingly welcomed. He‚Äôd be expected to laugh at the jokes, to agree with the things said, to play along. He would be expected to take the ribbing and jokes at his expense, and there would be a lot. He would be expected to keep to the unspoken contract. Adults let those kinds of gatherings happen because the people who attended played along. They didn‚Äôt complain too much when it came time to do something with or for the sake of the community. The tribe. The gang.

Rain walked, well aware he‚Äôd let the day, afternoon and early evening slip away from him. He‚Äôd left the others and caught a train, and he‚Äôd been unable to bring himself to come back here. ‚ÄòHome‚Äô.

Jittery nervousness had transformed into a dull feeling of dread. That dread leeched into and through him like a poison, as if his realization about his high chance of dying had transformed into something that made him feel like he was being eaten alive, being killed by the dread.

He would have thrown up, if he weren‚Äôt so tense that he wasn‚Äôt sure he could bend over and bring himself to.

He pushed himself forward. Erin‚Äôs house was the next one, and there was light in the window. He trudged onward, the earth at the side of the road giving way beneath his feet, as he sank in, pulled himself up and forward, then sank again in a few steps later.

He would have walked in the middle of the road, but Jay‚Äôs group was out there at the fire drinking, and Rain didn‚Äôt trust them or many of the others to have headlights on and their eyes on the road.

Erin was there, sitting at her window on the second floor. She was keeping an eye out for him, still wearing the shirt with the cross on the front from earlier. The light from her television cast the shadows around her in various shades of green.

She raised a hand in a wave as he drew close enough for the light from the house‚Äôs windows to illuminate him. He raised his own hand.

With the house being at the end of a path, and Erin being on the second floor, her voice was almost inaudible as she asked something. She pointed with him as she asked it, then raised her hand in a barely-visible ok sign.

Was he okay?

Rain stood a very real chance of dying.

He was standing there, not responding, his thoughts tearing through his brain. He had options but none of them were options. If he went to the Wardens for help he would become embroiled in something bigger, because he knew things and he‚Äôd be expected to share those things. The Fallen would target him and there was no guarantee the Wardens could keep him safe. There was a chance it would push away Erin and pull him away from the group, as he was taken to safe custody and expected to testify. There was a chance the revelation would mean Victoria pushed him away, or Sveta did, or even Chris or Kenzie.

He could share with the group, but for many of the same reasons he couldn‚Äôt go to the Wardens, there would be a price. Things would change.

The person online— no guarantees.

Mrs. Yamada — she could offer support, she could help him ask others for help, but there was a limit to what she could do.

Erin repeated the question, calling it across to Rain.

A moment later, she put her book, down, holding her hand out. Telling him to wait.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm okay!‚Äù he called out. He wasn‚Äôt.

Erin reversed direction and put her head out the window. In the background, one of her parents— her mom, it looked like, stepped into her room, standing behind her.

Rain raised a hand in a wave, and Erin‚Äôs mom waved back.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll talk to you tomorrow!‚Äù Rain called out.

‚ÄúYeah!‚Äù Erin replied.

Rain adjusted his bag at his shoulder, then resumed the trudge. The false normal and the lie that he was okay was something that felt almost real, he could hold to it for a short while.

Not for the entire way back. When he did arrive at the edge of the property, with its hastily constructed house, the fenced in yard, and the stable, with a field stretching out behind it, the dread, at least, seemed less pointed.

The knowledge he might die sat heavily, all the same.

He let himself into the house and put his bag by the stairs. Everyone was in the kitchen. His uncle was looking over the paper from earlier in the day. Allie had a crossword and dictionary, and Rain‚Äôs aunt was engaged in what seemed like her neverending stream of tidying-up and tending to the property.

‚ÄúSorry I‚Äôm late,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine,‚Äù his aunt said. ‚ÄúDid you eat?‚Äù

Rain shook his head.

‚ÄúFood‚Äôs on the stove if you want it. If you don‚Äôt, let me know so I can put the leftovers away.‚Äù

Rain got a bowl from the cupboard and approached the stove.

‚ÄúYou look like lukewarm shit, Rain,‚Äù Allie said.

Rain‚Äôs aunt smacked Allie across the back of the head, hard enough that when Allie bent forward, she stayed like that for a few long seconds.

‚ÄúHe does,‚Äù Allie said.

‚ÄúI probably do look like shit,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt mean she needs to say it,‚Äù Rain‚Äôs aunt said. She gave Allie a lighter slap on the back of the head, while Allie was still bent over her crossword.

Rain hadn‚Äôt yet ladled the stew into his bowl.

He couldn‚Äôt do nothing. He needed‚Ä¶ As horrible as this situation was, as horrible as each new thing he learned seemed to make the situation, he needed to figure something out.

‚ÄúUncle,‚Äù he said.

He heard the papers rustle.

‚ÄúFace your uncle if you‚Äôre addressing him,‚Äù his aunt said.

Rain did. His uncle was of average height, muscular as many of the farmers were, with graying blond hair that Rain‚Äôs aunt cut neatly every few days, and very tan, weather-worn skin. The man could have looked so normal and disarming, with a face that might even have looked friendly, but instead he wore a perpetual glower. He never smiled, and he rarely if ever spoke.

There was no light in his uncle. Had Rain not lived with the man for years, he might have said he was a sociopath, just in how he held himself, the look in his eyes, and how joyless his rote existence seemed. If the Fallen needed a job done and wanted able, loyal bodies, Rain‚Äôs uncle would go without question or hesitation.

‚ÄúWould you teach me to fight?‚Äù Rain asked.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt want to do that,‚Äù Allie said.

‚ÄúButt out, Allie,‚Äù his aunt said, hand going up but not delivering another smack. ‚ÄúThis is between boy and man.‚Äù

Rain‚Äôs uncle folded his paper, then stood from his chair, putting it back under the table. He made his exit by the side door, entering into the fenced-in yard, the door left open behind him.

‚ÄúWhat are you waiting for?‚Äù Rain‚Äôs aunt asked. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt keep him waiting.‚Äù

Rain hurried, going back to the bottom stairs where he‚Äôd left his bag. He opened the bag as he reversed direction, heading to the kitchen, fishing in the bag for the things he needed.

He had one mechanical arm out as he passed his aunt and cousin. His aunt was unreadable. Not as dark as his uncle was— his aunt gave the impression the light had been almost entirely extinguished, but the woman could smile, for the rarest of occasions. She had things she cared about and prioritized. Dim or reduced to dark embers, but not gone.

He pressed the arm to his shoulder blade, and felt the connection flare, burning through his nerves to his brain. A small, tiny window opened in his consciousness, with his awareness of the arm and its position. He was aware of the air against the current that ran along the outside ‚Äòskin‚Äô of the arm and hand.

He used the extra arm to help hold the bag while he got the other arm out, slapping it back against the blade of his other shoulder.

His uncle waited by the wooden fence, the perimeter made up of only three broad wooden slats punctuated by the stout posts.

Standing there, illuminated only by the porchlight, his uncle gave no impression there had ever been a light there at all.

Rain had two more arms to connect, but they were smaller, attached at the elbow, only reaching as far as his wrist. They were older and he‚Äôd tuned them back up to working order with the intention of leaving one for Kenzie to study. He‚Äôd forgotten, in his haste to leave.

He approached his uncle. When he got within three or so paces, his uncle took a step toward him. No prelude, no intent apparent in his action. With a second long stride, the man reached out to shove Rain‚Äôs shoulder hard, pushing him toward the fence.

Rain cast out the emotion power around them, and felt the feedback buzz, the faint response that let him know the power was working.

That done, he reached up. His normal hand grabbed his uncle‚Äôs wrist. A mechanical hand grabbed his uncle‚Äôs elbow, fingers digging in there, in an attempt to force it to bend. The smallest hand grabbed for two fingers, pulling them backward.

His uncle pulled his hand up and away, and then kicked Rain in the thigh.

Rain fell, his mechanical hands were too slow to let go, and he could see as the two right arms came apart in pieces, wires stretching between wrist and forearm, forearm and elbow, before snapping. The individual parts fell to the shadows and grass.

His uncle kicked him while he was down, boot to ribs.

Rain reached for the pieces, picking them up with two left hands. The forearm, broken at the front, was almost like a broken bottle. He scrambled back, two broken pieces of his arms held in his real hand and his one remaining, full-size mechanical arm.

He dismissed the emotion effect, re-cast it out, just to ensure it was over his uncle. Not that it seemed to do much. He‚Äôd tried letting it sit on people and some of the farm animals before. It didn‚Äôt work. He could only hope there was some nuance he could use.

Fuck, his ribs and leg hurt where he‚Äôd been kicked.

His uncle walked away, his back to Rain. He approached the fence, then reached over it. Allie wasn‚Äôt far away. She‚Äôd gone through the gate and was leaning against the outside of the fence, watching.

A shovel. Rain‚Äôs uncle had picked up the shovel that had been leaning against the fence, almost as long as Rain was tall, with a spade-shaped head. There was an implicit ‚Äòif you‚Äôre going to wield a weapon, so am I‚Äô to the act.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt kill him,‚Äù Rain‚Äôs aunt said, from the stairs to the kitchen.

Rain‚Äôs uncle turned, and gave Rain‚Äôs aunt a long, slow look.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to have to explain it to the leadership,‚Äù she said.

Rain‚Äôs uncle reversed his grip on the shovel, holding it near the spade-end with both hands.

Rain backed away a little as his uncle approached.

The first swing of the shovel was preliminary, measuring distance. Swung like a baseball bat, it made the ‚Äòwhoosh‚Äô sound as it sliced through the air. If Rain hadn‚Äôt leaned back, it might have connected with his nose.

Rain lunged forward. He had smaller weapons.

His uncle didn‚Äôt swing the shovel back the other way. Instead, moving his hand up to grip it at the middle, he swung it so the upper end caught Rain‚Äôs mechanical arm, the lower end caught his wrist.

The mechanical arm broke with the impact, the shattered forearm dropping from its grip.

Rain felt the pain of the impact against his wrist as something that extended along his entire forearm, through his hand, tingling in his fingers.

He knew how to throw a punch, and with his uncle holding nothing back, he had no reason to do so either. He closed the distance, his chest connecting with his uncle‚Äôs as he punched low, aiming for the stomach, just beneath the ribs. Repeated blows, strikes with fist sharp against muscle and fat.

Fingers tangled in his hair, gripped tighter until Rain‚Äôs scalp hurt. He was pulled away, then without the hand letting go, he was flung into the fence, cheekbone and shoulder crashing into the broad plank closer to the top.

He was pulled away, not allowed to get his balance, and then thrust toward the fence again.

He used his mover power to arrest the push, to make himself stop. He drove his elbow into his uncle‚Äôs arm, where only the connection pad and the shattered remnants of the arm remained, raking the damaged metal and wire against flesh.

His uncle pulled away, and Rain was there, suspended for another second.

Rain couldn‚Äôt cancel out his mover power before his uncle got his footing and came back at him, driving a knee into his middle. He crashed into the fence and landed hard.

He hauled himself to his feet, one hand on the fence, and his uncle kicked him before he was entirely there. A kick at the armpit, so Rain‚Äôs hand couldn‚Äôt support him any longer. His mover power wasn‚Äôt available to stop him from falling, and— and it wouldn‚Äôt have mattered in the slightest if it were.

The pain radiated through him, now. His uncle stood tall, one hand at his arm, which was bleeding, and paced. The feedback Rain got wasn‚Äôt accurate enough to let him know where his uncle was, and it was hard to find a position where he could look up and over.

He grabbed the fence and heaved himself to his feet.

His uncle looked at his aunt, and Rain took that as an opportunity to sprint full-bore for the man. He leaped, heedless of personal risk, of the fall that might follow, and kicked sideways with all of his force.

He connected, shin to side. He saw the pain on his uncle‚Äôs face. Then he used his power to suspend himself, before he could tumble hard to the ground.

It suspended him for too long. There was no canceling it, and however long it lasted, a second and a half, two seconds, maybe even approaching three seconds, it was enough time for his uncle to turn his way and kick him, hard.

Rain dropped, in too much pain to calculate how he broke free of the power‚Äôs hold, and landed in the grass and dirt.

He was kicked several times while he was down. Back, buttock, leg. He wasn‚Äôt sure if he‚Äôd been kicked sharply in the side or if it was only the way he‚Äôd recoiled and made an existing wound pull that made it feel like it.

His mechanical hands broke at the slightest excuse, his emotion power didn‚Äôt do anything he could identify, and his mover power made him a sitting duck in any real combat situation.

The kicking had stopped. Rain lay there, his breaths coming out as wheezes. His thoughts were so mired in sick hopelessness that he could barely think straight.

A hand was extended. It seized Rain by the upper arm, firm, and heaved him to his feet.

It occurred to Rain, too late, that his uncle wasn‚Äôt the kind of person to offer a helping hand.

Still firmly holding Rain‚Äôs upper arm, with Rain bent over, his uncle struck him across the face. It was only the fierce grip on Rain‚Äôs arm that kept him from being knocked to the ground yet again.

Again, Rain was struck across the face. His head sagged.

The next hit caught him backhanded, across the ear. It was impossibly loud, painful, and it made his thoughts dissolve into sparks. His ear rang like a siren in the wake of the hit.

Rain, almost insensate, punched in the general direction of his uncle‚Äôs stomach, turned his face toward the ground so it would be away of any further blows, and kept punching blind until his uncle let him go.

Rain stumbled back, snorted, coughed, and tried to straighten, before giving up on the latter. He put his hand on his knee to steady himself.

His uncle approached, and Rain backed up. His uncle‚Äôs turn to return the favor, now. Swats, a knee, a punch, a shove. Even the lighter contact was painful, because Rain hurt, and each light contact forced him to move one way or the other while existing bruises and injuries punished those movements.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Rain managed, huffing out the word. ‚ÄúStop.‚Äù

His uncle didn‚Äôt stop, pushing out with both hands to shove Rain back into the wooden fence.

With an edge of desperation, Rain pulled out the silver blades. It didn‚Äôt make his uncle hesitate.

He threw the first blade, and the pain at his armpit altered the trajectory, meant he didn‚Äôt finish the swing. The silver scythe passed through his uncle‚Äôs head, the two remaining pieces carrying forward, sailing out to strike the side of the house.

A silver line encircling his head, Rain‚Äôs uncle stood there, drawing in a deep breath.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Rain said. He hunched over, hands on his knees, coughed, then snorted. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt sneeze or do anything. That‚Äôs all. Thank you.‚Äù

His uncle remained where he was, glowering, eye sockets only barely illuminated by the silver light from the mark.

The mark would fade soon. Ten, twelve seconds. Rain watched and waited, nervous of the possibility of disaster.

The silver line thinned out, went away. Rain‚Äôs uncle touched his face. A moment later, the man strode toward Rain, a dark look on his face.

‚ÄúStop,‚Äù Rain said, voice weak. He realized the futility of it as he said it. His uncle didn‚Äôt intend to stop until one of them was unable to move.

The other blade still in his hand, he threw it out, with the blade only traveling a matter of feet before it crossed through his uncle‚Äôs midsection, the vertical and horizontal lines of the plaid work shirt illuminated in the gloom.

‚ÄúStop,‚Äù Rain said, again. ‚ÄúOr you‚Äôll die.‚Äù

His uncle looked down, spreading his hands.

Then, his expression changing, the man looked skyward, sighing. Rain took the twelve seconds of rest to try to gather his thoughts, not looking skyward, but toward the ground. He—

Heedless of the mark, his uncle kicked him. The force was such that the silver mark flared, and it cut what lay beneath.

Again and again, the man kicked Rain. He stomped once, as Rain lay too close to the ground to be properly kicked.

‚ÄúI think he learned whatever it is you wanted to teach him,‚Äù Rain‚Äôs aunt said. ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you come inside? I‚Äôll make you tea, and I‚Äôll look over those scratches.‚Äù

Rain waited, knowing that if his uncle decided to ignore the order, there would only be more pain. Pain that could kill him, if it meant he wasn‚Äôt able to fight back when Snag, Cradle, and Love Lost came for his head.

Instead, fabric draped over Rain‚Äôs head.

‚ÄúReplace it,‚Äù his uncle said. Perhaps the eleventh and twelfth words Rain had ever heard the man say to him.

Rain reached up and pulled the fabric away. The plaid shirt. Sliced across the middle. His uncle was fine, because—

Because, Rain realized, closing his eyes, the power only affected one thing at a time. It would hit clothes first, the person second.

He opened his eyes to watch as his uncle walked away, wearing an undershirt and jeans, opening the door to the kitchen and closing it behind him, the light in the fenced-in yard diminishing with the door closed.

Rain lay there, trying to breathe, hurting from head to toe.

‚ÄúDad doesn‚Äôt even have powers,‚Äù Allie said, from the other side of the fence.

Rain winced, realizing she‚Äôd seen. She was still there.

‚ÄúYou did better when you weren‚Äôt using your powers,‚Äù his cousin said. She paused. ‚ÄúYou okay?‚Äù

Rain‚Äôs nose felt stuffed, every heartbeat making his entire nasal cavity pound. He snorted, hard, and pain ripped through his skull, blood spraying the grass in front of his face. He huffed out a breath.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm—‚Äù he started. ‚ÄúFine.‚Äù

He was going to die. Not here, not because of this. But he was going to die.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure what you were expecting,‚Äù Allie said. ‚ÄúDad is the kind of guy who thought he‚Äôd teach five year old me how to swim by throwing me into a pond. I think this is him applying that same principle to teaching you to fight.‚Äù

Rain huffed out a breath. His ribs hurt like hell, but—

He drew in a deep breath, winced at the pain.

Not broken. He‚Äôd had broken ribs before.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if you were around then, but when mom had cancer, it was just dad and me and a couple cousins in the house. He‚Äôd do stuff like tell us to sweep, and if we didn‚Äôt sweep right, he‚Äôd give us the belt. He wouldn‚Äôt even tell us what we did wrong or why we didn‚Äôt meet expectations. We had to figure it out.‚Äù

‚ÄúI remember,‚Äù Rain managed. ‚ÄúI was there.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen why the hell did you think this was a good idea? There are other people you can ask. That you have been asking, unless you‚Äôve been lying to us. You could have gone to them.‚Äù

‚ÄúI could have. I wanted—‚Äù Rain coughed. ‚ÄúI wanted this.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis? Oh, you‚Äôve gone and lost your mind.‚Äù

Maybe, Rain thought. Maybe he had. He‚Äôd fit right in, if he had. But he‚Äôd wanted, needed to know if, when he was desperate and in very real danger, there was anything he could pull out or do.

There wasn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúYou sure you don‚Äôt need help?‚Äù Allie asked.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll manage,‚Äù Rain said, his voice coming out strained. He fumbled out with one hand, reaching for the fence.

It took him some time to get to his feet. He ended up leaning against the fence, hugging it, while trying to breathe properly.

He was pretty sure the dread and emotion in him was enough that he could have thrown up if he‚Äôd tried to. He was also pretty sure he would black out if he did.

A truck roared as it rolled down the dirt road, moving too fast in the dark. That would be why Rain walked on the side of the road when he walked that way in the dark.

‚ÄúRain,‚Äù Allie said.

‚ÄúMm?‚Äù

‚ÄúI know we‚Äôre not close. I‚Äôve probably been shitty to you.‚Äù

‚ÄúBetter than a lot of people,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúI mean I‚Äôm not in a position to ask any favors from you,‚Äù she said.

Leaning over the fence, still hugging it, he stared down at the dark grass on the other side. He didn‚Äôt respond.

‚ÄúBut I really, really need you to get your shit together,‚Äù his cousin said.

He winced, closing his eyes. He opened them almost immediately, because he worried he might black out.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve turned some heads and drawn a lot of attention,‚Äù Allie said. ‚ÄúYou managed to do something nobody really thought was possible. You put a rung on the ladder that‚Äôs even lower than the unpowered. The person with powers that suck. Because if you have shit powers, you‚Äôre not going to trigger and get other powers. You have no chance.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Rain said. He barked out a couple of coughs, feeling a stabbing in his sides with each one.

‚ÄúI really, really need you to figure something out,‚Äù Allie said. ‚ÄúIf you need something from me to help you figure it out, I can try helping. But I need you to be‚Ä¶ not this.‚Äù

He focused on breathing, absorbing the words.

‚ÄúYou know why I‚Äôm asking, right?‚Äù

He nodded slowly, mindful of the throbbing headache, pounding in his ear, and his sinuses. He wasn‚Äôt sure if she could see him in the gloom.

‚ÄúNobody really wants you as a husband for their daughter, or as a husband for them. They‚Äôll go through the motions but they don‚Äôt want you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúSooner or later, they‚Äôre going to get fed up with you. Then they‚Äôll try pairing you up with someone and getting some babies out of you, see if those kids end up being worth anything in a few years. When they do, nobody‚Äôs going to jump at the chance to be with you or marry their kid to you.‚Äù

Rain winced, tried to stand straighter.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôll look back and forth and everyone will avoid eye contact, and then their eyes will settle on my mom and dad. They‚Äôll pair me up with you, because that‚Äôs who mom and dad are. They‚Äôre dutiful, and they‚Äôve sunk so much into this that they aren‚Äôt going to stop believing anytime soon.‚Äù

He knew it to be true. He‚Äôd worried about it.

‚ÄúAnd don‚Äôt go thinking of Erin. I know you like her. I know you probably hold out some secret hope you‚Äôll get paired up with her.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine if you do. Everyone probably does. She‚Äôs hot. But it‚Äôs because she‚Äôs hot that she‚Äôs going to end up with some forty year old guy close to the leadership, or she‚Äôs going to run. Give up on her now. If you don‚Äôt, I won‚Äôt just be the pity incest wife, I‚Äôm going to be the pity incest wife with a heartbroken husband.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou could leave.‚Äù

‚ÄúEveryone thinks they‚Äôll leave if it looks like they‚Äôre going to get a bad pairing. How many actually do? When things are close to that point, they start keeping a closer eye on you. You get asked to have a chat with the leadership. They don‚Äôt leave you the choice.‚Äù

Rain used the fence to help himself stay upright as he limped toward the kitchen.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to be one of the idiots that thinks she can get away,‚Äù Allie said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm making peace with it.‚Äù

He paused as he saw the shadows of his destroyed tinker arms.

Slowly, he began working his way toward the ground, so he could pick up the pieces.

‚ÄúStop,‚Äù Allie said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs painful to watch you. Let me.‚Äù

He let her.

She hopped the fence, walked over to the shadows, and bent down, feeling out for the pieces and picking them up.

‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt going to zap me or anything, is it?‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt—‚Äù Rain paused. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt touch the oblong pieces, the thin ones. Hold them by the stems with the wires, or the shoulders.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

Gingerly, Allie collected most of the pieces. She handed them over to Rain. He took the contact pad that had ripped away and switched it off before gathering it into his arm with the torn shirt.

Allie gave him the last piece, then kept her hand on top of it.

‚ÄúFigure it the fuck out, Rain,‚Äù she said.

I‚Äôll die, I‚Äôll get killed by my cluster, and I won‚Äôt be a concern for you anymore, he thought, staring into the little dots where her eyes were reflecting the distant fire.

I‚Äôll die, he thought. I can‚Äôt fight my unpowered uncle. How can I fight‚Ä¶ all of that?

‚ÄúI‚Äôll try,‚Äù he said.

The door opened. Rain‚Äôs aunt.

‚ÄúAllie, there you are. Inside. Get the bigger first aid kit from the basement. I want to patch up your dad‚Äôs cuts, and the smaller kit doesn‚Äôt have any bandages.‚Äù

Allie turned to go, obedient.

‚ÄúIf you want first aid, Rain, knock on the master bedroom door, or go straight to Allie. She‚Äôll tend to you. For now, get yourself to bed. You‚Äôre coming to church in the morning.‚Äù

Rain swayed slightly on the spot, then said, ‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

The door closed behind his aunt.

He got to his bag and dumped the pieces of the arm into it. Picking it up, he made his way inside. The stew had been put away. No dinner.

He went up the stairs and into his room. He settled in at his desk. The day‚Äôs homework was on the table, waiting to be done.

Slowly, he set out the pieces of his tinker hands.

Days worth of work.

No secret to be uncovered, no use he hadn‚Äôt yet figured out. Not legs, not claws.

This, these fragile things, they were the only things that came to mind when he reached out for his tinker power. Between ten and thirty minutes passed while he found all the smaller pieces, setting them in the right places. He had some wire and tools on his desk, and he got them out. To start with, he would fix everything he could fix in five seconds. Then he would move on from there.

The spell was broken as his alarm clock buzzed. He always set it for the evening, not the morning, because there was a timeframe.

He started to rise to his feet, but he‚Äôd been sitting still too long, while hurt too badly. His body refused to cooperate.

With inching progress, he made his way toward the alarm clock.

‚ÄúRain!‚Äù his aunt called out from the other room. ‚ÄúShut it off!‚Äù

Inching progress, shuffling steps.

He made it to the alarm clock, but not to the bed.

Rain‚Äôs consciousness was snuffed out like a candle.

‚äô

Cradle.

His dreams are strange.

A hand slamming down on the table, a paper beneath it. A mouth opening. A man that might have been Cradle‚Äôs father spoke, but it wasn‚Äôt words that came out. It was the frantic cries of the crowd, the screams, the shouted jumble.

The paper crumpled slightly as the hand on it closed into more of a fist.

In the background, a very prim and proper woman stood with her back to Cradle.

The parents, Rain interpreted. Disappointment and anger. I can understand that.

The scene changed. A balding man in a suit, sitting across from a desk. The bulletin board behind him had child‚Äôs artwork on it.

His expression was plaintive, worried. The words from that somber older man‚Äôs face were the scream of someone that had been burned, stopping as lips closed together, starting as they parted. His hand moved more papers, sorting through the pile in front of him.

Cradle‚Äôs point of view moved, shaking left and right as he shook his head.

The balding older man‚Äôs expression changed from worry to something stronger. Upset. Deep concern.

The principal, Rain interpreted. He‚Äôd seen variations on this. It was usually like this, or else smoke, rubble, or broken glass poured from people‚Äôs mouths instead of words. Cradle wasn‚Äôt doing so well?

He could understand that too.

It‚Äôs even of a similar vein. Unrealized potential, as far as I can understand it. Report cards, teachers, father figures, they want something from him and he doesn‚Äôt deliver. He doesn‚Äôt hand it over.

Then the long hallway. The trudge. Cradle‚Äôs hand was visible as he reached up to fix his glasses, as he reached out to the window. In the distance, far away, the sounds of disaster could be heard. The stampede, the fire.

School again? A lonely hallway? Isolation? I used to call him the recluse.

Cradle took off his glasses, and all was a blur. When he put them back on, he was facing teenaged peers.

Their faces moved as if they were shouting, expressions twisting. The only sound to come out was that of the stampede. Feet tromping, people shouting with words blending into one another. Teeth came together as a word was finished, and the sound was of a bone breaking. One of the teenagers pushed Cradle down. His glasses were set ajar by the fall.

This time, as he fixed the glasses, he was in the shopping center, standing.

Things moved as if in slow motion. Inevitable.

What does Cradle feel when he‚Äôs here? Dread?

Cradle‚Äôs head turned, everything moving as if it was underwater, as he looked at a group of men and women with tattoos. They were loud, too loud, as they gathered together, talking among themselves.

He looked the other way. He saw other faces. Faces that would be in the crowd shortly. A couple that were about thirty years old. Then an older man and woman.

The old couple get trampled early on, Rain thought.

Eyes roved slow-motion in the other direction. In a store with colorful graphic images in frames, and other things in glass cases, a big guy with long hair, a nose ring and an impressive beard was talking to an older man, while tapping one of the framed cartoon images. No sound came out of his mouth as his lips moved.

Images like this would be the best Rain would get at seeing Snag‚Äôs face uncovered.

There were others. The twelve year old girl with her friends, that Snag would fail to help. She would die in the crush, after slipping from Snag‚Äôs grip.

A lot of the children and elderly in the mall would be counted among the dead.

One of the three girls said her goodbye to her friends. The movement was slow motion as she ran across the plaza of the mall.

She was smiling as she approached the woman who waited for her. The smile fell from her face, she slowed, then hung her head.

The woman showed the girl her watch, tapped it, her words were stern and entirely unheard. There was only silence in this slow motion prelude to the event.

The woman with wavy red hair, a sweater that failed to hide her impressive chest, and an ankle-length skirt. Heads turned to watch her berate the child. The child looked nervously back at her friends.

Love Lost.

Things accelerated, as the scene rushed forward. Everyone to their positions.

Three explosions in quick succession, loud after the silence, the blasts tearing across the plaza the opening of one of the exits. Blue flame.

Then the movement, everyone trying to get away. The layout of the shopping center allowed only one good escape route, and everyone rushed for it.

Another acceleration, skipping ahead in time. The sound of the stampede, the crowd, all of the noises that had been made or hinted at earlier, now came to the forefront, crashing into the present moment. Cradle was close to the front of the crowd. He was shoved, he tried to catch his balance, and he fell. His glasses came away from his face, they were stepped on.

Twice, he reached for the glasses, and his hands were stepped on. There was a desperation in it, more of a struggle to get them than there was even an attempt to stand. The scene was blurred but his hands were as clear as anything.

Close by, a woman screamed, and the sound was prolonged, multi-part.

He found his glasses and put them to his face with bleeding fingers. He was kicked, stepped on.

Did I subconsciously take myself there? Rain thought.

He reached up, hand extended.

Pleading for help, reaching and unanswered, Rain interpreted.

How did all of what came before lead into this?

‚äô

Rain was in the room. He picked up the chair.

He didn‚Äôt venture a response. He knew what the answer would be.

He didn‚Äôt really want to face the others, either. They were the people who wanted him tortured to death.

For now, he sat in the chair. There was no reason to stand. He didn‚Äôt even need to find his three tokens. It wasn‚Äôt as if he was giving them away, or getting anything.

His power would be what it was.

Snag approached the table, clearing away the debris, finding his glass. He turned to stare at Rain.

Rain wanted to answer that stare, wanted to provoke. He stared across to Cradle‚Äôs space instead. He breathed deep, none of the injuries from earlier present. They appeared as they were, in a way. Snag in the same sorts of clothing, partially hiding his appearance, never looking like he‚Äôd just come from work. Cradle wore civilian clothes. Love Lost‚Ä¶

Love Lost rose from the chair. Still wearing the muzzle-mask, still wearing the dress with the slit up the side, the heels, her nails painted. She never took off the mask, now, so it was enough of a part of her to be brought into this space.

Her eyes were downcast as she approached the dais and gripped the edge. She only lifted her eyes to stare Rain down. Abject hatred.

It felt like an hour passed before Snag spoke.

‚ÄúCradle. I‚Äôd like the coins before we run out of time.‚Äù

Cradle came from around the corner of one of the concrete slabs. He looked worse for wear.

It‚Äôs always harder when it‚Äôs your night, Rain thought.

Cradle found the coins, gripped them in one hand, and slammed the hand against the invisible barrier that separated his section from Snag‚Äôs. Snag caught one out of the air before it could hit the floor. The other two landed on the flat surface of the dais.

‚ÄúYou know what the shittiest part of this thing is?‚Äù Cradle asked.

Cradle always liked to talk on his nights.

‚ÄúYou infected us,‚Äù Cradle said, looking at Rain. ‚ÄúWe each got a piece of each other.‚Äù

‚ÄúBleed-through,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúSo you‚Äôve done some research,‚Äù Cradle said. ‚ÄúWe were pretty decent people before. Love Lost yelled at her daughter, but—‚Äù

Love Lost‚Äôs hand slammed against the dais.

‚ÄúBut she wasn‚Äôt evil,‚Äù Cradle said. He turned to Love Lost. ‚ÄúSorry.‚Äù

Love Lost glared at him.

‚ÄúSnag was even a bit of a hero,‚Äù Cradle said.

Snag sighed. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt really think so.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe girl you helped? Friend of Love Lost‚Äôs daughter? Come on,‚Äù Cradle said.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think so,‚Äù Snag said, looking away.

‚ÄúWe were decent people,‚Äù Cradle said. ‚ÄúAnd now we‚Äôre not. Because of you. Because you‚Äôre infecting us.‚Äù

Rain looked away.

‚ÄúKill yourself,‚Äù Cradle said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want any piece of you in me. Just‚Ä¶ wake up and kill yourself. You can‚Äôt be happy with the Fallen. So just end it. Kill yourself. Everything becomes easier.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to do that, and I‚Äôm not with the Fallen,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúNot anymore.‚Äù

‚ÄúKill yourself,‚Äù Cradle said. ‚ÄúAt least that way it‚Äôll be easy.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you listening to me?‚Äù Rain asked.

‚ÄúKill yourself,‚Äù Cradle said. ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt, then some time, maybe a month from now, maybe a year, we‚Äôll come for you. We‚Äôll take all of that ugliness you gave us and we‚Äôll give it back. With interest.‚Äù

The coins rattled in Snag‚Äôs hand.

‚ÄúKill yourself,‚Äù Cradle said.

Love Lost‚Äôs fingernails clicked against the top of the dais.

‚ÄúKill yourself,‚Äù Cradle said.

The fingernails clicked.

Rain stood, turned with his back to the dais, venturing further into his section of the room.

A bang made him turn. Cradle had slammed his hand against the dais.

‚ÄúPay attention,‚Äù Cradle said. ‚ÄúAnd kill yourself.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou think I‚Äôm going to listen to you?‚Äù Rain asked. ‚ÄúBecause you say it over and over?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think if I say it often enough, there‚Äôs a chance it‚Äôll catch you when you‚Äôre weak. It could cross your mind at a critical time. It‚Äôs a small chance, maybe, but I‚Äôm not doing anything else with the rest of my night. I could keep it up tomorrow night, or the night after. I could come up with something else.‚Äù

Nails clicked against the dais.

‚ÄúKill yourself,‚Äù Cradle said.

‚äô
