The church service concluded. The speakers rotated on the regular, and today‚Äôs was Mrs. May. She was a respected figure in the community, but she wasn‚Äôt respectable. She was a harpy of a person, with a shrill voice and a grating laugh she was inclined to use at the slightest provocation, and most people either loved her and her rhetoric, or they despised her. She performed a lot of sermons, usually with plenty of warning to others and often with women in attendance. Much of what she said appealed to that crowd.

Rain took some small solace in the fact that because his aunt and uncle had made him come, they had been obligated to sit through this. They weren‚Äôt part of Mrs. May‚Äôs sub-congregation.

He wanted nothing more than to go, to get to his workshop, and to do what little he could to prepare. As he made his way to the door, however, his aunt was caught up in a conversation with one of Mrs. May‚Äôs group. Oh, wasn‚Äôt the sermon so delightful? The word choice here, the passage, wasn‚Äôt it perfect? Rain was here, that was unusual, was Rain married off yet? No? What about Allie? Surely Allie had suitors.

Different preachers to appeal to different crowds, with diehard adherents attending every sermon. It didn‚Äôt matter that the ideas contradicted, that the sermon the nervous Reverend Patman gave to a small congregation of Mrs. Sims‚Äô type was the polite kind of message that could be heard elsewhere, while the inappropriately dressed Mrs. May preached how wives had the duty of keeping their husbands‚Äô balls drained, prostates massaged, and stomachs full.

The people who wanted to believe believed, and Mrs. Sims‚Äô type stayed because‚Ä¶ Rain wasn‚Äôt entirely sure. Because there was a safety in madness, maybe. Part of why he stayed, really. Or because leaving and trying to forge a life elsewhere was harder than staying and ignoring the ugliness and contradiction. Harder than lying to herself and thinking she could bring order to this chaos.

Rain walked through the door to the overcast outside. Allie joined him, her eyes widening slightly in the only communication she would give him that she didn‚Äôt agree with the sermon or the crowd.

‚ÄúHi Allie,‚Äù a guy said. He was about eighteen, his tousled blond hair was grown out, and he had a natural smile with a mouth that seemed too wide.

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù Allie said, shy. She looked down.

‚ÄúHi Rain. You look like you went to war and you fought your way through the entire enemy line.‚Äù

‚ÄúHi Lachlan. I think that might just be the politest way anyone could describe this,‚Äù Rain said.

Lachlan chuckled.

‚ÄúYou guys are just‚Ä¶ hanging out here?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre waiting for a ride,‚Äù Allie said. ‚ÄúI think Rain would rather get a ride than walk, after fighting through that battlefield you described.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can give you guys a ride,‚Äù Lachlan offered.

‚ÄúNo thank you,‚Äù Allie said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a dear, but I‚Äôll just wait for my parents.‚Äù

Lachlan twisted his head around. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre caught in conversation with the Screeching Mimis.‚Äù

‚ÄúShh! Lachlan!‚Äù Allie shushed him. Some heads had turned.

Lachlan grinned. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just saying, they‚Äôre going to be a while. Once those four get their hooks in, people can‚Äôt get away for half an hour or more, and with your parents not being regulars, there‚Äôs a lot to catch them up on.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt underestimate my mom and dad,‚Äù Allie said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre stern stock.‚Äù

‚ÄúI will keep that in mind,‚Äù Lachlan said, smiling like he‚Äôd been let in on a secret. He looked at Rain. ‚ÄúYou want a ride?‚Äù

Rain looked at Allie.

‚ÄúGo,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs embarrassing being seen next to you when you‚Äôre this beat up.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Lachlan asked. ‚ÄúBe fair, come on. Rain‚Äôs one of the esteemed. He‚Äôs blessed with power. He‚Äôs like nobility around here.‚Äù

‚ÄúBastard nobility, maybe,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre blessed,‚Äù Lachlan said, voice firm. He smiled, then said, ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm your humble, obedient servant that would be glad to take you anywhere you want to go. I‚Äôm at your service.‚Äù

Rain glanced again at Allie. ‚ÄúIf you could give me a ride to the machine shop, I‚Äôd be grateful.‚Äù

‚ÄúAbsolutely. Bye Allie.‚Äù

‚ÄúBye.‚Äù

Lachlan led Rain to his car. It was a nice one, a sleek blue sedan, roughly five years old, and in near-pristine condition considering it had survived the end of the world. Rain got in the passenger seat with a wince and a grunt.

Every part of him hurt.

He could remember being in the room, the repeated words, and he dreaded tomorrow. Every moment that passed ratcheted up the dread.

Being hurt and facing a night like that magnified the fact that he didn‚Äôt feel rested. Even naps were beyond him, when his thoughts were this disturbed.

He looked over at Lachlan, and felt a twinge of sadness.

The car whisked its way along the road, slowing here and there to give a wider berth to the people walking on either side.

‚ÄúYou like Allie, huh?‚Äù Rain asked.

Lachlan laughed. ‚ÄúYeah. It‚Äôs part of why I asked you if you wanted a ride. I‚Äôm at your disposal if you need anything at all, though. Don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm disloyal or selfish.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúI sort of hoped I could give her a ride too and have a chat.‚Äù

‚ÄúI guessed that too.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou know how I‚Äôm sort of the poster boy for the Fallen?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm eighteen, and I‚Äôm of a good age for marriage. They say I‚Äôve really helped out, so I can have my pick of almost anyone. I made it really clear I don‚Äôt want anyone who doesn‚Äôt want me, and the leadership told me anyone I took would come to love me in time. That‚Äôs how it works.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúBut I‚Äôd rather have someone who wants me, still. So I was wondering, you know‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúIf Allie was interested?‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you think she is?‚Äù

‚ÄúI could tell you,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs only what I think. With something as serious and binding as marriage, you‚Äôd want to be sure. I can ask her outright, then pass it on to you.‚Äù

Lachlan chuckled. ‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you want.‚Äù

‚ÄúNow I‚Äôm nervous. Yes. Yes! She‚Äôs great, you know. There was a campfire a month ago—‚Äù

‚ÄúYou heard her playing guitar?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe sang. She doesn‚Äôt like singing because some of the others, like Jay— don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm disloyal‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine.‚Äù

‚ÄúJay and some of the others make fun of her singing, or they join in and she hates that. But her singing is really nice. It was a small group, just a few of us, and we listened, and I think I fell in love with her right then. If I could listen to her sing for the rest of my life, I‚Äôd treat her like a queen.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll ask her. I‚Äôll tell her some of that, if you don‚Äôt mind it.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes. Sure. I‚Äôm nervous now,‚Äù Lachlan said. ‚ÄúI was also wondering— she‚Äôs not necessarily the only one I‚Äôm considering.‚Äù

Rain‚Äôs heart sank.

‚ÄúDo you know Nell?‚Äù

‚ÄúI know Nell,‚Äù Rain said, feeling relieved. ‚ÄúJay‚Äôs twin.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe has power too.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you like her?‚Äù

‚ÄúI— she‚Äôs pretty, and she‚Äôs told me she‚Äôs interested.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut do you like her?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe told me she‚Äôs interested, and she‚Äôs close to the leadership. Do you know if I have to say yes?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI might not be the person to ask.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the easiest to talk to.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf they told you that you can pick anyone‚Ä¶ you can probably pick anyone. But Nell might not be a fan of yours afterward.‚Äù

Lachlan frowned.

‚ÄúLet me ask Allie, on the down-low. Maybe if she says no, you go to Nell and act like she‚Äôs the first and last person you considered for a wife.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat if she says yes?‚Äù

‚ÄúThen you would have to decide if having her at your side is worth possibly having Nell be upset with you.‚Äù

Lachlan huffed out a sigh.

‚ÄúThe machine shop is just down the block,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúThank you for talking to me,‚Äù Lachlan said.

Rain looked his way.

Lachlan‚Äôs hand adjusted its position on the steering wheel. His hand trembled a little in the moments where it wasn‚Äôt gripping the wheel.

‚ÄúSure,‚Äù Rain said.

Lachlan pulled the car to a stop. ‚ÄúGotta ask you one more thing, if you don‚Äôt mind giving me a minute of your time.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúYou saved me more than a minute, so I don‚Äôt mind.‚Äù

Lachlan got out of the car as Rain did. In the time it took Rain to work his way to a standing position, Lachlan walked around the front of the vehicle to the side of the road and pulled off his t-shirt.

He turned so his back was to Rain. Rain, in turn, was faced with a tattoo. Words in bold letters, inches-high, shaded, with thick outlines. The first word was just below the nape of his neck, and the last was in the small of his back.

Jesus
Virgin-Mother-Fucking
Christ

Two hands, middle fingers extended, were on Lachlan‚Äôs shoulder blades, the fingers pointing up and outward. Each hand had a nail through the center.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs new. What do you think?‚Äù Lachlan asked. He smiled as he turned to look at Rain over one shoulder.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs big,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt it? It was hell to get it done. Shoulder blades and ribs especially, all in one session.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs‚Ä¶ very high quality. I see a lot of bad tattoos around here, and that‚Äôs‚Ä¶ the lines are straight, and the shading of the letters are good.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen you like it? Awesome. You think Allie would like it?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to speak for her. I can ask her.‚Äù

‚ÄúNah, I‚Äôll show her. I see her at the bonfires a lot. Thanks,‚Äù Lachlan said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll see you around. If you need anything—‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll ask.‚Äù

Lachlan grinned, and got back into his car.

Rain was left only with the deepest feeling of sadness. He was so tired, he ached all over, and his heart ached too. He wanted to tinker, and later, he would reach out to Erin. She would listen, he would give her a tempered version of how his days had been—

The machine shop was badly weathered, not well insulated, and existed primarily as a large shack, with two stories. It was where cars and pieces of equipment were brought to be repaired, with communal tools left for anyone to use.

The second floor, though, was mostly left to Rain. He winced with every step up, then let himself in.

He wasn‚Äôt alone.

Erin was already there, sitting with her knees to her chest, face buried in her arms.

Rain‚Äôs heart sank. A tiny, selfish part of himself bemoaned the fact that it didn‚Äôt stop. That he didn‚Äôt get to rest. It was threats to his life leading into him asking to be beaten to restless nights, church, Lachlan‚Ä¶

He wondered if that was the monstrous part of himself that he‚Äôd passed on to the others. The person he had been felt unrecognizable now, to the point he couldn‚Äôt even say what was him anymore.

Erin was crying. Clever, brave, beautiful, compassionate, caring Erin. Seeing her cry made him want to cry, more than anything else in the past twenty-four hours.

He had never seen her cry and he felt as terrified with the unanswered question of what had done this as he had felt with the threat of being tortured to death.

‚ÄúAre you okay?‚Äù

She jumped slightly at the words. She hadn‚Äôt heard him come in?

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she said. She blinked, and the blink squeezed out a tear. She looked away and wiped the tear away. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry. I know this is your workshop, but I needed to get away.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay. What happened?‚Äù

He didn‚Äôt want to know. He wanted to help her at the same time.

‚ÄúI had a run-in with Tim,‚Äù she said. She swallowed hard.

Tim. Another of Rain‚Äôs uncles. Tim who was Seir, who wore the preserved head of a horse but was the furthest thing from the lithe, athletic form of the horse, and the furthest thing from the attractive form of Seir the demon, as was described in the book some of the preachers liked to recite from. Tim was forty, fat, ugly, and he had standing sufficient that he would run the settlement if the top two people in charge were somehow unable to.

A run-in with Tim. Rain had his suspicions about what had happened. That it had happened to Erin?

‚ÄúI‚Äôd beat the shit out of him if I thought I could,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúYou look like you had the shit beat out of you,‚Äù Erin said. She blinked a few times, wiped away the tears. ‚ÄúAre you okay?‚Äù

He wasn‚Äôt, and he couldn‚Äôt tell her he wasn‚Äôt. Not when she was this upset.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm always a little bruised and scratched.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs more than bruises and scratches.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm okay,‚Äù Rain lied. ‚ÄúAnd you‚Äôre not. Can I do anything?‚Äù

As if that had brought everything back, Erin‚Äôs expression briefly crumpled up. She fixed it with apparent effort, and wiped away at more tears that had been squeezed loose.

She shrugged, and it was very, very apparent to Rain that she was trying to seem cavalier about something that wasn‚Äôt cavalier.

He had such a sick feeling in his chest, seeing this.

‚ÄúEvery time I cross paths with him, he makes comments,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúYeah. That‚Äôs— that‚Äôs Tim.‚Äù

She shrugged. ‚ÄúHe told me I should go to church. Mrs. May is lecturing, I think?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe finished.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd he said Mrs. May could teach me what I needed to know to please a husband.‚Äù

Rain nodded. If she was marrying Tim‚Ä¶

‚ÄúI told him to go fuck himself.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Rain said. He saw her expression and looked away.

‚ÄúI know it was stupid.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt— he has a lot of power. It‚Äôs not that he‚Äôs right, but sometimes you have to keep your head down. Some of these people will kill you if you say the wrong thing. Or worse. Surviving is— it‚Äôs the most important thing.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù she said. She averted her eyes. ‚ÄúI felt like I could, in the moment. There were people nearby. I— he pushed me up against a wall, he threatened me with some pretty vulgar stuff, with the crowd watching.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou need to get out of here,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre— you‚Äôre not Fallen. You‚Äôre decent. You‚Äôre kind. You think. You don‚Äôt believe this stuff. You don‚Äôt deserve this.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt go,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúBecause of Bryce? Your parents?‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course because of them! You don‚Äôt understand!‚Äù

‚ÄúI really don‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy parents are the good, decent people. If I have any good traits it‚Äôs because of them and how they raised me. They— they‚Äôre really kind, they were perfect. They tucked me in at night and they punished me fairly when I was wrong, they— they played with me and sat down to do my homework with me and they really truly loved me. They did everything right, they never embarrassed me.‚Äù

Rain stood there, taking that in. He tried to imagine what it was like.

‚ÄúThey— they talked to me and cared about what I had to say. They— they aren‚Äôt this.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey aren‚Äôt Fallen?‚Äù

‚ÄúThey aren‚Äôt! They‚Äôre‚Ä¶ they‚Äôre scared. The world ended and they lost everything, we lost family and friends and everything they worked for, and they broke down a little. These people got their hooks in and my parents bought it. But they‚Äôre still the same people. They‚Äôll turn around and realize how bad this is‚Ä¶ won‚Äôt they?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know.‚Äù

Fresh tears spilled forth. She buried her face in her folded arms, brought her legs closer.

‚ÄúYou need to get out, save yourself first. Then you can try pulling them out.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think if I do that, I‚Äôll lose them forever,‚Äù she said, her voice muffled.

Rain wasn‚Äôt sure what to say.

He‚Äôd never really had family, certainly not like Erin had described.

Even if she lost them forever, at least she would be okay.

‚ÄúMy dad,‚Äù Erin‚Äôs voice was small, muffled.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe was there, while Tim said all of that stuff. Bryce too. He just stood there. Then he apologized for my behavior.‚Äù

Rain was lost for words. He felt a tear well up and out and wiped it away before Erin could see.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúAfter Tim left, I freaked, and all my dad would say was that I shouldn‚Äôt have provoked him. He said I should go to church like Tim suggested. My dad, Rain. With Bry there.‚Äù

Rain reached out, then withdrew his hand.

‚ÄúI can get a car,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll borrow one, we can go for a drive. We‚Äôll do whatever you want, find your favorite food, talk. Get away from this.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to go out there,‚Äù Erin said. ‚ÄúNot like this. Can I stay here? Please?‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù Rain said. Was it for the best? If she got in a car with him, he wasn‚Äôt sure he would be able to stop driving her away from this. He‚Äôd been born to this, but she hadn‚Äôt.

He still felt lost. He wasn‚Äôt sure what to do.

‚ÄúDo you— can I give you a hug?‚Äù he asked.

She didn‚Äôt even answer. She rose to her feet, walked up to him, and wrapped her arms around him, face buried in his shoulder.

He put his arms around her. He‚Äôd never imagined such a thing could feel so horrible and harrowing. The horribleness didn‚Äôt even have anything to do with his injuries, that every point of contact hurt. It wasn‚Äôt his body that hurt.

Rain stared off into space, feeling much like he imagined the shell-shocked in war-zones to feel.

He thought of Cradle‚Äôs reaching out for help, people stumbling past him, knocking his hand away.

‚äô

‚ÄúHello? Mrs. Yamada speaking.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Rain. I‚Äôm— I‚Äôm really not doing great. Can we talk?‚Äù

‚ÄúI thought you might call. Victoria and Sveta reached out to me. I‚Äôd planned to call you this afternoon to check on you. Listen, I‚Äôm expecting a patient shortly, and I can‚Äôt adjust that. We can talk for a few minutes, or, if it‚Äôs not an emergency, I can call you in an hour and a half, and I can give you a lot more time.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúThe second one.‚Äù

‚ÄúBe easy on yourself, Rain. I‚Äôll call you in an hour and a half.‚Äù

Rain hung up.

He‚Äôd reached out and there was a reach back.

He had that.

Erin was asleep on the other end of the room, on a makeshift bed, Rain‚Äôs spare change of clothes piled atop her as a kind of blanket. Her hand was under her pillow and her gun was in her hand. He wasn‚Äôt sure if she knew he‚Äôd seen her do it.

Cradle had described him as a monster. He wasn‚Äôt sure if he was, but as he sat at his work table, trying to work quietly, he imagined he was willing to become a little more monstrous if it meant saving the likes of Erin from becoming a lost soul like Lachlan.

His tinkering might have been limited, but he had other skills. He‚Äôd survived in places more rustic than this for a time. He could make blades. He could make traps and snares. His scrap with his uncle had taught him he couldn‚Äôt win a fair fight against even the unpowered, not with his powers being what they were.

He‚Äôd draw on every resource he had to keep it from coming down to a fair fight. When he went back to the group tomorrow, it would be with a different mindset.

Shade — 4.6

‚ÄúHelp me understand how this makes any sense at all,‚Äù Natalie said.

We were outside of a bagel place, close to the station nearest the Wardens‚Äô Headquarters. Natalie had bought a salad with chicken bits in it. I‚Äôd never liked eating cold chicken, so I‚Äôd picked up a salad without the extras, and a toasted bagel sandwich with fish, black olives, tomatoes and cream cheese. We sat at a table outside.

Natalie was wearing a shirt with a folded collar under a work-suitable navy-blue sweater, with black slacks. I‚Äôd seen Kenzie wear a similar outfit a few days earlier, though Kenzie had had a skirt, and Kenzie had worn it better.

The group‚Äôs ‚Äòlawyer‚Äô. She was just a student, but mom‚Äôs verdict was that she knew her stuff well enough to serve, and she had a good sense of what was happening in the future.

I explained, ‚ÄúThe area we were surveilling had a team of heroes come through, at our urging. They had a brief interaction with the embedded villain population, suggested they might be sticking around, and then left.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd they were followed? By the entire group of villains?‚Äù

‚ÄúBy two, Hookline and Kitchen Sink,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThey were angry following the discussion, were previously established as exceedingly violent, and they have criminal acts that are awaiting process.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre not in the nine percent?‚Äù

‚ÄúIs it nine, now? I was hoping the number would go up, not down.‚Äù

‚ÄúNine now,‚Äù Natalie said.

‚ÄúThey aren‚Äôt. I think most of the villains in Cedar Point are trying to stay clear of that line,‚Äù I said. I took a bite of my sandwich, then wiped the cream cheese from the corner of my mouth with a flick of my thumb. Thoroughly disappointing.

Nine percent. I‚Äôd known it as the ten percent, which had been a neater, rounder number. With the courts badly behind, only a certain number of crimes and criminals were being rushed through court, and it wasn‚Äôt based on the time of the deed. There was something which might have resembled a balance right now, but it was slipping fast. People wanted to focus on getting themselves sorted out, there was plenty of work with reasonable pay, and the people who thought they could game the system ended up falling into the ten percent. For those who did, the hammer came down hard and decisively.

There was, however, a population of people who‚Äôd realized they could get away with things if they avoided being among the nine or ten percent worst offenders. It seemed to me that the gap was widening as people got more settled in and dissatisfied. I knew some areas were using a lottery system to deter the lesser criminals, choosing the crimes they‚Äôd act on and prosecute by drawing them at random.

‚ÄúDo you and did you know the crimes these two have awaiting process?‚Äù

‚ÄúHookline dangled someone out of a fourth story window. Witnesses saw. He was presumed to be acting as collections for a money lender. The neighbors heard shouting about debt, not when Hookline was there, but in general, with the victim and his partner.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you know this how, if it wasn‚Äôt pursued?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was reported on in the paper for that area, a few months ago. I have a copy of the article on my laptop. I had to take the picture with my phone so it‚Äôs not the best. Do you want to see it?‚Äù

Natalie shook her head. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll believe you.‚Äù

‚ÄúAfter the article there was a reaction to Hookline. Some public gatherings, anger, some backlash against the money lender. Hookline left. No telling if he was made to, fired, or if he wanted something easier. Ended up at Cedar Point.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd the other one? Kitchen Sink.‚Äù

‚ÄúOne of a couple who worked under Beast of Burden, who was crime boss for New Haven. Sink handled collections for the protection racket.‚Äù

‚ÄúAny serious crimes?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe trashed one business in a way that made it very clear his power was at use. He creates semi-random items and flings them around, and the business had a lot of semi-random items flung around, shelves trashed, windows broken.‚Äù

‚ÄúWas anyone hurt?‚Äù

‚ÄúI have no idea,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúVictim didn‚Äôt pursue anything. Authorities aren‚Äôt going to do anything if the victim isn‚Äôt talking.‚Äù

Natalie‚Äôs forehead wrinkled. It was a weird contrast for someone who had a whimsical pixie cut with a curl at the front and oversized glasses, to seem as joyless as she did. She didn‚Äôt seem to like her meal, and she seemed interested but not excited or engaged by this.

I ate more of my bagel sandwich, letting her think. It would have been so much better if it was salmon, but it wasn‚Äôt. The olives were mushy and lacked bite, which made me wonder if they were old, scavenged, imitation, or if they‚Äôd lost something in transport. The worst thing was the bagel — I‚Äôd eaten here before and it had been better then.

‚ÄúYou assaulted and battered two individuals,‚Äù Natalie said.

‚ÄúLet me get my laptop out.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey didn‚Äôt make the first move, by your own admission.‚Äù

‚ÄúTheir intent was clear. They had weapons. I‚Äôll show you the video.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease.‚Äù

I fished my laptop out of my bag, packed up my bagel and set it aside, and set the laptop down so Natalie could see. It was a bit warm from being in my bag and being left on low-energy mode, but the boot-up was fast. I already had the pertinent files and videos in a folder.

‚ÄúFirst video, overhead view. Do you have headphones?‚Äù

‚ÄúI do.‚Äù

I waited until she had them out. She put them on, and I plugged in the jack. I hit the spacebar to start the video. She watched, putting her arm up and over the top of the screen, to shield it from the sun. I offered my own arm to help. The video came in at an angle, zooming in, and showed most of the conversation, followed by Hookline and Sink‚Äôs retreat.

When she started to take off her headphones, I held up a finger, then navigated to the second video. It showed same events, but a better view of Houndstooth‚Äôs group, and then expanded out to show how Hookline and Sink were closing in.

Natalie watched the fight and the follow-up, with Sveta and I retreating. Moose did the work of freeing Hookline from underneath the car I‚Äôd blocked in.

It was hard to see in the noonday sun, especially when I was half-standing, my arm out to help shade the screen, but I could see Hookline‚Äôs reaction, slapping away Moose‚Äôs hand. He stalked off, and Sink belatedly followed, something held to his bleeding nose.

‚ÄúClear intent to injure,‚Äù Natalie said.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what I said. I did mention the weapons.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a view, and it isn‚Äôt my view,‚Äù Natalie said, reaching for her salad, ‚Äúthat if you have a power then you‚Äôre armed at all times. Sometimes judges hold that view. I would rather assume that you would have a judge that held that perspective and be wrong, than to assume the opposite and be wrong.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúA better option would be to inform the heroes.‚Äù

‚ÄúCouldn‚Äôt. Clairvoyants with some clairaudience,‚Äù I said. I opened a sub-folder, clicked an image, and let it pop up. A boy in a wheelchair, a woman pushing it. He wore a helmet with a fake brain under glass at the top. She wore a bird mask. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôd hear anything we communicated, so it was radio silence.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou could have dropped down in front of Houndstooth and told him about the situation.‚Äù

‚ÄúSimilar risk. We don‚Äôt want to hint at the prior relationship and we do want to suggest there‚Äôs a growing presence of heroes, to give them reason to second guess.‚Äù

Natalie sighed. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a very conservative person in reality, but I do think your situation needs a conservative eye.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can agree with that,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWith a citizen‚Äôs arrest, there needs to be an actual arrest. I recognize you had to leave after the other villains showed up, but normally the process of performing an arrest like that needs clear indication of a crime in progress or one just committed, and it needs the authorities to be involved.‚Äù

‚ÄúCitizen‚Äôs arrest?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúCapes get a lot more leeway with those.‚Äù

‚ÄúOne second. The process would be for you to contact me and contact the authorities, before anything happened.‚Äù

I opened my mouth to respond.

‚ÄúWhere possible, and it wasn‚Äôt possible here. I get that.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou would, with my counsel and go-ahead, step in, take action, and then wait for the authorities to arrive.‚Äù

‚ÄúAuthorities who are only acting on nine percent of the cases,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúWhy a citizen‚Äôs arrest and not an arrest with standing?‚Äù

‚ÄúA costumed arrest? We don‚Äôt know for sure if they‚Äôre going to allow those with the new legal system. I‚Äôd rather lean on something tidier that we can be fairly sure will carry forward.‚Äù

I leaned back in my seat. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a lot more conservative than I anticipated. Operating as if capes aren‚Äôt a thing?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think capes are going to be a thing,‚Äù Natalie said. ‚ÄúBut we have reason to believe they‚Äôre going to be a thing people are going to want to handle in a different, more careful way, now.‚Äù

I packed up my sandwich and pitched it into a nearby trash can.

‚ÄúNo good?‚Äù Natalie asked.

‚ÄúBagel was flavorless and textureless. It looked great and tasted‚Ä¶ not like it looked.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey got popular, so they started freezing excess bagels and defrosting them to serve.‚Äù

I made a face.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre making strides, Victoria, but I think we‚Äôre in for a culture shock when people realize that as much as they‚Äôve been waiting eagerly for things to get closer to normal, we‚Äôre not going to get a lot of the old normal we‚Äôre eager for, and we‚Äôre going to get some of the less pleasant parts.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre talking about the law?‚Äù

Natalie shrugged. She was holding her plastic thing of salad, spearing some with a plastic fork. Before popping it into her mouth, she said, ‚ÄúLots of stuff.‚Äù

My laptop was taking up some of her table real-estate, so I closed it and pulled it closer to me.

‚ÄúExpectations,‚Äù she said, once she was done swallowing. ‚ÄúIf I‚Äôm working with you, I need to know what yours are.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a simple question with an answer that could take me a day to get through.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour mom wanted me to ask you if you were still looking for work,‚Äù Natalie said.

I tensed a little.

‚ÄúI was asked to ask the question and pass on the response if you gave it.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen we pay you, it‚Äôs not for you to be a messenger between me and my mom. If I want to talk to her I can call her.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Natalie said. ‚ÄúShe had something else to pass on.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm not interested,‚Äù I said, my voice firmer. ‚ÄúThank you. I will get up and walk away.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease don‚Äôt. Really, please don‚Äôt. There are a lot of things I want to talk about sooner than later,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúDuring our last meeting, I know it was brief, but I wanted the lay of the land. I was hoping this meeting would be a chance to get a more comprehensive sense of what you wanted to do, and what I‚Äôm doing for you. Both of your mother‚Äôs questions tie into that.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid you talk to her about our meeting?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo. Not for the last one. For this one, I went to someone lateral to her. She approached me independently with these things, and told me to reach out to you if you didn‚Äôt reach out anytime soon. Because you would want to know.‚Äù

I wished I hadn‚Äôt thrown my lunch away. I would‚Äôve liked to have something to violently toss into the wastebasket, as an outlet for what I was feeling. I shook my head a little.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs relevant,‚Äù Natalie said. ‚ÄúAnd it‚Äôs important. I promise.‚Äù

I shook my head more. All around us, people were going to and from lunch. There was actually a city-like stream of cars on the road toward the center of the megalopolis proper.

‚ÄúTell me then,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThere were two attempted breaches into our email server last night. It looked like it was directed at your mother. They put a moratorium on sending and receiving email for three hours while they did some backend stuff, and there was another attempted breach partway through that. Tech people are looking into it.‚Äù

I nodded. I looked at my laptop. Cedar Point, except I wasn‚Äôt aware of anyone who would be especially good at that stuff there. The speedrunners were tinkers, but nothing suggested they were tinkers with talents that translated to hacking into the email servers in the Wardens‚Äô headquarters. Bitter Pill was a full tinker, but her specialty put her even further from that kind of operation.

Houndstooth appears, adding to pressure, Sveta and I make our appearance, and a little while later, an attempted look at a close relation‚Äôs emails. I could see the thread.

Would Tattletale have succeeded? If she had the power to see weaknesses, it could extend to security systems. During the bank robbery, she‚Äôd done something to gain access, though I couldn‚Äôt remember particulars. It had been ambient noise around then. She‚Äôd also collected info on Empire Eighty-Eight.

Someone they hired? Was the fact that they didn‚Äôt go straight to Tattletale important? A sign of a schism?

‚ÄúMy mother thinks it has something to do with me,‚Äù I concluded.

‚ÄúShe was called in for confidential discussion this morning, she got out of the meeting, said she couldn‚Äôt get in touch with you, and told me to reach out. I think so, yeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt have you being her messenger. It‚Äôd impact how this arrangment works,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúEven if it‚Äôs pertinent? Letting you know things like the possible breach into emails? That they‚Äôre looking into people close to you?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe problem is that it‚Äôs always going to sound like a good reason.‚Äù

‚ÄúCould it sound like a good reason because it is one? Sometimes, even?‚Äù

I drew in a deep breath. I collected my laptop and put it into my bag.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt leave, please. I don‚Äôt want to drive you away. I do want to understand,‚Äù Natalie said. ‚ÄúThe first and last thing I said at our last meeting was that I was concerned. I‚Äôm more concerned now.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy ask me about whether I was looking for work?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause she asked me to ask you, if I thought it was appropriate, and I thought it might be.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf fucking course,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt get angry,‚Äù Natalie said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not angry with you.‚Äù

‚ÄúBefore we got derailed, I was talking about expectations. You flew into that scene with no hesitation.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm invincible,‚Äù I said. A lie, yes, but I wasn‚Äôt about to trust her with the truth.

‚ÄúI know that, but isn‚Äôt there always some risk you‚Äôll be hurt, or that there will be some consequence? You‚Äôre paying me, you‚Äôre involving your family, and the hack could be the tip of the iceberg. I have to wonder, how much are you putting into this?‚Äù

‚ÄúI know my own limits, Natalie.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you looking for work?‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you going to report to my mother and tell her if I‚Äôm not?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Natalie said. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm offended that you‚Äôd ask.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been pulling occasional shifts here and there doing cape work. Keeping the peace at protests, standing guard here or there, in the general vicinity of cape functions. I volunteer too.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs the volunteer stuff as a cape?‚Äù

I sat back in my chair, and shifted the position of my bag. ‚ÄúYeah. Pretty much.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt seem like much of a balance.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre aware I‚Äôve never had that balance?‚Äù I asked, in my best ‚Äòget real‚Äô tone.

‚ÄúYou went to high school once upon a time, didn‚Äôt you?‚Äù

‚ÄúAs the girl that was an out and open superheroine,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúBecause of a decision my parents made.‚Äù

‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt seen my dad in years. I don‚Äôt even know if he survived. I know what it‚Äôs like to have parent issues,‚Äù Natalie said. ‚ÄúI do get it. But is this really what you want? Your mother is concerned—‚Äù

I grit my teeth.

‚Äú—I‚Äôm concerned. I can definitely see the similarities between you two. You‚Äôre both firm in your convictions and it seems like you both give things your all. She‚Äôs usually the first one in and the last one out at work.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan we stop talking about my mom?‚Äù I asked. Angrier than I‚Äôd intended.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Natalie said. She stopped there. ‚ÄúGive me a second. I‚Äôll compose my thoughts.‚Äù

I gave her a few seconds. My ankle crossed over the other, and the top foot tapped against the ground. My fingers fidgeted with the strap of the bag that laid against my chair.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm your lawyer. For you and your team.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot my team. Just a team I‚Äôm looking after.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs an implication of overseeing and ownership, but okay. I‚Äôm the lawyer. I can give you counsel, and if I know who you are and who you want to be, I can tailor that counsel. My tendency is to be conservative, because there‚Äôs a lot we don‚Äôt and won‚Äôt know.‚Äù

I nodded. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a degree to which I want conservative.‚Äù

‚ÄúI hear you. I would strongly encourage something more lawful. Calling first, letting authorities know, checking with the lawyer, doing what you‚Äôll do, working with authorities after.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot every situation allows for that. Having a plan is great, and I‚Äôm all about laying stuff out and being smart about things. Sometimes there‚Äôs no time, and you have to make choices.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Natalie said. She paused, fixing her glasses. ‚ÄúYes. If these are the three stages of the plan, with prelude, action, follow-up, maybe you can skip one, and you can explain it away to the authorities.‚Äù

I nodded. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not unreasonable.‚Äù

‚ÄúExcept‚Ä¶ If you have to skip two and rush the other, is it possible that you shouldn‚Äôt have acted at all?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe should have just let Houndstooth‚Äôs group get attacked from behind?‚Äù

‚ÄúOr waited to send them in,‚Äù Natalie suggested. ‚ÄúOr not had them come in at all, if you couldn‚Äôt be sure you‚Äôd be able to handle the lead-in and follow-up.‚Äù

I drummed my fingers on the table. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs more to it. These guys are in contact with people. If we let them operate as normal, try to catch them in the act, they‚Äôll use their leverage and catch us first. We have to apply some sustained pressure. Test their relationship with their contacts. We‚Äôve talked it over with other groups and they agree it makes a degree of sense.‚Äù

‚ÄúHoundstooth?‚Äù

‚ÄúThey were one. They really liked it, even.‚Äù

Natalie‚Äôs brow wrinkled. ‚ÄúYou said sustained. Do you have more lined up?‚Äù

‚ÄúA team is going to call a local realtor, looking into the possibility of moving in. We‚Äôll see if they react.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen?‚Äù she asked.

‚ÄúWe might have some more people lined up. Another group might be passing through, and we‚Äôll be more ready if something comes up. My cousin is swinging by.‚Äù

More brow wrinkles. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll pressure them until they crack.‚Äù

‚ÄúUntil they start to. Then we or someone we trust targets that weak point.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen things crack, it‚Äôs often sudden. Hook and Sink would be an example of that.‚Äù

I nodded.

‚ÄúIf it‚Äôs sudden, it‚Äôs hard to take the necessary steps before and after,‚Äù Natalie said.

‚ÄúIt could be,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to give me an answer right now, but please think about what you want this to be. You can act faster and more flexibly if you‚Äôre loose with the law, but you‚Äôll lose your chance at getting a big success past a judge‚Äôs desk. I can help you if that‚Äôs the route you need to go.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut you think we shouldn‚Äôt go that way.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe people on the team are young, so you need to think about what you‚Äôre teaching them. You need to think about your balance of real life and cape life.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not—‚Äù I started. ‚ÄúI never got that. Even before I had powers, the cape life had taken over.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can understand why you would resent her for that, but—‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not it,‚Äù I said.

She sat there, waiting like she was expecting me to elaborate.

I almost got angry. I pushed that back.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to get into particulars,‚Äù I said, calm. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs between me and her, and it would make things messy. Nobody benefits from that. Least of all you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll take your word for it.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll think about what you said. About what I want, what I‚Äôm doing, keeping an eye out for balance. The team and what they need.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe kind of counsel you need me to be.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúAbsolutely. But I need something from you too.‚Äù

Natalie nodded.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt involve my mother in this. Don‚Äôt pass on information, give hints, or respond to hints. Lawyer-client confidentiality should be in effect.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a lawyer, exactly. I can and do intend to do that, absolutely, but—‚Äù

‚ÄúAct like one, here. Please. She‚Äôll convey her side of the story, probably not in an obvious way, and I need you to be neutral. I won‚Äôt be sharing my side, but assume I have one.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Natalie said.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt get into that stuff. I can‚Äôt afford to,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúShe does care about you, you know,‚Äù Natalie said. ‚ÄúShe might not handle it in the best way, I don‚Äôt know the details, but I know that she is smart and caring, and both of those things are magnified when it comes to you.‚Äù

I stared at her. My first thought was that I wanted to strangle her, because of the frustration I felt even before what I‚Äôd just said, her going against it, and how she seemed to not get it at all. Even with an absent parent? I wondered if it was something wholly different, like a parent that had left and cut contact of their own volition, rather than a parent that she‚Äôd cut herself off from.

My second thought was to tell Natalie what my mother had done, and to hope she understood. Even if I knew it would blow things up, cause chaos, screw up Natalie‚Äôs relationship with a superior.

I could see the worry on her forehead, as she looked at me. In that look, I could see that I was the bad guy here. I was the one Natalie thought she had to worry about, and my mother was the smart, capable, caring professional.

Anything I did in reaction to this would only make me seem more unreasonable.

‚ÄúThank you for meeting with me,‚Äù I said, pushing the emotion back, doing my best to sound normal. ‚ÄúAre phone payments okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúThey are,‚Äù Natalie said.

I took a minute to get everything sorted out, glad to have something to focus on, then tapped my phone against hers.

Sixty dollars out of my account. A glance at the screen verified my account standing. I had two hundred for rent to Crystal, seventy five for utilities. Even before any possible temp jobs in costume, I had enough to get through next month, two or three more meetings with Natalie or even fewer with anyone we replaced her with. Natalie was cheap and willing and I didn‚Äôt disagree with her non-family related advice. It made sense.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAnd thank you for lunch.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll see you later,‚Äù I said.

She was the pawn, not the problem. My mother had chosen her for a reason. A play of a sort, possibly unintentional or automatic. It wasn‚Äôt a play my mom had made because she was a mastermind, natural or otherwise. It was just how she was, how she navigated people. Everyone close to her had had to learn how to deal with it.

The tragedy was that as much as it was a conscious or unconscious bid for a reconnection with me, it would achieve the opposite.

I put my music on, and walked to the nearest bit of park so I could take off without causing too much of a commotion.

‚äô

I let myself into the headquarters. I was secretly glad to find I wasn‚Äôt the first person in, seeing Kenzie at the desk, wearing the same clothes from yesterday.

As that fleeting sentiment passed, I was alarmed, seeing Kenzie at the desk, wearing the same clothes from yesterday.

‚ÄúKenzie?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúOh!‚Äù I heard her speak, though she didn‚Äôt move. Kenzie-at-the-desk winked out of existence.

‚Äú‚Ä¶Kenzie?‚Äù I tried again.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm on my way!‚Äù she said, through the computer speaker. ‚ÄúI was hooked in by phone and forgot I had a virtual me set up to appear if I called. It‚Äôs only half done. I‚Äôll be there soon! How are you?‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt dive too deep into the team stuff or tinkertech, Kenzie,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúTake a break, turn off your brain every once in a while.‚Äù

‚ÄúI turn off my brain by tinkering,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like how on some computers you can push the number so high it goes back to zero, except it‚Äôs brain activity.‚Äù

‚ÄúKenzie,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúPut the phone away. Close your eyes. Don‚Äôt fuss about things.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut—‚Äù

‚ÄúIs there an emergency?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen hang up, put the phone away, close your eyes, and don‚Äôt worry. Everyone‚Äôs coming, we‚Äôll tackle some things, compare notes, and all will be good.‚Äù

‚ÄúBye.‚Äù

‚ÄúBye Kenzie. See you soon.‚Äù

‚ÄúIn‚Ä¶ twelve minutes. About. And Rain is coming, but he‚Äôs going to be later. He‚Äôll arrive in—‚Äù

‚ÄúHang up the phone,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúOr I‚Äôm going to start unplugging things at random.‚Äù

‚ÄúBye then.‚Äù

I didn‚Äôt respond, because it was apparent that Kenzie had to get the last word. The ambient noise came through the phone for another few seconds before she hung up. The cube to the right of her desk went dark.

It was strange to be in the space when the others had yet to arrive. Normally, my focus was on the task at hand, here. I wanted to be the rock, unmovable, in case others needed to reach out. It was hard to be that with Natalie‚Äôs words in my mind and the room empty.

The whiteboards were people‚Äôs thoughts encapsulated. Mine was numbers to call, things to do, a rough timeline of events, with the next being Auzure‚Äôs call to Cedar Point. They were Houndstooth‚Äôs recommendation. I added notes about the hack.

Kenzie had her costume notes, tinker notes, some drawings in erasable marker of her face, a circle with large eyes, a kiss-shaped mouth, and two buns, and various hearts and stars. She had two boards, one mounted on the wall behind the one with two legs and four wheels, and the tinker notes spilled out from the side of the one in front to the one in the back. So did the stars and hearts, for that matter.

Chris‚Äô was at the other end, opposite her desk. I walked over to it, glancing at the others on the way. There were some names written down, but most had been erased.

Menagerie
Zoo
Zoological or Zoologic?
Hodgepodge or Hodge? Podge?

Note to self: bring books for Rain

All written in the bottom left corner. ‚ÄòChris‚Äô was in the top right corner, the ‚Äòh‚Äô smudged where a sleeve had rubbed up against it mid-write.

Ashley‚Äôs board was empty, except for a very elaborate, stylized rendition of her name. Kenzie had found some fonts and displayed them on the whiteboard for tracing. Ashley had okayed this one.

Just ‚ÄòAshley‚Äô. Nothing else figured out.

Rain had two boards, like Kenzie. One on wheels, another on the wall behind. Unlike Kenzie, they weren‚Äôt even remotely organized by topic. Snag, Love Lost, Cradle, ‚Äò5‚Äô, known acquaintances, tinker hands, contact pads, timeline for Snag‚Äôs operations, known places the cluster had been with lines drawn to names of acquaintances, name ideas with ‚Äòhandbreak‚Äô crossed out because Tristan had apparently vetoed it, a crude calendar with the names of cluster members filling in blanks, Love Lost due tonight‚Ä¶ and so on.

Just red marker and some brown, presumably to put in different words in gaps yet keep them distinct. Or because Kenzie had stolen the red marker to draw hearts.

Tristan‚Äôs was next to Rain‚Äôs, and Tristan‚Äôs was mostly devoted to team name ideas, room layouts, broader organization and schedule, and some minor notes on money spent. Byron hadn‚Äôt really showed up in the hideout, but Tristan had still devoted a quarter of the board to him. A list of movies. Aimed at letting Byron maintain a degree of communication with Chris and Rain, it seemed, from the comments on the side.

Sveta was taken up by a mix of art and names. She‚Äôd written out names not in a list, but as solitary words. Images had been drawn around them. Beneath ‚ÄòMoor‚Äô, a girl‚Äôs hair, wavy, with a fish head poking out to the right from between the two curtains of hair. It was very detailed for art on a whiteboard, with each scale getting a texture. Above ‚ÄòLash‚Äô was a feminine figure in stark black lines with back arched, head back, and breasts pointed skyward, the breasts so pointed they could have been used for Kenzie‚Äôs geometry homework. To the right of ‚ÄòCirrus‚Äô was a face drawn out in lines, frowning. ‚ÄòBerth‚Äô was sitting in the bottom right corner in tiny text. The image was so small it was barely legible. It might have been Sveta‚Äôs rendition of herself, potato-shaped with arms and legs flailing. A line was drawn between its head and the word ‚Äòno‚Äô, a speech bubble without the bubble.

I felt oddly fond at seeing it. That kind of mental working was inexplicable to me, but I liked seeing the hints of it.

After Sveta was my whiteboard, neatly organized, then Kenzie‚Äôs two, which I‚Äôd already noted.

I wanted to help them.

No. The boards didn‚Äôt convey it, the boards were things as they should be, even, but they needed help.

On so many levels, they needed help.

The by-proxy interaction with my mother had affected my mood. Natalie‚Äôs words and concerns had too, but it was hard to know how many of those were my mother‚Äôs and how many were her.

The concern, with emphasis on the word like I could remember Ashley doing‚Ä¶ Even after I‚Äôd been hurt by the Nine, had worse done to me by my sister, and gone to the hospital, I couldn‚Äôt remember my mother ever expressing concern for my activities as a cape. If such was expressed in Natalie‚Äôs expression and words, then I could believe it was Natalie‚Äôs.

Concern for what I was doing, the path I was walking? I could see it being my mother‚Äôs, through Natalie-as-proxy.

It made me sad and angry and frustrated all at the same time, and I didn‚Äôt have any outlets for that. The punching bag hadn‚Äôt yet arrived and been set up, and I wasn‚Äôt about to throw myself at the villains. Not that I wanted to operate that way.

The villains were so simple, so easy. Cedar point. Bad guy central. I was supposed to dislike what they did and I did dislike it. I didn‚Äôt see anything redeeming in them, I had the power to stop them, and I wholly planned to. If I could mess with Tattletale in the process? Bad guy, I was supposed to dislike her, she‚Äôd done little that redeemed her, and it was personal, besides? Yeah. Fuck yes. But I‚Äôd do it smart, not by impulse.

Others‚Ä¶ not so easy. My dad. Gilpatrick. Mrs. Yamada, even. They were the good guys and they hadn‚Äôt handled things perfectly. I felt varying degrees of heartbreak because of them but I couldn‚Äôt blame them. Not easy.

My life was filled with people I wanted to get angry at and couldn‚Äôt, because they were fundamentally broken and flawed. My mother. My sister. Amelia. Amy. I‚Äôd said her name and thought about her for ten lifetimes‚Äô worth, in just the span of two years. I felt vaguely ill that I was doing so now, even if it was for the sake of doing as Natalie had asked me to.

The only thing I hated more than being victim to other people‚Äôs emotional impulses and fucked-upness was when those other people were so close to me that it all came down on my head. The furthest thing from easy.

The door opened, interrupting my thoughts. I turned my head to see.

Sveta and Ashley. Tristan absent, even though he would normally catch the same train.

‚ÄúHi,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWhat are you doing standing in the dark? At least turn the lights on,‚Äù Sveta chided me.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs more than enough light from the windows,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs bright out.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd expect that behavior from Ashley, not you,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúSounds right,‚Äù Ashley said.

Sveta flicked the switch, looking up as the lights took their time coming on. It made me think of my mom. Turning on the lights, even when not strictly necessary. I could remember visiting friend‚Äôs houses and feeling like something was odd when other parents didn‚Äôt do it.

‚ÄúWhat are you doing?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúThinking.‚Äù

‚ÄúUh oh.‚Äù

‚ÄúConstructive thinking. I think. I hope. Had a chat with Natalie.‚Äù

‚ÄúUh oh,‚Äù Sveta said, again, as she sidled up to me.

I gave her a light push. She smiled, righted herself, and half-stepped, half-stumbled right next to me. She gave me a hug from behind, setting her chin on my shoulder.

Familiar sensation, there, in an eerie not-familiar way.

‚ÄúTristan‚Äôs walking the sprogs,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúRain‚Äôs late.‚Äù

‚ÄúKenzie mentioned,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThe second part. Sprogs?‚Äù

‚ÄúChris and Kenzie. I thought it was clever.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was.‚Äù

She nodded, head moving against my shoulder. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre looking at the boards?‚Äù

I gestured in the direction of the whiteboards. ‚ÄúNatalie wants to know our mission statement, so she can fine-tune her advice. She wanted a lot of things, some harder to put into words than others. I‚Äôm looking at the whiteboards, trying to figure out what the thread is and how I can help.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour board is empty, Ashley,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúSo?‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you going to call yourself Damsel of Distress?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúFor that matter, what are you doing, costume-wise?‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre going to tell me not to wear a dress while I‚Äôm out with you all, you can fuck off,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúNot wearing a dress could help with the Manton issues. You‚Äôre more likely to use your power to blow up the edge of a flapping dress than the part that hugs your body.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can fuck off,‚Äù she said, again.

‚ÄúAshley likes dresses,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve had conversations about it. She thinks I should wear some, and I‚Äôve had to repeatedly reinforce that I don‚Äôt have the legs for it, because I don‚Äôt have legs.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey multiply a lady‚Äôs grace,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt exaggerate a negative,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre attached to the image,‚Äù I observed.

‚ÄúObviously,‚Äù Ashley said, turning to face me.

She was attached to just that image. I wasn‚Äôt sure if she had multiple versions of the same dress, but she didn‚Äôt change things up much. She had, however, bought the new dress in Cedar Point, and we‚Äôd seen on camera as she considered nail polish.

She wanted to change, maybe. But‚Ä¶ how long had she stuck to this style? I‚Äôd fancied taking Sveta shopping, but now I was intrigued by this puzzle.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a shame you damage your dresses,‚Äù I said. I indicated the hem of her dress. ‚ÄúAre you learning to tailor or do you hire someone?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm studying it. Saves me money.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay, so‚Ä¶ I have a bit of a crazy idea,‚Äù I said.

She narrowed her eyes.

‚ÄúBear with me,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúBear with her,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúVictoria knows fashion.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre leading up to this like you know I‚Äôll hate it.‚Äù

I nodded.

‚ÄúOut with it, then,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúHair,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù was the response, without a beat missed.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt promise it would work, but hair can confuse the Manton effect. It might be that the power gets confused because it‚Äôs a part of your identity and a part of you, but it‚Äôs not alive either. There are parahumans who impregnate their costumes with hair to make them resistant to their own powers. There are some who have costumes that are just hair, or mostly hair, but those are pretty scanty, as you can probably imagine.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think I‚Äôve heard of that parahuman,‚Äù Sveta said. When I arched an eyebrow, she said, ‚ÄúThe hair impregnation thing.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to cut it off,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs fine. I‚Äôm not even sure it would work, and it would be a shame to do it if it didn‚Äôt.‚Äù

She nodded.

‚ÄúYou could try saving the hairs that come free while you‚Äôre sleeping or brushing your hair,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúHow much would I need?‚Äù Ashley asked.

‚ÄúIf it did work, you might not even need much. A strand every quarter-inch or so, along the length, or along the parts that are likely to get clipped by your power. Maybe a bit more.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd it‚Äôd be white hairs on a black background,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúYou could, you know, not wear black?‚Äù I ventured.

‚ÄúI like black,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs elegant. It works. The black dress every woman has in her closet for occasions is black for a reason.‚Äù

I was actually enjoying myself, because of the puzzle, and because it was my longest interaction with Ashley that hadn‚Äôt come to blows.

‚ÄúDye it?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt work,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúI have natural silver-blonde hair, but I use my power—‚Äù

She put her hand to the side of her head and used her power. I stepped back, stumbled into Sveta, then reached out to help her catch her balance.

Ashley‚Äôs hair settled back into place. Her pupils took a long few seconds to reappear.

The door swung open. It was Tristan, looking alarmed.

‚ÄúWe good,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúMy eyes and hair lose their color,‚Äù Ashley said, in a non-sequitur for Tristan.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôd lose the dye,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúProbably.‚Äù

Kenzie and Chris appeared behind Tristan. He let them in.

‚ÄúWhat happened?‚Äù Chris asked.

‚ÄúTalking fashion,‚Äù Sveta offered.

‚ÄúWhich involves reality-shattering explosions, naturally,‚Äù Chris said. He grinned.

He was wearing a newer t-shirt, with a gorn-metal band‚Äôs album cover on the front. Not my style. He was broader around the middle, but I diplomatically avoided mentioning it.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre taller,‚Äù I observed.

‚ÄúOne and a half inches taller,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúHe went with the indulgence thing yesterday,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúI knew there was a risk I might be useless for the day, putting myself in a state where I just sit around, eat, play games. So I fucked off. I‚Äôll hit anxiety a few times in the next while, but I‚Äôll make it mad twitchiness so there‚Äôs some more motive behind it, instead of it being paralyzing. That‚Äôll be fun.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat sounds like you‚Äôre going overboard. Shouldn‚Äôt you be balancing things out?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúShouldn‚Äôt you be minding your own business?‚Äù Chris asked. ‚ÄúGo talk fashion. I‚Äôm fine.‚Äù

He walked over to his corner, near where his whiteboard was. Kenzie moved to follow, and Chris turned around, reached out to grab her by the shoulders, and turned her to face us, before going back on his way, to his whiteboard.

‚ÄúFashion,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúOkay. We‚Äôve got some stylish and artsy people here. I‚Äôm not so up there on girl-fashion, but I‚Äôll contribute what I can.‚Äù

‚ÄúAshley is married to this look,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúMarried is the wrong word,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúHow would you put it?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúA long time ago, when I was still finding my way, I didn‚Äôt even have the clothes on my back, not intact ones. I had no friends, no family, and law enforcement was after me. I had nothing. I spent a lot of time thinking about who and what I wanted to be. Characters I liked, clothes I liked, people I‚Äôd thought were elegant and imposing. I found this. I built this,‚Äù Ashley said.

What had her role models been, for aesthetics? Cartoon movie villains? Evil sorceresses and witches?

‚ÄúWhen you had nothing, you found this, and you want to hold onto that,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI can understand that. I hold onto things that were important to me once.‚Äù

‚ÄúLike Weld,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúAmong others,‚Äù Sveta said, giving me more of a hug.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to hold onto anything,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúI am that. People spend their entire lives trying to find the right image for themselves and I found it when I was Kenzie‚Äôs age.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think you‚Äôre going to win this one, Victoria,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúTheoretically speaking,‚Äù I started.

‚ÄúAlright. I‚Äôm getting out of the line of fire,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be mean,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúCall with Auzure in a short bit. Rain might miss it,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúTheoretically speaking‚Ä¶ can I put something out there?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúCan I stop you?‚Äù Ashley asked.

‚ÄúTell me to and I‚Äôll stop right here. You can do your thing.‚Äù

Sveta rocked her head left and right on my shoulder, chin digging in, until I shrugged her off. Ashley considered.

‚ÄúTheoretically,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúTheoretically,‚Äù I picked up the prompt, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to be a hero. You have a crystal clear image of what you‚Äôll look like as a villain. Your every expectation is that you‚Äôll stop being a hero at one point and return to villainy.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not theory. That‚Äôs fact.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut what is theory is‚Ä¶ what if, to avoid your hero self and villain self getting mixed up, you tried something different, in the here and now? It keeps your villain persona distinct.‚Äù

Ashley folded her arms.

‚ÄúDifferent how? I get the impression you have something in mind,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúPshht!‚Äù Ashley made the sound, shushing Sveta.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt pshht me.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat if, theoretically,‚Äù I said, ‚ÄúYou cut off the hair? White hair for a white costume. You can still do something with black accents here and there, but we can go more‚Ä¶ white goth. Or something in that vein.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not goth,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm not cutting my hair.‚Äù

‚ÄúTheoret—‚Äù I started.

I saw her expression change.

More seriously, I said, ‚ÄúYou cutting your hair could be a commitment. You could go back to being the long-haired villainess, but only after a period of time. You‚Äôd be locking yourself into being a hero in the meantime.‚Äù

‚ÄúA hair-based time commitment,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no reason to do it,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúTo preserve my costume? For that minor gain, I‚Äôm supposed to risk looking like a simpleton? No.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat kind of black accents?‚Äù Kenzie asked.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúBlack around the eyes, like heavy eyeliner, maybe decoration in the hair, or as part of the mask, something to frame the edges of sleeves and dress.‚Äù

Kenzie went still. She gave Ashley a sidelong glance.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Ashley asked.

‚ÄúBack before Mrs. Yamada told me I wasn‚Äôt supposed to give anyone a birthday present, I was thinking about what to get you.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf Mrs. Yamada said no, then there‚Äôs probably a reason,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThe group was new and Ashley and I were only just starting to talk, so it would‚Äôve been weird, I think. It wouldn‚Äôt be for just Ashley either, it‚Äôd be for the group.‚Äù

‚ÄúSpit it out,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúEyes,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúI can put these things in your mask and it would project over your eyes. We could have you wear a white costume, and then there would be bits that are black, and then we could make your eyes totally, one hundred percent black, or totally white.‚Äù

‚ÄúHold up,‚Äù I said.

Kenzie turned my way.

‚ÄúWhen you say something like ‚ÄòI can make this‚Äô, I have to ask‚Ä¶ how easily?‚Äù

‚ÄúSuper easily. A few hours easy,‚Äù Kenzie said. When I didn‚Äôt shut her down, she turned to Ashley, ‚ÄúWe could have it so smoke comes off of your eyes and trails behind you as you walk. or blurry light, like when you wave a sparkler in the dark, or particles, like shapes, or blurs like your power makes, or—‚Äù

Ashley put a hand on top of Kenzie‚Äôs head. Kenzie stopped talking.

‚ÄúDo you want to? Do you like it?‚Äù

‚ÄúIf I went to buy you a gift, to balance it out, so it was equal, what would you want?‚Äù

‚ÄúWent? I don‚Äôt want you to go anywhere.‚Äù

‚ÄúI meant some other time.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo gift,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúHang out. Talk with me. Come on, we can use your whiteboard. We‚Äôll talk and take notes, and figure out what your costume might be. Let me search for things on my phone—‚Äù

Kenzie took Ashley‚Äôs hand and led her to the whiteboard, tugging her along. Ashley didn‚Äôt object too much along the way.

Near Kenzie‚Äôs computers, Tristan had his arms folded, his eyebrow raised. Sveta had her head cocked to one side as she studied me. Chris was dumping his bag out on his little table.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not hard to figure out or anything,‚Äù I said, quiet enough that only Sveta would hear me. ‚ÄúAt one point she said we were pretty similar people.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat leaves me with way more questions than answers,‚Äù Sveta said.

Tristan called out, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt get too into it, you two! We‚Äôre listening in on the call with Auzure soon!‚Äù

Ashley raised a hand, waving him off. Kenzie was just nonstop background chatter now.

‚ÄúWhat are you thinking?‚Äù Sveta asked. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre introspective today.‚Äù

‚ÄúExtraspective, right this moment,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThinking about the big picture.‚Äù

‚ÄúThink out loud.‚Äù

I shrugged. ‚ÄúThe team. How it fits together. How I fit into it.‚Äù

‚ÄúA bit of introspection then.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, not exactly,‚Äù I said, the thought clarifying as I said it. ‚ÄúHow‚Äôs Weld doing?‚Äù

‚ÄúIf he could get tired he‚Äôd be dog tired. I need to have a talk with him soon, before things get to a point where I don‚Äôt see him ever,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI hate to add anything to his plate, but I have to be assertive.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad you have him,‚Äù I said.

Sveta smiled. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad I have him too. Even if he‚Äôs tired and gone most of the time. Why are you asking about him?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen Jessica— When Mrs. Yamada asked me to sit in with the group and help out. She asked Weld first, didn‚Äôt she?‚Äù

‚ÄúAh, you caught that,‚Äù Sveta said. The smile disappeared. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry. I wasn‚Äôt sure if you did, and I didn‚Äôt want to risk hurting your feelings.‚Äù

‚ÄúWas I second choice?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think so. Sorry, I don‚Äôt know for sure, but Weld was asked and he said no, but he said he‚Äôd be free a little while after. She could have waited and had Weld sit in, but she chose you.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd she seemed okay, almost relieved, at me doing this,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúAs okay as she is with any of this,‚Äù Sveta said.

The display on the wall lit up. The trill of the phone filled the room.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre calling us first,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúEveryone come. Seems like Rain is going to miss this. Sucks.‚Äù

We gathered at the desk.

‚ÄúWe need something to call you,‚Äù the woman‚Äôs voice on the other line said. ‚ÄúDido speaking, with Auzure.‚Äù

‚ÄúDido, this is Capricorn. You‚Äôre on speaker with most of the rest of the team listening in. We‚Äôre working on the team name. We‚Äôll have something soon.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wanted to go over the particulars, make sure we do this right. We‚Äôre going to be calling‚Ä¶‚Äù

I mostly tuned it out. Tristan had it handled, and it wasn‚Äôt rocket science. I wasn‚Äôt that fond of Auzure, either.

Natalie had asked me what I was doing.

I‚Äôd been asked to be here. I was damaged, and Mrs. Yamada knew it. Why was I here, then? Yesterday, I might have said it was so I could provide this kind of direction and guidance. So I could talk to the lawyer, handle situations like Kenzie‚Äôs and Ashley‚Äôs, and be a friend to Sveta.

Was I right? Thinking that Yamada had felt like she‚Äôd done her job in putting me here? Was I overthinking things after my talk with Natalie, paranoia rearing its ugly head again?

‚ÄúBeautiful,‚Äù Dido said. ‚ÄúShould we conference you in?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got a number you can call, it‚Äôll route through to them, and it won‚Äôt be as blatant as a conference call.‚Äù

‚ÄúLovely. I wondered if I should mention something. Good to work with people who know what they‚Äôre doing. What number?‚Äù

Sveta mouthed the word ‚Äòslimy‚Äô at me.

Water off my back, now. I‚Äôd just dealt with my mom and this was easy by comparison.

Tristan gave the number, and the call was terminated.

He checked his phone.

‚ÄúRain wants to know if people are okay with him inviting Erin. They‚Äôre still half an hour away. She gave him a ride and they stopped along the way. He says he‚Äôs safe, no trouble, but he wants to talk, and he wants her here when he does.‚Äù

Tristan‚Äôs voice was just a bit tight.

‚ÄúI have suspicions,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúI know, I think,‚Äù Tristan said.

With that, I felt like the musings crystallized. I wouldn‚Äôt know until I talked to Jessica, but I had more of an idea. Things made a degree of sense.

‚ÄúNot here,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúHm?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúGut feeling, but we‚Äôll meet him to talk somewhere nearby, as soon as this call is wrapped up and we‚Äôve seen how they respond. Half an hour should be plenty of time. But let‚Äôs not do it here,‚Äù I said.

Shade — 4.7

‚ÄúHello? This is Andre Giannone.‚Äù

‚ÄúAndre, hello. We were hoping you could help us out. We want to rent some locations in Cedar Point.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhere did you get this number?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe went to the source. Mortari Construction handled the building in Cedar Point, and they gave us the name of‚Ä¶ Andrea Giannone? Could it be your daughter we‚Äôre wanting to contact?‚Äù

‚ÄúI am Andrea, I go by Andre. Easier, not having to explain that I‚Äôm not a woman. It‚Äôs a man‚Äôs name where I was born.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs great. Andre, aren‚Äôt you the one charged with leasing the properties?‚Äù

‚ÄúTheir records are out of date. I‚Äôve washed my hands of the business. Look elsewhere.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan you give us the number of the person we can call?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo. There are no vacancies in Cedar Point right now, and I won‚Äôt give you the number because I don‚Äôt know who is handling things.‚Äù

‚ÄòWon‚Äôt give you the number‚Äô, I noted. Not ‚Äòcan‚Äôt give you the number‚Äò. Despite not knowing?

‚ÄúA cursory internet search suggests there are a lot of vacancies in Cedar Point. People are noting it and asking why.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt know.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou live there.‚Äù

‚ÄúI keep to myself. Look elsewhere. Stop bothering an old man.‚Äù

‚ÄúMr. Giannone, I understand if you‚Äôre scared. Don‚Äôt answer me if you‚Äôre worried people are listening in. We‚Äôre heroes.‚Äù

Was the summary silence on the other end because he was worried people were listening in, or was it shock?

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre heroes. We‚Äôre a corporate team with plans of settling in. We know there are vacancies, and we know you still have signs up. If we can get this working, we‚Äôre going to look after you and the people in Cedar Point.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat? A corporate team?‚Äù

‚ÄúOf heroes, Mr. Giannone. We call ourselves Auzure. Au for the chemical symbol for gold, azure for blue, I don‚Äôt know if that will help you remember. You‚Äôll see us around, if we can do this without stepping on anyone else‚Äôs toes.‚Äù

‚ÄúToes? What?‚Äù

I glanced over the others, and saw Tristan doing the same thing. His eyes met mine. I wondered if he had the same thought I did, about how Dido‚Äôs clarification about the name would only confuse people.

‚ÄúJurisdictions, Mr. Giannone. It wouldn‚Äôt be good if we turned up there and ended up in a turf war with fellow heroes over who gets to help.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy would there be fighting to— there‚Äôs nothing here. There‚Äôs nobody here. It‚Äôs a nowhere place. Everyone who could leave left. Everyone else wants to be left alone.‚Äù

Was he aware of the contradiction in what he‚Äôd said? That there were no vacancies, but there was nobody there?

Dido went on, taking on a tone that made me think she was in sales. ‚ÄúIt might be a nowhere place right now, Mr. Giannone, but I promise you, Auzure can change that. The other heroes want to change it. Whatever happens, you‚Äôre going to get some stellar heroes in your neighborhood. Hopefully it‚Äôs us, and we can clear the way so that everyone that left can come back.‚Äù

Dido‚Äôs earnest, almost painful optimism toward the end was contrasted by the sputtering reply.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll make this place a warzone.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll handle things in a good way. Trust us. Auzure is gentle but we get the job done.‚Äù

There was inarticulate sputtering on the other side for a few seconds. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not the person to bother with this. Don‚Äôt call me again.‚Äù

Mr. Andre Giannone hung up the phone.

‚ÄúKenzie,‚Äù Tristan said, putting a hand on the back of Kenzie‚Äôs chair.

The camera shifted, focusing on a small house on the edge of the downtown strip. Tall windows and a realty sign, with the second floor having suggestions of an upstairs apartment.

‚ÄúI feel bad,‚Äù Dido said, speaking to the dead air.

‚ÄúCan we talk back to her?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúNo, but—‚Äù Kenzie hit a few keys. The call ended, and then the phone rang.

‚ÄúHere you are,‚Äù Dido said. ‚ÄúBeautiful. Was that what you needed?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to see,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúThe man you called is going out for a walk.‚Äù

Mr. Giannone was dressed in a suit jacket over what might have been a thin sweater or long-sleeved shirt, with nice hair combed straight back from his face, but where he might have looked dashing, gray hair or no, he had bad posture that made him look older than he probably was. He walked with what I could only call alacrity.

‚ÄúPatching in,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll send you the video after, but for now it‚Äôs going to be audio only.‚Äù

‚ÄúLovely! I get to see and hear the rest?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs part of the deal,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll pass on info about villains and the greater villain network as we pull things together. We‚Äôre hoping you‚Äôll keep from stepping on our toes in the meantime, as you put it. Houndstooth was saying you were better than some of your teammates about jumping into something like this without regard for us.‚Äù

‚ÄúHmm. I could see it if we were itching for something to do, but I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs likely. Right now, I don‚Äôt think we could. Too much to do already.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe war?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a big part of it.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow is it? How bad?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúI have no idea. It feels like none of the people doing the talking and negotiations want it to happen, especially as we‚Äôre getting hints about how bitter a war it could be. Earth C doesn‚Äôt mess around.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you think it‚Äôs going to happen?‚Äù Sveta asked. She sounded more anxious now.

‚ÄúThe diplomats and most of the people at the very top on both sides are fighting it, but it seems like things are moving inexorably in that direction. Yes.‚Äù

Sveta‚Äôs chin dropped a bit as she looked down at the ground. I reached out for her, and stopped as I heard a small ‚Äòthup‚Äô sound, followed by another.

Her arms and legs hadn‚Äôt moved, so I took it as her tendrils striking at the interior of her body in the same way a prisoner might punch the wall of their cell.

‚ÄúMy hope is we‚Äôll keep moving at this steady, unwilling pace, there will be an initial exchange of blows, and both sides back off,‚Äù Dido said. ‚ÄúMy worry is that something explosive will happen. Another broken trigger, an attack from Earth C doomsday radicals, an attack from the Fourth Sect, someone stupid from our world trying to take territory over there. I could go on. It might spark something lasting.‚Äù

I approached Sveta in a way that let her see I was coming, moving slowly. I wanted to ask if it was okay to make contact, and I didn‚Äôt want to say it out loud, where the others or Dido might hear.

‚ÄúFourth Sect?‚Äù Tristan asked. ‚ÄúHave I heard of this before?‚Äù

Sveta saw me and reached out. I took her hand in mine, and reached out with the other arm to put it around her shoulders.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd call it a cult but I‚Äôm not sure it‚Äôs the right term. They‚Äôre a minority power with a strong political voice. They want war, to thin their own populations after too much ‚Äòbe fruitful and multiply‚Äô. Hard to get into in any detail on that cycle. Some of Gimel‚Äôs biggest allies in Earth C are people who want to postpone war because it makes the Fourth Sect weaker.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour thinking is if they get to the point where they‚Äôre desperate, they‚Äôll try to spark something,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúNot my thinking. People higher than me. They‚Äôre some of what we‚Äôre watching out for.‚Äù

Tristan glanced at Sveta, then said, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre okay, right? We do have the edge on powers. Makes for an incredible toolbox.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe have an edge, but it‚Äôs not as big as you might think,‚Äù Dido said. ‚ÄúOur side has people who can detect or see powers, and what we keep hearing from them is that this guy has powers, but on the down-low. That woman has powers, nobody seems to be aware. A lot of them are using their abilities to maneuver into positions of power.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan we stop talking about this?‚Äù Sveta asked. It felt strange hearing so abrupt a question when I hadn‚Äôt felt it in her body or breathing.

‚ÄúWe can,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúTo cut in like that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt mind, love,‚Äù Dido said. ‚ÄúWe can talk about other things. I‚Äôd welcome the distractions.‚Äù

‚ÄúMr. Giannone is at the center of town. He seems to know where to go to talk to the villains,‚Äù Tristan reported.

‚ÄúLovely,‚Äù Dido said. ‚ÄúSome silliness to take my mind off of things.‚Äù

Silliness. We were treating this situation as serious, we were trying to save Cedar Point and the people within, and we were trying to break up a criminal organization before it extended its reach too far or imploded. With all of our various issues, with one team member‚Äôs life on the line, we were making sacrifices and devoting ourselves to this in the long term.

Silliness?

To someone that was trying to head off a war with another universe? I could concede her that, but I could also think she could have worded it way more respectfully.

I decided to write her off as a bit of a ditz and let it be.

Giannone entered the bar, and my first thought was that we wouldn‚Äôt have the audio or video.

Moments later, however, he emerged with Prancer.

‚Äú‚Ä¶not involved in this.‚Äù

‚ÄúAndre, if you don‚Äôt want to be involved, walking into the bar where we gather isn‚Äôt the way to do it. Not voicing your issues in earshot of ten people with powers. Let‚Äôs talk in my office.‚Äù

‚ÄúBeing seen walking into your office isn‚Äôt any better,‚Äù Andre Giannone said, resisting being led by the arm. Prancer stopped trying, and the older man said, ‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll keep it polite,‚Äù Prancer said, ‚ÄúBoth in what we talk about, and in appearing civil.‚Äù

The people in the bar could see out the window.

‚ÄúThey called me. What am I supposed to say? If this goes to court—‚Äù

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs not talk about court.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat if?‚Äù Andre said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not going to. The courts have too much to do to bother with someone like you. Even with people like us.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou said the heroes wouldn‚Äôt bother either, and how many have we seen or heard about now?‚Äù

‚ÄúAndre. Listen. If they decide they‚Äôll bother with petty crime, they‚Äôll come after me, the other villains. They won‚Äôt go after the scared citizens. If they thought someone had done something, they would think it was because the people were forced.‚Äù

Prancer‚Äôs tone changed at the end there. Too light to be anything but joking. I wondered how tone would play out with the court, if Giannone was charged. I let go of Sveta and walked over to the whiteboard to note the question. Something for a future discussion with Natalie or someone like her.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want this hassle,‚Äù Andre Giannone said.

‚ÄúI understand. We‚Äôre already taking steps. We‚Äôre getting information, we‚Äôre getting help. We‚Äôll have more in a bit, and we‚Äôll fill you in.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat am I supposed to do when they call?‚Äù

‚ÄúHang up. Say whatever you said. Tell them you have no space. Do whatever you have to, but don‚Äôt rent to them. And don‚Äôt show up at the bar. Call me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wanted to get you sooner than that.‚Äù

‚ÄúCall. Now, who was it that called?‚Äù

‚ÄúSomething about blue and gold.‚Äù

‚ÄúGoldenrod?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo. I don‚Äôt know. Maybe.‚Äù

I felt a kind of satisfaction at the confusion. Dido was a salesman, maybe, or a face-person, but she wasn‚Äôt a marketing person. The way she‚Äôd described Auzure hadn‚Äôt been a good way to make it memorable.

‚ÄúCould it have been Auzure?‚Äù Prancer asked.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs it, I think.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúI know someone I can ask for more details on what they‚Äôre doing. That‚Äôs good. Useful.‚Äù

‚ÄúWho do you know?‚Äù Dido asked, as if Prancer could hear her.

Prancer continued talking, oblivious. ‚ÄúNext time, remember. That‚Äôs all you need to do. Leave it to me to decide if we need to worry.‚Äù

He laid a hand on Andre Giannone‚Äôs shoulder as he said it. It was a way to show support, and also a way to steer his conversation partner, suggesting the man walk back the way he came.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve held up my end so far,‚Äù Andre said, resisting being guided as he said it.

‚ÄúAnd you get allowances others in the neighborhood don‚Äôt. Nobody knocks on your door. You have tenants.‚Äù

‚ÄúNobody‚Äôs knocking on my door, maybe, but I‚Äôm getting calls.‚Äù

‚ÄúA call. One,‚Äù Prancer said. He walked, one hand on Andre Giannone‚Äôs shoulder, getting Andre started on his way. ‚ÄúAnd we‚Äôre taking steps to rectify the unwelcome attention. Things should calm down soon.‚Äù
