‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Andre said. He looked at Prancer. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need to worry?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt need to worry.‚Äù

Andre walked away. Prancer stood where he was, hooking thumbs in his jacket pockets, head tilted. The camera got a good angled view of his expression as he turned around. A confident smile.

A smile for the people in the window who might be looking at him, but he spoke under his breath, too quiet for even Kenzie‚Äôs camera to pick up.

‚ÄúCan you get that for us?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúYep!‚Äù

It took a short bit, and Prancer didn‚Äôt re-enter the bar, instead walking over to the building across the street, where his ‚Äòoffice‚Äô apparently was.

‚ÄúWhat the hell is going on?‚Äù Prancer‚Äôs hiss came through the speakers.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going on,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúThank you for the help, Dido,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad to, hon. I was worried I‚Äôd bothered an old man for nothing, but he‚Äôs in this, isn‚Äôt he?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe had cues he was.‚Äù

‚ÄúLet us know if you need anything else.‚Äù

‚ÄúThanks,‚Äù Tristan said.

The conversation wrapped up with some goodbyes, and the call ended. Windows closed, and parts of Kenzie‚Äôs computer-cube went dark.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got one group passing through later this afternoon. We could postpone it if needed. These guys are Houndstooth‚Äôs recommends,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúVictoria? You‚Äôll handle it?‚Äù

‚ÄúMy cousin will come with. Just in case they‚Äôre keeping an eye out for me and have surface-to-air planned.‚Äù

‚ÄúMissiles?‚Äù Chris asked.

‚ÄúAnything,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre starting to adapt,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúInfo and help?‚Äù

‚ÄúAs far as info goes,‚Äù I said, ‚ÄúNatalie said someone tried hacking into the Wardens‚Äô headquarters, specifically targeting my mom.‚Äù

‚ÄúWasn‚Äôt me,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúI feel like if it was Tattletale, they would have been cleverer about it. Sveta, since you were seen too, though they probably can‚Äôt connect you to your past self, you might want to make sure all accounts are secure.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúThen that only leaves Rain,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúDecompress, take notes, do whatever. We leave to meet him in a few minutes.‚Äù

He was taking on the leadership role. Ashley had seemed to want it, and she‚Äôd included herself when Houndstooth had wanted to meet people in charge, but she wasn‚Äôt fighting him on this.

I noted that, and I wondered.

I watched as the tight cluster of the group broke up. No longer gathered around the screen, standing behind Kenzie‚Äôs desk, they moved toward their individual spaces. Chris had the largest bubble around him, where he didn‚Äôt have people within it. His gait was different than it had been.

Ashley went to her board. She‚Äôd been quiet throughout, and now she stopped in front of her whiteboard. A mix of her writing and Kenzie‚Äôs marked it, with her writing along the center, each line slanted as if it was written on an angle, like a tower of stacked coins that was about to buckle and fall. Kenzie‚Äôs writing marked the bottom third, with a few drawings of eyes.

Whatever means of communication they had devised between them, I couldn‚Äôt decipher it. I couldn‚Äôt even begin to read Ashley‚Äôs handwriting. Kenzie went to Ashley to resume their prior discussion.

‚ÄúYou okay?‚Äù Tristan asked. I turned to look. He was talking to Sveta. ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt like that talk about war.‚Äù

Sveta shrugged. She smiled as I joined their conversation. ‚ÄúThank you for the hug. I didn‚Äôt even realize how upset I was until you came up to me.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnytime,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWas it the thought of Weld over there that got you?‚Äù Tristan asked.

Sveta shrugged, but it wasn‚Äôt too effective with her suit. ‚ÄúWhat threw me was when Dido talked about how people with powers were getting positions.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúBecause it might not be only that. The people with positions might be getting powers.‚Äù

‚ÄúCauldron?‚Äù I asked.

Sveta nodded. ‚ÄúEarth C is a major reason we had the supplies to rebuild. They say they did it out of goodwill. I think Cauldron made it happen. Gave powers to key people so they would agree, made deals.‚Äù

She put out one arm, indicating the window and the city beyond it.

‚ÄúHow much of that was bought and paid for with crimes against humanity? I saw some of what they did. I heard a lot more about it. My entire life, this body of mine, it‚Äôs because of them,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs awful to think about.‚Äù

I looked out at the city that gleamed with traces of yellow and gold in the light of the early afternoon.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know a lot about them,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúI only know some,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThe info came out after, but it trickles out, there‚Äôs a lot of guessing to be done.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have to guess,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI can tell you more some day. But it‚Äôs going to take a few minutes longer than it takes to talk to Rain.‚Äù

Chris had joined Kenzie and Ashley‚Äôs conversation. Kenzie was bouncing with excitement, trying to get Chris‚Äô input. He seemed reluctant to dish, but quick to shoot down this idea or that idea.

‚ÄúYou want to sit on this, skip out on the Rain conversation?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI think I have to go, because I‚Äôm one of the only people who knows most of the story. It feels like I‚Äôm the only one who knows most of everyone‚Äôs story. I know yours, Victoria. I know Rain‚Äôs, I think. I have my suspicions about what he‚Äôs going to say.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think I know,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúAnd I have a few big worries.‚Äù

‚äô

I flew around the area before settling down. Everyone was gathered.

Erin drove a different vehicle than the last time. It was a sedan, small and very dusty. The accumulated fine dirt on the side had settled into waves that looked like very flat, spread out sand dunes, set on a vertical surface, with peaks, valleys, and patterns.

Erin opened the door. The dark makeup around her eyes was heavier, her hair was unwashed, and she wore a slim-fit sweatshirt with the sleeves rolled up, a cat on the sleeve. Her low-rise jeans were tucked into calf-height boots.

‚ÄúHi Erin,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúHi, critter,‚Äù Erin said. ‚ÄúHow are you doing?‚Äù

‚ÄúI was having a good day, but now this is happening. Feels ominous.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Erin said.

Rain took more time to get out of the passenger seat. He moved like an old man, shutting the door, letting a backpack fall to the ground by one of the car‚Äôs wheels. He had a black eye, his ear was swollen and scraped up, and his face looked asymmetrical in a way that suggested swelling on one side, with no distinct source. His knuckles and fingers were badly scraped up, with tape covering up some of them.

He was wearing a raglan tee with black sleeves, and jeans so old that they must have been as soft as sweatpants. The knees were worn through, and the knees beneath were speckled with scabs.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre hurt,‚Äù Kenzie said.

Rain nodded.

‚ÄúDid you get attacked?‚Äù Chris asked.

Rain shook his head. ‚ÄúNot by Snag‚Äôs group.‚Äù

It was hard, to pull back and watch. I‚Äôd tried for the call with Dido, stepped back to observe, letting Tristan take point with directing the others. He was good at it. Sveta being the one who had struggled had pulled me in a bit.

I wasn‚Äôt sure strict objectivity was the way to handle this, but getting too close didn‚Äôt help either.

That line of thought got me thinking about how I hadn‚Äôt ever really had to watch my back. Not among those I considered allies. Not among friends. Not among family.

And that, in turn, made me think about my sister, and the sick, hollow, angry experience of being betrayed by someone I‚Äôd thought I could trust more than I trusted myself.

I stood across from Rain and I felt like I had in the bank. The bank had been dusty, partially my fault, the floor scratched up by the passage of giant dogs, littered with discarded pieces of paper and dropped belongings. It had been dark, the rain pattering outside.

Much like Rain stood by the front of the car, hurting, his life in danger, my sister had stood a distance away from me, a knife to her throat.

Following that there had been the revelation of secrets. It wasn‚Äôt that I held Rain close to my heart or anything. It wasn‚Äôt even that I particularly trusted him. Only that I recognized the pattern.

‚ÄúShit,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre going to draw this out, at least tell me this isn‚Äôt you explaining everything and dropping something heavy on me,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúNo big news for you,‚Äù Rain said.

Tristan nodded.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to tell us what‚Äôs been going on with you?‚Äù Sveta asked.

Rain looked at Erin. ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs tied to this?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúKind of. She could walk away free and clear if she wanted, I think. She knows most of my situation. Not all.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm moral support,‚Äù Erin said.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúBecause there‚Äôs stuff you don‚Äôt know. Kind of. It‚Äôs complicated.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got a look in your eyes,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúFiercer.‚Äù

‚ÄúI spent a good day and got a beating trying to find that fierceness,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúThat thing that would let me say this. Tristan called me out, said I needed to tell you guys, because it impacts what we‚Äôre doing. I needed to do some figuring out before I was able.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Tristan said.

I was silent. I could only see the parallels. I held my tongue because I didn‚Äôt trust it. If this was an echo of that situation in the bank, I had no better idea on how to handle it now in the present.

No rain, no enclosed area. We were at the edge of a park. It was sunny out.

No knife to anyone‚Äôs throat, not that Rain‚Äôs expression said any different.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been hiding with powerful people,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúCapes, probably.‚Äù

Rain opened his mouth, then nodded.

‚ÄúA gang.‚Äù

‚ÄúA family,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúGang doesn‚Äôt really say it.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was always us and them. And there was a lot of hate directed at them,‚Äù Rain said.

The in-group, out-group‚Ä¶ and family. I could connect dots. I deliberately avoided doing so.

I focused on the situation instead, on the others. Chris was quiet, smiling slightly, but the smile had been a small, persistent thing since he‚Äôd nose-dived into indulgence. Tristan was quiet, but most of what he had to add were things that it was Rain‚Äôs responsibility to share. Ashley handled the questions.

No— Sveta joined her voice to Ashley‚Äôs. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre related to those powers. It‚Äôs why you have such a hard time pulling away.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Fallen,‚Äù Rain said.

I winced. There were a lot of implications to that.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúI kind of connected the dots already,‚Äù Sveta said. She put a hand on Kenzie‚Äôs shoulder. ‚ÄúYou first connected to Tristan after the God thing.‚Äù

‚ÄúReligion came up in therapy,‚Äù Rain said, for the benefit of the rest of us. ‚ÄúTristan came up to me after and asked about which church my family attended. I‚Äôd had a bad week. Nearly as bad as this week has been. We‚Äôd already connected some. Both of us have people invading our heads, questions of self, we talked a lot together in therapy. I cracked. I told him.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúMom and dad were looking for a church. I thought I‚Äôd ask Rain. I don‚Äôt think Rain‚Äôs church would‚Äôve suited them.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not funny,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt make jokes.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not laughing, Kenzie,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúThey hate black people, don‚Äôt they?‚Äù Kenzie asked Rain.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre a big group,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to get into just how varied the branches are, the different beliefs, how they add up, some of the leaders that have come and gone. It‚Äôs hard to just point at them and say they hate this or they hate that.‚Äù

‚ÄúMost of them hate black people,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚Äú‚Ä¶Yeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid your family? Did you? Do you?‚Äù

Rain looked back at Erin. ‚ÄúYeah. I did. Once. You have to understand— it‚Äôs hatred for anyone and everyone, because that way it keeps everyone close to the family. So ‚Äòblack‚Äô was just one more label, you know?‚Äù

‚ÄúBack at the first meeting with Mrs. Yamada. You kept giving me looks,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúThey weren‚Äôt because I pay attention to the clothes I wear and dress nice, or because you were trying to figure out what was wrong with me.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt about you,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI was figuring stuff out then. I was trying to reassess my whole way of thinking. It was me, not you.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was you,‚Äù Kenzie said. She paused. ‚ÄúBeing uncomfortable with me being there.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was—‚Äù Rain started. ‚ÄúMe being uncomfortable with everything.‚Äù

‚ÄúIncluding me. Especially me, right then,‚Äù Kenzie said. She paused, waited for a response. When Rain didn‚Äôt deny her, she added, ‚ÄúThat‚Ä¶ sucks.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not saying you suck. It sucks to hear it.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf it helps,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve changed a lot since then. I‚Äôm still figuring some stuff out.‚Äù

‚ÄúA lot of different groups to un-hate,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúI— kind of,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI still catch myself a lot. I think of things, I realize I‚Äôm making these assumptions. Then I want to change and I don‚Äôt know how. I try to use you guys as role models or talk to Mrs. Yamada, or I read, look up and watch a movie. But it‚Äôs a lot to re-teach myself.‚Äù

‚ÄúBlacks, Hispanics, Asians, Natives, Middle Easterners, then gay, trans,‚Äù Tristan rattled off.

‚ÄúDeeper than that,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI had to start with re-figuring women and how I thought about them. I‚Äôm still pretty shitty, as much as I‚Äôm trying, because I hear you rattle that off and my first thought is ‚Äòsome of these aren‚Äôt like the others‚Äô and I have to stop myself.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve said a few things,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúProbably.‚Äù

‚ÄúI figured you were a redneck.‚Äù

‚ÄúWorse,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúThey get in your head,‚Äù Erin jumped in. ‚ÄúThey got my parents. My little brother. They got Rain when he was little. I accept he‚Äôs trying.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere was a Fallen group that found a pair of people like me,‚Äù Sveta said.

Rain closed his eyes, looked down.

‚ÄúBoy and a girl. Case fifty-threes. Arizona. Peat and Fen. They showed up in a few cities, did some stunts, hero-ish. Junior level stuff. But they were juniors, we think.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know the story,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúThey were terrified of vehicles and they hated the idea of the PRT. They had a lot of peculiarities. They couldn‚Äôt stay in one place for long. Communities pulled together. It was a really cool thing, they‚Äôd get motel rooms paid for by fans, they had tutors come to visit. There was talk of trying to get them into the school system. It was tricky because they were tricky.‚Äù

Rain nodded.

‚ÄúIt was a really cool thing,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúThere were blogs that followed them, and they were really positive. There was art drawn of them— I really liked that. A couple of times a week there would be articles talking about how they were doing something new and better and it was a step forward.‚Äù

‚ÄúI knew some of it,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúYou should know all of it. There was a time in my life when I could only vicariously enjoy those sorts of things, and I‚Äôd wake up and I‚Äôd tell myself I would check the blog after lunch and I would check the art page after dinner, and that was the sort of thing that helped me get through the days. Weld stuff was first thing. There were others. But Peat and Fen were big.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúThey went down the wrong stretch of road and some Fallen jackasses on motorcycles thought they‚Äôd get a good reaction from people by holding the pair down and taking a chainsaw to their horns. To decorate their fucking helmets!‚Äù

Rain nodded, averting his eyes.

‚ÄúKnife marks suggested someone tried to cut off one of their faces to wear it as a mask. You can imagine how I felt,‚Äù Sveta said. She moved her hair, showing the edge of her face, the mass of pencil-thin black tendrils behind it. ‚ÄúSince I‚Äôm only a mask and an assortment of lethal weapons. You can imagine how I felt, when instead of my daily pick-me up I got the news that they‚Äôd died from loss of their horns.‚Äù

Kenzie ducked her head, and started to walk away. When I went to follow and check her head, Ashley held up a hand and bid me to stop, following Kenzie instead.

‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt an inquisition,‚Äù Erin said. ‚ÄúRain isn‚Äôt responsible for everything the Fallen have done.‚Äù

Sveta ignored Erin for the moment. ‚ÄúOther Fallen groups have taken us for freak shows. The embodiments of the end times. Tom and Jake Crowley. I know that‚Äôs not on you, Rain, but you have to realize they aren‚Äôt good people.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm more than aware.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen at least tell me you‚Äôre not going to go back,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúI have to,‚Äù Rain said.

I could see Sveta‚Äôs face fall.

‚ÄúI have to,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI have no choice. Really.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Sveta said, her voice sad. ‚ÄúI think you have more choice than you think you do.‚Äù

‚ÄúI really don‚Äôt. If I could do anything else, I would. I‚Äôm aware of a lot of things that are worse than Peat and Fen,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúWhat happened to Peat and Fen is pretty fucking bad,‚Äù Sveta said. She turned to Erin. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not responsible for what others did, but if you‚Äôre leaning on them for protection or strength, then that‚Äôs not okay. You can‚Äôt use that strength.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey have my family,‚Äù Erin said.

‚ÄúAnd they don‚Äôt let you go,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all‚Ä¶ very complicated.‚Äù

Ashley returned to the group. Kenzie was still sitting in the grass, a distance away, her back to us.

When I looked, Ashley gestured. Telling me to stay.

Rain looked pretty battered. Dejected.

He met my eyes.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs more to it,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúOh yeah,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúIf you won‚Äôt say it, then I will,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll guess. You killed people.‚Äù

Rain went very still.

I could remember a similar look on my sister‚Äôs face.

He huffed out a breath, hands at his lap as he slouched back against the front of the sedan, sitting against the hood. He didn‚Äôt seem to know what to do with his hands.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he finally said.

‚ÄúInnocents,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúKids,‚Äù Rain said. He looked in Kenzie‚Äôs direction. At Chris. Then he looked over his shoulder at Erin.

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù Chris asked.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been asking myself that a lot.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou maimed people,‚Äù Ashley said. Still on the offense.

‚ÄúLong term injuries. Burns,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúTo people of all ages.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor fun?‚Äù Ashley asked.

‚ÄúFor respect, if anything. I don‚Äôt know,‚Äù Rain said. He looked back to Chris, since he was really answering his question. ‚ÄúBecause a large part of me had only ever known the family, the lifestyle. All of the language — outsiders were‚Ä¶ less. It was okay to hurt ten of them if you helped one of the family‚Äôs.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey had your whole childhood to work on you,‚Äù Erin said.

‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt excuse it,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúNo. But it explains it,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúYour whole life?‚Äù I asked. My first time speaking in this conversation, maybe. I wasn‚Äôt sure — I was in a different mode.

‚ÄúMy parents were early adopters, mostly on the fringe. They got more into it as it grew. Renamed me early enough I don‚Äôt remember my original name. Rain O‚ÄôFire Frazier.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs terrible,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúShush,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúEverything about the Fallen is terrible,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúA few years after the name change, they sold me to a family halfway across the country, used the money to fuck off traveling like they‚Äôd always talked about. My guardians right now are people I‚Äôve called my aunt and uncle my whole life. I got powers with the cluster trigger, at a time I was just one more set of hands and a weapon, a henchman. That was supposed to elevate me and‚Ä¶ it did the opposite. That was my wake-up call.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good you had one,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like the idea of you going back,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúWhen you pull away is when things get worse, when violence happens.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs why I‚Äôm not pulling away,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre with us,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre doing your own thing.‚Äù

From the bank robbery to the period after. Trying to find normal again. Rain had been more open. Did that change the course of this particular river, compared to the one I‚Äôd known? Or were the key elements all there, still? The discomfort, the ‚ÄòI‚Äôm trying but I‚Äôm not going to do anything different‚Äô?

Did it still lead to disaster in the end?

‚ÄúIs the critter okay?‚Äù Erin asked. ‚ÄúKenz?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôll be fine if this ends and the group is still together,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúAre we?‚Äù Rain asked.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to say no,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúBut I think you need to go. Yesterday. Get out of there. Trust the Wardens.‚Äù

‚ÄúI would if I thought they would protect me,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúBut they‚Äôre busy. The news articles say they‚Äôre not even here lot of the time.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm okay,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúThis is ninety-five percent known stuff, and elaboration on other stuff.‚Äù

The voices of the others were a jumble. Chris didn‚Äôt care about anything. Ashley, as odd as it was, seemed most uncomfortable.

‚ÄúVictoria,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been quiet.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said.

I was aware of the silence that followed my statement.

‚ÄúSnag‚Äôs army. They‚Äôre after the Fallen,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúBut they want you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Rain said. His expression darkened as he said it. No illusions about what was in store for him if that happened.

‚ÄúBecause of the kids, and the others you killed. Because they blame you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Rain said.

I nodded.

‚ÄúI can tell you the details, if—‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to go,‚Äù I said, interrupting. I was aware of the looks I got. ‚ÄúTell Kenzie everything‚Äôs cool. I‚Äôll be back. I just need to think on this.‚Äù

No actions out of instinct. I‚Äôd think, piece everything together.

I flew away from the scene before I could say or do something I‚Äôd regret.

‚äô

Another group was patrolling the area that afternoon. Crystal and I stood on a square of crimson forcefield, well above Cedar Point, watching.

They were an older group, a bit of armor, some swords, a spear. One of them was a Brute who carried a crossbow bigger than I was. I‚Äôd always liked those things.

Simple. Easy. Bad guys bad and a bit lame. Good guys a bit lame and doing good work.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going back to the PRTCJ,‚Äù Crystal said. ‚ÄúNext week.‚Äù

I didn‚Äôt want her to go back. There was very little to like about the group.

Ironically, the advice I was following in regards to that had to do with cults. Not putting up too much of an offense, not scaring them into throwing up walls.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been two weeks,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúHow do they handle that?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo idea. Pay deduction, extra drills, demotion.‚Äù

‚ÄúI told you what I heard from D. There‚Äôs war on the horizon.‚Äù

D. Dido. In case we were being listened to. Prancer‚Äôs clairvoyants could have been listening in, and he could have hired additional intelligence gathering. No telling. We dodged particulars.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs part of why I‚Äôm going,‚Äù Crystal said.

‚ÄúSpooks me,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYou doing this spooks me,‚Äù Crystal said. ‚ÄúI want to meet everyone at some point.‚Äù

I nodded. ‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou think you have a handle on this?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think so,‚Äù I said. If ‚Äòthis‚Äô meant Cedar Point. ‚ÄúOn other stuff? Less sure.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat can I do? We want you more sure.‚Äù

‚ÄúLooks like our guests are free and clear. We‚Äôll see what they say later. I‚Äôve got a meeting. Do you mind flying with me?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad to. But we gotta eat.‚Äù

I wasn‚Äôt hungry, I was rarely hungry after thinking too much about the past, and I‚Äôd been thinking about it a lot during the discussion with Rain. Still, I nodded.

I picked up the bag and the books I‚Äôd placed atop the field, putting everything away. Crystal dropped the forcefield, and we flew with me leading the way.

It was already getting dark. The flight wasn‚Äôt a short one. I put on my music, because conversation was hard with the wind in my ears.

Time to think about Crystal and the PRTCJ. The war with Earth C. Rain. Kenzie. About what the hell I was doing here.

The sun had set by the time we arrived. The waterfront had a railing with oversized posts a boat could be lashed to. I leaned against the railing, checked my phone, and sent a message.

Mrs. Yamada approached from our right. She had food from a nearby food truck.

‚ÄúCrystal,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so nice to see you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou too,‚Äù Crystal said. She gushed just a bit as she said it. She‚Äôd met Mrs. Yamada at the hospital. They‚Äôd had talks about things. About Crystal losing Uncle Neil and Eric. About me.

There was a brief catching-up. Pleasantries. I chimed in once or twice, then found I didn‚Äôt have it in me. I stared out over the water.

‚ÄúI think— do you mind giving us privacy?‚Äù Mrs. Yamada asked.

‚ÄúSure. How‚Äôs the food here?‚Äù

‚ÄúThis? It‚Äôs good.‚Äù

‚ÄúWave when you want me to come back. I‚Äôll be enjoying the view until then.‚Äù

Mrs. Yamada leaned against the railing next to me. Her dinner smelled amazing and I still didn‚Äôt want to eat anything.

‚ÄúSorry to be eating while we talk. I haven‚Äôt had a bite to eat since grabbing a protein bar and a pear at five forty-five this morning.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúPlease eat. Thank you for seeing me.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you. Is everyone okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúIntact, yes. Okay? Were they okay when I met them?‚Äù

‚ÄúThey were in a place where I felt like they could finish their own journeys. Most of them. I imagine there‚Äôs some backsliding here and there, difficulties and things that aren‚Äôt okay because of external stresses and internal factors within the group.‚Äù

‚ÄúSome,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúSome figuring things out from moment to moment. Small triumphs.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs good. More or less what I expected.‚Äù

‚ÄúRain revealed his situation,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI heard,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúYou wanted to do some thinking.‚Äù

‚ÄúI did,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt do that thinking for you. But if you want to talk out loud, I can help you along the way.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen it comes to Rain, I think I get it,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not okay with it, but not in a way that‚Äôs going to ruin anything. It sucks to see the big and little things that affect the others. Some issues close to Sveta‚Äôs heart.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre thinking about something else,‚Äù she concluded.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúWhen Weld showed up at the first session, he said he was sorry he couldn‚Äôt sit in.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe did.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou asked him to counsel the group on their hero idea before you asked me.‚Äù

‚ÄúBefore the community center, before your boss called me. Yes.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe said no, but he could help in a while.‚Äù

‚ÄúMore or less.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut you chose me in the end. You could have waited and had him sit in, and he‚Äôs‚Ä¶ a great guy who everyone respects. You chose me, for reasons besides timing.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not much of a schemer.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not saying I‚Äôm wrong,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúNo it isn‚Äôt. But I‚Äôm worried if I say yes, then there‚Äôs expectations, and there‚Äôs disappointment if this doesn‚Äôt end up going well. I‚Äôm far from superhuman, I make mistakes, and this could be another. What are you thinking this is?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou wanted a quality I had, that Weld might not. I was thinking about the team, the traps we could fall into. Is it the paranoia? The fact I can‚Äôt quite trust people?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat seems like an unkind way to describe yourself.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs true.‚Äù

‚ÄúUnkind, still.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou wanted someone that isn‚Äôt too enmeshed into the group. Someone wary that‚Äôs seen the Asylum and knows the sort of thing that comes out of there. Someone that might see how they operate within the dynamic now that most have let their guards down. You think something‚Äôs up, and you didn‚Äôt tell me what it is because you didn‚Äôt want me going in with too many preconceived ideas. Because‚Ä¶ you wanted to see if I drew the same conclusions. Something bad‚Äôs in play with this group.‚Äù

She nodded to herself.

‚ÄúAm I wrong?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not wrong,‚Äù she said.

Shade — Interlude 4c

She stared up at the ceiling, tears in her eyes.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not like I didn‚Äôt give you warnings,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt change your mind?‚Äù she asked. It sounded like pleading, begging.

She looked at him. His head was shaved, his chin was marked with stubble, and he looked weary. The front door was ajar, the world outside dark. He had his jacket and shoes on, and he stood in the hallway, while she stood in the living room. The water hadn‚Äôt even dried from when he‚Äôd walked in from outdoors and it was clear in his body language he was about to go.

He took a long time to decide what to say.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd say you could tell me things were going to be different—‚Äù

‚ÄúThey will.‚Äù

‚Äú—But you‚Äôve told me it before,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt believe your words anymore.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt just about me,‚Äù she said, raising her voice.

‚ÄúSeventy-five percent me, twenty-five percent you, then,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt fucking reduce it to numbers,‚Äù she said, angry now.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve talked about this,‚Äù he said. His voice was calm, in stark contrast to hers. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve tried to be fair. I outlined what needed to change. That you needed to take it easier and be more reliable. I don‚Äôt even know where you are some nights, and it‚Äôs not because of work.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs part of the job!‚Äù she said. Her voice echoed down the hallway, and the echo came back different. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the work culture! How many times do I have to say it!?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve outlined what needed to change. The therapist took my side. She thought it was fair. We agreed on rules, the therapist signed off on them, and you broke them,‚Äù he said. His voice was more weary than his expression was. ‚ÄúHow many times have I had to get Ever out of bed late at night, get her things, and bring her to the hospital like that because you‚Äôve gotten hurt? You‚Äôre a mom.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm a human being! I‚Äôm trying to find a balance!‚Äù Again, the echo, louder, jumbled, not going away as it bounced off of the walls, building and multiplying.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs almost five. She‚Äôll be in kindergarten this September. In the last four years and seven months, She‚Äôs learned to walk, talk, do some chores, and she‚Äôs going to go into school knowing some reading, adding, and subtracting. She‚Äôs figured all that out. Why can‚Äôt you figure out your balance in that same time?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh fuck you, Lee!‚Äù

‚ÄúDad?‚Äù the voice was small.

Lee turned and stepped aside. The little girl— Everly, she‚Äôd crept up, and now she stood in the hallway that went from the front hall toward the bedrooms, fidgeting with her nightgown.

‚ÄúOh, hon—‚Äù her words were nearly drowned out by the jumble of sound.

‚ÄúHey Ever!‚Äù Lee‚Äôs voice interrupted hers, positive, happy. Were the point of view not from the woman‚Äôs perspective, Love Lost‚Äôs perspective, then nobody would‚Äôve heard the small, broken sound that escaped her throat. Another person might not have seen how the lens was watery, blurry at the bottom edges with tears.

Lee bent down and swept Ever up in his arms. ‚ÄúWhat are you doing out of bed?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre shouting.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo I‚Äôm not, goblin,‚Äù he said. He squeezed the girl in a hug. As he did, he turned, his face where Everly couldn‚Äôt see, and gave Love Lost an accusatory, disappointed look.

No I‚Äôm not. But she is.

‚ÄúWhere are you going?‚Äù Everly asked.

‚ÄúI have to go away for a bit.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou weren‚Äôt going to say goodbye?‚Äù

‚ÄúWere you?‚Äù Love Lost asked. She didn‚Äôt shout, but the words reverberated and echoed down the hallway and through the house as if she‚Äôd voiced the words with a megaphone.

Lee‚Äôs look was much fiercer, this time.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not goodbye,‚Äù Lee said, the gentle tone disconnected from expression. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to see you soon. Promise.‚Äù

‚ÄúWizards can‚Äôt lie, Daddy.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know, baby.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd we‚Äôre wizards. It‚Äôs not allowed. It‚Äôs a pact of a promise.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know. You and me, we‚Äôre wizards and we keep our word.‚Äù

Love Lost shook her head, looking away, elsewhere in the living room, down at her hand, which was clenched. When she opened her hand, her palm had a row of half-moon marks in it.

Lee set Everly down. ‚ÄúGo to your mom. Sorry, goblin, but I‚Äôve got to go.‚Äù

Everly looked at her mom, hesitated, both hands on her dad‚Äôs leg, then obediently crossed the way.

Love Lost knelt on the living room rug, folding her daughter into a hug, her head buried in the little girl‚Äôs shoulder and hair.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll send you the papers by the end of the week,‚Äù Lee said.

Love Lost flinched, whole-body, as the door shut with a solid impact. The sound broke up as well, scattered, became a hundred trampling shoes and boots, bangs. Picture frames rattling became another kind of rattle, of things clattering, falling down.

The floodgates opened, and her arms still encircling Everly, she used her thumbs and fingers to try to wipe tears away. To keep Everly from seeing.

‚ÄúWhy are you crying? Mom?‚Äù

She shook her head.

‚ÄúMom? What did I do?‚Äù

Her voice broke as she tried to speak. The noises were too loud— the jumble.

Her eyes were wrenched open as people pushed in close. Her surroundings were claustrophobic, not even accounting for all of the people. Folded tables and pallets on either side of her, many with papers stuck to them. The words ‚Äòevent‚Äô, ‚Äòconvention‚Äô stood out on the paper. People pushed, shoved, and Love Lost pulled closer to the wall, put her head down, burying her face in her daughter‚Äôs hair.

‚ÄúMom,‚Äù was the faint sound, almost drowned out.

Love Lost looked. She made eye contact with her daughter, now grown, twelve or so years old. Makeup around her eyes was thick, bright, smudged. Strands of red hair with one strand bleached and colored blue had fallen across her face. Everly looked terrified.

People pushed past, and Love Lost did what she could to hug her daughter closer. The space between the piles of stuff might have seemed like a refuge at one point, but it wasn‚Äôt big enough for two people. Love Lost sat on the ground, her back to the wall, pulling Everly in as tight as she could.

A man squeezed by, and Love Lost looked down at where her hand gripped her daughter‚Äôs waist. The friction of the man pushing past had skinned the back of her hand.

Love Lost shouted, inarticulate, and her own voice was inaudible. Angry shouts, telling people to get back, to give space. Someone tried to stick a leg into the gap between her and the folded tables leaning against the wall to one side. The tables rattled as the picture frames had, a steady, endless, echoing drum.

Her daughter said something, but the noises— too much noise.

I can feel the vibration of her speaking against Love Lost‚Äôs chest, Rain thought.

Love Lost screamed words at the crowd.

The pressure of the packed crowd was such that the stacked tables couldn‚Äôt handle it. Something gave, and the tables fell, sliding down against the ground, taking the legs out of a dozen people in the crowd. The result was a domino effect, people falling over and taking others with them. Others sought relief from pressure in moving over the crowd.

The ripple effect in the crowd was more like a tidal wave crashing through. One moment, where Love Lost‚Äôs eyes moved over the crowd, saw people falling, saw others pushing—

Her daughter was torn from her arms by the shift in the crowd. She watched, the scene slowing down, the noise dying out, fingers grasping, as Everly‚Äôs face was forced— shoved into the side of a table that hadn‚Äôt fully collapsed.

The only sound was the impact, a single, hard knock. The dull echo and the rattling.

Her eyes went first to the slash of red, the gap between nostril and teeth, where the upper lip had split. Then to Everly‚Äôs eyes, which pointed in slightly different directions, unfocused. Gone.

She reached for Everly and the movement of the crowd didn‚Äôt let her make contact. People moved in, stepping on her, on Everly‚Äôs body, and Love Lost fought, fierce, desperate, and animal.

A scream tore from her lips, a multi-note sound. Anger, desperation, despair, grief.

Love Lost leaned over the counter, hands at her temple, as the screaming on the television stopped, replaced by a jingle, jarring voices. Bugs danced on the screen, turning around to wiggle their rear ends, showing off the symbols stamped on their shells.

‚ÄúEverlyn,‚Äù she said.

Her hands moved at her temple, and the scene distorted with the movements.

‚ÄúEverlyn!‚Äù she raised her voice. The shout echoed through the apartment.

She heard the tromp of running feet. The sound echoed, became a part of the background noise.

‚ÄúYes mom?‚Äù the voice asked.

‚ÄúTurn it down. That‚Äôs loud enough to bother the neighbors. And turn it off, if you‚Äôre not watching.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was going to watch.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou were in your room.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wanted to find someone to watch it with me.‚Äù

Love Lost looked over as two stuffed toys were placed on the counter‚Äôs edge. Ugly things, with twisted faces. One of them looked like a ballsack with arms, legs, and a bulldog face. Ugly toys were apparently the in thing. The other was alright. A princess doll with red hair.

‚ÄúSee?‚Äù Everlyn moved the toys, animating them with wiggles and moving a finger up to raise the princess‚Äôs arm.

‚ÄúI see. Now turn it down.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

The toys were left where they were. A moment later, the volume of the children‚Äôs voices singing the repetitive song started dropping. The noise of the lingering echoes remained.

‚ÄúQuieter,‚Äù Love Lost said. Her fingers moved at her temples, drawing her eyes into slits, as she stared down at the sink.

The sound of the television dropped again. The two toys were whisked away from the edge of the counter.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù Love Lost said, raising her voice to be heard as the footsteps retreated at a run. She drew in a deep breath and sighed, aggrieved.

The peace lasted about five seconds. Something crashed, a loud sound that cascaded, as if everything had fallen down.

‚ÄúSorry!‚Äù Everlyn called out, from the other end of the house, her voice high. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll clean it up!‚Äù

Love Lost raised herself up straight, then went to the kitchen cupboard, retrieving a bottle of headache pills. She doled out two into her hand. The stem of a wine glass was briefly visible as she washed them down.

The theme song had ended, and the television was high cartoon voices, now.

Love Lost buried her face in her hands and sighed.

‚ÄúMom?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes?‚Äù

‚ÄúMom.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat is it, Everlyn?‚Äù Love Lost‚Äôs voice could only be described as barely restrained, slightly muffled with her face still in her hands.

‚ÄúCan I show you something?‚Äù

‚ÄúHow bad is the mess?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, that. I‚Äôll clean it up after. Can I show you something?‚Äù

‚ÄúCan it wait? Please? I‚Äôm not up for it right now.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

Love Lost remained where she was. The sounds in the background settled into a throbbing sync. The television show broke away to show ads, high cartoon voices replaced with adult announcers touting toys and kids screaming their glee in response.

She raised her head up, and a slice of color caught her eye. She looked— the princess doll, sitting on the edge of the counter. The weight of the doll held down a little booklet.

She set the doll aside, noting the paper shield stuck to the arm with two pieces of clear tape. The cover of the book had two women on it, both with red hair.

The woman in a dress with the shield was in the book, alongside a figure that wasn‚Äôt supposed to be a woman, but Everly. A child drawing herself as larger and more prominent, with a scarf drawn overlong, sprawling out over the page.

The red-haired wizard had once had a teacher but he was gone. There was only the knight who had ‚Äòraised her up‚Äô, who had red hair like her. The knight ‚Äòdetected‚Äô crimes and was always very tired and very grumpy.

Children on the television in the background shrieked. The sound became a growing echo of screams.

Love Lost‚Äôs vision blurred slightly, and she paged through. The lead-in to the book took a long time, and the confrontation at the end was brief, as the demon was slain.

Love Lost looked away, at a small collection of empty bottles on the counter, tucked beside the microwave and the wall, set out of reach.

She finished looking through the book‚Äôs ending. She closed it, hand pressing down the front cover so it would lie flat instead of sticking straight up. The teacher‚Äôs sticker was in the corner, a tiny superhero silhouette holding up a giant ‚ÄòA+‚Äô. The teacher had penned out a response, saying in length how much they loved it.

Love Lost‚Äôs thumbnail dragged against the construction paper, scratching the words the teacher had put down, the edge of the nail finding the grooves where the pen nib had dug into the softer paper.

She pressed the book to her chest, and picked up the doll. The paper shield came undone, and she carefully pressed the tape back into place along the doll‚Äôs arm.

She walked down the hallway, then pushed open the door.

Toys and stuffed animals were scattered across the floor. Love Lost‚Äôs eyes roved, over posters on the wall, mostly wizard things, more of the goblins. Homework assignments and one picture of Lee were taped to the wall, at waist height and below.

An eight year old Everly was on her bed, surrounded by toys. She watched her mother, expression solemn.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry I forgot to turn off the tv,‚Äù Everlyn said.

‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt matter.‚Äù

Everlyn looked at the closet. A set of metal poles with baskets had been pulled down, bringing down the basket from the back of the door in the process. The stuffed animals from within had been emptied onto the floor of the room, with one pole leaning against the child-size chair in the corner of the room.

Everlyn nodded.

‚ÄúI love this,‚Äù Love Lost said, pressing the book against her heart.

Everlyn smiled, ‚ÄúYou do?‚Äù

‚ÄúI love everything about it,‚Äù Love Lost said, for emphasis.

‚ÄúThere are parts I worried you wouldn‚Äôt like.‚Äù

‚ÄúI love it all,‚Äù Love Lost said. ‚ÄúCan I sit?‚Äù

Everlyn moved over so her mother could sit down beside her. She took the doll back.

‚ÄúWhen you wanted a scarf for Christmas, did you want one like this? Like—‚Äù

‚ÄúI like the one you gave me.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut did you want one like this?‚Äù Love Lost looked at pictures on the wall. The sound of her own heartbeat echoed, the sounds that the television spat out growing louder in the distance, like an onrushing train. She pointed. ‚ÄúLike that?‚Äù

Everlyn nodded, ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat do you say we go shopping later? We‚Äôll see what we can find.‚Äù

Everlyn nodded, emphatic. ‚ÄúYes please.‚Äù

Love Lost reached for her daughter and wrapped her in a hug.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to try to be a better mom, okay?‚Äù

Everlyn nodded.

Everlyn pulled to one side. The movement of people around her tugged her, threatening to pull her from her mother‚Äôs arms. Her expression was so afraid.

Again, just as before, down to the last detail, the pressure of the packed crowd was such that the stacked tables couldn‚Äôt handle it. The tables fell, sliding out and across the floor, bowling over a section of the crowd. Again, the domino effect, again, people fell over and knocked or pulled others down with them.

Again, people climbed over the fallen.

Once again, the sound seemed to fade. Once again, things moved in slow motion as Love Lost‚Äôs eyes moved along the same path, noting the same details, the same imminent result.

Her daughter was torn from her arms. Love Lost watched as Everly‚Äôs face was driven into the side of a half-fallen table.

Again, the only sound was the impact, a single, hard knock. The dull echo and the clatter after the fact.

Love Lost‚Äôs eyes traveled the exact same path as before, as if moving along a groove. First to the slash of red, the gap between nostril and teeth, where the upper lip had split. Then to Everly‚Äôs eyes, which each moved independently of the other. Gone.

The dull echo of the impact against the table was the only sound as she reached for her daughter. The movement of the crowd didn‚Äôt let her make contact. People moved in, trampling the two of them, separating them, and Love Lost fought, with nothing knightly or good about how she clawed with fingernails.

A sound tore from her lips, a sound in many parts, for a feeling that couldn‚Äôt be put to words or wordless scream.

Then that sound, too, went quiet.

Tear-blurred vision with light from the windows slicing in through the brief gaps that appeared between people became something else. Light on the horizon.

Love Lost sat with a ten year old Everlyn, facing the water, and the soft glow on the far side of it. All around them, people milled, noisy.

‚ÄúDo you want to do anything?‚Äù she asked.

Everlyn looked up at her, confused, then looked back.

Love Lost followed her daughter‚Äôs eyes. The orb of the sun was behind them, peeking in between buildings.

She turned to look at the light on the horizon. Gold.

‚ÄúDo anything?‚Äù Everlyn asked.

‚ÄúWe could go to the ice cream truck over there, and see if we can get anything.‚Äù

Her daughter looked at her as if she was crazy.

‚ÄúWe could go to the shelters, but I don‚Äôt think it would help.‚Äù

People ran this way and that. Not sure where to go. Love Lost seemed determined to stay still, stay calm.

She reached for her daughter‚Äôs hand, and that hand trembled as she took it in hers.

As if something had swept over it, the water briefly went still, every wave stopping, the ocean appearing as a flat expanse of ice or glass for the briefest moment.

The golden light flared, and it took nearly five seconds before the effect touched the water, breaking the spell. The ground shook as the effect carried into the ground beneath them, and some people who were running lost their balance.

Everlyn‚Äôs hands went to her mouth. One was the hand that Love Lost held. Love Lost gathered both hands up in her own.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt understand why the ice cream,‚Äù Everlyn said. A sentence garbled by confusion and stress.

‚ÄúI wasted so much time. I thought—‚Äù

She didn‚Äôt finish the statement.

Her daughter gave her a look, confused.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what to do,‚Äù Love Lost said.

‚ÄúHug me,‚Äù Everlyn said.

Love Lost hugged her daughter without hesitation or reserve, burying her face in Everlyn‚Äôs hair.

‚ÄúToo tight. That hurts,‚Äù Everlyn said.

The sound of the crowd mounted, the distant rumbles and rattling echoing. People brushed across Love Lost‚Äôs arm, in greater and greater numbers—

‚äô

Rain found himself in the room. He didn‚Äôt reach for the chair. He didn‚Äôt move.

The view of Gold Morning had been the third of seven scenes.

All punctuated by the same repeated event.

It had been the same way, every fifth night for the last year, with little variation. Sometimes more scenes, sometimes less. He‚Äôd seen all of these before.

It never hit him any less hard.

Snag was up, standing at the dais. Cradle, too, had approached it. Rain could hear the murmurs of their conversation.

He hated to look, but he looked.

Love Lost was in the small chair. The same chair that had been in Everlyn‚Äôs room.

Rain recognized the stuffed animals, the toys, and the little belongings. Nothing too personal, none of the wizard pictures. None of the swords-and-sorcery superhero stuff that the more moody eleven and twelve year old Everlyn had kept on her wall. None of the toys were ones she‚Äôd indicated any attachment to.

Hollow.

Love Lost sat in the chair, limp, not twitching a finger or shifting her posture. Tears marked her cheeks, darkened with the makeup from around her eyes. Unblinking, tears flowing, she glared at Rain.

It was disconcerting to see someone cry and not blink or move.

He hated this. He hated seeing that and he couldn‚Äôt imagine what it did to Love Lost. He hated that it took something away from the sympathy, that he had to temper it with his awareness of her wanting him dead.

She had been a deeply flawed person, but that didn‚Äôt make the love, the pain, or the resulting emotion any less felt. Just the opposite, in the end.

She poured hate into her glare as if she could somehow make Rain feel the loathing and anger.

With the personality bleed, he thought, she probably could.

‚äô

Rain felt his heart sink further as Victoria flew higher.

‚ÄúCrazy,‚Äù Erin said.

He looked back at her. She still stood by the door of her dad‚Äôs car. She looked so weary. ‚ÄúMe?‚Äù

‚ÄúHer. The flying, I mean. It‚Äôs crazy to go from a conversation to seeing someone take off and disappear into the sky like that.‚Äù

He‚Äôd wanted to convince Victoria more than anyone. She was the least biased in his favor because she hadn‚Äôt spent so long in group therapy, listening to his side of things, empathizing and sharing with him. A part of him had wanted to get her on his side because she wasn‚Äôt that far from all of the strangers he walked past or took the train with every day— every person who he knew would hate him if they knew his full, unfiltered story.

In the background, Kenzie had stood up. She was looking in Victoria‚Äôs direction. Sveta broke away from the group to approach her. Disconcerting, in a very different way, to see how Sveta turned her head away, and she hadn‚Äôt fixed her hair since moving it away. The thin-ness of her face, the fact that the only thing behind it was the muscle-like bundle of finger-thin tendrils.

He hadn‚Äôt seen that often. It reminded him of catching a glimpse of Erin‚Äôs bra strap. Something hidden, that he wasn‚Äôt supposed to see. It left him feeling uncomfortable in a completely different way.

Disconcerting, to see Sveta looking at him, catching him looking, and the anger and hurt in her eyes. He thought of Love Lost.

Sveta was one of the kindest people he knew. Having her angry at him? It sucked. But Peat and Fen had been the closest thing she‚Äôd had to kin for a long time.

He couldn‚Äôt wrap his head around that, because he‚Äôd never had real kin. He‚Äôd never been in one place for long enough, he‚Äôd never been welcomed.

‚ÄúYou look like you‚Äôre in shock,‚Äù Tristan said.

Rain blinked. Was he? ‚ÄúI— for a long time, yeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid you talk to Mrs. Yamada?‚Äù

‚ÄúYesterday afternoon. She helped me work up the courage to come. You were right. They all needed to know.‚Äù

Tristan nodded.

He was aware of the subset of the group that had gathered. Ashley, Tristan, Chris, and himself, with Erin in the background. He looked back at Erin.

He knew the accusation Moonsong had leveled against Tristan, and he had an idea of what that was about. Ashley hadn‚Äôt hidden her past. Three out of the five people present had killed in the past. It was disorienting, to track the number as it climbed.

Sveta had an especially bloody past. She‚Äôd even gotten blood on her hands after leaving the Asylum.

‚ÄúHas Victoria ever killed anyone?‚Äù Rain asked, before he realized he was asking it.

The reaction was as one might expect. Blinks. Surprise from Tristan. A snort and smile from Chris.

‚ÄúWhat are you asking?‚Äù Chris asked.

‚ÄúI thought the admission I‚Äôd killed people would have had more impact than the things the Fallen has done in the past,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt speak for the others, but I guessed,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúSomeone doesn‚Äôt have your kind of guilt without something that bad or worse,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt think you had a choice.‚Äù

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúBut it doesn‚Äôt change what I did.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúWhen I was talking to the group about understanding what I‚Äôd done and how, I knew that sometimes Mrs. Yamada would say things and it wasn‚Äôt to me. Most of the time, when you asked about things, it wasn‚Äôt about me, it was about you.‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Rain said.

Ashley shook her head. She looked the way Victoria had gone. ‚ÄúShe hasn‚Äôt killed anyone before, if I had to guess.‚Äù

‚ÄúJust Victoria and the kids, then.‚Äù

‚ÄúJust Victoria and Kenzie,‚Äù Chris said.

Rain looked at Chris. Chris shrugged. ‚ÄúAccidental.‚Äù

‚ÄúOnly Victoria and Kenzie. Sounds right,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúChrist,‚Äù Rain said, under his breath.

‚ÄúYou talking like that was what got me asking about you and Church, remember?‚Äù Tristan asked. He folded his arms. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs your plan?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got to drive Erin back tonight. If it‚Äôs okay, I‚Äôll get together with the group tomorrow. I‚Äôve got some junk for you to drop off, if that‚Äôs okay.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat kind of junk?‚Äù Chris asked.

‚ÄúBear traps, wire guillotines, blades without handles.‚Äù

‚ÄúReally,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not lying,‚Äù Erin said. ‚ÄúI helped him load the car.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre going to come after me. I‚Äôm going to plan accordingly. I‚Äôll cover my escape route, and I‚Äôll make sure I‚Äôm armed if they close the distance.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey run on walls,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúOr jump onto walls.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll cover the ground,‚Äù Rain said, firm. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll figure something out for the walls.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can help some with that. I‚Äôm going the anxiety route, so I‚Äôll be crawling up the walls for the next few days. I can give you some perspective on where to put traps.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúYou want to set traps‚Ä¶ around the headquarters?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúAnd some place we can retreat to if we go into Cedar Point and have to retreat out of. It‚Äôs going to be hard to find places that work that won‚Äôt put civilians in the target area.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can talk to Kenzie for that,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúMake them remotely armed.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay, wait, stop, stop,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúIs this really what we‚Äôre doing?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs what I‚Äôm doing,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúFor this specific scenario, as a just-in case. I have to do something, and this is stuff I know about.‚Äù

Tristan ran his fingers through his hair. He turned to Erin, asked, ‚ÄúAre you okay with this?‚Äù

‚ÄúA while ago, I wouldn‚Äôt have been,‚Äù she said. She set her jaw a bit, ‚ÄúBut I have a gun now, and I know how to use it. Half of the reason I‚Äôm carrying it is in case those people come after Rain, or if they come after me as a way of hurting him.‚Äù

Rain felt so sad, hearing that.

Sadder, at knowing the other reason she had it.

He hated this. He hated that he saw Tristan here, looking so distressed. He hated that Sveta was so upset, that Victoria was gone, that Kenzie wasn‚Äôt rejoining the conversation when being left out was something that bothered her so much.

He hated himself, for being at the crux of so much of that. He could remember Love Lost‚Äôs penetrating glare.

How much of this self-loathing stemmed from her loathing of him?

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what to say,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúGuns and maiming?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt need to say anything,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúI feel like someone needs to say something,‚Äù Tristan said. He looked around the group, at Ashley, Chris, Rain. He looked back at Sveta and Kenzie. ‚ÄúShit, out of the four of us, it‚Äôs supposed to be up to me to make the moral argument?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt need to argue,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúReally, I get it. It‚Äôs shitty, but I thought all day yesterday about this. I‚Äôve got to do something.‚Äù

Tristan paced a little, then walked a short distance away. He muttered something under his breath.

It was Byron who walked the same short distance back.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúHey,‚Äù Byron said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm supposed to talk to you, I guess, since Tristan can‚Äôt figure out how to.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got to stay alive,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt lie down and die, and the only way I can figure out how to get through this is to be a little more vicious. I‚Äôve been in these guys heads for a year. They will kill. They hate me that much.‚Äù

Images of Everlyn flickered through Rain‚Äôs mind‚Äôs eye.

Byron was nodding.

‚ÄúKill or be killed,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúMe being killed might be deserved,‚Äù Rain added.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt deserve to be tortured to death,‚Äù Erin said. ‚ÄúAnd I don‚Äôt believe in death for crimes committed either. Only in self defense, if there aren‚Äôt other options.‚Äù

‚ÄúDeath is a reality when powers come into play and people aren‚Äôt willing to play nice. It‚Äôs why so many of us have body counts. Other teams aren‚Äôt that different, I‚Äôm sure,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúA lot of powers don‚Äôt come with a ‚Äòstun‚Äô option. A lot of other powers don‚Äôt come as part and parcel with power-users who would or could use that option if they had it.‚Äù

Rain shook his head.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think you deserve the torture and-or murder kind of end either,‚Äù Byron said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to say no to the traps, or to Erin‚Äôs gun. If it comes to staying alive, use them. Do whatever you have to that doesn‚Äôt put others in harm‚Äôs way.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to say some other stuff, though,‚Äù Byron said. His expression was so different from Tristan‚Äôs. More serious by default than Tristan‚Äôs was when Tristan was being serious. His words had weight, even spoken more quietly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to tick Tristan off, saying this, but I‚Äôm going to start off by saying I really don‚Äôt like the team idea.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs going to tick him off, yeah,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúThe idea has good parts to it,‚Äù Byron said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs even cool to see people like Ashley and Kenzie talking about team names, getting excited about costumes. But that‚Äôs where they‚Äôre at, Rain. They‚Äôre still figuring it out. Victoria is focused on that right now, I think. A lot of talk of costumes and names.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe talked about that a fair bit,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúThe shitty part of the idea?‚Äù Byron asked. ‚ÄúThe thing that worries me? It‚Äôs the idea that the worst things might bubble to the surface and get in the way of this being genuine or good. Chris is talking about Kenzie making components or alerts for traps that are going to potentially maim? No. That‚Äôs‚Ä¶ really not right.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre talking about me?‚Äù Kenzie asked, smiling as she asked it.

‚ÄúMaiming?‚Äù Sveta asked.

The pair were rejoining the group, after their heart-to heart.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre talking about how far we‚Äôre willing to go to save Rain,‚Äù Byron said.

‚ÄúOh. That‚Äôs obvious. All the way,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúNot if it compromises stuff. Byron‚Äôs right.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre going to take serious measures, I think it should be separate from the team,‚Äù Byron said, quiet and serious. ‚ÄúLet them be heroes. Be a hero with them, with that other stuff being secondary. Keep it away from the hideout and headquarters.‚Äù

Rain nodded.

‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt mean these guys can‚Äôt help you,‚Äù Byron said. ‚ÄúIt means that if you‚Äôre planning on matching your enemy in preparing to go to war, you can‚Äôt ask others unequivocally to come with you.‚Äù

Rain nodded again. He felt something bitter well up deep inside, and his expression twisted as he looked away.

‚ÄúI missed stuff,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll tell you after,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúSorry Rain,‚Äù Byron said. ‚ÄúTake that as advice from someone in the diminishing population of people with reasonably clean hands. Advice from someone who had a very close up view of hands getting unclean.‚Äù

‚ÄúI shouldn‚Äôt ruin them,‚Äù Rain said, looking at the group.

‚ÄúEscalate if you have to, but don‚Äôt make it part of how the team operates,‚Äù Byron said. ‚ÄúBecause yeah, that might ruin them.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre overestimating how intact we were when we started,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm estimating that the team started from a place of healing and support,‚Äù Byron said. ‚ÄúIf this is going to work out at all, and I really don‚Äôt think it is, sorry Tristan, it needs to hold on to that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI like that,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù Byron said.

Ruined. Rain had a sick feeling in his gut. He looked back at Erin.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve spent nearly two years living with the Fallen,‚Äù Erin said. She smiled, but her heart wasn‚Äôt really behind it. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt go thinking you ruined me, because they‚Äôve got dibs.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat doesn‚Äôt make me feel better,‚Äù Rain said.

He was struck with the urge, almost panic-level, yet driven by that strong core he‚Äôd spent all of yesterday trying to dig up, to say something that would maybe save Erin. To tell the others to grab her, or to not let her go back. He could tell the truth and it might even work, or he could lie, and it would work slightly better, but be limited more to the short term.

She had a gun and she had it partially because she was his friend and she wanted to protect him.

She had it, in part, to protect herself against the people she was going back to.

‚ÄúThank you for hearing me out,‚Äù he said to the group. ‚ÄúI guess I‚Äôll see what Victoria says or does tomorrow. If I‚Äôm welcome.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think you are,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúAnd I think Erin is too, but we‚Äôll discuss if we‚Äôre okay having her in the headquarters. If we aren‚Äôt, we‚Äôll still hang out, talk, make sure everything‚Äôs good.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat sounds nice,‚Äù Erin said. ‚ÄúI could do with more friends than just Rain.‚Äù

Rain nodded. Privately, he wanted that for Erin too. Especially if something happened to him, he wanted her to have people to reach out to.

‚ÄúI wish you weren‚Äôt going back at all, Rain,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt say it enough.‚Äù

I wish I wasn‚Äôt going back either, Rain thought. I wish I wasn‚Äôt taking Erin back.

Byron blurred, his eyes flaring as he became Tristan.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúI appreciate you stepping in, sorry for pushing you into that conversation. I need to think. Take the rest of my time.‚Äù

There was another blur. Tristan became Byron again.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs late,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI think— we‚Äôll go back?‚Äù

Erin nodded.

‚ÄúWant a ride, By?‚Äù Rain offered. ‚ÄúTo the station?‚Äù

Byron nodded.

‚ÄúAnyone else?‚Äù Erin asked. Rain wished she hadn‚Äôt, but waited patiently while the others discussed.

They were going back to the headquarters, to check tapes and discuss, and to prepare for another patrol group that was going to do a walk-through of Cedar Point. It would just be Byron, Rain, and Erin in the car. Sveta had maybe noticed that Rain wanted to talk to his closer friends, and had steered the group‚Äôs arrangement slightly.

They three of them got in Erin‚Äôs dad‚Äôs car, leaving the traps and other junk in the boot. Rain took the passenger seat, suppressing his grunts and groans of pain as bruises made themselves felt. Byron took the back seat.

He wanted to talk to his friend, and he wasn‚Äôt sure how. The first fifteen minutes of the drive were agony, in a way.

Any other time, he would have been just fine with the fact that Byron was someone who seemed content to be quiet, to not make conversation.

They reached the train station, and Erin pulled into a parking spot.

‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt tell them about the room,‚Äù Byron said.

‚ÄúThe room?‚Äù Erin asked.

‚ÄúDream thing,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúShould I get out of the car or plug my ears or something?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI trust you.‚Äù

‚ÄúNah. You boys talk. I‚Äôm going to run to the vending machine, since it‚Äôs a long drive. You can fill me in on the way back if you want.‚Äù

She climbed out of the car.

Rain watched her go, feeling a pang of sadness.

‚ÄúShe looks stressed,‚Äù Byron observed.

‚ÄúBad day yesterday. It‚Äôs starting to catch up with her, Fallen being Fallen.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd even like this she‚Äôs so stunning it sucks the air out of the room,‚Äù Byron said.

Rain looked in the direction Erin had gone. ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know how you do it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not doing it. Not well.‚Äù

Rain wasn‚Äôt just talking about Erin.

‚ÄúToday wasn‚Äôt easy,‚Äù Byron said.

‚ÄúLast night wasn‚Äôt easy. If I wasn‚Äôt forced to sleep I‚Äôd have been up all night freaking out. Instead I had to have some of the shittiest memory-dreams, and then put on a poker face so I wouldn‚Äôt show any weakness to the people who want me dead.‚Äù

Byron thought for a moment, then said, ‚ÄúLast night was Love Lost?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Byron echoed him.

‚ÄúYou said something about the air being sucked out of the room, and I feel like it‚Äôs always that way. I can‚Äôt breathe, I can‚Äôt focus, I go from one bad moment to the next and I don‚Äôt even get the mercy of sleep. That‚Äôs without even taking Erin into account. Who‚Äôs—‚Äù

‚ÄúYou love her.‚Äù

Rain reeled at the idea.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt blame you. I don‚Äôt think anyone would.‚Äù

‚ÄúI— I spent all of last night watching someone have the one person they cared about most in the world get torn from them over and over again. Then I saw the aftermath. Hurting Erin would be the one way they could do that to me. I guess I do.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Byron said. ‚ÄúI think anyone in your situation, in ours, in this kind of thing, if they had someone being nice and cool, they‚Äôd cling to that. Love would be natural and inevitable.‚Äù

Rain nodded.

‚ÄúBut Erin‚Äôs special, I think. She‚Äôs someone you could fall in love with, in any situation, not just one where she‚Äôs the one port in an ugly storm.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Rain‚Äôs voice was hollow.

‚ÄúBe good to her,‚Äù Byron said.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt,‚Äù Rain replied. ‚ÄúBecause the most ‚Äògood‚Äô thing I could do for her would be to kidnap her and take her away from all of this. But if I did, she‚Äôd never talk to me again, and I‚Äôd lose my mind without her having my back. I hate myself for it.‚Äù

Byron was silent.

‚ÄúInstead, I‚Äôve got to drive back with her, take her back to that. Actual, serious danger. I feel like I‚Äôm going to panic any second, I can‚Äôt figure out a clear way out, you‚Äôre right that I can‚Äôt drag the others into it, so there‚Äôs a part of it I have to do myself, the uglier, more monstrous part and—‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs hard,‚Äù Byron said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôm strong enough. That‚Äôs why I decided at the last minute I couldn‚Äôt tell them about the room. If I did, I feel like they‚Äôd read a selfish undercurrent into things.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt would tie your hands,‚Äù Byron said.

‚ÄúIt— kind of. The room, and how the powers are doled out. It incentivizes us killing each other. I‚Äôm weak. I‚Äôm really weak. If I kill them, I probably get stronger. That‚Äôs my only way out, and if I admit it to the team, and if one of the cluster die, it‚Äôs going to be something entirely different from most of us having taken lives in the past, under duress or before the amnesty. It‚Äôs going to be real and now.‚Äù

Byron nodded slowly, looking out the window.

‚ÄúDoes that change how you see me? That I‚Äôm seriously thinking about killing them?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Byron said. ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt surprise me. I don‚Äôt exactly blame you, or blame you for not wanting to tell the others.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut?‚Äù

‚ÄúBut if you want to have that conversation, I think you should have it with Tristan, not me. You sound an awful lot like he did, and I don‚Äôt think he liked how it ended up.‚Äù

Byron opened the car door. He put a hand on Rain‚Äôs shoulder, brief, as he made his exit from the vehicle. He crossed paths with Erin, who was returning, accepted a chocolate bar from her, and disappeared around the corner.

Erin dumped the collection of junk food onto the space between the two front seats, then put the sodas in an empty trash bin on the floor of the car, so they wouldn‚Äôt roll around.

‚ÄúGood talk?‚Äù she asked.

‚ÄúYes, thank you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI thought you two needed the elbow room,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúSugar and caffeine is for if you want to stay awake on the way back.‚Äù

‚äô

Rain was startled awake by a hand at his shoulder. Candy wrappers fell from his lap as he sat up straighter.

It was dark out, Erin was in the driver‚Äôs seat, face illuminated by the reflection of her headlights.

She looked spooked.

The path to the camp cut through woods, and the boundary where the area had been cleared out and the settlement began was marked with posts and a signboard that hung overhead. ‚ÄòAbandon all hope, all ye who enter here‚Äô.

It was supposed to be a cute reference. It seemed apt now. Standing around the two posts, on either side of the road, were Tim, Jay, Nell, Levi, Amos, Ruby and Naomi.

Tim was the oldest in the group. His mask was a horse‚Äôs head, cut up, twisted around, and rigged to work as a mask. The mouth pointed up and to one side, teeth bared. Tim‚Äôs eye peered through the open eye socket of the horse‚Äôs, the back of the head and cheek of the horse serving to house the roll of Tim‚Äôs chin. He was tattooed heavily, with more black ink than pale white skin, all textured by heavy body hair. It was macabre enough it didn‚Äôt look ridiculous, especially in the stark light of the car‚Äôs headlights.

Not Tim, not really. Seir.

The teenagers were in civilian clothes, the crevices of their face cast into shadow by the angled light. Jay had his mask in hand, long hair held back by his baseball cap.

Erin‚Äôs hand went to the gearshift.

To park?

No. To reverse.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Rain said.

It wouldn‚Äôt work, they wouldn‚Äôt get away, and they‚Äôd be punished for trying, as sure as they would be any other time they tried to make a break for it.

‚ÄúJust‚Ä¶ drive,‚Äù he told her. ‚ÄúSlowly.‚Äù

Seir walked over, as the car crept forward. He stopped by Erin‚Äôs car door, peering at them with the one eye.

‚ÄúCozy,‚Äù The side of the horse‚Äôs head parted as Tim spoke, a slit opening up between temple and the joint of the jaw.

Erin kept her eyes forward.

‚ÄúWhat have I told you about not ignoring me?‚Äù Seir asked.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, sir,‚Äù Erin said, turning her head to look at him. Her neck and jaw were stiff.

Seir‚Äôs eye shifted, looking at Rain.

‚ÄúMy brother-in-law beat the shit out of you,‚Äù Seir said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúHe did. I literally asked for it, though.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo I heard. What candy is that?‚Äù

Rain felt in the dark cab of the car, until his hand rustled a bag that wasn‚Äôt empty. ‚ÄúGrape apes.‚Äù

Seir reached his hand through the window, and Erin twisted her face away. The hand was held out, and Rain placed the bag of candy in it.

Seir ripped the bag open, and put a handful of purple monkey gummies into his mouth. He chewed noisily.

‚ÄúYour repeated absences have been noticed,‚Äù Seir said, mouth full.

Rain was silent.

‚ÄúBuying candy?‚Äù Seir asked.

‚ÄúAnd using the internet, doing research on powers.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd?‚Äù

‚ÄúGoing into the city. Shopping.‚Äù

Seir chewed more candy. He didn‚Äôt ask any questions, and Rain didn‚Äôt volunteer anything.

The bag of candy was about the size of two fists put side-to-side. As time passed, Seir rummaged in the bag, found more, chewed them, cramming more into the slit in the horse‚Äôs head before he was even done with the last mouthful. He must have finished three quarters of the bag as the silence stretched on, his one eye on the pair.

Erin flinched as Seir tossed the mostly empty bag into her lap.

‚ÄúLeadership wants a chat with you,‚Äù Seir said.

Rain had been sleeping minutes ago, but now he was more than awake. Those words— if he‚Äôd gone straight to bed, no longer bound by the rhythm of his power and the demands of the room, even being as tired as he was, he wouldn‚Äôt have been able to sleep. Not after hearing that.

‚ÄúWith—‚Äù he started. He wanted to word it right. Couldn‚Äôt show weakness. ‚ÄúMe? Now?‚Äù

If he asked if that invitation included Erin, Seir might say yes, just out of spite, might make her go.

Please don‚Äôt make Erin go.

‚ÄúYou. We were to wait and bring you as soon as you turned up. Which is now,‚Äù Seir said.

Rain opened the car door. He didn‚Äôt look at Erin, he didn‚Äôt say a word. He got out of the vehicle. He closed the door.

She drove away, through the settlement center, to her parents‚Äô house.

Rain was left with his escort.

They talked among themselves, but they avoided talking to him. Seir remained close, ready to push at Rein‚Äôs back or shoulder if he dragged his feet. The rest were a half-circle behind and to either side of them. They talked among themselves, but they avoided talking to him.

Fear driving his senses to the next level, Rain was very aware of the smell of the grape apes. A candy he‚Äôd never be able to eat or smell again without feeling nauseous.

If he even got that far.

The house wasn‚Äôt even two years old, but it looked older, because the white paint on the wooden slat exterior was haphazardly applied, brush strokes long and the paint allowed to go thin. There was a white-painted fence, and none of the teenaged escorts went past the gate. They stopped beyond, standing guard there.

The front door was unlocked. Rain was ushered inside, the door was gently closed, and Rain was made to walk further.

In the living room, six of the senior Fallen were seated. Drinks sat on side tables, assorted snacks sat on a platter on the coffee table. The domestic scene was made eerie by the masks they wore. Demonic faces, many homemade. Several had been farm animals, the flesh altered with the power of a man Rain didn‚Äôt see present, so the pigs and sheep would have half-human, distorted faces before they were killed and skinned. Women in nice dresses with nice hair had heavy tattoos that reached up their necks and beneath their masks. A man wore the hide of an animal around his waist, wearing no shirt so the letters carved out and left to scar on his belly and chest would be visible.

Rain could trace his family connection to most of those present.

He could trace his connection to the meek young women who stood by, ready to serve anything requested. The one with her back to Rain had old lines of red dots soaked through the back of her blouse, criss-crossing.

The assembly was silent, wordless, watching from behind masks as Rain was urged to the stairs.

Even Seir didn‚Äôt go upstairs if he could help it.

Rain felt every ache and pain, every human doubt he‚Äôd experienced over the past two days, as he ascended those ten stairs. The second floor was spartan, with a long rug, a small table with a vase of wilted flowers on it, and a light overhead. The hallway extended to rooms to the left and the right.

He knew the door was to the left, but he looked the other way, as if there could somehow be an out.

He saw Lachlan, standing in the hallway, toothbrush sticking out of his mouth. He reached up to pull the toothbrush free.

‚ÄúRain,‚Äù Lachlan said, smiling. His voice was a hush. ‚ÄúHey, good to see you.‚Äù

Rain didn‚Äôt have the words to respond. It was surreal, seeing Lachlan here.

‚ÄúDid you talk to Allie?‚Äù Lachlan asked.

Rain stared at Lachlan. ‚ÄúNot the time, Lachlan.‚Äù

‚ÄúLeave the boy be, Lachlan,‚Äù Seir said.

A faint thump from the left end of the hallway made all of their heads turn.

One of the meek servant-girls from the living room stepped into the hallway to stand next to Seir, even though she looked like she didn‚Äôt want to. She looked up, checking.

‚ÄúGo,‚Äù Seir said.

Rain didn‚Äôt need to be told. He walked to the end of the hallway. The doorknob squeaked.

The inside of the room wasn‚Äôt all that decorated. Dresser, bedside table, and a four-poster bed with sheer drapes winding up the posts.

‚ÄúMama,‚Äù he said.

She wasn‚Äôt his mother, but it was how she was addressed.

Rain averted his eyes, but he could see the white drape of the nightgown, the feet on the floor. She was sitting so the post and the sheer drape kept him from seeing a lot of her.

But he saw some. Her presence jumped into his head. He looked away, but it didn‚Äôt help.

Mama Mathers. Taller than him, gaunt, wispy of hair. She wasn‚Äôt old, but she had the presence of an old woman, thin enough that it seemed like she would break or crumple into a heap if struck. She stood right next to him, leaning over him. She touched his face, and he flinched.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been pulling away,‚Äù she said. Her voice was just as ethereal as the rest of her. ‚ÄúThere is no away, Rain. You should know that.‚Äù

He remained still, trying not to look.

‚ÄúWe give the young ones so many allowances, and we‚Äôve given you more than most. We thought you would find yourself. Have you?‚Äù

‚ÄúWorking on it,‚Äù he said, his voice quiet.

‚ÄúHow long has it been since we last talked?‚Äù

‚ÄúYears, mama,‚Äù he said.

Her fingers traced his shoulder-length hair. ‚ÄúI told you to grow your hair long, back then.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, mama,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúDo you remember why? Any boy of mine that does anything to catch my eye, good or bad, I have them do it.‚Äù

Rain nodded. No words would have come out if he‚Äôd said anything, so he didn‚Äôt try.

‚ÄúThe girls know it, but the boys sometimes need to learn it. I‚Äôm content to let either be my soldiers, but that requires zeal. Not everyone has it. Not everyone cleaves to their role and position. Everyone has responsibilities, and it takes a soldier to obey.‚Äù

Rain nodded again.

Her voice took on a different tone. No less ethereal, but haunting-ethereal, now. ‚ÄúThe hair is to remind you that if you won‚Äôt be a soldier for the families, we‚Äôll have you be a slut. We‚Äôll get children out of you. If you fail at that, if they‚Äôre sickly or disobedient, we‚Äôll geld you like we would any of the farm animals.‚Äù

Rain‚Äôs nod was stiff.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre so distant. Have your aunt and uncle failed us? I‚Äôd thought your uncle was so dutiful.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôve done everything right,‚Äù Rain said, eyes on the corner of the rug on the floor.

‚ÄúYour uncle beat you. You‚Äôre weak but you‚Äôre one of our blessed,‚Äù she said, speaking in his ear. ‚ÄúWe could have him crippled or killed.‚Äù

‚ÄúI asked him to, mama.‚Äù

‚ÄúEven so,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúHe is— he‚Äôs everything you want in a soldier,‚Äù Rain said, and his words were halting as he tried to defend a man he didn‚Äôt even love or like. ‚ÄúHurting him to make a point or impart something onto me would hurt the Fallen more than it helped anything.‚Äù

‚ÄúAllie then,‚Äù she said. Her voice was a whisper now. ‚ÄúHas she said things to you, to make you pull away?‚Äù

‚ÄúAllie will be as dutiful a wife as my uncle is a soldier,‚Äù Rain said. His neck was so stiff his head shook slightly as he talked.

‚ÄúHave you talked about it with her,‚Äù Mama Mathers said. She leaned over to put her face in front of Rain‚Äôs. He closed his eyes. ‚ÄúLeaving?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe both know you don‚Äôt ever leave,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúThen where have you been, Rain?‚Äù she asked.

He couldn‚Äôt voice a response.

‚ÄúAnyone who can‚Äôt answer my questions isn‚Äôt a soldier,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIf I can‚Äôt get an answer when you‚Äôre right in front of me, I won‚Äôt breed you, either. We‚Äôll take your mind and identity, or we‚Äôll take your balls.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm weak,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be your soldier, but I need to figure that out first.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve had a year.‚Äù

The words echoed Lee‚Äôs response to Love Lost.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to kill the people who triggered alongside me. Hopefully, I can take their power.‚Äù

Her hand brushed his cheek.

‚ÄúYou have a time limit,‚Äù she said.

He nodded, stiff.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll be watching,‚Äù she said.

He nodded again.

There was only silence after that.

‚ÄúMay I go, mama?‚Äù he asked.

‚ÄúRain,‚Äù the voice came from the bed, even more ethereal and thin than it had been. He felt chills, hearing the voice. He felt the words worm into his head.

The bedsprings creaked as she stood, holding the pole to steady herself. He looked away. She only now stood from the bed.

‚ÄúRain,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúLook at me.‚Äù

He resisted.
