‚ÄúI will have you killed if you do not,‚Äù she said.

He looked.

He‚Äôd only seen her leg and foot, and she‚Äôd jumped into his head, tactile, audible, present, impossible to ignore.

Now, seeing her in full, it was more pronounced, heavier, insofar as the frail woman could be ‚Äòheavy‚Äô. Her hair was long, bleached silver, and frayed. Her face was thin enough that it appeared older.

It was worse.

‚ÄúWhy would you leave, when we haven‚Äôt talked?‚Äù she asked. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been standing there, talking to yourself.‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry, mama,‚Äù he said.

He knew how she worked, but he couldn‚Äôt ignore the apparition in situations like this, because ignoring her and having her turn out to be real was the sort of thing that got him killed.

‚ÄúEverything I said to you before now, it came from within you. I saw and heard much of it,‚Äù she said.

He hated seeing her, hated hearing her. He hated knowing it was for real.

‚ÄúYou should know these things to be absolute truth, divine and malign both,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThe fears, the promise you made.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, mama,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúEvery time you think of me or mention me, I will be there. I will know where you are and see what you are doing. I will take stock and I will make my judgments. You will think of me, while saying your prayers on waking and on retiring, kneeling by your bed. Before each meal.‚Äù

He nodded, stiff.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been years,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúYou only think about me a few times a day. I thought it was time we were reacquainted. You have your mission.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll kill my cluster.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd be a loyal soldier. Think of me,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt, you know what will happen.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes mama,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúAllie. Your aunt and uncle. Erin, her family. And you won‚Äôt see me. You‚Äôll see other things.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes mama,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúGive me a kiss, now.‚Äù

She didn‚Äôt bend down, so he had to raise himself up to give her a peck on the cheek. He hated the contact, he hated how large she loomed in his vision, how that would give her more of a foothold.

He hated everything.

‚ÄúGo, now, it‚Äôs late.‚Äù

He escaped the room, doorknob squeaking. In the process, he nearly collided with Elijah. It was only his own doing that stopped him.

Elijah held a bowl of water with a sponge floating in it in the crook of one arm. He had a slight smile on his face, barely visible through the long white-dyed hair he had. it was long enough to drape around his collarbone.

Behind that hair, his eyes were a milky cataract white. Not just for show. Seeing his cane was the only reason Rain hadn‚Äôt walked into him and spilled the water.

‚ÄúElijah. Escort Rain to the door, please. He seems unsteady on his feet.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, mama,‚Äù Elijah said. He fumbled, and found a place to set the bowl down on a dresser.

Rain didn‚Äôt want the escort, but he didn‚Äôt want to refuse. Mama Mathers—

Rain flinched as she appeared, standing further down the hallway.

The figure made a small sound of amusement.

Elijah fumbled for his arm, then seized it tight.

The blind leading the sighted. Rain went, reaching out for the railing as soon as it was in reach, so he could have something to hold onto, and so he could keep Elijah from falling if it came down to it.

‚ÄúOnly the guilty are as upset as you seem to be,‚Äù Elijah said, his voice smooth, silky, and dangerous.

Rain didn‚Äôt reply, focusing instead on the stairs, trying not to think—

Mama Mathers appeared at the bottom of the flight.

He‚Äôd gotten so good at controlling his thinking, and it was all for nothing, now. Even thinking about not thinking about her was now enough. It might be for weeks or months.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard, I know,‚Äù Elijah said. ‚ÄúI had a hard time with it for the first few years.‚Äù

They made it far enough down the stairs for Rain to see that the living room was empty, now, but for the meek women who acted as servants in the white cabin, cleaning up bottles and glasses,.

‚ÄúI fixed it myself, after getting powers,‚Äù Elijah said. ‚ÄúLooked myself in the eye, mirror right in front of me, and I told myself to enjoy it. To like it, my own mother a mere thought away. To be loyal.‚Äù

When Rain heard the word ‚Äòmother‚Äô, Mama Mathers appeared in the living room. They were fleeting images, each lasting for seconds, five or ten at a time. Her head would turn, and she would look around herself, or she would stare at him.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù Rain said. He wasn‚Äôt sure why he‚Äôd said it. Dangerous words. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry you had to go that far to find loyalty.‚Äù

Not better words, but he wasn‚Äôt thinking straight.

Elijah‚Äôs fingers dug into Rain‚Äôs arm.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt see anymore, Rain. My eyes have no power.‚Äù

Rain nodded. They were at the door now. Elijah didn‚Äôt let him go.

‚ÄúBut what I say? My words have more power than before. All I have to do is tell you to, and you‚Äôd want it. I could tell you to be gleeful to have the worst punishment we can offer, and you would be, because it would be in service of the Fallen and Mama.‚Äù

Again, the image, standing outside, wearing her nightgown, hair blowing in the wind.

‚ÄúLike I did for Lachlan,‚Äù Elijah said.

Rain nodded. ‚ÄúI know. But I don‚Äôt need that. I don‚Äôt want it.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhether you want it or not has nothing to do with it, Rain, and never did. Don‚Äôt disappoint mama.‚Äù

He let go of Rain‚Äôs arm. Rain stumbled on his way down the stairs.

‚ÄúBe careful walking home,‚Äù Elijah said, his tone light. ‚ÄúIt must be dark out.‚Äù

Rain pushed past the gate, passed Nell and Jay, who were still standing guard.

They started to approach him, and for the briefest moment, as he felt panic flare, his power appeared at his hands. They stopped, and Rain stumbled back more steps.

‚ÄúSorry, Rain Man,‚Äù Jay said. ‚ÄúI know it sucks.‚Äù

Nell sounded less sympathetic. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt do anything reckless now. Never goes well.‚Äù

Rain shook his head, turned and jogged away, down the dark dirt road, with scarce lighting.

When he couldn‚Äôt see anyone or anything around, he leaned over the ditch and emptied his stomach‚Äôs contents. It tasted like all of the preservatives in the candies he‚Äôd taken, so he could stay awake and keep Erin company. That reminded him of Seir, of Tim, and that only made his stomach churn more.

Mama Mathers crossed his mind and was standing on the road above, watching him, as he straightened.

He staggered past her.

He couldn‚Äôt go home. Too far away.

His workshop. It wasn‚Äôt far. Dark, it required fumbling. He let himself in, made his way up the stairs, and collapsed to the floor as soon as he had it shut behind him.

The fact that the light was on was slow to register.

‚ÄúRain,‚Äù Erin said.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt,‚Äù he said. He didn‚Äôt want her to see him like this.

She knelt beside him. He shook his head.

She wasn‚Äôt strong enough to move him, but when he realized what she was doing, he didn‚Äôt have the willpower left to resist. She pulled him closer, so his head was in her lap.

She stroked his hair and shushed him.

Mama Mathers stood above the two of them, watching, and he couldn‚Äôt bring himself to mention it.

When the cluster dream whisked his consciousness away, it was a mercy.

Shadow — 5.1

Experience told me that after waking up from a bad dream, it was better for me to move. The emotional and mental impact of being tired for the rest of the day was far lower than if I remained in bed and stewed. Either way, I rarely fell back into sleep.

It was one of the few things that had been easier at the hospital. Sleep had been regular, reliable. There hadn‚Äôt been any stretches where I‚Äôd have nightmares or insomnia for three nights in a row and the littlest things would be a grind by the third day. The drugs had been part of my diet, to ensure I fell asleep and woke up at certain times. They didn‚Äôt do much about the nightmares, but even waking up hadn‚Äôt ended the nightmare back then.

I was perpetually tempted to get something to help, but the degree to which I was tempted was a warning bell in the back of my mind.

Sleep, eating, having a space to retreat to, physical affection, attention, socializing, breathing. It was always the basic, animal things that came apart in the wake of stress and crisis. Things broke down, got twisted, or they were reminders.

I woke up and I pulled on a pair of jeans. Red-dyed raw denim, washed with something dark that made the creases and seams very apparent. They were a little looser fitting than my going-out jeans, and I‚Äôd settled into wearing them when I was at home and my dad was around, or now, when Crystal was around. It felt less like I was a slob if I was wearing them at home, especially if anyone dropped in.

Dean had tried on red jeans once, while I was shopping with him. His uncharacteristically self-conscious reaction had had me in stitches. If I hadn‚Äôt been able to fly, I would have been on the floor laughing. It was a good memory and a large part of why the jeans were a security-blanket level thing for me.

The memory had a nice second part, when Dean had mentioned that even the brief wearing of the jeans had turned his legs and underwear red. His best friends and I had been there as he‚Äôd recounted how concerned he‚Äôd been before realizing, and how the redness on his underwear had been worse where it pressed against the jeans, especially at the front. He‚Äôd described it as a clown-nose smudge on the front and his friends had been nearly falling out of their seats.

Even now, it put a smile on my face.

There were other memories too. Some from the same trip, others from other dates. He‚Äôd tried on a lot of jeans and to this day I could remember a pair where he had looked perfect: in profile, in the narrow waist and hips, the broad shoulders, the pert butt. He‚Äôd lifted up his shirt so I could see the fit, and I‚Äôd seen the thin trail of body hair leading up to his navel, his flat stomach, and the bones of his hips just above the jeans. Already warmed up by my laughing fit earlier, I‚Äôd worked myself up into a tizzy, the best words for it, and I‚Äôd maintained the tizzyness until twenty minutes later when we were cutting through the parking lot to the bus stop. I‚Äôd pulled him aside for a make out session.

I missed him so much it hurt, but the memories were happy ones and they were a good buffer against the bad night‚Äôs sleep. I kept my t-shirt and underwear on from yesterday and I went without a bra, pulling on a white sweater with too-long sleeves and a wide collar that left my shoulders bare.

The fit was snuggly and enveloping, as if the sweater itself was giving me a hug; kind of what I was shooting for when a not-insignificant part of me felt like I was five years old again, scared and wanting to crawl into bed with my mom and dad.

Set on putting the nightmare and the associated feelings behind me, I got some socks, underwear, sports bra, and a camisole top, stowing them in my bag where I already had my wallet. I pulled on some sneakers, sans socks, and headed to the balcony door. I eyed the clock in the kitchen as I passed it. Fifteen minutes to five.

I flew toward Cedar Point.

‚äô

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not wrong,‚Äù Jessica Yamada said.

I stared out over the water. There was something sinister at play with the team.

Crystal was out at the water‚Äôs edge now, leaning over the railing. Forcefields made a kind of table or tray for her to set her food down on. It drew the attention of bystanders, in a ‚Äòlook at that, how cool‚Äô way.

‚ÄúDouble agent? Someone under the influence of another?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúTelling you would be telling you who,‚Äù Jessica said. ‚ÄúWhich, unfortunately, would be betraying confidence.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan I think aloud?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can.‚Äù

‚ÄúI got on this track of thought because I have an ominous feeling. I liken it to, uh, to my sister.‚Äù

‚ÄúKeep in mind that hindsight might distort the picture with your sister. It‚Äôs easy to look back and think things were better or worse than they were.‚Äù

‚ÄúI— yes,‚Äù I said, conceding the point. ‚ÄúYes, but I can take key moments in isolation, scenes I remember with vivid detail, conversations down to the word, and I can use those as waypoints. I can recall what led up to what and what happened after, because I‚Äôve replayed it all in my head a thousand times, and I can compare that to this.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt lose sight of how replaying events in your head to such excruciating detail might distort the picture, as will gathering all of those like memories together.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll try not to,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThinking aloud‚Ä¶ you think something‚Äôs up. You‚Äôre equipped with all of the facts, you know people‚Äôs stories, most of the secrets. Sveta said something about how she‚Äôs kind of unique in how she knows the most about most people, if I‚Äôm included in things.‚Äù

‚ÄúI imagine she does.‚Äù

‚ÄúI had no background going in, but I called you to talk because I had worries, and I‚Äôm realizing the general shape of your worries and why you brought me in. We‚Äôre at the same conclusion, but we got here by different roads. Something‚Äôs wrong or it‚Äôs going to go wrong.‚Äù

Jessica ate while I talked.

‚ÄúYou would be allowed to break confidentiality if there was a real and imminent risk of danger, or if there was a danger to a vulnerable group. And in the event of child abuse?‚Äù

‚ÄúI would if I knew there was a danger to any involved,‚Äù Jessica said. ‚ÄúI would also have to disclose if required by law — a muddy thing these days, with the world hanging in suspension while the laws are being written.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve run into that a bit,‚Äù I said, thinking of Natalie.

‚ÄúAnd if I had to disclose to obtain payment or ensure proper care, as I would if I was giving care to someone who then had to go to the Asylum. In either of those two cases, for law or working with other mental health professionals, I would get the patient‚Äôs permission first.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo it‚Äôs not that, obviously. But you‚Äôre really worried. It‚Äôs something that you think is likely enough that you want me there to keep an eye on things.‚Äù

‚ÄúI gave some serious consideration to whether the risk, though not a certain one, was worth the cost to the patient, to my career, and to the other patients I might no longer be able to look after.‚Äù

I looked at Jessica. She took another bite of her barbecue chicken sandwich, adjusting the wrapper to catch the drips of sauce and bits of lettuce and onion.

‚ÄúWhat do you mean?‚Äù I asked.

With index finger and thumb still holding the sandwich, she held up some fingers to block her mouth while she chewed. I nodded, and waited for her to finish the mouthful.

She swallowed, paused, and then said, ‚ÄúI mean that if I were to report, there is a chance my reasons for reporting might be seen as insufficient, unproven, or unclear.‚Äù

‚ÄúJust a suspicion. A strong one. Not enough reason to bring authorities into it or take action against the person or people you‚Äôre worried about.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúWhat would happen?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to say. The future of the law is unclear. But I can say I would be tied up in proceedings as they judge whether I had merit, which could take months or even more than a year. Even if nothing happened, the fact that it even had to happen in the first place might impact who I could work for. I might have to take a leave from work, and I might not be able to work with the Wardens or with critical-risk, powered juveniles.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre kidding,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThe PRT was stringent about who they would hire and take into confidence, and there‚Äôs no reason to believe the next group to take power will be any less careful. Even with that in mind‚Ä¶‚Äù

She trailed off.

‚ÄúYou thought about telling people. That doesn‚Äôt seem‚Ä¶ just. There are a lot of people that rely on you. Even with the group therapy kids, it‚Äôs pretty clear. I feel like if they didn‚Äôt have you, some pretty bad stuff would happen. And they‚Äôre, what, ten percent of your caseload? Less?‚Äù

‚ÄúLess. But I can‚Äôt ignore one wrong involving my patients for the sake of ensuring I can maintain care for the rest. Thankfully, it isn‚Äôt that binary in reality. I can act clearly and decisively when there‚Äôs a clear and decisive danger. I can ask multiple someones that I know and respect to keep an eye out.‚Äù

‚ÄúMe being one?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, Victoria. You‚Äôre one of several. Some are waiting until the group is more visible, people in the Wardens will reach out and coordinate, they know where your group originated and that I‚Äôm concerned about where it may go.‚Äù

‚ÄúI may not be the best choice— I know you didn‚Äôt choose me, exactly. You wanted me to try and steer the group away from the hero thing. I volunteered myself for this and you were‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúRelieved to have one set of eyes on things, on a more ongoing basis.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúIf you need to back away from this, you can,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúTell me and I‚Äôll help. Others will help to keep an eye on things, if at more of a distance. I involved you initially and I was glad when you seemed to be interested and invested in a way that played to your strengths and that you enjoyed. I was, again, relieved to have more eyes on things. I do not, however, want you to suffer for it.‚Äù

I looked out over the water, which was so very dark and expansive. The city didn‚Äôt keep many lights on at night, with the power situation being what it was. Less lights to reflect down on the water after dark, less light reaching the clouds up above, to make the sky lighter.

Ink black darkness.

‚ÄúHow have you been?‚Äù she asked.

I shrugged.

‚ÄúBack at the Asylum, after you had worked on your motor control, I had you keep a journal, with the attendant‚Äôs help.‚Äù

Dark, heavy feelings, to match what I saw over the water.

‚ÄúEach day in the calendar started with a drawn out cross, with a number written in each of the four quadrants. We tracked how you were doing in various areas.‚Äù

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt make much progress.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou moved on to the independent care facility.‚Äù

More dark, heavy feelings.

‚ÄúHow would you fill it out now? Physically, emotionally, contextually, and in the immediate picture with your personal needs.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have no earthly idea,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúIt might be worth paying attention to,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúHave you called the number I gave you? The therapist?‚Äù

I shook my head.

‚ÄúIf you sat down with a friend or a loved one and they told you they felt as you have these past few days, their worries, wants, needs, and problems, would you want them to talk to someone qualified?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI guess I would.‚Äù

She took a bite of her sandwich, diplomatically avoiding saying something.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI hear you.‚Äù

‚äô

I stopped in at the group‚Äôs headquarters, landing on the fire escape, and unlocking the door with my key.

Lights started to turn on, computer monitors appearing, Kenzie‚Äôs cube glowing at the corners, as her projected image appeared in the computer chair, fritzing.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine. Go back to sleep, Kenzie,‚Äù I said, to the room. ‚ÄúI woke up early and decided to go flying. I‚Äôm using the shower.‚Äù

There was a pause, and then the various projections, images, screens, and lights went dark, in the reverse order they had turned on.

I wondered if I‚Äôd actually woken her up, and if she‚Äôd actually heard me.

The apartment was fairly spacious, to the point it could have been a two-bedroom place if it actually had walls. As it was, the only walls encircled the corner, where a single shallow closet and the bathroom were. The bathroom, I couldn‚Äôt help but note, was ridiculously small for the size of the overall apartment. Toilet, sink, and shower stall, with barely any room to squeeze in between one thing and the thing or things beside it.

I stepped into the bathroom and disrobed, leaning out past the door to hang up my jeans outside, so the humidity of the shower wouldn‚Äôt get at them. I hung up the rest of my clothes on the inside of the door.

It was paranoia over preserving the raw denim and bringing out any dye that regular wearing hadn‚Äôt already worn away, maybe, but I‚Äôd spent a week‚Äôs pay on the jeans. If they had been free, I still would have been attached to them, because they reminded me of Dean, and because they were getting to be the most comfortable jeans I‚Äôd ever had, after rigorous wearing. I was going to be fussy.

I hadn‚Äôt gotten to be fussy with other things. A year after I had gone to the hospital, my mom had donated just about all of my clothes to charity.

There had been things I‚Äôd bought with Dean, with friends, with Aunt Sarah or Crystal. Uncle Neil had always spoiled me rotten, going to Crystal for tips on what to get me, and there had been four or five things I would have liked to have. Some had been milestone things, dresses I‚Äôd worn to school events, clothes I‚Äôd gotten to take home from photo shoots, and small accessories I‚Äôd bought as rewards to myself, like saving my first thousand and two thousand dollars, when I‚Äôd thought I might move to another city to follow Dean, if the PRT moved him.

It hadn‚Äôt been like she‚Äôd needed the room. Dad had moved out by then, I was gone, my sister was gone. It had been‚Ä¶ her ripping off her own band-aid, by giving away my treasures.

I could have turned the shower to a scalding heat to try to find a physical way to reflect what I was feeling otherwise. I could have turned it to freezing cold, to wake myself up.

I opted for the embrace of warm water in lieu of the warm hug of the sweater I‚Äôd taken off. I got into the shower and used my flight, bringing my knees to my chest and hugging my legs tight, closing my eyes.

I rotated in the air a few times over the course of what might have been twenty minutes, letting the water pour over me. I didn‚Äôt open my eyes once for the duration, and I didn‚Äôt feel like I might fall asleep.

‚äô

I finished my recounting of my observations of the team. Jessica finished eating.

Rain was in a bad spot, and he‚Äôd revealed himself to be Fallen. Kenzie and Houndstooth. Ashley and her outbursts. Chris and his lopsided dips into one emotion. Sveta‚Äôs worries. Tristan and Moonsong.

‚ÄúNo team name, a lot of missing cape names. I know you don‚Äôt like the cape name thing—‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that I don‚Äôt like it,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúI think it can make sense to take a hero name as an adult, but for someone younger, it can be one part of a greater issue. It‚Äôs hard enough for a teenager to decide who they are without the icon, the mask, and the name taking so much focus.‚Äù

I wanted to argue the point so badly, and I was too tired to do it. A passionate debate about powers, identities and costumes with Jessica, outside of the bounds of a therapy session? It would have been great.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs going to be a war,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúRain is going to be swept up in it, if he hasn‚Äôt already. They‚Äôre hoping to kill him in the chaos. The others might be swept up in it.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll try to keep that from happening.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf it happens, we can try to make sure it happens in the safest, most controlled way possible,‚Äù I said. I saw the look on her face, and hurried to add, ‚ÄúI know you want to keep it from happening, but they want to protect each other, and they do want to stretch their wings and flex their powers. It‚Äôs part of being a cape.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt is,‚Äù Jessica said. ‚ÄúWhat about you?‚Äù

‚ÄúMe?‚Äù

‚ÄúWill you be swept up in it? Do you want to stretch your wings and flex your powers?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to flex my powers,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI do want to be involved. I‚Ä¶ see this as a snowball rolling downhill. It‚Äôs chaotic and it has the potential to do a lot of damage, some of it inevitable. But for all their flaws, I think they are holding onto what you wanted to impart on them, for the most part they need‚Ä¶ nudges.‚Äù

‚ÄúNudges?‚Äù

‚ÄúTo change the course of the snowball. Reassuring Sveta. Redirecting Ashley or giving her an excuse to do what she wants to do anyway. Keeping Kenzie from overcommitting herself. Tristan gets into things and needs a bit of a shake, and he‚Äôll step back from the headlong charge. Rain— more complicated, because it‚Äôs not him, exactly. Self doubt, but it‚Äôs external factors pushing in on him that we need to worry about.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd Chris?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt even know. I plan to keep a close eye on him, because I haven‚Äôt figured him out and he doesn‚Äôt seem like he wants to share any of himself, which makes me worry. I‚Äôll see if I can figure out what to do.‚Äù

‚ÄúNudges and keeping an eye on things,‚Äù Mrs. Yamada said. ‚ÄúI think you‚Äôre on the right track. Step back if this is wearing on you.‚Äù

I shook my head. ‚ÄúEverything wears on me. Eating and sleeping wear on me. Stepping back wouldn‚Äôt do me any good. I‚Äôll call your colleague. Do what I can.‚Äù

‚ÄúSelf care,‚Äù Jessica said. ‚ÄúYes. Be kind to yourself, reach out for help if you need it. You have friends. Don‚Äôt lose sight of that.‚Äù

I looked over in Crystal‚Äôs direction. She waved the foil-wrapped sandwich in the air, as if baiting me. I found myself tempted, when I hadn‚Äôt even been hungry before. ‚ÄúYeah. I just realized how ravenous I am. I feel like there are a hundred more things I should tell you that you need to know, but‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúNot enough minutes in the day, even if and when I get more with a helpful someone‚Äôs power. I know. Go eat.‚Äù

I stepped back from the railing. ‚ÄúSorry, I skipped breakfast and I tossed my lunch.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd have stern words for you, but I barely ate today either. Take care of yourself, Victoria.‚Äù

She hugged me.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll talk again soon,‚Äù she said, without breaking the hug.

I nodded.

I hadn‚Äôt worked out what I was doing in regard to Rain. A part of me had hoped for guidance. In the end, it had been better to give Mrs. Yamada the lay of the land. If she was suspicious, then my mention of outbursts, of backsliding, of stubbornness, confrontations or secrecy might have been the cue she needed to make a decision.

If she was okay with where things stood, then so was I. I would nudge, I would keep an eye out, and I would look after myself. I felt more peace than I had, having had the conversation.

‚ÄúBye,‚Äù I said, my voice not all there because I was a little choked up. I couldn‚Äôt wholly pin down why.

I broke the hug and went straight to my steaming barbecue chicken sandwich. Crystal too.

‚äô

Shower off. Tangled mane transformed to wet combed locks, wet locks transformed to damp braid. Clothes on: sports bra on under sweater, sleeves rolled up around the wrists, red raw jeans, socks and sneakers. The clothes I‚Äôd hung up on the bathroom door had been effectively steamed while I was in the shower, and my hands smoothed out the wrinkles that had accumulated from my clothes being in my bag.

Self care, to have a shower with no disturbances or worries about bothering Crystal. To dress in things that felt right.

The computers illuminated as I walked through the main room.

‚ÄúGo to sleep,‚Äù I said. The computers went dark.

I had to fish through three coarse paper bags of groceries that we‚Äôd stowed under one of the tables to find the food supplies. A small bag of lime and chili chips, a protein bar, some preservatives with pepperoni stick added in, more stick-shaped preservative packs with cheese in the mix, dried fruit, two bottles of vitamin water, and a large thermos of regular tap water

Breakfast.

Laptop. I flipped it open and turned it on. The agenda for the day was laid out in glowing words against a dark background. More groups would walk through.

I had messages from the night prior. Fume Hood. Another friend and support. Hero teams planning to patrol in Cedar Point. Other, related things. There was a vein of positivity running through it all. The hero teams reaching out, expressing interest, wondering about the response they‚Äôd gotten, or expressing curiosity about villains who‚Äôd showed their faces but hadn‚Äôt been involved. Who was that guy? What‚Äôs her history?

It was easy to be standoffish, to draw lines in the sand when it came to jurisdictions, to make territorial noises and see the other teams as competition.

This was a balancing act, but there were benefits. The heroes we were connecting with knew some of our names, faces, and voices.

The clock told me it was a quarter after six in the morning as I left the headquarters.

My feet left the fire escape and touched down in Cedar Point a few minutes later. The shifting temperature and the proximity of the water cast Cedar Point in a heavy mist. There weren‚Äôt many lights on, but the ones that were on made the surrounding mist glow.

Not many people awake.

I walked along the rooftops, flying up to the points higher than I could get with a skip or a jump. Briefly, I turned on my forcefield.

Briefly, I saw the mist stir, as facial features and hands moved through it. If I hadn‚Äôt known what I was looking at, I wouldn‚Äôt have been able to make much sense of the swirl here, the vaguely oval void there.

It wasn‚Äôt a good feeling, to verify that, but I‚Äôd treated my heart gently this morning, armoring it in sentiment. I could take that much.

I sat on the edge of a random rooftop, got my laptop out, and opened it.

There wasn‚Äôt internet here, but I had files saved on my computer. Random pictures I‚Äôd saved, old PRT documents I‚Äôd scanned and saved for printing for my collection, that I hadn‚Äôt gotten around to deleting or printing, and some things I‚Äôd typed up for the Patrol block.

One leg folded under me, the other dangling off the edge of the roof, I poised the laptop on my knee and dug for what I could find on costumes and branding. I created seven folders, one for myself and one for each of the six members of the team, and began copying files over to each, where relevant.

The pepperoni sticks were stale, brittle and tough enough I had to gnaw on them to soften them enough to bite through. Tasty, though.

A small truck beeped with surprising loudness as it backed into an alley. One person got out to guide it, waving and gesturing, as the headlights of the truck illuminated him in the fog.

The truck fully backed in, he turned around. Pausing, he looked up at me on the rooftop. He raised an arm.

I packed up my laptop and hopped off the roof. I landed silently behind him. He wore a jacket with a lime green reflective vest over it, and the combination made him look much bulkier than he was.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the one who knocked Moose on his ass,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúJust‚Ä¶ hanging around with your computer?‚Äù

I shifted my bag at my shoulder.

‚ÄúI saw the glow of the screen,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúFelt like I should make a stake. It‚Äôs easy to show up during the daylight hours, but it means something else if I could be here at midnight or at six in the morning. It‚Äôs interesting that it seems like the people who keep watch haven‚Äôt responded to me yet.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù he asked. ‚ÄúHuh.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs in the truck?‚Äù

‚ÄúProduce,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a good haul. My buddy back at the depot picked up a box of melons, it was liquid. Sloshed himself in watermelon juice, shoulder to toe. Long day of work ahead of him.‚Äù

‚ÄúJust shipping it out, leaving it to the stores to complain?‚Äù

‚ÄúI guess they hope enough people won‚Äôt bother that it balances out.‚Äù

I nodded.

‚ÄúWhat do you think?‚Äù he asked. He extended an arm.

I drew in a deep breath.

‚ÄúAbout Cedar Point,‚Äù he clarified.

‚ÄúI think this place is going to get wrapped up in a war,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù he asked. ‚ÄúBecause of the heroes coming through?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause it‚Äôs building up to something, whatever the people in charge seem to want,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThe war is going to start here or it‚Äôs going to come here.‚Äù

‚ÄúShould my buddy and I get out?‚Äù he asked.

‚ÄúYou might want to,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWe pay a fee to do business here, our manager covers that, but we have to face down the people in costume who collect the fee and give us a hard time, too. Boss can‚Äôt handle that. Stuff off the boats and trains hasn‚Äôt been as good lately, profit margins are getting slimmer. Maybe we‚Äôll try telling the manager it‚Äôs not worth it.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs it a problem? The heroes being here?‚Äù

He had to think about it.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I responded.

‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs a necessary one,‚Äù he added.

It meant a lot to me, to hear that. I held myself to the idea that if I couldn‚Äôt trust the law, I could trust what was right. If I couldn‚Äôt trust either, I could reach out.

I couldn‚Äôt trust the law. It was in flux. Natalie was trying to predict it, but it was more question mark than full stop. As for what was right, I wasn‚Äôt sure I could trust myself, and I couldn‚Äôt trust the team. Jessica could give me some direction, tell me that I was all clear if I kept an eye out, to nudge. The other teams could validate and suggest they liked this direction. Collaboration, at least, felt right.

Reaching out, I could get some affirmation from this nameless guy in a reflective green vest.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYou said war,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúNot a battle?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think it matters more,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThere are other places. They‚Äôll follow suit. The entire city might change course, depending on what happens.‚Äù

‚ÄúHuh. I‚Äôm Jerry, by the way,‚Äù he introduced himself. He pulled off a glove to extend his hand my way.

‚ÄúVictoria.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo hero name?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo hero costume,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúYet.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan I give you a nod or a wave if I see you, while you‚Äôre hanging around, then?‚Äù

‚ÄúBetter not. When the villains are awake, they‚Äôll be keeping an eye on things. With powers.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo shit?‚Äù

‚ÄúOn everything,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI might talk to my boss, then,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSounding more like I should stay clear.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúAnd you‚Äôll be here, then? Staking a claim? Preparing for war?‚Äù

‚ÄúMaking sure that if nothing else, instead of it being fifty villains and no heroes, it‚Äôs fifty villains and one hero. It‚Äôs me being ridiculous, but I feel like that‚Äôs important.‚Äù

‚ÄúLonely,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúNah,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI think I‚Äôll have allies when it counts.‚Äù

‚äô

The entire group arrived pretty much all together. Tristan, Ashley, Sveta, Chris, and Kenzie. The westbound train arrived at twelve-thirty, and the eastbound train was just shy of ten minutes later. Delays and other passing trains changed things up, but it seemed if the group wanted to meet at the station and walk together, they could.

‚ÄúHere already,‚Äù Ashley observed.

‚ÄúYep,‚Äù I said. I held up a hand as Kenzie walked past, and she gave me a high-five.

‚ÄúCool jeans,‚Äù she said, without turning.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù I said. She went straight to her desk, kicking the cube that sat on the ground by her chair to boot it up before falling back into her chair and hitting the lever to boost herself up.

‚ÄúDid you see the emails from the other teams?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll show you in a moment. You‚Äôll like it,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúThey were talking some and they like this. Cedar Point was a thing that was bothering a lot of people, I think.‚Äù

‚ÄúCivilians too, maybe,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI dropped in early enough the villains weren‚Äôt really awake. Talked to a few. Feelings on heroic intervention range from positive to mixed. Considering that feelings on heroes are mixed in the first place‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúWe were talking, thinking I‚Äôd pay a visit,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúKeep them on their toes.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd rather wait,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúRain said his trigger group would be out of commission for a few days while repairing and healing from injuries. It‚Äôs been a few days. They were hiring people, and they probably won‚Äôt wait too long before they use those hires, or else those people might get caught up in other activities.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm primed to do something, and I think you guys would rather I do it there than in here,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got— what, two teams coming through today?‚Äù

‚ÄúTwo with a third holding back. Third one is a single cape, they want to actually do something,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúWe need to discuss that one,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre paying,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIf we give him clear directions on how to ruin a villain‚Äôs day, he‚Äôll pay us two hundred bucks. It‚Äôs a good precedent.‚Äù

‚ÄúPeople are coming through,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúIf we need it, I‚Äôll be a distraction. I‚Äôm quick, I‚Äôll be in and out.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù Tristan said. He looked at me and Ashley.

‚ÄúIt was the original plan,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúI say let him.‚Äù

I made a so-so gesture.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll debate it when the time comes. It‚Äôs anxiety?‚Äù

‚ÄúYep. Mad Anxiety.‚Äù

‚ÄúGreat,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not the screaming one, is it?‚Äù

‚ÄúMad is the screaming one,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúI wanted to make an impact and if we need me as a distraction then screaming is good.‚Äù

Tristan said something Spanish under his breath and went to his whiteboard. Swear words, if I had to guess.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll go in,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúWe said I would after a few days, and if things are happening, I want to already be recognizable around there. Will the eye camera be ready?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúOh, Victoria, I bought some energy drinks if you want them. And I have a thermos of a coffee my dad and mom really like.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat coffee?‚Äù Sveta asked. ‚ÄúWeld and I were trying to find one he might like, but it turned out he wants it super bitter, because that‚Äôs the only way he can taste it. We had a bunch of things of coffee taking up space, and I took it on myself to drink it. I even gave some away.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou should bring it in,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúSupply the team.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe it didn‚Äôt occur to me. Except I can, because I don‚Äôt think about what I have in the cupboards unless I‚Äôm standing in front of an open cupboard. I have other stuff.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow far has this food experiment with Weld gone?‚Äù I asked.

So it went, the conversation sprawling, back and forth, casual, from work to life.

I‚Äôd woken up before dawn, taken the necessary time to pull myself together, and then tentatively reached out, to make sure I wasn‚Äôt just centered in my own self, but in what I was doing. Reaching out to make sure it seemed right and, to a slightly lesser extent, that it was within the bounds of the law. Reaching out, too, to have more contacts.

I had a bad feeling. No, more than that, I had bad feelings. About the team, what lay beneath the surface, the war over Cedar Point, the Fallen, the clash between Snag‚Äôs group and the Fallen, and the danger to Rain.

But I knew why I was here. A potential disaster lurked here. Knowing that made everything easier, in an ironic way. The dissonance of not feeling right about being here had eased.

There were clear, defined, acceptable enemies to face down.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want a wig,‚Äù Ashley said, to Sveta.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm saying, if you cut your hair—‚Äù

‚ÄúIf.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen it‚Äôs an option. It could even give you a secret identity. Kenzie, the eye thing you were talking about, you can give Ashley eyes with irises, right?‚Äù

‚ÄúI could.‚Äù

‚ÄúEye color, hair color, clothes,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúWigs get pulled off or lost in a fight,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs undignified.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou do realize I‚Äôm wearing a wig.‚Äù

‚ÄúI realize you‚Äôre wearing a wig and you have the capacity to pound someone‚Äôs face in or dangle them off the side of a building. They‚Äôll learn to respect you if you make them,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúYou do realize we‚Äôre supposed to be heroes, right?‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúNominally?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot nominally,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs nominally?‚Äù Kenzie asked. ‚ÄúHow do you spell it? I‚Äôll ask the computer.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm not about to do any of those things,‚Äù Sveta said.

Ashley ignored us. ‚ÄúMe? I can kick them, or I can turn them into a bloody smear using my power. That‚Äôs pretty much it. I don‚Äôt have the manual dexterity or hand strength to use a weapon, I can‚Äôt punch them without damaging my hands. Kicks won‚Äôt do enough, using my power does too much, and the mess would be inconvenient. I don‚Äôt want a wig.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt want a wig. Fine,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúI have some images on my computer,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúHair and eye makeup, some costume related.‚Äù

‚ÄúShow me?‚Äù Ashley asked.

We walked over to where my computer was on a table. I found the folder and opened it.

Sveta leaned over me, half-hugging me from behind as I clicked through the images.

‚ÄúI was thinking of a name to do with swans,‚Äù Ashley said, as I clicked.

‚ÄúAn awful lot of the bird names are taken,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIt was a trend once. What were you considering?‚Äù

‚ÄúSwansong,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIf I go with the white costume.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can check, but I‚Äôd have to go through my paper stuff,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt that kind of a bad omen of a name?‚Äù Sveta asked ‚ÄúLike, last dance or ‚ÄòI‚Äôm going to retire today‚Äô?‚Äù

‚ÄúI like bad omens,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúI like this one,‚Äù I said, indicating an image. ‚ÄúI have a folder for you too, Sveta, just so you know.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm curious what you‚Äôre thinking.‚Äù

‚ÄúAll over the place,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúLots of stuff where I might not even remember why I saved the image in your folder.‚Äù

‚ÄúGuys,‚Äù Tristan said.

He had our attention. His phone was to his ear.

‚ÄúRain‚Äôs nearby. He wants to know if he can bring Erin.‚Äù

Just like that, the mood of the room shifted.

We exchanged looks, and there were tentative nods, some real nods, no vetoes or refusals.

Tristan gave the a-ok. He hung up.

The silence lingered for a few seconds.

‚ÄúI like Erin,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm really glad Rain‚Äôs coming back so soon.‚Äù

‚ÄúYesterday was hard on him,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúAnd‚Ä¶ Co√±o, it was his night last night.‚Äù

‚ÄúHis night?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúHis dream,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs always hard.‚Äù

‚ÄúSounds like a good dream to me,‚Äù Chris said.

Tristan picked up an eraser from by the nearest whiteboard and threw it at Chris.

‚ÄúI like this one,‚Äù Ashley said. She tapped the frame of the laptop screen.

‚ÄúElaborate,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôd have to draw it on every time you went out in costume.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt could be projected,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúIt could,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIf it‚Äôs easy to do, we could do that. I think the thing to do would be to make sure you look good if the projector breaks or loses power, and then build on that.‚Äù

‚ÄúLike the wig idea,‚Äù Sveta said.

Ashley sighed.

Rain opened the side door of the headquarters, letting Erin in first before following.

I‚Äôd gathered myself together earlier in the day. For the first time since the Patrol block job, I felt like I almost had my feet under me.

Tristan had said Rain had dealt with a hard night on top of a hard yesterday. It showed. Something hollowed out, something wounded. He looked like I‚Äôd felt after Snag had gotten his hands on me.

When he approached the table next to his whiteboards, Erin stepped back a little to let him pass. It was a subtle thing that I couldn‚Äôt help but notice, but it played into the second half of my observation of him. That he seemed more dangerous. Where I felt stronger because I‚Äôd pulled myself together some and clarified my direction with Mrs. Yamada, Rain conveyed something more in how he‚Äôd come undone.

Even yesterday, his face swollen on the one side, black eye, cuts and scabs, it had seemed that idea had held true as he‚Äôd found the strength to reveal his background.

What had he dreamed, last night, that this was what had come to the surface? Was this the strength of desperation? Something else?

Rain greeted Tristan first, almost falling forward in a ‚Äòbro‚Äô half-hug with just the one arm, the pat on the shoulder.

He gave a nod to Ashley as she was closest to him as he rounded the table. Sveta gave him a pat on the shoulder, a smile, and a few murmured words that got Rain to nod a little, his expression relaxing a little in what might have been a smile for someone else. She left us to go talk to Tristan.

Rain stopped a distance away from me. He didn‚Äôt quite face me, and instead said, ‚ÄúWe good, Kenz?‚Äù

‚ÄúYup. I‚Äôm glad you came. And you brought Erin. You want to see my toys, Erin?‚Äù

Erin walked from the side door to Kenzie, but ninety-five percent of her attention was on Rain and me. I hadn‚Äôt quite seen her like this.

I hadn‚Äôt seen Rain like this. He almost swayed where he stood, eyebrows slightly furrowed, clearly in deep thought.

I didn‚Äôt like the Fallen. They scared the shit out of me. I hated everything they represented. He‚Äôd killed people, children, and it didn‚Äôt seem right that he was standing here and that was passing without incident.

Maybe his condition, mental and physical, represented just how hard he was fighting to get free. Maybe it suggested it wasn‚Äôt passing without incident.

I put out my hand. When he went to shake it, I grabbed him by the wrist, instead.

He flinched at the unexpected gesture, looked to one side, and stared off into space momentarily. There was a part of me that recognized that too. Bad dreams.

He forced his attention back to us and our exchange, looked down at our hands. He took my wrist. A clasp, more than a shake.

‚ÄúWe good?‚Äù he asked, not making eye contact. His voice was faintly rough-edged, like he‚Äôd screamed himself hoarse. As if a small part of Snag had found root in Rain‚Äôs throat.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre good,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs get ourselves organized,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúTraining wheels are off, and we‚Äôve got a few things going on today. Ashley‚Äôs going back in, and it makes sense to insert her before things get messy. Two hero teams are swinging through sometime after that, we‚Äôve got Chris on standby and one hero who wants to pay us to get a chance to do something, which we‚Äôll want to discuss.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs Prancer to account for too,‚Äù I said, releasing Rain‚Äôs wrist, approaching, ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs had a day to think about what we‚Äôre doing and a day to get countermeasures in place. He reassured his friends that he had a handle on this. Let‚Äôs prove him wrong.‚Äù

Shadow — 5.2

‚ÄúMaybe trouble,‚Äù Kenzie said.

I was digging through my bag when she said it. I set some of my things aside and headed to the front of the room. Erin was standing beside Kenzie, while Kenzie regaled her with stuff.

Rain was thirty feet away, sitting in his computer chair in his nook. Some of the tables we‚Äôd arranged were situated so the long side was against the wall, but in the interest of giving Rain some desk space, we‚Äôd set up two so the shorter ends of the table were against the wall and the tables jutted out into the room, his whiteboards against the wall between the tables. He‚Äôd unfurled a roll of paper tablecloth, laid out his arms on it, and was using marker to draw on the tablecloth and make references.

His bag was open, and I could see the jaws of a bear trap and a bit of chain within.

He looked up, met my eyes, then looked at the screen. He remained where he was. He, Sveta and I were the ones who hung back a bit. Him because of his work, and Sveta and I because we were rummaging in our bags.

‚ÄúContinuation of a bit of family drama,‚Äù Kenzie said. She hit a few keys. The camera‚Äôs image on the screen focused in on one section and rotated.

Nailbiter and a teenaged girl were standing outside of the nail place where Ashley had been comparing her nails to the outdated example images in the window. A middle-aged woman with bleached blonde hair was holding the teenager‚Äôs wrist. The angle didn‚Äôt allow for a very good view of Nailbiter or her expression. She didn‚Äôt seem to be doing anything to step in.

The teenager had a resemblance to her mother, but was slender. Her hair reminded me of how Byron wore his, it was the same medium-long length, slicked straight back from the face, but the teenager‚Äôs was bleached where Byron‚Äôs was black. In facial features and in expression, the teenager was a younger mirror of her mom. Neither was happy with the other.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs this?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the drama?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe girl is Colt. She was working for her parents, but business was slow, they weren‚Äôt paying her, and now she‚Äôs working for Nailbiter.‚Äù

‚ÄúWorking how?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúMuscle, I guess?‚Äù Kenzie asked.

‚ÄúShe can‚Äôt weigh more than a hundred and thirty pounds,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúOkay, well, she‚Äôs hanging out with Nailbiter and she‚Äôs getting paid, I think, because she‚Äôs had new clothes lately,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been watching her?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúHow do you know all of this?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not watching her watching her. That makes it sound like I‚Äôm being creepy spying on people. Geez. It‚Äôs because they keep having shouting matches at night, and idle cameras go on alert mode at loud noises, so I end up hearing stuff.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo you‚Äôre being creepy eavesdropping on people,‚Äù Chris said.

Kenzie glanced around her desk. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd throw something at you if I could find something I‚Äôm okay breaking.‚Äù

‚ÄúFamily issue, okay, but what‚Äôs going on now?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúAnd do we need to step in?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúColt left the place to go talk to Nailbiter on the street, and they started to leave when Colt‚Äôs mom, Tammy, went after her and stopped her. Her sister, who‚Äôs about my age, she went outside with Tammy the mom and ran back inside.‚Äù

‚ÄúAudio?‚Äù Sveta asked.

Kenzie hit a key.

Chris asked, ‚ÄúWho names their kid Colt? Or is that a shitty nickname?‚Äù Chris‚Äôs second question had him inadvertently talk over the start of the audio feed. Kenzie shushed him.

‚Äú‚Ä¶cking let me go!‚Äù

‚ÄúGet inside! You‚Äôre still in trouble for stealing!‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck you! I deserved something!‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs been helping, you haven‚Äôt!‚Äù

‚ÄúThe one time she helps, you decide to pay her, and I get fuck all because it‚Äôs the one time I decided to go out instead!? Fuck that, fuck you!‚Äù

‚ÄúIs this how we‚Äôre doing this!?‚Äù the mom screamed at Nailbiter, ignoring her daughter for the moment. ‚ÄúYou want money from us while you‚Äôre scaring away the business, and now you‚Äôre taking my little girl, too!?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not fucking little!‚Äù

‚ÄúShe decides,‚Äù Nailbiter‚Äôs voice had a slight whistle around the words. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm losing patience, Colt. If I walk away from here without you, I‚Äôm not bringing you along again.‚Äù

‚ÄúI decide, not her!‚Äù the mother raised her voice. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm the mother!‚Äù

‚ÄúThen the two of you need to decide,‚Äù Nailbiter said. ‚ÄúNow.‚Äù

Colt hauled back, her arm still in the firm grip of her mother‚Äôs two hands.

I looked at the door. If I flew over now—

A sound of an impact made me look back to the screen. Colt‚Äôs mother had turned away. Colt had her free hand raised. She‚Äôd slapped her mother.

Her mother moved to retaliate, and Colt pulled back out of the way. There wasn‚Äôt much heart behind the swing, either. Not for the mom. The teenager tugged to try to free her arm, and when she couldn‚Äôt, she swung again. Not a slap this time, but a punch.

Kenzie looked away before the second punch could land. She didn‚Äôt look back for the third or fourth.

‚ÄúShitty name girl‚Äôs got grit,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs grit.‚Äù

‚ÄúColt!‚Äù the father hollered the word, on emerging from the nail salon. Colt backed away, arm free of her mother‚Äôs grip, while the father advanced.

Nailbiter stepped forward and to the side, to put herself between Colt and her father. The father stopped in his tracks. He looked at his wife, then leaned over for a closer look, touching her cheek where it already looked like it was going to be a heck of a bruise.

He and his wife stood together as they squared off against Nailbiter.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs mine, now,‚Äù Nailbiter said.

‚ÄúAre you, Colt?‚Äù the father asked. He got angrier as he talked, ‚ÄúAre you hers? You‚Äôd hit your mother, who sacrificed so much for you?‚Äù

Colt looked spooked, in that moment. Kenzie zoomed the camera in further, moving the mouse.

It was Erin who said something. ‚ÄúSay no.‚Äù

‚ÄúFine. I‚Äôm hers,‚Äù Colt said. ‚ÄúFuck this. At least she pays me.‚Äù

‚ÄúBrave sounding words, while you‚Äôre standing behind her. You‚Äôre not going to stand aside, let us handle this as a family?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Nailbiter said. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs an employee.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want trouble,‚Äù the father said. ‚ÄúWe can leave it at this.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you want,‚Äù Nailbiter said.

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù Colt said. ‚ÄúLeave it and fuck off.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt come home,‚Äù the father said, and his voice was hard, now. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt show your face in front of me, your mother, or Reese again. Be her errand girl. I‚Äôm done trying with you.‚Äù

Colt was silent.

‚ÄúPatience lost,‚Äù Nailbiter said, the dry whistle catching on the ‚Äòs‚Äô of Lost. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going.‚Äù

‚ÄúMom?‚Äù Colt asked. I heard her ask that, and I wondered if she wanted her mother to grab her, to drag her away.

‚ÄúWhat are you asking me for?‚Äù Tammy asked, one hand at the side of her face. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre going to go, then go.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù Colt asked. She spat the words, ‚ÄúFuck you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll be by next week to collect,‚Äù Nailbiter said. ‚ÄúSee you then.‚Äù

Another whistle on the ‚Äòs‚Äô of ‚Äòsee.‚Äô Nailbiter and Colt walked away. The father hugged his wife.

‚ÄúIs this kidnapping?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Tristan said.

I shook my head. ‚ÄúWe could call authorities, but I have a hard time believing we‚Äôll be able to get cops out there, and have them take action with a nearly-18 person who doesn‚Äôt want to cooperate or go back home.‚Äù

‚ÄúHaving the police show up to take her away might make her dig her heels in more,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúStupid,‚Äù Erin said. ‚ÄúSo fucking stupid. Colt and her parents both.‚Äù

Her eyes were a touch moist as she shook her head, arms crossed, and ducked past Sveta and I.

‚ÄúToo close to home?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt talk about home. Sorry. Give me a second.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Sveta said. She met my eyes.

I had worries, but they were ones I‚Äôd rather not voice aloud. Nailbiter had a history that had seen her arrested and sentenced harshly, without much delay. Post-Gold Morning, she‚Äôd settled back into her role as a violent cape, serving as what might have been Beast of Burden‚Äôs second in command.

She was calmer than she‚Äôd been reported to be in the one article I‚Äôd been able to dig out of my boxes of notes, part of an article from a magazine, listing the Birdcage‚Äôs residents at the time. The last page of the article, annoyingly, hadn‚Äôt been preserved. I‚Äôd pulled the page out for whatever article or image was on the other side.

Either way, violent, as might have been expected for an ex-con with rusty nails instead of teeth. Prison and nine years might have changed her a bit from the person described in the article, but I doubted Colt was in good hands.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt want to ignore this. I‚Äôll make some calls later. I‚Äôll see what I can find on Nailbiter. She was from North Carolina, I think, and some of their capes are still around. I‚Äôd have to track down a veteran. We‚Äôll see what we‚Äôre up against. If I get a chance, I‚Äôll have a conversation with her.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd say what?‚Äù Chris asked. ‚ÄúParents don‚Äôt want her, intense nails-for-teeth lady does.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe didn‚Äôt want to go, and I think her parents wanted her to stay,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚Äú‚ÄòI never want to see your face again‚Äô sounds like a real term of endearment,‚Äù Chris said.

‚ÄúIf she‚Äôs with Nailbiter,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll talk with her,‚Äù I said. I looked at Ashley. ‚ÄúGiven the crowd you‚Äôre likely to run into while you‚Äôre over there, there‚Äôs a chance you may see her.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe hit her mom, several times,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúHer mom was willing to hit her back. Colt learned that behavior from someone.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre assuming she picked that up from her parents? That‚Äôs a bit of a leap. We can‚Äôt know for sure,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWe can guess,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúBut we can‚Äôt know,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs‚Ä¶ far from great, that situation, Colt, her parents. Maybe think about what you might say or do if you run into her.‚Äù

Ashley shook her head slightly.

‚ÄúNo?‚Äù

‚ÄúI was thinking more about Nailbiter,‚Äù Ashley said.

‚ÄúOkay, you should already know she‚Äôs dangerous,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm more dangerous, I‚Äôm not worried. I want to go. Sooner than later.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you still want to do the eye thing?‚Äù Sveta asked.

‚ÄúIf possible. I‚Äôll take my mask off when I‚Äôm with others.‚Äù

Sveta turned to me. ‚ÄúDid you find anything usable?‚Äù

‚ÄúMascara.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have stuff, plus the white cover-up. Erin? Do you have anything?‚Äù

‚ÄúI have stuff,‚Äù Erin said. ‚ÄúWhat are you doing?‚Äù

It was a series of last-minute tasks, Sveta, Erin and I helping do up Ashley so she could present a good face. Kenzie was high-energy, switching from watching to fiddling with the yet-to-be inserted eye camera to talking to Chris about what he was doing when he went out.

‚ÄúAny word on Snag‚Äôs group?‚Äù Rain asked. Ashley was in a chair with her back to the table Rain was using for work on his hands.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve seen Snag and Love Lost around,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúLove Lost more than Snag. She was in a bad mood yesterday. She went away for a while.‚Äù

‚ÄúSnag is tinkering, and if Victoria‚Äôs description of how he operates was any clue, he can tap into his other powers through his tech,‚Äù Rain said. He slapped something metal down on the table, hard. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm struggling with something that should be simple.‚Äù

‚ÄúI want to talk to you about tinker stuff after,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúI had some small arms for you to mess with, but they got broken,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúI have the contact pads.‚Äù

‚ÄúAwesome,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúI think we can figure something out.‚Äù

Ashley was patient as we applied some white and black eyeliner, then used Sveta‚Äôs cover-up to fix the color around the eyes.

‚ÄúI wish I could do this,‚Äù Sveta said. She was handling the holding of the various brushes and objects, so we could hand one to her and take another. ‚ÄúBut my hands can‚Äôt hold the brushes and pencils, and I wouldn‚Äôt feel safe with my tendrils out so close to Ashley‚Äôs face.‚Äù

‚ÄúTendrils,‚Äù Erin said.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what Rain told you, but I‚Äôd probably accidentally rip out Ashley‚Äôs eye.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf they do a bad job, we can wash it off and you can try,‚Äù Ashley said. ‚ÄúIf you rip out my eye, then I‚Äôll have the intimidation effect I want. Of a different sort.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù Sveta said, with an unusually sarcastic tone. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre fine with losing an eye, that‚Äôs badass. But you can‚Äôt wear a wig, because if it was knocked off, that would be embarrassing.‚Äù

Ashley sighed. I nearly stabbed her in the nose with the eyeliner pencil.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt move,‚Äù I told her.

I finished with the eyeliner, and stepped back to admire the work. A white line along the lower lid, to make the eyes appear larger, and black mascara, because her eyelashes were apparently white without. Erin had handled the careful application of fine veins of black eyeliner that fanned out from the eyes in parallel with the eyelashes. They had been drawn in waves with each wave washed out with pats of the white cover-up, so the lines appeared to fade out and have dimension. At each corner of each eye, I‚Äôd drawn a hooked triangle, with the hook pointing down at the inner corners and up at the outer ones.

Erin had a bit of the softer, artistic touch for the lines and fading-out, I had the steadier hand for the line work.

The only mirror was a compact mirror, too small to show everything, so I took a picture instead. I showed Ashley.

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù she said. She smiled.

‚ÄúStay put,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúEye camera. Here we go, and I can‚Äôt touch your face because I don‚Äôt want to smudge the nice makeup.‚Äù

‚ÄúCamera first next time, then,‚Äù Ashley said.

Erin clearly had the heebie jeebies, as Kenzie held the needle within a few inches of Ashley‚Äôs eye, swinging it within half of an inch of the eye as she rotated one part to get it tighter.

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúHere we go. Same as before, but don‚Äôt flinch and keep your eye fixed on one point. Making contact on three, ready?‚Äù

‚ÄúReady.‚Äù

‚ÄúZero, one, two, thre— wait.‚Äù

Ashley stayed stock still, waiting.

‚ÄúHaha,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúI should turn it on first, or it won‚Äôt phase in. That would‚Äôve been a mess.‚Äù

‚ÄúWould‚Äôve ruined my makeup.‚Äù

‚ÄúOn three, this time. Zero, one, two, three. Can you feel it this time?‚Äù

Erin shook her arms, as if she couldn‚Äôt shake off the goosebumps, and walked away, her back to the scene.

‚ÄúI feel like it‚Äôs there, but it doesn‚Äôt feel five percent there.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd‚Ä¶‚Äù Kenzie held up another, shorter needle. ‚ÄúFor the effect. On three. Zero, one, two, three.‚Äù

Kenzie stepped back. Ashley‚Äôs pupils were gone.

‚ÄúTa da!‚Äù

‚ÄúProjection?‚Äù

‚ÄúSuper low tech,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúI put liquid eraser on the projection caps, which aren‚Äôt phased in. It‚Äôs not perfectly matched to the rest of her eyes, but it works if you aren‚Äôt looking super close.‚Äù

I took a photo and showed Ashley.

She stood from her seat, and bent over, hand on Kenzie‚Äôs shoulder, planting a kiss on the very top of Kenzie‚Äôs head.

‚ÄúYou like it?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good.‚Äù Ashley looked at Sveta, Erin, Kenzie and I, and then said, ‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù

With that, she put her mask on carefully, eyes still decorated behind the eyeholes, and walked briskly on her way.

‚ÄúI feel pretty good about how we did there,‚Äù Erin said. ‚ÄúCan you send me the picture?‚Äù

I passed a copy of the picture to her phone.

She checked she had it, then smiled. ‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot a problem.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nice to have something. I haven‚Äôt had many wins lately.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you doing okay?‚Äù I asked.

She shook her head.

‚ÄúAnything I can do?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúThis is cool, superheroes, distractions,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI was super into this cape stuff once. And this stuff helps Rain, in a roundabout way. Which might end up helping me.‚Äù

Rain was at his whiteboard, scribbling furiously in red marker. He‚Äôd written a list of ten items, and he was erasing all but the bottom three, the aggressive side-to-side motion of the eraser making the whiteboard rattle against the wall.

‚ÄúRain?‚Äù I asked.

He stopped, still facing his whiteboard. ‚ÄúI had ten ideas on things I wanted to try. I did some napkin level tinker-notes and found out tolerances are lower than I thought. Scratch eight ideas, now I have two, which is probably going to become zero when I do the next set of calculations.‚Äù

‚ÄúBeing a tinker is hard sometimes,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúKenzie,‚Äù Rain said. He brought one hand up to his forehead, back still to the room. ‚ÄúIf I could build one of the things I‚Äôve seen you make, I‚Äôd be happy.‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Kenzie said.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt do stuff. It‚Äôs not hard, it‚Äôs impossible.‚Äù

‚ÄúGo easy, Rain,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry I touched a sore spot,‚Äù Kenzie said.

Rain shook his head, turning around, hand still at his forehead. He dropped it, looked at Kenzie, then looked away. ‚ÄúI do appreciate the thought. Yes, being a tinker sucks sometimes.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe you can take a look at my tech later,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúYou can see if it inspires stuff. And you can explain the contact pads. Being a tinker might have its bad points, but we can be two tinkers working together.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd like that,‚Äù Rain said, and it sounded a touch forced. ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

Kenzie‚Äôs smile looked more forced than Rain‚Äôs.

‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you take five minutes, step outside for some sun and fresh air?‚Äù Tristan asked.

Rain looked like he might resist. He looked at the board.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve said it helps,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs how you unwind. Nature and space to think.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have,‚Äù Rain said. ‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf it‚Äôs okay, I‚Äôll have the camera above the door turned on, so we can make sure you won‚Äôt get kidnapped,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúOr someone could keep you company.‚Äù

Rain nodded. ‚ÄúAlone is good. The camera is fine.‚Äù

‚ÄúGot it.‚Äù

He paused at the door. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre great, Kenz.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry I‚Äôm shitty, that wasn‚Äôt about you. I was ready to snap at anyone, I was so frustrated at this stuff.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay.‚Äù

‚ÄúGo outside. Take a bit,‚Äù Tristan said.

Rain stepped out onto the fire escape. The door slammed behind him, more because it was a heavy door than because he‚Äôd actively slammed it.

‚ÄúHe needs help,‚Äù Erin said, quiet.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a bad situation,‚Äù I said.

She nodded.

‚ÄúThat wasn‚Äôt about you, you know,‚Äù I could hear Tristan telling Kenzie. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs stressed.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know. But it isn‚Äôt cool. There‚Äôs a big part of me that feels like it is about me.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt isn‚Äôt. Cool or about you.‚Äù

I looked around the room. Chris was at his station at the point in the apartment furthest from the screens that wasn‚Äôt inside the bathroom. He was bent over a video game.

The cameras were capturing video from high overhead. One came down at an angle, and the other was a bird‚Äôs eye view, depicting only the tops of heads. Ashley had yet to arrive. The cameras tracked automatically, based on the people they recognized and their apparent importance. One was following Nailbiter and Colt.

But there was another measure of tracking: it seemed to judge by number. The other camera was shifting to look northward. The labels popped up as people were recognized, so distant they were barely more than stick figures. The labels congealed together into a single large label above the small crowd. Twelve unrecognized individuals.

‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt have a patrol coming through, did we?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúNot for an hour,‚Äù Tristan said. He turned to look. ‚ÄúOh what? Fuck me.‚Äù

Kenzie ran past Erin, Sveta and me to get to her desk, seizing control of the cameras. She focused in on the crowd.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs going on?‚Äù Tristan asked.

The costumes were distinct enough for me to recognize them before any icon came into view. Bold contrasts of light and dark, angles, armor panels, and bright colors. Masks tended to be full-face. All of it looked like they had one very tired designer working on their costumes. Cohesion to the max.

The camera caught the icon, and it popped up in a window, blur-corrected. A figure running to the side, drawn out as a collection of triangles and irregular shapes. Their arm was out and holding an arrow-shaped shield. Others had slight variants on the same icon, to play into costume textures and other minor details.

‚ÄúAdvance Guard,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWe haven‚Äôt talked to Advance Guard,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúWe actively avoided bringing Advance Guard into this.‚Äù

I looked at Erin and touched her shoulder. ‚ÄúDo you want to go get Rain?‚Äù

She nodded.

A second screen was projected onto the wall to our left. The camera began gathering blurry portraits together, lining them up in three rows and four columns, each showing one mask. As the camera got better resolution shots, they were overlaid over other shots of the same person, the images clarifying in stages as each image was uploaded. Some details remained blurry, while others became bold and precise.

Rain entered the room. He approached the desk with arms folded, looking weary.

Everything was still clarifying as Chris exited the washroom and belatedly joined us.

Spright was one. Shortcut another.

‚ÄúThey invited themselves?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúFuck them if they did,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúThis is our jurisdiction.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe can worry about that kind of thing later,‚Äù Sveta said. ‚ÄúDo we intervene?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt could be a trap,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs right,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúPrancer‚Äôs supposed to try something.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre supposed to think he paid off Advance Guard?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúHe could have,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre money hungry, with fancy costumes and nice facilities. I‚Äôve had pretty mixed reactions dealing with them, too.‚Äù

Tristan frowned. ‚ÄúOkay. I‚Äôm bothered they‚Äôre just marching in here. Assuming it‚Äôs not a trap, what‚Äôs even their plan?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe locals might have called for help,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúAdvance Guard could have been that help.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt hasn‚Äôt been that long,‚Äù Sveta said.

‚ÄúTwelve capes. Many I don‚Äôt know or recognize. I don‚Äôt want to rule anything out.‚Äù

‚ÄúMakes sense.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre good,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúAnd there‚Äôs a lot of them.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut they‚Äôre aggressive. Their usual M.O. is to blitz a target,‚Äù I pointed out.

‚ÄúNot out of the question here,‚Äù Tristan said.

Even though they were walking in as a group. The place being a peninsula mattered. It meant there were less routes to get in. It made it easier to keep watch. There would be eyes on Advance Guard, clairvoyant or no.

‚ÄúI should go,‚Äù Chris said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll have my phone. If we need to do something, I can jump in.‚Äù

‚ÄúBe careful,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll be fine. I‚Äôll change when I‚Äôm close. Don‚Äôt record me, Kenzie.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause I have to ditch the clothes, or I‚Äôll tear them to shreds. I‚Äôll be naked. I want privacy.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay, um, I‚Äôm very fond of you, Chris, but despite the fact that everyone seems to think ‚Äòtinker camera‚Äô and immediately think of that, the perverts, that‚Äôs not how I operate. I don‚Äôt want to see you naked, so you‚Äôre good.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm noting that you haven‚Äôt said you won‚Äôt record me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI won‚Äôt record you, Chris! Relax! You‚Äôd think you already did the anxiety thing.‚Äù

‚ÄúI did, yesterday, to get home faster.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay, um— lost my train of thought.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a good thing,‚Äù Tristan said, taking some authority. ‚ÄúChris, go. Kenzie, turn the cameras away.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll go too,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúNo. Hold back,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúHold back?‚Äù

Tristan said, ‚ÄúAshley‚Äôs in there. We don‚Äôt want her arrival to coincide with yours, and you‚Äôve shown up a lot. We already came pretty close with you and her being within a day of each other. Her being connected to Chris is less bad, and he won‚Äôt even be human. Let‚Äôs keep them from making the complete connection.‚Äù

I saw his hand move. Flat, at an angle, as if telling me to stop, but not quite stop.

He was trying to communicate something with me?

Caution? Something else?

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I said.

He gave me a little nod, turning back toward the screen. ‚ÄúWe send you in if it gets ugly.‚Äù

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs hope it doesn‚Äôt,‚Äù Rain said.

‚ÄúIs Ashley in their clairvoyant‚Äôs usual range?‚Äù Tristan asked.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúShould we call her anyway?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Tristan said.

I wanted to ask why he‚Äôd signaled me, but I could hardly do that. I likely wouldn‚Äôt get an answer until this was over with.

The villains were gathering. The initial group that appeared was roughly the same size as Advance Guard‚Äôs group.

I could see Kenzie‚Äôs labels with the attached names. Love Lost was in the crowd of villains. Snag was absent.

Colt was hanging back, not far from Nailbiter.

On the wall, the Advance Guard mugshots were filling in. I looked for the familiar first and found them already named. Spright, Shortcut.

Mayday, Siren, ReSound, Gong‚Ä¶

‚ÄúMayday,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúHe was Baltimore.‚Äù

Signal Fire, Flapper, Prong‚Ä¶

‚ÄúI trained under Signal in San Diego, too,‚Äù Kenzie said, adding, ‚ÄúI‚Äôd really like to use that training someday soon.‚Äù

‚ÄúSomeday,‚Äù Tristan said.

‚ÄúYou dropped the ‚Äòsoon‚Äô,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúWe need to talk about that, after.‚Äù

This was difficult enough without you getting involved, Advance Guard, I mused.

‚ÄúEvery time I run into Advance Guard, it‚Äôs a headache,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI run into the one incorrigible asshole in the group, their timing sucks, their choice of where to show up sucks, or it‚Äôs more than one of the above.‚Äù

‚ÄúMust be how Prancer feels,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúHeroes turning up out of nowhere.‚Äù

The two groups advanced until they were in sight of each other.

One of the capes on Advance Guard‚Äôs side held up a hand. She continued approaching until she stood halfway into no-man‚Äôs-land between the two factions.

Kenzie‚Äôs computer blipped as the label connected to the individual at the front. ReSound was the spokesman, apparently. Her outfit had a lot of circles reminiscent of records or speakers, with the depthed concentric shapes and circles of color in the center of black circles. The icon on her chest was made of crescent shapes, not triangles, with the shield being a half-circle.

Prancer didn‚Äôt step forward to meet her, not immediately. Instead, he waited for a moment, surrounded by his allies. Velvet was in the crowd. Moose was absent. So were Hookline and Kitchen Sink. Some stragglers were catching up.

Ashley entered the street, and Kenzie‚Äôs camera provided the label above her head: ‚ÄòSwansong‚Äô.

‚ÄúShould be Damsel, until she takes the name officially,‚Äù I said.

Kenzie typed it out, replacing it.

Damsel was situated near the back of Prancer‚Äôs group. Some people reacted, but nobody attacked or lashed out.

She didn‚Äôt even flinch at the people around her or the unexpected situation. She walked through the left side of the crowd, until she was near Prancer‚Äôs left flank. She leaned against a wall, arms folded, and stared at him, rather than at Advance Guard.

Prancer did note her presence, and looked momentarily annoyed.

The annoyance seemed to spur him forward. He met ReSound at the middle of no man‚Äôs land. The camera zoomed in to focus on them.

‚ÄúThis is getting tiresome,‚Äù Prancer said.

‚ÄúWhat ‚Äòthis‚Äô?‚Äù ReSound asked. I‚Äôd expected her voice to sound altered, as many capes with sonic themes did, but she sounded normal. Confident.

‚ÄúThe routine. You guys show up, you‚Äôre interested in the area, but you don‚Äôt commit.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe commit,‚Äù ReSound said.

‚ÄúHm? I don‚Äôt follow.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre committing. We‚Äôre staying for long enough to finish the job. We‚Äôre here to break up the villains in Hollow Point.‚Äù

‚ÄúJob. You were hired?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe hired ourselves,‚Äù ReSound said. ‚ÄúWe break up priority targets, and we got to talking. You guys seem priority enough.‚Äù

‚ÄúBased on what?‚Äù Prancer asked. His composure had cracked, but he didn‚Äôt raise his voice so much as he allowed emotion to affect his words. ‚ÄúWe sell grass, we live here. We don‚Äôt shit that much where we eat.‚Äù

‚ÄúWho was it?‚Äù ReSound asked. ‚ÄúKitchen Sink. Hookline?‚Äù

‚ÄúThey pointed you our way?‚Äù

‚ÄúSomeone thought they were funny names, and they were joking about it—‚Äù

Tristan groaned out loud.

‚Äú—and they wouldn‚Äôt say why they were here in the first place. They aren‚Äôt alone either. Others have been through. A lot of people find you very interesting.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre very boring villains, really,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúInsignificant.‚Äù

‚ÄúHoundstooth, no,‚Äù Kenzie said. ‚ÄúUgghh. I recommended you.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was fucking Foxtrot,‚Äù Tristan said. ‚ÄúFoxtrot is the clown in Houndstooth‚Äôs group.‚Äù

ReSound was taking a moment to consider Prancer‚Äôs claim of being boring.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt believe you,‚Äù ReSound said. She offered a half chuckle and said, ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt matter. We do this, we get some points with the public, and with the current attitude about capes? Points matter.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe outnumber you.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe train. I‚Äôm sure you went to great efforts to get your people together. Did you watch us on your cameras, then make sure to bring in a few more, so you could say you outnumbered us?‚Äù

‚ÄúCameras?‚Äù Prancer asked.

On camera, ReSound pointed skyward, not that far off from pointing directly at the camera we were using to watch the scene.

Some heads turned, following the pointing finger.

In the headquarters, Kenzie shoved her keyboard out of the way and brought her forehead down to the desk.

‚ÄúNot ours,‚Äù Prancer said.

‚ÄúAgain, I‚Äôm not sure I believe you,‚Äù ReSound said.

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre going to doubt everything I say, why are we even talking?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause we always declare war, Prancer.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo. You‚Äôre up to something.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat makes you think that?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe fact this conversation feels like someone trying to keep me on the line so they can get a wiretap, doling out just enough information to keep me interested. We‚Äôre done,‚Äù Prancer said. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt pick this fight.‚Äù

Prancer was halfway back to his group when Advance Guard took action.

Spright. He dashed forward. Enhanced movement, straight for the Hollow Point group. If he was a speedster, he wasn‚Äôt much of one. Faster than a normal human could manage, but hardly a blur.

‚ÄúAvant!‚Äù ReSound called out, and the sound was magnified, loud, echoing far faster than a normal echo could or should. The camera‚Äôs sound died, dissolving into crackles. Several of the Hollow Point villains covered their ears.

Prancer was one of them. Spright ran past him, and the leader of the Hollow Point group flared. He became blurry around the edges, with the blur reaching out five feet in every direction. It subsided, but he retained the effect around his silhouette. The gold on his costume, from his mask to the deer‚Äôs head in profile at his collarbone, with antler over one shoulder, all became larger, more intense, more like glass with amber colored lava within its confines. The green of his costume became smoky.

Breaker form.

But as he adopted the form, Spright used his own breaker form. It wasn‚Äôt much different, and Spright managed to keep ahead of Prancer, running toward the thinnest ranks of the stunned villains. Toward Ashley.

She used her power, a blast to drive herself in Spright‚Äôs direction, as she aimed to intercept. She was in the midst of people, which limited her options, so she ran several paces before she was clear to use another blast.

Still in breaker form, Spright reached out. A scintillating cloud of energy exploded from his hand. He used the recoil to change course.

Of course.

From there, it was a brawl. Spright disappeared into enemy ranks with his own powers exploding out around him. With the use of powers, he ducked and dodged between, went over, and slid under people. He made it out of the back of the crowd and dashed toward the deeper part of downtown. Ashley couldn‚Äôt keep up, but Prancer could.

Love Lost staggered forward as ReSound maintained her sonic assault. One we couldn‚Äôt hear or get a sense of, because the camera audio had died.

She ripped off her mask. Then she screamed back. Advance Guard was throwing up defenses before it seemed like the scream hit them.

I couldn‚Äôt hear what it sounded like, but I could see the effect. The people who weren‚Äôt fully protected, ReSound included, were laid low.

Had it not been for shimmering forcefield-like barriers and strange crystal growths, she might have been able to hit the entirety of Advance Guard, aside from the absent Spright. As it was, she got maybe three or four.

‚ÄúThe emotion attack,‚Äù Rain said.

Resound‚Äôs body language changed completely. A moment later, she lunged for Love Lost, swinging punches, grabbing.

The black haired woman didn‚Äôt let her make contact. She stepped back out of the way, raked with claws, avoided the grab, clawed again. With the second slash, blood was spilled.

The other affected people in Advance Guard were turning on teammates. Most shouted, silent with our lack of audio, rather than attack.

My first thought was, fuck Advance Guard.

My second thought was to register the blood. Blood. This is serious now.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre coming,‚Äù Tristan said.
